Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania
About_#1: Elon Musk cofounded six companies including electric car maker Tesla, rocket producer SpaceX and tunneling startup Boring Company.
About_#2: He owns about 25% of Tesla between stock and options, but has pledged more than half his stock as collateral for loans.
About_#3: SpaceX, founded in 2002, is worth $127 billion after a funding round in May 2022; it quadrupled its value in three years.
About_#4: Boring Company, which aims to defeat traffic, raised $675 million in April 2022 at a $5.7 billion valuation.
Did You Know?: Musk, who says he's worried about population collapse, has nine children with three women including triplets and two sets of twins.
In Their Own Words: I operate on the physics approach to analysis. You boil things down to the first principles or fundamental truths in a particular area and then you reason up from there.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Princeton University
About_#1: Jeff Bezos founded e-commerce giant Amazon in 1994 out of his garage in Seattle. He stepped down as CEO to become executive chairman in July 2021.
About_#2: He now owns a bit less than 10% of the company.
About_#3: He and his wife MacKenzie divorced in 2019 after 25 years of marriage and he transferred a quarter of his then-16% Amazon stake to her.
About_#4: Bezos has donated more than $400 million worth of stock to nonprofits in 2022, though it's unclear which organizations received those shares.
Did You Know?: Growing up, Jeff Bezos worked summers on his grandfather's ranch repairing Caterpillar tractors.
In Their Own Words: I didn't think I'd regret trying and failing. And I suspected I would always be haunted by a decision to not try at all.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Ecole Polytechnique de Paris
About_#1: Bernard Arnault oversees the LVMH empire of some 70 fashion and cosmetics brands, including Louis Vuitton and Sephora.
About_#2: In January 2021, LVMH acquired American jeweler Tiffany & Co for $15.8 billion, believed to be the biggest luxury brand acquisition ever.
About_#3: LVMH spent $3.2 billion in 2019 for luxury hospitality group Belmond, which owns or manages 46 hotels, trains and river cruises.
About_#4: His father made a small fortune in construction; Arnault got his start by putting up $15 million from that business to buy Christian Dior in 1985.
Did You Know?: Arnault apparently wooed his wife, Helene Mercier, a concert pianist, by playing Chopin and other classical composers on the piano.
In Their Own Words: I see myself as an ambassador of French heritage and French culture. What we create is emblematic. It's linked to Versailles, to Marie Antoinette.

Education: Drop Out, Harvard University
About_#1: Bill Gates turned his fortune from software firm Microsoft into diversified holdings including investments in zero-carbon energy.
About_#2: In May 2021, Bill and Melinda Gates each announced on Twitter they were ending their marriage after 27 years. They still co-chair the charitable Gates Foundation.
About_#3: Gates, who cofounded Microsoft with Paul Allen (d. 2018) in 1975, transferred at least $6 billion worth of shares in public companies to Melinda as part of the divorce settlement.
About_#4: As of March 2020, when Gates stepped down from the Microsoft board, he owned about 1.3% of the software and computing company's shares.
Did You Know?: When Gates was a kid, he spent so much time reading that his parents finally forbade him from bringing books to the dinner table.
In Their Own Words: Money has no utility to me beyond a certain point. Its utility is entirely in building an organization and getting the resources out to the poorest in the world.

Education: Master of Science, Columbia University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Nebraska Lincoln
About_#1: Known as the "Oracle of Omaha," Warren Buffett is one of the most successful investors of all time.
About_#2: Buffett runs Berkshire Hathaway, which owns dozens of companies, including insurer Geico, battery maker Duracell and restaurant chain Dairy Queen.
About_#3: The son of a U.S. congressman, he first bought stock at age 11 and first filed taxes at age 13.
About_#4: He has promised to donate over 99% of his wealth. So far he has given more than $49 billion, mostly to the Gates Foundation and his kids' foundations.
Did You Know?: Buffett still lives in the same Omaha, Nebraska, home he purchased in 1958 for $31,500.
In Their Own Words: Rational people don't risk what they have and need for what they don't have and don't need.

Education: Master of Science, Stanford University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Michigan
About_#1: Larry Page stepped down as CEO of Alphabet, the parent of Google, in December 2019 but remains a board member and a controlling shareholder.
About_#2: He cofounded Google in 1998 with fellow Stanford Ph.D. student Sergey Brin.
About_#3: With Brin, Page invented Google's PageRank algorithm, which powers the search engine.
About_#4: Page was CEO until 2001, when Eric Schmidt took over, and then from 2011 until 2015, when he became CEO of Google's new parent company Alphabet.
Did You Know?: Page has avoided public appearances since Sundar Pichai became Google's CEO, including Alphabet's 2019 shareholders meeting -- much to investors' chagrin.
In Their Own Words: You never lose a dream; it just incubates as a hobby.

Education: Master of Science, Stanford University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Maryland, College Park
About_#1: Sergey Brin stepped down as president of Alphabet, parent company of Google, in December 2019 but remains a controller shareholder and a board member.
About_#2: He cofounded Google with Larry Page in 1998 after the two met at Stanford University while studying for advanced degrees in computer science.
About_#3: Google went public in 2004 and began trading as Alphabet, a newly created parent company, in 2015.
About_#4: Brin was absent from public Alphabet events for much of 2019; he spent his time on Alphabet's moonshot research lab X.
Did You Know?: The richest immigrant in America, Brin has been an outspoken critic of Trump's immigration ban.
In Their Own Words: Obviously everyone wants to be successful, but I want to be looked back on as being very innovative, very trusted and ethical and ultimately making a big difference in the world.

Education: Drop Out, University of Chicago; Drop Out, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign
About_#1: Larry Ellison is chairman, chief technology officer and cofounder of software giant Oracle, of which he owns about 35%.
About_#2: He gave up the Oracle CEO role in 2014 after 37 years at the helm.
About_#3: Oracle has grown in part through steady acquisitions of software companies, the biggest of which was $28.3 billion for electronic health records company Cerner in 2021
About_#4: In 2020, Ellison moved permanently to the Hawaiian island Lanai, which he bought nearly all of in 2012 for $300 million.
Did You Know?: Ellison never finished college. He started out building databases for the CIA.
In Their Own Words: When people start telling you that you're crazy, you just might be on to the most important innovation in your life.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University; Drop Out, Stanford University
About_#1: Steve Ballmer is the high-wattage former CEO of Microsoft, who led the company from 2000 to 2014.
About_#2: He joined Microsoft in 1980 as employee No. 30 after dropping out of Stanford's MBA program.
About_#3: Ballmer oversaw Microsoft after the first dot-com crash and through efforts to catch up to Google in search capabilities and Apple in mobile phones.
About_#4: The same year he retired from Microsoft he bought the NBA's Los Angeles Clippers for $2 billion.
Did You Know?: Ballmer and Microsoft cofounder Bill Gates were classmates at Harvard.
In Their Own Words: Computer science is the operating system for all innovation.

Education: Drop Out, Stanford University; Bachelor of Science in Engineering, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Mukesh Ambani chairs and runs $104 billion (revenue) Reliance Industries, which has interests in petrochemicals, oil and gas, telecom and retail.
About_#2: Reliance was founded by his late father Dhirubhai Ambani, a yarn trader, in 1966 as a small textile manufacturer.After his father's death in 2002, Ambani and his younger sibling Anil divvied up the family empire.
About_#3: Reliance sparked a telecom price war with the launch of 4G phone and broadband service Jio in 2016. Today, it has more than 420 million subscribers and is readying to launch 5G services.
About_#4: Ambani is pivoting Reliance into green energy. The company will be investing $80 billion over the next 10-15 years on renewable energy and building a new complex next to its refinery.
Did You Know?: During the Covid-19 lockdown, Ambani raised more than $20 billion selling a third of Jio to a string of investors, such as Facebook and Google.
In Their Own Words: Anything and everything that can go digital is going digital. India cannot afford to be left behind.

About_#1: Gautam Adani is chairman of the $21 billion (revenue) Adani Group with interests in ports, airports, power generation and transmission, green energy, edible oils, cement and real estate, among others.
About_#2: Adani controls Mundra Port, India's largest, in his home state of Gujarat.
About_#3: Adani acquired a 74% stake in Mumbai International Airport, India's second-busiest, in September 2020. He's now the country's biggest airport operator.
About_#4: In 2022, Adani acquired Swiss firm Holcim's Indian assets for $10.5 billion to become India's second-largest cement producer.
Did You Know?: Adani owns Abbot Point, a controversial coal mining project in Australia, whose Carmichael coal mine is billed as one of the world's largest.
In Their Own Words: Being an entrepreneur is my dream job as it tests ones tenacity. I could never take orders from anyone.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Johns Hopkins University
About_#1: Michael Bloomberg cofounded financial information and media company Bloomberg LP in 1981.
About_#2: He put in the seed funding for the company and now owns 88% of the business, which has estimated revenues north of $12 billion.
About_#3: Bloomberg got his start on Wall Street in 1966 with an entry level job at investment bank Salomon Brothers. He was fired 15 years later.
About_#4: A major philanthropist, he has donated more than $12.7 billion to gun control, climate change and other causes.
Did You Know?: In November 2018, Bloomberg pledged $1.8 billion to Johns Hopkins University, his undergraduate alma mater, adding to $1.5 billion he had already given the school.
In Their Own Words: Organizations resist innovation and those that do inevitably fail because people are more comfortable with what they know than with what they don't.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico
About_#1: Mexico's richest man, Carlos Slim Helu and his family control América Móvil, Latin America's biggest mobile telecom firm.
About_#2: With foreign telecom partners, Slim bought a stake in Telmex, Mexico's only phone company, in 1990. Telmex is now part of América Móvil.
About_#3: He also owns stakes in Mexican construction, consumer goods, mining and real estate companies and 17% of The New York Times.
About_#4: His son-in-law Fernando Romero designed the Soumaya Museum in Mexico City, home to Slim's extensive, eclectic art collection.
Did You Know?: Every Sunday his father would give Carlos a 5-peso allowance, requiring him to record his purchases in a ledger.
In Their Own Words: When you live for others' opinions, you are dead. I don't want to live thinking about how I'll be remembered.

About_#1: Francoise Bettencourt Meyers, the granddaughter of the founder of L'Oreal, is the richest woman in the world.
About_#2: Bettencourt Meyers and her family own around 33% of L'Oreal stock.
About_#3: She has served on L'Oreal's board since 1997 and is chairwoman of the family holding company.
About_#4: She became France's reigning L'Oreal heiress in 2017 when her mother Liliane Bettencourt, then the world's richest woman, died at age 94.
Did You Know?: Bettencourt Meyers' inheritance was the subject of a sensational trial in France, in which a man was convicted of manipulating her ailing mother for her fortune.

Education: Drop Out, Harvard University
About_#1: Zuckerberg started Facebook at Harvard in 2004 at the age of 19 for students to match names with photos of classmates.
About_#2: He took Facebook public in May 2012; he now owns about 13% of the company's stock.
About_#3: Facebook changed its name to Meta in November 2021 to shift the company's focus to the metaverse.
About_#4: In June 2021, a judge dismissed antitrust cases brought by states and the federal government, which could have forced Facebook to sell off Instagram and WhatsApp.
Did You Know?: Zuckerberg and his wife, Priscilla Chan, are spending $3 billion in an attempt to end, cure or manage all disease by the year 2100.
In Their Own Words: We may not have the power to create the world we want immediately, but we can all start working on the long term today.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Arkansas
About_#1: Jim Walton is the youngest son of Walmart founder Sam Walton.
About_#2: He is chairman of the family's Arvest Bank, which today boasts assets of more than $20 billion.
About_#3: Jim sat on Walmart's board for more than a decade before yielding the seat to his son, Steuart, in June 2016.
About_#4: Collectively, he and other heirs of Sam Walton own about half of Walmart's stock.
Did You Know?: Jim Walton donated $1.2 billion in stock to the family foundation in June 2019.

About_#1: Zhong Shanshan is founder and chairman of Nongfu Spring, a bottled water company that listed its shares in Hong Kong in September 2020.
About_#2: Hangzhou-born Zhong dropped out of elementary school during China's chaotic Cultural Revolution.
About_#3: He later had jobs as a construction worker, a newspaper reporter and a beverage sales agent before starting his own business.
About_#4: Zhong also controls Beijing Wantai Biological Pharmacy, which makes rapid diagnostic tests for infectious diseases including Covid-19.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Trinity University
About_#1: Alice Walton is the only daughter of Walmart founder Sam Walton.
About_#2: She has focused on curating art, rather than working for Walmart like her siblings, Rob and Jim.
About_#3: In 2011, she opened the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in her hometown of Bentonville, Arkansas.
About_#4: Crystal Bridges features works from the likes of Andy Warhol, Norman Rockwell and Mark Rothko.
Did You Know?: After graduating from Trinity College in 1971, Walton briefly worked for Walmart as a buyer of children's clothes.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, Columbia University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Arkansas
About_#1: Rob Walton is the eldest son of Walmart founder Sam Walton.
About_#2: Walton took over as chairman upon his father's death in 1992.
About_#3: He retired as chairman in June 2015 and was replaced by his son-in-law, Greg Penner. Penner still sits on Walmart's board.
About_#4: He and other heirs of Sam Walton collectively own about half of Walmart's stock.
Did You Know?: Rob Walton, who has a law degree from Columbia University, helped Walmart prepare for its IPO in 1970.

About_#1: Changpeng Zhao, who goes by CZ, is the founder and CEO of Binance, the largest cryptocurrency exchange in the world.
About_#2: The Chinese-Canadian coder cut his teeth building high-frequency trading systems for Wall Street's flash boys.
About_#3: In 2021, Binance facilitated trades worth over $9.5 trillion, over two-thirds of all trading volume handled by centralized crypto exchanges.
About_#4: In February 2022, Binance announced that it plans to spend $200 million to buy a minority stake in Forbes via a SPAC transaction.
Did You Know?: Zhao was born in Jiangsu, China. His father, a professor, was labeled a pro-bourgeois intellect and temporarily exiled shortly after CZ was born.
In Their Own Words: We need to respect the market, with a level of caution too. It goes up and down in cycles. And especially the fact that it doesn?t always make sense.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Master of Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
About_#1: Charles Koch has been chairman and CEO of Koch Industries, America's second largest private company by revenue, since 1967.
About_#2: The diversified company has some $125 billion in revenues from businesses including pipelines, chemicals, software, automotive components and Dixie cups.
About_#3: His father, Fred Koch, improved a method of refining heavy oil into gasoline in 1927 and started the family business in 1940.
About_#4: The Kansas native owns a 42% stake in the firm, as did his brother David, who died in August 2019.
Did You Know?: Three Koch brothers (Charles, David and Bill) went to MIT; the trio were in the Beta Theta Pi fraternity and David and Charles played on the same club rugby team.
In Their Own Words: At Koch, we believe our emphasis on applying the principles of human progress is foundational to our long-term success. We've seen incredible results when we empower our employees to more fully become all they are capable of being.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Central Arkansas
About_#1: Julia Koch and her three children inherited a 42% stake in Koch Industries from her husband, David, who died in August 2019 at age 79.
About_#2: An Iowa native, Koch moved to New York City in the 1980s and worked as an assistant to fashion designer Adolfo.
About_#3: She worked with many of his high-profile clients, including First Lady Nancy Reagan.
About_#4: Julia met David via a blind date in 1991; they ran into each other again six months later, began dating and got married in 1996.

About_#1: Amancio Ortega of Spain is one of the wealthiest clothing retailers in the world.
About_#2: A pioneer in fast fashion, he cofounded Inditex, known for its Zara fashion chain, with his ex-wife Rosalia Mera (d. 2013) in 1975.
About_#3: He owns about 60% of Madrid-listed Inditex, which has 8 brands, including Massimo Dutti and Pull & Bear, and 7,500 stores around the world.
About_#4: Ortega typically earns more than $400 million in dividends a year. In November 2021, Inditex announced that his daughter Marta Ortega Pérez will become chairperson in April 2022.
Did You Know?: Ortega first began his career manufacturing textiles through a small family company in 1963.
In Their Own Words: In the street, I only want to be recognized by my family, my friends and people I work with.

Education: Drop Out, The University of Texas at Austin
About_#1: Michael Dell is the chairman and CEO of Dell Technologies, which was formed in 2016 when Dell merged with computer storage giant EMC.
About_#2: The estimated $60 billion Dell-EMC merger, which was finalized in 2016, was the largest technology acquisition ever.
About_#3: In late 2018 Dell Technologies returned to public markets through a complicated financial restructuring.
About_#4: Much of Dell's fortune lies in his private investment firm MSD Capital, which has stakes in hotels and invests in liquid corporate credit.
Did You Know?: Dell got his start at 19 selling computers out of his University of Texas dorm room, grossing $80,000 by the end of his freshman year.
In Their Own Words: I'm guilty of doing too much, and I'm guilty of not seeing mistakes coming. What I'm not guilty of is making the same mistake twice.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Nankai University
About_#1: Zhang Yiming is founder of Chinese tech giant ByteDance, best known for its insanely popular app TikTok, which has more than 1 billion users worldwide.
About_#2: Zhang resigned as CEO of Bytedance in May 2021 and as chairman in November 2021, reportedly under pressure from the Chinese government.
About_#3: ByteDance, which bought one of China's biggest private hospital chains in August, has interests in everything from news and education to video gaming.
About_#4: The privately held company, which raised money at a $180 billion valuation in 2020, reportedly agreed in September 2022 to spend $3 billion to buy back shares at a $300 billion valuation.

Education: Master of Arts, University of Cambridge
About_#1: David Thomson and his family control a media and publishing empire founded by his grandfather Roy Thomson.
About_#2: The family's biggest holding: more than 320 million shares of Thomson Reuters, where Thomson serves as chairman.
About_#3: In 2018, Thomson Reuters announced it was selling a controlling stake in Refinitiv, a financial data provider, to Blackstone for $17 billion.
About_#4: The family also holds a stake in telecom giant Bell Canada and own the Toronto-based Globe and Mail newspaper.
Did You Know?: Thomson has a diverse art portfolio reported to include pieces from Pablo Picasso and the world's top collection of English romantic painter John Constable.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Oregon
About_#1: Phil Knight, founder of shoe giant Nike, retired as chairman in June 2016 after 52 years at the company.
About_#2: Knight ran track at the University of Oregon and created Nike shoes with his former track coach, Bill Bowerman.
About_#3: In 1964, they each put up $500 to start what would become Nike, then called Blue Ribbon Sports.
About_#4: Today Nike's revenues are nearly $45 billion.
Did You Know?: Before cofounding Nike, Knight sold Japanese running shoes from the trunk of his car.
In Their Own Words: It is hard enough out there. Get all the help you can. Getting help really is just a part of that lifelong search for wisdom.

About_#1: Dieter Schwarz's Schwarz Group, with revenue of over $140 billion, is comprised of the Kaufland and Lidl (rhymes with needle) discount supermarkets.
About_#2: Schwarz inherited the company from his father, Josef, who became a partner in Suedfruechte Grosshandel Lidl & Co., a fruit wholesaler, in 1930.
About_#3: Dieter opened the first Lidl store in 1973, became CEO in 1977 when Josef died, and built Schwarz Group into Europe's largest retail empire, with 500,000 employees.
About_#4: Lidl entered the U.S. in 2017, promising to convince consumers to "Rethink Grocery." Its stores are mostly in Virginia and North and South Carolina.
Did You Know?: The Dieter Schwarz Foundation supports education and daycare facilities for children, as well as science and research projects.

Education: Doctorate, Chinese Academy of Social Sciences
About_#1: Robin Zeng is the founder and chairman of Contemporary Amperex Technology (CATL), one of the world's largest suppliers of batteries for electric vehicles.
About_#2: CATL, which listed on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2018, supplies batteries to such automakers as BMW, Volkswagen and Geely.
About_#3: Zeng holds a Ph.D. from the Institute of Physics at the Chinese Academy of Sciences.
About_#4: CATL is headquartered in Zeng's hometown of Ningde in Fujian Province.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Princeton University
About_#1: MacKenzie Scott is a philanthropist, author and the ex-wife of Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, to whom she was married for 25 years. As part of their 2019 divorce, she received a 25% stake in the online retailer.
About_#2: In May 2019, shortly after she announced the terms of the divorce on Twitter, she signed the Giving Pledge, promising to give away at least half of her wealth over the course of her lifetime.
About_#3: Between July 2020 and November 2022, Scott has details how she's given away $14.4 billion to nearly 1,600 nonprofits.
About_#4: Scott employs a "no strings attached" style of giving, wherein the nonprofits to which she donates have full control over how to best deploy the new funds.
Did You Know?: Scott and Bezos met in 1992 when they both worked at hedge fund D.E. Shaw. They married the next year and moved to Seattle in 1994.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Concordia University
About_#1: Rodolphe Saadé is the son of late shipping magnate Jacques Saade, who died in 2018.
About_#2: Jacques founded CMA CGM, now one of the world's largest shipping companies, in Marseille, France in 1978.
About_#3: Rodolphe jointly controls the company with his siblings, Tanya Saadé Zeenny and Jacques Saadé Jr., as well as his mother Naila.
About_#4: He took over from his father as chairman of the board and CEO of CMA CGM Group in 2017.

Education: Drop Out, High School
About_#1: François Pinault is honorary chairman of luxury group Kering, which owns fashion brands Saint Laurent, Alexander McQueen and Gucci.
About_#2: Pinault founded Kering, which started as a wood and building materials company, in 1963.
About_#3: In 1999, Pinault changed the direction of the business toward luxury goods when he bought a controlling stake in Gucci Group.
About_#4: Today the $20 billion (2021 sales) company, which also owns watch brand Girard-Perregaux, is run by Pinault's son, François-Henri.
Did You Know?: Pinault and his family also own several vineyards, a French soccer club, a theater in Paris and a luxury yacht and expedition company.

About_#1: Logistics magnate Klaus-Michael Kuehne is honorary chairman of Kuehne + Nagel International AG, based in Schindellegi, Switzerland.
About_#2: He joined the company, cofounded by his grandfather, in 1958, eventually taking over as CEO in 1966.
About_#3: In 2016, his Kuehne Holding AG acquired 20% of VTG, a rail logistics company. Two years later, it sold the stake to Morgan Stanley Infrastructure.
About_#4: He owns roughly 30% of shipping and logistics company Hapag-Lloyd, a holding he has steadily increased in recent years.
Did You Know?: Despite expressing frustration with the team's performance, Kuehne remains a minority owner of Hamburger SV, which plays in the second tier of pro soccer in Germany.
In Their Own Words: [Hamburger Sport Verein] is enormously close to my heart. I have been a fan from childhood, and I watch every match on television.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Shenzhen University
About_#1: Ma Huateng (also known as Pony Ma) chairs Chinese internet giant Tencent Holdings.
About_#2: Tencent's popular social messaging app WeChat has more than 1 billion users.
About_#3: Tencent, which owns a stake in U.S. videogame company Epic Games, is one of the largest videogame publishers in the world.
About_#4: It has stakes in electric car maker Tesla and music-streaming service Spotify, which in turn has a stake in its Tencent Music.

Full Name: Beate Heister & Karl Albrecht Jr. & family
About_#1: Heirs to the Aldi retail fortune, Beate Heister and Karl Albrecht Jr. are the children of Karl Albrecht Sr., who died in 2014 at age 94.
About_#2: After World War II, Karl Sr. and his brother, Theo Sr., who died in 2010 at age 88, took over their family's corner grocery store in Essen, Germany.
About_#3: In 1961, the brothers split ownership: Karl Sr. took the stores in southern Germany (Aldi Sued), plus rights to the Aldi brand in the U.K., Australia and the U.S.
About_#4: In the U.S., Aldi has more than 2,000 stores in 36 states, offering low prices and no-frills shopping.
Did You Know?: Beate Heister has never worked at Aldi Sued (South), but her son Peter Max Heister heads the advisory board. Son Christian also serves on the board.

About_#1: Giovanni Ferrero is executive chairman of his family's namesake confections business, which posted $14 billion sales in 2021.
About_#2: The firm is best known for its iconic Nutella chocolate-hazelnut spread, Kinder chocolates and Tic Tac mints.
About_#3: Giovanni served as co-CEO with his brother, Pietro, who died of a heart attack in 2011.
About_#4: In 2017 he stepped down as CEO but stayed on as executive chairman to focus on corporate strategy.
In Their Own Words: I strongly believe that attention to employees' needs, to their families, to their life even when they quit working, cements a social cohesion that is mutually beneficial.

Education: Drop Out, High School
About_#1: Nicknamed Superman, Li Ka-shing is revered as one of the most influential businessmen in Asia.
About_#2: Li retired as chairman of CK Hutchison Holdings and CK Asset Holdings in May 2018 but remains senior advisor.
About_#3: At the announcement of his retirement, Li joked that he'd been "working for a long time, too long."
About_#4: His son Victor now heads the conglomerate, which has more than 300,000 employees and operates in more than 50 nations.
Did You Know?: Li says it took him five minutes in December 2007 to decide to invest in Facebook, even though it barely had any revenues. He also invested in Siri and Spotify.
In Their Own Words: The burden of poverty and this bitter taste of helplessness and isolation sort of branded on my heart forever the questions that still drive me.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: The son of a dry goods store owner, Stephen Schwarzman founded private equity firm Blackstone with fellow billionaire Peter Peterson in 1985.
About_#2: Initially a boutique merger-and-acquisition advisory business, Blackstone grew into the world's largest buyout firm, with $941 billion in assets.
About_#3: While Peter Peterson (d. 2018) retired shortly after Blackstone's 2007 IPO, Schwarzman still presides over the business as chairman and CEO.
About_#4: Schwarzman got his start on Wall Street at Lehman Brothers; he writes in his 2019 memoir about mistakes by management at that firm.
Did You Know?: Blackstone is a combination of its founders' names -- "Schwarz" means black in German and Yiddish, while "Peter" means stone in Greek.

About_#1: Lee Shau Kee cofounded property developer Sun Hung Kai with Kwok Tak-Seng, the late father of Hong Kong's billionaire Kwok brothers.
About_#2: He started Henderson Land Development in 1976; the property giant now makes up the bulk of his wealth.
About_#3: In 2019, he stepped down as chairman of Henderson Land and appointed his sons, Martin and Peter, as co-chairmen.
About_#4: A dedicated philanthropist, he's donated more than $400 million toward education over the years.
In Their Own Words: When I was young, business came first, then wealth, then health and finally family. Now it's health first, then family, then my business and lastly wealth.

Education: Master of Science, Columbia University; Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Moscow State University
About_#1: Born in Ukraine, raised north of Moscow, Len Blavatnik immigrated to the U.S. in 1978 with his family; he studied computer science at Columbia University and received an MBA from Harvard Business School.
About_#2: He made an early fortune from Russian oil company TNK-BP, including billions in dividends paid by the joint venture and the sale of his stake in 2013 for $7 billion.
About_#3: After purchasing Warner Music in 2011 for $3.3 billion, he took the company public in June 2020 at quadruple the value.
About_#4: His investment firm Access Industries holds stakes in chemicals firm LyondellBasell, energy conglomerate Calpine and house flipping website Opendoor.
Did You Know?: Blavatnik bought artist Damien Hirst's giant gilded wooly mammoth skeleton entitled "Gone (but) Not Forgotten" for $15 million in 2014.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Bryn Mawr College
About_#1: Jacqueline Mars owns an estimated one-third of Mars, the world's largest candymaker, founded by her grandfather.
About_#2: She worked for the company for nearly 20 years and served on the board until 2016.
About_#3: Her son Stephen Badger is on Mars' board of directors.
About_#4: Mars serves on the board of the National Archives and was formerly on the board of the Washington National Opera.
Did You Know?: Mars owns a horse farm in Virginia that has trained horses ridden by Olympic medalists.

Education: Diploma, The Hotchkiss School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: John and his siblings Jacqueline and Forrest Jr. (died July 2016) inherited stakes in the candy firm Mars when their father died in 1999.
About_#2: He and Jacqueline each own an estimated one-third of the company. His late brother Forrest Jr.'s four daughters own the rest.
About_#3: The $45 billion (sales) candy, petcare and food company was founded by John's grandfather, Frank, in 1911.
About_#4: Mars is also a big name in pet care, with brands including Pedigree and Whiskas, as well as food like Ben's Original rice.
Did You Know?: John and his wife, Adrienne, are noted supporters of the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C.

About_#1: Alain Wertheimer is the chairman of Chanel, the French luxury brand.
About_#2: He owns the company with this brother Gerard, who oversees the watch division.
About_#3: His grandfather Pierre Wertheimer founded it with Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel, the company's namesake.
About_#4: Karl Lagerfeld, the public face of Chanel, died in February 2019 at the age of 85. He had been the company's creative director for over 35 years.
Did You Know?: Alain and Gerard breed and race thoroughbreds. Their horses have won races at the French Derby and the Breeders' Cup Turf in the U.S.

About_#1: Gerard Wertheimer and his brother Alain own French luxury brand Chanel.
About_#2: Gerard heads the company's watch division and lives in Switzerland.
About_#3: His grandfather, Pierre, partnered with Gabrielle (Coco) Chanel, the company's namesake, in the 1920s.
About_#4: Gerard and his brother own vineyards in France and Napa Valley, California.
Did You Know?: Gerard and Alain breed and race thoroughbreds.

About_#1: Germán Larrea Mota Velasco owns the majority of Mexico's largest copper mining company, Grupo México, which also has operations in Perú and the U.S.
About_#2: Under his leadership as president and CEO, Grupo México expanded into the infrastructure and rail transportation sectors.
About_#3: In 2014, the mining company faced scrutiny after a spill at its copper mine in Sonora, Mexico, contaminated two rivers nearby.
About_#4: The company agreed with a government request to deposit $150 million in a trust to compensate local residents harmed by the spill.

About_#1: Australia's richest citizen, Gina Rinehart built her wealth on iron ore.
About_#2: The daughter of high profile iron-ore explorer Lang Hancock, Rinehart rebuilt her late father's financially distressed company, Hancock Prospecting, becoming executive chairwoman in 1992.
About_#3: Hancock's biggest asset is the Roy Hill mining project, which started shipments to Asia in 2015. She's paid off the $7.2 billion debt taken on for this project.
About_#4: The mining magnate is also Australia's second-largest cattle producer, with a portfolio of properties across the country.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, PSG College of Technology
About_#1: Indian IT pioneer Shiv Nadar cofounded HCL in a garage in 1976 to make calculators and microprocessors with five friends.
About_#2: Today, his $11.8 billion (revenue) HCL Technologies is among India's largest software services providers.
About_#3: In July 2020, he stepped down as chairman of HCL Technologies, handing over the position to his daughter, Roshni Nadar Malhotra. He's now chairman emeritus and strategic advisor.
About_#4: HCL Technologies, which employs 211,000 people in 52 countries worldwide, hires high school grads and trains them on the job.
Did You Know?: Nadar's education was primarily in the south Indian language of Tamil, and he didn't start speaking much English until age 22.
In Their Own Words: I came from a rural background, but I did alright.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Doctorate, University of California, Berkeley
About_#1: Jim Simons is the founder of Renaissance Technologies, an esteemed quantitative trading hedge fund firm that manages about $50 billion.
About_#2: He founded Renaissance Technologies in 1982 and retired in 2010, but he still plays a role at Renaissance and benefits from its funds.
About_#3: Renaissance Technologies is famous for its Medallion Fund, a $10 billion black-box strategy that is only open to Renaissance's owners and employees.
About_#4: Simons has given $4 billion to philanthropic causes. His foundation is the primary funder of Math For America. He also supports autism research.

About_#1: Entrepreneur He Xiangjian built Midea Group into one of the world's largest appliance makers.
About_#2: In 1968, He led a group of 23 residents from the town of Beijiao in Guangdong Province to form a lid production workshop that became Midea.
About_#3: Midea Group, whose shares trade on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange, has more than 200 subsidiaries, including Germany-based robotics firm Kuka.
About_#4: He stepped down from Midea Group operations in 2012.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Hebrew University Jerusalem
About_#1: Miriam Adelson is the widow of Sheldon Adelson, the former CEO and chairman of casino company Las Vegas Sands, who died at 87 in January 2021.
About_#2: She now owns more than half of the New York Stock Exchange-listed gambling empire, which has casinos in Singapore and Macao.
About_#3: As GOP megadonors, Miriam and Sheldon Adelson donated $180 million to Republican campaigns and political action committees in 2020.
About_#4: Born in Israel, she became a medical doctor focusing on addiction.

Education: Master of Business Administration, University of Vienna
About_#1: Dietrich Mateschitz, who cofounded energy drink firm Red Bull in 1987, died in October 2022 at age 78.
About_#2: Before Red Bull, Mateschitz was a marketing executive for German consumer products company Blendax, known for shampoos.
About_#3: Mateschitz cofounded the energy drink company with Thai businessman Chaleo Yoovidhya (d. 2012); Yoovidhya's son Chalerm is a billionaire today.
About_#4: The two partnered to create Red Bull and aggressively invested in marketing to make the brand synonymous with extreme feats.
Did You Know?: Through Red Bull, Mateschitz has a stake in two racing teams worth more than $350 million, Red Bull Racing and Toro Rosso.

About_#1: Leonardo Del Vecchio, chairman of the world's largest producer and retailer of sunglasses and prescription glasses EssilorLuxottica, died at age 87 on June 27, 2022.
About_#2: Del Vecchio founded Luxottica in 1961, at age 25. Under his leadership, it acquired Sunglass Hut, Ray-Ban and Oakley and grew to make glasses for virtually every brand including Bulgari and Chanel.
About_#3: Del Vecchio, the 52nd richest person in the world on Forbes' billionaires ranks, was worth roughly $25 billion at the time of his death; his wife & 6 children will reportedly split his vast fortune.
About_#4: Del Vecchio was sent to an orphanage at age 7 because his widowed mother could not afford to support her 5 children.
Did You Know?: Del Vecchio's father peddled vegetables on the streets of Milan and died before he was born.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University
About_#1: Ken Griffin founded and runs Citadel, a Miami-based hedge fund firm that manages roughly $57 billion in assets.
About_#2: He founded Citadel in 1990 but first began trading from his Harvard dorm in 1987. He put a satellite dish on the roof to get real-time stock quotes.
About_#3: He is the founder of Citadel Securities, one of Wall Street's biggest market-making firms, responsible for one of every five stock trades in the U.S.
About_#4: During the pandemic, Griffin funded the State Department's rescue of 800 U.S. citizens from Wuhan and donated $45 million to community initiatives in cities like Chicago and Miami.
Did You Know?: The University of Chicago renamed its economics department after Griffin in 2017 after he donated $150 million.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Waseda University
About_#1: Tadashi Yanai built and runs Tokyo-listed retail clothing empire Fast Retailing, parent of the Uniqlo chain.
About_#2: Fast Retailing's other brands include Theory, Helmut Lang, J Brand and GU.
About_#3: The company reported net profit of $1.5 billion for the fiscal year ended August 2021 on revenue of $19.4 billion.
About_#4: Shares fell in 2021 because of rising cotton prices and lower sales in Japan and China.
Did You Know?: Yanai resigned as an independent director from the board of SoftBank Group after 18 years, in December 2019.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China
About_#1: William Ding is the CEO of NetEase, one of the world's largest online and mobile games businesses.
About_#2: NetEase's business partners include Mojang, a subsidiary of Microsoft, and Blizzard Entertainment.
About_#3: NetEase, facing tough competition in games from Chinese rival Tencent, expanded into movies, online music and e-commerce.
About_#4: Ding was China's richest man and its first internet and gaming billionaire back in 2003.

Education: Master of Business Administration, International Institute for Management and Development
About_#1: Susanne Klatten owns about 19% of automaker BMW; her brother, Stefan Quandt, owns nearly 24%.
About_#2: Their late mother, Johanna, was the third wife of legendary industrialist Herbert Quandt, who guided BMW to preeminence in the luxury market.
About_#3: An economist with an M.B.A., Klatten helped transform her grandfather's Altana AG into a world-class pharmaceutical/specialty chemical corporation.
About_#4: Klatten is the sole owner and deputy chair of Altana, which has more than $2.5 billion in annual sales.
Did You Know?: Klatten is founder of an innovation center at Technical University of Munich, UnternehmerTUM, which claims to be the leading center for business creation in Germany.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Pune University; Doctorate, Pune University
About_#1: Son of a horse breeder, Cyrus Poonawalla founded Serum Institute of India in 1966 and built it into the world's largest vaccine maker (by doses).
About_#2: Serum produces over 1.5 billion doses annually of a range of vaccines, including for measles, polio and flu.
About_#3: Under his U.K.-educated son Adar, Serum's CEO, the company invested $800 million to build a new factory to make Covid-19 vaccines.
About_#4: Serum has multiple Covid-19 vaccine partnerships and produces Covishield, the vaccine developed by AstraZeneca and Oxford University.
Did You Know?: Son Adar, featured in Forbes Asia's Heroes of Philanthropy list, is one of the brand ambassadors for the government's 'Clean India' mission.
In Their Own Words: We reach more children than Coca-Cola and PepsiCo can ever hope to.

About_#1: Wang Wei chairs S. F. Holding, also called SF Express. The package delivery service is known as China's version of FedEx.
About_#2: In March 2018, the company obtained China's first license for drone deliveries.
About_#3: S.F. was founded in the city of Shunde in Guangdong Province in 1993; Wang owns roughly 60% of the shares.
About_#4: Wang took the package delivery firm public through a reverse merger on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in early 2017.

About_#1: Qin Yinglin, chairman of China's Muyuan Foodstuff, made his fortune as the country's largest pig breeder in the world's biggest pork market.
About_#2: Qin was born in Neixiang County in Henan, China's most populous province.
About_#3: He studied animal husbandry at Henan Agricultural University, then started his own business with wife Qian Ying, who sits on the board of Muyuan.
About_#4: The couple started their venture with 22 pigs in 1992.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
About_#1: Sam Bankman-Fried was one of the richest people in crypto, thanks to his FTX exchange and Alameda Research trading firm, before his empire came crashing down in November 2022.
About_#2: After users began withdrawing their investments from FTX at a rapid pace, Bankman-Fried filed for bankruptcy for FTX, FTX's U.S. operations and Alameda Research.
About_#3: It's a stunning fall from grace for Bankman-Fried, who had been heralded as a modern J.P. Morgan for swooping in to save troubled crypto firms before his own firm blew up.
About_#4: The son of two Stanford law professors, he studied physics at MIT and traded ETFs at a quant firm before pivoting to crypto trading in late 2017.
Did You Know?: Bankman-Fried poured hundreds of millions into mainstream marketing, including the naming rights to leading esports league TSM and the Miami Heat's arena.
In Their Own Words: My goal is to have impact.

About_#1: Takemitsu Takizaki is the founder of Keyence, a supplier of sensors and electronic components for factory automation systems.
About_#2: He stepped down as chairman in March 2015 but remains on the board of directors and is honorary chairman.
About_#3: Sales to customers outside of Japan have grown steadily and account for more than 50% of revenue.
About_#4: Customers include auto parts makers, electronics firms and food packagers.

Education: Master of Science, Yanshan University
About_#1: Li Shufu is the chairman of Geely Automobile Holdings, one of China's largest automakers and one of the few not controlled by the state.
About_#2: Through his private holding company, he has been expanding globally since 2010, when he acquired Swedish car brand Volvo.
About_#3: Li has also bought stakes in Daimler, sportscar maker Lotus and flying car start-up Terrafugia.
About_#4: Li told Forbes Asia in 2014 he made his first cars from the sand as a boy. "We couldn't afford any toys. I couldn't imagine making a real car."
Did You Know?: Li holds an engineering degree from Yan Shan University and is a member of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.

About_#1: Emmanuel Besnier is the CEO and controlling shareholder of family-held Lactalis, one of the world's largest dairy firms with $20 billion in sales.
About_#2: His father founded the company in 1933. It now sells products including President brie, Milkmaid yogurts and Valbreso feta.
About_#3: His younger siblings, Jean-Michel and Marie, split the rest of the ownership in the family's milk and cheese giant.
About_#4: Besnier and his siblings own stakes in Parmalat, the maker of Babybel, Frommageries Bel and Boursin.
Did You Know?: Besnier has been called the "French Howard Hughes," "the Emperor of Cheese," and, thanks to his disdain for the press, "the invisible billionaire."

About_#1: R. Budi Hartono and his brother, Michael (whose fortune is listed separately), are the two richest people in Indonesia.
About_#2: The brothers get the bulk of their fortune from their investment in Bank Central Asia.
About_#3: The Hartonos bought a stake in BCA, after another wealthy family, the Salims, lost control of the bank during the 1997-1998 Asian economic crisis.
About_#4: The family first got rich in tobacco and is still one of the biggest clove cigarette makers in the nation.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania
About_#1: Leonard Lauder spent three decades running his family's publicly traded cosmetics giant, Est?e Lauder.
About_#2: The elder son of the eponymous makeup maven, Lauder joined his mother's company in 1958.
About_#3: He created the company's first R&D laboratory and started acquiring brands like MAC, Bobbi Brown and Aveda in the mid-1990s.
About_#4: Lauder stepped down as CEO in 1999. He is now chairman emeritus and is known around the company as "Chief Teaching Officer."
Did You Know?: Lauder gifted his massive Cubist art collection, worth more than $1 billion, to the Metropolitan Museum of Art in 2013.

About_#1: Guillaume Pousaz founded Checkout.com in 2012 to solve the problem of online payment processing for shops and shoppers around the world.
About_#2: In January 2022, Checkout.com raised $1 billion from private investors, valuing the company at $40 billion.
About_#3: Pousaz, who is CEO of Checkout.com, owns an estimated nearly two-thirds of the London-based company.
About_#4: Checkout.com benefited from the pandemic; the company says its payment processing volume tripled in 2020 from the prior year.

About_#1: Iris Fontbona is the widow of Andrónico Luksic, who built a fortune in mining and beverages before dying of cancer in 2005.
About_#2: He left his businesses to Fontbona and their three sons: Jean-Paul, Andrónico and Guillermo Luksic (who died of lung cancer in 2013 at age 57).
About_#3: Fontbona and her children control Antofagasta Plc, which owns copper mines in Chile and trades on the London Stock Exchange.
About_#4: Fontbona and her children also own a majority stake in Quiñenco, a publicly-traded Chilean conglomerate active in banking, beer and manufacturing.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Hangzhou Teacher's Institute
About_#1: A former English teacher, Jack Ma cofounded Alibaba Group, now one of the world's largest e-commerce businesses, in 1999.
About_#2: The former high-flying billionaire stepped down as Alibaba's executive chairman in 2019 and is now planning to give up control of fintech Ant Group.
About_#3: Ant's valuation has taken a massive hit, which by some estimates has fallen over 70% to as low as $70 billion, after its $35 billion IPO was torpedoed in late 2020 by China's financial regulators.
About_#4: Though Ma is largely keeping out of the public eye, his 88-meter superyacht Zen was spotted in June docking off the Spanish island of Mallorca. in 2021.
Did You Know?: Ma owns a vineyard in France.

About_#1: Michael "Bambang" Hartono is the second richest person in Indonesia, just after his brother R. Budi Hartono.
About_#2: The brothers get the bulk of their fortune from their investment in Bank Central Asia.
About_#3: The Hartonos bought the stake in BCA after another wealthy family, the Salims, lost control of the bank during the 1997-1998 Asian economic crisis.
About_#4: The family first got rich in tobacco and is still one of the biggest clove cigarette makers in the nation.
Did You Know?: Their late father, Oei Wie Gwan, acquired a bankrupt cigarette company in 1950, and later renamed it Djarum after the needle of a gramophone.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Princeton University; Doctorate, University of California, Berkeley; Master of Science, University of California, Berkeley
About_#1: Eric Schmidt left the board of Google parent company Alphabet in June 2019 after 18 years; he stayed on as a technical advisor until February 2020.
About_#2: Schmidt was Google's CEO from 2001 to 2011; prior to that he had stints as CEO of Novell and chief technology officer at Sun Microsystems.
About_#3: He co-founded Innovation Endeavors, a venture capital firm that has invested in Uber, SoFi, and Zymergen, among others.
About_#4: In May 2015, his family's investment vehicle bought a 20% stake in hedge fund firm D.E. Shaw & Co. for an undisclosed price.
Did You Know?: Schmidt's family is passionate about environmental sustainability and has donated to various projects related to renewable energy and climate change.
In Their Own Words: If you focus on your competition, you will never deliver anything truly innovative.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Long Island University
About_#1: Ray Dalio is the founder of the world's biggest hedge fund firm, Bridgewater Associates, which manages $150 billion.
About_#2: Working to make sure Bridgewater survives him, Dalio moved in 2018 to turn Bridgewater into a partnership and give employees more of a stake in the firm.
About_#3: Dalio grew up in a middle class Long Island neighborhood and started playing the markets at age 12, getting tips from golfers for whom he caddied.
About_#4: In 1975, after earning an MBA from Harvard Business School, he launched Bridgewater from his two-bedroom New York City apartment.
Did You Know?: In 2017, Dalio published "Principles: Life & Work," a New York Times bestseller that codifies his principles.
In Their Own Words: It's impossible to separate economics from managing money. Doing economic research makes me a better trader.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Michigan State University; LLB, Wayne State University
About_#1: Dan Gilbert cofounded what would become Quicken Loans, the largest mortgage lender in the U.S., in 1985 at 22 years old.
About_#2: Quicken, which originated $320 billion in mortgages in 2020, went public as Rocket Companies in August 2020 at a $36 billion valuation.
About_#3: He also owns the NBA's Cleveland Cavaliers.
About_#4: He and his companies have invested $5.6 billion to purchase and rehab a swath of buildings in downtown Detroit, with a plan to create 24,000 jobs.
Did You Know?: Gilbert started his mortgage lender with $5,000 earned from selling pizzas in college.
In Their Own Words: We are absolutely a more profitable (and better) business because we have a mission beyond the sole pursuit of profits.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Vanderbilt University; Medical Doctor, Washington University
About_#1: Thomas Frist Jr., a former Air Force flight surgeon, founded Hospital Corp. of America with his father in 1968.
About_#2: He took it public for the third time in 2011 after two management buyouts and owns over 20% of the company.
About_#3: HCA Healthcare owns and operates 187 hospitals and around 2,000 sites of care in 20 states in the U.S. and U.K.
About_#4: Frist Jr. doesn't have an executive position at HCA, but his sons, Thomas Frist III and William Frist, are board members.
Did You Know?: His brother, Bill Frist, was the U.S. Senate majority leader from 2003 to 2007, while George W. Bush was president.
In Their Own Words: You always win when you surround yourself with good people.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, Berkeley
About_#1: Masayoshi Son founded and runs mobile telecom and investment giant SoftBank Group.
About_#2: Investors in Son's Vision Funds include Apple, Qualcomm, Foxconn, the family office of billionaire Larry Ellison and Saudi Arabia's sovereign fund.
About_#3: The Vision Funds have invested in over 100 companies, including ride-share firm Grab, Korean e-commerce leader Coupang and India's Paytm.
About_#4: SoftBank's shares took a hit in 2021 after ride-hailing firm Didi Chuxing, facing pressure from Chinese regulators, decided to delist six months after its U.S. listing and relist in Hong Kong.
Did You Know?: Son spent more than $100 million on a 9-acre estate in Silicon Valley with a 9,000 square foot mansion.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Hobart and William Smith
About_#1: Abigail Johnson has served as CEO of Fidelity Investments since 2014, when she took over for her father, and has been chairman since 2016.
About_#2: Her grandfather, Edward Johnson II, founded the Boston-based mutual fund giant in 1946.
About_#3: She owns an estimated 24.5% stake of the firm, which has $3.7 trillion in managed assets.
About_#4: Johnson has embraced cryptocurrencies and, in 2018, Fidelity launched a platform that allows institutional investors to trade bitcoin and ether.
In Their Own Words: No matter how senior you get in an organization, no matter how well you're perceived to be doing, your job is never done.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Oxford University; Master of Arts, Oxford University
About_#1: Murdoch controls a media empire that includes cable channel Fox News, The Times of London and The Wall Street Journal.
About_#2: Murdoch sold most of Fox's movie studio, FX, and National Geographic Networks and its stake in Star India to Disney for $71.3 billion in March 2019.
About_#3: Murdoch's son, Lachlan, runs the new Fox, which consists of its broadcast, cable news, business and sports networks.
About_#4: Though several of his companies are known for their conservative tilt, he initially urged Mike Bloomberg to run for president against Donald Trump.
Did You Know?: Murdoch bought The New York Post, his first major U.S. purchase, in 1976; he still owns the tabloid.
In Their Own Words: My outlook, energy, self-assurance and sense of social purpose were fashioned in the slightly mad meritocracy that is the newsroom, where you start each day with a blank canvas and relentlessly strive to capture as much original news as possible.

Education: Associate in Arts/Science, Technical University of Karlsruhe
About_#1: Stefan Quandt owns 23.6% of automaker BMW; his sister, Susanne Klatten, the richest woman in Germany, owns 19.1%.
About_#2: Their late mother, Johanna, was the third wife of legendary industrialist Herbert Quandt, who guided BMW to preeminence in the luxury market.
About_#3: Both siblings serve on BMW's supervisory board; Quandt is deputy chairman.
About_#4: His holdings also include Heel (homeopathic medicine), Entrust (digital identity and data security) and Logwin (logistics).

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Oregon State University; Master of Science in Engineering, Stanford University
About_#1: Jensen Huang cofounded graphics-chip maker Nvidia in 1993, and has served as its CEO and president since inception.
About_#2: Huang owns 3.6% of Nvidia, which went public in 1999.
About_#3: Born in Taiwan, Huang moved to Thailand as a child, but his family sent him and his brother to the U.S as civil unrest mounted in the Asian nation.
About_#4: Under Huang, Nvidia became a dominant force in computer gaming chips and has expanded to design chips for data centers and autonomous cars.
Did You Know?: Shortly after arriving in the U.S., Huang was sent to a boarding school in rural Kentucky for troubled youth by his aunt and uncle, who mistook it for a prep school.

Education: Bachelor of Technology, Hefei University of Technology
About_#1: Huang Shilin is a former vice chairman of Contemporary Amperex Technology (CATL), one of China's largest battery suppliers for the electric vehicle industry.
About_#2: Huang resigned from the board in August 2022.
About_#3: Huang is a graduate of Hefei University of Technology.
About_#4: CATL went public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2018.

Education: Drop Out, New York University
About_#1: A digital trading pioneer, Thomas Peterffy chairs Interactive Brokers, which markets its specialized trading platform to sophisticated investors.
About_#2: He founded Interactive Brokers in 1993 after originally starting in market-making, and was CEO until December 2019.
About_#3: In March 2017, he announced part of his market-making operation would phase out. It had been under attack by faster competitors.
About_#4: Peterffy arrived in America in 1965 at age 21, the penniless descendant of Hungarian aristocrats who lost nearly everything to the Soviets.
Did You Know?: In high school in Hungary, Peterffy sold contraband Juicy Fruit gum to classmates at a 500% markup.

About_#1: Veteran Mumbai investor Radhakishan Damani became India's retail king after the March 2017 IPO of his supermarket chain Avenue Supermarts.
About_#2: Damani got into retailing in 2002 with one store in suburban Mumbai. Today his company has 271 DMart stores across India.
About_#3: Damani also holds stakes in a range of companies, from tobacco firm VST industries to cement producer India Cements.
About_#4: His property portfolio includes the 156-room Radisson Blu Resort in Alibag, a popular beachfront getaway close to Mumbai.
Did You Know?: Damani was a mentor to billionaire investor Rakesh Jhunjhunwala.

Education: Master of Science, Beijing Non-Ferrous Research Institute; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Central South Industrial University of Technology
About_#1: Wang Chuanfu's BYD reigns as king of China's nascent electric vehicle market, which is the largest EV market in the world.
About_#2: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway owns an approximately 6% stake in BYD.
About_#3: Born in a farm village in one of China's poorest provinces in 1966, Wang was orphaned as a teen and raised by his elder brother and sister.
About_#4: The high achiever made it to college, excelling as he trained his sights on battery technology.
Did You Know?: BYD stands for 'Build Your Dreams.'

About_#1: Reinhold Wuerth entered his father's wholesale screw business in 1949, at age 14, as the company's second employee and first apprentice.
About_#2: He took the reins in 1954 and honed a competitive advantage by delivering goods directly to customers on construction sites and in mechanical shops.
About_#3: Today, with annual sales of over $16 billion, the Wuerth Group has more than 400 companies and 83,000 employees around the world.
About_#4: Reinhold retired in 1994, but he still serves as chairman of the supervisory board of the Wuerth Group's family trusts.
Did You Know?: Wuerth's vast art collection, consisting of more than 18,500 pieces, began with an Emil Nolde watercolor painting acquired in 1964.
In Their Own Words: Everything has its time: the time of becoming, the time of being and the time of passing away. My objective is to keep the company youthful, in a state of becoming.

About_#1: Theo Albrecht Jr. and the heirs of his brother, Berthold, inherited one of the world's great retail fortunes.
About_#2: From a corner grocery store in Essen, opened in 1913, their father, Theo Sr., and his brother, Karl Sr., built their empire after World War II.
About_#3: Propagating the discount revolution in German retailing, they ran their Aldi supermarket chain based on a low-price strategy similar to Walmart.
About_#4: In 1961, the brothers split ownership: Karl Sr. took the stores in southern Germany, plus rights to the Aldi brand in the U.K., Australia and the U.S.
Did You Know?: Little is known about the personal lives of family members. Theo Jr. sits on the board of the family foundation.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Ohio State University
About_#1: Yang Huiyan owns 57% of real estate developer Country Garden Holdings, a stake largely transferred to her by her father Yeung Kwok Keung in 2007.
About_#2: Yang serves as co-chair of Country Garden; her younger sister Ziyang sits on Country Garden's board.
About_#3: Yang chairs Bright Scholar Education Holdings, a Chinese education company that went public on the New York Stock Exchange in 2007.
About_#4: Yang's aunt, Yang Meirong, holds a stake in Bright Scholar.

Education: Doctorate, Russian Academy of Economics; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Siberian Metallurgical Institute
About_#1: Vladimir Lisin is chairman of NLMK Group, a leading manufacturer of steel products.
About_#2: Lisin started out as an electrical fitter in a coal mine in Siberia and then worked as a steelworker in Central Russia.
About_#3: He then managed factories for Trans-World Group, a collection of commodities traders with stakes in aluminum smelters.
About_#4: Trans-World was later investigated for bank fraud. In 1995, Lisin was reportedly interviewed by Russian police in connection with a local politician's death; he denied wrongdoing.
Did You Know?: Lisin built one of Europe's largest shooting-range complexes in Lisya Nora, near Moscow.

About_#1: Fan Hongwei chairs Hengli Petrochemical, a chemical fiber supplier.
About_#2: She is the wife of Chen Jianhua, the chairman of Hengli's holding company; he is also a billionaire.
About_#3: The couple restructured their shareholding in the group in 2022, so that Chen's stake became larger than Fan's.
About_#4: Hengli Petrochemical, established in 2002, has manufacturing sites in the Chinese cities of Suzhou, Suqian and Nantong.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, St Xavier's College Calcutta
About_#1: Lakshmi Mittal serves as chairman of $76.6 billion (revenue) ArcelorMittal, the world's largest steel and mining company by output.
About_#2: Hailing from a steel clan, he separated from his siblings to start Mittal Steel then went on to merge the company with France's Arcelor in 2006.
About_#3: Buoyed by higher steel prices, Arcelor Mittal reported net income of $15 billion in 2021 after a net loss of $733 million in 2020.
About_#4: In 2019, Arcelor and Nippon Steel completed their $5.9 billion acquisition of Essar Steel, once controlled by billionaires Shashi and Ravi Ruia.
Did You Know?: Mittal has held a board seat at Goldman Sachs since 2008.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Western Australia; Ph.D, University of Western Australia
About_#1: Forrest started his first mining company, Anaconda Nickel (now called Minara Resources), in 1994.
About_#2: Nine years later, he founded Fortescue Metals Group, which mines and ships iron ore to China.
About_#3: Investing in sustainable energy projects, he's now focused on repositioning the company into a green energy powerhouse to produce steel in Australia.
About_#4: Fortescue Mining has a subsidiary, Fortescue Future Industries, which is exploring sustainable energy sources, including hydrogen.
Did You Know?: Known by his schoolboy nickname "Twiggy," Forrest was a onetime stockbroker and keen amateur boxer.
In Their Own Words: You cannot afford a world with slavery, which literally takes someone and turns them into a machine.

Education: Associate in Arts/Science, Guilin Medical University
About_#1: Jiang Rensheng chairs Shenzhen-listed vaccine firm Chongqing ZFSW Biological Products, known as Zhifei.
About_#2: A longtime distribution partner of Merck, Zhifei won the Chinese sales rights to the U.S. pharma's HPV drug in 2018.
About_#3: The company went public at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2010.
About_#4: Prior to striking out on his own, he worked as a primary school teacher and a government health official.

About_#1: Jindal Group, whose interests include steel, power, cement and infrastructure, is chaired by Savitri Jindal, widow of founder Om Prakash Jindal.
About_#2: Upon O.P. Jindal's death in 2005 in a helicopter crash, the group's companies were divided among his four sons, who now run them independently.
About_#3: The biggest assets of the group are overseen by her Mumbai-based son Sajjan Jindal, who runs JSW Steel, among much else.
About_#4: Jindal's younger, Delhi-based son, Naveen, manages Jindal Steel & Power.

About_#1: Wang Wenyin is chairman of cable and copper supplier Amer International Group.
About_#2: Shenzhen-headquartered Amer employs more than 17,000 workers.
About_#3: Amer's revenue in 2017 totaled $70 billion, according to company figures.

Education: Bachelor of Science, University of Science and Technology of China
About_#1: Li is founder and chairman of Shenzhen Mindray Bio-Medical Electronics, a supplier of medical devices.
About_#2: Mindray, founded in 1991, is headquartered in Shenzhen.
About_#3: Mindray's chairman Xu Hang is also a billionaire.
About_#4: Li holds an undergraduate degree from the University of Science and Technology of China.

Education: Associate in Arts/Science, University of Stockholm
About_#1: Stefan Persson is Sweden's richest person by way of global cheap chic fashion retailer Hennes & Mauritz, of which he owns 36%.
About_#2: Persson stepped down as chairman in May 2020 after 22 years in the role; his son Karl-Johan succeeded him.
About_#3: H&M was founded by Persson's father Erling in 1947.
About_#4: Persson's two other children, Charlotte Söderström and Tom Persson, and his sister Lottie Tham, are also billionaires.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Steve Cohen oversees Point72 Asset Management, a $26 billion hedge fund firm that started managing outside capital in 2018.
About_#2: For years Cohen ran SAC Capital, one of the most successful hedge funds ever.
About_#3: Cohen was forced to shut down SAC Capital after the firm pleaded guilty to insider trading charges that cost Cohen $1.8 billion in penalties.
About_#4: Cohen bought the New York Mets in 2020 for $2.4 billion, the highest sale price ever for an MLB team.

Education: Masters in Finance, Moscow Institute of International Relations
About_#1: Vladimir Potanin acquired a stake in Norilsk Nickel during Russia's privatization in 1995; today he owns just over a third of the company.
About_#2: Potanin served as deputy prime minister under Boris Yeltsin and maintains ties with President Vladimir Putin.
About_#3: Potanin spent $2.5 billion developing Rosa Khutor, a ski resort, snowboard park and freestyle skiing center for the 2014 Olympics; he still has a stake in it.
About_#4: In February, 2021 Norilsk Nickel was fined $2 billion for the huge oil spill in Arctic. The company disputed the figure, estimating the cost was only $300 million.
Did You Know?: Potanin split from early partner Mikhail Prokhorov, after the latter's highly publicized arrest on suspicion of trafficking prostitutes. (He wasn't charged.)

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: Fracking pioneer Harold Hamm founded and chairs Continental Resources, one of the nation's biggest independent oil companies.
About_#2: The 13th child of Oklahoma sharecroppers, he picked cotton barefoot as a child and started working at a gas station at age 16 to support his family.
About_#3: He eventually started his own trucking company hauling water to and from oilfields, then in 1971 took out a loan to drill his first well.
About_#4: In the 1990s he had the vision to use horizontal drilling and hydraulic fracturing in North Dakota's Bakken region, transforming the US oil industry.
Did You Know?: When Hamm divorced his wife of 26 years in late 2014, he wrote her a settlement check for nearly $975 million.
In Their Own Words: I see these people who spring out of nowhere with a new app that they're selling for a billion dollars. How good is that! That's fantastic! That's what it should all be about. There shouldn't be any limits.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, China Pharmaceutical University; Doctorate, Nanjing University
About_#1: Sun Piaoyang turned formerly state-led Jiangsu Hengrui Medicine into one of China's largest producers of anti-infection and tumor-treating medicines.
About_#2: Sun became the head of Jiangsu Hengrui in 1990 when he was 32 years old.
About_#3: Sun's wife Zhong Huijuan is the chair of Hansoh Pharmaceutical, a drug maker that listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in June 2019.

About_#1: Luo Liguo chairs Hoshine Silicon Industry, a supplier of silicon metals used in electronics, photovoltaic, and chemical products.
About_#2: Hoshine went public on the Shanghai Stock Exchange on October 30, 2017.
About_#3: Luo hails from an area famous for making straw hats; Luo started a successful straw-hat making business early in his career.
About_#4: Wife Wang Baodi is a Hoshine director, while daughter Luo Yi is the vice chairman.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Columbia Business School
About_#1: Peter Woo was chairman of property developer Wheelock & Co. and its main subsidiary, Wharf Holdings, before stepping down in 2015.
About_#2: His son Douglas, who now chairs Wheelock, took the company private in 2020.
About_#3: Beyond property, Wheelock and Wharf control important telecom, port and retailing assets, including luxury department store chain Lane Crawford.
About_#4: Woo started his career in 1972 with Chase Manhattan Bank in New York, where he met his future wife Bessie, daughter of the shipping tycoon Y.K. Pao.
In Their Own Words: You see people complain , 'Now we don't want people from the mainland to come here to use our facilities'. To me that's music to my ears when there is demand for your services.

About_#1: A captain by training, Gianluigi Aponte entered the shipping industry in 1970 with his wife Rafaela.
About_#2: Their company MSC has become the second-largest shipping line in the world by vessel capacity, just behind global leader AP Møller Maersk.
About_#3: In 2014, Gianluigi retired as CEO and became chairman. His son Diego took over until MSC tapped former Maersk COO Soren Toft as CEO in November 2019.
About_#4: MSC also operates in holiday cruises (MSC Cruises), inland logistics (Medlog) and port operations (Terminal Investment Limited).
Did You Know?: Gianluigi financed the acquisition of his first ship ever, a German vessel named Patricia, with a loan. The second ship he bought was named after his wife, Rafaela.

Education: Master of Business Administration, David A. Tepper School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pittsburgh
About_#1: David Tepper, arguably the greatest hedge fund manager of his generation, has been steadily returning money to client investors in recent years.
About_#2: Tepper's Appaloosa Management hedge fund firm now manages nearly $13 billion, down from a peak of $20 billion.
About_#3: He decided to move from New Jersey to Florida in 2016 and relocated his hedge fund firm there.
About_#4: In 2018, Tepper bought the Carolina Panthers professional football team in a $2.3 billion deal.
In Their Own Words: I am the animal at the head of the pack. I generally am. I either get eaten or I get the good grass.

About_#1: Renata Kellnerova is the widow of Petr Kellner, the former richest person in the Czech Republic, who died in March 2021 at age 56.
About_#2: Kellner died in a helicopter crash in Alaska during a heliskiing trip.
About_#3: Kellnerova and her four children control PFF Group, the $44 billion (assets) conglomerate with interests in financial services, telecommunications, media and real estate.
About_#4: She chairs The Kellner Family Foundation, which focuses on education.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Wisconsin, Eau Claire
About_#1: John Menard's home improvement retailer Menards brings in an estimated $13 billion in sales from more than 300 stores.
About_#2: His stores, which compete with Home Depot and Lowe's, are concentrated in the middle of the U.S., from Wyoming to Ohio.
About_#3: Menard first started a construction business in 1958, 20 years before Home Depot launched.
About_#4: Menard has developed a reputation for keeping a tight grip on his business, requiring even top executives to punch a time clock every morning.
Did You Know?: Menard grew up on a farm in Wisconsin as the oldest of eight children.

Education: Master of Business Administration, London Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Commodities king Kumar Birla is the fourth generation head of the storied, $45 billion (revenue) Aditya Birla Group.
About_#2: The group's interests span cement and aluminium to telecom and financial services.
About_#3: Birla inherited the family empire at age 28 when his father Aditya Birla died in 1995.
About_#4: In August 2021, he stepped down as chairman of debt-strapped telecom firm Vodafone Idea, formed by the 2018 merger between his Idea Cellular and Vodafone India.
Did You Know?: The Birla empire's roots go back to 1857 in cotton trading in Rajasthan state.
In Their Own Words: We have a last-man-standing philosophy that has helped us weather difficult times. We've always been very disciplined.

Education: Drop Out, New York University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Princeton University
About_#1: Carl Icahn is one of Wall Street's most successful investors and has been shaking up corporate America for decades.
About_#2: Icahn's primary investing vehicle is publicly traded Icahn Enterprises. He also runs an investment fund made up of his personal cash and money belonging to Icahn Enterprises.
About_#3: He spent the first months of the Trump Administration advising Donald Trump on regulatory overhaul, but left the position amid controversy.
About_#4: Icahn grew up in Far Rockaway, Queens. He graduated from Princeton with a degree in philosophy in 1957.
Did You Know?: Icahn was pushed by his mother to go to med school, but dropped out because he hated it.
In Their Own Words: Some people get rich studying artificial intelligence. Me, I make money studying natural stupidity.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Michigan
About_#1: Brothers Hank and Doug Meijer together own Michigan-based supermarket chain Meijer, which has 230 stores in the Midwest.
About_#2: The brothers took over the company from their father Frederik in 1990; they stepped down as co-CEOs in 2017.
About_#3: Hank and Doug, both in their 60s, still serve on the board of the company, which has an estimated $19.5 billion in sales.
About_#4: Their grandfather Hendrik, a Dutch immigrant, working with their father, started the company in 1934.
Did You Know?: Meijer pioneered the idea of one-stop shopping, now the staple of competitors like Walmart.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Colorado College
About_#1: Lukas Walton is a grandson of Walmart founder Sam Walton; he's an investor in businesses tackling environmental and social challenges.
About_#2: He inherited a fortune when his father, John Walton, died in a 2005 plane crash.
About_#3: He received about one third of his father's estate; his mother, Christy Walton, got about one sixth.
About_#4: He owns stakes in Walmart, First Solar and Arvest Bank, though he does not work for the companies.
Did You Know?: Lukas battled cancer as child. His mother has reportedly claimed that an all-organic diet eliminated his tumor.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Laurene Powell Jobs inherited her fortune--mostly through shares of Walt Disney and Apple--from her late husband, Apple cofounder Steve Jobs, who died in 2011.
About_#2: Powell Jobs is the founder and president of the Emerson Collective, a grantmaking and impact investing firm focusing on causes that include education, immigration, health and the environment.
About_#3: Powell Jobs purchased The Atlantic in 2017 and has invested in other media outlets and nonprofit newsrooms, including Axios, ProPublica, The Athletic and the Committee to Protect Journalists.
About_#4: She owns a minority stake in Monumental Sports, parent of the Wizards (NBA), Capitals (NHL), and Mystics (WNBA) and in 2022 invested in the WNBA's first-ever capital raise.
Did You Know?: Laurene Powell Jobs met her late husband Steve Jobs at Stanford U's business school when she attended a guest lecture he gave. He asked her out in the parking lot.
In Their Own Words: My relationship with money is that it's a tool to be self-sufficient, but it's not something that is a part of who I am.

About_#1: Former chemical engineer James Ratcliffe is the founder, chairman and majority owner of chemical powerhouse Ineos Group.
About_#2: The London-based conglomerate produces everything from synthetic oils and plastics to solvents used to make insulin and antibiotics.
About_#3: It's become one of the U.K. shale sector's largest players. Its 600 foot "Dragon Ships" were the first to transport U.S. shale gas into Europe.
About_#4: Ratcliffe mortgaged his house in 1992 to lead the buyout of a BP chemicals business; 6 years later, he bought a plant from that firm to form Ineos.
Did You Know?: An adventure seeker, Ratcliffe has made trips to both the North and South poles, and went on a month-long motorbike trip in South Africa in 2015.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Washington
About_#1: Donald Bren is America's richest real estate baron.
About_#2: His Irvine Co. owns more than 127 million square feet of real estate, mostly in Southern California.
About_#3: His empire includes more than 570 office buildings and 124 apartment complexes.
About_#4: Bren owns a 97% stake in Manhattan's MetLife Building.
