Did You Know?: Bren attended the University of Washington on a skiing scholarship and spent three years in the U.S. Marine Corps.

Education: EMBA, Ceibs; Bachelor of Engineering, Tsinghua University; Master of Science in Engineering, Tsinghua University
About_#1: Xu Hang is cofounder and non-executive director of Mindray Medical International, a supplier of medical devices.
About_#2: Mindray, founded in 1991, is headquartered in Shenzhen.
About_#3: Xu holds a bachelor's degree from Tsinghua University's Department of Computer Science and Technology.
About_#4: Xu also holds a master's degree in biomedical engineering from the Tsinghua University Department of Electrical Engineering.

About_#1: Lu Xiangyang was working at the People's Bank of China in 1995 when he teamed up with his cousin Wang Chuanfu to launch battery and auto maker BYD.
About_#2: Lu runs his own investment firm, Youngy Investment Holding Group.
About_#3: Wang, BYD's chairman, and Lu, the vice chairman, are both billionaires today from their holdings in the company.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Calcutta University
About_#1: The son of a pharmaceuticals distributor, Dilip Shanghvi borrowed $200 from his father to start Sun Pharmaceutical Industries in 1983 to make psychiatric drugs.
About_#2: The company is India's most valuable listed pharma outfit and gets two-thirds of its $4.5 billion annual revenue from overseas markets.
About_#3: He grew Sun through a series of acquisitions, the biggest of which was the 2014 purchase of scandal-tainted rival Ranbaxy Laboratories for $4 billion.
About_#4: Autoparts billionaire Vivek Chaand Sehgal sits on Sun's board.
Did You Know?: Photos of Shanghvi's family deity, Shrinathji, adorn Sun's factories and offices.
In Their Own Words: Our story is all about incremental growth. We're not looking for big leaps; we prefer small jumps.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Hebei Province
About_#1: Wei Jianjun leads China's largest SUV manufacturer, Great Wall Motor.
About_#2: Wei took over the debt-plagued Great Wall Automobile Industry Company -- the predecessor to the current business -- in 1990 when he was only 26.
About_#3: Wei worked at a carpet factory and a water-pump factory before joining Great Wall.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University
About_#1: Jorge Paulo Lemann started in investment banking and later became a controlling shareholder of Anheuser-Busch InBev, the world's largest brewer.
About_#2: His fellow controlling shareholders at AB Inbev include Brazilian business partners Carlos Sicupira and Marcel Herrmann Telles, both billionaires.
About_#3: In 2016 AB InBev completed its nearly $100 billion acquisition of SABMiller, acquiring brands including Pilsner Urquell and Foster's Lager.
About_#4: Lemann and his partners also own stakes in Restaurant Brands International, parent of Burger King and Canadian coffee chain Tim Hortons.
In Their Own Words: I quit playing professional tennis when I realized it would be hard to be among the 10 best in the world.

About_#1: Eyal Ofer is chairman of the Monaco-based Ofer Global, active in shipping, real estate, technology, banking and investments.
About_#2: He inherited part of his late father's shipping empire in 2011 and has expanded the holdings significantly.
About_#3: Through Global Holdings, his real estate firm, he owns the Manhattan properties 15 Central Park West, 1250 Broadway and 50 United Nations Plaza.
About_#4: Through Zodiac Group, his shipping company, he owns and operates more than 180 ships.
Did You Know?: Eyal inherited half of his father's vast art collection, said to be one of the world's most magnificent.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of New South Wales
About_#1: Mike Cannon-Brookes is cofounder of collaboration software firm Atlassian, based in Sydney.
About_#2: He and co-CEO Scott Farquhar started the company soon after graduating from college, funding it with credit cards.
About_#3: Atlassian, which has no sales team, boasts NASA, Tesla and SpaceX as customers.
About_#4: Cannon-Brookes has been a vocal advocate for reducing Australia's reliance on fossil fuels, in favor of renewable energy sources.
In Their Own Words: If you watch your [stock price] every day, it's like going to the casino. If you play roulette, your money is going to go up heaps and down heaps. What's the point of that? Let's focus on what the company is like in five years.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Northwestern Polytechnical University
About_#1: Wu Yajun is cofounder of Hong Kong-listed real estate developer Longfor Properties. She stepped down as chairman in October 2022.
About_#2: She and her ex-husband Cai Kui, who cofounded Longfor with her in 1993, divorced in 2012. He no longer has a role in the company.
About_#3: Wu, who holds a degree in engineering, worked as a journalist before entering the real estate business.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Rijnlands Lyceum Wassenaar; Doctor of Jurisprudence, University of Leiden
About_#1: Charlene de Carvalho-Heineken is one of the richest women in the world, thanks to her 23% stake in beer giant Heineken.
About_#2: She inherited the Heineken stake in 2002 from her late father, longtime CEO Freddy Heineken.
About_#3: Charlene, husband Michel de Carvalho, son Alexander de Carvalho and daughter Louisa Brassey all sit on Heineken boards.
About_#4: Charlene's mother, Martha Lucille Heineken-Cummins, died on Christmas Eve of 2020.
Did You Know?: Charlene's great-grandfather Gerard Adriaan Heineken opened a brewery in Amsterdam more than 150 years ago.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, London School of Economics; Bachelor of Arts/Science, London School of Economics
About_#1: Michael Platt is the cofounder and CEO of BlueCrest Capital Management, which he started in late 2000 after nearly a decade at JP Morgan.
About_#2: Platt built BlueCrest into one of the world's largest hedge fund firms; at its peak, it managed more than $35 billion in assets.
About_#3: A push into equities and poor results led to investor exits and he returned outside investors' money in 2015, remaking BlueCrest into a family office.
About_#4: The firm has flourished since then, generating a 95% net return in 2020 after returns in the 50% range in 2016, 2017 and 2019.

Education: Master of Science, Saint Petersburg State University
About_#1: Pavel Durov is the founder and owner of messaging app Telegram, which has more than 600 million users worldwide.
About_#2: Telegram, which is free to use, competes with messaging apps like Facebook's WhatsApp.
About_#3: Durov left Russia after he refused to cooperate with the Russian secret service and provide encrypted data of his first social network's users.
About_#4: Durov, who became a French citizen in 2021, moved himself and Telegram to Dubai in 2017.
Did You Know?: Durov is known as Russia's Zuckerberg because he created Vkontakte, Russia's biggest social network, at age 22.
In Their Own Words: As soon as one agency gets to uncontrollably monitor private communications, soon enough this access falls into the hands of third parties - bribers, hackers, agents of other countries.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of New South Wales
About_#1: Scott Farquhar is cofounder of collaboration software company Atlassian, based in Sydney, Australia.
About_#2: He and co-CEO Mike Cannon-Brookes started the company soon after graduating from college, funding it with credit cards.
About_#3: Atlassian, which doesn't have a traditional sales team, boasts NASA, Tesla and SpaceX as customers.
About_#4: Farquhar is cofounder of Pledge 1%, which urges companies to donate at least 1% of equity, employee time or products to charity.
In Their Own Words: We were always cash flow positive from the very early days, but that's largely because we were still eating ramen noodles.

About_#1: Reclusive tycoon Pallonji Mistry, who controlled 156-year-old engineering and construction giant Shapoorji Pallonji Group, died in June 2022 at age 93.
About_#2: The S.P. Group, run by Mistry's older son Shapoor, also owns Eureka Forbes, the country's leading brand of water purifiers.
About_#3: The family's biggest asset is an 18.4% stake in Tata Sons, holding outfit of the $103 billion (revenue) Tata Group, a conglomerate of 30 companies.
About_#4: After Mistry's younger son Cyrus was ousted as chairman of Tata Sons in October 2016, the two families have been at loggerheads.
Did You Know?: Mistry's first overseas project was building the palace of the Sultan of Oman in 1976.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, San Diego; Master of Science, University of California, San Diego
About_#1: Robert Pera is the founder and CEO of wireless equipment maker Ubiquiti Networks.
About_#2: Ubiquiti, which had revenue of $1.2 billion in fiscal 2020, sells wireless broadband systems with a focus on emerging markets.
About_#3: He owns nearly 75% of the publicly-traded firm.
About_#4: Pera started his career at Apple in 2003, and within 10 months of the job, founded Ubiquiti. He started working at the company full-time in 2005.
Did You Know?: Pera missed a year of high school because of a rare heart-valve infection.
In Their Own Words: It's just a matter of fighting through some short-term adversity and maintaining conviction in the vision.

Education: Drop Out, Syracuse University
About_#1: Donald Newhouse and his late brother, Samuel "Si" inherited the publishing and broadcasting empire Advance Publications decades ago.
About_#2: Donald long oversaw the newspaper business that his father Sam built up from the daily Staten Island Advance.
About_#3: His brother, Si, who ran magazine publisher Conde Nast for years, died in October 2017.
About_#4: Advance Publications also has stakes in Discovery Communications and social news site Reddit.
Did You Know?: In 2016, 67 years after he left Syracuse U. to join his father's business, Newhouse returned to receive an honorary degree and deliver the commencement speech.
In Their Own Words: To this day I still can't help but get to the office at 5, just about when you all will be getting home from this celebration, I guess.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Mumbai; Master of Business Administration, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Spurning his family's trading business, Uday Kotak started a finance firm in 1985 then went on to convert it into a bank in 2003.
About_#2: His Kotak Mahindra Bank is now among India's top four banks in the private sector, boosted by its 2014 acquisition of ING Bank's Indian operations.
About_#3: Kotak's 811 app draws its name from November 8, the day in 2016 when the government cancelled 86% of all rupees in circulation.
About_#4: In June 2020, Kotak sold some shares to reduce his stake in the bank as mandated by the Reserve Bank of India.
Did You Know?: Kotak was initially backed by tractor tycoon Anand Mahindra, who still holds a small stake in the bank.
In Their Own Words: Things change so fast, you can't afford to be complacent.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Al-Azhar University
About_#1: Aliko Dangote, Africa's richest person, founded and chairs Dangote Cement, the continent's largest cement producer.
About_#2: He owns 85% of publicly-traded Dangote Cement through a holding company.
About_#3: Dangote Cement has the capacity to produce 48.6 million metric tons annually and has operations in 10 countries across Africa.
About_#4: After many years in development, Dangote's fertilizer plant in Nigeria began operations in mid-2021.
Did You Know?: Dangote's grandfather was a successful trader of rice and oats in Kano, Nigeria's second largest city.
In Their Own Words: Nigeria is one of the best-kept secrets. A lot of foreigners are not investing because they're waiting for the right time. There is no right time.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Kuybyshev Engineering and Construction Institute
About_#1: Leonid Mikhelson is the founder and chairman of natural gas producer Novatek.
About_#2: In 2017 he bought a 17% stake in petrochemical company Sibur from Kirill Shamalov, Putin's reported former son-in-law, increasing his stake to 48%.
About_#3: In 2021 Sibur merged with TAIF Group, with extensive assets in the Republic of Tatarstan; among TAIF's owners are the sons of Tatarstan's first president.
About_#4: His partner in both Novatek and Sibur is sanctioned oligarch Gennady Timchenko, who is said to have close ties to President Vladimir Putin.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Punjab University
About_#1: Telecom tycoon Sunil Mittal's Bharti Airtel is among India's largest mobile phone operators with more than 474 million customers.
About_#2: Airtel, which has SingTel as its partner, competes with Mukesh Ambani's Reliance Jio and Kumar Birla's Vodafone Idea.
About_#3: Mittal also owns Airtel Payments Bank, a niche bank, in a joint venture with Kotak Mahindra Bank, controlled by fellow billionaire Uday Kotak.
About_#4: In January 2022, Google announced a $1 billion investment in Bharti Airtel,of which $700 million would be for a minority stake in the company.
Did You Know?: His son Kavin's SoftBank-backed Hike, once considered a rising unicorn, shut down its messaging service and is focusing now on gaming.

About_#1: Brothers Robert and Philip Ng control Far East Organization, Singapore's largest private landlord and property developer.
About_#2: The group was founded by their father Ng Teng Fong, who moved from China to Singapore in 1934 and came to be known as "The King of Orchard Road."
About_#3: Their Hong Kong arm, Sino Group, is run by older sibling Robert (pictured) and his son Daryl, while Philip oversees the Singapore interests.
About_#4: In October 2019, the Ngs opened the 416-room Fullerton Hotel Sydney in a 147-year-old heritage building that used to house the general post office.
Did You Know?: The brothers are staunch Christians and refer to Far East as a Christian enterprise.

About_#1: Joseph Lau is the former chairman of property developer Chinese Estates, most of which he acquired in 1986.
About_#2: The bulk of his fortune, however, is now derived from prime real estate holdings in Hong Kong.
About_#3: An avid art collector, his wealth also includes pieces from Warhol, Gauguin and Hockney that are worth at least $1 billion.
About_#4: He became a billionaire in 2006 and his brother Thomas is also a billionaire.
Did You Know?: Lau purchased a 12-carat blue diamond for a record-breaking $49 million in November 2015.

About_#1: Fashion maven Anders Holch Povlsen's fortune stems primarily from his nearly $4 billion (sales) retailer Bestseller.
About_#2: Povlsen's parents opened the family's first store in 1975 in the small Danish town of Ringkobing.
About_#3: He took over at age 28 and is now the sole owner of Bestseller, which peddles apparel under 11 brand names, including Jack&Jones, Only and Vero Moda.
About_#4: Povlsen also has significant stakes in retailer ASOS, online grocery store Nemlig and payments company Klarna.
Did You Know?: Povlsen owns more than 1% of all the land in Scotland.

About_#1: Dhanin Chearavanont is senior chairman of Charoen Pokphand Group, one of the world's largest producers of animal feed and livestock.
About_#2: Dhanin is the son of Chia Ek Chor, who along with his brother Choncharoen Chiaravanont, opened a shop selling seeds imported from China in 1921.
About_#3: CP's other assets include stakes in Chinese insurer Ping An and Hong Kong conglomerate CITIC.
About_#4: In 2017, after 48 years as chairman and CEO, Dhanin named eldest son, Soopakij, and the youngest, Suphachai, as CP's chairman and CEO, respectively.
Did You Know?: Dhanin's daughter Tippaporn runs real estate unit Magnolia Quality Development.
In Their Own Words: Work is relaxing if you are not too serious.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Huazhong University of Science and Technology
About_#1: Investor Gong Hongjia's fortune mainly comes from his stake in Hangzhou Hikvision Digital Technology, a supplier of surveillance products.
About_#2: He is the vice chairman and the biggest individual shareholder, with an 18% stake.
About_#3: Gong chairs Vcanbio Cell & Gene Engineering, a Shanghai-listed company engaged in the preparation, detection and storage of stem cells.
About_#4: Gong agreed to buy a 2.4% stake in C-Mer Eye Care Holdings, a Chinese medical services provider, in Dec. 2022.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Leningrad Institute of Economics; Master of Business Administration, University of Northumbria
About_#1: Alexey Mordashov is the majority shareholder in steel company Severstal, which he ran as CEO for 19 years before resigning in 2015.
About_#2: Hit by sanctions in 2022, he immediately transferred ownership of key assets, including shares of leisure company TUI and mining outfit Nordgold.
About_#3: Severstal sold off two U.S. steel plants in 2014, withdrawing from the market at a time of rising tensions between Russia and the West, and turned its focus to its domestic business.
About_#4: The son of mill workers, Mordashov rose to become the finance director of a steel mill.
Did You Know?: Mordashov is a council member at the Bolshoi Theatre.

Education: Liaoning University
About_#1: Wang Jianlin chairs Dalian Wanda Group, which has investments in real estate, finance and movie theaters.
About_#2: Dalian Wanda is one of the world's biggest commercial real estate developers with more than 260 plazas in China.
About_#3: After a buying spree, Wang has been retreating in recent years, selling his Chinese hotel and tourism portfolio for over $9 billion in 2017.
About_#4: In 2018, he sold a stake in Spanish soccer club Atletico de Madrid. He also sold a part of his stake in U.S. movie theater chain AMC.
Did You Know?: Wang served in the Chinese military from 1970 to 1986 before turning around a government real estate venture and then going into business himself in 1989.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Cornell University; Master of Business Administration, Samuel Curtis Johnson Graduate School of Management
About_#1: David Duffield cofounded not just one, but two successful enterprise software companies after age 40: PeopleSoft and Workday.
About_#2: He resigned as chairman of Workday in April 2021; he cofounded the HR and finance software firm in 2005 and took it public in 2012.
About_#3: Duffield cofounded PeopleSoft at age 47 in 1987 and sold it to Oracle for $10.7 billion in cash in 2005.
About_#4: As a child, Duffield mowed lawns and started his first business at 28. He says his most impactful job was a systems engineer at IBM after college.
Did You Know?: Duffield mortgaged his home to bootstrap PeopleSoft in the 1990s.
In Their Own Words: If you truly listen to what people are saying, you'll find out what's on their mind that they want to be comfortable with. And then you'll be more effective in addressing their concerns.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Leeds
About_#1: Triguboff is one of Australia's richest people. Born in China to Russian parents, he came to Australia as a teenager.
About_#2: Triguboff found success in business by providing higher-density living options in Sydney, Australia's largest city, which has traditionally been dominated by free-standing homes.
About_#3: His apartment-tower development company, Meriton, has a strong presence in Sydney, while it also has an imprint in southeast Queensland.
About_#4: He was one of Australia's first developers to see the potential of apartment living when most of his countrymen aspired to single-family homes.
Did You Know?: He began his working life in the textile business, making his move into real estate in the early 1960s.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Shenzhen University; Master of Arts, South China University of Technology
About_#1: Zhang Zhidong is also known as Tony Zhang.
About_#2: For 16 years until his retirement in September 2014, Zhang was the chief technology officer at Chinese gaming and social media giant Tencent.
About_#3: Tencent's portfolio includes messenger app WeChat, League of Legends game developer Riot Games, and minority stakes in Spotify and Snap Inc.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Hunan University
About_#1: Chen Bang chairs Aier Eye Hospital Group, China's largest ophthalmology chain.
About_#2: The group has also acquired 80 more outlets in the U.S., Europe and Hong Kong including Wang Vision Institute in Nashville, Tennessee.
About_#3: Aier is headquartered in Changsha in central China's Hunan Province.
About_#4: Chen dabbled in property and overseas investments until meeting a retired ophthalmologist, who inspired him to open his own hospitals.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Rice University; Master of Science, Rice University
About_#1: Investor John Doerr is chairman of venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins, formerly called Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers.
About_#2: Doerr is the only investor to appear on Forbes' Midas List of top venture capitalists every year for the past two decades.
About_#3: He joined the firm in 1980 after working at Intel and cofounding two companies.
About_#4: Doerr famously led Kleiner into Google in 1999, investing $12.5 million. He was also an early investor in Amazon, DoorDash, Slack and many more.
Did You Know?: Doerr holds multiple patents for computer memory devices.
In Their Own Words: The two things you really look for in a company are a powerful team and a large market.

About_#1: Four siblings, Srichand, Gopichand (pictured), Prakash and Ashok, control multinational conglomerate the Hinduja Group.
About_#2: Their group's businesses range from trucks and lubricants to banking and cable television.
About_#3: The brothers own valuable real estate in London, including the historic Old War Office building in Whitehall, which will house a Raffles Hotel.
About_#4: Srichand and Gopichand live in London and Prakash resides in Monaco while the youngest sibling Ashok oversees their Indian interests from Mumbai.
Did You Know?: The empire was started by their father, Parmanand Deepchand Hinduja, who traded goods in the Sindh region of India (now Pakistan) before moving to Iran in 1919.

About_#1: Kwong Siu-hing is the widow of Sun Hung Kai Properties co-founder Kwok Tak-seng, who died in 1990.
About_#2: She served as the company's chairman from 2008 to 2011 after her eldest son, Walter, was ousted in a feud with her two other sons Thomas and Raymond.
About_#3: She remains the biggest shareholder in Sun Hung Kai.
About_#4: Raymond has been the sole chairman since Thomas was sentenced to 5 years in prison in 2014 for bribery; he was released in 2019. Walter died in 2018.
Did You Know?: Kwong left Guangdong Province in mainland China for Hong Kong in 1947 and married Kwok at the age of 20.

About_#1: Pei Zhenhua's fortune arises from his holdings in Contemporary Amperex, a battery products supplier.
About_#2: Pei also chairs Shenzhen-listed Suzhou TA&A Ultra Clean Technology, which makes cleanroom products used by high tech manufacturers.
About_#3: Pei worked for the Jiangsu Textile Research Institute before he founded Suzhou TA&A in 1997.

Education: Master of Business Administration, A. B. Freeman School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Tecnológico de Monterrey
About_#1: Ricardo Salinas Pliego runs the number two Mexican TV broadcaster, TV Azteca, and retailer Grupo Elektra.
About_#2: His Grupo Elektra targets lower middle class consumers who borrow money from his banking arm, Banco Azteca, to buy items at Elektra stores.
About_#3: Elektra, which is publicly traded, was founded in the 1950s by Ricardo's grandfather, Hugo Salinas Rocha.
About_#4: Salinas appointed a new CEO to TV Azteca in January 2021, replacing his son, Benjamin Salinas Sada, who he'd appointed in 2015.

About_#1: Jim Pattison oversees a sprawling group that operates 25 divisions including packaging, food and entertainment.
About_#2: Pattison's first business was a GM dealership he bought in 1961.
About_#3: The Canadian billionaire also controls more than 40% of publicly-traded forest products company Canfor.
About_#4: His entertainment division includes Guinness World Records, the Ripley's Believe It Or Not! chain and Great Wolf Lodge's Canadian franchise rights.
Did You Know?: Pattison bought Frank Sinatra's Palm Springs home four years before the virtuoso died and kept it the way Sinatra had designed and decorated.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University
About_#1: Charles Schwab is chairman and founder of the brokerage firm that bears his name.
About_#2: The company averages 6 million trades per day across 34 million client accounts worth $7.1 trillion.
About_#3: Schwab was CEO of the business until 2008 and still owns about 7% of its stock.
About_#4: He founded the firm as a traditional brick-and-mortar brokerage in 1971, with $100,000 borrowed from his uncle.
Did You Know?: An avid collector of modern and contemporary art, Schwab is a trustee of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.

About_#1: Goh Cheng Liang gets the bulk of his wealth from a majority stake in Japan's Nippon Paint Holdings, the world's fourth-largest paint manufacturer.
About_#2: Goh started making paints in a small factory in Singapore before he went on to partner with Japan's Nippon Paint in 1962.
About_#3: In 2021, his son, Hup Jin, who chairs Nippon Paint, completed a $12 billion stock and cash deal that gave him a majority stake in Nippon.
About_#4: In March 2021, the company celebrated its 140th anniversary.
Did You Know?: The Gohs own luxury yachts and catamarans.

About_#1: Son of a Bangkok street vendor, Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi controls Thai Beverage, Thailand's largest brewer, known for its Chang beer.
About_#2: Other big assets include Singapore beverage and property giant Fraser & Neave.
About_#3: Charoen's retail empire includes hypermarket chain Big C Supercenter, acquired in 2016 for more than $6 billion.
About_#4: Charoen listed his privately held property unit, Asset World Corp, in October 2019 and continues to hold a majority stake.
Did You Know?: Charoen's son Panote, who looks after the property interests, is overseeing One Bangkok, a $3.5 billion mixed-use development in the heart of Bangkok.

Education: Bachelor of Science, SUNY Binghamton
About_#1: Yass is a cofounder of Susquehanna International Group, one of Wall Street's largest and most successful trading firms.
About_#2: He went to SUNY Binghamton, became a pro gambler, then began trading on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange in 1981 backed by billionaire Israel Englander.
About_#3: In 1987, he cofounded Susquehanna with a handful of partners; it's now a giant in options trading and making markets, with 2,000 employees worldwide.
About_#4: It recruits and trains traders using poker tournaments to sharpen decision-making skills; its traders have won 3 World Series of Poker bracelets.
Did You Know?: In the 1990s, Yass' father Gerald helped build Susquehanna's back-office bookkeeping operations.

About_#1: Fredriksen's empire includes oil tankers, dry bulkers, LNG carriers and deepwater drilling rigs.
About_#2: He first got into oil trading in the 1960s in Beirut, bought his first tankers in the 1970s, and ran crude for Iran in the 1980s.
About_#3: His offshore drilling rig firm Seadrill emerged from bankruptcy in 2018, with Fredriksen helping to raise about $1 billion in new debt and equity.
About_#4: His biggest holding is Marine Harvest, now named Mowi, which has rolled up competitors to become the biggest fish farmer in the world.
Did You Know?: Fredriksen gave up his Norwegian citizenship in favor of tax-haven Cyprus.
In Their Own Words: I've been doing this for 50 years. If I stopped I would probably drop dead.

Education: Medical Doctor, University at Buffalo
About_#1: Andreas Struengmann and twin brother Thomas were early backers of BioNTech, which partnered with Pfizer to make a vaccine for Covid-19.
About_#2: The brothers cofounded generic drugmaker Hexal in 1986 and sold it to Novartis in 2005 for some $7 billion.
About_#3: The brothers invest in biotech, pharma, life sciences and healthcare companies through their Zug, Switzerland-based investment firm, Santo Holding.
About_#4: In 2008, they established a neuroscience research center in Frankfurt named after their father, Ernst Struengmann.

Education: Master of Business Administration, University of Augsburg; Master of Business Administration, University of Augsburg
About_#1: Thomas Struengmann and twin brother Andreas were early backers of German firm BioNTech, which partnered with Pfizer to make a vaccine for Covid-19.
About_#2: The brothers cofounded generic drugmaker Hexal in 1986 and sold it to Novartis in 2005 for some $7 billion.
About_#3: The brothers invest in biotech, pharma, life sciences and healthcare companies through their Zug, Switzerland-based investment firm, Santo Holding.
About_#4: In 2008, they established a neuroscience research center in Frankfurt named after their father, Ernst Struengmann.
Did You Know?: After obtaining a business degree from the University of Augsburg, Thomas worked as a marketing manager for Schering-Plough.

Education: Master of Science, Moscow Institute of Steel and Alloys
About_#1: Mikhail Fridman, cofounder of Alfa Bank, Russia's largest non-state bank, was hit with sanctions after Russia invaded Ukraine.
About_#2: Soon after, Fridman (who also has Israeli citizenship) stepped down from his Luxembourg holding company, LetterOne, and reduced his shareholding.
About_#3: Fridman's properties in London, including the $100 million Victorian-era Athlone House estate where he mostly lived, have been frozen by the U.K.
About_#4: A Ukraine native, Fridman and his college buddies German Khan and Alexei Kuzmichev started commodities trader Alfa-Eco in 1989.
Did You Know?: Fridman filed defamation lawsuits against Buzzfeed and Fusion for reporting that his Alfa Group had a role in Russia's meddling in the U.S. presidential election.
In Their Own Words: I do not make political statements, I am a businessman with responsibilities to my many thousands of employees in Russia and Ukraine. I am convinced however that war can never be the answer. This crisis will cost lives and damage two nations.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Chulalongkorn University; Master of Science in Engineering, University of Southern California
About_#1: Sarath Ratanavadi is the CEO of Gulf Energy Development, one of Thailand's largest power producers.
About_#2: He took the company public in 2017 raising more than $700 million, in what was the country's biggest IPO in a decade.
About_#3: In 2021, Sarath acquired stakes in telecom giant InTouch Holdings and its wireless unit, Advanced Info Service (AIS).
About_#4: Gulf Energy is partnering with Singtel in a new venture to set up data centers in Thailand. In January 2022 it signed an agreement with Binance to set up a crypto exchange in Thailand.
Did You Know?: He went to college in Bangkok, then moved to the U.S. for a masters degree in engineering.

Source of Wealth: palm oil, shipping, property, Self Made
Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Raffles College
About_#1: Robert Kuok is the richest man in Malaysia. He owns Kuok group, which has interests in hotels, real estate and commodities.
About_#2: He founded the internationally renowned Shangri-La Hotels and Resorts chain in Singapore in 1971.
About_#3: His nephew Kuok Khoon Hong runs Wilmar International, in which Kuok has a valuable stake.
About_#4: Robert Kuok's youngest son Kuok Khoon Hua is CEO and vice chairman of Hong Kong property company Kerry Properties.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Wuhan University
About_#1: Lei Jun is the cofounder and chairman of Xiaomi, one of the world's most popular smartphone brands.
About_#2: Xiaomi went public on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange on July 9, 2018.
About_#3: Lei's first success was selling online retailer Joyo.com to Amazon in 2004 for $75 million.
About_#4: Lei listed Kingsoft, an antivirus software firm, on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 2007.

About_#1: Zhang Congyuan founded Huali Industrial, a shoe manufacturer, in 2004; the company now has factories in China, Vietnam and Dominica.
About_#2: Huali supplies dozens of brands including Nike, Puma, UGG and Vans.
About_#3: Zhang also cofounded Hong Kong-listed shoemaker Symphony Holdings, but sold his stake and is no longer with the company.
About_#4: He shares the fortune with his wife and children.

About_#1: Lui Che Woo chairs Macau casino operator Galaxy Entertainment Group and property developer K. Wah International Holdings, both listed in Hong Kong.
About_#2: Initially a construction materials supplier, K. Wah develops property, principally in Hong Kong and mainland China.
About_#3: Lui donated $1.2 billion in 2015 to endow his foundation and the Lui Che Woo Prize.
About_#4: Lui's eldest son, Francis, oversees Galaxy operations while daughter Paddy and son Alexander focus on K. Wah.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Rhode Island School of Design
About_#1: Brian Chesky cofounded peer-to-peer room and home rental company Airbnb with Nathan Blecharczyk and Joe Gebbia in 2008; Chesky is CEO.
About_#2: Airbnb went public in a blockbuster IPO on December 10, 2020, with the share price more than doubling to upwards of $144.
About_#3: A former bodybuilder, Chesky attended Rhode Island School of Design where he met Gebbia.
About_#4: Chesky is the son of two social workers; he made $40,000 a year as an industrial designer in Los Angeles before Airbnb took off.
Did You Know?: Broke and faced with rising rents, Gebbia and Chesky initially bought an air bed for their apartment and rented it out.
In Their Own Words: We had a saying that you would do everything by hand until it was painful. So Joe and I would photograph homes until it was painful, then we get other photographers. Then we'd manage them with spreadsheets until it was painful. Then we got an intern.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, New York University
About_#1: Israel Englander founded Millennium Management in 1989 with $35 million. Now, the hedge fund firm manages nearly $53 billion.
About_#2: Israel Englander, or Izzy, is the son of Polish immigrants.
About_#3: Englander's hedge fund uses a multi-manager platform, feeding more capital to those who perform well and getting rid of traders who perform poorly.
About_#4: Englander once backed a professional gambler named Jeff Yass, who began trading on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange in 1981 and has since become a billionaire.

Education: Drop Out, Harvard University
About_#1: Dustin Moskovitz helped launch Facebook in 2004 with then-roommate Mark Zuckerberg from their Harvard dorm.
About_#2: After leaving the social network in 2008, he cofounded Asana, a workflow software company.
About_#3: Asana went public in a direct listing on the New York Stock Exchange in September 2020.
About_#4: Most of his net worth lies in his estimated 2% stake in Facebook.
Did You Know?: He has an agreement that allows Mark Zuckerberg to vote his Facebook shares.
In Their Own Words: Success is very much the intersection of good luck and hard work.

Education: Master, Finance Academy under the Government of the Russian Federation; Master of Laws, Moscow Institute of International Relations
About_#1: An early Facebook investor and metals magnate, Alisher Usmanov was hit with U.S., U.K. and EU sanctions in the wake of Russia's invasion of Ukraine.
About_#2: His largest holding is his stake in iron ore and steel giant Metalloinvest. He also owns stakes in Xiaomi and other telecom, mining and media companies.
About_#3: Usmanov sold his 30% stake in Arsenal Football Club for nearly $700 million in cash in 2018.
About_#4: He made his first fortune producing plastic bags, a commodity so scarce in the former Soviet Union that people washed and reused them.
Did You Know?: In 1980, he was convicted of fraud and embezzlement; he served six years. Years later, the Uzbek supreme court ruled that the case against him had been trumped up.
In Their Own Words: I am proud that I know Putin, and the fact that everybody does not like him is not Putin's problem. I don't think the world loved Truman after Nagasaki.

Education: Bachelor of Technology, Indian Institute of Technology, BHU
About_#1: Jay Chaudhry is CEO of Zscaler, a cybersecurity firm he founded in 2008. It went public in March 2018.
About_#2: He and his family own 42% of the Nasdaq-listed firm.
About_#3: Before Zscaler, Chaudhry founded four other tech companies that were all acquired: SecureIT, CoreHarbor, CipherTrust and AirDefense.
About_#4: In 1996, Chaudhry and his wife, Jyoti, both quit their jobs and used their life savings to start cybersecurity firm SecureIT, his first startup.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Monash University
About_#1: Pratt is the executive chairman of Australia's biggest private company, Visy Asia-Pacific, a packaging and recycling business.
About_#2: His grandfather started the company in 1948 in Melbourne, and his late father Richard expanded it.
About_#3: He also owns Atlanta's Pratt Industries, the biggest U.S. manufacturer of corrugated cardboard.
About_#4: His sisters Heloise Pratt and Fiona Geminder also hold stakes in Visy and are fellow billionaires.
In Their Own Words: My policy in America is 'steady growth is forever.' We think sustainability is a wave that's not going away anytime soon.

Education: Master, University of Wisconsin Madison; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Zhejiang University
About_#1: Colin Huang, who also goes by Huang Zheng, is the former chairman of online discounter Pinduoduo, one of China's largest e-commerce sites.
About_#2: Pinduoduo raised $1.6 billion in a U.S. IPO in July 2018 amid criticism over its alleged sale of counterfeit products.
About_#3: A serial entrepreneur, Huang earlier founded online game company Xinyoudi and online e-commerce platform Ouku.com.
About_#4: Huang interned at Microsoft in both Beijing and Seattle before starting his career at Google in the U.S. in 2004.
In Their Own Words: I got to learn how to manage and accepted the status of being rich before I got rich.

Education: Associate in Arts/Science, Hebei Broadcast and Television University
About_#1: Jin Baofang is chairman and CEO of JA Solar Technology, which makes solar wafers and modules for solar panels.
About_#2: JA completed a backdoor listing on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2019. It had previously been privatized in 2018 following a Nasdaq listing.
About_#3: JA initially went public at the Nasdaq in 2007.
About_#4: Jin founded JA Solar in 2005; the company had nearly 30,000 employees at the end of 2021.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Tufts University
About_#1: Pierre Omidyar founded online auction firm eBay in 1995 and now serves on the company's board.
About_#2: In 2002 eBay bought online payment company PayPal and spun it off in 2014. Omidyar currently owns 5% of eBay and 6% of Paypal.
About_#3: Through his Omidyar Network, launched in 2004, he's put over $1.5 billion into impact investments and nonprofits that tackle global problems.
About_#4: A resident of Hawaii, Omidyar owns stakes in resort properties in California and Mexico and is developing real estate in Cabo San Lucas, Mexico.
Did You Know?: Born in France to Iranian parents, Omidyar moved to the U.S. with his family at age 6.
In Their Own Words: When you create wealth in a short time, you think about philanthropy as you think about a business.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Leningrad Mechanical Institute
About_#1: Gennady Timchenko has stakes in various Russian businesses, including gas company Novatek and petrochemical producer Sibur Holding.
About_#2: Timchenko ran a state-owned oil exporting company and became one of its largest shareholders when it was later privatized.
About_#3: One of Russia's most powerful people, he befriended Putin in the 1990s in Saint Petersburg when he and the Rotenberg brothers started a judo club called Yavara- Neva.
About_#4: Timchenko was sanctioned by the U.S. in 2014 and by the EU and U.K. in 2022.
Did You Know?: Timchenko sells bottled water and grows apples in Russia.
In Their Own Words: You have to pay for everything in your life. Even for your friendship with the president.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Purdue University; Master of Business Administration, Tippie School of Management
About_#1: Carl Cook took over as CEO of his parents' medical device manufacturer, Cook Group, when his father Bill died in 2011.
About_#2: The $2.5 billion (sales) company sold one of its subsidiaries Cook Pharmica to drug delivery technology company Catalent for $950 million in 2017.
About_#3: Cook's parents started the business in their Bloomington, Indiana apartment in 1963.
About_#4: Cook is the president of a life sciences division called Cook MyoSite, which is developing a cell therapy to treat urinary incontinence.
Did You Know?: Cook's father, Bill, sold medical supplies in Chicago, but hated the city, so packed up the family and moved to Indiana.

Education: Master of Science, Plekhanov Russian University of Economics
About_#1: Industrialist Andrey Melnichenko founded fertilizer producer Eurochem and coal energy company SUEK.
About_#2: The son of a Soviet physicist, Melnichenko dropped out of college when the Soviet Union fell in 1991 to start a chain of currency exchange booths.
About_#3: Two years later, he founded MDM Bank, which became one of Russia's most successful private banks.
About_#4: Melnichenko's companies, which employ more than 100,000, have invested some $23 billion into fertilizer and coal production over the past 15 years.
Did You Know?: His two yachts, including the world's largest sail-assisted yacht, SY A, have been frozen or deregistered by authorities in Italy and the Isle of Man.

Education: Graduate, Tsinghua University
About_#1: Wang Xing is founder and CEO of Meituan, a group created through a 2015 merger of Groupon-like group buying site Meituan and Yelp-like Dianping.com.
About_#2: Wang co-founded China's first college social network xiaonei.com, which was sold to Oak Pacific InterActive in 2006.
About_#3: Meituan Dianping went public on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 2018.
About_#4: Wang in 2021 transferred shares at the time worth more than $2 billion to his foundation amid a China antitrust investigation.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Kansas
About_#1: Over five decades, Philip Anschutz has built fortunes in oil, railroads, telecom, real estate and entertainment.
About_#2: He is the majority owner of the NHL's Los Angeles Kings, with a stake in the MLS's Los Angeles Galaxy, plus he owns the Crypto.com Arena, where the Kings play.
About_#3: His Anschutz Entertainment Group operates more than 350 owned or affiliated arenas and concert venues worldwide.
About_#4: On 320,000 acres in Wyoming, Anschutz aims to build one of the world's biggest wind farms.
Did You Know?: Anschutz owns two five-star resorts, the Broadmoor in Colorado Springs and Sea Island in Georgia.
In Their Own Words: When you see what can be done, the possibilities, you want to be involved in something. You want to own it.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of British Columbia; Doctorate, University of Waterloo; Master of Science, University of Waterloo
About_#1: "Professor Billionaire" David Cheriton, who is professor emeritus at Stanford University, made his fortune thanks to an early investment in Google.
About_#2: Cheriton and Andreas von Bechtolsheim (also now a billionaire) each invested $100,000 in Google when it was just getting started.
About_#3: The pair cofounded 3 companies: Arista Networks (IPO in 2014), Granite Systems (sold to Cisco in 1996) and Kealia (sold to Sun Microsystems in 2004).
About_#4: Cheriton resigned from Arista's board in March 2014 and has been unloading his stock; he still owns nearly 10% through a trust for his children.
Did You Know?: Cheriton, who is frugal in his personal life, is the third of six children of two Canadian engineers who grew up during the Great Depression.
In Their Own Words: I feel like I've been very fortunate in investing, but I still have the brain of a scrounger in terms of spending money.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard College
About_#1: Alexander Otto owns a stake in Otto Group and is majority shareholder and CEO of ECE Group, a commercial real estate firm focused on shopping centers.
About_#2: His late father, Werner Otto, started the empire by founding a mail-order business in Hamburg in 1949.
About_#3: With revenues exceeding $15 billion, Otto Group has more than 40 companies in retail (including Crate and Barrel), real estate and financial services.
About_#4: His stepmother Maren and her daughter Katharina share a 14% stake with him in Paramount Group, which owns and manages office properties in the U.S.
Did You Know?: Alexander's half-sister, Katharina Otto-Bernstein, writes and produces art movies in the U.S.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: Diane Hendricks chairs ABC Supply, one of the largest wholesale distributors of roofing, siding and windows in America.
About_#2: Hendricks cofounded the business with her late husband, Ken, in Beloit, Wisconsin, in 1982. She has run it since his death in 2007.
About_#3: She led ABC to make the two biggest acquisitions in its history, buying rival Bradco in 2010 and building materials distributor L&W Supply in 2016.
About_#4: The company has nearly 800 branch locations and nearly $15 billion in 2021 revenues.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Robert J. Trulaske, Sr. College of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Missouri
About_#1: Stan Kroenke is a real estate and sports mogul with an international portfolio.
About_#2: He owns some 60 million square feet of real estate -- much of it shopping plazas near Walmart stores.
About_#3: Kroenke owns the Los Angeles Rams, which he moved back to California from St. Louis in 2016.
About_#4: His sports empire also includes the Denver Nuggets, Colorado Avalanche, Colorado Rapids and the U.K.'s Arsenal soccer club.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Arkansas; Master of Arts, University of Arkansas
About_#1: Jones, co-captain of the University of Arkansas1964 national championship team, has long had football in his blood.
About_#2: His most valuable holding is the Dallas Cowboys, which he bought for $150 million in 1989. The team is currently valued at $8 billion.
About_#3: Jones made a name for himself as an oil wildcatter, making his first million in oil investments in the 1970s.
About_#4: He still invests in drilling opportunities as well as retail and residential real estate projects in Dallas.
Did You Know?: Jones jumped into the workforce at age 9 as a customer greeter at his parent's grocery store, named Pat's Supermarket.
In Their Own Words: "The Dallas Cowboys fans are the greatest fans on Earth. But I love Jag fans, I love Eagle fans, I love Redskin fans, Massillon High School fans, Canton McKinley fans...you're here tonight because you love the game, I am here because I love it too."

Education: LLB, Middle Temple
About_#1: Quek Leng Chan is the executive chairman of privately held Hong Leong Co. (Malaysia), which has interests in finance, food and property.
About_#2: He inherited part of his fortune from his father, one of three brothers who started a banking group in the 1920s.
About_#3: His cousin, Kwek Leng Beng, is also a billionaire and chairs Hong Leong Group in Singapore.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University
About_#1: Eduardo Saverin cofounded Facebook with Harvard classmate Mark Zuckerberg in 2004.
About_#2: Now a venture capitalist, he still derives most of his wealth from his small but valuable stake in Facebook.
About_#3: In 2016, he launched venture fund B Capital, with BCG and Bain Capital veteran Raj Ganguly. The fund has $6.5 billion in assets under management.
About_#4: In July 2022, B Capital raised $250 million to invest in early stage startups.
Did You Know?: Saverin was a competitive chess player from 1997 to 2001.
In Their Own Words: Entrepreneurship is really about passion. It really is not a job; it becomes your life.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Azerbaijan Institute of Oil and Chemistry
About_#1: A former Caspian Sea oil rig worker, Vagit Alekperov became a deputy minister overseeing the oil industry in the Soviet Union.
About_#2: In 1991 he took three large ministry-controlled oil fields and set up Lukoil, now Russia's largest independent oil company.
About_#3: Lukoil, of which he owns about 30%, was hit by U.S. sanctions in September 2014.
About_#4: Alekperov owns Dutch shipyard Heesen Yachts, where his 230-foot yacht Galactica Super Nova was built in 2016.
Did You Know?: Alekperov penned a book called "Oil of Russia: Past, Present and Future."
In Their Own Words: I have devoted my whole life to work. I have no friends and acquaintances outside my business world.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Renmin University of China
About_#1: Richard Liu, who also goes by Richard Qiangdong Liu, is the founder and chairman of China e-commerce firm JD.com; he stepped down as CEO in April 2022.
About_#2: Liu was arrested in Minneapolis in August 2018 for alleged sexual misconduct, but the county attorney did not pursue charges after an investigation. He reportedly settled a civil suit on the matter in October 2022.
About_#3: Liu opened a retail shop in 1998, but closed it six years later and moved the business online.
About_#4: JD.com has alliances with both Tencent and Walmart, which in turn own stakes in the company.

About_#1: Idan Ofer is one of two sons of shipping magnate Sammy Ofer, who died in 2011 and was once Israel's richest man.
About_#2: Ofer's Eastern Pacific Shipping operates a fleet of over 200 bulk, container and crude oil ships.
About_#3: He also owns 51% of Israel Corp., a publicly-traded chemicals, energy and shipping conglomerate.
About_#4: Israel Corp. spun off its power, transportation & shipping units into a listed firm called Kenon Holdings in 2015; Ofer is a controlling shareholder.
Did You Know?: Idan and his brother Eyal split their father's art holdings, a rare collection rumored to include pieces by Van Gogh and Picasso.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Gothenburg University
About_#1: Melker Schörling laid the foundation for his wealth when he accepted the CEO role of troubled security-giant Securitas in 1987.
About_#2: A little more than a decade later, he set up Melker Schörling AB as a holding company for his investments.
About_#3: The company holds stakes in precision-measuring tool maker Hexagon and lock manufacturer Assa Abloy.
About_#4: Citing health reasons, Schörling left all positions in the company in 2017, and has been replaced by his daughters Sofia and Märta.
Did You Know?: Schörling owns historic manor Edeby South of Stockholm, and is one of Sweden's largest landowners.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Williams College
About_#1: Chase Coleman started out as a hedge fund investor, but his Tiger Global Management has evolved into a broader investment firm.
About_#2: Tiger Global Management oversees some $75 billion in assets. Its venture capital arm is now its biggest unit.
About_#3: Prior to starting Tiger Global in 2001, Coleman worked for hedge fund legend Julian Robertson.
About_#4: Scott Shleifer joined Tiger Global in 2002 and cofounded its venture business a year later, which he still leads.

About_#1: Li Shuirong chairs Zhejiang Rongsheng Holding Group, a producer of petrochemicals through its listed Rongsheng Petrochemical.
About_#2: Li started his first business in 1989, producing polyester fiber cloth.
About_#3: Rongsheng also produces coal chemicals and polyester products.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Politecnico di Milano
About_#1: Stefano Pessina heads the world's largest drugstore chain, Walgreens Boots Alliance.
About_#2: Pessina's journey began in 1977 when he took over his family's pharmaceutical wholesaler, later renamed Alliance Santé, in Naples, Italy.
About_#3: He eventually expanded beyond Italy, merging his wholesaler with UniChem Group in 1997 and Boots Group in 2006.
About_#4: A year later, Pessina took Alliance Boots private in a reported $22 billion deal with private equity firm KKR.

Education: Master of Economics, Moscow Institute of Finance
About_#1: Mikhail Prokhorov sold a 49% stake in the Brooklyn Nets to Alibaba executive Joseph Tsai in a $2.3 billion deal in 2018.
About_#2: Much of Prokhorov's fortune stems from the 2008 sale of his stake in metals giant Norilsk Nickel.
About_#3: He has stakes in Russian power, insurance and banking sectors.
About_#4: He ran against Vladimir Putin in Russia's 2012 presidential race, gaining 8% of the vote.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro
About_#1: Marcel Hermann Telles is one of the controlling shareholders of Anheuser-Busch InBev, the world's largest brewer, of which he owns a minority stake.
About_#2: His fellow controlling shareholders at AB Inbev include longtime Brazilian business partners Beto Sicupira and Jorge Paulo Lemann, both billionaires.
About_#3: Telles and his partners also have shares of listed Restaurant Brands International, parent of Burger King and Canadian coffee chain Tim Hortons.
About_#4: In 2013, the trio's private equity firm 3G Capital and Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway bought H.J. Heinz & Company. Then Heinz merged with Kraft.
In Their Own Words: To get the big fish you have to be in the ocean.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Dartmouth College; Master of Business Administration, Harvard University
About_#1: Leon Black is the cofounder of private equity behemoth Apollo Global Management, which manages over $500 billion in assets.
About_#2: Black stepped down as Apollo's CEO and chairman in March 2021 after a board investigation found that he paid $158 million in fees to Jeffrey Epstein.
About_#3: He spent much of his early career at investment bank Drexel Burnham Lambert, where he eventually headed the mergers and acquisitions group.
About_#4: After Drexel filed for bankruptcy in 1990, Black founded Apollo with colleagues Joshua Harris and Marc Rowan, both of whom are billionaires.
Did You Know?: An avid art collector, Black spent $120 million in 2012 for one of four versions of Edvard Munch's painting "The Scream."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Rhode Island School of Design
About_#1: Joe Gebbia cofounded peer-to-peer room and home rental company Airbnb with Brian Chesky and Nathan Blecharczyk in 2008.
About_#2: In July 2022, Gebbia stepped back from his day-to-day role at Airbnb. He remains on the board and continues to chair its nonprofit arm, Airbnb.org.
About_#3: Gebbia owns a 9% stake in Airbnb.
About_#4: Gebbia and Chesky met as students at the Rhode Island School of Design, where he now sits on the board of trustees.
Did You Know?: Broke and faced with rising rents, Gebbia and Chesky initially bought an air bed for their apartment and rented it out.
In Their Own Words: Great ideas, I think they usually start out as polarizing. They either really tug on somebody's emotions or a latent desire that they have that's never been answered before or they really perturb them in some way.

Education: Drop Out, The University of Texas at Austin
About_#1: David Geffen is the founder of record labels Asylum Records, Geffen Records and DGC Records, as well as film studio DreamWorks.
About_#2: Born to Jewish immigrants in Brooklyn, Geffen started his career in the mailroom of talent agency William Morris, where he rose to become an agent.
About_#3: Throughout the years he has amassed an impressive contemporary art collection, including works by Jasper Johns, De Kooning and Jackson Pollock.
About_#4: A luxury property aficionado, he owns one of NYC's most expensive apartments, a house in the Hamptons and has owned two estates in Beverly Hills.
Did You Know?: To keep his job in the William Morris mailroom Geffen lied about having graduated from college and created a fake UCLA degree. He admitted it once he was successful.
In Their Own Words: It isn't about how tall you are or how good-looking you are or whether or not you can play football. It's about whether you can create a relationship.

Education: Drop Out, Baylor University
About_#1: Andrew Beal is the founder and owner of Beal Financial Corporation, which owns Beal Bank and has assets of more than $8 billion.
About_#2: The Texas banker is known for gobbling up distressed assets, including mortgages, bonds backed by commercial planes and IOUs to power plants.
About_#3: He made a tidy sum during the Great Recession, scooping up beaten-down assets while the nation's biggest banks were being bailed out by taxpayers.
About_#4: Born in Lansing, Mich., he scraped together cash early on fixing used televisions.
Did You Know?: Beal is a high-stakes poker player who has taken on the world's top players in Las Vegas.
In Their Own Words: Why do people not do the great deals and do all the stupid ones? It's crazy.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University; Master of Business Administration, Harvard University
About_#1: George Kaiser took over his family's Kaiser-Francis Oil Company in the 1960s.
About_#2: Kaiser bought the Bank of Oklahoma in 1991 for $60 million; he owns about 56% of the publicly-traded bank.
About_#3: He also owns 78% of publicly traded LNG firm Excelerate Energy as well as stakes in publicly traded fintech firm Alkami and the Oklahoma City Thunder.
About_#4: In the 1930s, Kaiser's parents fled Nazi Germany and settled in Tulsa, Oklahoma.
In Their Own Words: Those who have won the ovarian lottery by being born in an advanced society to loving parents have a special obligation to help restore the American Dream.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, National University of Colombia
About_#1: Luis Carlos Sarmiento Angulo took a fortune amassed in the construction industry and invested it in banks.
About_#2: His Grupo Aval now controls one third of all banks in Colombia. The octogenarian still chairs the company.
About_#3: After graduating with a degree in engineering, he briefly worked at a construction company, but took a 10,000 pesos payout and started his own firm.
About_#4: He bought Colombia's largest newspaper El Tiempo in 2012 for an estimated $250 million.
Did You Know?: At age 14 he worked part time at Colombia's national radio network making programs for children.

Education: Master of Science, Carnegie Mellon University
About_#1: Andreas "Andy" von Bechtolsheim is cofounder, chairman and chief development officer of network switching company Arista Networks.
About_#2: Much of his fortune stems from an early $100,000 investment in Google.
About_#3: He has earmarked his nearly 17% stake in Arista for his heirs.
About_#4: In 1982, he cofounded tech hardware firm Sun Microsystems with Bill Joy, Scott McNealy and Vinod Khosla. Oracle bought Sun in 2010 for $7.4 billion.
Did You Know?: Besides Arista, Bechtolsheim cofounded two other IT networking companies with David Cheriton (one sold to Sun Microsystems, another to Cisco).

Education: Drop Out, San Jose State University
About_#1: Jan Koum cofounded WhatsApp, now the world's biggest mobile messaging service, in 2009.
About_#2: Facebook bought the startup for $22 billion in cash and stock in 2014.
About_#3: He resigned as CEO of WhatsApp in April 2018 and announced he would leave Facebook's board as well.
About_#4: Koum worked at Yahoo for nearly nine years before leaving to found WhatsApp.
Did You Know?: Koum immigrated to California from Ukraine with his mother at age 16 and swept floors to make ends meet.
In Their Own Words: I want to do one thing and do it well.

Education: Masters of Public Health, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro
About_#1: Jorge Neval Moll Filho is a cardiologist and entrepreneur who founded Rede D'Or, one of Brazil's largest hospital and lab operators.
About_#2: Moll started with a health diagnostics imaging laboratory in 1977.
About_#3: Rede D'Or owns more than 30 hospitals. In 2010 Moll sold subsidiary Labs D'Or to publicly-traded Fleury SA for over $750 million.
About_#4: In 2015, private equity firm Carlyle Group and Singapore's sovereign-wealth fund GIC bought stakes in Rede D'Or, spending over $500 million.
In Their Own Words: Study a lot about a topic before starting a business...First dedicate yourself to one thing. Then, become an entrepreneur on that topic.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University
About_#1: Indian tech magnate Azim Premji's $10.4 billion (revenue) Wipro is among India's largest software services providers.
About_#2: Premji gave up studies at Stanford in 1966 to look after the family's cooking oil business when his father died, expanding it into software.
About_#3: Wipro has an innovation center in Silicon Valley, which is focused on developing new technologies and collaborating with startups.
About_#4: In July 2019, Premji's son Rishad, succeeded his father as Wipro's executive chairman.
Did You Know?: Premji is among the world's most generous billionaires, having given away $21 billion to his charitable foundation.

About_#1: Finn Rausing sits on the board of packaging company Tetra Lavel with his siblings Kirsten and Jörn.
About_#2: Finn's grandfather founded Tetra Pak, which invented aseptic ­packaging technology.
About_#3: The new packaging made it possible to store beverages like milk and orange juice in cartons instead of glass bottles
About_#4: His late father, Gad, bought out Finn's uncle Hans in 1995 for an estimated $7 billion.
Did You Know?: Finn is reportedly a financial backer of the Formula One team Alfa Romeo.

About_#1: Jorn Rausing's grandfather founded Tetra Pak, which invented aseptic ­packaging technology.
About_#2: The packaging made it possible to store beverages like milk and orange juice in cartons instead of glass bottles.
About_#3: His late father, Gad, bought out Jorn's uncle Hans in 1995 for an estimated $7 billion.
About_#4: Jörn and his two siblings Kirsten and Finn have equal stakes in TetraLaval and sit on the board of the parent company.
Did You Know?: A plan by pro-Palestinian terrorists to kidnap him was foiled in 1989.

About_#1: Kirsten Rausing owns a third of packaging company TetraLaval, and sits on the board together with her brothers Finn and Jörn.
About_#2: Kirsten's grandfather founded Tetra Pak, which invented aseptic ­packaging technology.
About_#3: The new packaging made it possible to store beverages like milk and orange juice in carton instead of glass bottles.
About_#4: Her late father, Gad, bought out Kirsten's uncle Hans in 1995 for an estimated $7 billion.
Did You Know?: Kirsten is an award-winning horse breeder in the UK, and is the chairman of The International Thoroughbred Breeders Federation.

About_#1: Wang Laisheng is vice chairman of Shenzhen-headquartered electronics manufacturer Luxshare Precision Industry.
About_#2: Luxshare, whose products include connectors and wireless headphones, is a supplier to Apple.
About_#3: Wang started his own business in the mid-1980s, and later teamed up with sister Wang Laichun to buy Luxshare in 2004.

Education: Drop Out, St. John's University (MN); Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Central Oklahoma
About_#1: Tom and Judy Love are the founders of convenience store chain Love's Travel Stops & Country Stores.
About_#2: They started their company in 1964, leasing a gas station in Watonga, Oklahoma for $5,000.
About_#3: Love's is a national chain with more than 490 locations in 41 states and estimated annual revenues of $20 billion.
About_#4: Tom, Judy and three of the couple's four children work for the company. Tom is Love's chairman and Judy is the executive secretary.
Did You Know?: Tom and Judy started their company with a $5,000 loan from his parents.

Education: Drop Out, Harvard University
About_#1: John Collison is cofounder and president of Stripe, a company that lets businesses and individuals accept payments over the internet.
About_#2: In April 2020, Stripe raised an $850 million funding round with a valuation of $36 billion.
About_#3: John and his brother Patrick hatched the idea for Stripe while both were in college in Cambridge at MIT.
About_#4: The company's first payment was processed while both were on vacation in South America.
Did You Know?: John and Patrick Collison took up coding as kids, competing against each other to master the craft.

Education: Drop Out, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
About_#1: Patrick Collison is the cofounder and CEO of Stripe, a company that lets businesses and individuals accept payments over the internet.
About_#2: In April 2020, Stripe raised an $850 million funding round with a valuation of $36 billion.
About_#3: Patrick and his brother John hatched the idea for Stripe while both were in college in Cambridge at MIT.
About_#4: Patrick handles engineering and serves as the public face of the company.
Did You Know?: The Collison brothers became teenage millionaires in 2008 when they sold their company Auctomatic to Live Current Media for $5 million.

Education: Doctorate, California Institute of Technology; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, Berkeley
About_#1: Silicon Valley pioneer Gordon Moore cofounded semiconductor firm Intel in 1968; he was CEO from 1975 to 1987 and chairman from 1979 to 1997.
About_#2: Prior to Intel, Moore was part of the "traitorous eight" that left Nobel Prize winner Bill Shockley's firm to found Fairchild Semiconductor in 1957.
About_#3: Moore is famous for his prediction that computer processing power would double every two years, an insight known as "Moore's Law."
About_#4: He and his wife launched the Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation in 2000. It has over $6 billion in assets and gives away $300 million in grants a year.
Did You Know?: Moore and his wife joined the Giving Pledge in 2012, promising to donate half of their wealth to charitable causes.
In Their Own Words: We seek durable change, not simply delaying consequences for a short time... Scientific methodology should be a cornerstone of nearly all of the Foundation's efforts.

Education: EMBA, Tsinghua University
About_#1: Wang Laichun chairs electronics manufacturer Luxshare Precision Industry, a producer of electronics connectors that counts Apple as a customer.
About_#2: Wang worked for Taiwanese billionaire Terry Gou's Hon Hai Precision Industry (also known as Foxconn) for 10 years.
About_#3: She left in 1999 and teamed up with her brother Wang Laisheng in 2004 to buy Luxshare; he is now the vice chairman.
About_#4: Wang holds an EMBA from Tsinghua University in Beijing.

About_#1: New Zealand's perennial richest person, Graeme Hart amassed a packaging empire using leveraged buyouts.
About_#2: Hart's holdings make everyday products like milk cartons, water bottles, paper and aluminum foil.
About_#3: Since 2013, his Rank Group has been selling off subsidiaries in an apparent move to pay down its debts.
About_#4: He listed Pactiv Evergreen, formerly known as Reynolds Group Holdings, in September 2020 on Nasdaq.

About_#1: Zheng Shuliang is the widow of China Hongqiao Group founder Zhang Shiping, who died in 2019.
About_#2: The couple's son Zhang Bao is the chairman of China Hongqiao Group, one of China's largest aluminum products suppliers.
About_#3: Daughter Zhang Hongxia leads Weiqiao Textile, a textile supplier.

About_#1: Cao Renxian chairs Sungrow Power Supply, a maker of solar PV inverters, wind power converters and power supplies.
About_#2: Cao taught at Hefei University of Technology from 1993 to1998 and founded Sungrow in 1997.
About_#3: The company trades on the Shenzhen stock exchange.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University
About_#1: Nathan Blecharczyk cofounded peer-to-peer room and home rental company Airbnb with Joe Gebbia and Brian Chesky in 2008.
About_#2: Blecharczyk, who is chief strategy officer, was the company's first engineer. He is also the chairman of Airbnb China.
About_#3: Airbnb now operates in over 100,000 cities in 191 countries. With 5.6 million listings worldwide, it has rented to 500 million guests and counting.
About_#4: Airbnb's business took a hit during the pandemic; in May 2020 the company laid off 25% of its workforce, nearly 1,900 people.
Did You Know?: Gebbia brought on Blecharczyk, who was a former roommate in San Francisco, as cofounder and chief technology officer.
In Their Own Words: It's better to have 100 users that love you than 1,000 users that like you. Find your evangelists and build for them.

About_#1: Frustrated with his family's vacuum, Dyson set out to invent a better version in 1978 using a cyclone to lift dirt.
About_#2: Dyson employs more than 5,800 engineers around the world and says it invests about $10 million a week in product development.
About_#3: In 2019 Dyson scrapped plans to build electric cars after telling staff they were not commercially viable.
About_#4: Dyson, who attended art school in London, does not have an engineering degree.
Did You Know?: After five years of testing and 5,127 prototypes, Dyson invented the world's first bagless vacuum cleaner.
In Their Own Words: We are reinventing ourselves all the time. We're battling against the status quo. We still feel small, agile, pioneering.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Marshall School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Witwatersrand
About_#1: Ivan Glasenberg holds the largest individual stake in Glencore, the world's biggest commodity trader.
About_#2: Glasenberg served as CEO of Glencore from 2002 until his 2021 retirement.
About_#3: After earning his MBA from the USC, Glasenberg started working as a marketer in the coal department of Marc Rich & Co. in his native South Africa.
About_#4: The company became Glencore in 1994 and went public in 2011.
Did You Know?: Glasenberg is a former South African race-walking champion.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Seoul National University; Master of Science, Seoul National University
About_#1: Kim Beom-su is the founder of Kakao, South Korea's biggest messaging app, which is installed in 90% of the country's smartphones. He stepped down as chairman and left the board in March 2022.
About_#2: Kakao's tens of millions of users also use the app for gaming, shopping and chatting.
About_#3: In 2014 Kakao acquired the country's No. 2 search engine Daum in an all stock transaction worth $3.3 billion which resulted in a back door listing.
About_#4: That same year the South Korean government classified Kakao as a large company; it is the first tech startup that made it into the big leagues.
Did You Know?: Kim grew up in poverty and paid his way through college by offering private tutoring, sometimes skipping meals to save money.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Keio University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Seoul National University
About_#1: Jay Y. Lee is the executive chairman of Samsung Electronics and leader of the country's biggest conglomerate. He was appointed to the role in October 2022, which had been left vacant since the death of his father in 2020.
About_#2: In 2017 he was jailed and charged with bribing a confidante of the once-imprisoned former president, Park Geun-hye, but was released in 2018.
About_#3: The verdict noted his role as one of "passive compliance to political power." He denies any wrongdoing and appealed the case with the Supreme Court.
About_#4: In January 2021, through a retrial, he was sentenced to two-and-a-half years in prison; his time already served will count toward the new sentence.
Did You Know?: He attended Harvard Business School but did not graduate as he was called back to Seoul amid his studies.

About_#1: Liu Yonghao is the longtime chairman of New Hope Group, which has nearly 70,000 employees and more than 600 subsidiaries in 30 countries.
About_#2: His daughter Liu Chang replaced him as chairman of the group's animal feed arm New Hope Liuhe, one of China's largest agribusiness firms, in 2013.
About_#3: In the U.S., New Hope owns stakes in Lansing Trade Group, a feed and raw materials trading company, and food processing outfit Ruprecht.
About_#4: New Hope Group also has interests in real estate and chemicals.
Did You Know?: With his 3 brothers, Liu founded New Hope Group in 1982, which started out as an animal feed business. The brothers split amicably in the mid-1990s.

Education: Registered Nurse, Lincoln University
About_#1: Ann Walton-Kroenke is the daughter of Bud Walton, who helped his brother, Sam, build Walmart into a retail giant.
About_#2: She inherited part of Bud's stake in the retailer when he died in 1995.
About_#3: A registered nurse, Walton-Kroenke is not involved in Walmart as a board member or an executive.
About_#4: Her husband is billionaire real estate and sports mogul Stan Kroenke.

Education: EMBA, China Europe International Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Fudan University
About_#1: Li Ping is the vice chairman of Contemporary Amperex Technology, a supplier of batteries for electric vehicles founded in 2011.
About_#2: Contemporary Amperex listed on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in June 2018.
About_#3: The company's clients include BMW and Volkswagen.
About_#4: Li Ping holds degrees from Fudan University and the China Europe International Business School.

About_#1: An heir to a Belgian sugar fortune, Eric Wittouck is a descendant of the family that founded Tiense Suicker.
About_#2: Wittouck's net worth has expanded dramatically thanks to Invus, a New York private equity firm that mostly manages Wittouck's money.
About_#3: Run by Ray Debbane, Invus has scored huge returns through investments like Blue Buffalo Pet Products and Weight Watchers.
About_#4: Wittouck's decision to remain fully invested in Invus is one of the greatest investment decisions ever. His cousins mostly pulled their cash out 20 years ago.

About_#1: Brothers Richard and Ian Livingstone own properties throughout London including high-end shops, swanky hotels and tony apartments.
About_#2: Among their signature projects is Panama Pacifico, a master planned city they're developing in Panama with Colombian billionaire Jaime Gilinski Bacal.
About_#3: When finished, Panama Pacifico will include 20,000 residential properties, industrial parks and retail and commercial space.
About_#4: Their real estate firm London & Regional operates hotels in L.A., Las Vegas and Miami.
Did You Know?: The sons of a dentist, Ian was a former optometrist and Richard, a chartered surveyor.

About_#1: Friedhelm Loh's group of companies provides software, products and services to industries including switchgear manufacturing and utilities.
About_#2: His largest company, Rittal, supplies electrical enclosures, climate-control technology, power-distribution gear and IT infrastructure.
About_#3: He inherited the business from his father, Rudolf, who invented the first mass-produced enclosures for electrical control systems.
About_#4: Today, the group has over 12,000 employees, 100 global subsidiaries and annual revenue of around $3 billion.
Did You Know?: Loh collects antique cars and publishes religious literature through his Christian Media Foundation.
In Their Own Words: Stagnation means regression.

About_#1: Technology entrepreneur Xavier Niel owned more than 70% of Iliad, the parent company of his telecom outfit Free, before he took it private in July 2021.
About_#2: His portfolio includes ownership of Monaco Telecom and Orange Switzerland, the latter of which he acquired in 2014 for $2.9 billion and renamed Salt.
About_#3: Niel's initial venture, WorldNet, was France's first Internet provider. He started it in 1993 at age 25 and exited seven years later for $50 million.
About_#4: He financed the construction of a startup incubator, Station F, which opened in Paris in June 2019, and created free computer programming school 42.
Did You Know?: Niel used to own a series of Parisian peep shows.

Education: Doctorate, University of Hamburg; Doctorate, University of Munich
About_#1: Michael Otto inherited shares in the retail empire his late father, Werner Otto, founded as a mail-order business in Hamburg in 1949.
About_#2: As chief executive, he ran his family's Otto Group for 26 years until 2007. He is now chairman of its supervisory board.
About_#3: With revenues exceeding $15 billion, Otto Group has more than 40 companies in retail (including Crate and Barrel), real estate and financial services.
About_#4: Michael's brother Alexander, stepmother Maren and her daughter Katharina -- all billionaires -- also own stakes in Otto Group.
Did You Know?: Michael's son, Benjamin, announced he wouldn't be following his dad's footsteps and become chief executive. He is managing partner instead.

About_#1: Johann Rupert is chairman of Swiss luxury goods firm Compagnie Financiere Richemont.
About_#2: The company is best known for the brands Cartier and Montblanc.
About_#3: It was formed in 1998 through a spinoff of assets owned by Rembrandt Group Limited (now Remgro Limited), which his father Anton formed in the 1940s.
About_#4: He owns 7% of diversified investment firm Remgro, which he chairs, as well as 25% of Reinet, an investment holding company based in Luxembourg.
Did You Know?: Rupert also owns part of the Saracens English rugby team and Anthonij Rupert Wines, named after his deceased brother.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Wuhan U of Science & Tec
About_#1: Hui Ka Yan is the embattled chairman of Hong Kong-listed Evergrande Group, one of China's biggest and most indebted real estate developers.
About_#2: Evergrande, which Hui took public in 2009, has over 800 projects in more than 280 cities but is battling to repay $300 billion in liabilities.
About_#3: Hui worked as a technician in a steel factory for 10 years after graduating college in 1982.
About_#4: Hui started Evergrande in Guangzhou in 1996 and began picking up low price properties in small markets. Its first project was Jinbi Garden.
Did You Know?: Evergrande owns the majority of Guangzhou Evergrande, one of China's most successful soccer teams.

About_#1: Pauline MacMillan Keinath is believed to be the largest shareholder of Cargill, the largest food company in the world, with an estimated 13% stake.
About_#2: Her late brother Whitney MacMillan was the last member of the family to serve as CEO of the business. He retired in 1995.
About_#3: Her great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.
About_#4: The family still owns roughly 90% of Cargill, which did $165 billion in 2022 sales across food, agriculture, financial and industrial divisions.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: Herbert Kohler Jr. was an heir to the fortune behind Kohler, the Wisconsin-based plumbing fixture manufacturer that bears his family's name. He died in September 2022.
About_#2: Kohler's grandfather founded the company in 1873 to manufacture hitching posts and farm tools.
About_#3: He ran the company for 43 years before stepping down as CEO in 2015. He was executive chairman until his death.
About_#4: At the time of his death, the company generated some $7 billion in revenues from furniture, tile, engines, generators and the toilets and faucets that it's best known for.
