Did You Know?: Herbert Kohler bred Morgan show horses on farms in Kentucky and Wisconsin.

Education: Ph.D, Columbia University
About_#1: Li cofounded and chairs WuXi AppTec, a global R&D and manufacturing services company that supports the pharmaceutical, biotech and medical device industries
About_#2: WuXi AppTec was formally known as Wuxi PharmaTech
About_#3: Li also chairs WuXi Biologics, a global open-access biologics technology platform company
About_#4: A subsidiary of WuXi AppTec broke ground on a 190 acre pharmaceutical campus in Delaware in August 2022.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Delhi University
About_#1: Property baron Kushal Pal Singh left an army posting in 1961 to join DLF, a company started by his father-in-law in 1946.
About_#2: Singh later built DLF City in Gurgaon, his showpiece township on the outskirts of Delhi, by acquiring land from farmers.
About_#3: Today, Delhi-headquartered DLF, run by his son Rajiv as chairman, is India's biggest listed property firm by market cap.
About_#4: In August 2017, Singh sold his one third stake in DLF's rental arm to GIC, Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, for $1.9 billion. In 2022, DLF launched a luxury residential project in Delhi with GIC.
Did You Know?: Singh is passionate about golf and collecting art.

About_#1: Zong Qinghou turned privately-owned Hangzhou Wahaha Group into one of China's largest homegrown sellers of bottled water, teas and milk drinks.
About_#2: Zong founded Hangzhou Wahaha as a store in a children's school in the city of Hangzhou in 1987.
About_#3: Zong is an outspoken advocate of lower taxes to support economic growth in China.
About_#4: His daughter Kelly is the heir apparent.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Nanjing University of Aeronautics & Astronautics
About_#1: Cai Kui cofounded real estate developer Longfor Properties with his then wife, Wu Yajun, one of China's richest women.
About_#2: They divorced in 2012, and Cai no longer has an executive role at the company.
About_#3: Cai established Junson Capital in Hong Kong in 2013.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Tennessee Knoxville; Master of Business Administration, Wake Forest University School of Business
About_#1: Charlie Ergen is the cofounder and chairman of satellite TV provider Dish Network and satellite communications company EchoStar.
About_#2: Ergen first began selling satellite dishes out of the back of a truck in Colorado in 1980.
About_#3: He took Dish public in 1996. Today, it boasts over 11 million subscribers.
About_#4: EchoStar, which has 10 satellites in space, was spun off from Dish in 2008.
Did You Know?: Ergen is the son of an Austrian-born nuclear physicist who worked at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory in Tennessee.
In Their Own Words: Part of management is to figure out how you're going to do things, and to be creative on how you're going to do things, and to prove the skeptics wrong.

Education: Master of Science, Jilin University; Bachelor of Science, Nanjing University
About_#1: Gao Jifan is the founder of Trina Solar, which began trading on China's tech focused STAR market in June 2020.
About_#2: Trina Solar raised $376 million to support the construction of photovoltaic power station projects and research and development.
About_#3: Trina Solar, which provides PV module and smart energy solutions, listed on New York Stock Exchange in 2006; it completed its privatization in 2017.
About_#4: Gao holds bachelor degree in chemistry from Nanjing University and a master degree from Jilin University.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Rutgers University
About_#1: Bernie Marcus and Arthur Blank cofounded Home Depot in 1978 after being fired from their jobs at a regional hardware store.
About_#2: In 1981, Marcus, Blank and early investor Ken Langone took Home Depot public. All three men are now billionaires.
About_#3: Marcus, who signed the Giving Pledge with his wife in 2010, has given away over $1 billion to education, hospitals, and Jewish causes.
About_#4: He threw a party for his 90th birthday in May 2019 and raised $117 million for his favorite nonprofits. President Trump sent a personal note, too.
Did You Know?: In the early days of Home Depot no one came into the store, so Marcus and Blank sent their kids out into the streets to hand $1 bills to anyone willing to walk in.
In Their Own Words: What makes America great? Risk, preparation, hard work, and a young man's willingness to shag carts from a parking lot because he has faith that he and his family can be great.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Oxford U Christ Church; Master of Arts, Oxford U Christ Church
About_#1: Nicky Oppenheimer, heir to the DeBeers diamond fortune, sold his 40% of the firm to mining group Anglo American for $5.1 billion in cash in 2012.
About_#2: He was the third generation of his family to run DeBeers, and took the company private in 2001.
About_#3: For 85 years until 2012, the Oppenheimer family occupied a controlling spot in the world's diamond trade.
About_#4: In 2014, Oppenheimer started Fireblade Aviation in Johannesburg, which operates chartered flights.
Did You Know?: In response to the Covid-19 pandemic, Oppenheimer donated more than $110 million to South African small businesses.

About_#1: Three Bajaj siblings, Niraj, Madhur and Shekhar Bajaj, hail from the storied clan behind the 96-year-old Bajaj Group.
About_#2: The group was chaired by their late cousin Rahul Bajaj, who died in February 2022 at age 83.
About_#3: The group is best known for motorcycle maker Bajaj Auto and financial services arm Bajaj Finserv.
About_#4: Youngest sibling Niraj, a Harvard Business School grad, chairs Bajaj Auto, while the eldest Shekhar oversees Bajaj Electricals.

Education: Drop Out, University of Arizona
About_#1: Ernest Garcia, II is the biggest shareholder of Carvana, an online platform for selling used cars and making auto loans that conducted an IPO in 2017.
About_#2: Carvana was founded by Garcia's son, Ernest Garcia, III, as a subsidiary of DriveTime Automotive and was later spun out.
About_#3: Garcia II also owns and runs DriveTime Automotive, the nation's fourth-biggest used car retailer.
About_#4: In 1990 when he was 33, Garcia pleaded guilty to a bank fraud charge related to his dealings with Lincoln Savings & Loan.
Did You Know?: The son of a liquor store owner who was for a while also the mayor of Gallup, New Mexico, Garcia was on the golf team at the University of Arizona.

Education: Master of Science, University of Massachusetts
About_#1: Paul Lee is the chairman of Yunnan Energy New Material, a supplier of film and packaging products.
About_#2: Yunnan Energy, also known as SEMCORP Advanced Materials Group, said in 2022 it will invest $916 million in a lithium battery component plant in Ohio.
About_#3: Clients include Panasonic, LG Chemical and Comtemporary Amperex Technology.
About_#4: His brother Li Xiaohua is the vice chairman of Yunnan Energy New Material and is also a billionaire.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, London School of Economics
About_#1: George Soros is a celebrated hedge fund tycoon who managed client money in New York from 1969 to 2011.
About_#2: In 1992, Soros shorted the British pound and reportedly made a profit of $1 billion. He became known as the man who broke the Bank of England.
About_#3: Soros shifted $18 billion from his family office to his Open Society Foundations as of 2018.
About_#4: Soros was born in Hungary; at 17 he left the country and put himself through the London School of Economics working as a railway porter and waiter.
In Their Own Words: I occupy an exceptional position. My success in the financial markets has given me a greater degree of independence than most other people. This allows me to take a stand on controversial issues: in fact it obliges me to do so.

About_#1: Wang Liping chairs Shanghai-listed Jiangsu Hengli High Pressure Oil Cylinder, which makes oil cylinders, hydraulic valves and hydraulic castings.
About_#2: Hengli's clients include Caterpillar.
About_#3: Wang founded the company in 1990.
About_#4: Wang graduated from Northeastern University of Technology, which is now part of Northeastern University.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Babson College; Master of Business Administration, Harvard University
About_#1: Ernesto Bertarelli inherited biotech giant Serono, maker of the multiple sclerosis drug Rebif, following his father's death in 1998.
About_#2: With his sister Dona, he expanded the company to $2.4 billion in revenues before selling it to Merck for over $13 billion in 2007.
About_#3: Ernesto and Dona co-chair the Bertarelli Foundation, which focuses on marine conservation and life sciences research.
About_#4: The family's Waypoint Group has investments ranging from commercial real estate in London to drug companies.
Did You Know?: Kirsty, Ernesto's wife, is a former Miss UK and a singer-songwriter; she co-wrote a chart-topping song for a British girl group.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Southern California
About_#1: Tamara Hughes Gustavson is the largest shareholder of Public Storage, the self-storage giant her father, B. Wayne Hughes (d. 2021), cofounded in 1972.
About_#2: Gustavson owns about 10% of the company, where she worked from 1983 to 2003. She has sat on its board since 2008.
About_#3: She's also on the board of American Homes 4 Rent, a publicly traded REIT focusing on single-family rental homes that her father cofounded.
About_#4: She's a director of the William Lawrence & Blanche Hughes Foundation, focused on childhood leukemia, and served on the board of her alma mater, USC, from 2010 to 2020.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro
About_#1: Most of Carlos "Beto" Sicupira's wealth comes from his shares of Anheuser-Busch InBev, the world's largest brewer, in which he owns about a 3% stake.
About_#2: His fellow shareholders at AB Inbev include longtime Brazilian business partners Jorge Paulo Lemann and Marcel Herrmann Telles, both billionaires.
About_#3: In 2016 AB InBev completed its nearly $100 billion acquisition of SABMiller, acquiring brands including Pilsner Urquell and Foster's Lager.
About_#4: Sicupira and his partners also own stakes in listed Restaurant Brands International, parent of Burger King and Canadian coffee chain Tim Hortons.
In Their Own Words: Costs are like nails. You have to always be cutting them. Otherwise, they will not stop growing.

Education: Associate in Arts/Science, Ecole Superieure Libre Des Sciences Commerciales Appliquees
About_#1: Laurent Dassault is one of Serge Dassault's four children who inherited their father's wealth when he died in May 2018.
About_#2: In 1991 after 13 years in banking, Serge joined Dassault Groupe, the family's aerospace and software conglomerate. He is now co-managing director.
About_#3: He also serves as director of Artcurial, the family's art auction house, which auctions horses and real estate, as well.
About_#4: Marcel, Laurent's grandfather, founded Dassault Aviation, a French aerospace company that started out making propellers in World War I.
Did You Know?: Dassault is the President of One Drop France, Guy Laliberté's charity, which aims to improve access to clean water

About_#1: Thierry Dassault is one of Serge Dassault's four children who inherited their father's wealth when he died in May 2018.
About_#2: In 2019, he succeeded sister Marie-Hélène Habert as the supervisory board president of family-controlled aerospace and software firm Dassault Groupe.
About_#3: He has been in and out of his family's company since 1979, with stints in the film world as a producer. He also runs his own investment vehicle, TDH.
About_#4: Marcel Dassault, Thierry's grandfather, founded Dassault Aviation, a French aerospace company that started out making propellers in World War I.
Did You Know?: Dassault is an air force colonel in the French military reserve.

Education: Master, Sciences Po
About_#1: Marie-Hélène Habert is one of Serge Dassault's four children who inherited their father's wealth when he died in May 2018.
About_#2: Habert was the president of the supervisory board of family-controlled aerospace and software conglomerate Dassault Groupe, but stepped down in 2019.
About_#3: She now serves as the conglomerate's Communication and Partnership director.
About_#4: Marcel, Habert's grandfather, founded Dassault Aviation, a French aerospace company that started out making propellers in World War I.

About_#1: Ma Jianrong, a former factory worker, chairs Shenzhou International Group Holdings, China's largest exporter and maker of knitwear and garments.
About_#2: Shenzhou's customers include Nike, Uniqlo and Adidas.
About_#3: Most of Shenzhou's revenue comes from overseas markets.
About_#4: Ma's brother-in-law Huang Guanlin is Shenzhou's general manager and an executive director.

Education: Law Degree, American University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, DePauw University
About_#1: Steven Rales and his brother Mitchell acquired a REIT in 1983 and merged it into their firm Danaher, named after a Montana creek.
About_#2: Focused on tax avoidance and cash flow, they acquired more than three dozen companies and turned Danaher into a diversified firm.
About_#3: Rales serves as chairman of the board at Danaher, which had around $29.45 billion in sales in 2021
About_#4: In July 2016, the industrial conglomerate spun off some of its assets into a new company, Fortive Corporation.
Did You Know?: His production company Indian Paintbrush funded some of Wes Anderson's movies, such as "Isle of Dogs", "Moonrise Kingdom" and "The Grand Budapest Hotel."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Yale University
About_#1: He is vice chairman and cofounder of Alibaba Group, and ranks as its second-largest individual shareholder after Jack Ma.
About_#2: In 2018, he bought 49% of the Brooklyn Nets National Basketball Association team; the following year he purchased the remaining 51%.
About_#3: He holds two degrees from Yale University--an undergraduate degree in economics and East Asian studies and a law degree.
About_#4: Taiwan-born Tsai carries a Canadian passport.
Did You Know?: Tsai accepted an initial salary of only $50 a month from Jack Ma when the pair first met in 1999.
In Their Own Words: I knew I was in an environment to learn, so I didn't want to stick out. I knew I had a knowledge that nobody else had, so people could trust that aspect to me... I don't pretend to do everything. I knew what my role was [on joining Alibaba].

About_#1: Francine von Finck and her 4 children inherited their fortune from her late husband and their father, August von Finck, who died at 91 in Nov. 2021.
About_#2: August inherited a business started by his grandfather, Wilhelm von Finck, in 1870.
About_#3: August's Merck Finck & Co. private bank spawned the Loewenbraeu breweries and insurers Munich Re and Allianz.
About_#4: August sold Merck Finck and the Allianz shares to Barclays Bank in 1990 and reinvested the money in a diverse portfolio.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of British Columbia
About_#1: Anthony von Mandl created the ready-to-drink alcoholic beverages White Claw Hard Seltzer and Mike's Hard Lemonade through his Mark Anthony Brands.
About_#2: Forbes estimates von Mandl's U.S. business generated over $3 billion in revenue in 2021, based on analyst estimates.
About_#3: He began his career in the Canadian wine business as an importer in the 1970s at age 22.
About_#4: He currently owns five wineries in Canada, including Mission Hill Winery in British Columbia's Okanagan Valley.
Did You Know?: Von Mandl's spirits portfolio includes Ireland's top end Glendalough Whiskey & Gin Distillery.

Education: Master of Business Administration, University of Gothenburg
About_#1: Swedish industrialist Carl Bennet controls five companies on the Stockholm stock exchange.
About_#2: His holdings include business group Lifco, medical supplies company Arjo and logistics company Elanders.
About_#3: He also controls medical products company Getinge, which Bennet and fellow investor Rune Andersson acquired from Electrolux in 1989.
About_#4: They ran the company together for nearly a decade before parting ways.
Did You Know?: Bennet has criticized Sweden's central-left government for not doing enough to battle youth unemployment in Sweden, and proposes a German-style apprentice system.

Source of Wealth: Manufacturing, New England Patriots, Self Made
Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Columbia University; Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School
About_#1: Robert Kraft bought the New England Patriots for $172 million in 1994; the team is now worth about $6 billion and has won six Super Bowl rings.
About_#2: Kraft, who sold newspapers outside the old Braves Stadium in Boston as a kid, made an early fortune in paper and packaging.
About_#3: Today his sports portfolio also includes the New England Revolution MLS club.
About_#4: He started a professional videogaming team in Boston, part of the Overwatch esports league, in 2017.
Did You Know?: Before he bought the Patriots, Kraft owned the Boston Lobsters, a World Team Tennis franchise.

Education: Medical Doctor, University of Indonesia
About_#1: Chairul Tanjung's CT Corp. is best known for issuing credit cards, operating hypermarkets and running TV stations.
About_#2: His Trans Retail has grocery stores under the Carrefour and Transmart brands.
About_#3: His group also controls the Wendy's franchise in Indonesia and owns the Versace, Mango and Jimmy Choo franchises.
About_#4: He has a stake in Indonesian national carrier Garuda, whose plan to restructure its $10 billion debt won approval from its creditors in 2022.
Did You Know?: Chairul is the son of a journalist.

About_#1: Manuel Villar chairs property developer Vista Land & Lifescapes run by his son Manuel Paulo. The company listed VistaREIT, a real estate investment trust, in June 2022 with an initial portfolio of 10 shopping malls and two office towers.
About_#2: Villar's biggest asset is his stake in Golden MV Holdings (formerly Golden Bria), a developer of mass housing projects and memorial parks.
About_#3: He also has three other listed entities including mall operator Vistamalls, home improvement chain AllHome and supermarket chain AllDay Marts.
About_#4: His wife Cynthia and son Mark are senators in the Philippines, while daughter Camille is a congressman representing their hometown Las Pinas in southern Metro Manila.
Did You Know?: Villar has been involved in politics and held positions including congressman, speaker of the house of representatives, senator, and senate president.

About_#1: Dairy heir Jean-Michel Besnier owns 20.7% of French dairy giant Lactalis, based in his family's ancestral hometown of Laval in western France.
About_#2: His grandfather founded the company in 1933, and his older brother Emmanuel now runs the firm as CEO and majority shareholder.
About_#3: Lactalis sells $20 billion of products including President brie, Milkmaid yogurts and Valbreso Feta.
About_#4: The family also own stakes in Italy's publicly traded Parmalat and Frommageries Bel, the French maker of Baby Bel, La Vache Qui Rit and Boursin.

About_#1: Dairy heiress Marie Besnier Beauvalot owns 20.7% of French dairy giant Lactalis, based in her family's ancestral hometown of Laval in western France.
About_#2: Her grandfather founded the company in 1933, and her older brother Emmanuel now runs the firm as CEO and majority shareholder.
About_#3: Lactalis sells $20 billion of products including President brie, Milkmaid yogurts and Valbreso Feta.
About_#4: The family also own stakes in Italy's publicly traded Parmalat and Frommageries Bel, the French maker of Baby Bel, La Vache Qui Rit and Boursin.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University
About_#1: Gustaf Douglas was born into nobility, but without exceptional riches.
About_#2: The Harvard graduate eventually ran state-owned TV channel SVT2 and newspaper Dagens Nyheter.
About_#3: In 1985 Douglas acquired a controlling stake in Swedish security firm Securitas, eventually turning into a global powerhouse.
About_#4: Today, his sons, Carl and Eric, sit on the board of both Investment AB Latour. They are also billionaires.
Did You Know?: To pay his tuition at Harvard Business School, Douglas started placing aggressive bets on stocks including Volvo.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Aarhus Business School; Master of Business Administration, International Institute for Management and Development
About_#1: Third-generation owner of Lego, Kjeld Kirk Kristiansen led the toy company known for its interlocking plastic bricks from 1979 to 2004.
About_#2: He and his three grown children together evenly split ownership of a 75% stake in the $7.2 billion (sales) business.
About_#3: He stepped down from Lego's board in 2019. His son Thomas, Lego's deputy chairman, will replace him as chair of family holding company Kirkbi in 2023.
About_#4: His grandfather Ole, a carpenter, started making wooden toys in his workshop in 1932 before moving into plastic in the 1940s.
Did You Know?: The original Legoland, built in 1968 in Kristiansen's hometown of Billund, is made up of over 20 million Lego bricks.
In Their Own Words: When children play games or build their own creations in the physical world, they actively challenge both the laws of nature and intellectual and physical limits.

About_#1: A fourth-generation owner of Lego, Sofie Kirk Kristiansen, her father, sister and brother together split ownership of a 75% stake in the company.
About_#2: Kristiansen is not involved in the business; her brother, Thomas, serves as Lego's deputy chairman.
About_#3: Her great-grandfather Ole, a carpenter, started making wooden toys in his workshop in 1932 before moving into plastic in the 1940s.
About_#4: The family has a 47.5% stake in theme park operator Merlin Entertainments, which it took private with a consortium.

About_#1: A fourth-generation owner of Lego, Thomas Kirk Kristiansen succeeded his father Kjeld as deputy chairman of the company's board in 2016.
About_#2: He, his two sisters and father together split ownership of a 75% stake in the $7.2 billion (sales) business.
About_#3: He is also chairman of the Lego Foundation and will succeed his father as chairman of Kirkbi, the family's holding company, in the spring of 2023.
About_#4: His great-grandfather Ole, a carpenter, started making wooden toys in his workshop in 1932 before moving into plastic in the 1940s.

Education: Master of Laws, New York University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Michigan; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Wayne State University
About_#1: Stephen Ross was a tax attorney before founding Related Companies in 1972 as an affordable housing developer.
About_#2: In all, Related has developed or acquired more than $60 billion worth of properties of all kinds from California to Abu Dhabi to Shanghai.
About_#3: After a decade of planning and construction, Related Co.'s Hudson Yards on Manhattan's west side opened to the public in March 2019.
About_#4: Related is building two new mega-developments, The 78 in Chicago and Related Santa Clara in California, that will be comparable in size to Hudson Yards.
Did You Know?: The single largest donor to alma mater University of Michigan, Ross has pledged a total of $378 million including $50 million announced in September 2017.
In Their Own Words: When you look at the rail yards today you have to have vision. A lot of ?vision.

About_#1: A fourth-generation owner of Lego, Agnete Kirk Thinggaard splits ownership of a 75% stake in the toy company with her father, sister and brother.
About_#2: Thinggaard also sat on the Lego Foundation's board until 2020, when she stepped down to join family holding company Kirkbi as a board observer.
About_#3: Her great-grandfather Ole, a carpenter, started making wooden toys in his workshop in 1932 before moving into plastic in the 1940s.
About_#4: The family has a 47.5% stake in theme park operator Merlin Entertainments, which it took private with a consortium in 2019.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Southern California
About_#1: Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff owns about 4% of the cloud computing software firm he cofounded in 1999.
About_#2: Before Salesforce, he spent 13 years at database software giant Oracle as a protege of Larry Ellison.
About_#3: Salesforce was a pioneer in hosting its software online, rather than installing it in clients' computer systems.
About_#4: He's an angel investor in dozens of tech startups and a prolific philanthropist.
Did You Know?: At 17, Benioff developed and sold Atari video games, and earned enough to pay his way to USC.
In Their Own Words: When I get something in my head, it's hard for me to just let it go.

Education: Master of Science, Vologda State Pedagogical University
About_#1: Dmitri Bukhman and his brother Igor own online gaming upstart Playrix.
About_#2: The company is best known for free mobile-app games such as Homescapes and Fishdom.
About_#3: Born and raised in northern Russia, the brothers started selling games online while Dmitry was still in high school.
About_#4: Playrix now does more than $2.7 billion in estimated annual revenue.

Education: Master of Science, Vologda State Pedagogical University
About_#1: Igor Bukhman and his brother Dmitry own online gaming upstart Playrix.
About_#2: The company is best known for free mobile-app games such as Homescapes and Fishdom.
About_#3: Born and raised in northern Russia, the brothers started selling games online while Dmitry was still in high school.
About_#4: Playrix now does more than $2.7 billion in estimated annual revenue.

About_#1: Francis Choi is the founder and chairman of Early Light International, the world's largest toymaker.
About_#2: Known as the "King of Toys," Choi also serves as vice chairman of Regal Hotels International.
About_#3: His wealth is anchored by his sprawling property portfolio in China, Hong Kong and Macau. His property assets include Kowloon City Plaza.
About_#4: Choi also owns luxury watch retailer Halewinner, which he bought in 2010 and is now run by his son Karson.
Did You Know?: Choi spent long hours building up his business in the 1970s. He went from floor to floor teaching families how to make toys and paid them by the piece.

About_#1: U.S.-trained scientist Murali Divi founded generics maker Divi's Laboratories 32 years ago as a drug research firm.
About_#2: Today, the company is among the world's top suppliers of active pharmaceutical ingredients.
About_#3: The company also does custom manufacturing for big pharma companies and produces nutraceuticals.
About_#4: Divi's Laboratories gets more than 85% of its annual revenue of $1.1 billion from exports.
Did You Know?: A fitness fanatic, he has built a yoga center at Divi's headquarters in Hyderabad.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Memphis
About_#1: Nancy Walton Laurie inherited a stake in Walmart from her father, Bud Walton, who helped his brother, Sam, build the retail giant.
About_#2: When Bud died in 1995, Walton Laurie and her sister, Ann Walton Kroenke, received enough Walmart stock to make them both billionaires.
About_#3: Walton Laurie and her husband, Bill, also own a portfolio of commercial real estate, several homes and two yachts.
About_#4: They gave $10 million in 2013 to the University of Memphis, their alma mater.
Did You Know?: In 1998, Walton Laurie founded Columbia Performing Arts Centre, a performing arts school for children through high school in Columbia, Missouri.

About_#1: Georg Schaeffler and his mother, Maria-Elisabeth, own Schaeffler Group, one of the world's largest producers of ball bearings and machine components.
About_#2: In 2009, he joined his mother. She'd been running Schaeffler after the death of her husband, Wilhelm, who founded the firm with his brother in 1946.
About_#3: A year before, the company took over tire and auto parts giant Continental AG in a $15-billion, debt-financed deal.
About_#4: In the wake of the financial crisis, it seemed the high-wire act might fail. But as the auto market rebounded, Continental's share price soared.
Did You Know?: Georg used to practice business law in Dallas. Colleagues only learned of his wealthy background after he first appeared on the Forbes list in 2003.
In Their Own Words: A little bit of luck is also part of it [the success of the Continental AG takeover]. But as you know, fortune favors the brave.

About_#1: Yao Liangsong is the chairman of Guangzhou-headquartered Oppein Home Group, one of China's largest makers of kitchen appliances and home furniture.
About_#2: Yao set up Oppein in 1994, and has prospered amid a rise in home ownership and growth in the middle class.
About_#3: Yao is a 1986 graduate of Beihang University, where he received a degree in machinery manufacturing.
About_#4: His brother Yao Liangbo is a member of the board of directors at Oppein.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Jiangsu Normal University; EMBA, Nanjing University
About_#1: Zhong Huijuan chairs Chinese drugmaker Hansoh Pharmaceutical, which produces oncology, psychoactive, antidiabetic and other drugs.
About_#2: Zhong's husband, Sun Piaoyang, is also a pharmaceuticals billionaire and leads Shanghai-listed Jiangsu Hengrui Medicine.
About_#3: Zhong owns over three quarters of Hansoh Pharmaceutical with their daughter, Sun Yuan.
About_#4: Headquartered in the Chinese coastal city of Lianyungang, Hansoh went public on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in June 2019.

About_#1: From almonds & oranges in California's Central Valley to grapefruits in South Texas, Stewart & Lynda Resnick owe their billions to nature's bounties.
About_#2: Nearly half of all Americans purchase one of their products, including Halos mandarin oranges, POM Wonderful and Fiji Water.
About_#3: Stewart bought his first farmland parcel in California in 1978 as a hedge against inflation, thus beginning their agricultural empire.
About_#4: A gifted marketer, Lynda dropped out of college at 19 to start her own ad agency. Stewart hired her to work for his janitorial business.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Claremont McKenna College; Doctor of Jurisprudence, UC Hastings
About_#1: George Roberts cofounded private equity giant KKR with Henry Kravis; in October 2021 the two men gave up their co-CEO titles; both serve as executive co-chairs of the firm.
About_#2: Along with his cousin Henry Kravis and their mentor Jerome Kohlberg (d. 2015), the three led KKR through debt-financed hostile takeovers starting in the 1970s.
About_#3: The firm is known for the 1988 buyout of RJR Nabisco, chronicled in the book "Barbarians At The Gate."
About_#4: KKR went public on the New York Stock Exchange in 2010.
Did You Know?: Roberts and his wife have a passion for art; they sit on the boards of the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco and the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.
In Their Own Words: For any partnership to succeed you have to have certain shared values, making sure that people are aligned with their interests, their values are shared, and there are people you can trust. After all, people do business with people they like.

Education: Drop Out, Villanova University
About_#1: Michael Rubin is the founder and CEO of online sports merchandising retailer Fanatics.
About_#2: After dropping out of Villanova University, Rubin started GSI Commerce, which he sold to eBay for $2.4 billion in 2011.
About_#3: As part of the deal he paid $500 million for majority ownership of 3 assets eBay didn't want: Fanatics, Rue La La and ShopRunner.
About_#4: In 2018, flash-sales site Rue La La acquired rival Gilt Groupe. In 2019, mall operator Simon Property Group took a 50% stake in the combined company.
Did You Know?: At age 12 Rubin founded a ski-tuning shop, called Mike's Ski & Sport, in his parents' basement.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Northwestern University
About_#1: Patrick Ryan is CEO and founder of Chicago based Ryan Specialty Group, a wholesale brokerage and specialty insurance firm.
About_#2: His first brokerage, Ryan Insurance, merged with Combined Insurance in 1982 to form Aon, one of the largest insurance firms today.
About_#3: He left Aon in 2008 after 41 years as CEO, and founded wholesale brokerage and specialty insurance firm Ryan Specialty Group two years later.
About_#4: In July 2021, Ryan brought RSG public in July with an IPO that valued the company at $1.3 billion.
Did You Know?: Ryan owns 10% of the Chicago Bears, the very first football team in the NFL.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School
About_#1: Activist investor Chris Hohn founded The Children's Investment Fund, a London-based hedge fund, in 2003.
About_#2: The son of a Jamaican car mechanic, Hohn attended Southampton University in the U.K. and got an MBA at Harvard.
About_#3: He briefly worked in consulting and private equity, before joining Richard Perry's hedge fund, Perry Capital, in 1996.
About_#4: He opened Perry's first U.K. office and launched his own portfolio, then left to start Children's Investment Fund.
Did You Know?: Hohn paid his ex-wife, Jamie Cooper, over $500 million in a divorce settlement in 2014, reportedly the largest ever in U.K. history at the time.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Duke University
About_#1: Marijke Mars and her three sisters are heirs to the family's giant candy and pet food company, Mars, Incorporated.
About_#2: All four sisters inherited estimated stakes in the company of 8% apiece when their father, Forrest Mars Jr., died in 2016.
About_#3: Her great-grandfather Frank Mars founded the candy company in 1911.
About_#4: Mars serves on the company's board of directors.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Vassar College
About_#1: Pamela Mars is an heir to her family's candy and pet food fortune.
About_#2: She and her three sisters each inherited an estimated 8% stake in Mars, Incorporated when their father, Forrest Mars Jr., died in 2016.
About_#3: Mars has held various roles at the company since her first job there in 1986. Currently she is the family's ambassador to the Mars pet care division.
About_#4: Mars acquired animal hospital chain VCA in 2017 plus animal hospital chain AniCura and U.K. vet chain Linnaeus, both in 2018.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Columbia University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: Valerie Mars and her three sisters each inherited an estimated 8% stake in candymaker Mars when their father, Forrest Mars Jr., died in 2016.
About_#2: Her great-grandfather Frank Mars founded the company in 1911.
About_#3: She began working at Mars in 1992 and today is the company's vice president of corporate development.
About_#4: Mars also sits on the company's board of directors.

Education: Master of Business Administration, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: Victoria Mars and her three sisters are heirs to the family's giant candy and pet food company, Mars, Incorporated.
About_#2: She and her sisters all inherited their own estimated 8% stakes in the company when their father Forrest Mars Jr. died in 2016.
About_#3: Her great-grandfather Frank Mars founded the candy company in 1911.
About_#4: The $45 billion (sales) company is best known for making candy such as M&Ms, Milky Way and Skittles.
Did You Know?: Victoria Mars stepped down as chair of the Mars Incorporated board of directors in 2017 after serving in that role for three years.

Education: Master of Science, University of Karlsruhe
About_#1: Hasso Plattner and four colleagues left IBM in 1972 to launch German enterprise software company SAP, which went public in 1988.
About_#2: He has served as chairman of the SAP supervisory board since May 2003, when he stepped down as CEO.
About_#3: His nonprofit Hasso Plattner Institute focuses on research and teaching in IT systems engineering, offering degree programs and free online courses.
About_#4: The institute has established Design Thinking schools at the University of Potsdam, Stanford University and the University of Cape Town.
Did You Know?: The Plattner-funded Museum Barberini in Potsdam, which opened in 2017, features his extensive collection of impressionist and modernist works.

About_#1: Austrian builder and investor Georg Stumpf started the Stumpf Group in 1994 with a $35,000 loan from his father.
About_#2: Its biggest asset is Exyte, a high-tech EPC construction firm based in Stuttgart, Germany that specializes in semiconductors.
About_#3: He also built the Millennium Tower, the tallest building in Vienna, and sold it to German fund MCP in 2003.
About_#4: Stumpf grew up playing golf with Karl Ableidinger, who once played golf professionally on the European Tour and is now his vice chairman.
Did You Know?: His villa in Vienna has a movie theater, an indoor swimming pool and a garage that fits 40 cars.

Education: High School Graduate, High School
About_#1: Christy Walton married into what is now the richest family in the world: Walmart's Walton clan.
About_#2: She inherited a stake in the retailer when her husband, John Walton, died in a 2005 plane crash.
About_#3: Christy received about one sixth of her husband's estate; her son, Lukas Walton, got about one third.
About_#4: She was one of the biggest backers of the Lincoln Project, an anti-Trump super-PAC that ran ads in battleground states during the 2020 campaign.
Did You Know?: Her son, Lukas, battled cancer as a child. She reportedly claimed that an all-organic diet eliminated his tumor.

Education: Drop Out, University of Piacenza
About_#1: A living legend in the fashion world, Giorgio Armani brought softened, minimalist style to high-end menswear.
About_#2: Armani left medical school to fulfill his military service, then got a job as a buyer and window dresser for Milan department store La Rinascente.
About_#3: He left to design clothes for Nino Cerruti and eventually launched his own line in the mid-1970s with the help of his partner, Sergio Galeotti.
About_#4: His business surged after he was asked to design actor Richard Gere's wardrobe for the 1980 blockbuster film American Gigolo.
Did You Know?: Armani owns Italian basketball club Olimpia Milano and has designed uniforms for the Italian Olympic and Paralympic teams.
In Their Own Words: I'm never satisfied. In fact, as someone who is forever dissatisfied and obsessive in his search for perfection, I never give up until I've achieved the results I want.

About_#1: Gopikishan Damani is the younger brother of billionaire Radhakishan Damani, now considered India's retailing king.
About_#2: They control listed retailing giant Avenue Supermart, which owns D-Mart, a supermarket chain with 271 stores.
About_#3: D-Mart offers a range of value-for-money products from food to apparel.
About_#4: Damani, together with his billionaire brother Radhakishan, reportedly bought a house in south Mumbai in 2021 for more than $100 million.
Did You Know?: He became a stock broker in 1992.

Education: EMBA, Xiamen University
About_#1: Ding Shizhong is the chairman and CEO of Anta Sports, one of China's largest homegrown sportswear makers.
About_#2: Brands sold by Anta include Fila, Fila Kids, Descente and Kingkow.
About_#3: Ding is the younger brother of Anta Vice Chairman Ding Shijia, who is also a billionaire based on his stake in the company.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Denver
About_#1: Jim Kennedy is the chairman emeritus of privately-held communications, automotive and media company Cox Enterprises. He was chairman from 2008 to 2021.
About_#2: He served as served as Cox's CEO 1988 to 2008; under his leadership revenues rose from $1.8 billion to $21 billion.
About_#3: Kennedy's grandfather, James M. Cox, founded Cox Enterprises in 1898 when he purchased the Dayton Evening News.
About_#4: Kennedy's first job at the company was as a production assistant in the newspaper division in 1972.
Did You Know?: A noted philanthropist, Jim Kennedy and his wife Sarah focus on education, healthcare and sustainability.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Moscow Institute of Steel and Alloys
About_#1: Ukraine native German Khan cofounded Alfa Group and LetterOne (Luxembourg), with fellow billionaires Mikhail Fridman and Alexei Kuzmichev.
About_#2: The college pals have been partners since 1989, when they started commodities trader Alfa-Eco.
About_#3: He is a cofounder of Alfa Bank, the largest non-state owned bank in Russia, which was hit with U.S. sanctions in April.
About_#4: Alfa Group's Tyumen Oil company merged with BP's Russian assets in 2003 to form TNK-BP.
Did You Know?: Khan, who is an Israeli citizen, wanted to immigrate to Israel in the late 1980s, but friend Mikhail Fridman convinced him to start a business with him in Moscow.
In Their Own Words: In business, confrontation is always a prelude to further partnership.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Central South University
About_#1: Liang Wengen chairs Shanghai-listed construction equipment maker Sany Heavy Industry and owns more than 20% of the company.
About_#2: Sany's holding company was founded in Hunan Province in 1989 as a small welding materials factory.
About_#3: Liang's UK-educated son Liang Zaizhong is a board director at Sany Heavy Industry; he also chairs Sany Heavy Equipment International.

Education: Diploma, High School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Denver
About_#1: Blair Parry-Okeden inherited a 25% stake in Cox Enterprises in 2007 when her mother, Barbara Cox Anthony, passed away.
About_#2: Cox Enterprises is a $20.9 billion (sales) communications, automotive and media company based in Atlanta; it owns cable TV firm Cox Communications.
About_#3: Blair's brother, Jim Kennedy, is chairman emeritus of the company.
About_#4: Her grandfather, James M. Cox, founded the company in 1898 with the purchase of Dayton's Evening News newspaper.
Did You Know?: Blair Parry-Okeden grew up in Hawaii and now lives quietly in Australia. She has no role at the company.

About_#1: Tsai chairs Want Want China, one of the world's largest suppliers of Chinese-style snacks and drinks.
About_#2: He also invests in hotels, financial services and media, including China Times newspaper and China Television Co.
About_#3: At age 19 Tsai took over his father's food business and promptly came up with an idea for a new product: crackers made from rice flour.
About_#4: Sons Kevin and Wang-Chia, along with nephew Cheng Wen-Hsien, are members of Want Want's board of directors.
Did You Know?: Want Want is pronounced Wang Wang and means prosperity and fortune.

About_#1: The three Bajaj siblings are the children and heirs of the late Rahul Bajaj, who was chairman emeritus of the storied Bajaj Group until his death in February 2022.
About_#2: The group was founded by their great-grandfather Jamnalal Bajaj, who set up the group in 1926 and was a follower of Mahatma Gandhi.
About_#3: Today, the Bajaj Group is a conglomerate of 40 companies in sectors such as two-wheelers, financial services and electrical appliances.
About_#4: Rajiv Bajaj, the older brother, runs Bajaj Auto, while his younger brother Sanjiv is in charge of the financial services business. Their sister, Sunaina, is not involved in the business.

Education: Master of Science, University of Akron; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Paints tycoon Ashwin Dani is a nonexecutive director of $3.1 billion (revenue) Asian Paints, founded by his father and three others in 1942.
About_#2: Dani joined the company, now among Asia's biggest paint companies, in 1968. It gets 85% of its annual revenue from the domestic market.
About_#3: The company also offers home painting services and an interior design service.
About_#4: His son Malav sits on the company's board.
Did You Know?: In response to the Covid-19 pandemic, Asian Paints introduced hand sanitizers and surface disinfectants.

Source of Wealth: oil and gas, IT, lotteries, Self Made
Education: Diploma, Hahnemann Medical College
About_#1: Karel Komarek started his business in oil and gas in the Czech Republic during the 1990s, right after the Velvet Revolution.
About_#2: In 2010, he stopped doing business with his father and sister to run his own investment group.
About_#3: His KKCG now invests in entertainment, information technology, real estate and biomedicine.
About_#4: He formed the Sazka Group (later renamed Allwyn) in 2016, and it quickly became the largest lottery owner in Europe.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Claremont McKenna College; Master of Business Administration, Columbia Business School
About_#1: Henry Kravis and George Roberts, cofounders of private equity firm KKR, gave up their co-CEO titles in October 2021; both serve as executive co-chairs.
About_#2: Kravis cofounded KKR with his cousin, George Roberts, and Jerome Kohlberg (d. 2015) in 1976. Kohlberg left the firm in 1987.
About_#3: KKR has some 100 portfolio companies that together generate $244 billion in revenues, making it one of the five largest private equity firms in the world.
About_#4: Kravis and Roberts took KKR public on the New York Stock Exchange in 2010 and converted it into a corporation in 2018.
Did You Know?: His economist wife, Marie-Jos?e Kravis, is president of the board of trustees at New York's Museum of Modern Art.

About_#1: Frederick Paulsen inherited small drugmaker Ferring Pharmaceuticals, founded by his father in 1950.
About_#2: When he took over running the business in 1983, it generated $15 million in annual revenue.
About_#3: Today the biotech outfit, which makes infertility, obstetrics, urology, gastroenterology and endocrinology drugs, has estimated sales of $2.2 billion.
About_#4: Ferring employs more than 6,500 people and has subsidiaries in nearly 60 countries.
Did You Know?: Paulsen enjoys extreme adventure travel: he was the first person to cross the Bering Strait from Alaska to Russia in an ultralight aircraft.

About_#1: The four adult children of the late Brazilian banking tycoon Joseph Safra, who died in December 2020, inherited a bit less than half of his fortune.
About_#2: Jacob Safra, 45, is responsible for the Swiss bank J. Safra Sarasin, Safra National Bank of New York and the family's U.S. real estate.
About_#3: David Safra, 36, manages Banco Safra in Brazil and J. Safra Group's Brazilian real estate holdings.
About_#4: Alberto Safra, 41, left the board of Banco Safra in 2019; he is based in Sao Paulo, Brazil.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Chicago
About_#1: Nassef Sawiris is an investor and a scion of Egypt's wealthiest family. His most valuable asset is a nearly 6% stake in sportswear maker Adidas.
About_#2: In December 2020, he acquired a 5% stake in New York-listed firm Madison Square Garden Sports, owner of the NBA Knicks and the NHL Rangers teams.
About_#3: He runs OCI, one of the world's largest nitrogen fertilizer producers, with plants in Texas and Iowa; it trades on the Euronext Amsterdam exchange.
About_#4: Orascom Construction, an engineering and building firm, trades on the Cairo exchange and Nasdaq Dubai.

About_#1: Xu Shihui chairs Chinese snack and beverage maker Dali Foods Group.
About_#2: Xu started out in the cookie business and then ended up acquiring 120 food brands.
About_#3: Dali went public in November 2015 on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.
About_#4: Xu's daughter Xu Yangyang is a Dali vice president and executive director.
Did You Know?: Xu works seven days a week and hopes his work style inspires other managers. (He met Forbes Asia in his office in 2016 during a national holiday.)

About_#1: Rahel Blocher owes her fortune to EMS-Chemie, the Swiss polymer and chemical giant that her family has run for decades.
About_#2: She received her stake when her father, Christoph Blocher, sold his shares to his children in 2004 to take a seat on the Swiss federal council.
About_#3: Her sisters, Magdalena and Miriam, and brother Markus, are also billionaires.
About_#4: Unlike Magdalena, who is the company's longtime CEO, Rahel isn't actively involved in EMS-Chemie's operations.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign
About_#1: An engineer by trade, Shahid Khan bought auto parts supplier Flex-N-Gate from his former employer in 1980.
About_#2: His design for a one-piece truck bumper was the basis for his success; the company now has 69 plants worldwide and over 26,000 employees.
About_#3: Khan also owns the NFL's Jacksonville Jaguars, which he bought in 2012, and the UK's Fulham football club, purchased in 2013.
About_#4: He and his son, Tony, launched All Elite Wrestling, a professional wrestling entertainment company and a competitor to WWE, in 2019.
Did You Know?: Shahid Khan arrived in the United States from Pakistan at age 16 with just $500 in his pocket.
In Their Own Words: You have to take your lumps and face reality... There's always some good in something bad happening to you, and you look for that.

About_#1: Magdalena Martullo-Blocher owes her fortune to her stake in EMS-Chemie, the Swiss polymer and chemical manufacturing giant.
About_#2: She took the company's reins in 2004 when her father, Christoph Blocher, departed to take a seat on the Swiss federal council.
About_#3: He sold his shares to Magdalena and her three siblings, Rahel, Miriam and Markus, who are also billionaires.
About_#4: Before joining the EMS-Chemie board in 2001, she held management positions at Johnson & Johnson and Swiss beverage maker Rivella.

Education: LLB, Universite Paris X Nanterre
About_#1: Vincent Bolloré runs his family's conglomerate Bolloré Group, which was founded in 1822 as a paper manufacturer of cigarettes wrappers and bibles.
About_#2: After a quick stint at Edmond de Rothschild bank, Bolloré took control of the struggling group in 1981 and turned it into a global giant.
About_#3: The group, which is active in media, advertising, shipping, construction and logistics, owns a majority stake in telecom conglomerate Vivendi.
About_#4: In 2018, French officials reportedly launched an investigation into Vincent Bolloré's dealings for alleged corruption. His group denied involvement.
Did You Know?: Bolloré is reportedly close friends with former French President Nicolas Sarkozy, whom he's hosted on his yacht.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, The University of Texas at Austin; Master of Science, The University of Texas at Austin
About_#1: Jeffrey Hildebrand cofounded Hilcorp in 1990; he later bought out his partner for $500 million.
About_#2: In 2020 Hilcorp finalized the $5.6 billion acquisition of BP's assets in Alaska.
About_#3: He has built Hilcorp into America's biggest privately owned oil company (by production volumes).
About_#4: In 2015, Hildebrand gave each of his 1,400 employees a $100,000 bonus after they doubled the size of his company in five years.
Did You Know?: In Aspen, Colo. Hildebrand owns a 1,000-acre ranch that used to belong to singer John Denver.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Haverford College
About_#1: Michael Kim cofounded MBK Partners, the Seoul-based private equity firm that bears his initials and manages more than $26 billion in assets.
About_#2: His ING Insurance Korea, which went public in 2017, was the first company wholly owned by a private equity firm to list on the Korean exchange.
About_#3: In September 2015 his firm's $6.1 billion takeover of Tesco's Korean operation, Homeplus, marked the country's biggest private-equity deal to date.
About_#4: Kim was born in South Korea and was educated in the U.S. from preparatory school onward; he obtained U.S. citizenship along the way.
Did You Know?: Kim is married to Park Kyung-ah, daughter of the late Park Tae-joon, a former prime minister and founder of the steel giant Posco.
In Their Own Words: I always thought the success I've had is due to some talent, yes, hard work, yes, but it's also due to luck. Recognition of that is critical to giving you a sense of reality and it's from that recognition that you get humility.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Missouri; Doctor of Jurisprudence, University of Missouri
About_#1: Kinder chairs oil and gas pipeline giant Kinder Morgan, the largest U.S. energy infrastructure firm, which owns or operates 83,000 miles of pipeline.
About_#2: He cofounded Kinder Morgan in 1997 after stepping down as president of energy and commodities firm Enron Corp.
About_#3: Kinder stepped down as CEO of Kinder Morgan in June 2015.
About_#4: His Kinder Foundation funds education, urban green space and quality of life initiatives in Houston.

Education: Doctorate, Stanford University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, San Diego
About_#1: A former computer science professor at Columbia University, David Shaw is the founder of D.E. Shaw, which manages over $60 billion in assets.
About_#2: Known for its use of sophisticated mathematical modeling and algorithms, the quantitative hedge fund firm was founded in 1988.
About_#3: In 2002, Shaw created an executive committee to oversee the company, and has since stepped away from its day-to-day operations.
About_#4: Several former execs have started their own successful businesses, including Amazon founder Jeff Bezos and Two Sigma hedge fund's John Overdeck.

Education: Doctorate, Johns Hopkins University; Master of Science, Johns Hopkins University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: Nicknamed the Cable Cowboy, John Malone is known for his penchant for media deals and complicated corporate structures.
About_#2: From the 1970s to the 1990s, Malone built up cable TV firm TCI as right hand man to founder Bob Magness (d. 1996).
About_#3: Malone became the CEO of TCI in 1973 at 29 years old, then sold the firm to AT&T for more than $50 billion in 1999.
About_#4: His Liberty Media, which owns the Atlanta Braves baseball team, closed a $4.4 billion acquisition of auto-racing league Formula 1 in January 2017.
Did You Know?: The Connecticut native is the nation's biggest individual landowner, with over two million acres across seven states.

About_#1: Vicky Safra inherited her fortune from her late husband, Brazilian banker Joseph Safra, who died in December 2020.
About_#2: Joseph Safra was Brazil's richest man, with banks on three continents and the Gherkin tower in London.
About_#3: Joseph and Vicky's four adult children inherited a portion of Joseph's assets and share an estimated $7.1 billion fortune.
About_#4: A citizen of Greece, Vicky Safra has lived for many years in Switzerland.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Maryland, College Park
About_#1: Tim Sweeney is cofounder and CEO of Cary, North Carolina game developer Epic Games.
About_#2: The private company is the maker of Fortnite, one of the world's most popular games, with over 400 million players.
About_#3: Epic raised $2 billion in April 2022 from the Lego family office and Sony in a funding round that valued the company at $31.5 billion.
About_#4: Fortnite was removed from the App Store in 2020 when Epic added a direct payment system to keep Apple from collecting a portion of in-app purchases.
Did You Know?: Sweeney is an active land conservationist in North Carolina, where he has purchased about 60,000 acres of forest land to keep it from being developed.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Pace University
About_#1: Adenuga, Nigeria's second richest man, built his fortune in telecom and oil production.
About_#2: His mobile phone network, Globacom, is the third largest operator in Nigeria, with 55 million subscribers.
About_#3: His oil exploration outfit, Conoil Producing, operates 6 oil blocks in the Niger Delta.
About_#4: Adenuga got an MBA at Pace University in New York, supporting himself as a student by working as a taxi driver.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: A preacher's son from a poor background, Hobby Lobby founder David Green opened his first crafts shop in 1970 with a $600 loan.
About_#2: His empire has grown from a single 300-square-foot store in Oklahoma City to 970 locations, with $7.7 billion in sales.
About_#3: A devout Christian, he still serves as Hobby Lobby's CEO and goes to work six days a week.
About_#4: Stores are closed on Sundays and workers make a minimum of $18.50 an hour as of January 2022, well above the federal minimum wage.
Did You Know?: Green worked as a stock boy at a general store in high school, where he swept floors and unloaded boxes for 60 cents an hour.
In Their Own Words: I don't care if you're in business or out of business, God owns it... How do I separate it? Well, it's God's in church and it's mine here? You can't have a belief system on Sunday and not live it the other six days.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Virginia
About_#1: Hedge fund manager Paul Tudor Jones II is known for his macro trades, particularly his bets on interest rates and currencies.
About_#2: In 1980, he founded Tudor Investment Corporation, which now manages $13 billion in assets.
About_#3: Jones got his start at his dad's small business paper, the Memphis Daily News, where he wrote under the name Paul Eagle in high school and college.
About_#4: He cut his teeth trading cotton futures at the New York Cotton Exchange, under the tutelage of renowned cotton trader Eli Tullis.
Did You Know?: Jones, who was a boxing champion in college, took up the sport after he failed to score a single point in sixth grade basketball.

Education: Master of Science, Moscow State University; Drop Out, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Russia's most influential tech investor, Yuri Milner was an early backer of Facebook and Twitter through his venture fund, DST Global.
About_#2: Milner sold those stakes and later invested in Spotify and Airbnb.
About_#3: Milner also bet big on Chinese tech companies, including online retailers Alibaba and JD. Com, and mobile phone maker Xiaomi.
About_#4: He has Israeli citizenship.
Did You Know?: A former physicist, Milner is a cofounder of the Breakthrough Prize, which rewards top scientists with lucrative prizes and a glitzy awards ceremony.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, Los Angeles; Doctorate, University of California, Los Angeles; Master of Science, University of California, Los Angeles
About_#1: Henry Samueli is a cofounder of chipmaker Broadcom.
About_#2: Samueli started Broadcom with fellow billionaire Henry Nicholas in 1991 in a Redondo Beach, Calif. condominium.
About_#3: In 2016, Broadcom was acquired by Singapore-based chip firm Avago for $37 billion in cash and stock.
About_#4: Samueli and his wife bought the Anaheim Ducks hockey team for $70 million in 2005; it's now worth $360 million.
Did You Know?: Samueli is the son of Polish Holocaust survivors.
In Their Own Words: People in the industry said, 'You guys are crazy, this will never work.' We were trying to build these high performance radios and communication circuits out of very average technologies. But we saw that it could be done.

Education: Master of Science, University of British Columbia; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Witwatersrand; Medical Doctor, University of Witwatersrand
About_#1: Medical doctor Patrick Soon-Shiong invented the cancer drug Abraxane. It became a blockbuster thanks to its efficacy against pancreatic cancer.
About_#2: He sold his drug companies Abraxis in 2010 and American Pharmaceutical Partners in 2008 for a combined $9.1 billion.
About_#3: He took his cancer drug maker NantKwest public in 2015 and his biotech startup NantHealth public in 2016.
About_#4: He owns NantWorks, a network of health startups, and has stakes in media firm Tribune Publishing and the Los Angeles Lakers.
Did You Know?: Soon-Shiong graduated from high school at age 16 and became a doctor at 23.
In Their Own Words: My quest was and is to improve the quality of life through science. That is what drove me then, and that is what is driving me now.

Education: Master of Arts, University of Stockholm
About_#1: Antonia Ax:son Johnson is the fourth generation member of her family to own conglomerate Axel Johnson.
About_#2: Ax:son Johnson succeeded her father as head of the privately held, diversified trading company in 1982.
About_#3: She stepped down as chairman in March 2015 and handed the reins over to her daughter, Caroline Berg.
About_#4: She still has a seat on the board, and most of the ownership.
Did You Know?: Ax:son Johnson went to Radcliffe College in Cambridge, MA as an exchange student in the early 1960s.

About_#1: Michael Kadoorie chairs CLP Holdings, the publicly traded power company his family co-founded in 1901.
About_#2: CLP Holdings now serves 80% of Hong Kong's population.
About_#3: Kadoorie is also chairman of the Hongkong and Shanghai Hotels, the global luxury chain that includes the Peninsula Hotels.
About_#4: The company celebrated its 150th anniversary in 2016.

Education: National Taipei University of Technology
About_#1: Lin chaired Chang Chun Group--one of Asia's largest petrochemical companies, with plants in Taiwan, China and Southeast Asia--until the end of 2013.
About_#2: He cofounded the business in 1949 with classmates Tseng Shin-yi and M.K. Liao, with only $100. He's the only surviving member of the trio.
About_#3: The name "Chang Chun" in Chinese loosely means "long spring," and reflects the wish among the three that their bonds would endure.

About_#1: Niels Peter Louis-Hansen is the deputy chairman of Coloplast, a large Danish healthcare company.
About_#2: The company provides medical devices and services in the fields of colostomy, continence and urology; products include colostomy bags and catheters.
About_#3: Hansen owns one-fifth of the public company and is its largest shareholder.
About_#4: His late father, Aage Louis-Hansen, founded the business in 1957 and took it public in 1983.
Did You Know?: Louis-Hansen is the largest shareholder in a Danish blood testing company called ViroGates, which had its IPO in 2018.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Michigan State University
About_#1: Michigan native Reinhold Schmieding started Arthrex, an orthopedic surgical tools company, in 1981 in Munich, Germany.
About_#2: Arthrex is now headquartered in Naples, Florida and has developed over 13,000 products used in shoulder, hip and other orthopedic surgeries.
About_#3: Privately-held Arthrex has estimated revenues of $3.1 billion; Schmieding owns more than 90% of the company.
About_#4: Schmieding is the son of German immigrants who moved to the U.S. just before he was born. His father, a dentist, wanted him to be a doctor.
Did You Know?: The company logo, an "X" formed by a tiny arthroscope and a grasper, was originally sketched by Schmieding.
In Their Own Words: Our corporate mission, making people better, is founded on healthcare innovation, new job creation, employee well-being, and charitable giving.

About_#1: Wee Cho Yaw is chairman emeritus of United Overseas Bank, Singapore's third-largest bank by assets.
About_#2: UOB was cofounded by his father Wee Khiang Cheng in 1935 as United Chinese Bank.
About_#3: After stepping down as the bank's chairman in 2013, Wee retired as director in April 2018, a position he had held for six decades.
About_#4: Wee's oldest son Wee Ee Chong is UOB's CEO, while younger son Wee Ee Lim has a board seat.
Did You Know?: The family's property arm Kheng Leong owns, among much else, 45 apartments in the Nassim, a luxury condo, acquired for $290 million.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, University of Milan
About_#1: Starting in the late 1970s, Silvio Berlusconi built media group Fininvest into a national force, importing American shows like 'Baywatch' to Italy.
About_#2: He entered politics in the 1990s and was first elected prime minister of Italy in 1994. He was convicted of bribing a former senator in 2015.
About_#3: The three-time prime minister was convicted of tax fraud in 2014 and was initially banned from running for political office until 2019.
About_#4: An Italian court lifted the ban in May 2018, and Berlusconi won a seat in the European Parliament the following year.
Did You Know?: Berlusconi got his start as a singer in nightclubs and on cruise ships.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Babson College
About_#1: Arthur Blank and Bernie Marcus cofounded Home Depot in 1978 after being fired from their jobs at a regional hardware store.
About_#2: Blank retired as Home Depot's co-chairman in 2001 and bought the NFL's Atlanta Falcons for $545 million in 2002 (his stake's now worth $1.8 billion).
About_#3: He brought pro soccer to Atlanta with his Major League Soccer team Atlanta United FC, which started playing in March 2017.
About_#4: In August 2017, both of Blanks' teams moved into their new $1.5 billion home, Mercedes-Benz Stadium, which hosted the 2019 Super Bowl.
Did You Know?: While an undergraduate at Babson College in the early 1960s, he started a landscaping and laundry pick-up service to cover his expenses.
In Their Own Words: If someone is out in the desert walking around, they're going to be thirsty. You just have to ask them what they want to drink.

Education: Master of Philosophy, Nanjing University
About_#1: Qian Dongqi chairs Ecovacs, a supplier of robotic vacuum cleaners, window washers and air purifiers.
About_#2: Ecovacs went public in China in May 2018.
About_#3: His son and heir apparent David Qian is vice chairman.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Maryland
About_#1: Chris Reyes and his brother Jude co-chair Reyes Holdings, a $35 billion (sales) food and beverage distribution company.
About_#2: The company got its start when the two brothers and their father bought a small Schlitz beer distributor in South Carolina for $740,000 in 1976.
About_#3: Reyes is already the largest beer distributor in the U.S. and also owns two Coca-Cola bottlers and distributors.
About_#4: Its customers include Heineken, Lagunitas, McDonald's and Chick-fil-A.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Wofford College
About_#1: Together Jude Reyes and his brother Chris run Reyes Holdings, a $35 billion (sales) food and beverage distribution company.
About_#2: The company got its start when the two brothers and their father bought a small Schlitz beer distributor in South Carolina for $740,000 in 1976.
About_#3: Reyes is already the largest beer distributor in the U.S. and also owns two Coca-Cola bottlers and distributors.
About_#4: In May 2017, Reyes Holdings announced that its soda distribution business would be expanding into California and Nevada.
Did You Know?: Reyes Beverage Group distributes 151 million cases of beer each year.

Education: Master of Science, Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology
About_#1: Nik Storonsky cofounded and runs U.K.-based financial services firm Revolut, which was valued by private investors at $33 billion in July 2021.
About_#2: Revolut offers everything from currency exchange and surcharge-free ATMs to global transfer payments and budgeting.
About_#3: The company, one of Europe's top unicorns, says it has handled more than 350 million transactions for more than 10 million customers.
About_#4: Storonsky, who also holds Russian citizenship, got his start as a derivatives trader at Lehman Brothers, then Credit Suisse.
In Their Own Words: It's not convenient to offer tens of products and let people choose...I just want to click a button and know that the product I'm using is the best.

About_#1: Zhou Qunfei chairs Lens Technology, a smartphone screen supplier whose customers include Samsung, LG, Microsoft and Nokia.
About_#2: A migrant factory worker as a teenager, Zhou has gone on to become one of the world's richest self-made women.
About_#3: Her consumer electronics supplier also laminates display panels for Tesla.
About_#4: Zhou first took the plunge as an entrepreneur in 1993 when she set up a watch parts company with relatives in an apartment in Shenzhen.
Did You Know?: Growing up she helped her family raise pigs and ducks for food and additional money.

About_#1: Deng Weiming chairs CNGR Advanced Material, which makes components of lithium batteries, some of which are used in cars.
About_#2: Customers include battery production firm Contemporary Amperex Technology, LG Chem and electric carmaker Tesla.
About_#3: Deng started his own business in 1995 age 27; he founded CNGR in 2004.
About_#4: His wife Wu Xiaoge is a CNGR director and vice president.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Dickinson College; Master of Science, University of Wisconsin
About_#1: Judy Faulkner founded medical-record software provider, Epic Systems, in a Wisconsin basement in 1979; it's now the largest company of its kind in America.
About_#2: Faulkner, a computer programmer, is CEO of the $3.8 billion (2021 sales) company, of which she owns 47%.
About_#3: Epic supports the medical records of over 250 million patients and is used by top medical centers such as Johns Hopkins and Mayo Clinic.
About_#4: The company has never raised venture capital or made an acquisition, and develops all its software in-house.
Did You Know?: Faulkner started Epic, originally named Human Services Computing, with $70,000; she and two part-time assistants were the only employees.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Peking University; Master of Arts, University at Buffalo
About_#1: Robin Li is the CEO and cofounder of Baidu, China's top search engine and one of the world's most popular websites.
About_#2: Baidu is known in China as a part of BAT -- Baidu, Alibaba and Tencent -- the trio of companies that rank as the country's three largest.
About_#3: In 2016, Li was criticized for trying to buy Baidu's iQiyi video channel at a bargain price; he failed and iQiyi went public in 2018.

About_#1: Singapore-born Ka Yee (Carrie) Wong Perrodo inherited international oil company Perenco when her husband Hubert Perrodo died in 2006.
About_#2: Perenco is one of the world's largest family-owned oil companies, with operations in Gabon, Peru, Vietnam and elsewhere.
About_#3: Carrie's eldest son, Francois, chairs Perenco while her daughter, Nathalie, oversees the family's winery investments in Bordeaux.
Did You Know?: Carrie was a top model in the 1970s when she met her husband Hubert while he was traveling the world in search of oil and gas.

About_#1: Brothers David and Simon Reuben built a fortune in real estate and technology.
About_#2: In December 2016, they sold 49% of their data center business, GlobalSwitch, to a consortium of Chinese investors for nearly $3 billion.
About_#3: The brothers were born in Mumbai and raised in the U.K., where David started off trading metals and Simon imported carpets and bought real estate.
About_#4: Their firm Transworld, a metals trader, invested in Russia and Kazakhstan in the 1990s and was active in trading aluminum.
Did You Know?: David resides part time in Monaco and Florida; Simon also spends time in Monaco.

Education: Drop Out, Sir John Cass College, London
About_#1: Simon Reuben shares a real estate, technology and investments fortune with his brother David Reuben.
About_#2: In December 2016, they sold 49% of their data center business, GlobalSwitch, to a consortium of Chinese investors for nearly $3 billion.
About_#3: They sold a further 25% of the business in July 2018 for $2.7 billion to a consortium of Asian institutional and private investors.
About_#4: The brothers were born in Mumbai and raised in the U.K., where David started off trading metals and Simon imported carpets and bought real estate.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Konkuk University; Master of Science, Konkuk University
About_#1: Seo Jung-jin is cofounder of Celltrion, a biopharmaceutical firm that makes drugs to treat cancer, influenza and rheumatoid arthritis, among others.
About_#2: With the success of biosimilars in South Korea, his Celltrion has become a favorite among investors.
About_#3: In March 2021, Seo stepped down as chairman of the Celltrion group.
About_#4: Seo's eldest son Jin-seok now chairs Celltrion Inc. and Celltrion Pharm while his other son Joon-serk chairs Celltrion Healthcare.

Education: Master, Moscow State Law Academy
About_#1: Roman Abramovich, who owns stakes in Russian steel giant Evraz and nickel producer Norilsk Nickel, has been sanctioned by the U.K., EU, Canada, Australia and Switzerland.
About_#2: His Chelsea FC was sold for nearly $5 billion in May 2022 to a group led by American billionaire Todd Boehly; he won't get the proceeds.
About_#3: He sold a 73% stake in Russian oil firm Sibneft to state-owned gas titan Gazprom for $13 billion in 2005.
About_#4: He spent more than $1 billion in Russia's Far East Chukotka region, where he was governor (reportedly at Putin's behest) from 2000 to 2008.
Did You Know?: Abramovich was orphaned as a child and dropped out of college.

Education: Drop Out, University of Miami
About_#1: Micky Arison is chairman of the world's largest cruise ship operator, Carnival Corp.
About_#2: He spent 34 years as CEO of Carnival, helping grow its fleet from two ships to more than 100, before stepping down in June 2013.
About_#3: Born in Tel Aviv, he immigrated to the U.S. as a young child with his father, Ted Arison (d. 1999), who cofounded Carnival in 1972 with a single ship.
About_#4: When Carnival was founded, Arison dropped out of the University of Miami to become a sales rep for the cruise line.
Did You Know?: Carnival's very first ship, dubbed Mardi Gras, ran aground on its maiden voyage.

About_#1: Edythe Broad is an American art collector and philanthropist.
About_#2: She was married to billionaire businessman Eli Broad from 1954 until his death in April 2021.
About_#3: Known for their philanthropy, Edythe and Eli established two foundations that support medical research, public education and the visual and performing arts.
About_#4: The foundations, which recently celebrated 50 years of grant making, have pledged or given away over $4 billion in grants.

Education: Taipei University of Marine Technology
About_#1: Terry Gou is the founder of Hon Hai Precision, the world's largest electronics contract manufacturer, whose top customers include Apple.
About_#2: He stepped down as the firm's chairman in June 2019, after 45 years at the helm; he remains at the firm as a director.
About_#3: Better known by its trade name, Foxconn, Hon Hai employs roughly a million people.
About_#4: The company bought Japanese electronics maker Sharp and Nokia's mobile phone brand in 2016.
Did You Know?: Gou founded the business in 1974 with $7,500 and a belief that electronics products "would be an integral part of everyday life."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Beijing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics; Master of Business Administration, Tsinghua University
About_#1: Jiang Bin chairs Goertek, a supplier of acoustic components in China.
About_#2: Goertek donated $20 million to Jiang's alma mater Beihang University to promote research and cultivate talent in May 2016.
About_#3: Jiang's wife Hu Shuangmei and brother Jiang Long are members of the board of directors at Goertek.
About_#4: Jiang holds degrees from Tsinghua University and Beihang University in Beijing.

Education: Master of Science, Carnegie Mellon University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Indian Institute of Technology; Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business
About_#1: Vinod Khosla is the founder of Khosla Ventures, a Silicon Valley venture capital firm.
About_#2: His firm, Khosla Ventures, invests in experimental technologies such as biomedicine and robotics.
About_#3: The firm scored exits in 2020 and early 2021 with IPOs of Affirm and DoorDash and SPAC listings of QuantumScape and Opendoor.
About_#4: Khosla cofounded computer hardware firm Sun Microsystems in 1982 with Andy Bechtolsheim, Bill Joy and Scott McNealy.
Did You Know?: Khosla attempted to found a soymilk company in India before immigrating to the United States in the 1970s.
In Their Own Words: Good isn't good enough; great is barely acceptable.

Education: Drop Out, City University of New York City College; Diploma, High School
About_#1: Ralph Lauren is executive chairman and chief creative officer of Ralph Lauren, his all-American fashion empire. He controls 85% of the voting rights.
About_#2: Lauren started the business in 1967 in a tiny office at the Empire State building. His first breakthrough came when Neiman Marcus ordered 1,200 ties.
About_#3: He stepped down from his position as CEO in 2015; His son, David, is chief branding and innovation officer.
About_#4: Born in the Bronx to Jewish immigrants, Ralph Lifshitz, as he was then known, worked as a part-time stock boy at a department store as a teenager.
Did You Know?: The man who made American fashion cool once donated $10 million to help restore the original Star-Spangled Banner.
In Their Own Words: When I design a collection I have a heroine in mind. She is the star of my movie.

Education: Master of Science, Columbia University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Cornell University; Master of Business Administration, MIT Sloan School of Management
About_#1: In April 2022, Doug Leone announced he was stepping back as global leader of VC firm Sequoia, effective following his 65th birthday in July.
About_#2: Leone guided Sequoia into tech investments including Medallia, Rackspace, RingCentral, ServiceNow and Nubank.
About_#3: Leone inherited the reins from firm founder Don Valentine in the mid-1990s, alongside Michael Moritz.
About_#4: He started his tech career at Sun Microsystems, a firm cofounded by another billionaire venture capitalist, Vinod Khosla.
Did You Know?: When Leone moved to New York with his family at age 11, he barely spoke a word of English.
In Their Own Words: Take full responsibilities of failures, and share the successes.

About_#1: Lucia Borges Maggi is the cofounder the Andre Maggi Group, also known as Amaggi, one of Brazil's largest producers of soybeans and other commodities.
About_#2: She cofounded Amaggi in 1977 with her husband, Andre Maggi, who died in 2001; she took over as head of the group after his death.
About_#3: Today she serves as an advisory member on the board of directors of Amaggi.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Technical College in Flensburg
About_#1: Horst Julius Pudwill is the cofounder and chairman of Techtronic Industries, a Hong Kong-based manufacturer of power tools and floor-care products.
About_#2: The company produces the iconic vacuum cleaner Hoover, which many people use as a verb (such as in the phrase "hoover the carpet").
About_#3: Pudwill was an engineer at Volkswagen in Germany before transferring to Hong Kong in the mid-1970s to become a general manager.
About_#4: Pudwill cofounded Techtronic in 1985 with Roy Chi Ping Chung.

About_#1: Abdulsamad Rabiu is the founder of BUA Group, a Nigerian conglomerate active in cement production, sugar refining and real estate.
About_#2: In early January 2020, Rabiu merged his privately-owned Obu Cement company with listed firm Cement Co. of Northern Nigeria, which he controlled.
About_#3: The combined firm, called BUA Cement Plc, trades on the Nigerian stock exchange; Rabiu owns 98.5% of it.
About_#4: Rabiu, the son of a businessman, inherited land from his father.

About_#1: Farm boy turned seed-genetics savant Harry Stine has made a fortune licensing corn and soybean genetics to multinationals like Monsanto and Syngenta.
About_#2: Stine founded and runs Stine Seed; his current obsession is tinkering with seed genetics that allow for better yields or pesticide resistance.
