About_#3: The son of a hardscrabble farmer, Stine became fascinated with seeds when he was a boy growing up in Iowa.
About_#4: He started farming at just five years old, driving a tractor to pick up straw bales.
Did You Know?: Stine owns a small home down the road from the Stine Seeds headquarters in Adel, Iowa, and drives to work in his Ford F-150 pickup truck.
In Their Own Words: We're going to be able to double corn yields very easily. And apparently a lot of people working in the same industry can't see that...They think, 'How can this be? And furthermore, how can this little farm kid out here be doing this?'

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: Dennis Washington parlayed an early love of machinery into a diversified business group called Washington Companies.
About_#2: Washington owns a copper mining, marine transportation and heavy equipment businesses.
About_#3: After working for his uncle's construction business, he struck out on his own with a $30,000 loan to start Washington Construction.
About_#4: Montana's richest person, Washington also has an investment in Seaspan Corp., cofounded by son Kyle, which now has more than 130 container ships.
Did You Know?: Washington got polio at age 8 and spent 8 months in a hospital and rehab clinic. He then spent time in government housing and shined shoes for pocket money.
In Their Own Words: People always ask me for my secret. There isn't one. You've just got to keep a level head and stay away from greed. I just think in my life I relied on my instincts and had good intuition, and things just kind of fell into place.

About_#1: Low profile Hasmukh Chudgar founded generics maker Intas Pharmaceuticals in 1977.
About_#2: Chudgar has long handed over operations to his sons Nimish and Binish, who run the $2.3 billion (revenue) company.
About_#3: Intas operates 15 factories of which 10 are in India and the rest in Europe and Mexico.
About_#4: In 2019 Intas launched an affordable drug to treat breast cancer called Eleftha, which is similar to Roche's Herceptin.
Did You Know?: Chudgar's third son Urmish heads the company's biopharma business and is a haematologist-oncologist.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Bowdoin College
About_#1: Stanley Druckenmiller made it big as a hedge fund manager for 30 years. He now manages his money through a family office.
About_#2: Until 2000, he worked for George Soros. The duo famously bet against the British pound in 1992 and made massive profits.
About_#3: He shut down his $12 billion hedge fund Duquesne Capital Management in August 2010, returning funds to clients.
Did You Know?: At Bowdoin College, Druckenmiller reportedly ran a hot dog stand for extra cash and graduated magna cum laude.
In Their Own Words: I love being around kids. I couldn't figure out why all these 70-year-olds wanted to hang out with me when I was 27. Now I understand, and I'm trying to steal their energy.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Jonathan Gray started at asset manager Blackstone Group fresh out of college in 1992 and later rose to head the firm's vaunted real estate group.
About_#2: Under Gray, Blackstone's real estate division became one of its most valuable branches; it now manages $208 billion in investor capital.
About_#3: He orchestrated the $26 billion buyout of Hilton hotels in 2007 then took it public again in 2013; the IPO was then the biggest ever for a hotel firm.
About_#4: In February 2018, Gray was named the firm's COO and president; he's considered a potential successor to cofounder and CEO Steve Schwarzman.
Did You Know?: Gray's family owned a small auto parts manufacturer in Chicago named Blackstone Manufacturing -- no relation to Blackstone Group -- and sold it in the 1970s.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Sogang University
About_#1: Kwon Hyuk-bin founded Smilegate in 2002 and has built it into one of the most successful gaming companies in South Korea.
About_#2: Following a 2008 partnership with Chinese internet giant Tencent, it released its most popular title, CrossFire.
About_#3: Kwon's Smilegate Holdings is one of the largest shareholders of Korean mobile game developer SundayToz.
About_#4: Through his Smilegate Foundation, Kwon has established schools in China and Vietnam, providing education in IT, among other subjects.
Did You Know?: Kwon's first venture in business was an ill-fated educational software company that he founded but soon tanked.
In Their Own Words: We do not ask for profit share because I think it's my responsibility to return the favor that the society had offered me.

About_#1: An era ended in June 2018 when Lowy sold his Westfield Corp. to a Franco-Dutch group in a $16 billion deal that was Australia's largest takeover.
About_#2: A Holocaust survivor, Lowy opened his first shopping center in Sydney in 1959, launching what became one of the world's largest mall businesses.
About_#3: Today the Lowys' main business is running their family investment house, Lowy Family Group, with offices in New York, Los Angeles and Sydney.
About_#4: Sir Frank is a principal of the group, along with his three sons, David, Peter and Steven.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Northern Colorado; Master of Arts, Western Michigan University
About_#1: Ronda Stryker is a director of Stryker Corp., the medical equipment company founded by her grandfather, Homer Stryker (d. 1980).
About_#2: She owns about 6% of Stryker Corp. which she inherited from her parents; she is the only one of her siblings to serve on the board.
About_#3: In 2011, she and her husband gave $100 million to create the Homer Stryker medical school at Western Michigan University.
About_#4: In 2016 the couple pledged $20 million to the Harvard Medical School Department of Global Health and Social Medicine to support equitable health care.
Did You Know?: Stryker taught special education at Kalamazoo, Michigan public schools.
In Their Own Words: I believe that, in my lifetime, we can create a movement and affect real change in billions of people's lives around the world, particularly women and children who often bear the brunt of the lack of access to health care.

About_#1: Alejandro Baillères Gual and his five siblings are the heirs to the mining fortune built by their father Alberto Baillères, who died in February 2022.
About_#2: Alejandro, age 61, is the president of Grupo Bal, the vehicle through which the family owns stakes in an insurance firm, a pension fund company and more.
About_#3: Alejandro is also vice chairman of mining company Industrias Peñoles, known for its silver mines.
About_#4: Juan Pablo Baillères, the youngest brother, is in charge of the cattle and bullfight division of Grupo Bal.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Calcutta University
About_#1: Cement czar Benu Gopal Bangur gets his wealth from a majority stake in Shree Cement, one of India's most cost-efficient cement producers.
About_#2: Shree, which was started in 1979 in Jaipur, sells branded cement under the names of Shree Ultra Jung Rodhak, Bangur Cement and Rockstrong.
About_#3: Bangur hails from a storied business clan in Kolkata and got control of Shree Cement in the 1990s after a family split.
About_#4: Today the company is run by his son Hari Mohan Bangur and grandson Prashant.
Did You Know?: The Bangurs were among the top ten business families in India in the 1950s and 1960s.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, North Carolina State University; Doctorate, North Carolina State University; Master of Science, North Carolina State University
About_#1: James Goodnight cofounded the analytics software firm SAS in 1976 with John Sall, whom he met while a PhD student at North Carolina State University.
About_#2: Goodnight has been at the helm since the company's inception, when it developed software to analyze agricultural data.
About_#3: SAS products are used by more than 80,800 organizations around the world; 2021 revenues were $3.2 billion.
About_#4: Goodnight and Sall, who is also a billionaire, founded private school Cary Academy together and co-own a country club and a hotel.
Did You Know?: Goodnight considered taking SAS public in 1999 while the dot-com boom approached its peak, but resisted the urge and avoided the steep market drop.
In Their Own Words: Ninety-five percent of my assets drive out the gate every evening. It's my job to maintain a work environment that keeps those people coming back every morning.

About_#1: Alain Merieux is chairman of Institut Merieux, a medicine and public health conglomerate specializing in diagnostics, immunotherapy and nutrition.
About_#2: Alain's grandfather, Marcel Merieux, founded the institute in 1897.
About_#3: Alain founded BioMerieux, one of the firm's publicly traded arms, which specializes in diagnostic tests for infectious diseases such as tuberculosis.
About_#4: The firm's other publicly-traded subsidiary, Transgene, develops vaccines to combat infectious diseases and cancers.
Did You Know?: Alain's grandfather was a laboratory aide to Louis Pasteur.

About_#1: Enrique Razon Jr. chairs International Container Terminal Services (ICTSI), the country's leading ports operator.
About_#2: International Container also has subsidiaries in the Asia-Pacific, Eastern Europe, Africa, and the Americas.
About_#3: Razon's grandfather started the business with a port in Manila in 1916, which his father rebuilt after WWII. Razon grew the business globally.
About_#4: The crown jewel of his hospitality firm Bloomberry Resorts is the Solaire Resort and Casino in the Philippines.
Did You Know?: Razon left school when he was 17 years old to take a minimum-wage job at the family's cargo-loading business and worked his way through the ranks.
In Their Own Words: Always be prepared for crisis.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Columbia University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Cornell University
About_#1: Robert F. Smith founded private equity firm Vista Equity Partners in 2000. It focuses exclusively on investing in software companies.
About_#2: With $96 billion in assets, Vista is one of the best-performing private equity firms, posting annualized returns of 31% since inception.
About_#3: In October 2020, Smith entered into an agreement with the DOJ and IRS, agreeing to pay $139 million for his role in a tax evasion scheme.
About_#4: As a college student, Smith secured an internship at Bell Labs after calling the company every week for five months.
Did You Know?: Smith is the first African-American to sign the Giving Pledge, a commitment to contribute the majority of his wealth to philanthropic causes.
In Their Own Words: We are only bound by the limits of our own conviction. We can transcend the script of a pre-defined story, and pave the way for the future that we design. We just need to tap that power, that conviction, that determination within us.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Rice University; Master of Arts/Science, Rice University
About_#1: Brian Armstrong is the chief executive of Coinbase, the largest cryptocurrency exchange in the United States.
About_#2: A former Airbnb software engineer, Armstrong cofounded Coinbase in San Francisco in 2012 with former currency trader Fred Ehrsam.
About_#3: Coinbase went public in a direct offering on Nasdaq on April 14, 2021, briefly reaching a market capitalization of $100 billion.
About_#4: Armstrong owns about 19% of Coinbase's shares.
In Their Own Words: I wanted the world to have a global, open financial system that drove innovation and freedom.

About_#1: Dannine Avara and her three siblings inherited Enterprise Products Partners, the energy pipeline giant founded by their late father, Dan Duncan.
About_#2: Formerly the richest person in Houston, Duncan died in 2010 at age 77 of a brain hemorrhage.
About_#3: Duncan started Enterprise Products in 1968 with $10,000 and a truck; now it owns over 50,000 miles of natural gas, oil and petrochemical pipelines.
About_#4: Avara's sister Randa Duncan Williams is the only sibling on the board of the company.

About_#1: Telecoms magnate Patrick Drahi is the founder and owner of multinational Altice NV, which he took private in January 2021 at a $7.3 billion valuation.
About_#2: Drahi built Altice with more than 20 acquisitions of lagging cable and mobile operators and has expanded further with highly leveraged deals.
About_#3: In 2021, he spent approximately $4.2 billion to purchase an 18% stake in British telecom giant BT Group.
About_#4: He stormed the U.S. in 2015 by buying a 70% stake in cable operator Suddenlink for $9 billion and snapping up Cablevision for $17.7 billion.
Did You Know?: Drahi owns auction house Sotheby's, which he took private in 2019.

Education: Houston Community College
About_#1: Scott Duncan and his three older siblings each inherited a stake in their father Dan Duncan's pipeline firm, Enterprise Products Partners, in 2010.
About_#2: Founded in 1968, the company owns natural gas processing plants, oil and gas storage facilities and over 50,000 miles of oil and gas pipelines.
About_#3: While his sister Randa Williams serves as non-executive chairman of Enterprise Products, Duncan and his other two siblings are not actively involved.

Education: Master of Arts, University of Houston
About_#1: Milane Duncan Frantz's father, Dan Duncan, founded Houston-based pipeline giant Enterprise Products Partners in 1968 and took it public in 1998.
About_#2: Frantz and her three siblings inherited a stake in the company after their dad died in 2010; only Randa Duncan Williams is involved in the business.
About_#3: Enterprise Products Partners now owns over 50,000 miles of oil pipelines and the largest oil storage facility on the Gulf Coast.
About_#4: A board member of Houston's Hermann Park Conservancy, Frantz also serves as a director of the Duncan Family Foundation.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Williams College
About_#1: Andreas Halvorsen runs hedge fund Viking Global Investors.
About_#2: A former Tiger Cub who once traded equities at Julian Robertson's Tiger Management, he struck out on his own with Viking in 1999.
About_#3: The Connecticut-based firm now manages more than $25 billion in assets.
About_#4: After flagship Viking Global hedge fund lost 4% net of fees in 2016, Halvorsen parted with CIO Daniel Sundheim and returned $8 billion to investors.

About_#1: Law chairs the Singapore-based Park Hotel Group, which manages more than a dozen hotels across Asia.
About_#2: The group caters to the luxury market under the Grand Park and Park Hotel brands.
About_#3: His son, Allen, runs the business from Singapore. Allen is married to a granddaughter of Singapore billionaire banker Wee Cho Yaw.
About_#4: His daughter Wendy, a lawyer, is executive director of Park Capital Group and oversees the clan's real estate investment.

About_#1: Nicolas Puech is a fifth-generation descendant of Thierry Hermès, who founded one of Paris's most famous luxury fashion brands.
About_#2: He resigned from Hermès' supervisory board in August 2014 but still owns about 5% of the company; other family members together hold a majority stake.
About_#3: In September 2014, Hermès and luxury giant LVMH reached an agreement to distribute LVMH's 23% stake in Hermes to its shareholders.
About_#4: The agreement settled a four-year dispute launched when LVMH accumulated the stock without its rival's knowledge.
Did You Know?: Hermès started as a saddle manufacturer.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Magnitogorsk Mining and Metallurgical Institute
About_#1: Viktor Rashnikov is the majority owner of Magnitogorsk Iron & Steel Works (MMK).
About_#2: Rashnikov got his start as a mechanic at MMK back in 1967.
About_#3: He built his ownership in the company to nearly 100% by buying shares on the market.
About_#4: Rashnikov stepped down as CEO of MMK in 2011 after 14 years in the job. He was sanctioned by the EU and U.K. in March 2022.
Did You Know?: Rashnikov owns a 460-foot, $240 million (estimated value) yacht named "Ocean Victory."

Education: Medical Doctor, Perm Medical Institute
About_#1: Rybolovlev' built his fortune in Uralkali, Russia's largest producer of potassium fertilizers, during the 1990s privatization era.
About_#2: He sold his stake in Uralkali for $6.5 billion in 2010 and doesn't appear to have any business in Russia these days.
About_#3: He has spent roughly $1 billion on property in Europe, including Greek island Skorpios and $400 million Monaco penthouse La Belle Époque.
About_#4: After a nasty years-long divorce battle, Rybolovlev was ordered to pay his ex-wife $605 million. In Oct. 2015 they reached an undisclosed settlement.
Did You Know?: Rybolovlev bought Maison de L'Amitie, Donald Trump's Palm Beach oceanfront mansion, for $95 million in 2008. He sold it off by 2019.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Rice University; Doctor of Jurisprudence, University of Houston
About_#1: Randa Duncan Williams is non-executive chairman of Enterprise Products Partners, the pipeline giant her father Dan Duncan (d. 2010) founded in 1968.
About_#2: Williams is the only one of four siblings involved in running the family business; all four inherited equal stakes in the company.
About_#3: Enterprise Products owns over 50,000 miles of energy pipelines, natural gas processing plants and a large oil storage facility on the Gulf Coast.
About_#4: Williams joined the family business in 1994 and became president and CEO of Enterprise Products in 2001.
Did You Know?: With a law degree from the University of Houston, Williams practiced law for about 6 years beginning in 1988, handling toxic tort cases and property liability cases.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Nanjing Normal University
About_#1: Chen Jianhua chairs Hengli Group, one of China's largest petrochemical businesses.
About_#2: Chen's wife Fan Hongwei chairs the group's listed petrochemicals arm Hengli Petrochemical; she's also a billionaire.
About_#3: The couple restructured their shareholding in the group in 2022, so that Chen's stake became larger than Fan's.
About_#4: Chen's daughter is a director of family-controlled, China OTC-traded Suzhou Wujijang Tongli Lake Travel.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania
About_#1: John Grayken is the founder and owner of Lone Star Funds, a private equity firm based in Dallas, Texas, that focuses on real estate investments.
About_#2: Since 1995, Grakyen has raised 21 funds and drawn over $85 billion in committed capital.
About_#3: The assets Lone Star buys are managed by Hudson Advisors, a firm also based in Dallas that Grayken owns with over 900 employees.
About_#4: Grayken is from a suburb south of Boston, but he renounced his U.S. citizenship for tax purposes in the 1990s and took Irish citizenship.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Southern Methodist University
About_#1: Ray Lee Hunt is the wealthiest of legendary oil wildcatter H.L. Hunt's 15 children.
About_#2: He chairs Hunt Consolidated, an oil and gas, real estate and investing conglomerate.
About_#3: His Hunt Oil is one of the largest privately-held oil companies in the U.S.
About_#4: Hunt Oil was one of the first to land an exploration deal in Iraq's Kurdistan region after the fall of Saddam Hussein.
Did You Know?: His half-brothers, W. Herbert and Nelson Bunker Hunt (d. 2014), once tried to corner the silver market.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Master of Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
About_#1: Philippe Laffont runs Coatue Management, a hedge fund and venture capital investor that focuses on technology-themed investing.
About_#2: Laffont founded Coatue Management in 1999. He is a so-called Tiger Cub, having spent time working at Julian Robertson's Tiger Management hedge fund.
About_#3: Coatue Management has $60 billion in overall assets under management.
About_#4: Coatue has invested in Tik Tok-parent Bytedance, Snapchat parent Snap and music streaming service Spotify, among many other companies.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, Los Angeles; Doctorate, University of California, Los Angeles; Master of Science, University of California, Los Angeles
About_#1: Henry Nicholas III and business partner Henry Samueli cofounded fabless semiconductor firm Broadcom in 1991 in a Redondo Beach, Calif. condominium.
About_#2: In February 2016 Broadcom was acquired by Singapore-based chip firm Avago for $37 billion in cash and stock and renamed Broadcom Ltd.
About_#3: Nicholas resigned from Broadcom in 2003 when he was just 43, five years after taking the company public.
About_#4: He's now focused on passing a crime victims' rights bill known as Marsy's Law, named for his murdered sister, which is now law in 12 states.

About_#1: Axel Oberwelland is proprietor of the German candy company August Storck KG, whose brands include Werther's Original, Riesen and Toffifee.
About_#2: Oberwelland's great-grandfather August Storck founded the business in the Westphalia town of Werther in 1903.
About_#3: At the time, sweets typically were sold unpackaged and without branding. He packaged his individually and gave them snappy names.
About_#4: Today, Storck employs over 5,000 people, sells products in more than 100 countries and generates around $2 billion in estimated annual revenue.
Did You Know?: In 1992, Klaus Oberwelland established the Stork Foundation to preserve endangered stork populations.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Western Australia
About_#1: Cliff Obrecht is cofounder and chief operating officer of design software maker Canva, which was valued by private investors at $40 billion in September 2021.
About_#2: Canva was launched in 2013 by Obrecht, now-wife Melanie Perkins and Cameron Adams in Sydney, Australia, but was met by investor skepticism due to its location.
About_#3: Like Perkins, he owns an estimated 18% stake. The couple has pledged to transfer more than 80% of their stake to the Canva Foundation for charitable causes.
About_#4: Defying the doubts, Canva has attracted 60 million monthly users to its freemium software, with 500,000 teams from companies like Intel and Zoom paying for it.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University; Master of Science, Stanford University
About_#1: John Overdeck is the cofounder of Two Sigma, a quantitative investing powerhouse with $60 billion in assets under management.
About_#2: Two Sigma's largest business is a data-driven hedge fund that absorbs large amounts of information to predict the prices of securities.
About_#3: Two Sigma also runs a market-making business, owns a Bermuda reinsurance company, operates a venture capital arm, a private equity arm and invests in real estate.
About_#4: Overdeck has given $260 million through his charitable foundation, Overdeck Family Foundation, which supports education programs and research.

Education: Drop Out, University of Western Australia
About_#1: Melanie Perkins is cofounder and CEO of design software maker Canva, which was valued by private investors at $40 billion in September 2021.
About_#2: Canva was launched in 2013 by Perkins, now-husband Cliff Obrecht and Cameron Adams in Sydney, Australia, but was met by investor skepticism due to its location.
About_#3: Like Obrecht, she owns an estimated 18% stake. The couple has pledged to transfer more than 80% of their stake to the Canva Foundation for charitable causes.
About_#4: Defying the doubts, Canva has attracted 60 million monthly users to its freemium software, with 500,000 teams from companies like Intel and Zoom paying for it.
In Their Own Words: If the whole thing was about building wealth, that would be the most uninspiring thing I could possibly imagine.

About_#1: Ruan Hongliang is founder, chairman and general manager of Flat Glass Group, a specialized glass manufacturer.
About_#2: Founded in 1998, Flat Group is headquartered in the city of Jiaxing in China's Zhejiang Province.
About_#3: Flat Group supplies floating glass, solar photovoltaic glass, engineering glass, and constructs power stations.
About_#4: The company went public on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in November 2015.

Education: Ph.D, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Princeton University
About_#1: David Siegel is the cofounder of Two Sigma, a quantitative investing powerhouse that manages $60 billion.
About_#2: Two Sigma's largest business is a data-driven hedge fund that absorbs large amounts of information to predict the prices of securities.
About_#3: Two Sigma also runs a market-making business, owns a Bermuda reinsurance company, operates a venture capital arm, operates a private equity arm and invests in real estate.
About_#4: Born in the Bronx, Siegel is a computer fanatic who got a computer science Ph.D. from MIT and worked at hedge funds D.E. Shaw and Tudor Investments.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business; Bachelor of Science, Stanford University
About_#1: Vélez is cofounder and CEO of Nubank, a Sao-Paulo based digital bank that offers credit cards, checking accounts and life insurance.
About_#2: Founded in 2013, Nubank went public as Nu Holdings on the New York Stock Exchange in December 2021; it has 35 million customers in Brazil, Mexico and Colombia.
About_#3: Vélez started Nubank after seeing that five Brazilian banks controlled 80% of the market and charged high fees for basic financial products.
About_#4: Before Nubank, he did stints in investment banking at Morgan Stanley, private equity at General Atlantic and venture capital at Sequoia.

About_#1: Juergen Blickle and his brother Rainer preside over SEW-Eurodrive, a manufacturer specializing in drive-automation and power-transmission solutions.
About_#2: The company, acquired by their father, Ernst, in 1945, now employs more than 19,000 people and generates around $3.7 billion in annual revenue.
About_#3: Its motor, gear and electronic components power conveyors, lifts and other applications in contexts ranging from auto assembly to commercial baking.
About_#4: In the U.S., it operates a manufacturing plant in Lyman, South Carolina, and has five regional assembly centers and dozens of technical sales offices.
Did You Know?: Juergen owns 50% of the company and Rainer, 44.9%. Just over 5% is held by Rainer's charitable foundation.

About_#1: Cheng Xue is the vice chairman of soy sauce maker Foshan Haitian Flavoring of China.
About_#2: Cheng holds a 9% stake in the company, which was restructured from a collective company to a limited company in 1995.
About_#3: Fellow billionaire Pang Kang chairs Haitian.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, California State Polytechnical University; Master of Science, Harvard University; Master of Science, University of Minnesota
About_#1: Jack Dangermond founded Esri, the industry leader in GIS technology, a specialized software used for creating digital maps.
About_#2: He founded the company in 1969 with $1,100 in personal savings and is thought of as the godfather of digital mapping technology.
About_#3: Esri has about a 40% share of the global geographic information system market.
About_#4: Esri has pledged $1 billion worth of free GIS Software to all American K-12 schools.
Did You Know?: Dangermond and his wife Laura go to work together every morning.
In Their Own Words: We kept ownership of our company and grew to it be what it is today. It gives some sense of what American business can be. It can grow from nothing, with people's imaginations, into advanced technology that makes a difference.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Xihua University
About_#1: Jiang Weiping chairs Shenzhen-listed Tianqi Lithium Industries, which makes lithium products and chemicals.
About_#2: Jiang worked as a technician, administrator and sales engineer before starting the business in 1997.
About_#3: Tianqi Lithium raised $1.7 billion in a Hong Kong stock offering in July 2022.

About_#1: Takahisa Takahara is CEO of Tokyo-listed diaper maker Unicharm, which his late father Keiichiro founded in 1961.
About_#2: Unicharm makes Moony and MamyPoko brand diapers, sanitary napkins, face masks, alcohol-based wipes and other personal care goods.
About_#3: About 60% of Unicharm's $6.6 billion annual revenue comes from outside of Japan, mainly from other Asian countries.
About_#4: Takahisa's father Keiichiro died in October 2018.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Brown University; Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Stanford University
About_#1: Wall Street's hottest dealmaker, Orlando Bravo is the first Puerto Rican-born billionaire.
About_#2: Bravo's firm, Thoma Bravo, which focuses solely on software deals, was ranked as world's top buyout investor in a 2019 report.
About_#3: In 2008, Bravo and partner Carl Thoma split with healthcare-focused partner Brian Cressey and created Thoma Bravo, a software dedicated buyout shop.
About_#4: Bravo once ranked as a top 40 junior tennis player and roomed with eventual French Open winner Jim Courier at Nick Bollettieri's tennis academy.
In Their Own Words: The opportunities today are the biggest I've ever seen. Right now we are in a huge, exploding and changing industry.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Seoul National University
About_#1: Hong Ra-hee is the widow of Samsung Group Chairman Lee Kun-hee, who had long been South Korea's richest person before his death in October 2020.
About_#2: She was the director of the Samsung Museum of Art, known as Leeum, and the Ho-Am Art Museum before her resignation in 2017.
About_#3: Hong is an arts graduate of Seoul National University, and both museums contain collections from her father-in-law, Samsung founder Lee Byung-Chull.
About_#4: Her father was chairman of one of Korea's largest daily newspapers, JoongAng Ilbo, which is now run by her nephew.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Northeastern University
About_#1: Edward Johnson IV is the grandson of Edward Johnson II, who founded Fidelity Investments in 1946.
About_#2: He is the brother of current Fidelity CEO and Chairman Abigail Johnson.
About_#3: Johnson is the president of Pembroke Real Estate, which is owned by Fidelity's parent company FMR.
About_#4: He owns a 5.56% stake in FMR, according to company documents filed with the Utah Department of Insurance in 2000.

Education: Master of Science, University of Massachusetts
About_#1: Li Xiaohua is the vice chairman of Shenzhen-listed Yunnan Energy New Material, a supplier of paper packaging materials and polypropylene film.
About_#2: Clients include Panasonic, LG Chemical and Comtemporary Amperex Technology.
About_#3: Li graduated from the University of Massachusetts with a major in polymer materials in 1993.
About_#4: He worked for World-Pak Corp. in the U.S. after graduation until 1996.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Delhi University
About_#1: Sri Prakash Lohia made much of his fortune producing PET and other petrochemicals.
About_#2: In the 1970s he and his father moved from India to Indonesia, where they cofounded Indorama Corporation as a maker of spun yarn.
About_#3: It is now a petrochemicals powerhouse, making industrial products including fertilizers, polyolefins, textile raw materials and medical gloves.
About_#4: Lohia remains chairman but lives in London. His son Amit is vice chairman.
Did You Know?: Lohia's brother-in-law Lakshmi Mittal is a steel billionaire based in London.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University
About_#1: Bobby Murphy cofounded Snapchat, the social media app popular with American teens.
About_#2: Snapchat's 293 million daily users share disappearing messages or photos and videos with captions, masks and filters.
About_#3: Murphy, Snap's chief technology officer, built Snapchat with his Stanford University fraternity brother Evan Spiegel.
About_#4: Murphy and Spiegel jointly own about a quarter of Snap but have voting shares that give them control over the board.
Did You Know?: In February 2017, Murphy and Spiegel created a foundation for education and the arts. They plan to donate up to 13,000,000 Class A shares to the nonprofit by 2027.
In Their Own Words: We weren't cool. So we tried to build things to be cool.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Instituto Tecnológico Autónomo de México
About_#1: María Asunción Aramburuzabala is by far México's best known businesswoman. She serves on the board of beer giant Anheuser-Busch InBev.
About_#2: With her mother and sister, she inherited a stake in beer giant Grupo Modelo from her father. Modelo was sold to AB InBev in 2013 for $20 billion.
About_#3: She has served as CEO of investment firm Tresalia Capital since 1996, and has led investments in construction, telecommunications and the Internet.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Duke University; Master of Business Administration, Fuqua School of Business
About_#1: Melinda French Gates is one of the most powerful women in philanthropy, as co-chair of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation.
About_#2: In May 2021, Bill and Melinda Gates announced they were getting divorced but will still remain co-chairs of the foundation.
About_#3: Melinda became a billionaire on her own after Bill Gates transferred her $2.4 billion worth of stock in May 2021, according to filings.
About_#4: As part of the foundation's mission to help all people lead healthy, productive lives, she has devoted much of her work to women's and girls' rights.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University
About_#1: Bruce Kovner is chairman of CAM Capital, founded in 2012, which manages his personal investment and business portfolios.
About_#2: Kovner is the founder and chairman of Caxton Associates, a global macro hedge fund. He retired in 2011 after running it for three decades.
About_#3: Kovner obtained his B.A. degree in Government from Harvard University in 1966. He lived in Quincy House during his time there.
About_#4: A longtime backer of conservative think tank American Enterprise Institute, Kovner also supports the Met Opera, Lincoln Center, and Juilliard.
Did You Know?: Kovner once worked as a cab driver in New York City.
In Their Own Words: Fundamentalists who say they are not going to pay any attention to the charts are like a doctor who says he's not going to take a patient's temperature.

About_#1: Pham Nhat Vuong studied in Russia and started a popular instant noodle business in the Ukraine in the 1990s before moving back.
About_#2: Today, Pham chairs Vingroup, one of Vietnam's largest conglomerates with interests in real estate, retail and healthcare among others.
About_#3: He turned some investments into non-profit ventures, including some in healthcare, education and sports. He also built a center of contemporary art.
About_#4: The group's main units include automaker Vinfast, property developer Vinhomes and Vinsmart, which makes smartphones and other devices.
Did You Know?: In December 2020, Pham and his wife's VinFuture Foundation established the $4.5 million VinFuture Prize for science and technological innovation.
In Their Own Words: I don't care how much money I make. I want to build things that make life beautiful.

About_#1: Investor Michal Solowow got his start in the late 1980s with construction company Mitex, which he sold in 2002 to French investor Eiffage.
About_#2: Solowow then plowed the proceeds into the nascent Polish stock market.
About_#3: Over the past several years he has been taking his companies private, including building materials producers Barlinek and Cersanit.
About_#4: He took his last main listed asset, chemical group Synthos, private in 2018.
Did You Know?: A once avid race car driver, Solowow was a championship European rally racer.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Leonard N. Stern School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, New York University
About_#1: Leonard Stern joined his father Max's pet supply business in 1959. Seven years later he expanded into real estate, acquiring a New Jersey warehouse.
About_#2: His Hartz Mountain firm owns more than 260 real estate properties, mostly in the New Jersey area.
About_#3: Most of Hartz's portfolio is in warehouses, including properties in New Jersey, Atlanta, Baltimore and Charlotte, N.C.
About_#4: Stern sold the pet business for $350 million in 2000. He has also ventured into publishing, energy, capital management and carpet cleaning.
Did You Know?: Leonard's father Max Stern arrived in New York from Germany in 1926 with 5,000 canaries -- a friend's way to repay a loan.

About_#1: Israeli industrial titan Stef Wertheimer sold two companies in 2013 and 2014; he is now focused on creating peace between Israel and Palestine.
About_#2: He builds industrial parks, or "capitalist kibbutzes," in disadvantaged and predominantly Arab regions of Israel in order to promote job creation.
About_#3: He sold his metal-cutting company ISCAR to Berkshire Hathaway in 2 stages: 80% for $4 billion in 2006, and the remainder for $2.05 billion in 2013.
About_#4: He also founded jet-engine blade maker Blades Technology and sold his 51% stake in 2014 to jet engine maker Pratt & Whitney for an undisclosed amount.
Did You Know?: Wertheimer was honored with the Oslo Business for Peace Award in 2010.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Columbia University; Master of Business Administration, Columbia University
About_#1: Rocco Commisso is the founder and CEO of cable company Mediacom, based in Chester, New York.
About_#2: He previously worked as CFO at Cablevision Industries, which was acquired by Time Warner in 1995.
About_#3: Commisso bought Italian Serie A soccer team Fiorentina in June 2019 for a reported price of between $150 million and $200 million.
About_#4: Commisso immigrated to America from Italy in 1962 at age 12. His first job was playing the accordion during movie theater intermissions.
Did You Know?: Commisso was offered a tryout for the 1972 U.S. Olympic soccer team. He arrived out of shape and did not make the squad.
In Their Own Words: I'm not scared of anything. In the business world, it's like soccer. The game gets played over a long period of time. You've got time to make decisions.

Education: Drop Out, New York University
About_#1: Jack Dorsey is CEO of payments company Block (formerly called Square); he was CEO of Twitter from 2015 until November 2021. He stepped down from the board in May 2022.
About_#2: Dorsey cofounded Twitter in 2006 with Ev Williams, Biz Stone and Noah Glass, and was CEO until 2008. He returned in 2015.
About_#3: In April 2020, he promised to give away $1 billion - then 28% of his net worth - to Covid-19 relief and other causes, via gifts of his Square stock.
About_#4: Dorsey cofounded Square with Jim McKelvey in 2009, then took it public in 2015; it was renamed Block in December 2021.
In Their Own Words: The best thinking time is just walking.

Education: Chinese Academy of Social Sciences; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Hubei University of Technology
About_#1: Lin Li chairs investment firm Shenzhen Liye Group, whose interests include a stake in Ping An Insurance Group as well as in real estate.
About_#2: Lin's first job was at the Bank of China in Shenzhen; he later worked for another lender, the Agricultural Bank of China.
About_#3: Lin added to his income by investing in stocks. He quit banking in 1995 to set up Liye Group.
About_#4: Lin also chairs ChinaLin Securities, a Shenzhen-based business whose shares trade on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Southern California
About_#1: 'Star Wars' creator George Lucas has largely retired from filmmaking since he sold his Lucasfilm to Disney in 2012 for $4.1 billion in stock and cash.
About_#2: Lucas is now focused on philanthropy: his charitable family foundation has more than $1 billion in assets.
About_#3: Lucas attended junior college in his hometown of Modesto, California where his parents ran a stationary store, before attending USC.
About_#4: He founded Lucasfilm, his production company, in 1971 and built his fortune through his movies and their merchandise.
Did You Know?: Lucas worked as a production assistant on Francis Ford Coppola's 1968 film 'Finian's Rainbow.'

Education: Bachelor of Science, Stanford University
About_#1: Evan Spiegel, CEO of Snap, became a billionaire at the age of 25.
About_#2: Each day some 293 million people use Snapchat to send disappearing photos and videos.
About_#3: Spiegel launched the company with Bobby Murphy, a Stanford University fraternity brother, in 2011.
About_#4: Murphy and Spiegel jointly own about a quarter of Snap but have voting shares that give them control over the board.
Did You Know?: Spiegel quietly became a dual American-French citizen in 2018.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Fordham University
About_#1: Zhao Yan chairs Hong Kong-listed Bloomage Biotechnology, which makes hyaluronic acid, an ingredient used in anti-aging skin creams.
About_#2: Besides biotech businesses, Zhao has interests in real estate, finance and sports.
About_#3: She holds an undergraduate degree with a major in biology from East China Normal University and a MBA from Fordham University in New York.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Michigan State University
About_#1: Tom Gores oversees more than 40 companies with some $36 billion in assets through his Los Angeles-based private equity firm, Platinum Equity.
About_#2: The Gores family moved from Israel to Michigan when Tom was four. In his youth, he stocked shelves at his father's small grocery store in Flint.
About_#3: His brother, Alec, is also a private equity billionaire. Tom and Alec spent their 20s learning the buyout business together before splitting in 1995.
About_#4: In January 2020, Platinum closed on its largest fund to date, raising a higher-than-expected $10 billion from investors.
Did You Know?: A sports nut, Gores played football, basketball and baseball in high school and still coaches youth soccer and basketball teams.
In Their Own Words: If we are making progress--then I am patient. If we are not making progress, I am very impatient.

Education: Master, Columbia University; Law Degree, New York Law School
About_#1: Leo Koguan is founder and chairman of $12.3 billion (sales) IT provider SHI International, which his ex-wife Thai Lee, also a billionaire, runs as CEO.
About_#2: Probably best known as Elon Musk "fanboy," Koguan claims to be the biggest Tesla investor in the world, and Tesla shares now make up the bulk of his fortune.
About_#3: At the start of the pandemic market chaos, he sold most of his stock holdings, including shares of Baidu and Nvidia, to buy long-term Tesla call options.
About_#4: Born in Indonesia, Koguan received a master's degree from Columbia University and a law degree from New York Law School. A U.S. citizen, he now resides in Singapore.
In Their Own Words: The future is brighter than people think. Many good people are trying to improve the state of mankind. I am doing my part.

Education: Master of Science, Moscow Institute of Steel and Alloys
About_#1: With college friends Mikhail Fridman and German Khan, Alexei Kuzmichev cofounded Alfa Group, including Alfa Bank, and LetterOne.
About_#2: He and his partners sold their 25% in joint venture TNK-BP for $14 billion in 2013.
About_#3: Fridman, Khan and Kuzmichev were all sanctioned by the EU and U.K. in February and March 2022. Alfa Bank was sanctioned by US in April.
About_#4: Kuzmichev stepped down from LetterOne's board in March
Did You Know?: Kuzmichev studied at Moscow Institute of Steel and Alloys with Fridman and Khan.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stockholm School of Economics
About_#1: Fredrik Lundberg is CEO and chairman of L.E. Lundbergforetagen AB, founded by his father Lars in 1944 as a construction outfit.
About_#2: Fredrik took over management of the firm in 1981.
About_#3: Today it's a diversified holding company with investments in property management and other businesses.
About_#4: Daughters Louise and Katarina, also billionaires, both sit on the board and each own a 14% stake in the group.
Did You Know?: Lundberg moved his family to Switzerland in 1985 to avoid punitive taxes but later returned to Sweden.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Drury University
About_#1: John Morris is founder and CEO of $6.5 billion (sales) outdoor gear retailer Bass Pro Shops.
About_#2: Morris started the company in 1972 by selling fish tackle from the back of his father's liquor store in Springfield, Missouri.
About_#3: In 2017, he bought rival Cabela's for $5 billion, nearly doubling the size of Bass Pro Shops.
About_#4: His Bass Pro Group also owns the world's largest boat manufacturer by volume, White River Marine Group, which makes fishing and recreational boats.
Did You Know?: At 22 years old, Morris competed in the first national B.A.S.S. fishing tournament and came in 21st place.
In Their Own Words: We share a steadfast belief that the future of our industry, and the outdoor sports we all love, depends -- more than anything else -- on how we manage our natural resources.

About_#1: Real estate investor Ivar Tollefsen started his first company at age 14, Tollefsen Enterprises, which rented out DJ-services and event equipment.
About_#2: With the earnings from his disco business he began building a real estate empire, now called Fredensborg AS.
About_#3: Fredensborg owns 100,000 apartments across Europe and, in 2017, bought an Oslo building that used to house the U.S. embassy.
About_#4: Tollefsen has led several polar expeditions and has competed in the Dakar Rally.

About_#1: The Wilson brothers own a majority stake in Reece Group, Australia's biggest bathroom and plumbing supplies chain.
About_#2: Their Reece also provides HVAC-R (heating, ventilation, air conditioning and refrigeration) to commercial and residential customers.
About_#3: The company, which has more than 800 outlets across Australia, New Zealand and the U.S, celebrated its centennial in 2020.
About_#4: John has retired from the board, but retains a large stake with his brothers Alan and Bruce.
In Their Own Words: "We like to keep things a mystery."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Salisbury State University
About_#1: Steve Bisciotti worked in staffing for a year after college before starting Allegis Group in 1983 with his cousin, fellow billionaire Jim Davis.
About_#2: What started in a basement has evolved into the largest staffing firm in the U.S., with $12.3 billion in yearly revenue.
About_#3: Bisciotti also owns the NFL's Baltimore Ravens, worth $3.4 billion. The team most recently won a Super Bowl title in 2013.
About_#4: Bisciotti, who was raised by a single mother in Baltimore, went to college at nearby Salisbury State University.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, University of Mumbai; Master of Science, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Mahendra Choksi is the son of one of four cofounders of BSE-listed Asian Paints.
About_#2: Family patriarch Ashwin Choksi, under whom the fortune was previously listed, died in September 2018.
About_#3: Mahendra is the late Ashwin Choksi's brother. His son, Manish, is the company's nonexecutive vice chairman.
About_#4: The company, one of India's leading paint makers, is run by a professional CEO.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Tsinghua University
About_#1: Jian Jun is chairwoman of biomedical supplier Imeik Technology Development, which makes products like skin fillers and facial implant threads.
About_#2: IMEIK listed on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in September 2020, in an IPO that raised more than $530 million.
About_#3: Jian worked for the state-owned China National Cereals Oils and Foodstuffs Import and Export Corp. early in her career.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, National Taiwan University
About_#1: Barry Lam is chairman of Quanta Computer, one of world's largest manufacturers of notebook computers and other electronics.
About_#2: Quanta is also one of the top makers of Apple's smartwatches.
About_#3: A Shanghai native, he moved to Hong Kong after China's revolution in 1949; he later studied and made his home in Taiwan.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Christ Church, Oxford University; Master of Business Administration, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Wales native Michael Moritz got his start as a journalist at Time Magazine after emigrating to America in 1976.
About_#2: Moritz wrote an early biography of Steve Jobs and Apple, "The Little Kingdom," while Time's San Francisco bureau chief.
About_#3: After making the jump to venture capital firm Sequoia Capital, Moritz invested in companies such as Google, LinkedIn and PayPal.
About_#4: A diagnosis with a rare and undisclosed medical condition led Moritz to step back from a leadership role at Sequoia in 2012.
Did You Know?: Moritz was appointed a Knight Commander of the Order of the British Empire in 2013 for his philanthropic work.
In Their Own Words: Every time we invest in a little company, it's a battle against the odds.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Malaya
About_#1: For decades Teh Hong Piow chaired Malaysian banking behemoth Public Bank, which he started in 1966. Teh died in December 2022 at age 92.
About_#2: He officially retired from Public Bank as nonexecutive chairman in 2019 ands named chairman emeritus. Deputy chairman Lai Wan took over as nonexecutive chairman.
About_#3: In addition to Malaysia, the bank serves millions of customers across Cambodia, China, Hong Kong, Sri Lanka and Vietnam.
About_#4: Teh had substantial stakes in the bank as well as in the listed insurance business, LPI Capital.
Did You Know?: Teh started his career as a clerk with Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp.

About_#1: Gary Wang was a cryptocurrency billionaire until the empire he built with Sam Bankman-Fried imploded in November 2022.
About_#2: Wang cofounded crypto exchange FTX and helped grow it into a leading marketplace for buying and selling crypto derivatives.
About_#3: After users began withdrawing their investments from FTX at a rapid pace, Bankman-Fried filed for bankruptcy for FTX, FTX's U.S. operations and Alameda Research.
About_#4: An MIT grad, Wang worked at Google, building systems to aggregate prices across millions of flights, before linking up with Bankman-Fried to launch trading firm Alameda Research and FTX.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro
About_#1: Andre Esteves began his career as an intern at Brazilian investment bank Pactual and eventually acquired control of the bank.
About_#2: Esteves sold Pactual to Swiss banking giant UBS in 2006 for $3.1 billion, forming the Brazilian subsidiary UBS Pactual.
About_#3: In 2009 he engineered the sale of UBS Pactual to investment firm BTG and became chairman of the board and CEO of the new firm.
About_#4: He was accused of obstruction of justice for Brazil's largest corruption scandal, Operation Car Wash, and jailed for almost three weeks in 2015.
In Their Own Words: The more well-off entrepreneurs that Brazil has, the better off the country will be.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Josh Harris cofounded alternative investment firm Apollo Global Management in 1990 with fellow billionaires Leon Black and Marc Rowan.
About_#2: The trio met at investment bank Drexel Burnham Lambert, and struck out on their own after the troubled firm filed for bankruptcy.
About_#3: Harris announced in 2021 he was stepping out of its board and is no longer involved day to day with Apollo.
About_#4: Josh has a stake and is Managing Partner of the Philadelphia 76ers, which has more than quintupled in value since he bought it with a consortium for $290 million in 2011.
Did You Know?: He founded Harris Philanthropies, a nonprofit focused on supporting youth and sports, wellness and disease prevention, and other causes, in 2014.

Education: Chartered Accountant, The Institute of Chartered Accountants of India; B.Com, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Investor with a Midas touch, Rakesh Jhunjhunwala, who passed away in August 2022, was often referred to as India's Warren Buffett.
About_#2: Son of an income tax officer, Jhunjhunwala started dabbling in stocks while still in college.
About_#3: He began investing with $100 in 1985 when the Bombay Stock Exchange Index was at 150; it now trades over 50,000.
About_#4: The most valuable listed holding in his portfolio at the time of his death was watch and jewellery maker Titan, part of the Tata conglomerate.
Did You Know?: His privately owned stock trading firm Rare Enterprises, derives its name from the first two initials of his name and his wife Rekha's name.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Bucknell University; Master of Business Administration, Leonard N. Stern School of Business
About_#1: In 1978, Ken Langone made an early investment in Home Depot and became a cofounder with Arthur Blank and Bernard Marcus, now billionaires.
About_#2: The grandson of Italian immigrants, Langone dug ditches for the Long Island Expressway before he went to Bucknell University to study economics.
About_#3: After two years in the U.S. army, he made a name for himself on Wall Street, taking Ross Perot Sr.'s Electronic Data Systems public in 1968.
About_#4: Langone, who gave $200 million to NYU's hospital a decade ago, pledged $100 million to its School of Medicine in August 2018. School is tuition-free.
Did You Know?: He donated $10 million to NYU's part-time MBA program in 1999 and $200 million to the university's medical center in 2008, which was renamed NYU Langone Health.
In Their Own Words: Bernard Baruch said "I got rich by selling soon." I got rich by never selling.

About_#1: Most of Ludwig Merckle's wealth is from HeidelbergCement; he owns 27% after having sold nearly half the company following the 2008 financial crisis.
About_#2: Along with other members of his family, he owns Phoenix Pharma SE, a drug wholesaler that also operates a chain of retail pharmacies.
About_#3: After his father Alfred's death in 2009, Ludwig impressively turned around a tumbling family fortune mired in crisis and debt.
About_#4: To finance the rescue, he sold drug maker Ratiopharm and nearly had to sell Phoenix.
Did You Know?: Ludwig Merckle was named Family Entrepreneur of the Year in 2017 by PwC's INTES Family Business Academy.
In Their Own Words: I did not want to brood on the past, but to look ahead, to secure the family heritage.

About_#1: Sandra Ortega Mera is the daughter of Amancio Ortega, cofounder of clothing giant Inditex, known for its Zara retail chain.
About_#2: She inherited her fortune from her mother, Rosalia Mera, who cofounded Inditex; she died suddenly in 2013.
About_#3: Now the second-richest person in Spain after her father, Sandra holds roughly a 4.5% stake in Inditex, but she is not involved in the company.
About_#4: She devotes her time to Fundación Paideia, the nonprofit her mother started that supports vocational training for people with disabilities.
Did You Know?: She holds a psychology degree from the Universidad de Santiago.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Pennsylvania State University
About_#1: Terry Pegula made a fortune in oil and gas and has since turned it into a sports empire that includes the Buffalo Bills and Buffalo Sabres.
About_#2: His oil and gas outfit, East Resources, sold the bulk of its assets to Royal Dutch Shell for $4.7 billion in 2010.
About_#3: He bought the Sabres the next year for $189 million and in 2014 outbid groups led by Donald Trump and Bon Jovi to pick up the Bills for $1.4 billion.
About_#4: A former math major, Pegula switched to petroleum engineering on a scholarship and joined Getty Oil after graduation.
Did You Know?: His daughter, Jessica Pegula, is a professional tennis player.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Northwestern University
About_#1: Karen Pritzker is one of 11 billionaire Pritzker heirs. Her grandfather, A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), built industrial conglomerate Marmon and Hyatt hotels.
About_#2: She has invested in public companies like Apple, as well as hundreds of private biotech and medical device firms.
About_#3: In late 2021, Softbank-backed Pear Therapeutics went public after a $1.6 billion SPAC deal with Pritzker's Thimble Point Acquisition Corp.
About_#4: Pritzker and her late husband Michael Vlock donated to Yale, Teach for America and the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Miami University of Ohio
About_#1: Mitchell Rales and his brother Steven acquired a real estate investment trust in 1983 and merged it into the firm Danaher.
About_#2: Over the years they acquired more than three dozen companies and turned Danaher into an industrial firm with $29.45 billion in revenues.
About_#3: In July 2016, Danaher spun off its industrial technologies, measurement and petroleum businesses into Fortive Corporation.
About_#4: Mitchell Rales retired from his position at Fortive Corp. in 2021 but he is still chairman of Danaher's executive committee.
Did You Know?: Mitchell donated more than $1 billion in art to his Glenstone Museum in Potomac, Maryland. In 2018, the museum opened Pavilions, a 204,000 square feet extension.

About_#1: Wolfgang Reimann and three of his siblings and three of his siblings own 95% of Luxembourg-based investment firm JAB Holding Company s.à r.l (JAB).
About_#2: Upon the death of their father in 1984, Wolfgang and eight other heirs each inherited 11.1% of JAB; five of them subsequently divested their stakes.
About_#3: The brands associated with the Reimann fortune include Pret A Manger, Krispy Kreme donuts, Peet's Coffee and Panera Bread.
About_#4: Wolfgang is a descendant of chemist Ludwig Reimann, who, in 1828, joined with Johann Adam Benckiser and his namesake chemical company.
Did You Know?: In 2016, the Reimanns commissioned a study which revealed close ties between their family, its business and the Nazi regime during World War II.

About_#1: Matthias Reimann-Andersen and three of his siblings own 95% of Luxembourg-based investment firm JAB Holding Company s.à r.l (JAB).
About_#2: Upon the death of their father in 1984, Matthias and eight other heirs each inherited 11.1% of JAB; five of them subsequently divested their stakes.
About_#3: The brands associated with the Reimann fortune include Pret A Manger, Krispy Kreme donuts, Peet's Coffee and Panera Bread.
About_#4: Matthias is a descendant of chemist Ludwig Reimann, who, in 1828, joined with Johann Adam Benckiser and his namesake chemical company.
Did You Know?: In 2016, the Reimanns commissioned a study which revealed close ties between their family, its business and the Nazi regime during World War II.

About_#1: Stefan Reimann-Andersen and three of his siblings own 95% of Luxembourg-based investment firm JAB Holding Company s.à r.l (JAB).
About_#2: Upon the death of their father in 1984, Stefan and eight other heirs each inherited 11.1% of JAB; five of them subsequently divested their stakes.
About_#3: The brands associated with the Reimann fortune include Pret A Manger, Krispy Kreme donuts, Peet's Coffee and Panera Bread.
About_#4: Stefan is a descendant of chemist Ludwig Reimann, who, in 1828, joined with Johann Adam Benckiser and his namesake chemical company.
Did You Know?: In 2016, the Reimanns commissioned a study which revealed close ties between their family, its business and the Nazi regime during World War II.

About_#1: Renate Reimann-Hass and three of her siblings own 95% of Luxembourg-based investment firm JAB Holding Company s.à r.l (JAB).
About_#2: Upon the death of their father in 1984, Renate and eight other heirs each inherited 11.1% of JAB; five of them subsequently divested their stakes.
About_#3: The brands associated with the Reimann fortune include Pret A Manger, Krispy Kreme donuts, Peet's Coffee and Panera Bread.
About_#4: Renate is a descendant of chemist Ludwig Reimann, who, in 1828, joined with Johann Adam Benckiser and his namesake chemical company.
Did You Know?: In 2016, the Reimanns commissioned a study which revealed close ties between their family, its business and the Nazi regime during World War II.

About_#1: Ruan Liping chairs Shanghai Stock Exchange-listed power strip supplier Gongniu Group, which went public in February 2020.
About_#2: Ruan hails from China's eastern Zhejiang Province and graduated from Wuhan University with a major in engineering machinery major.
About_#3: Ruan cofounded Gongniu with his brother Ruan Xueping, who is vice chairman of the company and is also a billionaire.
About_#4: Ruan worked as a power strip salesman early in his career.

About_#1: Ruan Xueping is the vice chairman of Shanghai Stock Exchange-listed power strip supplier Gongniu Group.
About_#2: Ruan cofounded Gongniu with his elder brother Ruan Liping, who is now also a billionaire, in 1995.
About_#3: Gongniu went public in February 2020.
About_#4: Both brothers hold Hong Kong citizenship.

Education: Doctorate, Stanford University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, Berkeley
About_#1: Early Microsoft employee Charles Simonyi is the man behind some of the company's most successful software, including Word and Excel.
About_#2: The developer has a Ph.D. in computer science from Stanford, and worked on one of the first personal computers at Xerox.
About_#3: He joined Microsoft, then a fledgling firm, as employee No. 40 in 1981, and spent two decades in application development.
About_#4: A native of Hungary, he left Microsoft and in 2002 and founded Intentional Software, which develops platforms for productivity apps.
Did You Know?: Simonyi paid $60 million to jet to the International Space Station on a Russian rocket in 2007 and 2009, making him the only tourist to have visited space twice.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Santa Clara University
About_#1: Real estate mogul John A. Sobrato began selling homes in Palo Alto while he was still a student at Santa Clara University.
About_#2: He later worked with his mother to develop industrial properties, and founded his own real estate company in 1979.
About_#3: The Sobrato Organization owns over 7.5 million square feet of office space in Silicon Valley, with tenants like Netflix, plus about 6,700 apartments.
About_#4: Sobrato is chairman emeritus of his Cupertino-based firm, while his son, John M. Sobrato, serves as chairman of the board.
Did You Know?: Sobrato's mom started the family's real estate empire in the 1950s, when she sold her late husband's restaurant and bought property south of San Francisco.
In Their Own Words: If you are successful in a particular business, you have an obligation to share some of that success with the communities where you were able to succeed.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Central Missouri State University
About_#1: David Steward is the founder and chairman of IT provider World Wide Technology.
About_#2: In the early days, Steward sometimes went without a paycheck and once watched his car get repossessed from the office parking lot.
About_#3: Today he is majority owner of the $14.5 billion (sales) company, whose customers include Citi, Verizon and the federal government.
About_#4: He grew up in the segregated South with seven siblings; his father worked as a mechanic, janitor and trash collector.
Did You Know?: Steward's daughter was a producer of the 2016 movie Manchester by the Sea.

Education: Law Degree, University of West Bohemia
About_#1: Real estate mogul Radovan Vitek got his start during Slovakia's voucher privatization in the 1990s.
About_#2: He moved to the Czech Republic in 1997, where he took over a cooperative and turned the headquarters into a luxury hotel.
About_#3: His CPI Property Group owns 1 million square meters of lucrative real estate in Berlin, Germany.
About_#4: CPI also has property in Budapest, Croatia, the Cote d'Azure and Poland including shopping centers.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Ohio State University
About_#1: Les Wexner founded L Brands, a global retail empire that included Victoria's Secret and Bath & Body Works, and served as CEO for more than 5 decades.
About_#2: Wexner announced in 2020 that he would step down and sell a majority stake in Victoria's Secret for $525 million to a private equity firm.
About_#3: Wexner got his start in 1963, when he used a $5,000 loan from his aunt to open The Limited, which sold only fast-moving items like shirts and pants.
About_#4: His ex-confidant and financial manager Jeffrey Epstein was accused of sex trafficking; in mid 2019 Wexner said the late Epstein took funds from him.
Did You Know?: Wexner collects Picasso paintings and vintage Ferraris, and has a 300-foot yacht, appropriately named Limitless.
In Their Own Words: If you start painting yourself into a corner, life starts shutting down. There is always hopefully a next.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, U of Oldenburg
About_#1: Aloys Wobben, who founded wind turbine firm Enercon in the 1980s, died in mid 2021 at age 69, reportedly after a long illness
About_#2: Enercon focuses on supplying turbines for on-shore wind parks and is not active in the U.S. It's the second-biggest player in Europe behind Vestas.
About_#3: The company's big technological breakthrough came in 1992 with the launch of the first gear-less wind turbine.
About_#4: In contrast to some of its competitors, Enercon not only produces and sets up wind turbines but also offers service programs for its plants.
Did You Know?: In October 2012, Wobben, known as "Mr. Wind" in Germany, transferred his 100% stake in Enercon into a family trust.
In Their Own Words: Contributing to the preservation of creation, so that our planet remains habitable, is my mission.

Source of Wealth: real estate, private equity, Self Made
Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Michigan; Doctor of Jurisprudence, University of Michigan
About_#1: In 1968, Sam Zell started Equity Group Investments, which today invests in industries like energy, logistics and healthcare.
About_#2: The forefather of modern real estate investment trusts, Zell chairs five public companies, including one of the nation's largest residential REITs.
About_#3: His $39 billion sale of office REIT Equity Office to Blackstone just before the market crashed in 2007 was among the largest real estate deals ever.
About_#4: Around the same time, he led an $8.2 billion buyout of newspaper owner Tribune Company, which quickly went bankrupt.
Did You Know?: Zell's family escaped Poland by train hours before Hitler's army bombed the tracks that ran through their town. They reached the U.S. by way of Japan in 1941.
In Their Own Words: Never take yourself too seriously. Nobody laughs at me quicker than I do.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Grenoble University
About_#1: Bamford and his family own JCB, a construction equipment manufacturer with $2.9 billion in revenues.
About_#2: His father launched JCB in a garage in Uttoxeter, England, in 1945.
About_#3: JCB sells products in 150 countries. Customers include the U.S. military.
Did You Know?: The brand is so ingrained in British culture that a JCB is to a backhoe what a Kleenex is to a tissue.

About_#1: Rainer Blickle died in March 2021. Prior to his death, he and his brother Juergen presided over SEW-Eurodrive, a German auto parts manufacturer they inherited.
About_#2: The company, acquired by their father, Ernst, in 1945, employs more than 19,000 people and generates around $3.7 billion in annual revenue.
About_#3: Its motor, gear and electronic components power conveyors, lifts and other applications in contexts ranging from auto assembly to commercial baking.
About_#4: In the U.S., it operates a manufacturing plant in Lyman, S.C., and has five regional assembly centers and dozens of technical sales offices.
Did You Know?: Rainer owned 44.9% of the company and Juergen, 50%. Just over 5% is held by Rainer's charitable foundation.

About_#1: Clive Calder became a billionaire in 2002, when he sold his music company Zomba Group to German mass media corporation Bertlesmann for $2.7 billion.
About_#2: The crown jewel of his empire was Jive Records, the record label behind many of the first commercially successful hip hop artists.
About_#3: The South Africa native founded Zomba in London in 1975, then opened an office in New York City in 1978.
About_#4: Known for shunning the spotlight, Calder now lives in the Cayman Islands with his wife.
Did You Know?: Johannesburg native, Calder started out playing in a band at age 18 to support his mother and sister after his father's death.

Education: Doctorate, Free University of Amsterdam
About_#1: The bulk of Frits Goldschmeding's fortune comes from his 32% stake in staffing company Randstad Holding, with branches in 38 countries.
About_#2: The company paid more than $400 million in 2016 to acquire U.S.-based job hunting site Monster.com.
About_#3: Goldschmeding founded the business in 1960, calling it Uitzendbureau Amstelveen; he changed the name to Randstad four years later.
About_#4: He took the company public in 1990, then retired in 1998; he no longer has a management role at the company.
Did You Know?: In 2015, he started The Goldschmeding Foundation for People, Work and Economy, which promotes economic education.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Melbourne University
About_#1: Ananda Krishnan is a Harvard Business School grad and former oil trader.
About_#2: His holdings include stakes in telecom outfit Maxis, media firm Astro Malaysia Holdings and oilfield services-provider Bumi Armada.
About_#3: Krishnan's Indian telecom firm, Aircel, in which he had invested an estimated $7 billion, filed for bankruptcy protection in 2018.
Did You Know?: Krishnan divides his time between Malaysia and France.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Chicago
About_#1: Joe Mansueto started independent investment research firm Morningstar in 1984 with $80,000 in savings.
About_#2: Mansueto stepped down as CEO in 2017 after more than 30 years at the helm.
About_#3: He owns just under half of the publicly traded firm, which manages or advises on more than $200 billion in assets.
About_#4: In 2018, the Chicagoan paid $255 million for the iconic Wrigley Building and $106 million to buy the Belden-Stratford apartment building.
Did You Know?: Mansueto and his wife donated $35 million in 2016 to create an institute to study urban innovation at their alma mater, the University of Chicago.

About_#1: Odd Reitan is the sole owner of Reitangruppen, which is one of the largest chains of grocery stores in Norway.
About_#2: The son of single-store grocers, he opened his own shop in 1972 named AS Sjokkpris, or "Chocking price."
About_#3: Now his privately held Reitangruppen owns grocery and convenience stores throughout Scandinavia and the Baltic, and employs 38,000 people.
About_#4: Reitan's son, Ole Robert, is the Administrative director of grocery chain REMA 1000; son Magnus oversees Reitan Convenience.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Columbia Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Georgetown University
About_#1: Antony "Tony" Ressler cofounded private equity giant Apollo Global Management with brother-in-law and fellow billionaire Leon Black in 1990.
About_#2: Like Black, he had previously worked at Wall Street firm Drexel Burnham Lambert, where he was known for his role in the bond department.
About_#3: In 1997, he cofounded private equity firm Ares Management. He stepped down as CEO in December 2017 and became executive chairman.
About_#4: Ressler owns a minority stake in the Milwaukee Brewers baseball team and is the majority owner of the NBA's Atlanta Hawks.
Did You Know?: His sister, Debra, is married to fellow Apollo cofounder Leon Black.

Education: Ph.D, Massachusetts Institue of Technology; Master of Science, University of Rochester; Bachelor of Science, University of Science and Technology of China
About_#1: Tang Xiao'ou is the cofounder and executive director of artificial intelligence firm SenseTime.
About_#2: He is responsible for the company's research strategies as well as partnerships with universities and academic institutions.
About_#3: The company soared after its $740 million Hong Kong IPO in January 2022 despite being added to a U.S. investment blacklist in December.
About_#4: Tang continues to teach AI-related courses such as image processing at the Chinese University of Hong Kong.

About_#1: Tse Ping is a member of the billionaire Dhanin clan from Thailand and the guiding hand behind Hong Kong-listed Sino Biopharmaceutical.
About_#2: He stepped down as chairman of Sino Biopharmaceutical in 2015 and ceded the role to his daughter Theresa, while staying on as an executive director.
About_#3: Trapped in China during the turbulent Mao-era Cultural Revolution, Tse was shipped off to the countryside from the southern city of Shantou and lost the opportunity to attend college.

Education: Master of Science, Stanford University; Bachelor of Science, Tsinghua University; Master of Science, Tsinghua University
About_#1: Ken Xie is the cofounder and CEO of Fortinet, a cybersecurity firm that offers firewalls, cloud security and other services to businesses.
About_#2: The son of two Chinese academics, Xie's parents hoped that he would become a professor and sent him to Stanford University to study engineering.
About_#3: Xie became interested in entrepreneurship while at Stanford, founding his first company, a software firewall business named SIS, in 1993.
About_#4: He started another cybersecurity firm, NetScreen, three years later, before founding Fortinet in 2000.

Education: Drop Out, Texas Tech University; Drop Out, University of Houston
About_#1: Tilman Fertitta is the owner of the Houston Rockets. The NBA approved the $2.2 billion purchase by Fertitta in October 2017.
About_#2: Fertitta also owns the Golden Nugget Casinos and Landry's, a Texas-based restaurant and entertainment company.
About_#3: Landry's brands include Landry's Seafood House, Bubba Gump Shrimp Co. and Saltgrass Steak House.
About_#4: Fertitta took Landry's private in 2010 in a deal worth $1.4 billion.
Did You Know?: Fertitta first learned the food business at his father's seafood restaurant where he worked after school.

About_#1: Son of a rubber trader, Prajogo Pangestu got his start in the timber business in the late 1970s.
About_#2: His company Barito Pacific Timber went public in 1993 and changed its name to Barito Pacific after cutting back on its timber business in 2007.
About_#3: In 2007 Barito Pacific acquired 70% of petrochemicals firm Chandra Asri, which also trades on the Indonesia Stock Exchange.
About_#4: In 2011 Chandra Asri merged with Tri Polyta Indonesia and became the country's largest integrated petrochemicals producer. Thaioil acquired a 15% stake in Chandra Asri in July 2021.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Southern California
About_#1: Through his Majestic Realty, Los Angeles-based developer Edward Roski Jr. owns more than 87 million square feet of industrial real estate across the country.
About_#2: Majestic Realty is developing a 441-acre business park on the site of Pennsylvania's former Bethlehem Steel plant, with tenants including Crayola and Walmart.
About_#3: Roski's father founded Majestic Realty in 1948.
About_#4: Roski Jr. helped lead development of the Staples Center in downtown L.A., and is a minority owner of the L.A. Kings and the L.A. Lakers.
Did You Know?: Roski spent four years as a Marine Corps officer in Vietnam, earning two Purple Hearts.

About_#1: Teddy Sagi founded gambling software developer Playtech in 1999 and built it into a $700 million (sales) firm that trades on London's stock exchange.
About_#2: Sagi sold a 12% slice of Playtech for almost $400 million in 2016; he sold the rest for $88 million in November 2018.
About_#3: He has taken 4 companies public on London's AIM: Playtech, Market Tech, online payments processor SafeCharge and cybersecurity company Kape.
About_#4: Sagi took Market Tech (now Labtech London) private in July 2017; it owns a portfolio of London property including tourist hot spot Camden Market.
Did You Know?: Sagi plans to rejuvenate Camden Market by introducing technology and high-tech operations.
In Their Own Words: The way the world is going, people like to have engagement and entertainment. People want to connect with each other, to see each other.

About_#1: Thomas Straumann owns a 17% stake in the world's largest manufacturer of dental implants, publicly held Straumann Holding.
About_#2: Straumann's grandfather Reinhard founded the company in 1954 as an alloy research company that developed implants to treat bone fractures.
About_#3: Straumann's father Fritz met real success during the 1970s with the introduction of titanium dental implants.
About_#4: Straumann joined the company's board of directors in 1990 and shifted the firm's focus to dental products only.
Did You Know?: Straumann owns the luxurious Hotel Les Trois Roi in Basel, Switzerland.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Tatung University
About_#1: David Sun cofounded and helps run Kingston Technology, which makes storage and memory products, as COO from a cubicle on the sales floor.
About_#2: With longtime partner John Tu, Sun launched a computer memory business out of a garage and sold it to now defunct PC maker AST a few years later.
About_#3: The pair started Kingston by making surface-mount memory chips after losing most of their first fortune in the stock market.
About_#4: Sun and his wife, Diana, have a foundation that provides grants to education programs for under-served youth in the U.S. and Taiwan.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Technische Universität Darmstadt
About_#1: Kingston Technology CEO John Tu runs the firm, which makes storage and memory products, from a cubicle on sales floor.
About_#2: With longtime partner David Sun, Tu launched a computer memory business out of a garage and sold it to now defunct PC maker AST a few years later.
About_#3: After losing a fortune in the stock market in 1987, the pair started Kingston to manufacture surface-mount memory chips.
About_#4: Tu, a Chinese native who grew up in Taiwan, got an engineering degree in Germany and then immigrated to the U.S. in 1971.
Did You Know?: Tu met his business partner David Sun, who is 10 years his junior, at a basketball league.

About_#1: Erich Wesjohann is the chairman and namesake of Germany-based EW Group, the world's largest poultry breeding and genetics company.
About_#2: EW Group was founded in 1999, when Wesjohann and his brother Paul-Heinz decided to split up their family chicken company, originally dating to 1932.
About_#3: In 2020, EW Group pulled in total revenue of $3.3 billion. Two U.S. poultry breeders Aviagen and Hubbard make up key assets in EW Group's portfolio.
About_#4: The low-profile billionaire and his wife have transferred a portion of ownership in EW Group to other members of their family over the years.

Education: Ph.D, Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology
About_#1: Alexander Abramov is chairman of steel company Evraz, which is also his biggest holding.
About_#2: Abramov got his start as the head of a research lab before the collapse of the Soviet Union.
About_#3: In 1992, he founded a precursor to Evraz Holding and made a fortune exporting metals and coal from the Urals and Siberia.
