About_#4: After the 1998 Russian financial crisis, he bought up hobbled steel companies on the cheap, including two U.S. firms, Claymont Steel and Oregon Steel.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, Northwestern University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign
About_#1: Real estate tycoon Neil Bluhm is the owner of marquee Chicago properties like 900 North Michigan and the Ritz Carlton.
About_#2: Bluhm also owns several casinos in Pittsburgh, Philadelphia, Chicago and Schenectady, New York.
About_#3: After attending law school and working as an attorney in Chicago, he cofounded JMB Realty in 1970.
About_#4: Bluhm's online gaming outfit Rush Street Interactive went public in 2020 through a reverse merger with a blank check company.
Did You Know?: Bluhm has donated generously to Northwestern University, where he studied law, most recently pledging $45 million to Northwestern Medicine in February 2022.
In Their Own Words: Everybody in America came from some immigrant place, or else they're Native American. That's what made America great.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Southern California
About_#1: The little-known king of subprime car loans, Don Hankey presides over the $19 billion (assets) Hankey Group, a Los Angeles-based auto services empire.
About_#2: His Westlake Financial Services works with more than 30,000 car dealerships in all 50 states to provide car loans to people with bad, or no, credit.
About_#3: The Hankey Group also includes a real estate firm and a Toyota dealership, plus auto insurance, rental car and dealer software companies.
About_#4: As a teen Hankey worked as a lot boy, washing and polishing cars, and then as a salesman at his father's Los Angeles Ford dealership.
Did You Know?: The returns-obsessed Hankey has a strict rule for each of his businesses: achieve a 30% pretax return on equity and 20% revenue growth annually.
In Their Own Words: What I take pride in is having profitable companies.

About_#1: The four Kwee siblings control privately held Pontiac Land, which owns an array of luxury hotels and iconic office towers across the island-nation.
About_#2: Pontiac Land was founded by their Indonesian father Henry Kwee, a textile trader and real estate developer, who migrated to Singapore in 1958.
About_#3: In New York, the brothers own a majority stake in a luxury tower designed by French architect Jean Nouvel, located beside the Museum of Modern Art.
About_#4: In 2017, the brothers acquired the Cappella Hotel group from legendary luxury hotelier, Horst Schulze, for an undisclosed sum.
Did You Know?: In March 2018 they sold their 50% stake in the landmark Capitol Singapore project to erstwhile partner Perennial Real Estate Holdings for $380 million.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University
About_#1: Jane Lauder, granddaughter of cosmetics legend Est?e Lauder, is an executive vice president and chief data officer at Est?e Lauder.
About_#2: Lauder joined Est?e Lauder in 1996, a year after graduating from Stanford University. She previously managed the company's Clinique and Origins brands.
About_#3: Est?e Lauder, which her grandmother cofounded in 1946, now has over 20 brands and revenues of $17.7 billion.
About_#4: Jane Lauder has served on Est?e Lauder's board of directors since 2009.

About_#1: Gwendolyn Sontheim Meyer inherited an estimated 8% stake in food giant Cargill.
About_#2: The heiress spends most of her time on a farm in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif., training horses that compete in show jumping.
About_#3: Her great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, the son of a Scottish sea captain, founded Cargill in Conover, Iowa in 1865.
About_#4: The family still owns roughly 90% of Cargill, which did $165 billion in 2022 sales across food, agriculture, financial and industrial divisions.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Cambridge University
About_#1: A chartered accountant, John Reece joined chemicals conglomerate Ineos in 2000 as financial director, less than two years after its founding.
About_#2: Formerly a partner at PricewaterhouseCoopers, where he specialized in working with chemicals firms, Reece still sits on Ineos' board.
About_#3: The London-based conglomerate produces everything from synthetic oils and plastics to solvents used to make insulin and antibiotics.
About_#4: It's become one of the U.K. shale sector's largest players. Its 600 foot "Dragon Ships" were the first to transport U.S. shale gas into Europe.

About_#1: Eric Smidt is CEO of $6.5 billion (sales) Harbor Freight Tools, a home improvement retailer that has over 1,300 stores.
About_#2: Smidt was a teenager when he started Harbor Freight Tools with his father Allan in 1977. He earned enough credits at his job to graduate high school.
About_#3: In the beginning, Harbor Freight was a mail-order business that sold tools out of a small warehouse in North Hollywood.
About_#4: Smidt became president of the company in 1985 and CEO and sole owner in 1999.
Did You Know?: Smidt and his wife live in a 35-room Beverly Hills mansion called "the Knoll," whose previous residents include oilman Marvin Davis and country singer Kenny Rogers.

Education: Master of Science, Moscow State University of Railway Engineering
About_#1: Viktor Vekselberg, a Ukrainian-born aluminum baron, made his first million selling scrap copper from worn-out cables.
About_#2: He later bought several medium-size aluminum smelters and bauxite mines and united them into Sual Holding in 1996.
About_#3: Eleven years later, he merged it with billionaire Oleg Deripaska's Russian Aluminum to form UC Rusal. Both were sanctioned by the U.S. in April 2018.
About_#4: A partner of billionaires Mikhail Fridman and Len Blavatnik in oil company TNK-BP, he sold his stake in 2013 to state-owned Rosneft for $7 billion.
Did You Know?: Vekselberg owns a large art collection, including nine Faberge eggs he bought from the Forbes family for a reported $100 million.
In Their Own Words: For me, being rich means being responsible first and foremost. Money is hard to earn, but it is even harder to manage it correctly.

Education: High School Graduate, High School
About_#1: Ronald Wanek is the founder of America's largest home furniture manufacturer and retailer, Ashley Furniture.
About_#2: Wanek grew up poor on a dairy farm in Minnesota, where his grandfather and great uncle built furniture as a hobby.
About_#3: He started his first furniture manufacturing business, Arcadia Furniture, in 1970 with a loan from his father and money he got from selling his home.
About_#4: Six years later he bought retailer Ashley Furniture, which had been around since the 1940s.
Did You Know?: Wanek has donated millions to the Mayo Clinic to help improve treatment for a heart defect that affected his granddaughter at birth.
In Their Own Words: All of a sudden, one day you're the big guy in the industry. At first I didn't know if I liked being the big guy, because with this came a new responsibility.

About_#1: Rene Benko is the founder of Signa Holding, which manages more than $12 billion in real estate assets and is one of Europe's largest real estate and retail firms.
About_#2: As a high schooler, Benko worked as a local real estate developer's assistant and racked up so many absences from school that he couldn't graduate.
About_#3: At age 22, he founded the company that grew to become Signa; it now owns buildings in Germany, Austria, Switzerland and Italy.
About_#4: In 2018, Signa merged department store chains Karstadt and Galeria Kaufhaus in a joint venture with Hudson's Bay Company, then bought out its partner.
Did You Know?: Former Formula One world champion Niki Lauda, who died in 2019, was a significant shareholder of Signa.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Auburn University
About_#1: John Brown ran Stryker Corp., a medical device and software company, for 32 years before retiring as chairman in 2009.
About_#2: Stryker's revenues climbed from $17 million to $6.7 billion under Brown's leadership. He led the IPO of Stryker in 1979.
About_#3: Brown is chairman emeritus of Stryker's board and owns slightly more than 5% of the company.
About_#4: Stryker Corp. was founded by orthopedic surgeon Dr. Homer Stryker from Kalamazoo, Michigan in 1941, who made devices to help with procedures.
Did You Know?: Brown still walks 2 miles, 5 days a week, after an ankle injury forced him to give up running.

Education: Master, China Europe International Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Tongji University
About_#1: Chen Zhiping is the chairman and CEO of Smoore International, a supplier of vaping devices, and China's first vaping billionaire.
About_#2: Smoore International Holdings supplies components for vaping devices to Japan Tobacco, British American Tobacco and NJOY.
About_#3: Smoore International went public in July 2020, raising more than $900 million on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.
About_#4: Smoore cofounder Xiong Shaoming is also a billionaire.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Cambridge University
About_#1: Andrew Currie has been a director at chemicals giant Ineos since 1999, a year after the company was founded by fellow billionaire James Ratcliffe.
About_#2: The Cambridge University natural sciences grad started his career at BP Chemicals, spending 15 years in technical and managerial roles.
About_#3: He later became a director at Inspec Group, the former parent company of Ineos, until it was acquired by another chemical company in 1998.
About_#4: Ineos has become one of the U.K. shale sector's largest players. Its 600 foot "Dragon Ships" were the first to transport U.S. shale gas into Europe.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Middlebury College
About_#1: Jim Davis bought a small Boston shoemaker in 1972 and turned it into $4.4 billion (sales) New Balance.
About_#2: Davis is the chairman of New Balance, and his wife Anna, who joined the company in 1977, is the vice chairman.
About_#3: He and his family own an estimated 95% of the company, which is private.
About_#4: New Balance is known for its running shoes but also makes clothing and equipment for lacrosse and soccer.
Did You Know?: In 2015 New Balance moved into a $500 million development in Boston that also houses practice arenas for the Boston Bruins and the Celtics.

Education: Drop Out, John Carroll University
About_#1: Dolan, his wife Helen and 6 children own controlling stakes in AMC Networks and Madison Square Garden's entertainment and sports companies.
About_#2: Dolan sold Cablevision, the cable giant he launched in 1973 with 1,500 customers, to billionaire Patrick Drahi's Altice for $17.7 billion in 2016.
About_#3: After dropping out of John Carroll University, the Cleveland native got his start creating sports newsreels for TV stations from his home.
About_#4: He moved to New York in 1952, making industrial films before wiring lower Manhattan with cable and founding HBO's predecessor, which he sold in 1973.
Did You Know?: His brother, Larry Dolan, owns the Cleveland Indians baseball team.

Education: Associate in Arts/Science, SUNY Tech Alfred
About_#1: Tom Golisano founded payroll giant Paychex in 1971 with just $3,000 and a credit card.
About_#2: He served as CEO until 2004 and remains a director of the publicly-traded company.
About_#3: Born in Rochester, New York, to a macaroni salesman and a seamstress, Golisano ran for governor three times under the Independence Party of New York.
About_#4: In 2011, he sold the Buffalo Sabres to billionaire Terry Pegula for $189 million, after rejecting a higher bid that would have taken them out of town.
Did You Know?: Golisano is married to former tennis star Monica Seles.
In Their Own Words: I can't say that payroll is an interesting business in and of itself. But being able to deliver it to 100,000 companies in a timely fashion? Now that is interesting.

Education: Law Degree, Masaryk University
About_#1: Daniel Kretinsky runs and owns Energeticky a prumyslovy holding (EPH), the biggest energy group in Central Europe.
About_#2: EPH, which employs more than 25,000 people, distributes and supplies electricity as well as provides gas storage and transmission.
About_#3: During the 2020 market crash, he took the stock market by storm making bets on companies like Macy's, Foot Locker, Sainsbury and Royal Mail.
About_#4: Kretinsky also owns stakes in French newspaper Le Monde and German retail giant Metro AG.
Did You Know?: Kretinsky is co-owner of Sparta Prague, one of the biggest soccer clubs in the Czech Republic.

About_#1: Massimiliana Landini Aleotti and her three children inherited pharmaceutical giant Menarini from her late husband, Alberto Aleotti, in 2014.
About_#2: Alberto built Menarini into one of Italy's leading drug companies, with 16 manufacturing sites around the world and more than 17,000 employees.
About_#3: Alberto Aleotti began working at Menarini in 1964, and bought the company from its owners in the early 1990s.
About_#4: In 2011, Aleotti handed over the reins to his daughter Lucia, who became chairman, and his son Alberto Giovanni, who became vice chairman.

About_#1: Joe Lewis owns the Tavistock Group, with more than 200 assets across 13 countries.
About_#2: Through Tavistock, Lewis owns Premier League soccer team Tottenham and has a stake in U.K. pub operator Mitchells & Butlers.
About_#3: He has a variety of other investments, including luxury club resorts, restaurants, hotels and an Australian agriculture firm.
About_#4: Lewis continues to expand his vision for his Lake Nona development near Orlando, where Disney is moving 2,000 jobs and the high-tech Wave Hotel opened in late 2021.
Did You Know?: Born above a pub in London's East End, Lewis helped his family build a catering business. He sold it and became a currency trader.

About_#1: Li Chunan is a director at LONGi Green Technology Industry, one of China's largest suppliers of solar cells.
About_#2: LONGi is headquartered in the historical Chinese city of Xi'an.
About_#3: LONGi was founded in 2000.
About_#4: LONGi President Li Zhenguo is also a billionaire.

About_#1: Shigenobu Nagamori is founder, chairman and CEO of motor manufacturer Nidec.
About_#2: Nidec bills itself as the world's largest manufacturer of motors for hard-disk drives and optical drives.
About_#3: Nagamori has said publicly that his goal is to hit ¥10 trillion ($91 billion) in revenue by 2030, partly by focusing on motors for electric vehicles.
About_#4: In June 2020, the company appointed former Nissan Motor executive, Jun Seki, as president and COO.

About_#1: Kjell Inge Rokke owns nearly 67% of publicly traded Aker, a shipping and offshore drilling conglomerate.
About_#2: He got his start selling fish off a boat in Seattle before returning to Norway where he built a fleet and a reputation as a ruthless corporate raider.
About_#3: In 2016 Aker decreased its ties to the industry that made Rokke rich, selling a stake in fishing firm Havfisk to Leroy Seafood Group for $250 million
About_#4: Rokke commissioned a nearly-600-foot yacht in 2017 that will spend part of its time on environmental research missions in partnership with WWF Norway.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Qingdao University
About_#1: Chris Xu founded Shein in 2012 and has turned it into a fast-fashion phenomenon with Gen Z, selling trendy clothes in more than 150 countries.
About_#2: Backed by Sequoia China, it's one of the world's most popular shopping apps whose users love its low prices.
About_#3: The company raised money at a valuation of $100 billion in the first half of 2022; it subsequently fell back amid a global stock rout.
About_#4: In 2022, Shein opened its first U.S. distribution facility in Whitestown, Indiana.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Chinese Culture University; Ph.D, National Chengchi University; Master of Business Administration, National Taiwan University
About_#1: Yin leads Taiwan's Ruentex Group, which has interests in financial services and real estate.
About_#2: He also has stakes in Nan Shan Insurance.
About_#3: His grandfather founded the business and his wife chairs Ruentex Industries.
Did You Know?: In 2013 Yin donated $100 million to create the Tang Prize, an award modeled on the Nobel Prize.

About_#1: Middle East retail king M.A. Yusuff Ali presides over $8 billion (revenue) LuLu Group International, with 255 stores and shopping malls in the Gulf and elsewhere.
About_#2: Hailing from a village in Kerala state in south India, Yusuff Ali left for Abu Dhabi in 1973 to join his uncle's small distribution business.
About_#3: In April 2020, a member of Abu Dhabi's royal family reportedly acquired a 20% stake in LuLu for $1 billion.
About_#4: Yusuff Ali is reportedly planning to list the retail business in 2023.
Did You Know?: Yusuff Ali donated $6.8 million to fight the Covid-19 pandemic.He also built and donated a treatment center with 1,400 beds in Kerala.

About_#1: Coates is co-CEO of Bet365, one of the world's largest online gambling companies, along with her billionaire brother, John.
About_#2: Coates first trained as an accountant before taking over a number of her family's betting shops and then selling them to bookmaker Coral.
About_#3: Noting the success of online gambling businesses, Coates bought the domain Bet365.com in 2000 and launched the website in 2001.
About_#4: She owns around half of privately held Bet365, which facilitates more than $65 billion in bets a year.
Did You Know?: At university Coates studied the STEM field of Econometrics while working for her father crunching numbers in his betting shops.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Humboldt State University
About_#1: Fisher is executive chairman and co-chief investment officer of Fisher Investments, which he founded in 1979 with $250.
About_#2: The firm currently has more than $197 billion in assets under management.
About_#3: The author of 11 books, 6 of which are national best sellers, he now writes for USA Today, the Financial Times and several other publications.
About_#4: In the summer of 1964, a 13-year-old Fisher earned $1.20 an hour picking fruit, sawing and fertilizing in his native San Mateo County, California.
Did You Know?: Fisher wrote an investing column in Forbes magazine for more than 32 years, penning his last one in late 2016.

About_#1: Peter Grogg founded Switzerland-based biochemical company Bachem Holding AG in 1971 and served as CEO until 2002 and then chairman until 2012.
About_#2: Bachem develops and manufactures active pharmaceutical ingredients, including peptides, amino acid derivatives and other organic molecules.
About_#3: Grogg is the majority shareholder of Bachem Holding AG with 61.6 percent ownership.
About_#4: The majority of his ownership in Bachem Holding AG is held through his asset management firm Ingro Finanz AG.
Did You Know?: In 1971, Grogg bootstrapped Bachem with 50,000 Swiss Francs.

Education: Master of Science, University of Karlsruhe
About_#1: Dietmar Hopp left IBM with four colleagues in 1972 to launch German enterprise software company SAP (Systems, Applications, Products).
About_#2: He served as co-CEO from 1988, the year SAP went public, to 1998 and then as chairman of the supervisory board until 2003.
About_#3: In 1996, he transferred most of his SAP shares to a charitable foundation.
About_#4: That entity, Dietmar Hopp Stiftung, supports sports, medicine, education and social programs, and has distributed around $1 billion since its start.
Did You Know?: Hopp is the main financial backer of TSG 1899 Hoffenheim, a soccer club that plays in the First Bundesliga, the top division of Germany's league system.

About_#1: Sumet Jiaravanon has been executive chairman of Charoen Pokphand Group, Thailand's biggest conglomerate, since 1993.
About_#2: He is the the older brother of Thai billionaire Dhanin Chearavanont, senior chairman of CP Group.
About_#3: Sumet is listed separately from Dhanin based on his ownership of close to a 13% stake in the family's vast assets.
About_#4: He also chairs the family's Chinese arm Chia Tai Group.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Witwatersrand
About_#1: The bulk of Nathan "Natie" Kirsh's fortune comes from U.S.-based Jetro Holdings, which owns restaurant supply stores Jetro Cash and Carry and Restaurant Depot.
About_#2: Kirsh owns 70% of the company, which supplies wholesale goods to bodegas, small stores and restaurants in the United States.
About_#3: Kirsh made his first fortune in his native Swaziland, where he launched a corn milling business in 1958.
About_#4: He expanded into wholesale food distribution in apartheid South Africa, and then into supermarkets and commercial property development.
Did You Know?: Kirsh owns one of London's tallest skyscrapers, Tower 42, which is home to more than 50 international companies.
In Their Own Words: You can't take money with you. And if you can't do good things with it, you're a bloody fool.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Shanghai Jiaotong University; Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business
About_#1: Stanford grad Forrest Li founded and runs online gaming firm and e-commerce firm Sea, which also has interests in e-payments and financial services.
About_#2: Li entered the ranks of Singapore's richest, after listing Sea on the New York Stock Exchange in October 2017.
About_#3: Backed by Tencent, which now has a 20% stake, Sea's other investors include private equity firm General Atlantic and Robert Kuok's son Kuok Khoon Hua.
About_#4: In March 2022, Sea shut down its Indian e-commerce unit, citing market uncertainties.
Did You Know?: When a college tutor couldn't pronounce his Chinese name Xiaodong, Li adopted the name Forrest after watching the movie Forrest Gump.
In Their Own Words: We want to continually push the boundaries.

Education: Master of Business Administration, INSEAD
About_#1: Rudolf Maag's fortune stems from medical devices.
About_#2: Maag got an M.B.A. from Insead in 1973 and began working his way up the corporate ladder at pharmaceutical company Sandoz AG of Switzerland.
About_#3: He later moved to dental giant Straumann, where in 1990 he bought out the medical device division and later took it public as Stratec Medical.
About_#4: In 1999 he merged Stratec with Swiss medical device powerhouse Synthes and built up a 15% stake, which was later sold to Johnson & Johnson.
Did You Know?: Maag is the son of a butcher.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Tennessee Chattanooga
About_#1: Gary Rollins presides over Orkin, the biggest pest control company by revenues in North America.
About_#2: He ran the company with his brother, Randall Rollins, until Randall's death in 2020.
About_#3: Of the 19 subsidiaries under the Atlanta-headquartered Rollins Inc. umbrella, exterminator Orkin is the best known. Combined, the businesses have revenue of more than $2 billion.
About_#4: The company was founded by Rollins' father and uncle, who bought several local radio stations and named it Rollins Broadcasting. It went public in 1961.
Did You Know?: The name Orkin derives from Latvian immigrant Otto Orkin, a 14-year-old who in 1901 was selling poison door-to-door. Rollins bought Orkin in 1964 for $62 million.

About_#1: Uğur Şahin is CEO and cofounder of German biotech firm BioNTech, which partnered with Pfizer to produce the first Covid-19 vaccine approved in the US.
About_#2: Şahin led BioNTech to start on a vaccine for the coronavirus in early 2020; it partnered with Pfizer in March 2020 and got approval in December.
About_#3: Şahin, who was born in Turkey and grew up in Germany, owns about 17% of BioNTech, which went public on the Nasdaq in October 2019.
About_#4: In 2001 Şahin and his immunologist wife, Özlem Türeci, cofounded Ganymed Pharmaceuticals; Astellas Pharma acquired Ganymed in 2016 for $460 million.
Did You Know?: Şahin's parents worked in a Ford factory iin Germany; he was trained as a doctor and worked as a researcher and a professor.

Education: Drop Out, Fanshawe College
About_#1: Mark Scheinberg co-founded PokerStars with his father, Isai, and built it into the world's biggest online poker company.
About_#2: Scheinberg, who owned 75% of parent business Rational Group at the time, pocketed more than $3 billion from the sale.
About_#3: He helped launch PokerStars in 2001, at age 28, and benefited tremendously from the poker boom that soon swept the U.S. and the rest of world.
About_#4: Scheinberg has invested some of his proceeds from the sale in luxury hospitality assets through his real estate investment vehicle, Mohari.
Did You Know?: Born in Israel, Scheinberg moved to a Toronto suburb as a teen and worked in hospitality and traveled to Asia and South America after one year of college.

Education: Master of Arts, Zhongnan University of Economics and Law
About_#1: Shen Guojun owns stakes in mining company Yintai Resources, real estate business Metro Land, and retailer Intime, where he served as chairman.
About_#2: Shen worked in a state-run bank before he started his own business.
About_#3: Alibaba partnered with Shen to take Intime private in 2017 in a transaction worth over $2 billion.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Calgary
About_#1: Dennis "Chip" Wilson is the founder and former CEO of Lululemon, which he started with a single store in Vancouver in 2000.
About_#2: He took the athleisure company public in 2007 but resigned as chairman in 2013 and removed himself from the business completely in 2015.
About_#3: Although Wilson has no management role at Lululemon, he remains its biggest individual shareholder with an 8% stake.
About_#4: Wilson, his wife and five sons now operate a holding company called Hold It All, which invests in apparel, real estate and private equity.
Did You Know?: The son of a seamstress, Wilson's first retail venture was Westbeach Snowboard, which he started in 1979 to sell apparel for surfers, skaters and snowboarders.
In Their Own Words: There's been a movement toward comfort. Everyone has experienced that. It's really tough to go back to anything else.

About_#1: China restaurateur Zhang Yong is chairman of Sichuan hotpot chain Haidilao, which went public in September 2018.
About_#2: Haidilao now has $3.8 billion in sales from 1,300 restaurants, mostly in China but also in the U.S., Japan, South Korea and Singapore.
About_#3: Haidilao is renowned for its spicy dishes and attentive customer service, including offering free manicures for waiting customers.
About_#4: Having never finished high school, the entrepreneur says he didn't even know how to prepare the typical Sichuan hotpot when he started.
Did You Know?: Haidilao means deep-sea fishing, or literally "scooping the bottom of the ocean."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Bard College
About_#1: James Cox Chambers inherited an estimated 17% stake in communications, media and automotive conglomerate Cox Enterprises from his mother Anne Cox Chambers.
About_#2: His grandfather, James M. Cox, founded what became Cox Enterprises in 1898.
About_#3: Both his sisters, Katharine Rayner and Margaretta Taylor, also inherited an estimated 17% stake each in Cox Enterprises.
About_#4: Neither James nor his sisters or mother have ever had an active role in the company.
Did You Know?: James Chambers is a Bard College trustee and alum.

About_#1: Jaran Chiaravanont is the eldest of four brothers of the clan behind Thai conglomerate Charoen Pokphand Group.
About_#2: Jaran, who started working in the family's livestock feeds business in the 1950s, used to manage the Charoen Pokphand shop.
About_#3: Jaran is listed separately from his younger billionaire sibling Dhanin Chearavanont based on his 12.76% stake in the family's vast assets.

About_#1: India's cola king, Ravi Jaipuria, presides over RJ Corp. which is into everything from beverages and fast food to healthcare and education.
About_#2: His listed flagship Varun Beverages is one of PepsiCo's biggest bottlers outside the U.S.
About_#3: The youngest of three brothers, Jaipuria studied in the U.S. and returned home in 1985 to join the family business as a bottler for Coca-Cola.
About_#4: After a family division in 1987, in which he got one bottling plant as his share, he switched to PepsiCo.
Did You Know?: Varun Beverages is named after his son and Devyani International after his daughter.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, University of Oklahoma
About_#1: When Koon Poh Keong returned home to Malaysia from the U.S. after graduation, he found no jobs on offer and Malaysia was in a recession.
About_#2: Poh Keong started his company by rallying his four brothers, who pooled $50,000 and began an aluminum-extruding company.
About_#3: Poh Keong is group CEO of aluminum company Press Metal while his brother Poh Ming is the executive vice chairman.
About_#4: He founded the company with his brothers by renting a factory in Puchong, Selangor, a state on the west coast of Peninsular Malaysia.

About_#1: Li Liangbin chairs Jiangxi Ganfeng Lithium, a supplier of lithium chloride and other lithium products.
About_#2: Ganfeng is headquartered in China's Jiangxi Province.
About_#3: In 2000, Li bought the factory which became the predecessor business of Ganfeng.
About_#4: Li received a Bauhinia Cup Technology Innovation Award from Hong Kong Polytechnic University in 2013.

About_#1: Liang Feng is a co-founder and the chairman of Shanghai Putailai New Energy Technology, a supplier to the lithium-ion battery industry.
About_#2: Putailai's clients include Samsung and LG.
About_#3: Liang holds an undergraduate degree in automation from South China University of Technology.
About_#4: He also holds a master's degree in economics from Zhejiang University.

About_#1: Wolfgang Marguerre founded Octapharma in Switzerland in 1983 and turned it into one of the world's largest manufacturers of blood plasma products.
About_#2: Positioned in a lucrative market, Octapharma has production plants in six countries, over 7,500 employees and annual revenue of around $2.7 billion.
About_#3: In the U.S., which is the most profitable blood plasma market, the company operates more than 70 donation centers.
About_#4: Octapharma is a leading corporate sponsor of Save One Life, an international nonprofit that supports children and adults with blood disorders.
Did You Know?: Octa is taken from the Greek word for eight, the factor deficient in people with hemophilia A.
In Their Own Words: We must never allow ourselves to become complacent, or to think that we have achieved "enough."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Sarah Lawrence college
About_#1: Katharine Rayner inherited an estimated 17% stake in media and automotive conglomerate Cox Enterprises from her mother, Anne Cox Chambers.
About_#2: Cox Enterprises, a private communications, media and automotive conglomerate started by Rayner's grandfather, has $20.9 billion in revenues.
About_#3: Her siblings, James Chambers and Margaretta Taylor, also inherited an estimated 17% stake each in Cox Enterprises.
About_#4: Neither Rayner nor her siblings or mother have ever had an active role in the company.
Did You Know?: Rayner lives in East Hampton, N.Y. She is known to be an avid gardener.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Tuck School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, Berkeley
About_#1: Carlos Rodriguez-Pastor took over leadership of Banco Internacional del Peru when his father died and has invested its profits in other businesses.
About_#2: Pastor owns the majority of the publicly traded company Intercorp Financial Services.
About_#3: He also owns companies working in the retail, real estate, and education industry in Peru.
About_#4: Rodriguez-Pastor founded InRetail in Panama in 2011, a holding company that owns supermarkets, malls and drugstores.
Did You Know?: Rodriguez-Pastor and his family fled to California from Peru in 1968 after a political coup in his native country.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Finch College
About_#1: Margaretta Taylor inherited an estimated 17% stake in communications, media and automotive conglomerate Cox Enterprises from her mother, Anne Cox Chambers.
About_#2: Her grandfather, James M. Cox, founded what has become Cox Enterprises in 1898.
About_#3: Her siblings, James Chambers and Katherine Rayner, also inherited an estimated 17% stake each in Cox Enterprises.
About_#4: Margaretta's son, Alex Taylor, is CEO and chairman of Cox Enterprises, a $20.9 billion (revenues) media and automotive company.
Did You Know?: Neither Margaretta nor her siblings or mother have ever had an active role in the company.

About_#1: You Xiaoping chairs Huafon Group, a maker of polyurethane products.
About_#2: Huafon Group is also involved in metals, finance, logistics and trade.
About_#3: One of its units, publicly traded Zhejiang Huafeng Spandex, supplies spandex products.

Education: Master of Engineering Management, China University of Mining and Technology; Bachelor of Engineering, Shandong Institute of Business and Technology
About_#1: Eric Yuan is the founder of Zoom, a video communications tool that went public in April 2019; Zoom usage surged during the coronavirus pandemic.
About_#2: He was previously a manager of WebEx at Cisco, which acquired the video conferencing company in 2007.
About_#3: Born in China, Yuan move to Silicon Valley in 1997 after eight failed attempts to obtain a visa.
About_#4: At the IPO, Yuan owned 22% of Zoom, which was valued at just over $9 billion before trading began.
In Their Own Words: "If we make our customers happy, we'll be happy."

Education: Master of Business Administration, Stanford University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: In 1959 Robert Bass and his brothers inherited $2.8 million each from their oil tycoon uncle Sid Richardson.
About_#2: Robert has helped launch a half dozen investment shops including his Oak Hill Advisors.
About_#3: Bass' private jet start-up Aerion collapsed in May 2021 amid reported financial difficulties.
About_#4: With wife Anne, Bass has given at least $70 million to Duke and $55 million to Stanford.
Did You Know?: Bass is lead investor in the near $9 billion private equity portfolio managed by Oak Hill Capital.

Education: EMBA, Harvard University
About_#1: Alexandre Behring is a cofounder and the managing partner of 3G Capital, a multibillion-dollar Brazil-born, U.S.-led investment firm.
About_#2: Behring chairs Kraft Heinz and is co-chairman of Restaurant Brands International, parent of Burger King and Canadian coffee chain Tim Hortons.
About_#3: New to the Forbes Billionaires list in 2020, Behring is a well known figure in the private equity world.
About_#4: His partners at 3G Capital include fellow billionaires Jorge Paulo Lemann, Marcel Telles and Carlos Alberto Sicupira.

Education: Doctorate, Savannah College of Art and Design
About_#1: Chan Laiwa's Fu Wah International Group is one of the largest real estate developers headquartered in Beijing.
About_#2: Fu Wah is best known for its Jinbao Street development with Jinbao Tower, the Regent Building and the Beijing Hong Kong Jockey Club.
About_#3: Fu Wah has also been expanding outside of China in recent years, investing in hotels in Australia and New Zealand.
About_#4: Chan is the curator of the China Red Sandalwood Museum.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Johns Hopkins University
About_#1: Jeff Greene became a billionaire by buying credit default swaps on subprime mortgage-backed bonds as the housing market crashed.
About_#2: Most of his fortune is now held in real estate in Los Angeles and South Florida, plus equities and other investments.
About_#3: Greene spent over $30 million in the summer of 2018 trying unsuccessfully to win the Democratic primary for governor of Florida.
About_#4: To pay for college, he relied on scholarships, loans and part-time jobs; he taught Hebrew 3 days a week and checked IDs outside the gym and library.
Did You Know?: Greene has spent more than $20 million on his nonprofit Greene School for 'high potential' children in Palm Beach. It now has over 100 students.
In Their Own Words: I was once part of the 99%. I never thought I'd ever be part of the 1% but just the fact that I could try to achieve that was motivating. That's what this country is about.

About_#1: Montri Jiaravanont is honorary chairman and director of the Charoen Pokphand Group, one of Thailand's sprawling conglomerates.
About_#2: He is the older brother of Thai billionaire Dhanin Chearavanont.
About_#3: Montri was executive director for two years at listed CP Pokphand Co.
About_#4: He is listed separately from his better-known sibling based on his ownership of a 12.63% stake in the family's vast assets.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: Charles Johnson is the second largest shareholder in Franklin Resources, a global investment management firm also known as Franklin Templeton Investments.
About_#2: Johnson became CEO at age 24 in 1957, a decade after his father, Rupert Johnson Sr., founded the company.
About_#3: Johnson spent 56 years at the company before handing over the chairman's post to his son, Gregory, in 2013.
About_#4: His daughter Jennifer, a champion of the company's data science capabilities and fintech initiatives, was named CEO in 2019.
Did You Know?: Charles' father Rupert named the company after Benjamin Franklin, who he believed epitomized the ideas of frugality and prudence in regard to saving and investing.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Franklin Pierce University
About_#1: Elizabeth Johnson is the granddaughter of Edward Johnson II, who founded Fidelity Investments in 1946.
About_#2: She is the sister of current Fidelity CEO and Chairman Abigail Johnson.
About_#3: In 2013, Johnson founded Louisburg Farm, a stable of show jumping horses based in Wellington, Florida.
About_#4: She owns a 5.56% stake in FMR, according to company documents filed with the Utah Department of Insurance in 2000.

Education: Master, Drexel University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Sun Yat-sen University
About_#1: Lin Bin is vice chairman of Xiaomi, one of the world's most popular smartphone brands.
About_#2: Lin cofounded the company in 2010 and was president until 2019. Early on he oversaw recruiting, legal, finance, strategic partnerships and overseas expansion.
About_#3: Before joining Xiaomi, he was an engineering director at Google from 2006 to 2010.
About_#4: Earlier in his career, Lin worked at ADP and Microsoft.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University
About_#1: Hiroshi Mikitani is founder and CEO of Rakuten, Japan's biggest e-commerce retailer.
About_#2: In 2021, Rakuten posted a loss of nearly $1.2 billion on revenue of $14.4 billion.
About_#3: The firm launched its new $5.5 billion mobile service, which was to start in October 2019, in April 2020.
About_#4: Rakuten's $300 million investment in ride-sharing firm Lyft resulted in losses and Mikitani stepped down from Lyft's board in 2020.
Did You Know?: In 2010, he led an "Englishnization" campaign at Rakuten, making English the company's official internal language in an effort to improve employees' English.

Education: High School Graduate, High School
About_#1: Isaac "Ike" Perlmutter beat out fellow billionaire Carl Icahn for control of bankrupt comic book firm Marvel in 1998; he serves as the chairman.
About_#2: He revived the company's stock by producing action-hero movies like 'Spiderman,' 'Daredevil,' 'Hulk' and 'Iron Man.'
About_#3: In 2009, he sold a majority of Marvel to Disney for $4 billion in cash and stock.
About_#4: Perlmutter immigrated to the U.S. from Israel with just $250 in 1967 and sold toys on the streets of Brooklyn, where he was introduced to Marvel.
Did You Know?: Perlmutter is a veteran of the Six-Day War in 1967 between Israel and neighboring states Egypt, Jordan and Syria.

Education: Master of Business Administration, St Gallen University
About_#1: Michael Pieper's Artemis Group controls the Switzerland-based Franke Group, maker of kitchen sinks and other industrial-grade kitchen equipment.
About_#2: Pieper is CEO and sole shareholder of the group, which was founded in Rorschach, Switzerland in 1911 and acquired by Michael's father, Will, in 1975.
About_#3: Michael took over in 1989, expanding the company into eastern Europe, Asia, Africa and the Americas.
About_#4: Artemis also owns a stake in precision cutting technology company Feintool, Swiss real estate and teak plantations in Costa Rica and Nicaragua.

About_#1: Issad Rebrab is the founder and CEO of Cevital, Algeria's biggest privately-held company.
About_#2: Cevital owns one of the largest sugar refineries in the world, with the capacity to produce 2 million tons a year.
About_#3: Cevital owns European companies, including French home appliances maker Groupe Brandt, an Italian steel mill and a German water purification company.
About_#4: After serving 8 months in jail on charges of corruption, Rebrab was released on January 1, 2020. He denies any wrongdoing.
Did You Know?: Rebrab is the son of militants who fought for Algeria's independence from France.
In Their Own Words: We [Algerians] have great potential; we can make up for lost time.

Education: Law Degree, National Taiwan University; Ph.D, Southern Methodist University
About_#1: Tsai Hong-tu chairs Cathay Financial Holdings, a financial services company that made his father Taiwan's wealthiest man before he died.
About_#2: His father, Tsai Wan-lin, died in 2004.
About_#3: Brothers Cheng-ta and T.Y. are billionaires, as are their cousins Richard and Daniel Tsai.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Leonard N. Stern School of Business; Graduate, National Taiwan University
About_#1: With billionaire brother Daniel, Richard Tsai leads Fubon Financial Holdings, a family company with interests in banking, insurance and securities.
About_#2: The brothers are also investors in Taiwan Mobile, a mobile phone service provider, and momo.com, a home shopping and e-commerce business.
About_#3: Cousins Tsai Hong-tu, Tsai Cheng-da and T.Y. Tsai are also billionaires.

About_#1: Wang Junshi is a director and deputy general manager of Ginlong Technologies, a manufacturer of solar inverters.
About_#2: Wang Junshi cofounded Ginlong with son Wang Yiming in the eastern Chinese coastal city of Ningbo in 2005.
About_#3: Wang was a high school teacher earlier in his career.
About_#4: Son Wang Yiming chairs Ginlong.

Education: Drop Out, Miami Dade College
About_#1: Shari Arison inherited a fortune from her late father Ted who founded cruise ship line Carnival Corp., and has reinvested much of it.
About_#2: Israel's richest woman, Arison created The Doing Good Model - guidelines for incorporating social good into running a business.
About_#3: She has invested in various real estate projects, including a desalination plant and a thermo-solar power plant.
About_#4: She also owns 16% of Bank Hapoalim, Israel's largest bank.
Did You Know?: She received the annual Medal of Light award from Israel's parliament in 2016 for her work with Holocaust survivors through the Arison Family Foundation.

About_#1: Alain Bouchard cofounded convenience store conglomerate Alimentation Couche-Tard with a single Quebec shop in 1980.
About_#2: As executive chairman, Bouchard still oversees the $54 billion (sales) company, which boasts more than 14,000 owned or franchised stores worldwide.
About_#3: Bouchard, who grew the business rapidly by snatching up competitors, retired as president and CEO in September 2014.
About_#4: In 2017, Couche-Tard acquired Texas-based CST Brands for $4.4 billion (including debt) and Minnesota-based Holiday Stationstores for $1.6 billion.
In Their Own Words: I've learned that when you stick to it and you focus, you win.

Education: Doctorate, Oregon State University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Minnesota; Master of Science, University of Minnesota
About_#1: Austen Cargill II is one of 12 billionaire heirs to Cargill, the family business where he served as a vice president until retiring in 2001.
About_#2: His great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.
About_#3: The family still owns roughly 90% of Cargill, which did $165 billion in 2022 sales across food, agriculture, financial and industrial divisions.
About_#4: Before becoming a Cargill executive, Austen earned a Ph.D. and worked as a marine biologist for the company.

About_#1: James Cargill is one of 12 billionaire heirs to Cargill, America's second largest private company after Koch Industries.
About_#2: His great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.
About_#3: The family still owns roughly 90% of Cargill, which did $165 billion in 2022 sales across food, agriculture, financial and industrial divisions.
About_#4: The Cargill-MacMillan family collects an estimated 18% of net profits as dividends every year.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Georgia Institute of Technology
About_#1: Ben Chestnut founded what later became Mailchimp with Dan Kurzius in 2001 as a side project to their web design company.
About_#2: Mailchimp's email marketing software for small businesses garnered enough customers that in 2007 they committed to it full time.
About_#3: Wary of giving up control to outside investors, Chestnut and Kurzius bootstrapped growth from profits and took no outside money.
About_#4: In September 2021, Intuit announced it would acquire Mailchimp in a $12 billion cash and stock acquisition.
Did You Know?: Chestnut learned about small business from his mom, who ran a hair salon from the family's kitchen in Georgia.
In Their Own Words: I want people to see that the past 17 years were just a warm-up.

Education: Master of Science, Military Academy F.E.Dzerzhinsky
About_#1: A former military man-turned-financial whiz, Fedun met his partner Vagit Alekperov in the late 80's while teaching in the Siberian city of Kogalym.
About_#2: In the 1990s Fedun helped Alekperov privatize Lukoil, which was formed from top Russian oil properties. He owns a nearly 10% stake in the oil company.
About_#3: Alekperov now heads Lukoil, and Fedun works as his right hand man.
In Their Own Words: We have always been friends with the authorities and have always been loyal and helpful to the authorities. And our authorities, thank God, appreciate it.

About_#1: Johann Graf owns Novomatic Group, which operates casinos worldwide and also sells slot machines, video poker games and electronic table games.
About_#2: Raised by his grandparents in a small flat without running water, he apprenticed as a butcher and was expected to take over his family's butcher shop.
About_#3: Instead Graf began importing American pinball machines to Austria via Belgium, then became an agent for a British slot machine company.
About_#4: In 1980 he stuck out on his own with Novomatic, which he quickly expanded into Switzerland and then the East Bloc after the fall of the Iron Curtain.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Xiamen University
About_#1: Huang Yi chairs Zhongsheng Group, one of China's largest national car dealerships.
About_#2: Zhongsheng focuses on luxury and mid-to-high-end brands such as Mercedes-Benz, Lexus, Porsche and Land Rover.
About_#3: Huang and Li Guoqiang, Zhongsheng's CEO, established Zhongsheng Group in 1998.
About_#4: Huang received an undergraduate degree in economics from Xiamen University in 1983.

About_#1: Before joining mineral firm Kazakhmys in 1995, Vladimir Kim obtained academic credentials in civil engineering, economics and business administration.
About_#2: He was named chairman in 2005, before Kazakhmys became the first Kazakh company to list on the London Stock Exchange.
About_#3: In a 2014 restructuring, Kazakhmys de-merged into private company Kazakhmys Corp. and a separate public company, KAZ Minerals plc.
About_#4: Kim still has a stake in KAZ Minerals and a majority of Kazakhmys Corp., which inherited most of the group's mature mining (mostly copper) assets.

Education: High School Graduate, High School
About_#1: Dan Kurzius founded what later became Mailchimp with Ben Chestnut in 2001 as a side project to their web design company.
About_#2: Mailchimp's email marketing software for small businesses garnered enough customers that in 2007 they committed to it full time.
About_#3: Wary of giving up control to outside investors, Kurzius and Chestnut bootstrapped growth from profits and took no outside money.
About_#4: In September 2021, Intuit announced it would acquire Mailchimp in a $12 billion cash and stock acquisition.
Did You Know?: Kurzius was a part-time DJ and competitive skateboarder before getting into web design.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Ronald Lauder is the youngest son of makeup maven Estee Lauder, who founded her eponymous beauty company in 1946.
About_#2: He became the chairman of Clinique Laboratories in 1994 and still occupies that position today.
About_#3: Lauder spent a total of 40 years as a board member. He stepped off in 2009, but was reelected to the board in 2016.
About_#4: The president of the World Jewish Congress and a Trump donor, Lauder has informally advised the White House on Israel.
Did You Know?: Lauder has amassed roughly 4,000 works of art worth at least $1 billion and also has a sizeable collection of medieval armor and arms dating from the 3rd century BC.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Montana State University
About_#1: Marianne Liebmann is one of 12 billionaire heirs to Cargill, America's second largest private company after Koch Industries.
About_#2: Her great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.
About_#3: The family still owns roughly 90% of Cargill, which did $165 billion in 2022 sales across food, agriculture, financial and industrial divisions.
About_#4: The Cargill-MacMillan family collects an estimated 18% of net profits as dividends every year.

About_#1: Tobi Lutke is the cofounder and CEO of Shopify, a Canadian e-commerce firm that helps companies set up and run online stores.
About_#2: He owns about 6% of Shopify, which went public in 2015.
About_#3: Shopify had $4.6 billion in 2021 sales; it is used by some two million businesses, including Kylie Cosmetics, Allbirds and Rothy's.
About_#4: Lutke grew up in Germany, where he learned to code by age 12 and left school at 16 to enter a computer programming apprenticeship.
Did You Know?: Lutke has said most Shopify employees will continue to work remotely after the pandemic is over.
In Their Own Words: Amazon is trying to build an empire. Shopify is trying to arm the rebels.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Claremont McKenna College; Doctor of Jurisprudence, University of Chicago; Master of Business Administration, University of Chicago
About_#1: Tom Pritzker, one of 11 billionaire heirs in the Pritzker clan, serves as the executive chairman of hotel giant Hyatt.
About_#2: Hyatt Hotels dates back to 1957 when Tom's father, Jay Pritzker (d. 1999), purchased the first Hyatt House motel near Los Angeles International Airport.
About_#3: Tom's father Jay and uncle Robert acquired manufacturing firm Marmon in the 1950s and expanded it; Tom led Marmon's 2008 sale to Berkshire Hathaway.
About_#4: Pritzker stepped down from the board of Royal Caribbean Cruises in 2020 after two decades as a director.
Did You Know?: Pritzker is an Honorary Professor of History at Sichuan University in Chengdu, China.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Scott Shleifer cofounded Tiger Global Management's private equity investing arm in 2003, two years after Chase Coleman founded the hedge fund firm.
About_#2: Tiger Global's venture funds now make up the bulk of the firm's $75 billion in net assets under management.
About_#3: Shleifer made lucrative bets on several Chinese tech companies for Tiger, including JD.com, ride-hailing app Didi Chuxing and e-commerce giant Meituan.
About_#4: Shleifer worked for three years as an analyst at Blackstone after graduating from the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School.

Education: Master of Science, University of Texas, Austin
About_#1: Oil tycoon Autry Stephens started a sole proprietor business in Texas and drilled his first well in 1979.
About_#2: That company grew into Endeavor Energy Resources, a privately held oil exploration and production firm.
About_#3: Endeavor is one of the largest private oil producers in the U.S., generating some 200,000 barrels of oil equivalent per day.
About_#4: The company has the rights to drill on more than 500,000 acres in the U.S., mainly in Texas.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Stanford University
About_#1: PayPal cofounder Peter Thiel remains a general partner of venture capital firm Founders Fund, where he is involved in firm strategy and weighs in on its large investments.
About_#2: Among its investments are Stripe and SpaceX, two of the most valuable unicorns in the world.
About_#3: He also cofounded CIA-backed big data startup Palantir, which went public via a direct listing in 2020.
About_#4: Thiel, the first big investor in Facebook, has sold most of his stake in the social network; in February 2022 Facebook said Thiel would leave the board this year.
Did You Know?: Thiel found himself at the center of controversy after Forbes revealed in May 2016 that he was secretly funding lawsuits in an attempt to destroy Gawker Media.

Education: Chinese Culture University
About_#1: Tsai Cheng-ta sits on the board of Cathay Financial Holdings.
About_#2: His father Tsai Wan-lin, who ran Cathay for years, was Taiwan's wealthiest person at the time of his death in 2004.
About_#3: Brothers Hong-tu and T.Y., and cousins Richard and Daniel Tsai, are all billionaires too.

About_#1: Maximilian Viessmann is Co-CEO of Viessmann Group, a German manufacturer of heating, refrigeration and climate-control equipment.
About_#2: The great-grandson of founder Johann Viessmann, he oversees the private company's climate solutions portfolio.
About_#3: Before joining the business, which has 12,000 employees and 23 production divisions in 12 countries, he worked at Boston Consulting Group.
About_#4: He holds a bachelor's degree in Industrial Engineering from TU Darmstadt and a master's in IE from Karlsruhe Institute of Technology.
Did You Know?: He is a member of Vordenker Community, an initiative of German newspaper Handelsblatt and BCG bringing together 300+ young business leaders in Germany.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University; Master of Science, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology
About_#1: Hansjoerg Wyss' fortune stems from his 2012 sale of medical device manufacturer Synthes, which he founded, to Johnson & Johnson for $20.2 billion.
About_#2: He now holds stakes in publicly-traded biotech companies NovoCure and Molecular Partners.
About_#3: One of the most philanthropic people in the world, Wyss also has charitable foundations with assets of over $2 billion.
About_#4: In 2014, he pledged $120 million to two universities, University of Zurich and ETH Zurich, to establish a center to accelerate medical breakthroughs.
Did You Know?: In 2016 his Wyss Foundation donated 16,000 acres of forest land to a Romanian conservation organization.

Education: Master of Business Administration, The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania
About_#1: Zhang Tao was the CEO of restaurant review site Dianping when it merged with Groupon-like Meituan in 2015.
About_#2: Meituan went public in Hong Kong in 2018.
About_#3: Zhang received an MBA from Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania in 2002, and returned to China in 2003, when he set up Dianping.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Columbia University
About_#1: Daniel Ziff and brothers Robert and Dirk inherited a fortune that dates back to 1927 when their grandfather cofounded publishing company Ziff Davis
About_#2: Daniel's late father, William Jr., built up Ziff Davis, which became best known for such trade publications as PC Magazine and Car and Driver.
About_#3: The publishing business was sold for $1.4 billion in 1994.
About_#4: The brothers created the Ziff Brothers Investments and greatly expanded their inheritance with hedge funds in the U.S. and in London.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Columbia University; Master of Business Administration, Harvard University
About_#1: Dirk Ziff and his brothers Robert and Daniel inherited a fortune from their grandfather, who cofounded publishing company Ziff Davis in 1927.
About_#2: The brothers' late father built up Ziff Davis, publisher of PC Magazine and Car and Driver, and sold the company for $1.4 billion in 1994.
About_#3: Through their Ziff Brothers Investments, which had hedge funds in the U.S. and in London, the brothers greatly expanded their inheritance.
About_#4: In 2015, Dirk Ziff formed his own family office, Ziff Capital Partners.
Did You Know?: In 2021, the Ziffs sold their late father's estate in Manalapan, Florida for $94 million. It was originally listed in 2015 for $200 million.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, Cornell University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University
About_#1: Like his brothers Dirk and Daniel, Robert Ziff, the middle billionaire child, owes his fortune to his grandfather's publishing company, Ziff Davis.
About_#2: The brothers' late father, William Jr., built up Ziff Davis, published PC Magazine and Car and Driver, and sold the company for $1.4 billion in 1994.
About_#3: The brothers created the Ziff Brothers Investments and increased those proceeds by tenfold with hedge funds in the U.S. and in London until 2014.
About_#4: Though their offices ceased operations, they are also reportedly investing with investors who were formerly at their hedge funds.
Did You Know?: Robert graduated magna cum laude from Harvard University in electrical and computer engineering, then finished Cornell Law School as the first in his class.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, University of Waterloo
About_#1: Father and son Kapil and Rahul Bhatia's (pictured) biggest asset is InterGlobe Aviation, whose IndiGo is India's biggest airline by market share.
About_#2: IndiGo, which was cofounded with billionaire airline veteran Rakesh Gangwal in 2006, has a 58% domestic market share (as of August 2022).
About_#3: It has a fleet of 279 aircraft and flies to 100 destinations, including 26 overseas.Its CEO is airline veteran Ronojoy Dutta, a former president of United Airlines.
About_#4: In 2019, the Bhatias and Gangwal had a public falling out over how IndiGo is run. In 2022, Gangwal stepped down from the board and said he would be gradually selling his stake.
Did You Know?: An electrical engineer, Rahul Bhatia's first business venture was in telecom but that never took off due to regulatory hurdles.
In Their Own Words: Rahul Bhatia:If you keep driving costs down and improving efficiency, the runway is long.

Education: Bachelor of Business Administration, Michigan State University
About_#1: Mat Ishbia is chairman and CEO of Michigan-based mortgage lender United Wholesale Mortgage, now UWM Holdings, founded by his father Jeff in 1986.
About_#2: He owns a 71% stake in the company, which went public through a merger with a blank check company in 2021.
About_#3: Launched as a side gig while Jeff worked as an attorney for his day job, UWM grew to become America's largest wholesale lender in 2015.
About_#4: Mat joined the firm in 2003 after graduating from Michigan State and became CEO in 2013.
Did You Know?: Ishbia was on the Michigan State team that won the NCAA men's basketball championship in 2000 and worked alongside coach Tom Izzo for a year before joining UWM.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Simon School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Williams College
About_#1: Frozen food mogul Robert Rich, Jr. leads Rich Products, founded by his father, Robert Rich Sr. (d. 2006) in 1945.
About_#2: Rich Products made its mark with the first non-dairy whipped cream and expanded into non-dairy frozen foods.
About_#3: Products include cakes, icings, pizza dough, meatballs and more.
About_#4: Rich Jr. became the firm's president in 1978 and took over as chairman in 2006. The company has $3.6 billion in annual sales.
Did You Know?: Rich Jr. is an avid sports enthusiast and once tried out for the U.S. Olympics ice hockey team as a goalkeeper.

Education: Doctorate, Tufts University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Zurich Polytechnic
About_#1: Thomas Schmidheiny gets the bulk of his fortune from cement and building materials giant Lafarge Holcim, which was formed via a mega-merger in 2014.
About_#2: His grand-uncle Ernt founded the family business in 1912; over time the family built an empire of bricks and cement.
About_#3: His father Max divided the estate in 1984 and Thomas inherited cement and concrete supplier Holcim. His brother Stephan got concrete supplier Eternit.
About_#4: Thomas, now honorary chairman of Holcim, left the board in 2018. He retired as chairman in 2003 after running the company for 20 years.
Did You Know?: Schmidheiny's son co-founded Berlin-based film distributor DCM and his daughter built a brewery in Latin America.

About_#1: Alexandra Schoerghuber oversees private family investment company Schoerghuber Unternehmensgruppe, as chairwoman of the group's supervisory board.
About_#2: It has stakes in a brewery co-owned with Heineken and in Arabella Hospitality, a hotel joint venture with Marriott.
About_#3: The group also owns one of Germany's largest real estate companies, Bayerische Bau und Immobilien GmbH, which builds, owns and manages properties.
About_#4: Its Productos del Mar Ventisqueros S.A., based in Puerto Montt, Chile, specializes in the cultivation and processing of salmon.
Did You Know?: The family is known for its support of modern art.

About_#1: Erik Selin is CEO of publicly traded real estate firm Fastighets AB Balder, which he founded in 2005.
About_#2: Selin skipped college to focus on his stock investments but lost it all in the crash of 1987, before moving on to property trades.
About_#3: At age 24, Selin convinced a local bank to lend him $2 million to finance a deal for a residential development in Ängelholm, Sweden.
About_#4: Today over 60% of the real estate held by Balder is residential.
Did You Know?: Selin claims to have started reading annual reports at age 12 and trading securities at age 14 with money from summer jobs.

Education: LLM, Georgetown University; LLB, National Taiwan University
About_#1: With billionaire brother Richard, Daniel Tsai leads Fubon Financial Holdings, a family company with interests in banking, insurance and securities.
About_#2: The brothers are also investors in Taiwan Mobile, a mobile phone service provider, and momo.com, a home shopping and e-commerce business.
About_#3: Cousins Tsai Hong-tu, Tsai Cheng-da and T.Y. Tsai are also billionaires.

About_#1: The bulk of Dona Bertarelli's wealth comes from the 2007 sale of her family's biotech business Serono for over $13 billion.
About_#2: In the 1990s Dona was Serono's executive director of public and professional affairs.
About_#3: Her brother Ernesto is the richest man in Switzerland. They split ownership of most family assets.
About_#4: She now focuses her time on marine conservation efforts and is a special adviser to the United Nations.
Did You Know?: Bertarelli became the fastest woman to sail around the world when her team raced for the Jules Verne Trophy in 2016.

Education: Master, Saint Petersburg Mining University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, State Central Institute of Physical Culture
About_#1: Andrei Guriev is deputy chairman of PhosAgro, one of the world's largest producers of phosphate-based fertilizers.
About_#2: A former communist committee leader in Moscow, Guriev got his start as deputy director at Mikhail Khodorkovsky's Menatep Group in 1990.
About_#3: After Khodorkovsky, his former boss and once Russia's richest person, went to jail, Guriev led a buyout of Menatep subsidiary PhosAgro.
About_#4: His son, Andrei A. Guriev, is PhosAgro's CEO and was sanctioned by the EU on March 9.

About_#1: Brazil's Luciano Hang has found success with department store chain Havan by focusing heavily on physical stores rather than online sales.
About_#2: Hang cofounded Havan in 1986; today it employs some 20,000 people in 155 locations, all in small to mid-sized Brazilian cities.
About_#3: Hang bought out his cofounder early on and today owns nearly all of Havan, which had about $1.9 billion in 2020 revenues
About_#4: Hang has many followers on social media; he regularly live streams about politics on Facebook and gets up to 1 million views.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Shaoxing University; Master of Business Administration, Zhejiang University
About_#1: Hu Baifan chairs Shenzhen-listed Zhejiang NHU, one of the world's largest producers of vitamins A and E.
About_#2: After graduation from college in 1982, Hu spent six years teaching chemistry at a remote vocational school in China.
About_#3: With money borrowed from his fellow teachers, Hu started a workshop in 1988 to make industrial ethanol from leftover materials from other factories.

About_#1: Georgia's richest man Bidzina Ivanishvili made his money in metals and banking in Russia, then cashed out and moved back home in 2003.
About_#2: Ivanishvili was elected prime minister of Georgia in October 2012.
About_#3: Thirteen months later he stepped down after his party won the presidential elections, saying he'd fulfilled his task.
About_#4: He entrusted about $1 billion to Credit Suisse, but more than $100 million of that sum was apparently stolen by the bank's manager Patrice Lescaudron.
Did You Know?: Ivanishvili lives in a 108,000-square-foot compound in the mountains overlooking Tbilisi. His vast art collection includes Picasso's Dora Maar with Cat.
In Their Own Words: "A person doesn't need billions. Two hundred million is enough. After that it's just a sport."

About_#1: Lee Yeow Chor and Lee Yeow Seng are the sons of the late Lee Shin Cheng, who died in June 2019.
About_#2: The brothers inherited stakes in IOI group, a palm oil and property empire built by their father.
About_#3: Lee Yeow Chor (pictured) is group managing director and chief executive of IOI Corporation and holds a law degree from King's College, London.
About_#4: Lee Yeow Seng, who also studied law, is the executive vice-chairman of IOI Properties.
Did You Know?: The late Lee grew up on a rubber plantation where his father ran a Chinese food shop.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Northeast Agriculture University; EMBA, Peking University
About_#1: Leng Youbin chairs China Feihe, one of China's largest suppliers of infant formula.
About_#2: China Feihe listed its shares on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in late 2019.
About_#3: Hongguang Dairy Plant, the predecessor of Feihe, was founded as a state-owned enterprise in 1962; the Feihe brand was officially born in 1984.
About_#4: Leng graduated from Northeast Agricultural University in China's northeast Heilongjiang Province in July 1995 through a correspondence course.

About_#1: Theo Mueller inherited food and dairy firm Theo Mueller Group, which was founded in 1896.
About_#2: Founded by his grandfather in Bavaria, the village dairy had only four employees when Theo Mueller took the reins from his father in 1971.
About_#3: He improved processing techniques and distribution infrastructure, turning it into the first dairy in Germany to offer fresh milk products nationwide.
About_#4: Aside from dairy, Mueller Group is active in packing, logistics, vehicle maintenance, fruit processing, a fish restaurant chain and artisanal bakeries.
Did You Know?: In 1995, two armed men dressed up as policemen tried to kidnap Theo Mueller. He lashed around and escaped. In the afternoon, he was back at his office desk.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of North Carolina
About_#1: Superstar trader Julian Robertson, who helped pioneer the modern day hedge fund industry, has died at age 90.
About_#2: Born and raised in North Carolina, Robertson served two years in the Navy after graduating from UNC Chapel Hill.
About_#3: Robertson founded his highly successful Tiger Management in 1980 and ran it for 20 years.
About_#4: He closed his fund in 2000 and went on to manage his own book and seed several funds started by his disciples, dubbed Tiger Cubs and Tiger Seeds.
Did You Know?: He took a year off from investing in 1979 to write a novel in New Zealand. He eventually owned several lodges, resorts and golf courses there.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania; Master of Business Administration, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Marc Rowan is the CEO and a cofounder of Apollo Global Management, one of the biggest U.S. private equity firms, with over $500 billion in assets.
About_#2: Rowan met Apollo cofounders Leon Black and Joshua Harris while working at investment bank Drexel Burnham Lambert's M&A division.
About_#3: The trio founded Apollo in 1990, after Drexel filed for bankruptcy following a cash shortage caused by turmoil in the junk bond market.
About_#4: In March 2021, Rowan replaced Black as Apollo's CEO, after the latter stepped down due to his longtime relationship with sexual predator Jeffrey Epstein.
Did You Know?: Rowan owns several restaurants in Long Island's swanky Hamptons area, including Lulu Kitchen and Bar in Sag Harbor.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: Emanuele (Lino) Saputo chaired his family's eponymous dairy company from 1969 until his August 2017 retirement.
About_#2: His son, Lino Jr., who has served as president and CEO since 2004, succeeded him as chairman.
About_#3: The elder Saputo's father, Giuseppe, founded the business in 1954 with $500 and a bicycle for deliveries after immigrating to Canada from Sicily.
About_#4: Lino grew the company in the following decades, taking it public in 1997; today its products are sold in more than 40 countries.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Toronto
About_#1: Jeff Skoll built his fortune as eBay's first full-time hire and president in 1995; he left eBay in 2001, three years after its IPO.
About_#2: His Skoll Foundation quadrupled its grants to $200 million in 2020 in response to the pandemic.
About_#3: The Skoll Foundation and Skoll Global Threats Fund have distributed about $600 million worldwide, aiming to reduce poverty, among other goals.
About_#4: In 2016 his Participant Media movie production firm won its first best picture Academy Award for the film "Spotlight."
Did You Know?: Skoll was born and raised in Canada and pumped gas to pay his way through the University of Toronto. He became a U.S. citizen in 2007.
In Their Own Words: When my friend Pierre Omidyar approached me with his idea for eBay, I was very sure of what to do. With my newly minted [MBA] degree in hand, I said 'Pierre, what a stupid idea!' Luckily, I soon realized that Pierre was onto something.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology; Master of Science, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology
About_#1: The world's first drone billionaire, Frank Wang is founder and CEO of DJI, the biggest seller of consumer drones.
About_#2: Wang founded DJI in 2006 and ran it out of his dorm room at Hong Kong University of Science & Technology.
About_#3: DJI, which reportedly has more than $2 billion in sales, raised money at an estimated valuation of $15 billion in 2018.
About_#4: DJI is best known for its Phantom Drones, which retail for around $1,000.
Did You Know?: The son of a teacher turned small-business owner, Wang spent most of his childhood reading about model airplanes.

About_#1: Maria Fernanda Amorim is the widow of Americo Amorim, who died in July 2017. She and her three daughters inherited his fortune.
About_#2: Americo Amorim spent six decades in his family's cork business, Corticeira Amorim, and invested in an energy company and banks in several countries.
About_#3: His grandfather started Corticeira Amorim in 1870; the company has dominated the cork industry ever since.
About_#4: Amorim's biggest asset is an estimated 18% stake in Portuguese oil and gas company Galp Energia, which is chaired by her eldest daughter Paula.

Education: Master of Science, Moscow Institute for Transport Engineering
About_#1: Leonid Boguslavsky is founder of early stage venture capital firm RTP Global, founded as ru-Net in 2000 in Russia.
About_#2: One of his first investments was an early bet on Russian search engine firm Yandex, on which he apparently made 400 times his initial money upon exit.
About_#3: RTP has invested in 90 companies, five of which became multibillion dollar public companies: Yandex, EPAM, Delivery Hero, RingCentral and Datadog.
About_#4: In the early 1990s, he built one of Russia's largest IT solutions integrators, which he sold to PwC in 1996. He stayed on initially as a senior partner.

Education: Drop Out, High School
About_#1: Richard Branson owes his fortune to a conglomerate of businesses bearing the "Virgin" brand name, including Virgin Atlantic and Virgin Galactic.
About_#2: The son of a barrister and flight attendant, Branson got his start with a mail-order record business some 50 years ago.
About_#3: He primarily lives on a luxe British Virgin Islands retreat, Necker Island, which he bought for $180,000 in 1978.
About_#4: Alaska Air acquired his Virgin America airline in 2016, a move he opposed but didn't have the votes to stop.
Did You Know?: When he sold Virgin Records for $1 billion in 1992, Branson ran down London's Ladbroke Grove crying, upset over parting with the business.
In Their Own Words: My biggest weakness in life is that I can't say no.

Education: Bachelor of Business Administration, University of Florida
About_#1: Robert Brockman built a fortune as a software entrepreneur. He died in August 2022 at age 81.
About_#2: Brockman was the former chairman and CEO of Reynolds and Reynolds, which sells software and services to automotive dealerships.
About_#3: He got his start at IBM selling mainframe computer services to auto dealers, then launched Universal Computer Services in 1970.
About_#4: In 2000 he committed $1 billion in seed capital for billionaire Robert F. Smith to launch private equity giant Vista Equity Partners.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, National Cheng Kung University
About_#1: Chen chairs Yageo, an electronics-component maker whose parts are found in everything from mobile phones to tablet PCs to cars.
About_#2: Chen started Yageo in 1977 and took the company public 16 years later.
About_#3: An avid art buyer, he has works by Gerhard Richter, Mark Rothko, Andy Warhol and Francis Bacon.
About_#4: His mountain home has spectacular views of Taipei.

About_#1: Chu Mang Yee is a former government official who controls Hong Kong-listed real estate developer Hopson Development.
About_#2: Chu's daughter, Chu Kut Yung, is the company's chairman.
About_#3: Over his business career, Chu has built experience in trading and construction as well as real estate development.
About_#4: Founded in 1992, Hopson focused on mid- and high-end residential projects.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Southern California
About_#1: Scott Cook is the cofounder of financial software giant Intuit, known for products like QuickBooks, TurboTax and Mint.
About_#2: The Harvard Business School grad worked for Procter & Gamble and Bain before launching Intuit in 1983.
About_#3: He stepped down as CEO in 1994, but continues to hold a stake of less than 3% and remains chairman of the $12.7 billion (fiscal 2022 sales) company.
About_#4: Cook and his wife are big supporters of education and have donated millions to universities and are impact investors in several ed-tech funds.
Did You Know?: Cook was an early investor in Snapchat. He met cofounder Evan Spiegel after giving a guest lecture at Stanford.
In Their Own Words: Dig for feedback on yourself. I did not do this. When I started work I waited for my boss to give me feedback -- which is the moral equivalent of taking the steering wheel for your life and handing it to someone else.

Source of Wealth: online media, Dallas Mavericks, Self Made
Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Indiana University
About_#1: Mark Cuban founded video portal Broadcast.com with fellow Indiana University alum Todd Wagner in 1995 and sold it to Yahoo for $5.7 billion in 1999.
About_#2: Today he owns the NBA's Dallas Mavericks and has stakes in Magnolia Pictures, AXS TV and dozens of small startups.
About_#3: He sold stamps door-to-door as a kid and gave disco lessons to help pay his way through Indiana University.
About_#4: Cuban was inspired to strike out on his own when he was fired from a software shop for closing a $15,000 sale instead of cleaning up the store.
Did You Know?: Cuban started Broadcast.com with Wagner so they could watch Hoosier basketball while living in Dallas.
In Their Own Words: It doesn't matter if the glass is half-empty or half-full, all that matters is that you're the one pouring.

About_#1: Guenther Fielmann is the founder of eyeglasses giant Fielmann AG; his family controls almost 72% of its shares.
About_#2: He opened his first optometry shop in Cuxhaven, Germany, in 1972, and took the company public in 1994. It now has almost 800 outlets.
About_#3: The company, which sells roughly half of all prescription eyeglasses in Germany, also has outlets in France, Italy and Poland, among other countries.
About_#4: In 2016, son Marc, who studied at the London School of Economics, joined the company's management board. In 2018, he became co-CEO.

About_#1: Martin Haefner's fortune largely stems from his former stake in IT management software maker CA Technologies, acquired by Broadcom in July 2018.
About_#2: He inherited half of his father Walter's stake in CA Technologies when he died in June 2012, then the world's oldest billionaire at 101.
About_#3: He also inherited part of car dealer AMAG, which sells brands including Volkswagen, Audi, Bentley and Porsche.
About_#4: His sister, Eva Maria Bucher-Haefner, inherited equal stakes in CA Technologies and AMAG. He bought her stake in AMAG in 2018.

Education: Drop Out, University of Central Arkansas
About_#1: In 1961, Johnelle Hunt and her late husband J.B. (d. 2006) sold their home and took out loans to start a rice hull packaging operation.
About_#2: Eight years later, the couple bought five trucks and seven trailers to launch trucking firm J.B. Hunt Transport Services.
About_#3: The Lowell, Arkansas, business went public in 1983 and is now one of the biggest transportation companies in the nation, with $12.2 billion in sales.
About_#4: Hunt, who stepped down as corporate secretary in 2008, remains the firm's largest individual shareholder, with a 17% stake.
Did You Know?: The daughter of a poultry business owner, Hunt studied to be a teacher at University of Central Arkansas before leaving to marry J.B.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Leonard N. Stern School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, New York University
