About_#1: Koo is the honorary chairman of Chailease Holding, an equipment-leasing outfit operating in Taiwan, mainland China and Southeast Asia.
About_#2: Chailease comprises more than 45 companies with over 100 offices and 6,000 employees. It operates throughout China and in 12 other countries.
About_#3: The first generation of Koos made their fortune in camphor, salt, sugar, and land. Koo's father, financier Jeffrey Koo, Sr., who died in 2012, was dubbed the "Father of the Credit Card" in Taiwan.
About_#4: Andre's business empire operates independently from the Koo family's holdings.
Did You Know?: The Andre Koo Lobby at NYU's Stern School of Business is named after Koo. He has been sponsoring the school's Andre Koo Tech MBA program since its inception in 2018.

About_#1: Lai Meisong is the founder and chairman of Shanghai-based ZTO Express, an express delivery firm profiting from a boom in e-commerce in China.
About_#2: ZTO listed on the New York Stock Exchange in October 2016.
About_#3: Alibaba and its logistics arm Cainiao Network hold an approximately 10% stake in ZTO.

Education: Drop Out, Stanford University
About_#1: Richard Li is a son of one of Hong Kong's wealthiest billionaires Li Ka-Shing. He chairs Asia-based investment company Pacific Century group.
About_#2: Pacific Century owns most of life insurance company FWD, which operates in ten markets across Asia, including Hong Kong and Singapore.
About_#3: The group also has interests in businesses spanning financial services, technology and property.
About_#4: Li established a communications and media empire with PCCW, a Hong Kong-based company which controls the city's largest mobile phone operator HKT.
Did You Know?: Li started Star TV in 1991 with $110 million he received from his father; he sold the company, which had a viewership in the tens of millions, to Rupert Murdoch.

About_#1: Politician and property magnate Mangal Prabhat Lodha founded developer Lodha group in Mumbai in 1980, now known as Macrotech Developers.
About_#2: A native of the desert state of Rajasthan, Lodha started off by building middle-class homes in Mumbai's far-flung suburbs.
About_#3: After his sons Abhishek and Abhinandan joined the business in 2003, the firm went on an expansion binge picking up prime land parcels. Abhinandan has since left the business.
About_#4: Lodha built Mumbai's Trump Tower, a 75-story luxury skyscraper, located in a complex called The Park, in midtown Mumbai.
Did You Know?: Lodha was the Mumbai president of the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party until 2022.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Southern California; Master of Business Administration, University of Southern California; Master of Science, University of Southern California
About_#1: Russian immigrant Igor Olenicoff fled the Soviet Union with his family at age 15, and eventually built up a substantial real estate empire.
About_#2: His Olen Properties owns 8 million square feet of office space and 17,000 residential units in California and seven other U.S. states.
About_#3: Olenicoff's daughter and heir-apparent, Natalia Ostensen, assists in running the day-to-day operations.
About_#4: In 2007, Olenicoff pleaded guilty to lying on his tax return about keeping $200 million in offshore accounts, and agreed to pay $52 million in back taxes and fraud penalties.
Did You Know?: The Tsarist-connected Olenicoff family fled to Iran during World War II, where Igor attended American missionary school.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, College of the Holy Cross
About_#1: Mark Shoen owns roughly one-fifth of Amerco, the publicly traded parent company of U-Haul.
About_#2: Shoen's parents, L.S. and Anna Mary Shoen, cofounded U-Haul, the truck-and trailer-rental company, in 1945.
About_#3: He sided with his brother Joe in a nasty family feud in which Joe wrested control of U-Haul away from their father.
About_#4: Shoen is also owner of one of the largest private self-storage operations in the U.S., which does business with U-Haul.

Education: State Central Institute of Physical Culture
About_#1: Andrei Skoch has been a member of the State Duma, Russia's legislative body, since 1999.
About_#2: He and his former partner Lev Kvetnoi were born in a settlement near Moscow and studied at the same athletics school, Institute of Physical Culture.
About_#3: The partners merged their business with that of billionaire Alisher Usmanov. Kvetnoi later sold out.
About_#4: As a member of the Duma, he isn't allowed to own stakes in businesses so his shares in USM are held by his father Vladimir and his daughter Varvara.
Did You Know?: He built a memorial to fallen Russian soldiers in Lushun, China, formerly known as Port Arthur, the site of the bloodiest battles of the 1904-05 Russo-Japanese War.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: FedEx founder Fred Smith came up with the idea for the company for a term paper at Yale in 1965.
About_#2: After graduation, Smith served in Vietnam with the Marines. He returned home and launched FedEx in 1971.
About_#3: FedEx lost $29 million in its first 26 months, so Smith flew to Vegas and won $27,000 at the blackjack tables, enough to keep the business afloat.
About_#4: The company now has annual revenue of more than $90 billion.
Did You Know?: Smith was fraternity brothers at Yale with former President George W. Bush.
In Their Own Words: "No business school graduate would recommend gambling as a financial strategy, but sometimes it pays to be a little crazy early in your career."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Bogazici University
About_#1: Murat Ulker owns 63% of Yildiz Holding, which produces a wide range of food products and non-alcoholic beverages.
About_#2: Yildiz spent $850 million to buy Belgian chocolatier Godiva in 2007 and $3.2 billion to buy United Biscuits of the U.K. in 2014.
About_#3: To establish a more global structure, he merged United Biscuit, Ulker Biscuit and DeMet's Candy under the roof of London-based Pladis Foods.
About_#4: In early 2019, Godiva announced the sale of parts of its Asia-Pacific business, along with a production facility in Belgium, to PE firm MBK Partners.
Did You Know?: In 2020, Ulker handed over the chairmanship of Yildiz, which he'd held for 20 years, to his nephew Ali Ulker.
In Their Own Words: My name is Murat; I don't need any other title.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Ecole Centrale Paris; Master of Business Administration, Harvard University; Master of Science in Engineering, University of Minnesota
About_#1: Stéphane Bancel is the CEO of Cambridge, Massachusetts-based biotech firm Moderna, known for its Covid-19 vaccine.
About_#2: He became CEO of Moderna in 2011 and owns a roughly 8% stake in the publicly traded company.
About_#3: Before joining Moderna, Bancel was the CEO of French diagnostics company BioMérieux, founded by fellow French billionaire Alain Mérieux.
About_#4: Moderna's Covid-19 vaccine was granted full FDA approval on January 31, 2022, it had previously received emergency-use authorization in December 2020.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Samford University
About_#1: Bubba Cathy and his brother, Dan, run fast-food juggernaut Chick-fil-A, the fried chicken chain founded by their father, Truett (d. 2014), in 1967.
About_#2: He grew up in the business, rising from construction apprentice to senior vice president in 1995.
About_#3: Today Bubba serves as Chick-fil-A's executive vice president and is president of the company's Georgia-based Dwarf House and Truett's Grill.
About_#4: His brother, Dan, serves as chairman of the religious company that is known for closing every Sunday. His nephew, Andrew, is CEO.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Georgia Southern University
About_#1: Fried chicken billionaire Dan Cathy is chairman of Chick-fil-A, the fast-food juggernaut his father, Truett Cathy (d. 2014), founded in 1967.
About_#2: He grew up doing odd jobs in his father's restaurants, including scraping chewing gum from table bottoms with a butter knife.
About_#3: Cathy became CEO in 2013, sparking nationwide protests when he made anti-same sex marriage remarks. His son, Andrew Cathy, took over as CEO in November 2021.
About_#4: His brother, Bubba Cathy, serves as executive vice president of the chicken chain, which is known for staying closed on Sundays.
Did You Know?: Cathy plays the trumpet and is an avid motorcyclist and licensed pilot.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Samford University
About_#1: Trudy Cathy White is the only daughter of Truett Cathy (d. 2014), the founder of Chick-fil-A.
About_#2: Cathy White serves as an "ambassador" at the company, attending new restaurant openings and other corporate events.
About_#3: Her brothers, billionaires Dan and Bubba Cathy, run the fried chicken chain as chairman and executive vice president, respectively.
About_#4: Cathy White, who spent 10 years as a missionary in Brazil, cofounded Christian nonprofits Lifeshape and Impact 360 Institute.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, National Taiwan University
About_#1: Jason Chang chairs Taiwan's Advanced Semiconductor Engineering.
About_#2: Along with his brother Richard, Jason is one of the main investors in commercial real estate developer Sino Horizon Holding.
About_#3: ASE is the world's largest provider of independent semiconductor assembling and test manufacturing services.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Heidelberg University
About_#1: Dagmar Dolby owns about 36% of publicly-traded audio technology firm Dolby Laboratories, which her husband Ray Dolby (d. 2013) founded in 1965.
About_#2: The company pioneered surround sound technologies used in thousands of films and products, and most recently, in video games and mobile devices.
About_#3: Her two sons share voting power over some assets. David is a board member at Dolby Labs; his brother, Tom, is a novelist and filmmaker.
About_#4: Since 2015, she has committed over $160 million to the University of Cambridge, where Ray Dolby earned a Ph.D. in physics.
Did You Know?: Dagmar Dolby graduated from Heidelberg University in her native Germany. She met Ray in 1962 while studying in a summer language program in the U.K.

Education: B.Com, University of Manitoba
About_#1: Bruce Flatt is one of the biggest and best investors you've likely never heard of.
About_#2: Flatt runs Brookfield Asset Management, the $600 billion (assets) alternative manager with real estate, infrastructure and private equity operations.
About_#3: A Winnipeg native, he joined an accounting firm out of college, then took a job at Canadian conglomerate Brascan, which soon nearly collapsed.
About_#4: He helped revive Brascan through a series of savvy real estate deals and became CEO in 2002, refashioning the firm into Brookfield Asset Management.
In Their Own Words: Never put yourself in a situation where you have to sell something in an environment where you should be buying.

About_#1: Masatoshi Ito is honorary chairman of Japan's biggest retail group, Seven & i Holdings.
About_#2: Seven & i Holdings has more than 79,000 stores in 19 countries and $54 billion in annual revenue.
About_#3: The company is best known for its thousands of 7-Eleven convenience stores in Japan, the U.S. and China.
About_#4: The company also runs Denny's restaurants in Japan and owns department stores, supermarkets, and financial services firms.
Did You Know?: Ito is Seven & i's largest shareholder but owns only a minority stake in the company.

Education: Ph.D, Moscow Aviation University
About_#1: Viatcheslav Kantor is a large shareholder of publicly traded Acron, one of Russia's largest fertilizer producers.
About_#2: Kantor graduated from the Moscow Aviation Institute and set up a computer trading company in the late 1980s.
About_#3: He later received a contract to carry out an environmental impact assessment at the Azot chemical plant in Novgorod.
About_#4: That plant was later renamed Acron and privatized in 1993.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, National Taiwan University; Doctorate, University of Tennessee Knoxville; Master of Science, University of Tennessee Knoxville
About_#1: Min Kao cofounded GPS maker Garmin with the late Gary Burrell in 1989, after the duo led development of the first GPS navigator at Allied Signal.
About_#2: Min Kao is executive chairman of the navigation firm, which has annual revenue of about $5 billion and makes everything from GPS for cars to weather radar for airplanes.
About_#3: Garmin has brought GPS navigation and wearable technology to the automotive, outdoor, fitness, aviation, and marine markets.
About_#4: Kao stepped down as CEO in 2012 but remains executive chairman and a member of the board.
Did You Know?: Garmin is a mix of the first names of cofounders Gary Burrell and Min Kao.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Xiamen University
About_#1: After making a fortune in scrap steel during the 1990s, Lin Xiucheng shifted into the light-emitting diode (LED) business.
About_#2: He injected his LED business into a Shanghai-listed firm in exchange for a majority stake and changed its name to Sanan Optoelectronics in 2008.
About_#3: Lin shares majority ownership of his main holding company, Fujian Sanan Group, with son Lin Zhiqiang.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Columbia University; Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Harvard University
About_#1: Sami Mnaymneh is co-CEO of H.I.G. Capital, a private equity firm with $50 billion under management.
About_#2: Mnaymneh cofounded H.I.G. in 1993 with Tony Tamer and the duo became known for being the masters of middle-market deals.
About_#3: In addition to operations in Europe and Latin America, H.I.G. has a large credit business.
About_#4: Prior to starting H.I.G., Mnaymneh was a managing director at Blackstone and a vice president of mergers and acquisitions at Morgan Stanley.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Rutgers University; Master of Science in Engineering, Stanford University
About_#1: Tony Tamer is the co-CEO of H.I.G. Capital, a private equity firm with $50 billion under management.
About_#2: Tamer cofounded H.I.G. Capital in 1993 with Sami Mnaymneh; the duo have been masters of middle-market private equity deals.
About_#3: In addition to operations in Europe and Latin America, H.I.G. also runs a large credit business.
About_#4: Prior to founding H.I.G. Capital, Tamer was a partner at Bain & Company.
Did You Know?: Tony Tamer is intensely media shy, even by the secretive standards of private equity.

About_#1: Richard White founded software company WiseTech Global in 1994 to help logistics companies manage goods and information across supply chains.
About_#2: Since the company went public in 2016, WiseTech's shares have soared due to strong growth in revenue and acquisitions worldwide.
About_#3: He is the company's chief executive and retains a controlling stake.
About_#4: Touted as Australia's next Atlassian, Sydney-based WiseTech has more than 18,000 customers in 165 countries.

About_#1: Michael Ashley is founder and CEO of the U.K.'s largest sporting goods retailer Sports Direct.
About_#2: Ashley started Sports Direct in 1982 when he was 18 years old; the company now has more than 800 stores.
About_#3: The company went public in 2007, with Ashley pocketing $1.8 billion from the IPO. That same year, he bought famed soccer club Newcastle United.
About_#4: He has acquired dozens of companies, including boxing glove maker Everlast, Wimbledon supplier Lillywhites and department store House of Fraser.
Did You Know?: Ashley commutes to work by helicopter.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Bucknell University
About_#1: Ron Baron is the CEO of Baron Funds, a money management firm he founded in 1982; it manages about $60 billion.
About_#2: The buy-and-hold investor's $10 billion flagship fund, Baron Growth, has an annual turnover of just 3%.
About_#3: Baron owns one of the biggest estates in the Hamptons, which he assembled from 2001 to 2009 at a total cost of $152 million. It's worth much more now.
About_#4: The son of an engineer (dad) and purchasing agent (mom) for the federal government, Baron wanted to be a doctor but didn't get into medical school.
Did You Know?: To help pay for college, Baron worked as a cabana boy, lifeguard, water-ski instructor and ice cream truck driver.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Texas at Austin
About_#1: Bert "Tito" Beveridge is the founder of Tito's Vodka.
About_#2: Tito's, one of the fastest growing spirits brands in America, sold an estimated 88 million bottles of vodka in 2018, up from 63 million in 2017.
About_#3: Beveridge started the company in 1997 with $90,000 borrowed using 19 credit cards. He slept on floors and couches while he built the business.
About_#4: The business got its first big break after winning the 2001 World Spirits Competition in San Francisco against 72 vodkas from around the world.
Did You Know?: Beveridge grew up comfortably in San Antonio, where he played polo. As a youngster he wanted to pursue a career training horses.
In Their Own Words: If someone tells me my brand isn't a craft-distilled spirit because it's too big, I just say, 'I make it the same way I've always made it. I just have a lot more stills.'

Education: Bachelor of Business Administration, College of William & Mary
About_#1: Todd Boehly cofounded holding company Eldridge in 2015, after building Guggenheim Partners' credit business and serving as president.
About_#2: Boehly acquired some of Eldridge's first assets from Guggenheim, including insurer Security Benefit, which provides deal financing to this day.
About_#3: Eldridge has grown into a diverse conglomerate with investments ranging from Bruce Springsteen's song rights to daily fantasy and sports-betting firm DraftKings.
About_#4: Boehly personally holds minority stakes in the Los Angeles Lakers and Los Angeles Dodgers (Eldridge has a separate minority stake in the latter).
Did You Know?: Boehly and his wife Katie, who met at Wiliam and Mary, gave an undisclosed sum to the college to build the Boehly Center for Excellence in Finance.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, Harvard University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Washington
About_#1: David Bonderman is chairman and founding partner of private equity giant TPG, which managed over $120 billion in assets as of August, 2022.
About_#2: "Bondo" met his longtime business partner Jim Coulter while working for billionaire Robert Bass. The pair left in 1992 to found TPG.
About_#3: Their first big deal was a $66 million investment in faltering Continental Airlines, which ultimately made them a $640 million profit.
About_#4: Together the two are still principal owners of TPG; Bonderman operates from Fort Worth and Coulter from San Francisco.
Did You Know?: Bonderman studied Islamic law in Egypt and Tunis, and published an article for the Harvard Law Review titled "Modernization and Changing Perceptions of Islamic Law."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Fudan University; Master of Business Administration, Fudan University
About_#1: Guo Guangchang chairs Fosun International. He transformed the conglomerate into an insurance-focused investment group.
About_#2: In December 2016, Fosun agreed to sell U.S. insurer Ironshore to Liberty Mutual for about $3 billion to help raise cash.
About_#3: Fosun purchased a 74% stake in Indian pharmaceuticals company Gland Pharma in 2017.
About_#4: Fosun's investments range from steelmaking to mining, tourism and pharmaceuticals.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Alberta; Doctor of Jurisprudence, University of Alberta
About_#1: Daryl Katz amassed a fortune in the pharmacy business, buying the Canadian rights to U.S. franchise Medicine Shoppe in 1991.
About_#2: A few years later he snatched up struggling Canadian drugstore chain Rexall, then expanded to the U.S. market.
About_#3: Katz, the son of a drug store owner, has since sold off all of his pharmacy operations, pivoting his Katz Group to real estate and entertainment.
About_#4: He has been co-developing a $2 billion, 25-acre complex in Edmonton's downtown that will include offices, condos and retail, among others.
Did You Know?: Katz started off his career as a lawyer, then ran a chain of frozen yogurt stands after buying the Alberta franchise rights to Yogen Früz with other investors.

Education: Associate in Arts/Science, George Washington University; LLB, George Washington University
About_#1: In 1952, a 26-year-old Ted Lerner borrowed $250 from his wife to start a real estate company, selling homes for developers.
About_#2: He sold 22,000, then decided to become a builder. Today his Lerner Enterprises is among the largest owners of real estate in the Washington, D.C area.
About_#3: Since 2006 Lerner has owned the Washington Nationals baseball team. In June 2018, Ted passed control of the team to son Mark.
About_#4: The family donates to charities including Children's National Hospital in DC, George Washington University and Hebrew University in Jerusalem.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad; B.Com, Mumbai University
About_#1: Former investment banker Falguni Nayar quit her job to start Nykaa, a retailer of beauty products in 2012.
About_#2: Nykaa's marquee investors include U.S. private equity giant TPG Growth as well as billionaires Harsh Mariwala and Harry Banga.
About_#3: Nykaa, which means "one in the spotlight," currently sells more than 4,500 brands online as well through more than 100 stores across India.
About_#4: Nayar took Nykaa public in November 2021, becoming India's richest self-made female entrepreneur in the process.
Did You Know?: Nayar has an MBA from the elite Indian Institute of Management in Ahmedabad.
In Their Own Words: We are feeling a coming-of-age kind of excitement as a company.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Dartmouth College; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Southern Methodist University
About_#1: Rees-Jones started as a bankruptcy attorney, but wanted to make deals, not clean up after them.
About_#2: In 1984 he started Chief Oil & Gas and became a pioneer of the shale fracking boom.
About_#3: A lucky guy, he grossed $7 billion on 7 deals in 7 years.
About_#4: His new house on Dallas Country Club is appraised by the county at $26 million.
Did You Know?: He hired Garth Brooks for wife Jan's 60th birthday party (600 guests).

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Creighton University
About_#1: Online stock trading pioneer Joe Ricketts founded brokerage firm Ameritrade four decades ago in Omaha, Nebraska and took it public in 1997.
About_#2: His company acquired TD Waterhouse for $2.9 billion in stock and cash in 2006 and renamed itself TD Ameritrade.
About_#3: In 2019, competitor Charles Schwab announced it would acquire TD Ameritrade in a $26 billion deal.
About_#4: Ricketts retired from the board of directors of TD Ameritrade in 2011 but remained its largest individual shareholder.
Did You Know?: It took Ricketts nine years to graduate from Creighton University because he periodically had to stop and earn money to pay his tuition.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, Southern Methodist University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, The University of Texas at Austin
About_#1: In 1996 he reinvested $500 million from selling the family's oilfields into the purchase of Omni Hotels.
About_#2: The Omni chain has 60 locations and 21,000 rooms nationwide with big new hotels in Dallas, Atlanta and Boston.
About_#3: He gave $25 million to the University of Texas business school in 2013.
About_#4: In 2019 he completed the $170 million renovation of Omni Barton Creek Resort in Austin.
In Their Own Words: Just tell the truth. It's basic.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Southern California; Master of Science, University of Southern California
About_#1: Silicon Valley venture capitalist Mark Stevens was a partner at Sequoia Capital when the firm invested in hits like Google, PayPal and LinkedIn.
About_#2: Now he is investing in startups through his firm S-Cubed Capital.
About_#3: Stevens joined Sequoia in 1989 after stints at Intel and Hughes Aircraft, and spent some two decades at the venture capital firm.
About_#4: He serves on the board of fabless semiconductor firm Nvidia and owns a minority stake in the Golden State Warriors NBA basketball team.
Did You Know?: His first job, at 16, was as a cook at Jack in the Box in Culver City, Calif.

About_#1: Gustav Magnar Witzoe owns nearly half of Salmar ASA, one of the world's largest salmon producers.
About_#2: His stake was gifted to him in 2013 by his father, Gustav Witzoe, who founded the company in 1991.
About_#3: Salmar has led the industrialization of fish farming in Norway, refining the product into more sophisticated cuts with higher margins.
About_#4: The elder Witzoe still runs the company; Gustav Magnar, meanwhile, is trying to make his own mark investing in real estate and tech startups.
Did You Know?: Fish farming is now one of Norway's biggest industries; in 2016 Salmar harvested close to 130,000 tons of salmon.

Education: Ph.D, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
About_#1: Xie Liangzhi chairs Beijing-based Sinocelltech Group, a supplier of biological products.
About_#2: Xie holds a Ph.D. from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in chemical engineering.
About_#3: He worked for Merck & Co. in the U.S. as a senior engineer from 1997 to 2002.

About_#1: Yeung Kin-man is the founder, president and chief technology officer of Biel Crystal.
About_#2: Lam Wai Ying, Yeung's wife and Biel's chairman, owns 49% of the business; Yeung holds 51%.
About_#3: Biel is a supplier of smartphone touch screens to Apple and Samsung, and employs 83,000 people around the world.
About_#4: The company plans to go public in Hong Kong in 2022.

About_#1: Zhang Hejun chairs Ningbo Deye Technology, a supplier of products ranging from inverters to solar air conditioners and water pump controllers.
About_#2: Zhang founded the company in the eastern Chinese city of Ningbo in 1990.
About_#3: Ningbo Deye Technology went public at the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 2021.
About_#4: Deye's business partners include Midea, Haier, TCL and AUX.

Education: Master, University of Economics in Bratislava (UEB)
About_#1: Nicknamed the Czech Donald Trump, Andrej Babis was elected prime minister of the Czech Republic in December 2017; he stepped down from office in December 2021.
About_#2: His fortune comes from Agrofert, which operates more than 210 companies in everything from agriculture to renewable energy to media.
About_#3: The leader of the political party ANO (which means "Yes"), he gave up daily management of Agrofert in 2013.
About_#4: Prior to the election, he was required to put Agrofert into trusts to comply with a Czech conflict-of-interest law.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Università Cà Foscari di Venezia
About_#1: Giuseppe De'Longhi is chairman of De'Longhi SpA, which produces high-end coffee makers and espresso machines.
About_#2: De'Longhi's son, Fabio, is the CEO of the company, which pulls in over $2 billion in annual revenue and sells products in more than 100 countries.
About_#3: The company was founded in 1902 in Treviso, Italy as a small industrial manufacturing workshop. A century later, its headquarters remain in Treviso.
About_#4: The company makes portable heaters, air conditioners, appliances for food preparation, cleaning tools and coffee machines.

Education: Drop Out, University of California, Los Angeles
About_#1: Barry Diller founded internet and media conglomerate IAC in 1995. He remains senior executive and chairman.
About_#2: IAC runs websites like Care.com and owns a majority stake in Angi Inc., which controls websites like HomeAdvisor and Angi.
About_#3: Diller is also chairman of online travel giant Expedia, which acquired its holding company, Liberty Expedia, in a $2.6 billion deal in 2019.
About_#4: Prior to founding IAC, he worked at ABC, Paramount and Fox and oversaw launches of hit TV shows including "Cheers" and "The Simpsons."
Did You Know?: Diller never graduated from college and got a job in the mail room at William Morris talent agency.
In Their Own Words: What I really do think it takes [to have a successful communication tool, is] rolling out new product, and if that new product is good and appealing, then you'll more than likely survive and probably thrive.

About_#1: Christian Haub runs his family's Tengelmann Group, a retail conglomerate that began with a shop opened in Muelheim an der Ruhr in 1867.
About_#2: Its operations include home-improvement chain OBI; clothing and non-food discounter KiK; and online retailer babymarkt.de.
About_#3: The group also invests in startups and is active in services (energy, plus audits and consulting), property management and real estate development.
About_#4: Older brother Karl-Erivan had taken over as CEO after father Erivan Haub died in early 2018. Then Karl-Erivan went missing while on a ski tour in April 2018.
Did You Know?: The Haubs own some 3,000 acres in Methow Valley, in Washington state. The property includes a resort, Sun Mountain Lodge. They also have a buffalo ranch in Wyoming.

Education: Master of Science, Huazhong University of Science and Technology
About_#1: Huang Li chairs Wuhan Guide Infrared, a supplier of infrared imaging systems whose customers include China's military.
About_#2: Huang founded Wuhan Guide Electric in 1999 to focus on infrared product design, manufacture and sales.
About_#3: Wuhan Guide Electric morphed into Wuhan Guide Infrared in 2004, went public in 2010 and trades on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange.

Education: Diploma, High School; High School Graduate, High School
About_#1: Marian Ilitch and her husband, Mike, who died in 2017, cofounded Little Caesars Pizza in 1959.
About_#2: Mrs. I, as she's known, now owns the pizza chain, which hauls in more than $4.5 billion in annual systemwide sales.
About_#3: She also owns the Detroit Red Wings and MotorCity Casino Hotel; the Detroit Tigers are owned by a family trust.
About_#4: Ilitch is helping build a $1.4 billion sports and entertainment district in Detroit that includes a new headquarters with pizza-shaped windows.
Did You Know?: Ilitch is a former Delta Airlines ticket agent.

Education: Master of Economics, Dagestan State University
About_#1: Suleiman Kerimov gets most of his fortune from his 76% stake in Russia's biggest gold producer, Polyus.
About_#2: Kerimov was sanctioned by the U.S. in 2018 for alleged money laundering related to the purchase of villas in France. The EU sanctioned him in March 2022.
About_#3: A trained economist, Kerimov made a career investing in distressed companies in Russia.
About_#4: He cashed out and heavily invested in investment banks such as Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs before the 2008 financial meltdown. He lost billions.
Did You Know?: A native of Dagestan, Kerimov represents the republic in Russia's Federation Council.

About_#1: Edwin Leong is the sixth son of Henry G. Leong, a comprador of British trading house Jardine Matheson, who died when Edwin was just 9.
About_#2: Now he runs real estate development firm Tai Hung Fai Enterprise, which has more than 1,000 properties, ranging from shops to parking lots and hotels.
About_#3: He is the founder of the Tai Hung Fai Charitable Foundation, which focuses on helping needy children and the elderly.
About_#4: Leong made headlines for purchasing Hong Kong's most expensive retail property for nearly $160 million in 2016.

Education: Master of Science, Indian Institute of Technology
About_#1: N.R. Narayana Murthy is the legendary cofounder and retired chairman of Indian tech giant Infosys, in which he continues to hold a minority stake.
About_#2: Murthy stepped down as chairman in 2011 after 30 years with the company but returned in 2013 to hand over management to a professional CEO in 2014.
About_#3: In 2017, Murthy was in the news for raising concerns over alleged corporate governance lapses at Infosys, which the company denied.
About_#4: The controversy led to the CEO's resignation and a board shakeup, which saw the return of retired cofounder Nandan Nilekani as nonexecutive chairman.
Did You Know?: Murthy's son-in-law Rishi Sunak, a Conservative party MP in the U.K., is the chancellor of the exchequer since 2020.
In Their Own Words: Bad news must take the elevator and good news can take the stairs.

Education: Ph.D, Moscow State University
About_#1: Aven is a co-owner of Alfa Bank and LetterOne along with Mikhail Fridman, Khan and fellow billionaires Alexei Kuzmichev and Andrei Kosogov.
About_#2: Aven and his partners were all sanctioned by the EU and U.K. in February and March 2022; Aven stepped down from LetterOne's board in March.
About_#3: He grew up in Moscow, graduated from Moscow State University, and worked at the Institute for Systems Studies at the Soviet Academy of Sciences.
About_#4: In 1989 he went to work at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; two years later he was tapped to be Putin's minister of foreign economic relations.
In Their Own Words: In the early 90s, it was crucial to be able to be friends, to build relationships. The role of informal relationships is very important in Russia in general, it definitely means much more here than in the West.

About_#1: Joesley Batista is one of two billionaire brothers who control publicly traded JBS S.A., one of the world's largest meat processing companies.
About_#2: Their father, Jose Batista Sobrinho, founded a small butcher shop in Anapolis, in central Brazil. It grew by acquiring slaughterhouses in the region.
About_#3: Joesley and his brother Wesley took control in the 2000s, leading JBS's 2007 acquisition of U.S. pork and beef processor Swift & Co. for $225 million.
About_#4: In 2017 Joesley was arrested as part of a large Brazilian bribery probe and reportedly held for six months.

About_#1: Wesley Batista is one of two billionaire brothers who control publicly traded JBS S.A., one of the world's largest meat processing companies.
About_#2: Their father, Jose Batista Sobrinho, founded a small butcher shop in central Brazil in 1953. It grew by acquiring slaughterhouses in the region.
About_#3: Wesley and his brother Joesley took control in the 2000s, leading JBS's 2007 acquisition of U.S. pork and beef processor Swift & Co. for $225 million.
About_#4: In 2017 Wesley was arrested as part of a large Brazilian bribery probe and reportedly held for six months.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Goucher College
About_#1: Margot Birmingham Perot is the widow of the late technology entrepreneur and presidential candidate H. Ross Perot, Sr.
About_#2: She gave her husband a $1,000 check to start Electronic Data Systems. He sold EDS to GM in 1984, netting $1.5 billion.
About_#3: She and her family helped endow Dallas's Margot Perot Center, which has delivered more than 120,000 babies since 1983.
About_#4: The former teacher also philanthropically supports the Perot Museum of Nature and Science and the Global Fund for Children.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, Pepperdine University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Southern California
About_#1: Rick Caruso is a Los Angeles real estate developer who has built some of the country's most successful shopping centers.
About_#2: Caruso is running for mayor of Los Angeles in 2022. In June, he advanced to a run-off with Democratic Rep. Karen Bass to be held on November 8.
About_#3: Three of Caruso's retail centers--The Grove, The Americana and Palisades Village--rank among the 15 largest in the country in sales per square foot.
About_#4: The grandson of Italian immigrants, Caruso opened a retail center in 1992 and has more recently expanded into residential, office and hospitality.
Did You Know?: His father, Henry Caruso, founded Dollar-Rent-a-Car. As a teenager Rick washed cars at an airport rental center.
In Their Own Words: What guides my strategy is my love for the human spirit and connecting what we do to how people live their lives. I never viewed it as a complicated formula.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Villanova University
About_#1: Jim Davis is cofounder of Allegis Group, the largest staffing firm in the U.S.
About_#2: He founded Allegis (then called Aerotek) in 1983 with his cousin Steve Bisciotti, who is also a billionaire.
About_#3: Allegis now has offices on four continents and boasts an annual revenue of $12.3 billion.
About_#4: Through Redwood Capital, the cousins also invest in everything from retirement communities to propane distribution.
Did You Know?: Davis is a minority owner of the MLB's St. Louis Cardinals.

About_#1: Walter P.J. Droege and wife Hedda im Brahm-Droege founded Droege Group in 1988. It is one of the world's largest advisory and investment practices.
About_#2: Droege Group has a hybrid business model, providing expertise to consulting clients and making "buy-and-build" investments, which is now its focus.
About_#3: By providing capital, management resources and "value-add" know-how, it follows an "Entrepreneurship-as-a-Service" principle in engaging with clients.
About_#4: In 2018, Ernest-W. Droege, the couple's eldest son, joined the management board and succeeded his father as CEO.
Did You Know?: Walter, who remains on the board of directors, owns 78% of the group. Hedda is vice-chairwoman of the supervisory board and holds 22%.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Georgetown University; Master of Business Administration, Rice University
About_#1: Dan Friedkin owns Gulf States Toyota, which sold $9.4 billion worth of Toyotas in 2019.
About_#2: The company, based in Houston, has exclusive rights to distribute Toyota vehicles in Texas, Arkansas, Louisiana, Mississippi and Oklahoma.
About_#3: His father Thomas, who started the business in 1969, died in March 2017.
About_#4: Friedkin is also an investor in luxury hospitality management firm Auberge Resorts, which has properties in Aspen and Cabo San Lucas.
Did You Know?: His Friedkin Conservation Trust is working to preserve more than 6 million acres in Tanzania.

About_#1: Finland's richest person, Antti Herlin, is chairman of Kone Corporation, the world's third-largest maker of elevators and escalators.
About_#2: His great-grandfather initially invested in Kone in 1924, and Herlin served as CEO from 1996 to 2006.
About_#3: Kone's products appear around the world in such places as Shanghai Hongqiao International Airport and Makkah Clock Royal Tower hotel in Saudi Arabia.
About_#4: During his tenure as CEO, he expanded operations through acquisitions and alliances, and was given control of the firm as reward by his father Pekka.
Did You Know?: After his father's death, 3 of his siblings sued him over his larger stake. The dispute was solved in 2005, leaving the siblings with stakes in spinoff Cargotec.
In Their Own Words: I'm passionate about elevators. It's quite a funny thing. ... We take these metal boxes so seriously.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Washington & Lee University
About_#1: W. Herbert Hunt is one of legendary oil wildcatter H.L. Hunt's 15 children.
About_#2: He owns a refinery in Louisiana and oil company Petro-Hunt, which operates in six states including Oklahoma and North Dakota.
About_#3: In 2013, Hunt sold his Bakken oilfield acreage to publicly traded Halcon Resources for $1.5 billion in cash and stock.
About_#4: With brother Nelson Bunker Hunt (d. 2014), he tried to corner the world silver market in 1980, but failed when the price of the metal collapsed 80%.
Did You Know?: His brother Lamar Hunt (d. 2006) owned the Kansas City Chiefs. Half-brother Ray Lee Hunt runs a separate oil company, Hunt Oil.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Huadong Normal University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Huadong Normal University
About_#1: Jason Jiang leads Focus Media, a Chinese outdoor advertising firm that delisted in the U.S. in 2013 following negative publicity from a short seller.
About_#2: Focus Media was acquired by Hedy Holdings, a public Chinese computer manufacturing firm, in a backdoor listing in China in 2016.
About_#3: Hedy changed its name to Focus Media in October 2017.
About_#4: Alibaba Group invested more than $2 billion in Focus Media and Jiang's holding company in 2018.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Washington & Lee University
About_#1: Rupert Johnson Jr. is the vice chairman of Franklin Resources, a global investment management firm also called Franklin Templeton Investments.
About_#2: He is the second largest shareholder in the firm with 19.2%, after his half brother Charles who chaired the company until 2013.
About_#3: Their father, Rupert Sr., founded Franklin Distributors in 1947; the business grew and went public in 1983.
About_#4: Rupert Jr. joined in 1965 and has been vice chairman since 1999. His nephew Gregory Johnson now serves as chairman and CEO.
Did You Know?: His father Rupert named the company after Benjamin Franklin who he believed epitomized the ideas of frugality and prudence in regard to saving and investing.

About_#1: Two-wheeler tycoon Vikram Lal's Eicher Motors makes the iconic Royal Enfield motorbikes.
About_#2: Eicher, which has three factories in India, sold close to 600,000 bikes in the fiscal year ended March 2022, nearly flat from the previous year.
About_#3: His son Siddhartha stepped down as chief executive in April 2019 but stayed on as managing director. In August 2021, shareholders opposed his proposed salary hike.
About_#4: Eicher has a joint venture with Sweden's Volvo to make trucks and buses.
Did You Know?: Royal Enfield is the oldest motorcycle in continuous production, since 1901, in the world.

About_#1: Lam and her husband Yeung Kin-man own Hong Kong's Biel Crystal, which makes screens for smartphones.
About_#2: Lam, Biel's chairman, owns 49% of the business; Yeung holds 51%.
About_#3: Biel is the largest supplier of glass screens for cell phones, tablets, and watches to Apple and employs 83,000 people around the world.
About_#4: While weakening iPhone demand may affect shipments to Apple, they also supply Samsung and Sony and have stated they expect stable revenue.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, San Francisco State University; Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business
About_#1: Chris Larsen cofounded Ripple in 2012 to facilitate international payments for banks using blockchain technology.
About_#2: Ripple counts American Express and Santander among its 100-plus customers.
About_#3: Larsen stepped down as Ripple CEO in December 2016 but remains executive chairman.
About_#4: Prior to Ripple, he cofounded online mortgage lender e-Loan in 1996 and Prosper, a peer-to-peer lender, in 2005.
In Their Own Words: The Internet of value is more than just laying out a new way of doing finance. I think, fundamentally, this represents the final step in globalization.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: Richard Schulze worked as an electronics components manufacturer representative before opening his stereo equipment shop, Sound of Music, in 1966.
About_#2: He grew it into the chain of superstores he renamed Best Buy.
About_#3: He is chairman emeritus of Best Buy and its largest individual shareholder with an 11% stake.
About_#4: Schulze served as the company's CEO from 1983 to 2002 and stepped down as chairman in 2012, when a scandal erupted around his hand-picked CEO.
Did You Know?: In 2019, Best Buy named Corie Barry as CEO. She became the first woman to lead the company in its 53-year history.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, Harvard University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Rochester
About_#1: Hedge fund magnate Paul Singer is known for his high-profile, and often combative, dealmaking.
About_#2: He founded his hedge fund firm, Elliott Management, in 1977 with $1.3 million. The firm now has some $56 billion in assets under management.
About_#3: He famously spent 15 years warring with the government of Argentina over bond payments, which resulted in a $2.4 billion payout to his firm in 2016.
About_#4: Elliott took over beleaguered soccer club AC Milan in 2018 and sold it for $1.2 billion to RedBird Capital Partners in 2022.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Brown University
About_#1: Barry Sternlicht runs Starwood Capital Group, a private equity firm that specializes in real estate investments.
About_#2: Starwood Capital has $120 billion of assets under management, making it one of the world's biggest real estate investors.
About_#3: Sternlicht founded Starwood Capital in 1991 and later started the W hotel chain and Starwood Property Trust, one of the biggest mortgage REITs.
About_#4: Sternlicht has sponsored five SPACs since 2020, including one that took senior care provider Cano Health public in June 2021.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Tsinghua University
About_#1: Su Hua founded Kuaishou as a GIF-maker app in 2011, then transformed it into a video-sharing and live-streaming platform.
About_#2: Kuaishou went public in an IPO at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in Feb. 2021.
About_#3: Pre-IPO investors in the IPO included funds managed by Fidelity and BlackRock.
About_#4: Su, a native of Hunan, was reportedly born in a village that didn't have electricity until 1998.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Creighton University; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Northwestern University
About_#1: Mark Walter is CEO of investment firm Guggenheim Partners, which has over $300 billion in assets under management.
About_#2: Walter helped found the firm in the late 1990s after he folded his Chicago-based company, Liberty Hampshire, into the Guggenheim family office.
About_#3: A yearlong SEC probe into Guggenheim over controversial real estate deals linked to Walter reportedly ended in May 2019 with no penalty.
About_#4: Walter's personal investments include stakes in plant-based food maker Beyond Meat and online car vendor Carvana.
Did You Know?: Walter, who earned a law degree from Northwestern University before going into finance, gave $40 million to the school in 2014.

Source of Wealth: plush toys, real estate, Self Made
Education: Drop Out, Kalamazoo College
About_#1: Ty Warner is the creator of Beanie Babies, the plush toy fad of the 1990s.
About_#2: Warner used the profits from selling Beanie Babies to assemble a high-end hotel portfolio, including the Four Seasons in New York.
About_#3: His Ty Inc. still sells a related Beanie Baby toy called a Beanie Boo around the world.
About_#4: His Las Ventanas al Paraiso resort in Mexico rents its Ty Warner Mansion for $35,000 a night.
Did You Know?: A onetime bellman, car valet and fruit market vendor, Warner found his calling as a salesmen--peddling encyclopedias and later stuffed animals at toymaker Dakin.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Donetsk National University
About_#1: The son of a coal miner, who got his start buying up mining assets during the 90s privatization era, Akhmetov's fortune was hard hit by the war.
About_#2: His largest holding is mining and steel firm Metinvest Group, whose plants in Mariupol and Avdiivka sustained damage from Russian attacks.
About_#3: The company declared force majeure on March 1. On March 31, Akhmetov said that his holding company, SCM, would file lawsuits against Russia for damages related to the invasion.
About_#4: His energy firm DTEK, which had provided roughly 30% of Ukraine's electricity, has been damaged by shelling.
In Their Own Words: I am in Ukraine and I am not going to leave the country. I share the same feelings with all Ukrainians: I am sincerely waiting for the victory of Ukraine in this war.

About_#1: Brothers Martin and Olivier Bouygues own just over 20% of their eponymous industrial conglomerate Bouygues Group.
About_#2: The Paris-headquartered giant, which boasted $40 billion in sales in 2020, operates in more than 100 countries in construction, telecoms and media.
About_#3: Martin has been chairman and CEO of the company for more than two decades, while older brother Olivier is a board member.
About_#4: Their father Frances (d.1993) started the construction firm in 1952. Their mother died in 2017 at age 93.
Did You Know?: Martin is a close friend of former French President Nicolas Sarkozy and is the godfather of Sarkozy's son.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University
About_#1: Bernard Broermann is the founder of Asklepios Kliniken GmbH, one of the three largest operators of private hospitals in Germany.
About_#2: His first hospital opened in 1984, and the group now employs more than 35,000 people and has 160 hospitals and medical clinics worldwide.
About_#3: Asklepios holds a majority stake in mediClin AG, a German operator of hospitals and clinics.
About_#4: In July 2020, it increased its 25% stake in rival Rhoen-Klinikum AG to 85%.
Did You Know?: Broermann, from a family of farmers, has M.B.A. degrees from Harvard University and INSEAD.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Hanyang University
About_#1: Chung Mong-Koo was chairman of Hyundai Motor, South Korea's largest automaker, for more than 20 years before stepping down in March 2020.
About_#2: He was succeeded by his only son Euisun, who is also a billionaire.
About_#3: He is the second son of the late Chung Ju-yung who came from a peasant family and later founded the Hyundai Group, once Korea's biggest conglomerate.
About_#4: His second-biggest holding is in the publicly-listed auto parts company Hyundai Mobis.
Did You Know?: Chung is often nicknamed a "bulldozer" for his blunt and forceful style.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Syracuse University
About_#1: Daniel D'Aniello is one of three billionaire founders of private equity firm Carlyle Group.
About_#2: He stepped down as chairman in January 2018 and now serves as chairman emeritus of Carlyle, which is approaching $400 billion in assets under management.
About_#3: D'Aniello worked at Trans World Airlines, Pepsi and Marriott before joining William Conway Jr. and David Rubenstein to start Carlyle in 1987.
About_#4: He attended Syracuse University on a scholarship, studying transportation economics, and later got his MBA at Harvard.
Did You Know?: He worked 60 hours a week in the summers and 20 hours a week during school as a stock boy in a produce market from age 9 until graduation.
In Their Own Words: When you think you know what is right, check with somebody whose wisdom you admire.

About_#1: Traudl Engelhorn was a member of the storied German industrial clan whose patriarch, Friedrich Engelhorn, founded the chemical company BASF in 1865.
About_#2: Her husband, Peter Engelhorn, was the brother of Curt, who ran the family business Boehringer Mannheim for more than three decades.
About_#3: Traudl netted approximately $2.45 billion after Curt initiated the sale of the company to Roche for $11 billion in 1997.
About_#4: She lived a quiet life in Lausanne, Switzerland and avoided publicity.
Did You Know?: Together with her late husband, Traudl built up one of Europe's biggest collections of contemporary glass art.

About_#1: Piero Ferrari is vice chairman and 10% owner of luxury race car company Ferrari. His father Enzo founded Ferrari.
About_#2: Piero became a billionaire when Ferrari listed its shares on the New York Stock Exchange in October 2015.
About_#3: The company went public as part of a spinoff from Fiat Chrysler.
About_#4: He became the sole heir after his stepbrother and Enzo's first son, Alfredo "Dino" Ferrari, died from muscular dystrophy in 1956.
Did You Know?: Piero owns several yachts and owns a stake in Italian luxury yacht builder Ferretti Group.

About_#1: Carlo Fidani runs Orlando Corp., the Toronto-area real estate company he took over following his father's death in 2000.
About_#2: The company has interests in construction and development, plus manages some 44 million square feet of industrial, office and commercial space.
About_#3: His grandfather founded the business as Fidani and Sons in 1948; Carlo took over in 2000 following his father's death.
About_#4: Fidani was made a Member of the Order of Canada in September 2018, an honor recognizing his achievements and service to the country.
Did You Know?: He co-owns the Canadian Tire Motorsport Park, a multi-track motorsport venue in Ontario that he purchased with Canadian racer Ron Fellows.

About_#1: Yakir Gabay owns 10% of Frankfurt-listed German real estate company Aroundtown SA, where he serves as deputy chairman of the advisory board.
About_#2: Aroundtown has a $30 billion-plus portfolio of commercial real estate in Europe.
About_#3: It also has a 40% stake in Grand City Properties, which owns around 65,000 apartments in Germany and London.
About_#4: Originally from Israel, Gabay previously served as CEO of the underwriting arm of Bank Leumi, one of Israel's largest banks.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School
About_#1: Jaime Gilinski Bacal built one of the largest banking empires in Latin America through a series of mergers and acquisitions.
About_#2: The Colombian is redeveloping a former U.S. Air Force base alongside the Panama Canal with British billionaire brothers Ian and Richard Livingstone.
About_#3: After getting an MBA at Harvard in 1980, Gilinski worked in Morgan Stanley's mergers and acquisitions division.
About_#4: His primary residence is in London, but Gilinski also has houses in New York, Panama, Miami and Colombia.
In Their Own Words: There is a moment in life when you have to take all of the risk, just put all of the cards on the table.

About_#1: Bertil Hult dropped out of college to start a business in his dormitory's basement in 1965, organizing trips to help students learn English in the UK.
About_#2: Today his company, EF Education First, run by his three oldest sons, offers educational travel and language training in 50 countries.
About_#3: EF sends teens on summer courses to the UK. and U.S. in such a scale that it makes EF one of the largest buyers of flights across the Atlantic.
About_#4: As the official supplier of language training for the 2016 Olympic games in Rio De Janeiro, EF says it helped teach English to 1 million Brazilians.
Did You Know?: For his 70th birthday, Hult flew guests in chartered jets to Shanghai for a multi-day party, which included a performance by Janet Jackson.
In Their Own Words: Those who don't move with the time, should be moved in time.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Vassar College
About_#1: Martha Ingram and her family own book distribution and marine firm Ingram Industries.
About_#2: Ingram took over the business after her husband Bronson Ingram died in 1995.
About_#3: She spun off the computer distribution business into publicly-traded Ingram Micro in 1996; it was acquired by Chinese company HNA in December 2016.
About_#4: Martha stepped down as chairman in 2008. Her sons Orrin and John took over as CEO and chairman, respectively.
Did You Know?: One of Martha's sons, David, runs Ingram Entertainment, an independent company that distributes DVDs and videogames.

About_#1: Lee Yin Yee is the founder and chairman of Xinyi Glass Holdings.
About_#2: Xinyi Glass produces glass products for the automobile, construction and household good industries.
About_#3: Early in his career, Lee was involved in auto-parts trading.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Columbia University
About_#1: Daniel Loeb is the founder of Third Point, a New York-based hedge fund launched in 1995 that manages $14 billion.
About_#2: Loeb is known for launching activist campaigns against corporate boards, shaking up companies in various industries and countries.
About_#3: Despite briefly enlisting a co-chief investment officer in 2019, Loeb, who also serves as Third Point's CEO, reassumed the role of sole CIO in 2020.
About_#4: The Margaret and Daniel Loeb Foundation supports Alzheimer's research, education reform and LGBT rights.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Columbia College
About_#1: Janice McNair, widow of Robert (Bob) McNair, inherited her late husband's 80% stake in the NFL's Houston Texans; he died in 2018.
About_#2: The couple met at Columbia College in South Carolina in the late 1950s and moved to Houston. Together they had four children and 15 grandchildren.
About_#3: Bob made his first fortune selling his power generator company Cogen Technologies to Enron for $1.5 billion in 1999.
About_#4: With the proceeds of Cogen's sale, he paid $600 million that year for the 32nd NFL franchise for Houston.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Mumbai; Master of Business Administration, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Ajay Piramal started out in his family's textile business at age 22 in 1977 but went on to build a pharma empire through acquisitions.
About_#2: In 2022, Piramal demerged the pharma and financial services businesses of his flagship Piramal Enterprises.
About_#3: Piramal inked his biggest deal in 2010 when he sold his domestic formulations business to Abbott Labs for $3.8 billion.
About_#4: Piramal's wife Swati is vice-chairman while his daughter Nandini and son Anand have board seats.
Did You Know?: Piramal is a non-executive director of Tata Sons, the holding outfit of the Tata group.
In Their Own Words: If it happens, it's good; but if it didn't happen, it's still good.

About_#1: Lynsi Snyder is the heir to beloved West Coast chain In-N-Out Burger, which her grandparents founded in 1948.
About_#2: She became a billionaire in 2017 on her 35th birthday, when she received the final portion of her inheritance, an additional stake in the chain.
About_#3: Snyder's uncle and father, both previous In-N-Out presidents, died young; by 2000, Snyder, then just 18, was the last family heir.
About_#4: She steadily received stakes in the business for a decade as part of a complex trust created by her grandparents.
Did You Know?: A devout Christian, Snyder sports three bible verse tattoos.
In Their Own Words: It's not about the money for us. Unless God sends a lightning bolt down and changes my heart miraculously, I would not ever sell.

About_#1: Peter Spuhler, former CEO of Stadler Rail, built a fortune buying up railcar makers across eastern Europe.
About_#2: In 2019, Spuhler took Stadler Rail public through an IPO that valued the company at $3.8 billion.
About_#3: His wife's grandfather had started Stadler five decades earlier, and in 1989, he bought the company from her grandmother for $6 million.
About_#4: Over the years Stadler has built railcars to climb to Germany's highest peak and designed ones to withstand the brutal Helsinki winters.

About_#1: Kerry Stokes took a winding path en route to earning a fortune with his Seven Group Holdings, which has media, construction and mining assets.
About_#2: Early in his life his mother gave him up for adoption, and he later dropped out of school at age 14.
About_#3: He started his career selling Caterpillar tractors and trucks in Australia and eventually China, before moving into media with Seven Group.
About_#4: In August 2021, he retired as chairman of Seven Group Holdings.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Kalamazoo College; Master of Architecture, University of California, Berkeley
About_#1: Jon Stryker's grandfather founded Stryker Corp., which sold $14.4 billion in medical equipment in 2020.
About_#2: Stryker inherited a stake in the company but does not work there.
About_#3: He is president and founder of the Arcus Foundation, which supports the advancement of LGBTQ human rights and the conservation of great apes.
About_#4: In 2021, Jon and husband Slobodan Randjelović gave $15 million to the ACLU Foundation to focus on LGBTQ and HIV issues.
Did You Know?: Stryker married his long-time partner Slobodan Randjelovic in December 2016.
In Their Own Words: The simple truth is that the legacy of lynching in this country is part of our shared history as Americans. The reverberations of lynchings and racial terror are felt throughout our society even today.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, New York Law School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, United States Military Academy
About_#1: The son of a truck driver from Brooklyn, Vincent Viola started electronic-trading firm Virtu Financial in 2008 and took the company public in 2015.
About_#2: Market-maker Virtu completed a series of secondary offerings in May 2019 to help repurchase more than $500 million in stock from Viola.
About_#3: Viola splurged on real estate with stock sale proceeds, buying a beachfront Florida condo and spending $108 million on Arizona's tallest skyscraper.
About_#4: Viola is the owner of the NHL Florida Panthers. He graduated from West Point in 1977 and New York Law School in 1983.
Did You Know?: Donald Trump appointed Viola to be Secretary of the Army in December 2016 but Viola withdrew his nomination two months later citing business conflicts.
In Their Own Words: "From the first day at West Point, my focus and purpose was about selfless leadership, putting others before yourself and being ready to sacrifice for others so that the mission and the goal would be accomplished."

Education: Doctorate, Carnegie Mellon University; Master of Science, Carnegie Mellon University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay
About_#1: Romesh Wadhwani is chairman of Symphony AI, an enterprise AI firm with operations in retail, financial services and manufacturing that he founded in 2017.
About_#2: He stepped down as CEO of SymphonyAI at the start of 2022 in a move to start to ready the firm for a potential public offering.
About_#3: He is also chairman of ConcertAI, an AI company focused on healthcare and life sciences that was valued at $1.9 billion by venture capital investors in March 2022.
About_#4: After graduating from the Indian Institute of Technology, he went to Carnegie Mellon and received a Ph.D. in 1972 in electrical engineering.
Did You Know?: Born in present day Pakistan, Wadhwani was only a few days old when his parents fled to India as the British Indian Empire underwent partition.
In Their Own Words: The ability to achieve without family background, ethnicity or social status being barriers in the way. To me, that's my definition of the American dream.

About_#1: Juan Domingo Beckmann Legorreta inherited a nearly 51% stake in tequila firm Becle S.A.B., maker of Jose Cuervo, from his father Juan Francisco Beckmann.
About_#2: Juan Domingo Beckmann is CEO of Becle, which went public on the Mexican stock exchange in February 2017.
About_#3: His sister Karen Beckman Legorreta inherited nearly 36% in Becle from their father and is a billionaire as well.
About_#4: The company has been in the family for more than 250 years.

Education: Master of Business Administration, MIT Sloan School of Management; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Universidad Politecnica de Madrid
About_#1: Rafael Del Pino y Calvo-Sotelo is the chairman of Spanish infrastructure operator and construction firm Ferrovial, and owns about 20% of the shares.
About_#2: The company, which his father founded in 1952, manages large airports and highways around the world, including London's Heathrow airport.
About_#3: In Spain, Ferrovial provides municipal services to 172 large cities.
About_#4: The company is listed on the Madrid stock exchange.

Education: Master of Science, Saint Petersburg State University
About_#1: Sergey Dmitriev cofounded software company JetBrains in 2000.
About_#2: JetBrains' tools are used by more than 10 million software developers and project managers around the world.
About_#3: Dmitriev serves as president of the Prague-based business.
About_#4: His partner, Valentin Kipyatkov, is also a billionaire.

Education: Master of Science, Indian Institute of Technology
About_#1: Cofounder of Infosys Senapathy "Kris" Gopalakrishnan retired from the company in 2014.
About_#2: He occupied various positions at Infosys including that of CEO and vice chairman.
About_#3: Since his retirement he has personally invested in a slew of startups through his business incubator Axilor Ventures and some venture funds.
About_#4: Gopalakrishnan has also funded and created Itihaasa, a digital app that chronicles the evolution of India's IT industry.
Did You Know?: He contributed $2.5 million to establish a center for innovation and entrepreneurship at IIT Madras, his alma mater.

About_#1: James Irving owns J.D. Irving, a conglomerate with more than two dozen companies in frozen foods, retail, shipbuilding, transportation and more.
About_#2: His timber and forestry operation, based in New Brunswick, has planted over a billion trees since 1957.
About_#3: His family's fortune dates back to the 19th century, when his grandfather left Scotland and launched a general store and lumber and farming companies.
About_#4: His father added to the empire with oil operations in the 1920s; upon his 1992 death the three brothers James, Arthur and John split the assets.
Did You Know?: Irving's brother, Arthur Irving, is also a billionaire, though inter-family relations have reportedly turned fractious and the brothers reportedly rarely speak.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yonsei University
About_#1: Lee Boo-jin is the president and chief executive of Hotel Shilla, one of Seoul's top lodging and conference centers.
About_#2: Hotel Shilla? is also the country's biggest duty-free operator after Lotte.
About_#3: Lee Boo-jin has also served as an advisor for the trading department of Samsung C&T, her family's de-facto holding company.
About_#4: Daughter of late Samsung Group patriarch Lee Kun-hee, she split her father's empire with her mother Hong Ra-hee, brother Jay Y. and sister Seo-hyun.
Did You Know?: She is the eldest daughter of Samsung Chairman Lee Kun-hee and has been nicknamed "little Kun-Hee" by the local press for her business acumen.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
About_#1: Samuel Tak Lee owns property management company Langham Estate, a swath of prime retail and office space in London's West End.
About_#2: He has built up his holdings to some 14 acres between the neighborhoods of Soho and Mayfair.
About_#3: His property empire stretches from Hong Kong and London to Geneva.
About_#4: In May 2020 Lee sold his entire stake in London-based Shaftesbury, a publicly traded real estate company, at a discount for $589 million.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Amherst College; Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School
About_#1: Thai Lee is CEO of $12.3 billion (sales) IT provider SHI International, which has 15,000 customers including Boeing and AT&T.
About_#2: Born in Bangkok, Lee grew up in South Korea and moved to the U.S. for high school.
About_#3: Lee's father, a prominent economist who traveled the world promoting his country's postwar development plan, was the first Korean to graduate from Amherst.
About_#4: A Harvard MBA, she did stints at Procter & Gamble and American Express before SHI.
In Their Own Words: We have no executive parking. We don't have a special executive compensation plan. We try to make sure that everybody feels valued.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Michigan; Doctor of Jurisprudence, University of Michigan
About_#1: Eric Lefkofsky made his fortune from the daily deals site Groupon, which he founded in 2008 with Andrew Mason and longtime business partner Brad Keywell.
About_#2: Lefkofsky serves on Groupon's board, but spends the bulk of his time running healthcare startup Tempus, which uses data to improve cancer treatment.
About_#3: Together Lefkofsky and Keywell also founded VC firm Lightbank, which has made investments in over 100 companies, including social media firm Sprout Social.
About_#4: Lefkofsky grew up outside of Detroit and went to the University of Michigan for his undergraduate and law degrees.
Did You Know?: Lefkofsky and Keywell owned stakes in the Wrigley Building located on Chicago's Magnificent Mile but sold them in June 2018.
In Their Own Words: In my adult life, I've started five companies. I've basically had five good ideas in 20 years.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, University of Tulsa
About_#1: Ermirio Pereira de Moraes' late father, Jose Ermirio de Moraes, founded family-owned Grupo Votorantim, one of Brazil's largest conglomerates.
About_#2: Votorantim operates in more than 20 countries in the aluminum, pulp and paper, energy, agribusiness, and cement industries.
About_#3: The group dates back to 1918, when Jose Ermirio de Moraes bought a textile factory in Sao Paulo.
About_#4: The family still controls 100% of the business. Ermirio Pereira's sister, Maria Helena, is also a Votorantim shareholder and a billionaire.

Education: High School Graduate, High School
About_#1: Maria Helena Moraes Scripilliti's late father, Jose Ermirio de Moraes, founded family-owned Grupo Votorantim, one of Brazil's largest conglomerates.
About_#2: Votorantim operates in more than 20 countries in the aluminum, pulp and paper, energy, agribusiness, and cement industries.
About_#3: The group dates back to 1918, when Moraes Scripilliti's father bought a textile factory in Sao Paulo.
About_#4: The family still controls 100% of the business. Maria Helena's brother, Ermirio Pereira, is also a billionaire.

About_#1: Brothers Augusto and Giorgio Perfetti own candy and gum giant Perfetti Van Melle, a private company with more than $2.6 billion in revenues in 2018.
About_#2: The company's top-selling brands include Mentos and Airheads.
About_#3: In 2001, the Perfettis acquired Netherlands-based Van Melle. Five years later they also acquired Spain's Chupa Chups.
About_#4: Their father Ambrogio and uncle Egidio started the company in 1946 as a chewing gum business in a small town near Milan.
Did You Know?: Their father and uncle were inspired to start the company after seeing American soldiers bring gum to Europe during World War II.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, SUNY Binghamton
About_#1: Thomas Secunda is a cofounder of financial services and media company Bloomberg LP.
About_#2: He built the company's financial products, most notably its lucrative terminal business.
About_#3: Terminals account for an estimated 80% of Bloomberg LP's more than $12 billion in estimated revenue.
About_#4: He holds a 4% stake in Bloomberg LP and still leads its terminal division.

About_#1: Israeli investor Shaul Shani sold Brazilian firm Global Village Telecom to Vivendi for $4.5 billion in 2009; his take was $1.4 billion.
About_#2: He has since increased his fortune via mezzanine lending and investments in emerging economies.
About_#3: Starting in the 1980s, he cofounded three companies; two of them, Oshap Technologies and Tecnomatix, were acquired for $210 million and $228 million.
About_#4: In 2014, Shani took control of Israeli communications equipment maker ECI Telecom; he agreed to sell to publicly traded Ribbon Communications in 2019.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, College of the Holy Cross; Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School
About_#1: Joe Shoen is the president and chairman of U-Haul's parent company Amerco. He owns around 20%.
About_#2: His parents, L.S. and Anna Mary Shoen, cofounded the truck and trailer rental company in 1945.
About_#3: Worried that his father was wrecking the company, Joe led a coup in 1986, forcing his dad into retirement and alienating most of his 12 siblings.
About_#4: Despite his problems working with his own dad, Joe's son Sam is an executive at Amerco.
Did You Know?: Shoen wrote his thesis at Harvard Business School on the self-storage business.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, Los Angeles
About_#1: Steven Udvar-Hazy, who immigrated to New York from Hungary as a child, is credited with creating the airplane leasing industry.
About_#2: He started his own airline in his 20s, but realized there was easier money to be made in buying planes and leasing them to airlines.
About_#3: Udvar-Hazy's first airplane leasing firm, International Lease Finance Corp., was sold to AIG in 1990 for $1.3 billion.
About_#4: He started his second airplane leasing company, Air Lease Corp., in 2010 and took it public a year later. He remains chairman.
Did You Know?: Udvar-Hazy took his first flying lesson as a teenager and is still certified to fly multiple jets.
In Their Own Words: Growing up in Hungary, I was fascinated by airplanes because I felt closed in living in a Communist country. I looked at aviation as a route to freedom.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, San Diego State University
About_#1: Russ Weiner founded energy drink company Rockstar in 2001.
About_#2: Weiner sold Rockstar to PepsiCo in 2020, in a deal worth more than $4 billion.
About_#3: The son of right-wing talk-radio star Michael Savage, Weiner ran for California State Assembly in 1998.
About_#4: Though he lost the race, Weiner caught the eye of his father's friend, Skyy Vodka founder Maurice Kanbar, who quickly hired him.
Did You Know?: Weiner started a yard service company in his Northern California neighborhood at age 8 and worked the drive-thru at Wendy's at 15.

About_#1: Metals and mining magnate Anil Agarwal turned a tiny scrap metal business into London-headquartered Vedanta Resources.
About_#2: In October 2018, Agarwal took Vedanta private after paying more than $1 billion for the one-third of the metals firm that he didn't already own.
About_#3: His listed Sterlite Technologies has hived off its power transmission business into a separate unit and listed an infrastructure investment trust.
About_#4: Agarwal has a majority stake in India-listed Vedanta.
Did You Know?: Agarwal has pledged to give away 75% of his wealth to charity. In 2021, he signed the Giving Pledge.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Joseph M. Katz Graduate School of Business
About_#1: Former securities trader Somphote Ahunai started renewable energy outfit Energy Absolute in 2006. He took the company public in 2013.
About_#2: Energy Absolute has expanded into energy storage with a $3 billion battery gigafactory project to make lithium-ion batteries. This opened in December 2021.
About_#3: Its subsidiary, Energy Mahanakorn, has built 1,855 charge stations for electric vehicles across the country.
About_#4: Its subsidiary Mine Mobility's first electric car is a five-seat hatchback. Another unit, Absolute Assembly Company, manufactures electric buses.

Education: Master of Business Administration, University of Florence
About_#1: Patrizio Bertelli is co-CEO of the handbag and fashion empire Prada alongside his wife, Miuccia Prada, whose grandfather founded the company in 1913.
About_#2: He met Miuccia in 1977, the same year she and her siblings Alberto and Marina inherited the business.
About_#3: Patrizio, who ran a luxury leather company at the time, joined Prada a year later.
About_#4: Focusing on the business side, he pushed Prada to expand its product offerings beyond high end luggage, handbags and steamer trunks.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology; Master of Business Administration, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Airline veteran Rakesh Gangwal made his fortune from InterGlobe Aviation, the parent outfit of budget airline IndiGo, India's largest by market share.
About_#2: Gangwal started his airline career with United Airlines in 1984 and went on to run US Airways Group as its chief executive and chairman.
About_#3: Gangwal cofounded IndiGo, headquartered outside Delhi, with pal Rahul Bhatia (also a billionaire) in 2006 with one aircraft.
About_#4: The Miami resident owns close to 37% of the company and served as a board member.
Did You Know?: The Indian-born mechanical engineer studied at the Indian Institute of Technology, Kanpur before getting his M.B.A. at Wharton.

About_#1: Paul Gauselmann has been called the "pope of the amusement business" in Germany.
About_#2: He began his career in 1957 working as an apprentice telecommunications inspector and mounted jukeboxes in his spare time.
About_#3: In 1964, he founded the company that turned into Gauselmann Group. He opened the first Merkur amusement arcade in 1974.
About_#4: Today, Gauselmann Group has annual revenue of around $3 billion and employs more than 13,000 people.
Did You Know?: For his 65th birthday in 1999, Gauselmann created the Gauselmann Family Foundation operating in youth welfare and work for the elderly.

About_#1: Hao Hong is the chairman of Shenzhen-listed Asymchem Laboratories, which provides pharmaceutical outsourcing services.
About_#2: Hao Hong's wife Ye Song is a non-executive board member and serves as a board member of several Asymchem subsidiaries.
About_#3: Asymchem went public at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2016; it added a listing at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 2021.
About_#4: Hao Hong holds a Ph.D. in pharmaceutical chemistry from the Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences.

Education: Bachelor of Technology, South China University of Technology
About_#1: He Xiaopeng is the co-founder and chairman of Xpeng, an electric vehicle maker.
About_#2: Xpeng listed its shares on the New York Stock Exchange in 2020 and at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 2021..
About_#3: He founded browser UCWeb before Xpeng; UCWeb was acquired by Alibaba Group in 2014.

About_#1: Together with his brother Wolfgang, Michael Herz derives his fortune from two of Germany's most recognized companies: Tchibo and Beiersdorf.
About_#2: Their father, Max, along with Carl Tchiling-Hiryan, founded Tchibo, which imports and sells coffee, in 1949. Max passed away in 1965.
About_#3: Tchibo expanded into retailing a range of other consumer goods and services including clothing and electronics.
About_#4: Family holding company maxingvest ag controls 100% of Tchibo and around 47% of the voting shares of Beiersdorf, whose brands include Nivea and Eucerin.
Did You Know?: Max Herz came up the idea of opening stores where coffee could be both sipped and sold over the counter -- a forerunner to Starbucks.

About_#1: Together with his brother Michael, Wolfgang Herz derives his fortune from two of Germany's most recognized companies: Tchibo and Beiersdorf.
About_#2: Their father, Max, along with Carl Tchiling-Hiryan, founded Tchibo, which imports and sells coffee, in 1949. Max passed away in 1965.
About_#3: Tchibo expanded into retailing a range of other consumer goods and services including clothing and electronics.
About_#4: Family holding company maxingvest ag controls 100% of Tchibo and around 47% of the voting shares of Beiersdorf, whose brands include Nivea and Eucerin.
Did You Know?: Max Herz came up the idea of opening stores where coffee could be both sipped and sold over the counter -- a forerunner to Starbucks.

About_#1: New Brunswick native Arthur Irving owns 100% of Irving Oil, which operates gas stations and oil refineries, through the Arthur Irving Family Trust.
About_#2: Arthur is a third-generation member of a Canadian dynasty. His grandfather, James Dergavel Irving, started the family business in the late 1800s.
About_#3: His dad Kenneth Colin (K.C) Irving added oil operations in 1920s; Arthur and his 2 brothers reportedly divided up the empire after KC's death in 1992.
About_#4: Arthur's brother James Irving, also a billionaire, took over a conglomerate that spans shipbuilding to forestry.
Did You Know?: In August 2018, Irving Oil acquired Tedcastle Holdings, an Irish company that imports and distributes fuel throughout Ireland via its Top Oil brand.
