Education: Master of Science, Stockholm School of Economics
About_#1: Victor Jacobsson cofounded Klarna in 2005, pioneering the buy-now, pay-later model in fintech that flourished before stumbling in 2022.
About_#2: He left the company in 2012 but retains a stake in the business estimated at around 9%.
About_#3: Klarna lets consumers pay for small and large retail items in installments. In July 2022, private investors valued the company at $6.7 billion, down from a prior $45.6 billion.
About_#4: It is a fully licensed bank in Europe, where it offers checking accounts, savings accounts and debit cards.

About_#1: Marc Ladreit de Lacharriere is chief executive and chairman of Fimalac, an investment group primarily focused on digital media and real estate.
About_#2: Ladreit de Lacharriere purchased all of Fimalac's shares and took the company private in July 2017.
About_#3: He founded Fimalac in 1991 and bought a stake in Fitch Ratings in 1998.
About_#4: Fimalac sold 30% of Fitch Ratings to media firm Hearst for $1.97 billion at the beginning of 2015, bringing Hearst's stake to 80%.

About_#1: Paper magnate Patrick Lee was born in Hainan, came to Hong Kong as an orphan and learned the art of trading from an uncle.
About_#2: After early success in handbags he noticed that he was having trouble finding boxes for his exports, leading to him to start a paper company.
About_#3: Today, Lee & Man Paper is an industrial-packaging behemoth in China.
About_#4: Sons Raymond and Edmond run operations. Lee now spends his time mentoring students.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Vanderbilt University
About_#1: Max Lytvyn cofounded popular grammar checking tool Grammarly in 2009 with Alex Shevchenko and Dmytro Lider; his current title is head of revenue.
About_#2: The three Ukrainian-born entrepreneurs all worked together on Lytvyn and Shevchenko's previous startup, My Dropbox, a plagiarism detection service.
About_#3: They came up with the idea to launch Grammarly as a subscription-based product aimed at helping students with grammar and spelling.
About_#4: Now using a freemium model, the company claims to reach 30 million people a day and boasts big-name clients like Zoom, Cisco and Dell.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Ecole centrale de Paris; Master, Syracuse University; Ph.D, Syracuse University
About_#1: Gilles Martin is the executive chairman of Eurofins Scientific, a Luxembourg-based laboratory services company listed on the French stock exchange.
About_#2: Martin, who founded the original lab in 1987, owns an estimated 25% of the company through the family's holding company Analytical Bioventures.
About_#3: His brother Yves-Loic owns an estimated 11% stake. He served as CTO from 1998 until 2015 and now is a board member.
About_#4: Eurofins has 400 labs in 41 countries and is prominent in food and pharmaceutical products testing.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Colgate University; Master of Business Administration, University of Chicago Booth School of Business
About_#1: Ramzi Musallam joined private equity firm Veritas Capital in 1997 and became CEO in 2012 after founder Robert McKeon's death.
About_#2: Since Musallam took over, Veritas' assets under management have grown from $2 billion to $43 billion.
About_#3: Veritas specializes in acquiring companies in heavily regulated industries like national security, healthcare and education.
About_#4: In October 2020, Dyal Capital Partners bought an 11.8% stake in Veritas that valued the firm at $6.15 billion.
In Their Own Words: "I, and the firm, maintain a very close proximity to government because government is at the forefront of all the complexities and issues that confront us."

About_#1: Georg Nemetschek is the founder and deputy chairman of software company Nemetschek Group, which has over 3,000 employees and users in 142 countries.
About_#2: He started using design software in his own engineering office in the late 1960s, long before computers became available for personal use.
About_#3: The company, which serves the architecture, engineering and construction industries, went public in 1999.
About_#4: Nemetschek Group expanded into 3D animation and motion design, securing access to the media industry. Its software has around six million users.
Did You Know?: In 1971, he was appointed as a professor at the Munich University of Applied Sciences. He served as dean of the Civil Engineering department from 1977 to 1996.
In Their Own Words: The success of Nemetschek SE cannot only be credited to our personal performance, but also to the competence of our staff and the political and social environment in the German Federal Republic, which has safeguarded a framework of entrepreneurship.

About_#1: Akio Nitori founded discount home furnishings chain Nitori Holdings; its shares trade on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
About_#2: The company has expanded in urban markets like Tokyo and has more than 600 stores mostly in Japan.
About_#3: Nitori, the firm's chairman, founded the first store in 1967. He stepped down as president in 2016.
About_#4: The chain has stores outside Japan in China, Taiwan and the U.S.
Did You Know?: To earn money for college tuition and expenses, he worked collecting unpaid bar tabs and hustling pool, among other jobs.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Dan Och founded Och-Ziff Capital Management, now a publicly traded hedge fund firm, in 1994.
About_#2: Och stepped down as chairman in 2019 after years of client withdrawals and no longer has a role with the hedge fund.
About_#3: The firm changed its name to Sculptor Capital Management in August 2019, further cutting its ties with its founder.
About_#4: Och now runs his family office, Willoughby Capital, a growth equity investor with a portfolio that includes Robinhood, Coinbase and Instacart.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Gujarat University; Master of Science, Gujarat University
About_#1: Indian pharma magnate Pankaj Patel controls listed company Zydus Lifesciences (formerly Cadila Healthcare), which was cofounded by his late father in 1952 to make vitamins.
About_#2: A pharmacy grad, Patel joined the firm in 1976 and took charge in 1995 after a formal separation between the two founding families.
About_#3: The $1.9 billion (revenue) generics maker is headquartered in Ahmedabad.
About_#4: His son Sharvil has been the company's managing director since July 2017.
Did You Know?: Patel is also chairman of the board of governors of the Indian Institute of Management-Udaipur.
In Their Own Words: What we do tomorrow is more important than what we did yesterday.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, New York University
About_#1: John Paulson made his fortune betting against subprime mortgages at the peak of the 2007 credit bubble.
About_#2: His hedge fund firm, Paulson & Co., was started in 1994 and enjoyed success as a niche fund until Paulson put on his "big short" in 2007.
About_#3: In July 2020, Paulson announced that he would be returning capital to investors and converting his hedge fund into a family office.
About_#4: Paulson's hedge funds managed $36 billion at their peak, but by the end of 2018 they totaled about $6 billion.

Education: Doctorate, University of Milan; Doctorate in Pedagogical Sciences, University of Milan
About_#1: Miuccia Prada is the co-CEO and lead designer of the handbag and fashion empire Prada, which was founded in 1913 by her grandfather.
About_#2: She runs the business with her husband and co-CEO, fellow billionaire Patrizio Bertelli.
About_#3: In 1977 she and her siblings Alberto and Marina inherited the company.
About_#4: That same year, Miuccia met Bertelli, who ran a luxury leather company at the time but joined Prada a year later.
Did You Know?: Muiccia reportedly spent five years training and performing as a mime.
In Their Own Words: You need to be curious and never stop studying. You have to challenge yourself to think every day to understand and react to what is happening.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University
About_#1: One of 11 billionaire heirs to the Hyatt Hotels fortune, Jean "Gigi" Pritzker is a Los Angeles-based movie producer.
About_#2: In 2015 she founded Madison Wells Media, a media and entertainment company that champions ?badass women? and unknown stories.
About_#3: Films she has produced include "Drive," "Rabbit Hole," "Ender's Game," and the Oscar-nominated "Hell or High Water? and Oscar-winning ?The Eyes of Tammy Faye.?
About_#4: Through her Pritzker Pucker Family Foundation, she donates to the arts, education and community-oriented nonprofits.
Did You Know?: The name of her company, Madison Wells Media, is named for her great-grandfather who sold newspapers at the corner of Madison Avenue and Wells Street in Chicago.
In Their Own Words: The reality of this business is it's extremely mercurial and you don't have control over most pieces...There's a lot of reflection after each film. This isn't a business for the faint of heart.

About_#1: The richest grocer in Spain, Juan Roig is president and majority owner of supermarket giant Mercadona.
About_#2: Roig, his brother Fernando and wife Hortensia Herrero, also billionaires, bought the chain in 1981 from the Roigs' father when it had just 8 stores.
About_#3: By 2006, Mercadona had opened its 1,000th store; it now has more than 1,600 locations, including nearly 30 stores in Portugal.
About_#4: Mercadona's 95,000 employees receive a 25% share of the company's pretax profits.
Did You Know?: Roig created an "innovation cluster" in Valencia, Spain, where he invests in young entrepreneurs.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Duke University; Doctor of Jurisprudence, University of Chicago
About_#1: David Rubenstein is one of three billionaire founders of private equity firm Carlyle Group, which is approaching $400 billion in assets under management.
About_#2: He cofounded Carlyle in 1987 with William Conway Jr. and Daniel D'Aniello. He now serves as non-executive co-chairman.
About_#3: Rubenstein got his start as a Carter Administration official and later became an attorney.
About_#4: In the early days Rubenstein raised the money and managed Carlyle's stable of advisers, which included George H.W. Bush.
Did You Know?: In 2007 Rubenstein bought one of just four surviving originals of the 13th-century Magna Carta for $24.5 million from late billionaire H. Ross Perot.
In Their Own Words: The obsession with the making of money rarely leads to the actual making of money. The obsession with achieving excellence and with doing the best job possible, doing something no one else can do as well is usually what leads to making a fortune.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Northern Michigan University
About_#1: Howard Schultz took charge of Starbucks in the 1980s and turned a regional coffee company into one of the world's top brands.
About_#2: Schultz expanded Starbucks from 11 stores to more than 33,000 worldwide and made it a social hub for many Americans.
About_#3: In 2018, he stepped down from a company he joined in 1982. Returning in 2022, he serves as the Starbucks interim CEO, while searching for a successor.
About_#4: Schultz explored a 2020 presidential bid, but said in September 2019 that he would not run because it would risk the re-election of Donald Trump.
Did You Know?: Schultz grew up in a Brooklyn housing project. When he was 7, his dad, a cloth diaper delivery driver, fell on the job; he had no insurance or salary.
In Their Own Words: From day one, I wanted to build the kind of company my father never got a chance to work for. A company that honors and respects the dignity of work and the dignity of all men and all women.

Education: Master of Business Administration, University of Toronto
About_#1: Alex Shevchenko is the cofounder of popular grammar checking tool Grammarly and serves as product lead.
About_#2: He launched the company in 2009 alongside fellow Ukrainian entrepreneurs Max Lytvyn and Dmytro Lider.
About_#3: The trio had all worked together on Lytvyn and Shevchenko's previous startup, My Dropbox, a plagiarism detector.
About_#4: Initially programmed as a service to help students with their grammar and spelling, Grammarly claims it today reaches 30 million people a day.

Education: Drop Out, University of Maryland
About_#1: Dan Snyder initially made his fortune with a marketing business, Snyder Communications, that he started as a college dropout.
About_#2: After taking the company public in 1996, Snyder sold it to French firm Havas for $2.1 billion in stock in 2000.
About_#3: In 1999, he bought the NFL's Washington DC franchise for $750 million, borrowing $350 million to do so; it's now worth $4.2 billion.
About_#4: After years of controversy over the Native American origins of the team's former name, the Redskins, Snyder renamed the team the Commanders in 2022.
Did You Know?: In 1996, Snyder was the youngest public-company CEO on the New York Stock Exchange.

About_#1: Jerzy Starak chairs the supervisory board of Polpharma, one of Poland's largest drug manufacturers.
About_#2: Polpharma specializes in pharmaceuticals used in cardiology, neurology and gastroenterology.
About_#3: A diversified investor, Starak also holds a stake in publicly traded agribusiness ZT Kruszwica and herbal product producer Herbapol.
About_#4: Starak started out with chemical company Comindex in the 1970s.

About_#1: Udo and Harald Tschira are the sons of Klaus Tschira, the software pioneer who cofounded SAP (Systems, Applications, Products) in 1972.
About_#2: Klaus retired from the company in 1998, stepped down from its supervisory board in 2007, and passed away in 2015.
About_#3: He was a trained physicist and hobby astronomer; an asteroid between Mars and Jupiter has been named after him.
About_#4: His sons carry on the activities of the Klaus Tschira Foundation, which promotes learning in natural sciences, mathematics and computer science.
Did You Know?: Klaus Tschira's passion for astronomy began at an early age. His classmates at school called him "the planet kid."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Texas Arlington
About_#1: Kelcy Warren cofounded pipeline company Energy Transfer in 1996.
About_#2: Warren, who cofounded the company with fellow billionaire Ray Davis, stepped down as CEO in 2020 but remains executive chairman.
About_#3: Energy Transfer operates over 120,000 miles of pipeline that move approximately 30% of America's oil and natural gas.
About_#4: In 2017, despite protests, Energy Transfer finished building the $3.8 billion Dakota Access Pipeline after an executive order by President Donald Trump.
Did You Know?: When he was young, Warren spent summers working with his dad as a welder's assistant on Sun Pipeline in Texas.

Education: Associate in Arts/Science, Brevard Community College; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Southern College of Optometry; Doctorate, Southern College of Optometry
About_#1: Herbert "Herbie" Wertheim is an optometrist and inventor who built a fortune over five decades of investing in stocks.
About_#2: Wertheim, who is dyslexic and struggled in school, joined the U.S. Navy at age 17 after facing truancy charges.
About_#3: He founded and still runs Brain Power Inc., a manufacturer of optical tints for eyeglasses; it holds more than 100 patents and copyrights.
About_#4: Since 1970, he has invested his profits from Brain Power into the stock market and is the largest individual shareholder in aerospace firm Heico.
Did You Know?: As a child, Wertheim ran away from home, finding work picking oranges in Florida or living with the Seminole Indians.
In Their Own Words: "If you want to become a millionaire, you learn how to make a dollar, and you do it over and over until you have a million."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Harvard University
About_#1: Identical twins Cameron and Tyler Winklevoss cofounded cryptocurrency exchange Gemini in 2014; today it processes about $200 million a day in trades.
About_#2: Cameron is Gemini's president; Tyler is CEO.
About_#3: The former Olympic rowers are best known for accusing Mark Zuckerberg of stealing their idea for a social network.
About_#4: They used some of their $65 million legal settlement with the Facebook CEO to start stockpiling Bitcoin.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Harvard University
About_#1: Identical twins Tyler and Cameron Winklevoss cofounded cryptocurrency exchange Gemini in 2014; today it processes about $200 million a day in trades.
About_#2: Tyler is Gemini's CEO; Cameron is president.
About_#3: The former Olympic rowers are best known for accusing Mark Zuckerberg of stealing their idea for a social network.
About_#4: They used some of their $65 million legal settlement with the Facebook CEO to start stockpiling Bitcoin.

About_#1: Denise York's family owns over 90% of the San Francisco 49ers, one of the 10 most valuable teams in the NFL.
About_#2: York's father, Edward Debartolo Sr. (d. 1994) bought the team for $13 million in 1977. It is now worth $5.2 billion.
About_#3: York took control of the 49ers in 2000 from her brother, Edward Jr., who found himself in legal trouble after owning the team for 23 years.
About_#4: Denise and her husband John have four children, the oldest of whom, Jed, serves as the current CEO of the 49ers.
Did You Know?: York's first job after college was building the HR department of the family's company.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Tsinghua University
About_#1: Zhao Lixin is the CEO of China semiconductor supplier GalaxyCore
About_#2: GalaxyCore went public at the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 2021
About_#3: GalaxyCore's customers include Oppo, Xiaomi, Samsung and Lenovo
About_#4: GalaxyCore was founded in 2003

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Ludwig Maxmilian University
About_#1: Known for his glamorous lifestyle, Hubert Burda inherited and ran his family's media company for over 20 years before handing over the reins in 2010.
About_#2: He has transferred Burda Media shares to his two children, Elisabeth and Jacob (each now hold 37.4% of the company).
About_#3: However, because "rights of usufruct" entitle Hubert to receive economic benefits from those shares, Forbes attributes the ownership to him.
About_#4: Burda Media's portfolio consists of 600 media products in 20 countries, including Focus and Bunte and the German editions of Cosmopolitan and Playboy.
Did You Know?: Hubert founded the Felix Burda Foundation after his son Felix died of colon cancer at age 33. It's focused on raising awareness about the cancer.

About_#1: Francesco Gaetano Caltagirone is the president of Caltagirone, a holding company with interests in construction, cement, real estate, finance and publishing.
About_#2: His family, which hails from Sicily, was in the construction and real estate business, which he expanded and took into other sectors.
About_#3: In 1999, after buying several papers, he built media group Caltagirone Editore, Italy's sixth largest newspaper publisher.
About_#4: The bulk of his wealth is now stakes in two publicly traded firms: insurance company Assicurazioni Generali and cement giant Cementir.
Did You Know?: An engineer by training, Caltagirone got his degree while working for the family business.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Marcos Galperin is founder and CEO of e-commerce platform MercadoLibre, the eBay of Latin America.
About_#2: MercadoLibre, which operates in 18 Latin American countries and Portugal, went public in 2007 on the Nasdaq.
About_#3: Galperin majored in economics and finance at the University of Pennsylvania and got an MBA from Stanford University.
About_#4: He worked at Argentine oil company YPF for three years and as a summer intern at JPMorgan before starting MercadoLibre in 1999.
Did You Know?: eBay, once MercadoLibre's largest shareholder with 18%, sold its stake in 2016 for more than $1 billion.
In Their Own Words: Successful entrepreneurs are typically stubborn contrarians, since creating a new reality that most people believe cannot exist will typically take a lot of time and several failures along the way.

About_#1: Li Xiang is the founder and CEO of Beijing-based electric vehicle startup Li Auto, which listed on the Nasdaq in July 2020.
About_#2: The firm is known for its six seat SUV Li One, which features both a battery pack and a gas-powered engine that charges the battery on the go.
About_#3: This technology allows Li Auto to build EVs with smaller, more affordable batteries while maintaining long driving ranges.
About_#4: Li Xiang, who founded Li Auto in 2015, is also the founder of New York Stock Exchange listed Chinese website Autohome Inc.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Dartmouth College; Master of Business Administration, Harvard University; Diploma, Phillips Academy Exeter
About_#1: One of Julian Robertson's "Tiger Cubs," Stephen Mandel started his hedge fund firm, Lone Pine Capital, in 1997.
About_#2: Mandel stepped back from managing investments for Lone Pine Capital in January 2019 but remains a managing director.
About_#3: Mandel built up a reputation as one of the hedge fund industry's best when it comes to fundamental analysis and bottom-up stock picking.
About_#4: Mandel has poured hundreds of millions into his Zoom Foundation. The hedge fund also has its Lone Pine Foundation.
Did You Know?: Mandel donates to the Environmental Defense Fund, of which he is a board trustee.
In Their Own Words: If you can manage a classroom and inspire kids, it's going to be a hard thing for you to do, but it's just unbelievable preparation for anything you're going to do in life.

Education: Drop Out, Harvard University
About_#1: Gabe Newell has led Valve Corp., which develops video games, since he cofounded it in 1998 with former Microsoft colleague Mike Harrington.
About_#2: The company found initial success with games like Half-Life and Portal.
About_#3: Valve Corp. plays a big role in PC game sales through its Steam digital store; some liken it to the iTunes of video games.
About_#4: Steam sells game licenses to 125 million users of its own and other developers' titles and collects a percentage of the sales.
Did You Know?: Newell was hired by Steve Ballmer as Microsoft's 271st employee after dropping out of Harvard.

About_#1: Maja Oeri is a descendant of Fritz Hoffmann-La Roche, founder of Switzerland-based pharma behemoth Roche.
About_#2: She is a controlling shareholder of Roche, with just over 7.5% of the voting equity of the company.
About_#3: At least fifteen other members of her extended family own shares of Roche as a group with pooled voting rights.
About_#4: Oeri, a patron of the arts who studied art history in college, serves as a vice chair on the board of the Museum of Modern Art in New York City.

Education: Certificate, Harvard Business School
About_#1: Paolo and Gianfelice Rocca oversee the Techint Group, the global conglomerate founded by their grandfather, industrialist Agostino Rocca.
About_#2: Agostino helped build Italy's steel industry in the 1930s then launched the Techint Group in Argentina in 1945.
About_#3: Its companies operate in steel production, engineering and construction projects, mining, oil and gas and the Italian hospital and healthcare sector.
About_#4: In all the Techint Group pulls in more than $22 billion in annual sales and employs about 52,000 people globally.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Shanghai Jiaotong University; Master of Arts, Yale University
About_#1: Neil Shen is the founding and managing partner of Sequoia China, the Chinese arm of a successful Silicon Valley venture capital firm.
About_#2: After three years as the Midas List's top investor, Shen appeared second in 2021 and third in 2022 due to TikTok parent ByteDance, Meituan and Pinduoduo.
About_#3: Shen was a successful entrepreneur himself earlier on in his career, cofounding travel site Ctrip.com before joining Sequoia.
About_#4: Shen had previously worked as an investment banker at Deutsche Bank Hong Kong, Chemical Bank, Lehman Brothers and Citibank.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, Southern Methodist University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Vienna
About_#1: Helmut Sohmen was chairman of the shipping giant BW Group for 28 years, before he stepped down and handed the reins to son Andreas in 2014.
About_#2: The Austrian citizen has lived in Hong Kong for decades and is married to Anna Pui Hing Pao, the eldest daughter of the late shipping tycoon Y.K. Pao.
About_#3: He supports a graduate scholarship program for Chinese lawyers studying at his alma mater, Southern Methodist University in Texas.
About_#4: His billionaire brother-in-law, Peter Woo, controls Wheelock & Co., a Hong Kong-based real estate firm.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, California State Los Angeles; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Southwestern Law School
About_#1: Donald Sterling, born Donald Tokowitz to Jewish immigrants, built a fortune largely by buying down-at-the-heels apartment buildings in Los Angeles.
About_#2: Sterling owned the Los Angeles Clippers for 33 years; his wife Shelly sold in 2014 after a tape of his racist remarks to his then-mistress surfaced.
About_#3: The Chicago-born billionaire bought the Clippers in 1981 for $12.5 million when the team was based in San Diego. It was sold for $2 billion.
About_#4: Besides a swath of apartments in L.A.'s Westside and Koreatown, he also owns the Beverly Hills Plaza Hotel.
Did You Know?: In 2006, Sterling was sued by the Department of Justice on the charge of refusing to rent to African-Americans.

Education: High School Graduate, High School
About_#1: Arizona Beverages cofounder Don Vultaggio has built his fortune one 99-cent tallboy can of iced tea at a time.
About_#2: He got his start in the 1970s selling beer and soda from the back of an old van in Brooklyn's toughest neighborhoods, where others refused to go.
About_#3: In 1992 he went into iced tea, launching Arizona from a Brooklyn warehouse and quickly toppling the competition with taller cans and flashier labels.
About_#4: Arizona sells some $4 billion worth of tea, juice, water and alcoholic drinks annually, including its popular green tea and Arnold Palmer lines.
Did You Know?: Arizona's flamboyant, Southwest-themed packaging was inspired by his Queens home, which stood out thanks to white and turquoise stucco and a cactus garden out front.
In Their Own Words: The simple math says if you get the price that makes a consumer want to buy it and buy it again, and the competition doesn't look as good or taste as good, you've got a business.

Education: Medical Doctor, Hebei Medical University; Medical Doctor, Nanjing University of Chinese Medicine
About_#1: Wu Yiling chairs Yiling Pharmaceutical, which makes cardiovascular and flu drugs, among others.
About_#2: Wu, whose father was a doctor, practiced Chinese medicine for 11 years himself before he founded Yiling Pharmaceutical in 1992.
About_#3: Yiling's Lianhua Qingwen capsules have been recommended by China health experts for treating mild Covid cases.
About_#4: The company is listed on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange.

About_#1: Zhu Gongshan chairs GCL-Poly Energy Holdings, a producer of polysilicon used to make solar panels.
About_#2: Zhu is active in business groups, including the Global Green Energy Council and Asian Photovoltaic Industry Association.
About_#3: Son Zhu Yufeng is a member of GCL-Poly's board of directors.
About_#4: Chu also chairs GCL System Integration Technology, whose shares trade at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange.

Education: High School Graduate, High School
About_#1: Gayle Benson is the widow of Tom Benson (d. March 2018), former owner of the NFL New Orleans Saints and NBA New Orleans Pelicans.
About_#2: She is now the owner of both teams, despite a multi-year dispute with Tom's daughter and grandchildren over control of family assets.
About_#3: Family members sued, claiming Tom was mentally incompetent; the parties ended the dispute in early 2017 with a confidential settlement.
About_#4: Gayle worked as an interior designer starting in the 1970s and founded thoroughbred horse racing company GMB Racing in 2014.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Dartmouth College
About_#1: William Conway Jr. is one of three billionaire founders of private equity firm Carlyle Group.
About_#2: Conway stepped down as co-CEO in January 2018 and now serves as non-executive co-chairman with cofounder and billionaire David Rubenstein.
About_#3: The trio took Carlyle public on the Nasdaq exchange in 2012 and the firm is now approaching $400 billion in assets under management.
About_#4: They used their Beltway connections--George H.W. Bush was among their advisers--to invest in defense-oriented companies.
Did You Know?: Conway was owner of Merrywood, Jackie O's childhood home in McLean, Virginia, until 2005 when he sold the estate to former AOL CEO Steve Case for $24.5 million.
In Their Own Words: As you're trying to build your net worth, don't confuse it with your self-worth, which is much more important.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Punjab University
About_#1: Gurbachan Singh Dhingra is the vice chairman of Berger Paints India, the country's second-largest paint maker by revenue.
About_#2: He controls the company with his brother Kuldip Singh Dhingra, also a billionaire.
About_#3: In 1991 the brothers bought Berger Paints, then the country's smallest paint maker, from liquor tycoon Vijay Mallya.
About_#4: Apart from India, Berger has a presence in Bangladesh, Nepal, Poland and Russia.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Delhi University
About_#1: Kuldip Singh Dhingra chairs Berger Paints India, the country's second-largest paint maker by revenue.
About_#2: Djhngra and his brother Gurbachan Singh Dhingra, also a billionaire, have a controlling stake in the company.
About_#3: In 1991 they bought Berger Paints, then the country's smallest paint maker, from former billionaire Vijay Mallya.
About_#4: Apart from India, Berger has a presence in Bangladesh, Nepal, Poland and Russia.

Education: Bachelor of Commerce, Bocconi University
About_#1: Luca Garavoglia is chairman of Campari Group, one of the world's largest alcoholic beverage companies.
About_#2: Campari's brands includes Skyy Vodka, Wild Turkey, Aperol and Campari.
About_#3: Garavoglia inherited his stake in the company from his parents. His mother, Rosa Anna Magno Garavoglia, died in 2016.
About_#4: He now owns an estimated 27% of the company, which listed on the Milan Stock Exchange in 2001.
Did You Know?: His Campari group reportedly sold a villa on the French riviera to fellow billionaire Rinat Akhmetov in January 2020 for 200 million euros.

About_#1: Mother and son Vinod and Anil Rai Gupta draw their fortune from their holding in flagship Havells India.
About_#2: The company, which is run by Anil, makes everything from electrical and lighting fixtures to fans, refrigerators and washing machines.
About_#3: Havells was founded by Vinod's late husband Qimat Rai Gupta in 1958 as an electricals trading business.
About_#4: The company has 14 factories and sells in more than 50 countries.
Did You Know?: The late founder bought the brand 'Havells' from a Delhi trader back in 1971.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Tennessee Knoxville
About_#1: Jimmy Haslam is chairman of Pilot Flying J, the truck stop company founded in 1958 by his father, who paid $6,000 for a gas station in Virginia.
About_#2: Berkshire Hathaway paid a reported $2.8 billion for 39% of Pilot in 2017 and will acquire another 41% by 2023.
About_#3: Pilot has more than 800 locations in North America and generates about $26 billion in annual revenue.
About_#4: Haslam joined the board in 1975, when he was 20 and a senior at the University of Tennessee; Pilot's annual sales were about $50 million at the time.
Did You Know?: His brother Bill Haslam, also a billionaire, served as governor of Tennessee from 2011 to 2019.

About_#1: Susan Carol Holland is the chair of the board of Milan-based Amplifon, the world's largest retailer of hearing aids.
About_#2: Amplifon was founded in 1955 by her father, British-born Algernon Charles Holland, to provide hearing care for people injured in World War II.
About_#3: Her father served in the British Special Operations Executive during the war, receiving the honor of Member of the Order of the British Empire.
About_#4: Amplifon developed digital hearing aids in the 1990s and entered the North American market with the acquisition of Miracle-Ear in 1990.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Moscow State University
About_#1: In 1992, Timur Kulibaev created the company Altyn Alma to engage in financial and investment activities; it later morphed into Almex LLP.
About_#2: An investment in mobile service paid off in 2004, when a company he controlled sold Kar-Tel, operating in Kazakhstan, to VimpleCom for $350 million.
About_#3: In 2014, he sold Altynalmas Gold to Polymetal, part-owned by Russian billionaire Alexander Nesis, for cash and company shares.
About_#4: Kulibaev and his wife, Dinara, own a majority stake in Halyk Bank of Kazakhstan.
Did You Know?: Timur Kulibaev has been known to deploy layers of offshore entities in his transactions.

Education: Doctorate in Pedagogical Sciences, State Institute of Theatre Arts (GITIS, Moscow)
About_#1: A daughter of Kazakhstan's former president Nursultan Nazarbayev, Dinara Kulibaeva jointly owns a majority of Halyk Bank with her husband, Timur Kulibaev.
About_#2: Their portfolio also includes investments focused on the construction, operation and servicing of oil and gas wells.
About_#3: She benefited from the 2014 sale of Altynalmas Gold to Polymetal, part-owned by Russian billionaire Alexander Nesis, for cash and company shares.
About_#4: Forbes assumes all of Kulibaeva's assets are owned 50/50 with Timur, giving them an equal net worth.
Did You Know?: A graduate of Moscow's Institute of Theater Arts, Kulibaeva served as head of the president's education foundation, which supports Kazakh students with financial aid

About_#1: Michel Leclercq set up a small sporting goods store called Decathlon in 1976.
About_#2: It's now one of the world's largest athletic retailers with more than $15 billion in sales from more than 1,500 stores in 51 countries.
About_#3: Leclercq is cousin of Gerard Mulliez, the patriarch of the famed French retail dynasty behind Auchan department stores.
About_#4: Leclerq and his immediate family own approximately 40% of the company; the extended Mulliez family own about 40% as well.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Universidad Iberoamericana
About_#1: Pablo Legorreta is the founder of Royalty Pharma, the world's biggest acquirer of pharmaceutical royalty streams.
About_#2: Royalty Pharma, which conducted an IPO in 2020, has collected revenue slices of blockbuster drugs like Humira, Imbruvica, Lyrica, and Xtandi.
About_#3: A former investment banker at Lazard Fr?res, Legoretta started Royalty Pharma in New York as a private equity vehicle in 1996.
About_#4: Legoretta is the sole owner of RP Management, the investment manager that oversees Royalty Pharma's $17 billion of assets.

About_#1: Margarita Louis-Dreyfus is the majority owner and chairwoman of agricultural commodities giant Louis-Dreyfus.
About_#2: Her husband Robert Louis-Dreyfus died of leukemia in 2009, leaving her a 69.6% stake in the now 167-year-old business.
About_#3: She reportedly pledged her shares to take out a $1 billion loan in 2019 to buy out minority stakes owned by family members.
About_#4: In 2016, she sold French soccer team Olympique Marseille to former Dodgers owner Frank McCourt, but held onto a 5% stake.
Did You Know?: Born and raised in Russia, Louis-Dreyfus was reportedly orphaned at age 11 when her parents died in a train crash.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, Berkeley; Master of Business Administration, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Mike Milken joined what became investment bank Drexel Burnham Lambert in 1969 and expanded the market for high-yield junk bonds.
About_#2: He was banned from the securities industry after pleading guilty to securities fraud in 1990. In February 2020, President Trump pardoned him.
About_#3: Milken chairs the Milken Institute think tank, which produces the annual Milken Global Conference in Los Angeles, the Davos of the West Coast.
About_#4: Milken has investments in private equity, hedge funds, venture capital and more than one asset management firm.
Did You Know?: Milken founded what is now called the Prostate Cancer Foundation in 1993 after his own battle with prostate cancer.
In Their Own Words: Finance can change the world and create millions of jobs by empowering people with ability.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Carroll School of Management
About_#1: Denis O'Brien runs and owns 94% of Digicel, a mobile phone network provider that operates in the Caribbean, Asia Pacific and Central America.
About_#2: Following the 2010 earthquake in Haiti he funded the restoration of Port-au-Prince's Iron Market and his Digicel Foundation built 150 schools.
About_#3: O'Brien got his big break selling his Irish mobile outfit, Esat Telecom Group, to British Telecom Group in 2000 for $2.8 billion.
About_#4: He has investments in healthcare and the PGA Catalunya and Quinta do Lago resorts on the Iberian peninsula.
Did You Know?: O'Brien once sold horse pills.
In Their Own Words: If you just focus on risk, you can't do a thing.

About_#1: Writer and filmmaker Katharina Otto-Bernstein is the daughter of late Werner Otto, who turned his mail-order business in Hamburg into a global empire.
About_#2: She inherited a minority stake in Otto Group and its more than 40 companies in retail (Crate and Barrel), real estate and financial services.
About_#3: She's also a shareholder of ECE, the family's commercial real estate company focused on shopping centers. Her brother Alexander is CEO.
About_#4: She, her mother Maren and brother Alexander share a 15% stake in Paramount Group, which owns and manages office properties in the U.S.
Did You Know?: Katharina is a member of the board of directors of the Metropolitan Opera as well as the International Council of the Guggenheim Museum.

About_#1: Packer is the largest shareholder of Crown Resorts, which owns casinos in Australia and London. He took over the empire of his late father, Kerry.
About_#2: Packer stepped down from Crown Resorts' board in March 2018. Four months later, he resigned from the board of his family company, Consolidated Press.
About_#3: Packer's board exits were reportedly due to mental health issues, following a tough year when Crown exited its Macau and U.S. gambling investments.
About_#4: Packer settled with his older sister Gretel in 2015, agreeing to a division of assets 10 years after their late father's death.
Did You Know?: Packer was briefly engaged to American singer Mariah Carey but he broke off the engagement and reportedly had to pay her a settlement.

Education: Law Degree, University of Ferrara
About_#1: Sergio Stevanato is chairman of the board emeritus of the Stevanato Group, a medical packaging firm based in Piombino Dese, Italy.
About_#2: Founded by his father Giovanni in 1949, the company is now run by his sons Franco and Marco, who serve as chairman and vice chairman, respectively.
About_#3: Stevanato Group went public on the New York Stock Exchange in July 2021.
About_#4: Stevanato Group is the second-largest maker of glass vials in the world and a major supplier of vials for several Covid-19 vaccine manufacturers.
Did You Know?: He owns a winery in northeast Italy, Tenuta Stella, named after the Stevanato Group's original name, Soffieria Stella.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Boston University; B.Com, University of Mumbai
About_#1: The media-shy heir of a pharma fortune, Leena Tewari chairs privately held USV India, which her late father Vithal Gandhi set up with Revlon in 1961.
About_#2: USV specializes in diabetic and cardiovascular drugs, with a portfolio that spans biosimilar drugs, injectables and active pharmaceutical ingredients.
About_#3: The $511 million (revenue) company is run by her husband, Prashant, an Indian Institute of Technology grad and mechanical engineer from Cornell.
About_#4: In 2018, USV acquired German generics firm Juta Pharma for an undisclosed sum.
Did You Know?: Tewari loves animals and travels into forests across India.

About_#1: Yitzhak Tshuva made his billions in energy and real estate.
About_#2: His private El Ad Group, a real estate firm, has developments in Manhattan, Florida, Louisiana, Montreal and Israel.
About_#3: His is also the controlling shareholder of Delek Group, a publicly-traded conglomerate with interests in automotives, oil and gas.
About_#4: His family immigrated from Libya to Israel when he was six months old. He later served in the Israeli army and worked in Israel's Ministry of Defense.

About_#1: Paul-Heinz Wesjohann is the chairman and namesake of Germany-based PHW Group, with $3 billion in annual sales.
About_#2: PHW is the owner of Wiesenhof, which is the largest poultry processor in Germany. Overall the group employs 7,000 across Europe.
About_#3: The firm also manufactures plant-based products for brands including Beyond Meat and Livekindly in Europe.
About_#4: PHW Group was founded in 1999, when Wesjohann and his brother Erich decided to split up their family chicken company, originally dating to 1932.

About_#1: Zeng Fangqin chairs Lingyi Technology, a parts supplier for smartphones, tablets and laptop computers.
About_#2: Its products are used by Apple and Huawei.
About_#3: Zeng returned to China after starting her career in Silicon Valley.
About_#4: In March 2018, Zeng completed a backdoor listing of Lingyi Technology on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange for around $3.2 billion.

About_#1: Zhou Bajin and his daughter Zhou Xiaoping control Changzhou Xingyu Automotive Light Systems, a supplier of automotive lighting systems.
About_#2: Xingyu's customers include BMW.
About_#3: Daughter Xiaoping is Xingyu's chairman.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, New York University
About_#1: William R. Berkley founded insurance firm W.R. Berkley with only $2,500 in 1967 while he was getting his MBA from Harvard.
About_#2: His company, which went public in 1974, insures everything from mobile surgery units to jewels to fine art and has operations in 60 countries.
About_#3: Berkley stepped down as CEO in 2015 but remains chairman; he owns 20% of the company, which generated $9.5 billion in sales in 2021.
About_#4: His son, William Robert Berkley Jr., is the current CEO and president.
Did You Know?: Berkley chairs the board of trustees of NYU, his alma mater.

Education: Drop Out, New York University
About_#1: John Catsimatidis is best known as the owner of New York City supermarket chain Gristedes.
About_#2: He also owns oil refinery United Refining in Pennsylvania, which he bought out of bankruptcy, and real estate in New York and beyond.
About_#3: He moved with his family from Greece to New York when he was an infant and grew up in an apartment in Harlem.
About_#4: He worked as a grocery clerk while attending New York University but dropped out for a chance to own a piece of the shop where he worked.
Did You Know?: Catsimatidis has a weekly talk radio show, the Cats Roundtable, during which he interviews people involved in politics.

About_#1: Che Jianxing is the founder of Red Star Macalline, one of China's largest furniture retailers.
About_#2: Che took up carpentry instead of finishing high school.
About_#3: He and his colleagues started a store with $80,000 and 500 pieces of furniture in 1988.

About_#1: Gustavo Denegri is the chairman of biotech company DiaSorin SpA; the bulk of his fortune is a 45% stake in the publicly-traded company.
About_#2: In 2000, his private equity firm acquired the distressed DiaSorin from American Standard Companies and built it into a global player in diagnostics.
About_#3: His first breakthrough came when his Gruppo Pro-Ind, a components firm, merged with Piaggio, owner of motor scooters Vespa and Aprilia.
About_#4: He is one of few Italian businessmen to have built billion-dollar companies in more than one sector.

About_#1: Charles Edelstenne cofounded Dassault Systèmes, aviation giant Dassault's software and consulting arm, in 1981.
About_#2: Today he and his family own around 6% of French-listed Dassault Systèmes; he is chairman of the board.
About_#3: A qualified accountant, Edelstenne started working at Dassault Aviation in 1960 as head of the financial studies department.
About_#4: He has served in a variety of leadership positions at Dassault, including CEO stints at both Dassault Systèmes and Dassault Aviation.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Bowdoin College; Master of Science, Stanford University
About_#1: Reed Hastings, cofounder and co-CEO of Netflix, revolutionized how the world is entertained. He owns about 2% of Netflix, which went public in 2002.
About_#2: Hastings cofounded Netflix in 1995, the same year he sold his first company, Pure Software, to Rational Software.
About_#3: The video-streaming service offers TV shows and films, as well as original content, to 222 million members globally.
About_#4: Netflix originally operated as a DVD subscription service, but began streaming content in 2007.
Did You Know?: The son of a Nixon administration lawyer, Hastings studied math at Bowdoin and served in the Peace Corps in Swaziland.
In Their Own Words: Incredible people don't want to be micromanaged. We manage through setting context and letting people run.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Amherst College; Master of Business Administration, Harvard University
About_#1: Amos Hostetter Jr. made a fortune in the 1990s as cable TV pioneer and now is most active in philanthropy.
About_#2: He set out with an MBA and $1,500 in the 1960s to invest in a cable TV company that eventually became Continental Cablevision.
About_#3: He sold it to US West for $11 billion in 1996.
About_#4: His family's Barr Foundation donates tens of millions of dollars each year to support the arts and education and fight climate change.
Did You Know?: Hostetter owns seaside property on Nantucket, and one of the island's best French restaurants, The Chanticleer.

Education: Drop Out, Brown University
About_#1: Most of Brad Jacobs' fortune comes from XPO Logistics, a commercial trucking company that delivers goods to warehouses and distribution centers.
About_#2: XPO Logistics also has a truck brokerage business that connects drivers with shipments.
About_#3: Jacobs created XPO Logistics in 2011 and serves as chairman.
About_#4: In 2021, XPO spun off its warehousing business into GXO Logistics, which contracts with retailers to manage inventory and fill orders.
Did You Know?: A trained classical pianist, Jacobs studied piano and mathematics at Brown University before dropping out.

About_#1: Friedrich Knapp presides over one of Europe's largest fashion companies, New Yorker GmbH, which has more than 1,000 stores in 40 countries.
About_#2: The low-profile billionaire, with Tilmar Hansen and Michael Simson, started the retailer in 1971, with one store in the German town of Flensburg.
About_#3: Today, the chain employs more than 18,000 people and has revenues of around $2 billion.
About_#4: New Yorker is known for targeting a younger audience with fashion ranging from outerwear and knitwear to jeans and athletic apparel.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania
About_#1: William Lauder is chairman of cosmetics giant Est?e Lauder, a position he's held since 2009.
About_#2: A member of the family's third generation, he was Est?e Lauder's CEO from 2004 to 2009.
About_#3: He's a grandson of Est?e Lauder, who founded the cosmetics firm, and eldest son of Leonard Lauder, who was CEO and chairman for 17 years.
About_#4: He lives in a Park Avenue co-op, and has homes in New York's Westchester County and in Aspen, Colorado.
Did You Know?: Lauder graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and now sits on the institution's board. He started lecturing Penn MBA students in 2012.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Amherst College; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Columbia University
About_#1: Richard LeFrak became CEO of the LeFrak Organization in 2003 when his father Sam died.
About_#2: The father-son team transformed the business, which started in France in 1883, into one of the largest real estate developers in the New York area.
About_#3: Holdings include LeFrak City - a 20-building, 5,000-unit apartment complex in Queens - and hundreds of acres across from Manhattan to Newport, N.J.
About_#4: Known for apartments for moderate-income tenants in the areas around New York City, LeFrak has recently been expanding into luxury and new markets.
Did You Know?: Sons Jamie and Harrison are being groomed to be the next generation of LeFraks to run the business.
In Their Own Words: The real estate business is just a proxy for the demographics of a community. If a community is growing, the real estate business benefits from it. If the community is shrinking, then the real estate business gets damaged.

About_#1: Li Guoqiang is a founder and the CEO of Zhongsheng Group, one of China's largest car dealers.
About_#2: Zhongsheng focuses on luxury and mid-to-high-end brands such as Mercedes-Benz, Lexus, Porsche and Land Rover.
About_#3: Li and Huang Yi, chairman of Zhongsheng, established Zhongsheng Group in 1998.

About_#1: Known as the coal king, Singapore-born Low Tuck Kwong is the founder of Bayan Resources, a coal mining company in Indonesia.
About_#2: He also controls Singapore's renewable energy company Metis Energy - formerly known as Manhattan Resources - and has interests in The Farrer Park Company, Samindo Resources and Voksel Electric.
About_#3: Low is backing SEAX Global, which is building a submarine sea-cable system for internet connectivity linking Singapore, Indonesia and Malaysia.
About_#4: Low worked for his father's construction company in Singapore as a teenager and then moved to Indonesia in 1972 for greater opportunities.
Did You Know?: The animal lover has sponsored a zoo with gibbons, sun bears, peacocks and orangutans.

About_#1: Akira Mori is the chairman, co-CEO and owner of real estate developer Mori Trust.
About_#2: Mori Trust owns more than 100 properties in Tokyo and across Japan, including office buildings and hotels.
About_#3: His daughter, Miwako Date, has been president and co-CEO of Mori Trust since 2016.
About_#4: Date has said that the company planned to invest $10 billion in new projects, with about 20% going overseas.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Dartmouth College
About_#1: Anthony Pritzker runs The Pritzker Group, a private equity firm; his brother J.B. was involved until he became governor of Illinois in January 2019.
About_#2: The Pritzker Group owns and runs industrial firms, particularly in the packaging sector. It also has a stake in Elon Musk's rocket company SpaceX.
About_#3: Tony is one of 11 billionaire heirs to the Chicago-based Pritzker family fortune, which includes Hyatt Hotels, chaired by his cousin Tom Pritzker.
About_#4: He spent 20 years running middle-market manufacturing and distribution companies, including firms within the Pritzker family's Marmon conglomerate.
Did You Know?: Pritzker has made political donations to Democrats, Republicans and the Libertarian party.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Brooklyn College; Master of Business Administration, Leonard N. Stern School of Business
About_#1: Ira Rennert is the founder of the Renco Group, an industrial empire with estimated annual revenues of $5 billion.
About_#2: Renco's holdings include a stake in military truckmaker AM General, lead and zinc producer Doe Run Company and U.S. Magnesium Corp., among others.
About_#3: His mother emigrated to the U.S. from Poland at age 3 and his father came from Romania at age 14.
About_#4: A Brooklyn native and former credit analyst, he began building his fortune by investing in junk bonds in the 1980s.
Did You Know?: Rennert has a 114,000-square-foot Hamptons estate with an assessed value of $262 million.

Education: LLB, University of Virginia; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Villanova University
About_#1: B. Francis Saul II inherited his grandfather's property management firm, B.F. Saul Company, and turned it into a real estate empire.
About_#2: B.F. Saul Company owns 9.8 million square feet of retail and office space across the country along with 19 hotels.
About_#3: He also owns The Hay-Adams, a 5-star hotel across the road from the White House that brands itself as "discreetly luxurious."
About_#4: He sold Chevy Chase Federal Savings Bank to Capital One in 2009 for $476 million.
Did You Know?: Saul received a papal award in 1991 for his service as a prolific donor to Catholic causes.
In Their Own Words: If you forgot about me, I'd be grateful.

About_#1: Shi Yonghong cofounded Sichuan hot pot chain Haidilao in 1994 with Zhang Yong, also a billionaire, and two friends who became their wives.
About_#2: The company, which had about $4.4 billion in sales from almost 1,300 locations in 2020, went public in Hong Kong in September 2018.
About_#3: Known for offering special services such as free manicures for waiting customers, Haidilao has expanded to the U.S., Japan, South Korea and Singapore.
About_#4: Shi, who owns his stake in Haidilao with wife Li Haiyan, has a stake in Yihai International, hot pot condiment maker that was spun off from Haidilao.

About_#1: Song Chi-hyung is founder and chairman of Dunamu, which operates South Korea's dominant cryptocurrency exchange.
About_#2: In September 2021, Dunamu raised $85 million at a valuation of $8.7 billion.
About_#3: Its investors include Kakao Ventures and Silicon Valley-based venture capital firm Altos Ventures.
About_#4: Before starting Dunamu with Kim Hyoung-nyon, Song worked at local mobile payment company Danal.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, California State Long Beach
About_#1: The films of Steven Spielberg, a three-time Academy Award-winning director, have grossed more than $10 billion worldwide.
About_#2: Spielberg became a household name directing movies like 'Jaws' and 'Jurassic Park.'
About_#3: In 1994, he cofounded DreamWorks studios with Jeffrey Katzenberg and David Geffen.
About_#4: Today, a slice of the cash from every ticket at Universal theme parks goes directly into his pocket thanks to blockbuster hits like 'Indiana Jones.'
Did You Know?: After failing to get into USC film school, Spielberg got his start as an unpaid intern in the editing department of Universal.

About_#1: Danielle Bellon is the widow of Pierre Bellon, who founded food service and catering company Sodexo in 1966.
About_#2: Pierre Bellon, who expanded Sodexo to 56 countries, died in January 2022 at age 92.
About_#3: Danielle and Pierre's daughter Sophie is chairwoman of the Paris-listed company.
About_#4: Sodexo began to grow internationally in 1971; its 412,000 employees now serve 100 million people daily.
Did You Know?: Sodexo has catered for a wide range of customers, feeding people at locations from mining sites in Africa to six Olympic games since 1988.

About_#1: A former math tutor, Byju Raveendran founded online ed-tech company Byju's in 2011.
About_#2: The company's last funding round in March 2022 valued it at around $22 billion. Byju's investors include Mark Zuckerberg and Tencent.
About_#3: Byju's flagship app, aimed at school children from grades one to 12, has registered a cumulative 42 million downloads.
About_#4: His wife Divya, who was one of his early students, helps him run the company and also sits on the board.
Did You Know?: The company collects old and unused smart devices, loads them with Byju's content and distributes them to poor children.
In Their Own Words: This is not a business which I started as a business. It's a passion which ended up becoming a business.

About_#1: Cho Tak Wong is the chairman of Fuyao Glass Industry Group, one of Asia's largest manufacturers of auto glass.
About_#2: Cho's hobbies include golfing and collecting art.
About_#3: Cho counts Audi, Fiat, Ford, Honda and Nissan among his customers.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, Brooklyn Law School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Tufts University
About_#1: Real estate developer Charles Cohen bought out his father and uncle and quadrupled the family real estate empire to 12 million square feet.
About_#2: Most of his fortune is in high end office buildings in New York City and design centers in several cities.
About_#3: WeWork leases office space from Cohen Brothers Realty's 750 Lexington Avenue and 135 East 57th Street in Manhattan.
About_#4: Cohen owns high end luxury brands such as Harrys of London, Savile Row tailor Richard James and luggage company T. Anthony.
Did You Know?: Cohen wrote the 1985 movie quiz book "Trivia Mania."
In Their Own Words: When I turned 14, I stopped following the Yankees and started reading Variety. There was nothing more exciting to me than being in line to see a movie when it opened.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, University of Michigan
About_#1: Kenneth Dart is an heir to the Dart Container foam cup fortune and an investor based in the Cayman Islands.
About_#2: Born in Michigan, he renounced his U.S. citizenship in 1994, obtained citizenship from Belize and relocated to the tax-free Cayman Islands.
About_#3: He invested part of his fortune in distressed sovereign debt from Greece to Argentina and made large profits by rejecting restructuring deals.
About_#4: His largest assets are stakes in tobacco firms British American Tobacco and Imperial Brands, which first became public knowledge in late 2020.

Education: Doctorate, University of Florida; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Zurich
About_#1: Martin Ebner founded Swiss bank BZ Bank in 1985, then started his own investment firm, BZ Group, in 1988.
About_#2: He has quietly rebuilt a huge fortune after his indebted BZ Group lost most of its value in 2002.
About_#3: Today he owns multimillion-dollar stakes in various companies through his investment vehicle, Patinex.
About_#4: His biggest holdings include healthcare company Vifor Pharma, software firm Temenos and real estate investor Intershop.

Education: Master of Science, Stanford University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Tulane University
About_#1: David Filo cofounded Yahoo, which sold its core business to Verizon for $5 billion in cash in 2016.
About_#2: The most valuable part of Yahoo - its stakes in Alibaba and Yahoo Japan - morphed into a company called Altaba. Altaba voted to liquidate in 2019.
About_#3: He and his wife Angela established the Yellow Chair Foundation in 2000; it supports education, civil liberties, gender equality and the environment.
About_#4: Filo and his wife Angela established the Yellow Chair Foundation in 2000; it supports education, civil liberties, gender equality and the environment.
Did You Know?: Filo's wife Angela, a photographer and educator, sits on Stanford's Board of Trustees. David got a master's degree from Stanford in 1990.
In Their Own Words: It's going to be interesting to see how society adapts to a lot of these changes that AI is bringing to us...I think with that kind of change comes a great opportunity, but kind of both on the positive and potentially negative side.

About_#1: Fluxa Rossello is the executive chairman of Grupo Iberostar, one of Europe's largest hotel companies.
About_#2: In 2017 Iberostar generated more than $2.9 billion in revenues; it has hotels in 30 countries and 27,100 employees.
About_#3: The roots of the Iberostar Group date to the 19th century when the Fluxa family started a footwear business in Majorca, Spain.
About_#4: In 1986 Miguel joined the family company, which was still small, and founded the first Iberostar hotels in Majorca and the Canary Islands.

About_#1: After acquiring a fortune in the early 1980s from his trading firm J.W. Henry & Co., John Henry started building a sports empire.
About_#2: Henry and his partner Tom Werner bought the Boston Red Sox in 2002 for $380 million and delivered the Sox' first World Series win in 86 years in 2004.
About_#3: Their Fenway Sports Group holds the majority stake in New England Sports Network and Nascar's Roush Fenway Racing.
About_#4: Henry also has a stake in Premier League soccer team Liverpool, which won the Champions League in June 2019.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Babson College
About_#1: Peter Kellogg sold brokerage house Spear, Leeds & Kellogg to Goldman Sachs for $6.5 billion in cash and stock in 2000.
About_#2: Kellogg joined the firm, where his father was a partner, in 1973 and took over several years later.
About_#3: Under his leadership, the firm became the first specialist brokerage to control more than 10% of the stocks trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
About_#4: After selling to Goldman in 2000, Kellogg turned his attention to reinsurance outfit IAT, which he led as CEO until 2015 and still chairs.

Education: High School Graduate, High School
About_#1: James Leprino owns the world's largest mozzarella cheese maker, with $3.5 billion in estimated annual sales.
About_#2: His Leprino Foods is the exclusive supplier of cheese to Domino's, Papa John's and Pizza Hut.
About_#3: After graduating high school in 1956, he started working with his father full-time at his market.
About_#4: In 1958, after larger chain grocery stores had forced the Leprino market to close, the Leprino Foods cheese empire started with $615.
In Their Own Words: Your employees have got to know you're not a phony. They've got to believe in you.

Education: Master of Arts/Science, Tashkent State University
About_#1: The Uzbekistan-born Makhmudov is the main owner of metals conglomerate UGMK, which controls 300 mining companies scattered across Russia.
About_#2: Makhmudov is also a shareholder in Transmashholding, Russia's largest maker of locomotives and rail equipment.
About_#3: In 2003, Makhmudov and his former business partner Oleg Deripaska were accused in American courts of leading a "massive racketeering scheme."
About_#4: They denied it, and the lawsuit was eventually dismissed on jurisdictional grounds.
Did You Know?: From 1984 to 1988, he worked as an interpreter for a group of Soviet military advisers in Libya and Iraq.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Universidad Comercial de Deusto; Law Degree, Universidad Comercial de Deusto
About_#1: Daniel Mate is the former head of zinc at commodities giant Glencore.
About_#2: The Spaniard owns slightly more than 3% of the London-listed company.
About_#3: Mate joined Marc Rich & Co. in 1988 in Switzerland, six years before the firm was bought out by management and changed its name to Glencore.
About_#4: Mate rose to co-directing the zinc, copper and lead commodity department in 2000. He retired in July 2020.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, London School of Economics
About_#1: Aristotelis Mistakidis, known as "Telis," stepped down from his role as the director of Glencore's copper business at the end of 2018.
About_#2: In 2018, Canadian regulators fined and banned Mistakidis from serving as a director due to compliance violations.
About_#3: Mistakidis got his start in commodities at Cargill and joined Marc Rich & Co. in 1993. Later, the firm was bought by management and renamed Glencore.
About_#4: He first became a billionaire in 2011 when Glencore went public, and currently owns more than 3% of the company's stock.
Did You Know?: Mistakidis is a citizen of both the United Kingdom and his native Greece.

Source of Wealth: billboards, Los Angeles Angels, Self Made
Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Arizona
About_#1: Arturo Moreno is the owner of the Los Angeles Angels baseball team, which he bought in 2003 for $184 million. It is now worth about $2 billion.
About_#2: Moreno's initial fortune came from billboard advertising company Outdoor Systems, which he sold to Infinity Broadcasting in 1999 for $8.7 billion.
About_#3: He has stakes in other billboard advertising companies, as well as commercial real estate holdings throughout Phoenix.
About_#4: Moreno's $325 million plan to develop a new Angels baseball stadium was scuttled in May 2022, by Anaheim's City Council.
Did You Know?: The oldest of 11 children, Moreno was drafted into the Vietnam War before attending the University of Arizona on the G.I. Bill.
In Their Own Words: There's two types of education. One where you learn by a book, and you're taught, and the other one is a baseball bat. Every time you make a mistake somebody comes and hits you in the back of the head.

About_#1: Nan Cunhui chairs Zhejiang Chint Electrics, a supplier of meters and power transmission equipment.
About_#2: Nan is a standing committee member of the All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce and chairman of Zhejiang Federation of Industry and Commerce.
About_#3: He is also the president of Zhejiang Chamber of Commerce.

About_#1: Julio Ponce Lerou owns a 17% stake in Sociedad de Quimica y Minera de Chile (SQM), a publicly-traded chemicals and mining company.
About_#2: He resigned as chairman of SQM in April 2015, citing personal reasons.
About_#3: SQM is one of the world's largest miners of lithium, which is used in batteries for electric cars.
About_#4: For almost 40 years Ponce headed SQM, which also mines and sells potassium nitrate and iodine -- chemicals used in fertilizers.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Duke University; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Northwestern University
About_#1: Jay Robert "J.B." Pritzker is the governor of Illinois; he unseated Republican incumbent Bruce Rauner as a Democratic candidate in 2018.
About_#2: An heir to the Hyatt Hotel fortune, Pritzker ran private equity firm Pritzker Group with his brother Anthony until March 2017.
About_#3: His charitable foundation supports nonprofits primarily in Chicago, including the Ounce of Prevention Fund, which provides early-childhood education.
About_#4: His uncle Jay Pritzker (d. 1999) founded Hyatt Hotels and his father Donald (d. 1972) managed and developed the chain.
Did You Know?: With a net worth of $3.2 billion, Pritzker is the richest politician in office in the U.S.

Education: LLB, University of Mumbai
About_#1: One of four brothers of a property family, Chandru Raheja ventured out on his own in 1996.
About_#2: Today his privately held K. Raheja Corp. is one of Mumbai's leading developers and is run by his sons Neel and Ravi.
About_#3: Raheja is known for its IT parks, hotels, malls and department store chain, Shoppers Stop.
About_#4: His Chalet Hotels, which owns a string of hotels such as the J.W. Marriott in Mumbai and the Westin in Hyderabad, listed in 2019.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Missouri; Master of Business Administration, University of Missouri
About_#1: Rodger Riney is the cofounder of discount brokerage firm Scottrade, which is now part of TD Ameritrade.
About_#2: After college, Riney turned down a job at a top engineering firm and joined a Missouri investment company for less pay.
About_#3: A decade later, he quit his job, drove 1,500 miles from St. Louis to Scottsdale, Ariz. and cofounded Scottrade in 1980.
About_#4: Riney, who bought out his partner in 1985, expanded the firm to 3 million client accounts with a total of $170 billion in assets under management.
In Their Own Words: From the very early days until today, I have been surrounded by good people who just want to work hard and help others. It is just incredible.

Education: Master of Science, Shenzhen University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Zhejiang University
About_#1: Shi Yuzhu is chairman of Giant Interactive, an online game developer and operator in China.
About_#2: Giant, which had traded in New York, was relisted on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2016 through a reverse merger with Chongqing New Century Cruise.
About_#3: Shi was a revered entrepreneur in China in the 1980s when he first made his fortune in computer hardware.
About_#4: A graduate of Zhejiang University, Shi got his degree in math.

About_#1: Song Zuowen's privately-held Nanshan Group has interests in aluminum, apparel, education, tourism and a regional airline.
About_#2: It listed its main aluminum company, Shandong Nanshan Aluminum, on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 1999.
About_#3: Nanshan Group is the majority investor in startup Qingdao Airlines, which launched in April 2014.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Columbia Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Columbia University
About_#1: Real estate baron Jerry Speyer redeveloped landmarks like Rockefeller Center and the Chrysler Building in Manhattan.
About_#2: Jerry is the chairman of Tishman Speyer and his son Rob is CEO. Until 2015, they held co-CEO titles.
About_#3: Tishman Speyer has developed over 152 million square feet, including skyscrapers in New York, Chicago, Berlin, London, Frankfurt and Paris.
About_#4: Speyer started the firm with his late father-in-law, Robert Tishman, in 1978. The marriage ended in divorce, but the company survived.
Did You Know?: Speyer was chairman of the Museum of Modern Art's board of trustees for 11 years and was elected chairman of New York Presbyterian Hospital in 2018.

About_#1: Julia Thiele-Schuerhoff inherited a portion of the fortune that her late father, Heinz Hermann Thiele, built up, including a stake in vehicle braking systems maker Knorr-Bremse AG.
About_#2: Her father joined Knorr-Bremse's legal department in the late 1960s and took over control in the mid-1980s.
About_#3: He withdrew from operational duties in 2007, chaired the supervisory board, was named honorary chairman in 2016, and took the company public in 2018.
About_#4: When he died in February 2021, at age 79, Heinz Hermann also owned 50% of railroad equipment maker Vossloh and 12.4% of German airline Lufthansa.
Did You Know?: She is cofounder of Knorr-Bremse Global Care, established in 2005 following the devastating tsunami in Southeast Asia.

Education: Master of Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Liverpool
About_#1: Chee Chen was the chairman and chief executive of Hong Kong-listed Orient Overseas, one of Hong Kong's last great shipping dynasties.
About_#2: In 2018 Tung Chee Chen and his brother, Tung Chee Hwa, sold their entire 68.7% stake to China shipping giant COSCO.
About_#3: Founded in 1947 by his father, Tung Chao Yung, the empire had more than 330 offices in 70 countries.
About_#4: The sale netted the brothers $4.34 billion.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Chinese Culture University; Master of Business Administration, Southeastern Louisiana University
About_#1: Roger Wang is chairman of real estate firm Golden Eagle International, which builds malls and office buildings in eastern China.
About_#2: The Chinese native grew up in Taiwan and came to the U.S. in pursuit of an M.B.A. in 1970.
About_#3: He first got rich building condos around L.A. and returned to China in 1992 to start Golden Eagle.
About_#4: His firm's department store arm, Golden Eagle Retail Group, trades on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.
Did You Know?: Wang once sold insurance and managed a drugstore and a furniture company.

About_#1: Wu Shaoxun chairs Jing Brand, a supplier of Chinese liquor.
About_#2: Wu worked for a textile company after leaving the army in 1980.
About_#3: Seven years later, he took a job at a distillery factory in Daye in China's Hubei Province; the business was the predecessor to Jing.
About_#4: Wu bought that business in 1998; Jing's sales in 2017 exceeded $1.6 billion.

About_#1: Zhang Wenzhong is the controlling shareholding of Wumart Holdings Inc.
About_#2: Wumart is a multi-brand retailer with supermarkets and department stores, among other businesses.
About_#3: He was sentenced to 18 years in prison for financial violations in 2008 and released in 2013.
About_#4: Zhang's earlier convictions were overturned by China's high court in 2018, clearing his record.

About_#1: Chen Kaixuan chairs Guangzhou-headquartered Liby Group.
About_#2: Liby Group manufactures washing powder, washing detergent, washing soap, and washing liquid products.
About_#3: Chen set up Liby with his brother, Chen Kaichen, in 1994.

About_#1: Beatriz Davila de Santo Domingo is the widow of Colombian beer baron Julio Mario Santo Domingo, who died in 2011.
About_#2: She controls more than a third of the Santo Domingo family's Luxembourg-based holding company, through which she owns shares in Anheuser-Busch InBev.
About_#3: Her two sons Alejandro and Andres Santo Domingo own the next-largest stakes; Alejandro took over the family business after Julio Mario's death.
About_#4: The family also owns a stake in Château Pétrus, a French wine estate near Bordeaux that produces some of the world's most expensive wines.

About_#1: Antonio del Valle Ruiz swapped a stake in a Mexican bank for control of what is now chemical conglomerate Orbia Advance Corp.
About_#2: He and his six children own a 42% stake in Orbia Advance Corp., formerly called Mexichem.
About_#3: Del Valle also owns a majority stake in Grupo Financiero BX+, which controls the bank Banco Ve Por Mas.
About_#4: In 2015, Del Valle and business partner Carlos Slim did an IPO of their construction conglomerate, Elementia.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Middlebury College
About_#1: The son of billionaire Gustaf Douglas, Carl has sat on the board of the family's investment company Wasatornet for more than a decade.
About_#2: The Douglas family is the largest shareholder of Latour AB, which holds stakes in Securitas AB and Assa Abloy, the world's largest lock producer.
About_#3: Latour is also the main shareholder in AB Fagerhult, one of the leading European manufacturers of light fixtures and several other public companies.
About_#4: Carl is a board member of Latour AB, and is vice chairman of Securitas and Assa Abloy.
Did You Know?: Douglas is an acclaimed underwater explorer and led the expedition in the Baltic Sea that discovered the warship Sword dating to 1676.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Lund University
About_#1: The son of billionaire Gustaf Douglas, Eric has sat on the board of the family's investment company Wasatornet for more than a decade.
About_#2: The Douglas family is the largest shareholder of Latour AB, which holds stakes in Securitas AB and Assa Abloy, the world's largest lock producer.
About_#3: Latour is also the main shareholder in AB Fagerhult, one of the leading European manufacturer of light fixtures and several other public companies.
About_#4: Eric is a board member of Latour AB, chairman of the boards of Pod Investment AB and Sparbössan Fastigheter AB, and vice chairman of AB Fagerhult.
Did You Know?: The Douglas family earned its nobility via Robert Douglas, a Scottish immigrant who became general over the Swedish forces and fought in the Thirty Years' War.

Education: Master, University of Miami
About_#1: Juan Carlos Escotet is the founder of Caracas-based banking group Banesco.
About_#2: Banesco is operational in Panama, the Dominican Republic, Puerto Rico, Colombia and the United States.
About_#3: His son, Juan Carlos Escotet Alviarez, died in March in a boating accident trying to rescue his fiance who had fallen overboard.
About_#4: Escotet began working as a messenger for Banco Union when he was 17 while studying economics. In 1986, he founded a brokerage firm.
Did You Know?: He has four grown sons, all of whom work with their father at Banesco.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Monash University; LLB, Monash University
About_#1: Fiona Geminder owns a substantial stake in listed plastics-packaging business Pact Group, with her husband Raphael Geminder.
About_#2: She also holds a large stake in her family's paper packaging and recycling business, Visy Asia-Pacific.
About_#3: She holds the stake with her brother Anthony Pratt and sister Heloise Pratt, who are both also billionaires.

About_#1: Gu Yuhua controls Jason Furniture (Hangzhou), which listed in Shanghai in October 2016.
About_#2: He started his career at a sofa workshop that he opened in eastern Nantong in 1982.
About_#3: Gu's son Gu Jiangsheng is Jason's chairman; another son, Gu Hailong, sits on the board.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Southern Methodist University
About_#1: Jim Irsay owns the Indianapolis Colts, the NFL team he inherited from his father, Robert Irsay (d. 1997).
About_#2: He grew up with the Colts, living with the team during summer camp and traveling on the team bus.
About_#3: Irsay played football at Southern Methodist University, where he studied broadcast journalism, before joining the Colts' front office.
About_#4: He worked in everything from ticket sales to public relations before being named GM in 1984, at 24. Upon his father's death, Irsay became 100% owner.
Did You Know?: Irsay owns an original manuscript of the Jack Kerouac novel "On the Road" plus guitars from several rock legends, including Prince, Bob Dylan and Jerry Garcia.
In Their Own Words: I believe we're all artists, that business is art.

About_#1: Kuok Khoon Hong cofounded Wilmar in 1991 and built it into one of the world's largest palm oil producers.
About_#2: He listed Wilmar's Chinese subsidiary, Yihai Kerry Arawana, in a $2.1 billion IPO in October 2020 on the Shenzhen stock exchange.
About_#3: Kuok's other investments include stakes in billionaire Zhong Sheng Jian's Yanlord Land as well as Perennial Real Estate Holdings.
About_#4: Kuok co-owns the Aviva Tower in London with Indonesian billionaire and Wilmar cofounder Martua Sitorus.
Did You Know?: BandLab Technologies, a digital music startup founded by Kuok's son Kuok Meng Ru, owns the U.K. music brand NME, which has launched in Asia.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania
About_#1: Aerin Lauder, the eldest daughter of billionaire Ronald Lauder, serves as style and image director at beauty company Est?e Lauder.
About_#2: Lauder has worked for Est?e Lauder, founded by her grandmother, since 1992. She served as a board member from 2004 to 2016.
About_#3: In 2012, she founded luxury lifestyle brand AERIN, which sells everything from lamps to handbags. The line is sold in 40 countries.
About_#4: Her sister, Jane Lauder, is an executive vice president at Est?e Lauder and sits on the board.
Did You Know?: Aerin inherited her grandmother's East Hampton home and still lives there in the summer with her family.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Parsons School of Design
About_#1: Lee Seo-hyun oversees the Samsung Welfare Foundation, a charity founded by her late father Lee Kun-hee, former chair of Samsung Electronics.
About_#2: She also heads the advisory board at The Leeum, Samsung Museum of Art in Seoul.
About_#3: In December 2018, she stepped down as president of the group's fashion division, Samsung C&T, a post she held for three years.
About_#4: She joined Samsung Group's Cheil Industries as a manager in 2002, after graduating from the Parsons School of Design in New York.
Did You Know?: Lee developed the company's casual-wear brand Bean Pole and was behind the 2011 acquisition of the Italian exotic leather brand Colombo via della Spiga.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Peking University
About_#1: Li Yongxin is a cofounder and the chairman of Shenzhen-listed Offcn Education Technology.
