About_#2: Offcn was merged into China-listed Yaxia Automobile in 2019.
About_#3: Offcn provides online and offline training for applicants of civil service exams.
About_#4: Offcn operates study centers and schools in more than 300 Chinese cities; it enrolls more than one million students.

Education: Doctorate, Brandeis University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Clark University
About_#1: Jeffrey Lurie, a former professor of social policy, is the outspoken owner of the Philadelphia Eagles NFL team.
About_#2: In 1994, Lurie took out a loan to buy the Philadelphia Eagles for $185 million. The team is now worth $4.9 billion.
About_#3: Lurie took an executive role at General Cinema Corporation, the film company founded by his grandfather, in 1983.
About_#4: Two years later, he founded Chestnut Hill Productions, where he produced a string of mostly forgettable movies.
Did You Know?: Lurie flipped burgers at a Massachusetts drive-in theater before becoming an adjunct assistant social-policy professor at Boston University.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Arizona
About_#1: Mary Alice Dorrance Malone is the largest shareholder of the Campbell Soup Company.
About_#2: She sits on Campbell's board alongside her billionaire brother, Bennett Dorrance.
About_#3: Her grandfather, John T. Dorrance, invented the condensed-soup formula that transformed the company in 1897.
About_#4: Billionaire Daniel Loeb's activist hedge fund, Third Point, tried unsuccessfully to oust her and other board members in 2018.

Education: Master of Arts, University of Glasgow
About_#1: Ronald McAulay owns a large stake in CLP Holdings, the power company chaired by brother-in-law Michael Kadoorie.
About_#2: He also has a stake in the Hongkong and Shanghai Hotels, which operates the famous Peninsula Hotel in Hong Kong.
About_#3: He resigned from the board of the former in 2016 and the latter in 2017 after decades of service.
About_#4: His son, Andrew, is chairman of Kadoorie Farm & Botanic Garden in the New Territories.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Waterloo
About_#1: Apoorva Mehta is the executive chairman and founder of Instacart, a San Francisco-based grocery delivery firm most recently valued at $13 billion.
About_#2: Born in India, Apoorva lived in Libya before moving to Canada, where he eventually studied engineering at the University of Waterloo.
About_#3: He worked as an engineer at Blackberry, Qualcomm and Amazon before leaving his job to be an entrepreneur in 2010.
About_#4: He came up with ideas for around 20 products (none worked out) before starting Instacart in 2012.
Did You Know?: Before founding Instacart, Mehta tried to create a product focused on social networking for lawyers.

About_#1: Arnon Milchan owns film and TV production company New Regency Enterprises.
About_#2: New Regency has produced hits like Pretty Woman, Mr. and Mrs. Smith, The Revenant, Birdman and Bohemian Rhapsody.
About_#3: Milchan transformed his family's bankrupt fertilizer company, which he took over in 1962 at the age of 21, into a $125 million business.
About_#4: He was a business student, professional soccer player and consultant for weapons systems between Israeli Defense Forces and U.S. defense contractors.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Kansai University
About_#1: Masahiro Noda is chairman and CEO of publicly traded computer-system integrator and custom software maker Obic.
About_#2: Obic is known for its accounting software and its television ads featuring a Kabuki actor.
About_#3: Noda launched the business with his wife's savings in 1968.

About_#1: Maren Otto is the third wife of the late Werner Otto, who began a retail empire by founding a mail-order business in Hamburg in 1949.
About_#2: She inherited a stake in the family's Otto Group and its more than 40 companies in retail (Crate and Barrel), real estate and financial services.
About_#3: She's also a shareholder of ECE, the family's commercial real estate company focused on shopping centers. Her stepson Alexander is CEO.
About_#4: With Alexander and her daughter, Katharina, she shares a 14% stake in Paramount Group, which owns and manages office properties in the U.S.
Did You Know?: Her daughter, Katharina Otto-Bernstein, writes and produces art movies in the U.S.

About_#1: Renzo Rosso owns denim powerhouse Diesel plus designer brands Maison Margiela, Viktor & Rolf and Marni through his Only the Brave holding company.
About_#2: Rosso got his start at age 15, when he borrowed his mother's sewing machine and made his first piece of clothing: a pair of bell-bottoms.
About_#3: He later joined denim guru Adriano Goldschmied at an Italian manufacturing company called Moltex, which he renamed Diesel in 1978.
About_#4: Seven years later he bought out Goldschmied's stake and positioned Diesel as an upscale choice for denim.
Did You Know?: Rosso picked the name "Diesel" for his company as a nod to the oil crises after the 1973 Arab-Israeli War.

Education: Drop Out, University of Miami
About_#1: Lynn Schuterman's husband Charles Schusterman founded Samson Resources in 1971 and grew it until his death from leukemia in 2000.
About_#2: Lynn and Charles' daughter Stacy became co-CEO of Samson Resources in 1999 and the sole CEO in 2005.
About_#3: Under Stacy Schusterman's leadership, the family sold most of the company's assets to a KKR-led group for $7.2 billion in 2011.
About_#4: Lynn Schusterman held onto some oil and gas assets, which are part of Samson Energy, chaired by her daughter Stacy.

About_#1: Gil Shwed, considered the inventor of the modern computer firewall, founded Check Point Software in 1993 with Shlomo Kramer and Marius Nacht.
About_#2: The company went public on the Nasdaq in 1996.
About_#3: Shwed owns about 20% of Check Point's stock and serves as its CEO.
About_#4: Checkpoint, which develops cybersecurity software, counts many of the largest U.S. companies as its clients.
Did You Know?: Shwed first joined the billionaires list in 2001, only to fall off in 2003 when the tech bubble burst. He returned to the billionaire ranks in 2011.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign; Master of Business Administration, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign; Master of Science, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign
About_#1: Tom Siebel built software firm Siebel Systems and sold it to Oracle in 2006 for $5.8 billion in cash and stock.
About_#2: A former salesman at Oracle, he left in 1990 to launch Siebel Systems.
About_#3: In 2009, he created C3.ai, an enterprise AI firm he took public in 2020 at a near $10 billion valuation.
About_#4: C3.ai started as a clean energy firm. It was briefly named C3IoT in 2016 to chase the internet of things market.
Did You Know?: Siebel was attacked by an elephant on a 2009 safari trip in Serengeti; he barely escaped death and has undergone 19 reconstructive surgeries.
In Their Own Words: Information technology is not going to be about computers. It's more fundamental than that. It's going to be about food, it's going to be about water, it's going to be about healthcare and it's going to be about energy.

Current Role: Chairman Emeritus Of The Board Of Simon Property Group
Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, City College of New York
About_#1: In 1960, Herb Simon and his brother Melvin (d. 2009) founded the precursor to Simon Property Group.
About_#2: Simon Property Group is now one of the world's largest real estate investment trusts, with 233 properties globally, including 198 in the U.S.
About_#3: Simon is chairman emeritus; his nephew, David, who is Melvin's son, has been CEO since 1995.
About_#4: Simon also owns the Indiana Pacers, which he bought with his brother. The team is worth more than $1.6 billion.
Did You Know?: Simon was raised in a Bronx walk-up, the son of a Jewish tailor who emigrated from Central Europe.

About_#1: Friede Springer inherited a stake in media giant Axel Springer Verlag from her husband, Axel, following his death in 1985.
About_#2: Hired as the nanny of his two sons, Springer eventually married Axel, who trained her to take over the business.
About_#3: Among the largest publishing houses in Europe, Axel Springer is active in over 40 countries. Its newspapers include Bild and Die Welt.
About_#4: The company acquired TV news station N24 (since rebranded as Welt) and the New York-based digital news outlet Business Insider in 2015.
Did You Know?: To ensure continuity, in 2020 Friede Springer gave a 15% stake in Axel Springer to CEO Mathias Doepfner and sold him an additional 4.1%.
In Their Own Words: I have always said that I will ensure continuity in the company. All my life, its future has been very important to me.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Macau University
About_#1: Wang Zhenhua is the chairman of property developer Future Land Development Holdings.
About_#2: Hong Kong-listed Future Land Development is headquartered in Shanghai.
About_#3: Wang first entered the property development business in 1993.
About_#4: Wang received an EMBA degree from Cheung Kong Graduate School of Business in July 2005.

About_#1: Hans-Peter Wild sold the last of a WILD Flavors stake to agricultural processing giant Archer-Daniels Midland in 2014 for about $3 billion in cash.
About_#2: His father founded WILD Flavors in 1931 and the company grew into a leading supplier of flavors and extracts, sweeteners, and fermentation technology.
About_#3: He worked for a marketer of mineral oil and chemicals before joining the family business in 1974 and helping to expand its portfolio.
About_#4: Wild still owns Capri Sun, the famed fruit juice brand that originated in the 1960s.
Did You Know?: As a student studying business and law, Wild traveled abroad in search of innovative alternative sources of raw materials for the family business.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Duke University
About_#1: In 1999 William "Beau" Wrigley Jr., an heir to the Wrigley's chewing gum fortune, took over the business his great-grandfather started in 1891.
About_#2: Wrigley Jr., who was CEO, expanded the company in 2005 by purchasing Altoids and Life Savers from Kraft Foods for $1.46 billion.
About_#3: In 2008, he sold the Chicago-based firm to candy giant Mars Inc. for $23 billion in cash.
About_#4: In 2018, Wrigley became CEO of Parallel, a company that makes and sells cannabis products in Florida, Massachusetts, Texas and Nevada.
Did You Know?: Wrigley's great grandfather originally sold baking soda. He switched businesses after realizing that the chewing gum he gave away was much more popular.

About_#1: Xia Zuoquan was an early executive and is a director of BYD, which makes electric buses and plug-in electric cars and batteries.
About_#2: Xia worked in the Hubei branch of The People's Insurance Company before he joined BYD in 1997.
About_#3: He graduated from Guanghua School of Management of Peking University with an MBA in 2007 and studied computer science as an undergraduate.
About_#4: Xia founded investment firm Zhengxuan Capital in 2004; one of its investments is robotics company Ubtech.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Huazhong Agricultural University
About_#1: Xue Hua is cofounder and chairman of Guangdong Haid Group, a supplier of animal feed products.
About_#2: Haid employs 20,000 people.
About_#3: Xue graduated from Huazhong Agricultural University with a major in aquaculture in 1992.

About_#1: Mohed Altrad heads $2.6 billion (sales) Altrad Group, which provides construction and maintenance services.
About_#2: Altrad began life as an orphaned Bedouin in the Syrian desert. He was raised by his grandmother and attended school against her wishes.
About_#3: He eventually won himself a scholarship to study in France, where he earned undergraduate degrees in physics and math and a Ph.D. in computer science.
About_#4: After stints at tech firms and the Abu Dhabi National Oil Company, he bought a bankrupt scaffolding manufacturer in France with a partner in 1985.
Did You Know?: When Altrad immigrated to France from Syria in 1969, he didn't speak French and survived on one meal a day.
In Their Own Words: "I had no special dream - only the ambition not to accept my initial destiny."

Education: Master of Business Administration, Stanford University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: Sid Bass inherited several million dollars from his oil tycoon great-uncle Sid Richardson in 1959. He's been diversifying ever since.
About_#2: Bass has nurtured the careers of famed investors like Richard Rainwater.
About_#3: He personally negotiated the $6 billion sale of Bass oilfields in 2017 with then ExxonMobil CEO Rex Tillerson.
About_#4: He rescued ice cream maker Blue Bell with a $125 million loan after a 2015 listeria outbreak.
Did You Know?: The 2018 Malibu wildfires destroyed the Frank Gehry-designed home Bass bought there in 2015 for $15 million.

About_#1: Nick Caporella is the chairman and CEO of National Beverage, which he founded in 1985; it's best known for its LaCroix brand of sparkling water.
About_#2: The Pennsylvania native started out as a contractor and worked as the CEO of telecom firm Burnup & Sims before founding his soft drinks business.
About_#3: He kickstarted National Beverage by buying soda brand Shasta, then later added LaCroix to the portfolio in 1996.
About_#4: The market capitalization of the Fort Lauderdale, Florida company more than quadrupled between 2015 and 2018 thanks to the popularity of LaCroix.
Did You Know?: Caporella got his first taste of success in construction, where he reportedly scraped together $250 for a down payment on a used dragline excavator in 1957.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Northeastern University; Bachelor of Engineering, Northeastern University Engineering
About_#1: Cheng is the cofounder of Kuaishou, a short video platform headquartered in Beijing.
About_#2: The company went public in an IPO at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in Feb. 2021.
About_#3: Pre-IPO strategic investors included funds managed by Fidelity and BlackRock.
About_#4: Kuaishou cofounder Su Hua is also a billionaire.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Oregon State University
About_#1: Wesley Edens cofounded asset manager Fortress Investment Group in 1998. He remains with the firm as its chairman.
About_#2: A former BlackRock partner, Edens first became a billionaire alongside his four cofounders when Fortress went public in 2007.
About_#3: Amid scrutiny of management's use of capital, Fortress shares tanked 60% within a year of its offering. By 2009, Edens was no longer a billionaire.
About_#4: Fortress was acquired by SoftBank in 2017 for $3.3 billion. He walked away with about $500 million pretax.

Education: Bachelor of Business Administration, University of California, Berkeley
About_#1: Behdad Eghbali cofounded Clearlake Capital in 2006 with Jose E. Feliciano. The private equity firm is based in Santa Monica, California.
About_#2: Clearlake Capital says it has more than $70 billion in assets under management; it is known for scoring some of the private equity industry's best returns.
About_#3: In May 2022, Clearlake Capital joined billionaire investor Todd Boehly and several others in the $3 billion purchase of English soccer team Chelsea FC.
About_#4: Prior to Clearlake, Eghbali worked in private equity for TPG Capital for several years.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: The country's third largest landowner, Archie Aldis "Red" Emmerson and his family own nearly 2 million acres.
About_#2: His Sierra Pacific Industries is the largest private lumber production firm in the nation, with 14 sawmills across California and Washington.
About_#3: Emmerson and his father Curly started SPI in 1949. It went public in 1969 but four years later they bought out their partner and took it private
About_#4: Today, Red's sons George and Mark run the firm as president and chairman, respectively, though Red is still at the office nearly every day.
Did You Know?: Emmerson was kicked out of boarding school in 1946 for telling a friend that he should pin a condom on the bulletin board, which he did.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Princeton University; Master of Business Administration, Stanford University
About_#1: Jose E. Feliciano cofounded Clearlake Capital in 2006 with Behdad Eghbali; both men are managing partners. The private equity firm is based in Santa Monica, California.
About_#2: Clearlake Capital says it oversees more than $70 billion in assets under management; it has scored some of the industry's best returns.
About_#3: In May 2022, Clearlake Capital joined billionaire investor Todd Boehly to buy English soccer team Chelsea FC; the firm is known for buying software, industrial and consumer products companies.
About_#4: Feliciano worked in investment banking at Goldman Sachs and was the chief financial officer of govWorks before it declared bankruptcy in 2000.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Zhejiang Shuren University; EMBA, Zhejiang University
About_#1: Fu Liquan chairs Zhejiang Dahua Technology, one of China's biggest surveillance businesses.
About_#2: Fu worked at a small electrical equipment factory before starting his first equipment plant in 1993.
About_#3: Fu's wife Chen Ailing is a member of the Dahua's board of directors.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Trinity College Connecticut
About_#1: David "Sandy" Gottesman's fortune mostly came from his early investment in Berkshire Hathaway, where he sat on the board. He died in September 2022.
About_#2: A Harvard Business School graduate, Gottesman cofounded the investment firm First Manhattan Co., which was an early investor in Berkshire Hathaway.
About_#3: Gottesman met Warren Buffett in 1962 and they remained friends for six decades.
About_#4: At the time of his death, First Manhattan managed more than $20 billion in assets.

About_#1: Graff Diamonds International chairman Laurence Graff operates at the top of the diamond jewelry market, with more than 60 retail stores worldwide.
About_#2: Graff clients have included Donald Trump, Oprah Winfrey, Larry Ellison, Elizabeth Taylor and the Sultan of Brunei.
About_#3: He built his business from nothing, after dropping out of school at 14 and scrubbing toilets as a jeweler's apprentice in London's Hatton Garden.
About_#4: He owns a polished diamond trading firm in Switzerland, real estate in London's Mayfair district and a stake in a S. African diamond wholesaler.
Did You Know?: Graff splits his time between homes in Gstaad, London, St. Tropez, New York City and his 150-foot Feadship yacht.
In Their Own Words: "I'm a complete thoroughbred in the business."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Southern California
About_#1: Jeff Green is CEO and chairman of The Trade Desk, an advertising tech firm he founded in 2009.
About_#2: His digital ads company, which went public in 2016, specializes in social, mobile and video advertising.
About_#3: The Trade Desk, a Nasdaq-listed company, had $836 million in revenue in 2020, up 26% year-over-year.
About_#4: Prior to The Trade Desk, Green was founder and chief operating officer of AdECN, an online advertising exchange acquired by Microsoft in 2007 for an undisclosed sum.
Did You Know?: Green is a graduate of the University of Southern California, where he studied marketing communications.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, St. Louis University
About_#1: Jim Kavanaugh is the CEO of IT provider World Wide Technology.
About_#2: With David Steward, he started the St. Louis-based company in 1990 by selling computers and printers to telecom companies like AT&T.
About_#3: Kavanaugh personally fulfilled one of the company's first orders by renting a truck and driving 500 PCs to Omaha.
About_#4: WWT is now a $14.5 billion (sales) company that sells software and hardware to customers including Citi, Verizon and the federal government.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Harvard Law School; Bachelor of Arts/Economics, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor
About_#1: Steve Klinsky founded $37 billion (assets) investment firm New Mountain Capital in 1999.
About_#2: Klinsky rose to become one of the top partners at Forstmann Little, an early private equity titan, before striking out on his own.
About_#3: One of the buyout industry's top performers, New Mountain Capital specializes in private equity, private credit and real estate.
About_#4: Its private equity business, known for buying and growing small and midsized companies through acquisitions, has never had an investment default.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Amherst College; Master of Business Administration, Harvard University
About_#1: John Middleton made his fortune selling his family's storied tobacco business to Philip Morris' parent, Altria, in 2007 for $2.9 billion in cash.
About_#2: The original business, John Middleton Inc., was founded as a small retail tobacco shop in Philadelphia in 1856 by his great-great-grandfather.
About_#3: The company began manufacturing cigarettes in the 1950s and launched the Black & Mild cigar brand in 1980.
About_#4: Middleton bought out his relatives' stakes in the company in 2003 for about $200 million amid tobacco lawsuits that threatened to harm the business.

Education: Bachelor of Business Administration, University of Washington
About_#1: Veteran banker Jerry Ng, with more than three decades of experience, gets his wealth from a stake in Bank Jago.
About_#2: He acquired shares of what was then called Bank Artos in December 2019.
About_#3: Bank Jago is transforming itself into a digital bank and is looking to work with small and medium fintech enterprises.
About_#4: Ng has previously held top positions at Bank Danamon Indonesia and Bank Central Asia. Until February 2019 Ng was president director of Bank BTPN.
Did You Know?: He is a trustee at the Blum Center for Developing Economies at the University of California, Berkeley.

About_#1: Nie Tengyun is the chairman and president of Yunda Holding, one of China's largest express delivery companies.
About_#2: The company finished a backdoor listing in China in December 2016 and changed the listed company's name from Ningbo Xinhai Electric to Yunda Holding.
About_#3: Nie established the company in 1999 with only 17 employees; today, it employs more than 9,000 people.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Indian Institute of Technology
About_#1: Nandan Nilekani is the cofounder of tech giant Infosys and its non-executive chairman since August 2017.
About_#2: Nilekani, who left Infosys in 2009, was brought back in 2017 after a boardroom shakeup at the company and the sudden departure of its CEO.
About_#3: Nilekani is credited with building Aadhaar, India's mammoth identity card scheme, while chairman of the Unique Identification Authority of India.
About_#4: The tech magnate, who still has shares in Infosys, has backed Fundamentum, a venture capital fund aimed at technology companies. In August 2022, it raised $227 million for its second fund.
Did You Know?: He teamed up with Ratan Tata, former chairman of the Tata Group, to start Avanti Finance to provide microloans to the poor.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Baltimore
About_#1: The colorful founder of GoDaddy, Bob Parsons, sold off his remaining stake in the web hosting firm and stepped down from the board in 2018.
About_#2: Parsons grew up "poor as a church mouse" in inner-city Baltimore and struggled in school, flunking the fifth grade.
About_#3: He sold software firm Parsons Technology to Intuit for $64 million in 1994; three years later he launched Jomax Technologies, later renamed GoDaddy.
About_#4: In 2014, Parsons founded PXG, which makes high-performance golf equipment and apparel.
In Their Own Words: In business you wind up trying a lot of things, most of which won't work. The way you become a good business person is to fail, fail, fail and fail.

About_#1: Former surgeon Prasert Prasarttong-Osoth cofounded Bangkok Dusit Medical Services, Thailand's largest private hospital operator, in 1972.
About_#2: Bangkok Dusit has a $370 million luxury healthcare complex in Bangkok that includes a 290-room Movenpick hotel.
About_#3: Prasert also owns and runs regional airline, Bangkok Airways, which he took public in 2014.
About_#4: In June 2020, Bangkok Dusit dropped its plan to acquire listed rival Bumrungrad International Hospital and eventually sold all its shares.
Did You Know?: PPTV, his digital TV channel, has the rights to broadcast matches of the English Premier League.

About_#1: Qiu Guanghe is the chairman of Zhejiang Semir Garment Co., which makes and sells apparel.
About_#2: Its Semir brand operates 1,000 retail stores throughout China in cities such as Beijing, Shanghai and Hong Kong.
About_#3: Semir's children's clothing brand Balabala signed a deal in 2016 to open 50 stores in Saudi Arabia.
About_#4: Qiu founded the fashion retailing group in 1996 in his hometown of Wenzhou, a trading mecca in Zhejiang Province.

Education: Doctorate, University of North Carolina; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Vermont
About_#1: Richard and Robert Sands' father, Marvin, founded a humble wine business in 1945 at age 21.
About_#2: That small operation has ballooned into a publicly traded behemoth now called Constellation Brands, which generates over $8 billion in annual revenue.
About_#3: The company is known for its relentless streak of acquisitions. Subsidiaries include Robert Mondavi wine and Svedka Vodka.
About_#4: Constellation also holds the rights to Grupo Modelo's U.S. beer business, including its Modelo and Corona labels.
Did You Know?: In August 2018 Constellation Brands announced a $4 billion investment in Toronto-listed cannabis firm Canopy Growth, in exchange for a 38% stake.

Education: Law Degree, Pace University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Skidmore College
About_#1: Robert and Richard Sands' father, Marvin, founded a humble wine business in 1945 at age 21.
About_#2: That small operation has mushroomed into a publicly-traded behemoth now called Constellation Brands, which generates over $8 billion in annual revenue.
About_#3: Robert Sands, who joined the company in 1986 as general counsel, was CEO from 2007 until March 2019. He is now executive chairman.
About_#4: The company is known for its relentless streak of acquisitions. Subsidiaries include Robert Mondavi wine and Svedka Vodka.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Minnesota
About_#1: T. Denny Sanford owns First Premier Bank, which specializes in offering credit cards to high-risk borrowers.
About_#2: The Sioux Falls, South Dakota, bank has just 17 branches, but is one of the largest issuers of Mastercards - many with steep rates and low limits.
About_#3: An active philanthropist, Sanford says he wants to die broke. But he faces a rare problem: He says he can't get rid of his fortune fast enough.
About_#4: Thanks to hefty dividends from First Premier, Sanford is no closer to bankruptcy than when he began, despite giving nearly $2 billion to charity.
Did You Know?: Sanford has given nearly $1 billion to Sanford Health, a group of 43 nonprofit hospitals formerly called the Sioux Valley Health System.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Swiss Federal Polytechnical Institute; Master of Science, Swiss Federal Polytechnical Institute
About_#1: Naguib Sawiris is a scion of Egypt's wealthiest family. His brother Nassef is also a billionaire.
About_#2: He built a fortune in telecom, selling Orascom Telecom in 2011 to Russian telecom firm VimpelCom (now Veon) in a multibillion-dollar transaction.
About_#3: He's chairman of Orascom TMT Investments, which has stakes in an asset manager in Egypt and Italian internet company Italiaonline, among others.
About_#4: Through his Media Globe Holdings, Sawiris owns 88% of pan-European pay TV and video news network Euronews.
Did You Know?: Sawiris helped found The Free Egyptians, a liberal political party, at the onset of Egypt's uprisings in 2011.

Education: Master, Czech Technical University, Prague
About_#1: Coal, energy and real estate investor Pavel Tykac began as a computer distributor in the early 1990, plowing profits into a small regional bank.
About_#2: In 1992 he and four colleagues cofounded Motoinvest, which specialized in hostile takeovers during the Czech Republic's privatization program.
About_#3: His largest assets are two Czech coal mining firms and a power plant that he owns through Lichtenstein-based Sev.en Energy Group.
About_#4: In 2019, Sev.en Energy purchased a 50% stake in InterGen, which operates power plants in the United Kingdom and Australia.

About_#1: Todd Wanek is the CEO of Ashley Furniture, the largest home furniture manufacturer and retailer in America.
About_#2: His dad, Ron Wanek, started the company in the 1970s with a loan from his father and money he got from selling his home.
About_#3: After graduating from college, Wanek and his new wife Karen spent five years living in Asia, where he managed the company's factory in Taiwan.
About_#4: In 1994, Wanek returned to the U.S., but continued to run international operations. He was promoted to chief operating officer in 1996.
Did You Know?: During high school and college, Wanek held a number of odd jobs at Ashley, including helping on the production line and shipping furniture.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Princeton University
About_#1: Meg Whitman is best known for taking eBay from $5.7 million to $8 billion in sales as CEO from 1998 to 2008.
About_#2: Whitman currently serves as the United States ambassador to Kenya.
About_#3: She was CEO of Hewlett-Packard from 2011 to 2015, where she oversaw its split into HP Inc. and Hewlett Packard Enterprise.
About_#4: She stepped down as HPE's chief executive in February 2018. She sat on the boards of Procter & Gamble and General Motors before becoming an ambassador.
Did You Know?: Whitman ran for Governor of California in 2010 as a Republican and lost, despite spending a reported $140 million of personal funds on her campaign.
In Their Own Words: My mother taught me that you don't have to be perfect to be a leader, but you can't be timid. That lesson is part of the reason I went to eBay. I'd been running a multimillion-dollar business at Hasbro but sensed a very big opportunity.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Tsinghua University; Master of Science, Tsinghua University; Master of Science, University of Manitoba
About_#1: Michael Xie is the cofounder and chief technology officer of Fortinet, which provides cybersecurity services to businesses like Panasonic and Siemens.
About_#2: The Chinese native moved to North America in the 1990s to study engineering at the University of Manitoba in Canada.
About_#3: After graduating, Xie worked at several network security companies before cofounding Fortinet with brother Ken Xie in 2000.
About_#4: The siblings took the California-based firm public in an IPO nine years later. It had revenue of $3.3 billion in 2021.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Renmin University of China
About_#1: A politician turned entrepreneur, Ye Chenghai chairs Shenzhen Salubris Pharmaceuticals which makes cardiovascular, cancer and anti-infective drugs.
About_#2: Ye was the mayor of Shenzhen in the 1980s.
About_#3: Ye's son Kevin is Salubris' CEO; his daughter Ye Yujun is a board member.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Henan Normal University
About_#1: An Kang, a former doctor, is the chairman and largest shareholder of Hualan Biological Engineering, a producer of vaccines and blood products.
About_#2: An won a national science award at age 29.
About_#3: An's hobby: Reading.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Vanderbilt University
About_#1: John Arnold shocked the hedge fund world in 2012 when, at just 38 years old, he announced he would no longer manage other people's money.
About_#2: A hugely successful energy trader, Arnold once worked at Enron, earning the disgraced company a reported $750 million the year it went bankrupt.
About_#3: From its ashes, Arnold built his own hedge fund, Centaurus Advisors.
About_#4: In recent years Arnold has invested in solar farms and deepwater oil developments in the Gulf of Mexico.
Did You Know?: As a kid, Arnold's earliest trades included buying hockey cards in Texas and selling them in Canada. "Looking back what I was doing was geographic arbitrage."

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, University of Michigan
About_#1: Arun Bharat Ram is chairman of $1.5 billion (revenue) SRF, a maker of specialty chemicals and packaging film.
About_#2: Bharat Ram started his career in 1967 with the Delhi Cloth & General Mills (now DCM), owned by his family.
About_#3: He set up SRF in 1970, as a manufacturer of nylon tire cords. Today, the company has 14 manufacturing plants, including in Thailand and South Africa.
About_#4: Both his sons, Ashish and Kartik, help him run the business.
Did You Know?: Bharat Ram is a keen musician and has learnt to play the sitar under the late renowned musician Ravi Shankar.

About_#1: Tomasz Biernacki is the founder and chairman of Poland's largest grocery chain, Dino Polska.
About_#2: Biernacki opened his first shop in 1999; today the company has nearly 1,000 stores that also produce their own meat products.
About_#3: Biernacki took Dino Polska public in 2017.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Southern Oregon University
About_#1: Travis Boersma is the cofounder and executive chairman of Oregon-based coffee chain Dutch Bros.
About_#2: Boersma took Dutch Bros public on the New York Stock Exchange in September 2021; he owns about 40% of the shares.
About_#3: He and his late brother Dane (d. 2009) started selling coffee from a pushcart in Grants Pass, Oregon in 1992 after quitting the family dairy business.
About_#4: Dutch Bros added the first of its now popular drive-through locations in 1994, and now has more than 600 shops in 14 states.

About_#1: Chan Tan Ching-fen is the wife of the late Hong Kong property tycoon Chan Tseng-His. She controls the largest shareholding in Hang Lung Group.
About_#2: Hang Lung is run by her eldest son, Ronnie, whose son Adriel became the group's executive director in late 2016.
About_#3: Ronnie's brother Gerald leads the family's Morningside Group, a private equity and venture capital investor.

About_#1: Chen Dongsheng is the founder and chairman of Taikang Life Insurance, one of China's largest insurers.
About_#2: Chen's wife is the granddaughter of Mao Zedong, the communist revolutionary who became the founding father of the People's Republic of China.
About_#3: Chen is a member of the board of directors of Xiaomi, one of the world's most popular smartphone brands.
About_#4: Chen holds an undergraduate degree in political science and PhD in economics from Wuhan University.

About_#1: The billionaire in the white lab coat, Jean Coutu founded the Canadian drugstore chain that bears his name.
About_#2: In 2017 Coutu agreed to sell the publicly-traded company to European supermarket giant Metro for $4.5 billion in cash and stock.
About_#3: Son of a pediatrician, he opened his first pharmacy in 1969, offering low prices, good customer service and extended hours.
About_#4: Coutu, who was chief executive until 2002 and then again from 2005 to 2007, grew The Jean Coutu Group by acquiring many of his competitors.

About_#1: Ralph Dommermuth leads United Internet, one of Germany's largest Internet access providers serving home users and small- to medium-sized businesses.
About_#2: He launched United's predecessor company, 1&1 AG, in 1988 with a borrowed desk and $285,000 saved from working as a computer salesman.
About_#3: United went public on Germany's stock exchange for high-tech companies, the Neuer Markt, in 1998.
About_#4: United, of which Dommermuth owns just over 50%, has expanded its offerings to include mobile telecommunication services and data centers.
Did You Know?: Dommermuth owns a 4% stake in Borussia Dortmund, a soccer club in the German Bundesliga.
In Their Own Words: In my office, presentations are not allowed. A good idea fits into a beer coaster.

About_#1: Beer industry veteran Walter Faria bought Grupo Petropolis in 1998 and transformed it into one of Brazil's largest beer-and-beverage companies.
About_#2: His Grupo Petropolis makes Itaipava beer, one of Brazil's most popular brews.
About_#3: Founded in a mountainous region in the state of Rio de Janeiro, Grupo Petrópolis is the country's only large brewery that is 100% Brazilian owned.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Letourneau College
About_#1: Bob Gaglardi founded Northland Properties, which has interests in hotels, restaurants, sports and construction.
About_#2: Gaglardi launched the business in 1963 with a $5,000 loan, opening his first Sandman Inn hotel four years later in British Columbia.
About_#3: He continued to put up Sandman Inns throughout Canada, plus expanded into real estate and restaurants.
About_#4: In 2011 he and his son, Tom, purchased the then-bankrupt Dallas Stars NHL team in a $240 million deal.

Education: Doctorate, Monash University
About_#1: Gandel owns half of the southern hemisphere's largest shopping mall, Chadstone, with more than 500 stores in eastern Melbourne.
About_#2: He also has a big stake in listed property trust Vicinity Centres, which owns the other half of Chadstone, plus other malls and outlets.
About_#3: He first got rich by expanding his Polish immigrant parents' clothing chain for women, Sussan, now owned by his niece, Naomi Milgrom.
About_#4: But he made most of his wealth from the shopping malls he bought from Myer department stores for $37 million in the 1980s.
Did You Know?: Gandel says the key to his success was the deregulation of shopping hours and shopping becoming a leisure activity.

About_#1: Hua Xuande chairs Zhejiang ZoneBanner Jiuzhou Group, which controls Shanghai-listed pharmaceutical supplier Zhejiang Jiuzhou Pharmaceutical.
About_#2: Hua's daughter, Hua Lirong, chairs Zhejiang Jiuzhou Pharmaceutical.
About_#3: In September 2019, Jiuzhou Pharmaceutical acquired U.S. pharmaceutical ingredient firm PharmAgra Labs for a reported $16 million.
About_#4: In 2019 Jiuzhou also took over a Chinese subsidiary of Swiss pharmaceutical maker Novartis to help expand its production.

About_#1: Middle East retail magnate Micky Jagtiani drove a taxi in London before moving to Bahrain and starting a baby products shop in 1973.
About_#2: He built it into the Dubai-headquartered Landmark Group, which his wife Renuka runs today as chairman and CEO.
About_#3: Landmark has 2,200 stores spread across 24 countries in the Middle East, Africa, Southeast Asia and the Indian subcontinent.
About_#4: His three children are directors in the group, overseeing different aspects of the business.
In Their Own Words: Retail is not rocket science. I have always been a hands-on person.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Cornell University; Doctorate, Cornell University; Master of Science, Cornell University; Master of Business Administration, Samuel Curtis Johnson Graduate School of Management
About_#1: H. Fisk Johnson III is the chairman and CEO of SC Johnson, a privately-held cleaning products company.
About_#2: He is the fifth generation of the Johnson family to lead the company.
About_#3: The company, which has $11 billion in estimated revenues, is best known for brands like Windex, Off! and Pledge.
About_#4: Fisk and his three siblings are all shareholders of SC Johnson.
Did You Know?: H. Fisk received 4 degrees from Cornell University: a bachelor's, a master's in engineering, an M.B.A and a Ph.D.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Cornell University; Master of Business Administration, Kellogg School of Management
About_#1: S. Curtis is a great-great-grandson of Samuel Curtis Johnson, who founded SC Johnson, the family's cleaning products company, in 1886.
About_#2: In 2014, he was sentenced to four months in jail and fined $6,000 after pleading guilty to misdemeanor sexual assault of his stepdaughter.
About_#3: S. Curtis had been the chairman of family-owned industrial cleaning company Diversey, but stepped down before his arrest in 2011.
About_#4: SC Johnson is known for products including Pledge, Windex and Drano.
Did You Know?: Like his parents and his three siblings, Curt attended Cornell University.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Cornell University
About_#1: Helen Johnson-Leipold is an heir to family-owned SC Johnson, a privately-held cleaning products company.
About_#2: Helen is the chairman and CEO of Johnson Outdoors, a publicly-traded company that sells outdoor gear.
About_#3: She is also chairman of the Johnson Financial Group, which includes family-owned Johnson Bank.
About_#4: SC Johnson products include Pledge, Off! and Windex; the company has $11 billion in revenues (estimate).
Did You Know?: Like her parents and siblings, Helen attended Cornell University.

About_#1: Bolivian-born Miguel Krigsner founded Grupo Boticario, Brazil's second-largest cosmetics company behind number one, Natura.
About_#2: Grupo Boticario operates in cities around Brazil and seven other countries. Krigsner owns nearly 80% of the $1.15 billion (revenues) firm.
About_#3: His brother-in-law Artur Grynbaum joined as a financial assistant and worked his way up to CEO of the group. He owns about 20% of the group.
About_#4: In 1990 Krigsner create Foundation Boticario de Protecao a Natureza--a foundation to protect nature--which receives about 1% of Grupo Boticario's net income annually.
In Their Own Words: Everything will make sense when you look back. From the moment I was born, I was never able to separate my personal life from my professional life.

About_#1: Li Jianquan chairs Winner Medical, a supplier of disposable wound care and surgical products.
About_#2: Winner, which began manufacturing cotton-based medical dressings in 1991, went public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in September 2020.
About_#3: The company also makes protective face masks and surgical gowns, as well as bandages and gauze products.
About_#4: Winner products are sold at more than 40,000 pharmacies across China and in more than 70 countries.

About_#1: Lin chairs Pxmart, one of Taiwan's largest supermarket chains.
About_#2: Lin also controls real estate developer Yuanlih Construction and Hwatai Bank of Taipei.
About_#3: He bought Pxmart from the government in 1998.

Education: Drop Out, Cornell University
About_#1: She is the great-great-granddaughter of SC Johnson (d. 1991), the company's founder.
About_#2: She is an heir to family-owned SC Johnson, the privately-held cleaning products company whose products include Pledge and Windex.
About_#3: Winifred and her siblings pledged $150 million to Cornell in 2017 to fund the SC Johnson College of Business.
Did You Know?: Marquart lives with her family in Virginia Beach, the only sibling to live outside of their hometown of Racine, Wisc.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Bangalore University; Master of Science, Melbourne University
About_#1: Mazumdar-Shaw, one of India's richest self-made women, founded India's largest listed biopharmaceutical firm by revenue, in 1978. The firm has successfully forayed into the lucrative U.S. market.
About_#2: The company has Asia's largest insulin factory in Malaysia's Johor region.
About_#3: In September 2021, vaccine billionaire Cyrus Poonawalla's Serum Institute of India agreed to acquire a 15% stake in Biocon Biologics, a Biocon subsidiary.
About_#4: In February 2022, Biocon Biologics inked a deal to acquire the biosimilars business of Viatris for $3.3 billion.
Did You Know?: Mazumdar-Shaw wanted to be a doctor but couldn't get into medical school.
In Their Own Words: My legacy is going to be in affordable healthcare. I am willing to invest in developing that model and the policies around it.

About_#1: Patrice Motsepe, the founder and chairman of African Rainbow Minerals, became a billionaire in 2008 - the first black African on the Forbes list.
About_#2: In 2016, he launched a private equity firm, African Rainbow Capital, focused on investing in Africa.
About_#3: Motsepe also has a stake in Sanlam, a listed financial services firm, and is the president and owner of the Mamelodi Sundowns Football Club.
About_#4: In March 2021, Motsepe was elected president of the Confederation of African Football, the sport's governing body on the continent.
Did You Know?: In 2013, the mining magnate was the first African to sign Bill Gates' and Warren Buffett's Giving Pledge, promising to give at least half his fortune to charity.

About_#1: Alfred Oetker owns one third of Geschwister Oetker, a German holding company with brands spanning wine and spirits, chemicals and luxury hotels.
About_#2: Geschwister Oetker was formed in 2021 after the Oetker family agreed to divide their $8 billion (sales) conglomerate into two independent groups.
About_#3: The original business, Dr. August Oetker, began in 1891 when his great-grandfather started selling non-perishable baking powder.
About_#4: Alfred serves as co-CEO of Geschwister Oetker with his brother Carl Ferdinand. Their sister Julia is the third owner.
Did You Know?: Alfred has two sons with his wife, Princess Elvira Grimaldi, whose family is the Sicilian branch of the Grimaldis of Genoa and Monaco.

About_#1: Carl Ferdinand Oetker owns one third of Geschwister Oetker, a German holding company with brands spanning wine and spirits, chemicals and hotels.
About_#2: Geschwister Oetker was formed in 2021 after the Oetker family agreed to divide their $8 billion (sales) conglomerate into two independent groups.
About_#3: The original business, Dr. August Oetker, began in 1891 when his great-grandfather started selling non-perishable baking powder.
About_#4: Carl Ferdinand serves as co-CEO of Geschwister Oetker with his brother Alfred. Their sister Julia is the third owner.

About_#1: Julia Oetker owns one third of Geschwister Oetker, a German holding company with brands spanning wine and spirits, chemicals and luxury hotels.
About_#2: Geschwister Oetker was formed in 2021 after the eight Oetker siblings agreed to divide their $8 billion (sales) conglomerate into two separate groups.
About_#3: The original business, Dr. August Oetker, began in 1891 when her great-grandfather started selling non-perishable baking powder.
About_#4: Julia's brothers, Alfred and Carl Ferdinand, serve as co-CEOs of Geschwister Oetker.

About_#1: Or Wai Sheun runs Kowloon Development, which boasts a portfolio of projects across Hong Kong, Macau and China.
About_#2: The company has mainland projects in Shenyang, Wuxi, Tianjin and elsewhere.
About_#3: Its Hong Kong-listed subsidiary Polytec Asset is involved in the oil industry in Kazakhstan and the ice-storage business in Hong Kong.
About_#4: Kowloon Development also distributes films.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Boston University
About_#1: Silicon Valley real estate developer Jay Paul builds and leases office space to big tech firms, including Hewlett-Packard, Amazon and Apple.
About_#2: His privately held Jay Paul Co. has developed some 12 million square feet of office space in Silicon Valley.
About_#3: His first project in San Francisco-proper was 181 Fremont, a 70-story tower with offices and 67 luxury condos up top, which opened in 2018.
About_#4: Paul is developing about 4 million square feet of office space in downtown San Jose, with plans for a new office campus and several high-rises.
Did You Know?: Paul lives in San Francisco's affluent Pacific Heights neighborhood. He owns two yachts and at least one Picasso painting.

About_#1: German-Chilean mogul Horst Paulmann is the founder of Cencosud, one of the largest retail conglomerates in Latin America.
About_#2: The publicly-traded company has 140,000 employees and operations in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Peru and Colombia; Paulmann owns a 53% stake.
About_#3: As a teenager, Paulmann moved from his native Germany to Chile after World War II and opened his first supermarket in 1976.
About_#4: Cencosud has nearly 1,000 supermarkets and dozens of shopping centers, including Costanera Center in Chile, South America's largest mall.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Bandung Institute of Technology
About_#1: Theodore Rachmat, known as Teddy, founded Triputra group in 1998; it now has four business lines, including agribusiness, manufacturing and mining.
About_#2: Rachmat owns a minority stake in listed coal company Adaro Energy, where he is Vice President Commissioner.
About_#3: He started out at automotive group Astra International, founded by his uncle William Soeryadjaya, in 1968. He eventually became CEO.
About_#4: His son Ariano is Vice President Director and Deputy CEO of Adaro Energy.
Did You Know?: Triputra means three children.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Beloit College; Master of Arts, Northern Illinois University
About_#1: John Sall cofounded statistical software firm SAS with James Goodnight in 1976.
About_#2: The two partners met at North Carolina State, where Sall was studying graduate-level statistics and Goodnight was pursuing his Ph.D.
About_#3: SAS saw $3.2 billion in revenue in 2019 and has more than 83,000 customers, including banks, government agencies and insurance companies.
About_#4: SAS offers employees generous workplace perks, including an on-site health care center, pharmacy and daycare services.
Did You Know?: Sall and Goodnight co-own a country club, hotel and spa in Cary, North Carolina.
In Their Own Words: We live in the age of big data, and most of this data is stored in databases. Making it easy to get this data into an analysis helps turn "big data" into "big statistics."

Education: Diploma, University of Munich
About_#1: Stefan von Holtzbrinck, his brother Dieter and sister Monika Schoeller inherited Holtzbrinck Publishing Group from their father, Georg.
About_#2: Originally founded as a book club in 1948, Holtzbrinck's businesses include Macmillan Publishers, S. Fischer Verlag and Holtzbrinck Digital.
About_#3: In 2006, Dieter sold his shares to his siblings, leaving each of them with 50% of the company. Monika died in 2019.
About_#4: Holtzbrinck Ventures (now HV Capital) was founded in 2000 as an investment arm of the publishing business and became independent in 2010.
Did You Know?: Stefan, who serves as CEO of Holtzbrinck Publishing Group, is a lawyer by trade.

About_#1: Nusli Wadia is chairman of the Wadia Group, a cookies-to-aviation empire with roots in shipbuilding dating back to 1736.
About_#2: Group companies include Britannia Industries, home textiles company Bombay Dyeing and budget airline Go First (formerly GoAir).
About_#3: Privately held Go First which was planning a stock market listing earlier this year has put it on hold.
About_#4: Wadia is often referred to as a corporate samurai by the Indian press for waging numerous legal battles.
Did You Know?: Wadia is the grandson of Muhammad Ali Jinnah, founder of Pakistan.
In Their Own Words: I don't draw wooden swords.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania
About_#1: Steve Wynn created some of Las Vegas' most notable casinos, including The Mirage, Treasure Island, Bellagio and Wynn Las Vegas.
About_#2: He resigned as Wynn Resorts' chairman and CEO in 2018 after dozens of women accused him of sexual misconduct; Wynn denies the allegations.
About_#3: Wynn cofounded Wynn Resorts with his then-wife, Elaine Wynn, in 2002. They later divorced. She is now among the largest shareholders of the casino company.
About_#4: He battled for years with Elaine over their divorce agreement and with former partner Kazuo Okada, whom he accused of bribery; Okada denied it.
Did You Know?: Wynn's name was stripped from the University of Iowa's vision institute, which received $20 million in donations from him, after allegations of sexual misconduct.

Education: Drop Out, York University
About_#1: Barry Zekelman took over his family's steel business at age 19 and has since grown it into one of North America's largest steel pipe and tube makers.
About_#2: He sold the company to the Carlyle Group in 2006 for some $1.2 billion, but continued to help run it. He and his family bought it back in 2011.
About_#3: Today Barry and his two brothers, Clayton and Alan Zekelman, split 100% ownership of the $5 billion (revenues) firm, now named Zekelman Industries.
About_#4: He made headlines when he was captured on a secret recording of a 2018 Trump donor dinner, bending the president's ear about the steel business.

Education: Bachelor of Law, University of Melbourne
About_#1: Cameron Adams is cofounder and chief product officer of design software maker Canva, which was valued at $40 billion in September 2021.
About_#2: He owns an estimated 9% stake.
About_#3: An ex-Googler who had founded his own startup in Sydney, Australia, Adams was recruited by Melanie Perkins and Cliff Obrecht to be an advisor for Canva.
About_#4: Instead, Adams signed on as the startup's third cofounder in June 2012. He leads technical development for the company.

About_#1: Former rice trader Vanich Chaiyawan controls Thai Life, Thailand's second-biggest life insurer by total premiums written.
About_#2: The company is run by his son Chai, who is Thai Life's CEO and president. Vanich's daughter, Varang is also a senior executive and sits on the board.
About_#3: Thai Life sells mostly through agents and is known for its emotionally-charged TV commercials.
About_#4: Japan's Meiji Yasuda has a 15% stake in Thai Life.
Did You Know?: Vanich also owns a tiny stake in Thai Beverage, fellow billionaire Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi's Singapore-listed brewer and distiller.

Education: Master of Arts, University of Missouri; Ph.D, University of Missouri
About_#1: Andrew and Peggy Cherng are cofounders of the $3.5 billion (sales) Chinese fast food chain, Panda Express, which has over 2,200 locations.
About_#2: The Cherngs also run famed ramen house, Ippudo, in Berkeley, CA and have investments in chains that sell everything from pizza, salad and cheesecake.
About_#3: Peggy came to the U.S. from Hong Kong in 1967 to attend Baker University, where she met husband Andrew as freshmen.
About_#4: The couple started Panda Express in 1982 in the second largest mall in Los Angeles County.
Did You Know?: Andrew has a master's degree in applied mathematics; he first got into the food business with his father, opening a sit down restaurant in Pasadena in 1973.
In Their Own Words: Back in 1973 it was about making a living for the family. Today it's about challenging ourselves and seeing what all of us on the team can achieve; living into Panda's mission of inspiring better lives.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of New Orleans; Master of Science, University of New Orleans; Ph.D, University of Utah
About_#1: Jim Clark cofounded the Netscape browser and has since multiplied his wealth through timely tech investments.
About_#2: The former Stanford professor got in early on Apple, Facebook, Twitter and Palantir.
About_#3: Clark is married to Kristy Hinze, a former Victoria's Secret and Sports Illustrated model.
About_#4: An ocean lover, his yachts include the 300-foot sailing yacht Athena and the 138-foot sloop Hanuman.
Did You Know?: Clark was the key financial backer of the Japanese dolphin hunting documentary "The Cove."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Western Ontario
About_#1: Canadian-born fast-food mogul Cowin built his fortune on burgers, fried chicken and pizza.
About_#2: He founded and chairs Sydney-based Competitive Foods Australia, which operates Burger King's Australian franchise as Hungry Jack's.
About_#3: The franchise boasts more than 400 stores and a food-processing division.
About_#4: Cowin is also the top shareholder of Domino's Pizza Enterprises, the listed Australian franchisee of the U.S. parent company.
Did You Know?: Cowin started with one KFC outlet in Perth, after emigrating in 1969.

About_#1: Giuseppe Crippa is the founder of Technoprobe, an Italian manufacturer of probe cards, small devices that test the functionality of microchips.
About_#2: He started Technoprobe in his garage and attic in 1989 alongside his son, Cristiano, while still working at semiconductor firm ST.
About_#3: In 1995, he retired from ST to focus on Technoprobe full-time and opened the firm's first office northeast of Milan in 1996.
About_#4: Technoprobe expanded to France, Singapore and the United States in the 2000s, before eventually going public on Euronext Milan in February 2022.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Kuban State University
About_#1: Sergei Galitsky is the founder of Magnit, one of Russia's biggest supermarket chains and cosmetics retailers with more than 15,000 stores.
About_#2: Galitsky was CEO of Magnit until February 2018 when he sold almost all of his shares in the company to the state bank VTB for $2.4 billion.
About_#3: Galitsky got his start in 1994 as a perfume and beauty supplies wholesaler.
About_#4: An admirer of Wal-Mart, he opened his first grocery store in 1998 and advertised using the slogan "Always Low Prices."
Did You Know?: Galitsky owns the soccer team Krasnodar and a soccer academy. He has invested about $460 million in a new soccer stadium nicknamed Galiseum by local journalists.
In Their Own Words: This [stadium] will never pay off but it's more than just a stadium: This is one of the points of attraction in the city. I want our children and grandchildren to be proud of it.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Stanford University
About_#1: Ernest Garcia III is the CEO and cofounder of Carvana, an ecommerce platform for buying and selling used cars.
About_#2: Garcia launched Carvana in 2012 as a subsidiary of DriveTime, a traditional used car business that operates 126 dealerships in 25 states.
About_#3: Garcia started Carvana as a way to sell used cars directly instead of relying on middlemen; the company also offers financing services.
About_#4: In 2017 Garcia II spun Carvana out of his father's company Drivetime in an IPO that raised $225 million.

About_#1: Peter Gilgan has built houses for some 90,000 homeowners since founding Mattamy Homes in 1978.
About_#2: Gilgan, who grew up as one of seven children in a middle class family, worked as an accountant before going into building.
About_#3: Inspired by the New Urbanism movement, he set out to construct suburban dwellings that broke from the bland and impersonal developments.
About_#4: Mattamy (named after the two oldest of his eight children, Matt and Amy) began designing and building planned communities from the ground up in 1986.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Loyola University Chicago
About_#1: Joseph Grendys runs Koch Foods, a poultry processor that slaughters, ships and sells chicken under its own brands and through private label products.
About_#2: The $5 billion (estimated revenues) business makes buffalo wings and chicken strips for Walmart and nuggets for Burger King.
About_#3: Grendys joined Koch in the mid-1980s after graduating from Loyola University, lured by a 50% equity offer from original owner Fred Koch.
About_#4: At the time it was just a one-room shop with 13 employees, and its main business was taking bones out of chicken and cutting up the meat.
Did You Know?: Grendys still lives in the modest Chicago split-level home where he grew up.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Ohio State University
About_#1: Thomas Hagen is chairman of Erie Indemnity and has been a part of the company for more than 50 years, including three years as CEO from 1990 to 1993.
About_#2: The publicly-traded insurance company was cofounded by his late wife Susan's father, H. O. Hirt, and his friend O. G. Crawford.
About_#3: Susan Hagen, who was Erie's longest serving director, died in June 2015 at age 79.
About_#4: Now the nation's 13th largest auto insurer and 12th largest home insurer, the firm began with a business plan scribbled in a 10-cent notebook in 1925.
Did You Know?: Hagen is a retired U.S. Navy Reserve Captain.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Connecticut College
About_#1: Robert Hale is the founder and CEO of wholesale telecommunications provider Granite Telecommunications.
About_#2: Hale founded Granite in 2002, less than six months after his previous company, Network Plus, filed for bankruptcy.
About_#3: The company provides voice, data and other communications services to businesses and governmental agencies in the U.S. and Canada.
About_#4: Granite generated over $1.6 billion in sales in 2021; the company says more than two thirds of the largest 100 U.S. companies are clients.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Master of Science, University of New South Wales; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Sydney
About_#1: Michael Hintze started London-based hedge-fund firm CQS, which is led by his flagship Directional Opportunities fund.
About_#2: Born in China to Russian parents, Hintze was raised in Australia and served a 3-year stint in the army before making his way to London in the 1980s.
About_#3: He is a noted supporter of the arts and sciences and was granted Knighthood in 2013 in recognition of his charitable contributions in the U.K.
About_#4: He maintains a connection to his home country through his MH Premium Farms, which owns a portfolio of agricultural properties in Australia.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Santa Clara
About_#1: Pansy Ho chairs Shun Tak Holdings, a property developer in Hong Kong and Macau that runs ferries between them and operates hotels.
About_#2: Shun Tak Holdings was founded by her father, legendary Macau gaming kingpin Stanley Ho, who died in May 2020.
About_#3: Ho also has major shareholdings in Macau casino operators MGM China and her late father's SJM.
About_#4: She cleared more than $1.5 billion from MGM China's 2011 IPO.

Education: Master of Science, Imperial College London
About_#1: Alan Howard cofounded Brevan Howard Asset Management, a European hedge fund specializing in macro trading, in 2002.
About_#2: The firm was once one of the world's top macro hedge funds, with assets under management peaking at $40 billion in 2013.
About_#3: A streak of uninspiring returns led to billions in investor withdrawals, but solid returns in recent years mean money is now returning to the firm.
About_#4: In October 2019, Howard stepped down as CEO to focus solely on investing and to give portfolio managers more autonomy.

Education: EMBA, National Chengchi University; National Taiwan University
About_#1: Ma was the founder of Taiwan financial services company Yuanta Financial Holdings; his younger son Wei Chen sits on the board.
About_#2: Ma was sentenced in 2014 to seven and a half years in prison in a breach-of-trust case, but he hadn't been jailed due to the onset of dementia.
About_#3: The Ma family holds one of Taiwan's top art collections.
About_#4: He died in October 2022 at age 82.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, American University of Beirut, Lebanon; Master of Business Administration, American University of Beirut, Lebanon
About_#1: Najib Mikati is the cofounder, with his billionaire brother Taha, of Beirut-based investment firm M1 Group.
About_#2: Its investments include stakes in South African telecom firm MTN, fashion retailer Pepe Jeans, and real estate in New York, London and Monaco.
About_#3: Mikati and his brother Taha founded Investcom in 1982, selling satellite phones at the height of Lebanon's civil war.
About_#4: They expanded into Africa where they built cellphone towers in Ghana, Liberia and Benin, among other countries.
Did You Know?: He was prime minister of Lebanon between 2011 and 2013, and is currently a member of parliament.
In Their Own Words: One's country is worthy of having its citizens' devotion without expecting anything in return and without limits.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, American University of Beirut, Lebanon
About_#1: Taha Mikati is the cofounder, with his billionaire brother Najib, of Beirut-based holding company M1 Group.
About_#2: Its investments include stakes in South African telecom firm MTN, fashion retailer Pepe Jeans, and prime real estate in New York, London and Monaco.
About_#3: Mikati and his brother Najib founded Investcom in 1982, selling satellite phones at the height of Lebanon's civil war.
About_#4: They expanded into Africa where they built cellphone towers in Ghana, Liberia and Benin, among other countries.
Did You Know?: Mikati bought a bunch of satellite phones and sold them to friends and associates in Beirut in the early 80s for $50,000 apiece.

Education: Drop Out, University of Utah
About_#1: Utah-based Gail Miller owns the Larry H. Miller Group, which has interests in real estate, healthcare, finance and entertainment businesses.
About_#2: She and husband Larry (d. 2009) turned a single Toyota dealership into the eighth-largest auto dealer group in America before she sold it to Asbury Automotive in 2021 for $3.2 billion.
About_#3: The Millers purchased the Utah Jazz NBA team in 1986 for $22 million; in 2020 the family agreed to sell it to billionaire Ryan Smith for $1.66 billion. They still own a small stake.
About_#4: In 2018, she published the book "Courage To Be You: Inspiring Lessons From An Unexpected Journey."
In Their Own Words: Coming up in a poor family, I learned an awful lot of things about living life that I would never have learned otherwise - things like how to create something out of nothing.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Property magnate Vikas Oberoi controls and runs Mumbai-listed Oberoi Realty, known for its high-end suburban condos.
About_#2: Oberoi owns a Westin hotel in suburban Mumbai and is building the city's first Ritz-Carlton hotel and residences.
About_#3: Oberoi, who is not related to the family behind the Oberoi hotel chain, is also building a mall, hotel and office tower in midtown Mumbai.
About_#4: Amid the pandemic-induced lockdown in 2020, the company inked a lease agreement for 1.1 million square feet in its upcoming office tower in Mumbai with Morgan Stanley.
Did You Know?: Oberoi is married to Gayatri, a former Bollywood actress.
In Their Own Words: One can use the principles of karma to build a better brand and that is what we have tried to do.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Vanderbilt University
About_#1: Ross Perot Jr. founded real estate development company Hillwood, whose diversified portfolio is estimated to exceed 70 million square feet.
About_#2: His father, late billionaire presidential candidate Ross Perot Sr., let his son borrow against his fortune to start his real estate empire.
About_#3: Perot Jr.'s Hillwood has developed and acquired nearly 250 million square feet of industrial space and 90 residential communities.
About_#4: Hillwood also built AllianceTexas, an inland port on 27,000 acres of pasture outside Fort Worth, which is home to 61,000 employees and 525 companies.
Did You Know?: A former Air Force pilot, Perot Jr. was the first person ever to circumnavigate the globe in a helicopter.
In Their Own Words: I got to see the American dream unfold in my living room.

About_#1: Pinheiro Koren de Lima, an oncologist, used money he saved from his medical practice to launch a hospital in the Brazilian city of Fortaleza in 1986.
About_#2: Over the years, he added more hospitals, then health clinics and eventually health insurance, creating what's now Grupo Hapvida.
About_#3: He took Hapvida public in April 2018 on the Sao Paulo stock exchange.
About_#4: He is Hapvida's chairman, while his sons Jorge and Candido Junior, also billionaires, sit on the board of directors.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Trinity College Connecticut; Doctor of Jurisprudence, University of Chicago
About_#1: Matthew Prince cofounded the web infrastructure and security company Cloudflare in 2009. It went public in September 2019.
About_#2: Prince owns about 10% of the company and serves as CEO.
About_#3: Pre-IPO, its investors included Google's venture firm CapitalG, Microsoft, Baidu and Qualcomm Ventures.
About_#4: Before Cloudflare, Prince was a law professor and cofounded Unspam Technologies, which helped block spam content for clients.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University; Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Stanford University
About_#1: Penny Pritzker is one of 11 billionaire heirs in the Pritzker clan, and the only one who has served in the White House.
About_#2: A key fundraiser for Presidents Obama and Biden, Pritzker was the U.S. Secretary of Commerce from 2013 to 2017.
About_#3: Pritzker is the founder and chairman of PSP Partners, a private investment firm with ventures in real estate, hedge funds and startups.
About_#4: Since re-entering the private sector, Pritzker has joined the boards of Microsoft and enterprise software startup Icertis.
Did You Know?: Pritzker was the first U.S. commerce secretary to visit Myanmar.

Education: Drop Out, Nihon University
About_#1: Yasumitsu Shigeta is chairman of Tokyo-listed Hikari Tsushin, which sells mobile phones at its HIT Shop chain of stores.
About_#2: The company also sells insurance and office equipment.
About_#3: He founded Hikari Tsushin in 1988.
About_#4: His wealth peaked at $42 billion before the dotcom crash in 2001 wiped out much of his fortune.

Education: Master of Science, Stockholm School of Economics
About_#1: Siemiatkowski cofounded Klarna in 2005, pioneering the buy-now, pay-later model in fintech that has been struggling in 2022.
About_#2: Klarna lets consumers pay for small and large retail items in installments. In July 2022, investors valued the company at $6.7 billion, down from a prior $45.6 billion.
About_#3: The lower valuation for Klarna means that Siemiatkowski is no longer a billionaire; he owns about 7% of Klarna.
About_#4: Siemiatkowski attended the Stockholm School of Economics and worked at an accounts-receivable factoring firm before starting Klarna.

About_#1: Barry Silbert is the founder and CEO of Digital Currency Group (DCG), a conglomerate of five cryptocurrency-focused companies.
About_#2: DCG's biggest revenue generator: digital asset manager Grayscale, which oversees $28 billion worth of Bitcoin, Ether and other assets.
About_#3: Through its numerous subsidiaries, DCG has also invested in more than 200 crypto startups.
About_#4: Prior to launching DCG, Silbert, a former investment banker, sold stock trading platform Second Market to Nasdaq in 2015 for an undisclosed amount.

About_#1: Daniel Sundheim is chief investment officer of hedge fund D1 Capital Partners, which he founded in 2018.
About_#2: The firm has around $22 billion in assets under management, with the majority invested in private companies.
About_#3: Sundheim bought a minority stake in the NBA's Charlotte Hornets from majority owner Michael Jordan in September 2019.
About_#4: Sundheim graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and spent 15 years working under billionaire Andreas Halvorsen at Viking Global Investors.

About_#1: Rita Tong Liu's portfolio includes prime Hong Kong office buildings such as the China Insurance Group Building and Austin Plaza, along with entire floors at Grand Millennium Plaza, Shun Tak Centre and Lippo Center.
About_#2: She entered the real estate business in 1976, wading into luxury flats and houses. She later went into the business of parking spaces.
About_#3: She was married to a high school sweetheart, the eighth of nine sons of Liu Po Shan, founder of Chong Hing Bank.
About_#4: After her husband died in 2003 she transitioned into grade-A commercial offices, capitalizing on the soaring prices in Hong Kong's financial district.
Did You Know?: Her grandmother worked the family business selling groceries and brewing rice wine in Macau. Then her widowed mother built houses with imported timber.

About_#1: Tran Dinh Long founded Hoa Phat Corp., an equipment and parts distributor, in Hanoi in 1992.
About_#2: Hoa Phat is now the biggest steel maker in Vietnam, making office equipment, steel pipes and construction steel.
About_#3: Hoa Phat's new $3 billion steel factory in Dung Quat, Vietnam has an annual capacity of five million tons.
About_#4: He's planning a further $3 billion expansion to meet the country's rising demand for steel.
Did You Know?: Tran is just the second businessman in Vietnam to buy a private plane.
In Their Own Words: A company needs to constantly grow. If it stops, it dies.

About_#1: John Caudwell founded mobile phone retailer Phones 4u before selling his stake in 2006 and 2011.
About_#2: Born into a working-class family, he and brother Brian first started selling mobile phones in 1987.
About_#3: Six years later the brothers founded Singlepoint, a mobile service provider that was acquired by Vodafone in 2003 for $650 million.
About_#4: Caudwell pumped his share of the money into Phones 4u, which grew into the U.K.'s largest independent mobile phone retailer.
Did You Know?: Caudwell is dating Lithuanian cycling champion and former Olympian Modesta Vzesniauskaite.
In Their Own Words: Those of us who have yet to find philanthropy may find there is a far greater reward from it than from wealth creation. I will give away at least half my wealth during my lifetime and after my death.

Education: Master of Business Administration, HEC Paris
About_#1: Philippe Foriel-Destezet, who founded staffing company Ecco in 1964, died at age 85 in June 2021. His company grew to become France's largest supplier of temporary personnel.
About_#2: Foriel-Destezet merged Ecco with Klaus Jacobs's Swiss firm Adia to create Adecco in 1996; the company is publicly traded.
About_#3: He stepped down as co-chairman of Adecco in 2005 and was made an honorary president in 2006.
About_#4: Through his Luxembourg holding company, Akila Finance, he owned more than 4% of the firm.

Education: Bachelor of Business Administration, London School of Economics; Bachelor of Business Administration, University of Zurich
About_#1: Walter Frey inherited his father's auto dealership group. In 1926, Emil Frey opened an automotive repair shop that became the Emil Frey Group.
About_#2: The company is now the largest auto dealer in Europe with operations in service, dealerships, and financing.
About_#3: Like his father, Walter was an accomplished race car driver. Walter controls the company but his interests also extend to politics and sports.
About_#4: He served in the Swiss parliament from 1987 to 2001; he is also president of Zurich ice hockey club ZSC Lions.

Education: Bachelor of Social Sciences, University of Milan
About_#1: Alessandra Garavoglia is a director of the board of Campari Group, one of the world's largest alcoholic beverage companies.
About_#2: Campari's brands includes Skyy Vodka, Wild Turkey, Aperol and Campari.
About_#3: Garavoglia inherited her stake in the company from her parents. Her mother, Rosa Anna Magno Garavoglia, died in 2016.
About_#4: She now owns an estimated 24% of the company, which listed on the Milan Stock Exchange in 2001.
Did You Know?: Garavoglia wrote her college dissertation on domestic life in Louisa May Alcott's American classic, "Little Women."

Education: Bachelor of Science, Oregon State University
About_#1: Peter Gassner is the CEO and founder of Veeva Systems, a cloud software provider for pharmaceutical and biotech companies.
About_#2: Before Veeva, Gassner worked at IBM, PeopleSoft and Salesforce.
About_#3: After 4 years at Salesforce, he saw an opportunity to offer software focused on life sciences built on Salesforce's platform.
About_#4: Gassner started Veeva in 2007, with Matt Wallach, who had a background in tech sales to big pharma.
Did You Know?: Gassner flies coach on international trips and likes to ride his bike to work.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, York University
About_#1: Mitchell Goldhar founded real estate firm SmartCentres in the early 1990s, then developed more than 265 shopping centers in the ensuing two decades.
About_#2: In May 2015, he sold most of SmartCentre's assets to SmartREIT (formerly Calloway REIT), for about $880 million in shares, cash and assumed debt.
About_#3: Goldhar, who chairs SmartREIT, also owns various developments across Canada through his private company Penguin Investments.
About_#4: This includes a stake, along with SmartREIT, in the Vaughan Metropolitan Centre, a 100-acre master planned development north of Toronto.
Did You Know?: Goldhar studied political science at York University and teaches a real estate development course at the University of Toronto.

About_#1: Otto Happel, who studied engineering, inherited his father's dust-removal business and turned it into thermal engineering firm GEA.
About_#2: In 1999, he sold his 50.1% GEA stake to Germany's MG Technologies for around $775 million in cash and kept a 10% interest in the combined group.
About_#3: In 2005, the company renamed itself GEA Group. Happel cashed out in 2006, selling his remaining stake to institutional investors for $700 million.
About_#4: In 2015, he attended the World Economic Forum in his role as chairman of the Swiss private wealth management firm Luserve AG.
Did You Know?: A foundation in his name supports projects in the developing world.

About_#1: From his spare bedroom in Bristol, England, Peter Hargreaves and pal Stephan Lansdown founded a financial-services firm in 1981.
About_#2: Hargreaves was a chartered accountant for businesses like KPMG before starting the company, Hargreaves Lansdown.
About_#3: He no longer sits on the firm's board, but still owns nearly a third of the $116 billion (assets under management) business.
About_#4: In 2017 Hargreaves launched Blue Whale, a fund manager for UK investors.
Did You Know?: Hargreaves is reportedly the second biggest financial backer of Brexit, donating more than $4 million to the cause.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University
About_#1: Bom Kim is the founder of South Korean e-commerce giant Coupang, which went public on the New York Stock Exchange in March 2021.
About_#2: Mimicking U.S.-based Amazon, Coupang is disrupting South Korea's online retail space by slashing prices and investing heavily in swift deliveries.
About_#3: In November 2018, it raised $2 billion from SoftBank's Vision Fund at a $9 billion valuation, making it Korea's most valuable privately-held startup.
About_#4: The March 2021 IPO of Coupang the biggest U.S. listing of an Asian company since Alibaba in 2014; Bom owns a roughly 10% stake.
Did You Know?: Kim worked at Boston Consulting Group before founding Vintage Media Company, which he sold in 2009. He started Coupang the next year.

About_#1: Li Gaiteng is the founder of Shanghai Flyco Electrical Appliance, a maker of personal care appliances such as electric razors and hair dryers.
About_#2: Li's wife Lin Yu'e is an executive director at Flyco, which is 88% owned by Li.
About_#3: Li started the business after working as a motorcycle repairman.

Education: EMBA, Peking University
About_#1: Li Liufa chairs the Tianrui Group of China, whose business includes steel, tourism, cement and minerals.
About_#2: Li worked at a fertilizer factory in Henan Province in the late 1970s before setting up his first business -- a small steel casting factory.
About_#3: Li holds an EMBA degree from Peking University.

About_#1: Lu Weiding is the CEO of Wanxiang Group, one of China's largest diversified non-government businesses.
