About_#2: Lu Weiding is the son of Lu Guanqiu, who founded the predecessor of Wanxiang Group in 1969; Guanqiu died in 2017.
About_#3: Wanxiang has yet to disclose the distribution of Lu Guanqiu's assets among the beneficiaries of his will.
About_#4: Lu Weiding chairs China Wanxiang, whose business includes insurance and fintech.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Harsh Mariwala transformed his family's trading business in spices and edible oils into consumer goods giant Marico.
About_#2: Marico, which is best known for its Saffola cooking oil and Parachute hair oil, sells in 25 countries.
About_#3: The company also sells Saffola FITTIFY, a range of healthy soups and shakes. It has ntroduced immunity boosting products under Saffola ImmuniVeda.
About_#4: Mariwala's other interests include Kaya, a chain of skin care clinics.
Did You Know?: His son Rishabh has a board seat at Marico and overlooks Sharrp Ventures, the Mariwala family office.

About_#1: Samir Mehta gets the bulk of his wealth from Torrent Pharmaceuticals, flagship of his family's $2.7 billion (revenue) Torrent Group.
About_#2: The 63-year-old company was founded by his late father Uttambhai Nathalal Mehta, who was a salesman for Swiss pharma giant Sandoz.
About_#3: He also has a stake in Torrent Power, which provides electricity to more than 3.7 million customers in his home state of Gujarat and two other states.
About_#4: While Samir Mehta runs the pharma unit, his older sibling Sudhir's son,Jinal, oversees the power firm.
Did You Know?: His father started his career as a government clerk in 1944.

About_#1: Sudhir Mehta is chairman emeritus of the $2.7 billion (revenue) Torrent Group comprising Torrent Pharma, Torrent Power and Torrent Gas.
About_#2: His younger brother Samir Mehta, also a billionaire, chairs the pharma and power companies.
About_#3: His son Jinal Mehta is managing director of Torrent Power. His younger son Varun is executive director in the power business.
About_#4: Torrent Power distributes electricity to more than 3.7 million customers in his home state of Gujarat and two other states.
Did You Know?: The 63-year-old pharma company was founded by their late father Uttambhai Nathalal Mehta, who was a salesman for Swiss pharma giant Sandoz.

About_#1: Pawan Munjal, son of late Brijmohan Lall Munjal, founder of Hero Group, who died in 2015 at age 92, runs motorcycle flagship Hero MotoCorp.
About_#2: A former partner of Japan's Honda, Hero is the world's largest producer of two-wheelers by volume having sold more than 100 million units to date.
About_#3: After parting ways with Honda in 2011, Pawan has led a global expansion with factories in Colombia and Bangladesh.
About_#4: In September, the group's renewable energy arm, Hero Future Energies, partnered with global investment firm KKR to invest $450 million in expanding capacity.
Did You Know?: Munjal's younger sibling Sunil stepped down as Hero' s joint managing director in 2016 to run his own independent businesses.
In Their Own Words: A lot of hard work and a little bit of luck, I guess, can create magic.

About_#1: Vietnam's first self-made woman billionaire took her budget airline, VietJet Air, public in February 2017.
About_#2: She launched the airline in 2011 and made a big splash early on with ads featuring bikini-clad flight attendants.
About_#3: She also has investments in HD Bank and real estate, including three beach resorts.
About_#4: In October 2021, she pledged $200 million to Oxford University's Linacre College for a new graduate centre and to endow post-graduate scholarships. The college will be renamed Thao College.
Did You Know?: Nguyen got the idea to launch a low-cost airline while she was a trader, when she predicted that demand for air travel in Vietnam would increase.
In Their Own Words: I have always aimed big and done big deals. I have never done anything on a small scale. When people were trading one container [of goods], I was already trading hundreds of containers.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Madhukar Parekh is chairman of Pidilite Industries, a company founded by his late father, Balvant Parekh, in 1959.
About_#2: He has a minority stake in Pidilite, which is India's leading maker of adhesives and sealants.
About_#3: Pidilite's range of products includes construction chemicals, art materials and organic pigments.
About_#4: His younger brother, Ajay Parekh, also a billionaire, has a board seat.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Ural State Technical University
About_#1: Sergei Popov has cashed out of all his major investments in recent years.
About_#2: He and his former partner Andrei Melnichenko made a fortune managing finance and industrial group MDM.
About_#3: They later created TMK, one of the world's largest oil and gas pipe manufacturers, with fellow billionaire Dmitry Pumpyansky.
About_#4: They sold out to Pumpyansky in 2006. That same year the partners started to divide up their assets, a process completed in 2012.
Did You Know?: Popov is a founder of a private fund called Agat, which has a mentoring program that offers young businesspeople startup capital.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: Haim Saban turned his success with children's TV show "Mighty Morphin Power Rangers" into Fox Family Channel, a joint venture with News Corp.
About_#2: Saban, who repurchased Power Rangers back in 2010, sold it for a second time in 2018, this time to Hasbro in a $522 million deal.
About_#3: Saban and a group of private equity investors purchased Spanish language TV Network Univision Communications for $13.7 billion in 2007.
About_#4: In February 2020, Univision agreed to sell a majority stake for an undisclosed price to two firms: Searchlight Capital Partners and ForgeLight LLC.
Did You Know?: Born in Egypt to Jewish parents, Saban moved with his family to Tel Aviv when he was a child and lived in a one-room flat.
In Their Own Words: Huggable lamb that I am, people tell me I'm a tough negotiator.

Education: Bachelor of Technology, Indian Institute of Technology; Master of Arts/Science, Princeton University
About_#1: Sarma founded hedge fund SRS Investment Management in 2006 after five years at Chase Coleman's Tiger Global and now manages $10 billion.
About_#2: SRS owns 43% of Avis through common stock and equity swaps, and Sarma has served on the car rental company's board since May 2020.
About_#3: Avis stock surged 456% in 2021, fueled by talk of adding electric vehicles to its fleet, which helped Sarma's flagship fund return 35%.
About_#4: Sarma is an Indian immigrant who came to New York to get his master's at Princeton and spent three years as a consultant at McKinsey.

About_#1: Klaus-Peter Schulenberg is founder and CEO of CTS Eventim, leader in the European ticket and live entertainment market.
About_#2: His acquisition of regional concert promoters, ticketing agencies, venue operators and event producers has created friction with cartel authorities.
About_#3: Before the coronavirus pandemic, the company, of which Schulenberg owns 39%, sold more than 250 million tickets annually.
About_#4: In 2018, Germany's transportation ministry awarded CTS Eventim and Austria's Kapsch TrafficCom a 12-year contract to collect passenger vehicle tolls.
Did You Know?: Hit hard by the pandemic, CTS Eventim's revenues for first nine months of 2020 fell 79% from the prior year, to $255 million.
In Their Own Words: I've been asked why CTS Eventim, over all these years, has been so well received by the capital market. The reason is simple: we've always placed a higher value on the good of our company than on the capital market's appraisal.

Education: Drop Out, University of Northern Colorado
About_#1: Pat Stryker is a philanthropist and founder of Bohemian Foundation, which supports music, community, global and civic programs.
About_#2: The healthcare heir has given $225 million to charity over her lifetime, primarily through the foundation.
About_#3: Her grandfather founded Stryker Corp., which sold $14.4 billion worth of medical equipment in 2020.
About_#4: In 2016, she and her brother, Jon Stryker, gave a combined $10 million to fund the nation's first memorial to the victims of racial terror lynchings.
Did You Know?: Stryker lives in Fort Collins, Colorado, where she has been redeveloping downtown real estate.
In Their Own Words: Dad (Lee Stryker) believed strongly in justice and equality and through his words and deeds taught us those values from the earliest age.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Jeff Sutton built a fortune buying Manhattan storefronts, and boasts pricey leases to brands such as Armani and Prada.
About_#2: He first made waves by signing American Girl to his Fifth Avenue store for the doll retailer's first flagship location in Manhattan.
About_#3: The doll retailer opened the store in 2003; it moved to Rockefeller Plaza 15 years later.
About_#4: In late 2016, Sutton and SL Green signed Nike to a new lease, wooing the sports brand out of its Trump-owned location.
Did You Know?: As a retail broker, Sutton drove a Payless Shoesource executive around and asked him to point to a location he wanted. He then bought it and leased it to him.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Tennessee Technological University
About_#1: Jon Yarbrough started Video Gaming Technologies, which produced casino games, in 1991.
About_#2: The business grew due to the proliferation of tribal casinos; Yarbrough says he's worked with around 35 tribes in 100-plus locations over the years.
About_#3: Yarbrough sold his company to Australian firm Aristocrat Leisure in 2014 for about $1.3 billion.
About_#4: These days he manages his investments, which include real estate and tech stocks, through his family office Yarbrough Capital.
Did You Know?: As a college student, Yarbrough loaned his foosball table to a local arcade in exchange for 50% of its profits; now he keeps the table in his office.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Carnegie Mellon
About_#1: Gang Ye cofounded online gaming and e-commerce firm, Sea, with Forrest Li.
About_#2: He's been group chief operating officer since January 2017, following his previous role as group chief technology officer.
About_#3: Ye previously worked at the Economic Development Board of Singapore and palm oil major Wilmar International.
About_#4: Backed by Tencent, which now has a 20% stake, Sea's other investors include private equity firm General Atlantic.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Zhejiang University
About_#1: Yi Zheng chairs Hithink Royal Flush Information Network, a Shenzhen-listed financial data supplier.
About_#2: He cofounded his first IT company back in October 1994 and Hithink's predecessor business Shanghai Hexin in 2001.
About_#3: He owns 36% of Hithink.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University
About_#1: Bill Ackman founded and runs Pershing Square Capital Management.
About_#2: Ackman created Pershing Square in 2004 and rose to fame for his short of bond insurer MBIA and his rescue of mall operator General Growth.
About_#3: Coming out of the crisis, he at times topped Wall Street with activist wins on Canadian Pacific, Fortune Brands and Allergan.
About_#4: He hit hard times after trying to merge Allergan and Valeant in 2014. He made over $1 billion on the former, but lost $3 billion on the latter.

About_#1: Markus Blocher is a billionaire thanks to two Swiss chemical companies, EMS-Chemie and Dottikon ES Holding.
About_#2: Blocher got his start working at EMS-Chemie, the Swiss polymer and chemical manufacturer that his family has run for decades.
About_#3: He received a stake in the firm when his father, Christoph Blocher, sold his shares to his children to take a seat on the Swiss federal council.
About_#4: Markus eventually sold his shares in EMS-Chemie and took over Dottikon, its spinoff.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: Neal Blue is chairman and CEO of $3.1 billion (est. sales) General Atomics, a defense company based in San Diego.
About_#2: The company is best known as the manufacturer of the Predator drone, one of the first drones to fly over Afghanistan after 9/11.
About_#3: The largest private government contractor in the U.S., GA's clients include foreign nations such as Italy, Spain, and the UAE.
About_#4: With his brother Linden, he bought the then nuclear energy company from Chevron for a reported $60 million in 1986.
Did You Know?: Linden Blue, who owns a smaller stake and is a vice president at the company, is worth $800 million.

About_#1: Eva Maria Bucher-Haefner's fortune mostly stems from her former stake in IT management software maker CA Technologies, acquired by Broadcom in 2020.
About_#2: She inherited half of her father Walter's stake in the business when he died in June 2012, then the world's oldest billionaire at 101.
About_#3: She and her brother, Martin Haefner, also inherited equal stakes in car dealer AMAG.
About_#4: Bucher-Haefner sold her stake in AMAG to Martin, who is also a billionaire, in late 2018.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Taipei University of Marine Technology
About_#1: Chang Kuo-Hua is the oldest son of shipping tycoon Chang Yung Fa, who died in 2016 at the age of 88.
About_#2: In 1968 Yung Fa founded Evergreen Marine, now one of the world's largest transportation companies.
About_#3: Brothers Kuo-Hua, Kuo-Ming and Kuo-Cheng also inherited stakes in EVA Airways and hotels in Taiwan, mainland China, Paris and Bangkok.
About_#4: Kuo-Hua sits on the board of Evergreen Marine.

Education: Drop Out, High School
About_#1: A high school dropout, Todd Christopher founded hair care products company Vogue International in 1987.
About_#2: Christopher sold a stake to the Carlyle Group in 2014. Two years later, they sold the company to Johnson & Johnson for $3.3 billion.
About_#3: Before the sale, Vogue International borrowed several hundred million dollars and made a $400 million distribution to Christopher.
About_#4: Vogue International owns hair care brands like OGX and Maui Moisture.
Did You Know?: The fourth generation of a family of hairdressers, Christopher opened his first salon in his twenties. Short on cash, he slept in his salon to save money.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Korea University; Master of Business Administration, University of San Francisco
About_#1: Euisun Chung was appointed chairman of Hyundai Motor in March 2020, succeeding his father, Mong-Koo Chung, who retired from the board.
About_#2: As president of Kia from 2005 to 2009, Chung grew the subsidiary auto brand faster than Hyundai Motor.
About_#3: A bulk of his fortune is derived from auto parts maker Hyundai Glovis.
About_#4: He is the only son of Mong-Koo Chung, who is also a billionaire.
Did You Know?: Chung worked at the New York office of Japanese trading house Itochu Corp. before joining Hyundai's auto parts affiliate, Hyundai Mobis, in 1994.

About_#1: Bernie Ecclestone took Formula One from a niche racing competition to a global phenomenon over a four decade career.
About_#2: The man dubbed "F1 Supremo" by the British tabloids finally gave up the helm in January 2017, when Liberty Media bought F1 for $4.4 billion.
About_#3: Son of a trawler captain, he built one of the U.K.'s largest used car dealerships after World War II then bought the Brabham racing team in 1971.
About_#4: Ecclestone eventually took control of F1's governance and lorded over the business despite selling most of his stake in the late 1990s.
Did You Know?: Ecclestone met former model Slavica, who was his wife for 24 years until their 2009 divorce, while jetting from race to race in the 1980s.

About_#1: Michael Federmann is chairman of Federmann Enterprises, a family-owned private holding company with diversified interests.
About_#2: Through the family holding group, he owns an estimated 28% of Elbit Systems, a $4.6 billion (2020 sales) defense and homeland security tech company.
About_#3: He also owns an estimated 43% of Dan Hotels, a publicly-traded Israeli hotel chain.

About_#1: Gudrun Heine's father founded Karl Storz SE & Co. KG in 1945 to manufacture ENT (Ear, Nose & Throat) instruments, headlamps and binocular loupes.
About_#2: Karl Storz pioneered the idea of introducing into the body (via a flexible fiber-optic cable) bright light generated by an external source.
About_#3: This "cold light illumination" innovation paved the way for modern endoscopy and laid the foundation for the company's future success.
About_#4: Today, with a portfolio of 15,000+ products, Storz is a leader in endoscopy instruments for human and veterinary medicine as well as industrial use.

About_#1: Austrian heiress Heidi Horten, who was known for her nearly billion dollar art collection, died on June 12, just days after opening her own private museum in Vienna.
About_#2: Horten amassed her art collection, spanning some 500 works from the likes of Bacon, Picasso and Warhol, over several decades.
About_#3: Horten inherited a $1 billion fortune from her husband, Helmut Horten (d. 1987), who founded the German department store Horten AG in 1936.
About_#4: She met the much older Horten in a bar in Austria in 1959, when she was 19.
Did You Know?: She was an avid ice hockey fan.
In Their Own Words: I am proud, with my collection and the construction of the museum, to have created something lasting, which future generations will also be able to experience when they visit my museum and take joy in the art that has given me such joy for so long.

About_#1: Huang Dawen derives his fortune from a stake in Shanghai-listed Hoshine Silicon Industry.
About_#2: Huang is also the vice chairman of Ningbo Hoshine Apparel.
About_#3: Hoshine Silicon Industry makes silicon and silicon-related products in China.

About_#1: Sheldon Lavin owns OSI Group, a $6 billion (revenues) global meat processor that started out as the original fresh hamburger supplier to McDonald's.
About_#2: OSI still supplies most of McDonald's meat products worldwide, and produces plant-based burgers for Impossible Foods.
About_#3: Lavin joined OSI as a consultant in 1970 to figure out how to finance the company's first modern meat plant as McDonald's franchising took off.
About_#4: He became a fulltime employee and took over the business in the 1980s, acquiring an estimated 90% stake over time.
Did You Know?: German immigrant Otto Kolschowsky started a butcher shop in the Chicago suburbs in 1909 which eventually became OSI.

About_#1: Li Min chairs Fuzhou Rockchip Electronics, a supplier of integrated circuits for smartphones and tablet computers.
About_#2: Rockchip's clients include Intel, Samsung, Huawei.
About_#3: Li cofounded Rochchip in the Chinese city of Fuzhou in 2001.
About_#4: Li is a graduate of eastern China's Zhejiang University.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Sun Yat-sen University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Zhongnan University of Economics and Law
About_#1: Liang Yunchao chairs Guandong By-health, one of China's largest producers of vitamins and health supplements.
About_#2: Every few years he invites young leaders to join a "wildlife training" boot camp to test their stamina, Liang told Forbes Asia in 2015.
About_#3: His favorite boot camp spots include Teklimakan Qumluqi in Xinjiang, the world's second largest desert, and Antarctica.

Education: Drop Out, Stanford University
About_#1: Joe Liemandt is the founder of ESW Capital, an investment firm that purchases software companies.
About_#2: ESW Capital has purchased more than 100 small U.S. software companies with a strategy of moving their workforce to foreign freelance workers.
About_#3: Liemandt is known for founding Trilogy Software, a product and sales configuration software company that was prominent in the 1990s.
About_#4: He dropped out of Stanford to start Trilogy Software. By age 27, he was on the cover of Forbes magazine.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, University of Wales
About_#1: Strive Masiyiwa overcame protracted government opposition to launch mobile phone network Econet Wireless Zimbabwe in his country of birth in 1998.
About_#2: He owns just over 50% of the publicly-traded Econet Wireless Zimbabwe, which is one part of his larger Econet Group.
About_#3: Masiyiwa also owns just over half of private company Liquid Telecom, which provides fiber optic and satellite services to telecom firms across Africa.
About_#4: His other assets include stakes in mobile phone networks in Burundi and Lesotho, and investments in fintech and power distribution firms in Africa.
Did You Know?: After studying at university in Britain, Masiyiwa worked at ZPTC, Zimbabwe's phone company.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Toho Gakuen tanki University
About_#1: Masahiro Miki owns a majority stake in discount shoe store chain ABC-Mart.
About_#2: ABC-Mart owns U.S. shoe brand Danner.
About_#3: A former amateur boxer, Miki founded ABC-Mart in the 1980s.
About_#4: He stepped down as chairman of the publicly traded company in 2007.

About_#1: Low-profile founder of Nirma, Karsanbhai Patel, started out mixing detergents in his backyard and selling them door-to-door on his bicycle.
About_#2: His low-price Nirma brand sparked a detergents war with bigger rivals such as Unilever and Procter & Gamble.
About_#3: Today Nirma is one of the largest producers of soda ash in the world by volume.
About_#4: Patel has long handed over operations to the next generation and took the company private in 2012.
Did You Know?: Patel was born into a farmer's family in Gujarat and started his career as a lab assistant.

About_#1: Arvind Poddar and his family control Balkrishna Industries, which provides off-highway tires for the agriculture, mining and construction sectors.
About_#2: Poddar is chairman and managing director of the company while his son Rajiv is the joint managing director.
About_#3: With roots in the textile business going back to 1951, Balkrishna Industries started making bicycle tires in 1963.
About_#4: Poddar entered the off-highway tire market in the mid-1990s and now supplies to clients in Europe and the Americas.

About_#1: Remo Ruffini turned around a nearly bankrupt luxury sportswear firm Moncler, taking the company public in 2013 in one of Italy's largest IPOs in years
About_#2: Ruffini started out as the company's creative director in 1999 and a few years later bought the brand. Now chairman and CEO, he owns a 20% stake.
About_#3: Ruffini introduced new colors and designs at Moncler, and partnered with the Carlyle Group to expand internationally.
About_#4: He got his start in the U.S. working for his father's clothing company, Gianfranco Ruffini.
Did You Know?: In December 2021, in Ruffini's first acquisition since taking over, Moncler bought sportswear brand Stone Island in a $1.4 billion cash-and-stock deal.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, University of New South Wales; Master of Science in Engineering, University of New South Wales
About_#1: Eddy Kusnadi Sariaatmadja cofounded Emtek in 1983 as the exclusive Compaq computer distributor in Indonesia; he has a majority stake.
About_#2: Emtek currently controls three Indonesian TV channels, SCTV, Indosiar and O Channel.
About_#3: His son Alvin Sariaatmadja is president director of Emtek, which is formally called Elang Mahkota Teknologi.
About_#4: Emtek has collaborated with Alibaba's Ant Financial for Dana, a digital payment system in Indonesia.
Did You Know?: In 2017, his media company Emtek hosted the Indonesian Diaspora Network Global event, featuring former U.S. President Barack Obama as a speaker.

About_#1: Sybill Storz's father founded Karl Storz SE & Co. KG in 1945 to manufacture ENT (Ear, Nose & Throat) instruments, headlamps and binocular loupes.
About_#2: Karl Storz pioneered the idea of introducing into the body (via a flexible fiber-optic cable) bright light generated by an external source.
About_#3: This "cold light illumination" innovation paved the way for modern endoscopy and laid the foundation for the company's future success.
About_#4: Today, with a portfolio of 15,000+ products, Storz is a leader in endoscopy instruments for human and veterinary medicine as well as industrial use.
Did You Know?: Her sister, Gudrun Heine, also owns 44%.

About_#1: Lawrence Stroll masterminded Michael Kors' hugely successful IPO in 2011 with business partner Silas Chou, a Hong Kong fashion tycoon.
About_#2: The bulk of Stroll's fortune comes from selling his shares in the American fashion brand; he sold the last of his stake in 2014.
About_#3: In Aug. 2018, Stroll led a group of investors to buy Formula One racing team Force India for £90 million plus assumption of £15 million in debt.
About_#4: After leading a $235.6 million (£182 million) investment in Aston Martin in early 2020, Stroll became executive chairman of the car company.
Did You Know?: Stroll collects vintage Ferraris, one of which he purchased for a record-breaking $27.5 million in 2013.

About_#1: Siblings Wijono and Hermanto Tanoko control Avia Avian, reportedly Indonesia's second-largest domestic paint company.
About_#2: The company was founded in 1978 by their father Soetikno Tanoko.
About_#3: Under Hermanto, the group has expanded into consumer goods, property and retail.
About_#4: The brothers took the company public in 2021.

Education: Master of Business Administration, University of Vienna; Master of Laws, University of Vienna
About_#1: Tojner bought German microbattery maker Varta in 2007 for $40 million and floated the business on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange in 2017.
About_#2: His 56% stake in Varta, which is reported to make the batteries for Apple AirPod Pros, is worth more than $1 billion.
About_#3: A serial entrepreneur, he has run an online gambling website, invested in real estate and hotels and has investments in other industrial companies.
About_#4: He bought the Hotel InterContinental Vienna for 50 million euro in 2012 but local opposition has stalled his efforts to redevelop it.

Education: Fordham University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania
About_#1: New York Attorney General Letitia James sued Trump and his business in September 2022, saying the Trump Organization had engaged in years of financial fraud by lying about the value of its assets to make itself look more creditworthy to financial institutions.
About_#2: While much of Trump's fortune remains tied up in New York City real estate, the former president got a $730 million boost from Trump Media and Technology Group, the parent company to Twitter knockoff Truth Social.
About_#3: The former U.S. president also owns golf courses and a winery, and he has licensed his name to companies around the world.
About_#4: In 2019, he changed his official residence from Trump Tower in New York City to Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, FL.
Did You Know?: Trump played basketball, football, soccer and baseball while attending the New York Military Academy in Cornwall-on-Hudson, New York.
In Their Own Words: I took a lot of finance courses at Wharton. First they taught you all the rules and regulations. Then they taught you that those rules and regulations are really meant to be broken.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, National Taiwan University; Master of Science in Engineering, University of Cincinnati
About_#1: Tsai is chairman and CEO of smartphone chipmaker MediaTek, which was spun off from another company he ran.
About_#2: Faced with escalating competition in a plateauing sector, Tsai brought in Rick Tsai (who is not related) as his co-CEO in June 2018.
About_#3: Tsai studied electrical engineering first in Taiwan and later in the U.S.
Did You Know?: Long-regarded as the father of Taiwan's chip-design industry, Tsai was nicknamed "King of the Bandit Phones" since MediaTek powered mainly low-end mobile phones.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Southern Methodist University
About_#1: John Tyson is chairman of Tyson Foods, which produces about 20% of America's beef, pork and chicken.
About_#2: The conglomerate owns beloved brands like Hillshire Farms, Jimmy Dean and Aidells sausages.
About_#3: Tyson Foods was originally founded by his grandfather in 1935.
About_#4: Tyson began working at Tyson Foods at 13, transferring eggs to incubators in the hatchery and vaccinating chickens on the farm.
In Their Own Words: You strive every day to try to do the right thing. It goes back to my granddad, to my dad and the people he had around him and it's reflected in today's company and leadership. We care about our folks, our communities, our farmer relationships.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Universidad Iberoamericana
About_#1: Rufino Vigil Gonzalez is a Mexican steel baron and chairman of specialty steel firm Industrias CH.
About_#2: In 2001 Industrias CHi bought just under 83% of Grupo Simec, a steel smelter with factories in Guadalajara and Mexicali.
About_#3: He owns about 67% of Industrias CH, which has operations in Mexico, Canada and the U.S.

About_#1: Wang Ning is founder and CEO of Pop Mart International Group, a toy company that listed its shares in Hong Kong in December 2020.
About_#2: Wang, who founded Pop Mart in 2010, owns about 46% of Pop Mart's shares.
About_#3: Pop Mart sells small figurines that cost about $8 in so-called blind boxes that don't reveal the exact toy inside.
About_#4: The company partners with artists to come up with different lines of toys.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, People's University of China; Doctorate, Tianjin University
About_#1: Energy entrepreneur Wang Yusuo went into business after he failed to pass the country's tough college entrance exams.
About_#2: Wang's ENN Group is a vertically integrated natural gas company with interests in China and overseas.
About_#3: Wang's main listed companies are ENN Natural Gas, ENN Energy Holdings and ENC Digital Technology
About_#4: Wang's son Wang Zizheng is a director on the board of ENN Group.

About_#1: Wu Zhigang chairs Shanghai-listed bakery chain Shenyang Toly Bread.
About_#2: Wu was a teacher at an industrial school before founding the chain with his son Wu Xuequn in 1995; Xuequn is the company's general manager.
About_#3: Wu Zhigang's wife, Sheng Yali, and sons Wu Xuedong, Wu Xuequn and Wu Xueliang hold shares in Toly.
About_#4: Xuedong, Xuequn and Xueliang are board members.

About_#1: Oren Zeev is the founding partner of Zeev Ventures, a one-man, Silicon Valley-based venture capital firm that makes early-round investments in tech companies.
About_#2: He led early investments in small start-ups that evolved into billion-dollar companies, such as Chegg, Houzz, TripActions, Tipalti and Firebolt.
About_#3: Prior to that, he worked at IBM in Israel and was a partner at private equity firm Apax Partners.
In Their Own Words: I only invest in companies that I feel proud to tell others about.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Long Island University; Master of Science, New York University
About_#1: Charles Zegar is one of four billionaire cofounders of financial services and media giant Bloomberg LP.
About_#2: Zegar, who got a computer science degree at NYU, built the first software for Bloomberg LP's terminals.
About_#3: The son of a subway conductor, he was widowed as a young man and remarried in 2001.
About_#4: He and his current wife, Merryl Snow Zegar, donate to Jewish causes and inner-city education via their Zegar Family Foundation.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Renmin University of China; Master of Business Administration, The Yale School of Management; Master of Arts, Yale University
About_#1: Zhang Lei is the founder and CEO of Hillhouse Capital Management.
About_#2: Zhang holds and MBA and M.A. in international relations from Yale University.
About_#3: Zhang holds a B.A. from Renmin University in Beijing, where he is vice chairman of the board of trustees.

About_#1: Zhang Xin and her husband Pan Shiyi lead real estate developer Soho China.
About_#2: Soho China is listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange and develops office towers in Shanghai and Beijing.
About_#3: In June 2021, U.S. firm Blackstone said it would buy the majority of Soho China for as much as $3.05 billion.
About_#4: Prior to founding Soho China, Zhang worked on Wall Street for Goldman Sachs and Travelers Group.

About_#1: Zhu Yan, the widow of Zuo Hui, inherited the fortune held by the KE Holding founder after his death in May 2021.
About_#2: KE Holdings, which trades on the New York Stock Exchange, is one of the world's largest real estate brokerage chains, with $10.8 billion revenues in 2020.
About_#3: Zuo Hui, a pioneering real estate tycoon who founded and ran listed firm KE Holdings, died at age 50 of an undisclosed illness.
About_#4: Zuo Hui formed KE Holdings in 2018 to encompass several companies: Lianjia, Beike and a property financial services firm he'd launched in 2010.

Education: LLM, Harvard University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, McGill University; Master of Business Administration, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Real estate icon Mortimer Zuckerman stepped down as Boston Properties chairman in 2016 after nearly five decades running the REIT.
About_#2: The son of Ukrainian Jewish immigrants who settled in Montreal and sold tobacco and candy, Zuckerman founded Boston Properties in 1970.
About_#3: Zuckerman became a U.S. citizen in 1977, and took Boston Properties public two decades later.
About_#4: He still owns roughly 5% of the public company, which operates a diverse portfolio of primarily office space totaling nearly 50 million square feet.
Did You Know?: In October 2016, Columbia University announced the Mortimer B. Zuckerman Mind Brain Behavior Institute; he pledged $200 million in 2012 to fund it.
In Their Own Words: America will never recover its full prosperity and the jobs it can create as long as individual legislators yield to the blandishments and blackmail of special-interest groups.

About_#1: Juan Abelló sold his family's pharmaceutical company the early 1980s and then put the money into a variety of investments.
About_#2: He owns a stake in for-profit education company Laureate Education.
About_#3: He also owns a piece of Prestige Motor Holdings, the largest shareholder of car maker Aston Martin.
About_#4: He often appears in tabloids alongside well-known politicians and members of Spanish artistic and cultural circles.

About_#1: John Armitage is the cofounder and chief investment officer of Egerton Capital, a hedge fund firm with $22 billion under management.
About_#2: Armitage was born in the U.K., but in 2018 he changed his citizenship to Irish.
About_#3: Egerton Capital has generated $22.6 billion of net gains since inception in 1995, according to LCH Investments.

About_#1: Bang Si-hyuk is the founder and chairman of Hybe (formerly Big Hit Entertainment), one of Korea's largest music labels and entertainment agencies.
About_#2: He took the company public in October 2020 in what was South Korea's largest IPO in three years, which made him a billionaire.
About_#3: Hybe's success is attributed to its seven-member boy band, BTS, which scored five No. 1 albums on the U.S. Billboard 200.
About_#4: Bang worked as a composer for JYP Entertainment, one of Korea's "Big Three" music agencies, before venturing out on his own.

About_#1: Miriam Baumann-Blocher's fortune stems from her stake in Ems-Chemie, her family's Swiss polymer and chemical manufacturing giant.
About_#2: She received her stake in 2004 when her father, Christoph Blocher, sold his shares to his children to take a seat on the Swiss federal council.
About_#3: Over the years Miriam and her brother Markus sold most of their shares to their sisters, Magdalena and Rahel, to run businesses of their own.
About_#4: In 2007 Miriam purchased Läckerli-Huus, a Swiss confectionery and baked goods company that she still manages today.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, Stanford University; Master of Business Administration, Stanford University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Calif Davis
About_#1: Riley Bechtel ran Bechtel, his family's construction and engineering firm, from 1990 to 2014.
About_#2: He stepped down as CEO in 2014 after being diagnosed with Parkinson's disease.
About_#3: His son Brendan is the current chairman and CEO and the fifth generation to run the company.
About_#4: Together, Riley and Brendan own an estimated 20% of the company; Riley continues to serve as a Bechtel board member.

About_#1: Wilhelm Beier is the chairman of the supervisory board of Dermapharm, a pharmaceutical company he founded in 1991.
About_#2: Dermapharm, based in Gruenwald near Munich, manufacturers generic drugs for maladies ranging from insect bites to fungal diseases and osteoporosis.
About_#3: Nearly half of its revenues come from the so-called "parallel trade'': arbitraging price differences for drugs between countries.
About_#4: Dermapharm, which went public in 2018, is expanding into the business of medical marijuana. Beier and his family still own 65% of the company.
Did You Know?: Wilhelm's wife Elisabeth, who owns 12.5% of Dermapharm, runs the company's international business, while son Michael runs online perfume shop Point Rouge.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, New York University
About_#1: The son of a wealthy art collector, Nicolas Berggruen was born in Paris and moved to the U.S. to attend New York University.
About_#2: He first worked in real estate for Bass Brothers Enterprises before founding Berggruen Holdings in 1985 to manage his investments.
About_#3: In 1988, he cofounded Alpha Investment Management, a fund of hedge funds operation that was sold to Safra Bank in 2004 for an undisclosed amount.
About_#4: His Berggruen Holdings owns office buildings and apartments in Berlin, Germany; Portland, Oregon and Albany, New York.
In Their Own Words: "By not only learning but then by investing in the world of ideas, in the world of new ideas, I could not only learn something for me, but hopefully contribute."

About_#1: Bui Thanh Nhon is chairman of the Nova Group, whose flagship is real estate company No Va Land Investment Group.
About_#2: The group's other interests include consumer goods, entertainment and food and beverage.
About_#3: He used to work for the government before venturing out on his own in 1992, with a company selling animal feed and medicine.
About_#4: He got into real estate in 2007 with a condo project in Ho Chi Minh City.

About_#1: Cao Longxiang chairs Hubei Jumpcan Pharmaceutical, one of China's largest drug companies.
About_#2: Cao was a manager at a cement factory before taking a job with the predecessor to Jumpcan.
About_#3: Cao's son, Cao Fei, is a member of the board at Jumpcan and serves as vice chairman.

About_#1: Deng Wen chairs Sichuan Teway Food Group, a supplier of hot-pot condiments.
About_#2: Deng acquired three brands owned by Teway in 1999 when the company was a collective.
About_#3: Teway raised $79 million in a China IPO to support expansion in 2019.

Education: Bachelor of Science, University of Bucharest; Master of Science, University of Bucharest
About_#1: Daniel Dines is cofounder and CEO of UiPath, a robotic process automation company that went public on the New York Stock Exchange in April 2021.
About_#2: Dines started DeskOver in 2005 in Bucharest, Romania. He later renamed it UiPath and moved its headquarters to New York City in 2018.
About_#3: Customers like Japan's Sumitomo Mitsui bank or Toyota North America can spend millions on UiPath's virtual "robot" that can automate complex, repetitive tasks.
About_#4: An avid reader, Dines said in a 2019 Forbes cover story that he reads in the mornings, often not showing up to UiPath's office until 11 am.

Education: Master of Business Administration, New York University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, San Diego
About_#1: Joseph Edelman is CEO and portfolio manager of Perceptive Advisors, a New York-based hedge fund firm with $10 billion under management.
About_#2: Edelman founded Perceptive Advisors in 1999 and focuses on investing in biotechnology stocks.
About_#3: Edelman's main Perceptive Life Sciences hedge fund is down 20% in 2021. Ithas lost money in only three years since inception.
About_#4: His fund generated returns of 52% in 2019 and 29% in 2020.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Saskatchewan; Doctor of Jurisprudence, University of Toronto
About_#1: N. Murray Edwards derives much of his fortune from stakes in Canadian oil and mining companies.
About_#2: His largest investments include oil sands miner Canadian Natural Resources, aerospace firm Magellan and a minority stake in the NHL's Calgary Flames.
About_#3: A lawyer by training, Edwards made the jump to business at age 28 after promising a dying friend that he would always pursue his passions.
About_#4: He started a merchant bank with partners in the late 1980's, but they spent half their initial capital on digging a natural gas well that came up dry.
Did You Know?: Edwards worked four nights a week during high school as a hockey referee.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Manhattanville College
About_#1: Jane Goldman is America's only female billionaire running a real estate firm. She heads up Solil Management, which she owns with her three siblings.
About_#2: The youngest daughter of Sol Goldman (d. 1987), once New York's biggest landlord, she oversees a portfolio that includes at least 400 properties.
About_#3: Trophies include apartments on the Upper East Side and the block of land in Midtown Manhattan that includes the Olympic Tower and the Cartier Mansion.
About_#4: The family also owns a 17% stake in the World Trade Center developments in lower Manhattan.
Did You Know?: The New York City resident paid $31 million in 2015 for a Palm Beach estate originally owned by the Kennedys; she sold it for $70 million in June 2020.

About_#1: Stewart Horejsi began buying stock in Berkshire Hathaway for as little as $265 per share after reading John Train's "The Money Masters" in 1980.
About_#2: He attended annual meetings when they were fewer than a dozen people in folding chairs; now Berkshire's class A stock is the world's most valuable.
About_#3: Horejsi (pronounced hor-ish) still owns some Berkshire shares, but has also put hundreds of millions of dollars into his own closed-end mutual fund.
About_#4: After graduating from the University of Kansas in 1962, Horejsi returned home to Salina, Kansas to take over his family's welding supply company.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, SUNY Buffalo
About_#1: Jeremy Jacobs is chairman of concessions juggernaut Delaware North, a private company that serves 500 million people per year across four continents.
About_#2: The business was founded in 1915 by his father, who began by selling popcorn and peanuts
About_#3: The New York-based company is currently considered a global leader in hospitality management & food service management.
About_#4: Jacobs is also the owner of the NHL's Boston Bruins ice hockey team, and he was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame in 2017.
Did You Know?: Jacobs owns a Florida restaurant with legendary golfer Jack Nicklaus, with whom he shares a birthday.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University; Master of Business Administration, Harvard University
About_#1: Hamilton "Tony" James was recruited to Blackstone Group in 2002 to help run its rapidly expanding private equity and asset management business.
About_#2: As the COO and president, James oversaw Blackstone's rise to the biggest buyout firm on the planet, with $941 billion in assets under management.
About_#3: He handed day-to-day management duties to Blackstone head of real estate Jonathan Gray in February 2018 and retired as executive vice chair in January 2022.
About_#4: He started his career at investment bank Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, then worked at Credit Suisse after it acquired DLJ, before joining Blackstone.
Did You Know?: While an undergrad at Harvard, James played on the soccer team as a fullback, making the team as a walk on.

Education: Master of Science, Saint Petersburg State University
About_#1: Valentin Kipyatkov cofounded software company JetBrains in 2000.
About_#2: JetBrains' tools are used by more than 10 million software developers and project managers around the world.
About_#3: His partner, Sergey Dmitriev, is also a billionaire.
About_#4: Kipyatkov, like his partner Dmitriev, has dual citizenship in Russia and Cyprus, and lives in Cyprus.

About_#1: Martin Lorentzon cofounded Spotify in 2006 with his friend Daniel Ek; they launched the streaming music service two years later.
About_#2: The service has more than 180 million users, 87 million of whom are paying subscribers.
About_#3: Via a dual-class share system, Lorentzon, a Swedish entrepreneur, owns 12% of the shares, but has 43% voting control.
About_#4: Lorentzon is a Silicon Valley-veteran who held senior roles at search engine Alta Vista in the 1990s; he took European ad network Tradedoubler public.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Baylor University; Master of Business Administration, Broad College of Business
About_#1: Drayton McLane turned his family's grocery distribution company, McLane Co., into an international firm and sold it to Walmart.
About_#2: McLane became president and CEO of the company and ran it for almost 30 years, averaging a yearly sales growth of 30%.
About_#3: In 1991, he sold McLane Co. to his friend Sam Walton for $50 million and 10.4 million shares of Walmart.
About_#4: In 2003, Walmart sold the company to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $1.45 billion.
Did You Know?: McLane started working for the family business at the age of nine, spending Saturdays and summers sweeping floors and stacking inventory.

About_#1: Benjamin Otto inherited a 15.1% stake in Otto Group, which his grandfather, Werner, started as a mail-order business in 1949.
About_#2: His father, Michael Otto, he ran the business for 26 years until 2007. He is now chairman of its supervisory board.
About_#3: With revenues exceeding $15 billion, Otto Group has more than 40 companies in retail (including Crate and Barrel), real estate and financial services.
About_#4: Benjamin joined the family company as an executive director in 2012.

Education: Drop Out, Lehigh University
About_#1: Former race car driver Roger Penske is the founder, chairman and CEO of publicly-traded car and truck dealer Penske Automotive Group.
About_#2: The business is best known for its auto dealerships, which sell new and used cars, and its iconic yellow rental trucks.
About_#3: Penske started his career with one car dealership in 1965, opened with a $75,000 loan from his father.
About_#4: In June 2019, President Trump announced that Penske will be awarded a Presidential Medal of Freedom, the highest civilian award in the U.S.
Did You Know?: He was named Sports Illustrated's race car driver of the year in 1961.
In Their Own Words: Without a little risk in your life every day, you start to get sloppy, and that is something I don't want to be. I want to be on the leading edge with our people and the company.

Education: Master, Ecole centrale de Paris
About_#1: Olivier Pomel is the CEO of Datadog, a cloud monitoring company he cofounded with Alexis Lê-Quôc, the firm's chief technology officer, in 2010.
About_#2: Datadog listed on the Nasdaq in September 2019, raising nearly $650 million and nabbing a $10.9 billion market cap on its first day of trading.
About_#3: Pomel and Lê-Quôc became billionaires in May 2020 after a blockbuster earnings release sent shares soaring; Pomel owns 4% of Datadog shares.
About_#4: The French natives met while undergraduates at Ecole Centrale Paris, where both received Master's degrees in computer science.

Education: Bachelor of Business Administration, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Jean Salata is a Chilean citizen who has lived and worked in Hong Kong since 1989.
About_#2: In 2000 he led a management buyout of Baring Private Equity Asia, which now manages roughly $37 billion in assets.
About_#3: Salata is currently CEO of Baring, which he joined in 1997. He previously held posts at Bain and AIG.
About_#4: In March 2022, Baring announced it was being acquired by Sweden's investment firm EQT for $7.5 billion. The deal is expected to close in the fourth quarter of 2022.

About_#1: Arnout Schuijff is the cofounder of Adyen, an Amsterdam-based payment processing company.
About_#2: He stepped down from the company's management board in 2021.
About_#3: Schuijff, who owns around 5% of Adyen, became a billionaire when it went public in 2018. He sold 15% of his stake in 2019.
About_#4: Schuijff started the company in 2006 with Pieter van der Does, who is the company's CEO.

About_#1: Hua Shen chairs semiconductor and power module supplier StarPower Semiconductor; its products are used in the energy and machinery industries.
About_#2: Shen was an engineer at Infineon Technologies and a senior program manager at Xilinx before forming StarPower in 2005.
About_#3: StarPower went public at the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 2020.
About_#4: Shen received a MS in applied science from Yale in 1992 and a PhD from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1995.

About_#1: Martua Sitorus cofounded Wilmar with Kuok Khoon Hong, now also a billionaire, in 1991.
About_#2: Sitorus stepped off the board of Wilmar, now the world's largest palm oil trader, in July 2018.
About_#3: He and his brother Ganda cofounded KPN Corporation with interests in palm oil plantations, property development and cement manufacturing.
About_#4: In partnership with the Ciputra Group, Gama Land is building a township in Medan, North Sumatra.
Did You Know?: A former economics student, Sitorus traded shrimp as a teenager, then switched to palm oil.

About_#1: Zygmunt Solorz-Zak founded Polsat, one of the first national commercial broadcasters in the Eastern Europe.
About_#2: It is now part of his Cyfrowy Polsat, Poland's leading pay-TV operator.
About_#3: Solorz-Zak is handing over the reins of his business empire including mobile, energy and financial products, to his sons Tobias Solorz and Piotr Zak.
Did You Know?: Solorz-Zak made his first fortune importing used cars from Germany.
In Their Own Words: I always wanted to prove that a Pole can do it. Everybody was saying: Solorz won't make it. And I have built a big company.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Wake Forest University School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Washington & Lee University
About_#1: Stephens Inc., his Little Rock investment bank, was founded by his uncle Witt in 1933; his father Jackson joined in 1946.
About_#2: The outfit underwrote Walmart's public offering in 1970.
About_#3: The brothers plowed their earnings into private equity, hewing to the investment criteria, "whim and caprice."
About_#4: Stephens grew up in the business, became CEO in 1986 and bought out his cousins in 2006.

About_#1: Tang Jinkui is vice chairman of Shenghong Group, headquartered in the eastern Chinese city of Suzhou.
About_#2: Shenghong completed a backdoor listing of its chemical fiber business in Shanghai in 2018.
About_#3: It subsequently changed the listed company's name from Jiangsu Wujiang China Eastern Silk Market to Jiangsu Eastern Shenghong.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Dartmouth College
About_#1: The son of a holocaust survivor, Alan Trefler worked at his father's small antique restoration company as a teen, before starting Pegasystems in 1983.
About_#2: He was 27 when he launched the software company, which focuses on streamlining business and enhancing customer engagement.
About_#3: The Cambridge, Mass.-based company, which he took public in 1996, now brings in more than $1 billion in annual sales and employs some 5,700 people.
About_#4: Alan and his wife Pamela are founders of the Trefler Foundation, through which they have donated to public education and health care in Boston.
Did You Know?: In 1975, when Trefler was a sophomore computer science and economics double major at Dartmouth College, he won the World Open Chess Tournament.
In Their Own Words: There is an industrial revolution that has to come to software and it's got to be around rethinking technology so that the business people can be more involved in and have more control.

About_#1: Masateru Uno is the founder, chairman and CEO of Cosmos Pharmaceutical, which has more than 1,100 drugstores in Japan and China.
About_#2: The company sells medicines and cosmetics as well as food and beverages.
About_#3: Masateru's son, Yukitaka, is an executive at the company.
About_#4: Cosmos Pharmaceutical trades on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Brigham Young University
About_#1: Frank VanderSloot founded and runs Melaleuca, which makes more than 400 products ranging from health supplements to eco-friendly household cleaners.
About_#2: Melaleuca sells them direct from the factory to more than one million consumers every month through its online store.
About_#3: Born into a poor farming family, he ran the farm while his father worked a railroad job, then lived in a laundromat to pay his way through school.
About_#4: He is a major landowner -- with an estimated 117,500 acres across Idaho, Utah and Montana -- and he runs a leading purebred angus cattle operation.
Did You Know?: VanderSloot is an avid indoor rower and holds six world records.

Education: EMBA, China Europe International Business School
About_#1: Wu Guangming is founder and chairman of China's Jiangsu Yuyue Medical Equipment & Supply.
About_#2: The company is a supplier of blood pressure monitors and diagnostic equipment.
About_#3: Wu was born in a fisherman's family, and cofounded the predecessor of Yuyue with his father in 1990s.

Education: Ph.D, Shanghai Jiao Tong University
About_#1: Wu Kai is the scientist in chief of Contemporary Amperex Technology, a supplier of lithium-ion batteries.
About_#2: Wu holds a PhD from Shanghai Jiaotong University.
About_#3: Earlier in his career, Wu was a lecturer at Wuhan University of Technology.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, South China University of Technology
About_#1: Ye Fan is founder and chairman of Meidong Auto, a luxury auto dealership.
About_#2: Brands sold by Meidong include Porsche, Lexus, Toyota and Hyundai.
About_#3: Ye holds an undergraduate degree in inorganic non-metallic materials from South China University of Technology.

About_#1: Yoo owns a 14% stake in online gaming giant Nexon through NXC.
About_#2: Her husband Kim Jung-ju built up Nexon and then retired from management in 2006; he died in February 2022 at age 54.
About_#3: She joined NXC in 1995 and has been serving as its statutory auditor since 2010.

About_#1: Zhou Jianping chairs HLA, one of China's largest apparel manufacturers and retailers.
About_#2: Zhou got into the apparel business with money he earned from running a photo studio.
About_#3: Zhou's son Zhou Lichen is HLA's vice chairman.

About_#1: Jose Joao Abdalla Filho is the son of J. J. Abdalla, a Brazilian entrepreneur and politician who built a real estate and textile company.
About_#2: In the 1950s, the group his father led became one the largest manufacturers of cement in the country, employing over 40,000 people.
About_#3: Abdalla Filho used the money he inherited to open Banco Classico, which owns stakes in a number of Brazilian companies.
About_#4: His Banco Classico owns 5% of Eletrobras, Brazil's largest electric utility, and almost 7% of Cemig, an energy giant that owns over 200 companies.
Did You Know?: His late father J.J. Abdalla was a doctor, businessman, and politician. He became mayor of Birigui, a small town in the state of Sao Paulo, and a congressman.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University
About_#1: Computer engineer Brian Acton cofounded messaging app WhatsApp with Jan Koum in 2007; the two had met while working at Yahoo.
About_#2: The pair sold WhatsApp to Facebook for $22 billion in cash and stock in 2014. Acton left WhatsApp at the end of 2017.
About_#3: Acton received about $3 billion for his stake in WhatsApp. The mobile messaging app has over 1 billion users in 180 countries.
About_#4: In Feb. 2018, he committed $50 million to Signal Foundation - the nonprofit behind the signal mobile app focused on preserving private communication.
Did You Know?: Five years before Facebook bought WhatsApp, Acton had applied for a job at Facebook and was rejected.

About_#1: Bill Alfond is one of four heirs who are billionaires thanks to Warren Buffett's purchase of the Dexter Shoe Company.
About_#2: Bill's father, Harold Alfond, bought an old mill in Maine in 1958 and turned it into a shoemaker that sold millions of boots and casual shoes a year.
About_#3: In 1993 Harold sold the company to Buffett for about $420 million in Berkshire Hathaway stock, now worth billions due to the rising share price.
About_#4: Bill and his two siblings, Ted and Susan, also share about 5% of Fenway Sports Group, which owns the Boston Red Sox and Liverpool FC.

About_#1: Susan Alfond and her three siblings inherited a fortune created by their father, who started Dexter Shoe Company.
About_#2: Her father, Harold Alfond, bought an old mill in Maine in 1958 and turned it into a shoemaker that sold millions of boots and casual shoes.
About_#3: In 1993 Harold sold the company to Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway for $420 million of stock; the shares are worth billions of dollars now.
About_#4: Susan and her two brothers, Ted and Bill, also share about 5% of Fenway Sports Group, which owns the Boston Red Sox and Liverpool FC.

About_#1: Ted Alfond is one of four heirs who are billionaires thanks to Warren Buffett's purchase of the Dexter Shoe Company.
About_#2: Ted's father, Harold Alfond, bought an old mill in Maine in 1958 and turned it into a shoemaker that sold millions of boots and casual shoes a year.
About_#3: In 1993 Harold sold the company to Buffett for about $420 million in Berkshire Hathaway stock, now worth billions due to the rising share price.
About_#4: Ted and his two siblings, Bill and Susan, also share a roughly 5% stake in Fenway Sports Group, which owns the Boston Red Sox and Liverpool FC.

About_#1: Felix Baker is the cofounder of Baker Brothers Advisors, a New York hedge fund firm that specializes in biotechnology stocks.
About_#2: Baker started his hedge fund firm with his brother, Julian Baker, in 2000. The firm now manages $36 billion.
About_#3: Felix Baker and his brother started their fund-management careers in 1994 with a biotechnology investing partnership with the Tisch Family.

About_#1: Julian Baker is the cofounder of Baker Brothers Advisors, a New York hedge fund that specializes in biotechnology stocks.
About_#2: Baker started his hedge fund him with his brother, Felix, and it now manages about $36 billion.
About_#3: Julian Baker and his brother started their fund-management careers in 1994 with a biotechnology investing partnership with the Tisch Family.

About_#1: Karen Beckmann Legorreta inherited a nearly 36% stake in Becle S.A.B., maker of Jose Cuervo tequila, from her father, Juan Francisco Beckmann Vidal.
About_#2: She serves on the board of Becle, where her brother Juan Domingo Beckmann Legorreta is the CEO; he is also a billionaire.
About_#3: The company has been in the family for more than 250 years.

About_#1: Maurizio Billi is president of Eurofarma, a Brazil-based pharmaceutical firm that sells generic versions of drugs such as Viagra.
About_#2: Eurofarma was founded by his father in 1972 and became one of the largest pharmaceutical companies in Brazil, with over $1 billion in revenues.
About_#3: Eurofarma expanded to Central and South America by acquiring medical suppliers, labs, and other pharmaceutical companies.
About_#4: The company states it has grown 17% on average over the past 15 years. It now employs over 6,000 people.

About_#1: Otto Philipp Braun owns 23% of the medical device company B. Braun Melsungen, which began in 1839 as a small pharmacy that sold herbal remedies.
About_#2: His father, Ludwig Georg Braun, took the reins in 1977, when the company had just $24 million in annual sales. Revenues have grown to around $8 billion.
About_#3: Today, with more than 64,000 employees globally, B. Braun manufactures products ranging from infusion and injection solutions to surgical instruments.
About_#4: The first sixth-generation family member to work in the company and serve on its board, Otto Philipp stepped down in 2017.

Education: Master of Science, University of Calgary
About_#1: Uber chairman Garrett Camp cofounded the ride-hailing startup with Travis Kalanick in 2009.
About_#2: The Uber mobile phone app lets users request a ride and a driver-contractor is routed to pick them up -- with Uber getting a cut of the fare.
About_#3: Camp owns about 4% of Uber, which listed its shares on the New York Stock Exchange on May 10, 2019.
About_#4: Before Uber, Garrett Camp founded web discovery tool StumbleUpon, which he sold to eBay in 2007 for $75 million.
Did You Know?: In mid-2015, Camp bought back a majority stake of StumbleUpon and said he would advise its management team.
In Their Own Words: I believe that our business can have 10x the impact it has today--once we have additional leadership and training in place, and evolve our culture to be more inclusive and respectful.

About_#1: Chen Hua chairs Shenzhen-headquartered property developer Kingkey Group.
About_#2: Founded in 1994, Kingkey, which is 90% owned by Chen, also has property projects in Beijing, Tianjin and Zhanjiang.
About_#3: In addition, Kingkey owns 19.8% of Shenzhen-listed food company Shenzhen Kondarl Group.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: John Paul DeJoria is the founder of tequila maker Patr?n Spirits Co. and cofounder of hair care company John Paul Mitchell Systems.
About_#2: He slept in his car and sold shampoo door-to-door before he teamed up with Paul Mitchell in 1980 and turned $700 into John Paul Mitchell Systems.
About_#3: In 1989 DeJoria and partner Martin Crowley acquired a stake in Patr?n, then sold it to Bacardi in 2018 in a $5.1 billion deal.
About_#4: DeJoria launched a line of 3D cellphones under his ROK Stars brand in March 2019.
Did You Know?: DeJoria supports a number of charities, including anti-poaching group Sea Shepherd Conservation Society who named a vessel after him.
In Their Own Words: Success unshared is failure.

About_#1: Beda Diethelm is Swiss hearing aid manufacturer Sonova's largest individual shareholder, with a 10% stake.
About_#2: Diethelm joined what would become Sonova in 1965, receiving a chunk of equity from the former owner in 1980.
About_#3: Sonova has sales of roughly $2.8 billion and is based in Stafa, Switzerland and has production facilities in Vietnam and China.
About_#4: Born in the tiny village of Galgenen, Switzerland, Diethelm first dabbled in electronics as an apprentice for a radio and TV technician in Zurich.

Education: Master of Science, Bangalore University
About_#1: K. Dinesh is a cofounder of Indian tech giant Infosys.
About_#2: Since stepping down from the company's board in 2011, he and his wife Asha have devoted themselves to philanthropy.
About_#3: Ashraya Hastha Trust, their philanthropic arm, focuses on education, healthcare, animal welfare and agriculture.
About_#4: They have funded a cancer center at the Narayana Health Hospital and a clinic; the latter is on their ancestral land in Mysore city.
Did You Know?: Dinesh's daughter Divya runs VedaEarth, a brand of herbal personal care products. His daughter Deeksha has a corporate counselling firm.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Arizona
About_#1: The grandson of John T. Dorrance, the inventor of condensed soup, Bennett Dorrance owns a 15% stake in Campbell Soup.
About_#2: Dorrance is a founding partner of DMB Associates, a real estate development firm with projects in Arizona, Utah, California and Hawaii.
About_#3: A licensed pilot, Dorrance owns a private hangar in Scottsdale, Arizona that sometimes houses his vintage car collection.
About_#4: The Dorrance Scholarship, established by Bennett and Jacquelynn Dorrance in 1999, has supported 150-plus first-generation college students in Arizona.

About_#1: Marcel Erni is the cofounder of Partners Group, a Swiss private equity firm with more than $127 billion in assets under management.
About_#2: He started Partners Group in 1996 with fellow billionaires Alfred Gantner and Urs Wietlisbach; the trio had all worked at Zurich's Goldman Sachs.
About_#3: The firm was reportedly created in a 300-square-foot office with Ikea desks, with its founders pooling together $100,000 for its startup capital.
About_#4: Partners Group went public in Switzerland a decade later, and Erni still owns roughly 5% of the stock.

About_#1: Abhay Firodia is chairman of Force Motors, maker of vans, pickup trucks, SUVs and tractors and privately held auto parts firm Jayahind Industries.
About_#2: The company, earlier known as Bajaj Tempo when it was a joint venture with the Bajaj clan, is run by his son Prasan since 2009.
About_#3: It was founded by his late father, Navalmal Firodia, in 1958, who fell out with the Bajaj family in 1968 after a bitter feud.
About_#4: The bulk of Firodia's wealth is from stakes he continues to hold in various Bajaj companies.
Did You Know?: Firodia is building a museum that spotlights the culture, history and philosophy of the Jain community in India.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Brigham Young University
About_#1: Alfred Gantner is the cofounder of Partners Group, a Swiss private equity firm that manages more than $127 billion.
About_#2: Gantner started Partners Group in 1996 after stints at UBS and Goldman Sachs, where he met cofounders Marcel Erni and Urs Wietlisbach.
About_#3: The firm went public in Switzerland in 2006 and the trio each own roughly 5% of the stock.
About_#4: Gantner earned his MBA from the Brigham Young University Marriott School of Management, Utah.

About_#1: Allan Goldman, the former co-chair of America's most valuable family-run real estate portfolio, died at age 78 on January 15, 2022.
About_#2: Allan and his sister Jane took over the business' leadership when their father Sol, a legendary real estate investor, died in 1987.
About_#3: The family's Solil Management owns at least 400 properties across New York City, from retail and office space near Madison Avenue to uptown co-ops.
About_#4: Several years before his death, Allan stepped back from overseeing Solil Management on a day-to-day basis due to health issues.
Did You Know?: Sol started buying up foreclosed properties for bargain prices in the 1950s. His trademark was all-cash deals whenever possible.

About_#1: Real estate heiress Amy Goldman Fowler is one of four siblings who equally split ownership of Solil Management, which owns 400 properties.
About_#2: Amy is the second-youngest daughter of late patriarch Sol Goldman. His trademark was all-cash deals whenever possible.
About_#3: She worked in the real estate office when she was younger. Now her younger sister Jane runs it.
About_#4: She lives on a 200-acre farm in Rhinebeck, New York and also has a home in Memphis.
Did You Know?: Her husband Dr. Cary Fowler helped start the climate change conscious Svalbard Global Seed Vault.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University
About_#1: Mergers and acquisitions maven J. Tomilson "Tom" Hill started off his career at investment bank First Boston, where he cofounded the M&A department.
About_#2: Hill later became a partner at Lehman Brothers in the 1980s, where he befriended Blackstone cofounders Peter Peterson and Stephen Schwarzman.
About_#3: In 1993, after being ousted as co-CEO at Lehman, he joined Peterson and Schwarzman at Blackstone, their growing private equity firm.
About_#4: Hill, who took over Blackstone's hedge fund group in 2000 and became vice chairman in 2007, stepped down from his position in January 2019.
Did You Know?: While at Lehman, Hill was involved in high profile deals such as Time Inc.'s $14 billion merger with Warner Communications, which created media behemoth Time Warner.

About_#1: Hong Jie is the chairman of 3trees, a supplier of coatings.
About_#2: 3trees went public on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 2016.
About_#3: The business is headquartered in southern China's Fujian province.
About_#4: 3trees has more than 5,000 employees.

Education: Drop Out, University of Southern California
About_#1: Jim Jannard founded sunglasses empire Oakley out of his car in 1975. His first product was a motorcycle grip that wicked sweat during long rides.
About_#2: It went public in 1995 and sold to Luxottica for $2.1 billion in cash in 2007.
About_#3: By then he was working on his next project, Red Digital, building high-resolution cameras used in movies like "Avatar" and "The Hobbit."
About_#4: He launched Red Hydrogen One, a holographic smartphone, in Nov. 2018. It was plagued with issues, but he says the second version will be better.
Did You Know?: The USC pharmacy student dropped out in the 1960s after clashing with professors over bringing his dog to class.

Education: Drop Out, University of California, Los Angeles
About_#1: Kalanick, who cofounded ride-hailing firm Uber in 2009, stepped down as CEO in June 2017 and left the board on Dec. 31, 2019.
About_#2: Kalanick is now CEO of CloudKitchens, a virtual restaurant company that has raised money from the Saudi Arabia Public Investment Fund.
About_#3: Kalanick cofounded two tech startups before Uber: online file-exchange service Scour and file-sharing company RedSwoosh.
About_#4: In November and December 2019, Kalanick - who had owned about 4% of Uber - sold all his shares for more than $2.5 billion (before taxes).
Did You Know?: Kalanick dropped out of UCLA in 1998 to work on Scour full-time with some classmates.
In Their Own Words: With the technology in our pockets today, and a little smart regulation, we can turn every car into a shared car, and we can reclaim our cities starting today.

About_#1: Real estate heiress Diane Kemper is one of four Goldman siblings who co-own Solil Management, which owns at least 400 properties in New York City.
About_#2: Trophies include retail and office space along Madison Avenue in midtown and high-end coops on the Upper East Side.
About_#3: Diane is the second-oldest child of late patriarch Sol Goldman, who started buying up foreclosed properties for bargain prices in the 1950s.
About_#4: Diane headed the residential leasing department for several decades. She scaled back due to health issues several years ago.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Seton Hall University
About_#1: George Kurtz is cofounder and CEO of CrowdStrike, a cloud-based cybersecurity company based in Sunnyvale, Calif. that went public in June 2019.
About_#2: Kurtz owns a 6% stake in the company, which he cofounded with Dmitri Alperovitch in 2011; Alperovitch has since left the company.
About_#3: In 2016, when internal emails from the Democratic National Committee were leaked to the public, the DNC hired CrowdStrike to investigate the hack.
About_#4: CrowdStrike recorded $1.45 billion in revenues in the year through January 31, 2022.

Education: LLB, University of London
About_#1: Kwek Leng Beng is the executive chairman of Singapore's Hong Leong Group, founded by his father in 1941.
About_#2: Kwek is also executive chairman of City Developments, the island state's second-largest property developer.
About_#3: Kwek's son, Sherman, took charge as group CEO of City Developments in 2018 following a decade in various roles.
About_#4: In December 2021, City Developments agreed to sell the Millennium Hilton Seoul and the adjoining land to South Korean asset manager IGIS Asset Management for $934 million.
Did You Know?: His cousin, Quek Leng Chan, also a billionaire, runs the Hong Leong Group's Malaysian operations.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Yale University
About_#1: Geoffrey Kwok is the elder son of the late Walter Kwok, former chairman of Hong Kong's largest developer, Sun Hung Kai Properties.
About_#2: Walter died on Oct. 20, 2018 at age 68. He had been ousted as company chairman in 2008 in a feud with his two brothers, Thomas and Raymond.
About_#3: After his death, Geoffrey and his brother, Jonathan, took over Empire Group Holdings, a property developer that Walter started after he left SHKP.
About_#4: The brothers inherited Walter's direct stake in SHKP and are named beneficiaries of one-third of five large family trusts held by their grandmother.

About_#1: Maritsa Lazari is the widow of late billionaire Christos Lazari, who died in 2015, a few months shy of their 50th wedding anniversary.
About_#2: The couple, who met in London, married in 1965.
About_#3: Christos eventually created a successful fashion line called Drendie Girl. The couple used the profits from that business to buy up property.
About_#4: Lazari Investments owns more than 3 million square feet of commercial real estate in London, mostly office space that it rents out.
Did You Know?: Maritsa was a cofounder of the real estate business and serves as a director. Her three children are also involved in the company.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Ecole Centrale Paris
About_#1: Alexis Lê-Quôc is the chief technology officer of Datadog, a cloud monitoring company he founded with Olivier Pomel, the firm's CEO, in 2010.
About_#2: Datadog listed on the Nasdaq in September 2019, raising nearly $650 million and nabbing a $10.9 billion market cap on its first day of trading.
About_#3: Lê-Quôc and Pomel became billionaires in May 2020 after a blockbuster earnings release sent shares soaring; Lê-Quôc owns 6% of Datadog shares.
About_#4: The French natives met while undergraduates at Ecole Centrale Paris, where both received a master's in computer science.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: Angela Leong is the managing director and largest individual shareholder of casino company SJM Holdings. She is also an elected Macau legislator.
About_#2: Publicly traded SJM Holdings, one of six companies authorized to operate casinos in Macau, has 20 casinos.
About_#3: She is the fourth wife of the late Stanley Ho, who started Sociedade de Turismo e Diversões de Macau, or STDM, which controls SJM Holdings.
About_#4: Leong, who started investing in her early 20s, also has a large portfolio of Hong Kong properties, to which she owes the vast majority of her wealth.
Did You Know?: Leong came from a wealthy army family, but things changed when her father died in 1974. She joined a dance school partly for the free accommodation, as her family had to move out of government housing.
In Their Own Words: Don't do anything if you have no idea about what it is. Work on it even if you don't like it. When you buy a flat, if the investment's value drops, don't just think about making money. Think about what you can use it for in the future.

About_#1: The reclusive property mogul made his money by building modestly priced housing for Taiwan's middle class through his privately held Pau Jar Group.
About_#2: An early foray overseas also landed Lin in the middle of another hot growth story - the hyperactive real estate market in Australia.
About_#3: In 2018, Lin swooped up stakes in China Bills Finance, Taishin and SinoPac, sending a shudder up the spine of Taiwan's sleepy financial establishment.
About_#4: He also acquired stakes in the listed Far Eastern Department Stores, castings supplier Yeong Guan group and elevator manufacturer Yungtay Engineering.

About_#1: Sergio Mantegazza built a tour and travel empire from Globus, the company his father Antonio founded in 1928.
About_#2: Today, the travel group includes European river cruises and guided tours in the U.S., the U.K., Canada, Australia and South Africa.
About_#3: Mantegazza also owns a significant stake in his family's collection of residential and commercial Lugano real estate.
About_#4: In 2014, he sold his flagging Monarch Airlines to Greybull Capital for £75 million.
Did You Know?: On his "Lady Marina" yacht, Mantegazza has played host to high profile guests that reportedly have included Tina Turner.

About_#1: Hans Melchers derives the lion's share of his fortune from a large stake in HAL Trust, an investment company based in Monaco and listed in Amsterdam.
About_#2: In the late 1960s, Melchers purchased chemical manufacturing company Melchemie from his father.
About_#3: Melchers retired as CEO in 2002. The company was renamed Melspring, and it was acquired by Olmix in 2006.
Did You Know?: A passionate fan of bridge, Melchers started his own professional team and provided funding for the 2011 World Bridge Championship held in the Netherlands.

About_#1: Tom Morris founded TJ Morris, which owns discount retailer Home Bargains, in 1976.
About_#2: One of seven children of a Liverpool shopkeeper, he is the third generation of his family to run a retailer.
About_#3: Morris, who closely guards his privacy, reportedly used a bank overdraft to start his business at the age of 21.
About_#4: Home Bargains stocks everything from health and beauty products to candy and toys, often bought at a discount from brands trying to offload product.

About_#1: Eugene Murtagh founded building materials manufacturer Kingspan Group in 1965.
About_#2: He owns about 15% of the Dublin- and London-listed company, which primarily sells insulation products for commercial and industrial projects.
About_#3: Kingspan has grown through acquisitions and has 100 manufacturing facilities in some 70 countries, with revenue of over $3 billion billion in 2021.
About_#4: Murtagh stepped down as chairman and non-executive director of Kingspan in 2021, succeeded by Jost Massenberg.

About_#1: Philip Niarchos, the oldest son of the late shipping magnate Stavros Niarchos, inherited much of his father's art collection.
About_#2: The collection was purchased in 1957 for $3 million from actor Edward G. Robinson and includes some of the world's most recognizable pieces.
About_#3: It is said to be the largest private collection of Van Gogh's work, notably his ear-less self portrait, and includes Picasso's iconic "Yo, Picasso."
About_#4: Since inheriting the collection, Philip has added post-war and contemporary works, including pieces by Andy Warhol and Maurizio Cattelan.
Did You Know?: Andy Warhol rendered CAT scans of Philip's head into a series of paintings called Philip's Skull, completed in 1985.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Lawrence Technological University; Bachelor of Science, Wuhan University; Master, Wuhan University
About_#1: Pan chairs the Blue Moon Group, a supplier of liquid detergent and soap.
About_#2: Pan is the wife the Blue Moon's founder and CEO Luo Qiuping.
About_#3: Pan was a technical consultant until her formal appointment as Blue Moon's chief technology officer in 2003.
About_#4: Blue Moon was founded in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou in 1994.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: Sean Parker's fortune stems from his brief tenure, at age 24, as Facebook's president.
About_#2: Parker is now a venture capital investor and philanthropist.
About_#3: Parker's interest in music led him to invest in Spotify in 2010. He left the Board of Directors in June 2017.
About_#4: He launched his Parker Foundation in 2015 with $600 million earmarked for science, global health and civic engagement.
