Did You Know?: Parker cofounded music sharing service Napster at age 19 and Plaxo, a contact management startup, at 21.
In Their Own Words: Your biggest challenge as an entrepreneur is not concealing your idea from others or keeping your idea secret. It's actually convincing people that you're not crazy and that you can pull [it] off.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Brigham Young University
About_#1: Early Silicon Valley property baron Richard "Dick" Peery partnered with John Arrillaga, buying farmland in the 1960s and turning it into office parks.
About_#2: Peery's longtime business partner since the 1960s, Arrillaga died in early 2022.
About_#3: In 2006 Peery and Arrillaga sold many of their buildings for $1.1 billion.
About_#4: Peery, who dropped out of the Stanford MBA program, had gained early experience managing his father's small property portfolio.
Did You Know?: He and his sister endowed Brigham Young University with $3 million to establish the H. Taylor Peery Institute of Financial Services, named after their late father.

Education: Drop Out, High School
About_#1: Gregorio Perez Companc built energy conglomerate Perez Companc and sold it to Brazilian energy giant Petrobas for $1 billion in 2002.
About_#2: In December 2009, he stepped down from active involvement in business, and gave his 75% stake in food giant Molinos Rio de la Plata to his children.
About_#3: He had eight children with his wife Maria del Carmen Sundblad Beccar Varela.
About_#4: He founded Pérez Companc foundation after Margarita, his eldest daughter, died in a car accident in the 1980s.

Education: Doctorate, Harvard University
About_#1: Sebastian Piñera will finish his second four-year term as president of Chile in March 2022. He previously served from 2010 to 2014.
About_#2: Pinera's popularity among Chilean citizens has waned amid growing unrest over inequality that sparked violent protests in 2019.
About_#3: He made a fortune from credit card company Bancard, which he founded in 1976.
About_#4: He divested many assets over the years. After the 2010 election he unloaded his 26% stake in Chilean airline LAN for $1.5 billion.
Did You Know?: After his first presidential term, Piñera spent time on charitable work, including his Fundación Futuro, which supports education, culture and conservation in Chile.
In Their Own Words: The road to development is never paved. It's full of obstacles and full of traps. It's necessary to avoid the Christopher Columbus syndrome, who never knew where he was going, where he got to, and the government paid all the expenses

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Lake Forest College; Doctor of Jurisprudence, University of Chicago
About_#1: Nicholas (Nick) Pritzker is a cousin of the late Jay Pritzker and his brothers Donald and Robert, who built the Hyatt hotel chain.
About_#2: Pritzker spent many years leading Hyatt's new hotel development efforts but he has since sold most of his Hyatt stock.
About_#3: He has shifted his attention and investment dollars to causes like clean energy, marijuana legalization and criminal justice reform.
About_#4: He cofounded and cochairs Clean Energy Trust, which invests in clean energy companies in the Midwest.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Vanderbilt University; Master of Science, Vanderbilt University
About_#1: Jeff Rothschild made his fortune at Facebook, which he joined in 2005 as vice president of infrastructure engineering.
About_#2: After five years as the VP, Rothschild took on an advisory role, and left Facebook in June 2015.
About_#3: Before Facebook, Rothschild cofounded Veritas Software, which was sold to Symantec in 2004 for $13.5 billion in stock.
About_#4: In March 2018, Rothschild joined the board of Pure Storage, a Mountain View, Calif.-based data storage company.
Did You Know?: When Facebook hired Rothschild in 2005, he was 50 years old, making him the oldest executive at the time.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign
About_#1: Steven Sarowitz founded online payroll firm Paylocity in 1997 after working at several other payroll firms.
About_#2: Sarowitz, who serves as chairman of Paylocity, took the company public in 2014.
About_#3: Sarowitz is a member of the Sierra Club and is passionate about environmental issues.
About_#4: Through his Julian Grace Foundation, he has donated to the American Headache Association, the Angioma Alliance and the Boys and Girls Club.
Did You Know?: Sarowitz was the Executive Producer of the award-winning documentary, Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise.

About_#1: Isabella Seràgnoli is the sole shareholder of Coesia, one of the world's largest packaging firms with operations ranging from cigarettes to cosmetics.
About_#2: Coesia started out as a motorcycle production firm named G.D. in 1923 and was taken over by her father, Enzo, in the late 1930s.
About_#3: The firm moved into packaging in the 1950s, initially for confectionery and soap, when Enzo's brother Ariosto invented an automatic wrapping machine.
About_#4: G.D. took off in the 1960s with the invention of the cigarette packing machine 4350/Pack, making it the dominant supplier in the tobacco industry.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Queens University
About_#1: Stephen Smith is the founder, chairman and CEO of Canadian mortgage lender First National Financial.
About_#2: Smith launched the company in 1988, just four years after being personally bankrupt, and took it public in 2006.
About_#3: He also owns about half of Canada Guaranty Mortgage Insurance Company and a stake in publicly-traded Canadian bank Equitable Group.
About_#4: In 2018, he bought half of Walmart Canada Bank from Walmart and put up over $110 million to start the private equity fund Peloton.
Did You Know?: Smith has passed his love of heli-skiing onto his three adult children, and Smith's wife cooks for the tight-knit family every Sunday night.
In Their Own Words: There's only one thing I'm more passionate about than buying businesses: Heliskiing.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Marquette University
About_#1: Bill Stone started financial-software firm SS&C Technologies in 1986 with the $20,000 he had saved from his days as a KPMG executive.
About_#2: His product became popular among asset managers, bankers and insurers who wanted to electronically manage their books.
About_#3: He guided the firm to an IPO in 1996, but the dot-com crash nearly crippled the company in 2001.
About_#4: Stone refocused and added services such as data centers, then took the company private in 2005.
Did You Know?: Between June 1999 and December 2001, SS&C went from 610 employees to 250, as the markets crashed.

Education: Master, Tsinghua University
About_#1: Sun Hongbin is the founder and chairman of Sunac China Holdings, one of China's largest real estate developers.
About_#2: Sunac is headquartered in Tianjin, and its shares trade on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.
About_#3: Sunac has expanded into the entertainment and hotel business by acquiring assets from China's Wanda Group.
About_#4: Sun, a U.S. citizen, received his master's degree from Tsinghua University and completed an advanced management program at Harvard Business School.

Education: Bachelor of Science, De La Salle University
About_#1: Henry Sy Jr. is co-vice chairman of SM Investments, a major conglomerate founded by his late father, Henry Sy Sr.
About_#2: He also serves as chairman of SM Prime, the group's property arm with interests in malls, residences, offices, hotels and convention centers.
About_#3: He is the eldest son of the founder; elder sisters and three younger brothers are also all involved in the business.
About_#4: In 2017 he set up Big Boss Cement, entering an industry that has benefitted from President Duterte's massive infrastructure push.
Did You Know?: Sy was chief executive of the National Grid Corporation of the Philippines, a private power operator; he stepped down in 2016.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of the East
About_#1: Andrew Tan chairs Alliance Global, a holding company with interests in food and beverage, gaming and real estate.
About_#2: The son of a factory worker, Tan built his fortune developing large apartment complexes around Manila.
About_#3: Alliance Global runs Emperador, the world's largest brandy company by sales volume.
About_#4: Tan's son Kevin is chief executive of Alliance Global and chief strategy officer of property developer Megaworld.

About_#1: Kenneth Tuchman is the founder and CEO of call center outsourcing giant TTEC, a public company operating on six continents.
About_#2: Tuchman's personal frustration with the way businesses approached customer service led him to found the company in 1982.
About_#3: Today, he is the majority owner of the $1.9 billion (sales) company, which handles customer inquires via phone, messaging and social media.
About_#4: Tuchman originally studied architecture at a junior college and dropped out to pursue his own business ventures.
Did You Know?: As a teenager, Tuchman sold millions of puka shell necklaces to retailers, becoming one of the largest shell importers from the Philippines.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, University of Liverpool
About_#1: Tung Chee Hwa is the eldest son of shipping magnate Tung Chao Yung, who founded what became one of Hong Kong's largest shipping companies.
About_#2: After running Orient Overseas for 14 years, Chee Hwa handed over the reins to younger brother Chee Chen in order to serve as Hong Kong's first chief executive.
About_#3: In 2018 the two brothers sold their entire 68.7% stake to China shipping giant COSCO, pocketing US$4.34 billion.
About_#4: His two sons, Alan and Andrew, were both executives at Orient Overseas.

About_#1: Bulat Utemuratov is a Kazakhstani investor. One key transaction: the 2007 sale of Kazakhstan's ATF Bank to Italian bank UniCredit for a reported $2.2 billion.
About_#2: In 2012, he led the sale of mineral company Kazzinc to commodities firm Glencore for $1.4 billion in cash and shares.
About_#3: Utemuratov purchased 88% of Kazakhstan's Forte Bank for $400 million in 2014.
About_#4: He also owns the Burger King franchise in Kazakhstan, which has nearly 50 locations in the country.

About_#1: Anna Katharina is the daughter of Martin Viessmann, who chairs the executive board of a German manufacturer of heating, refrigeration and climate-control equipment.
About_#2: Her brother, Maximilian, is co-CEO of Viessmann Group, founded by their great-grandfather Johann Viessmann in 1917.
About_#3: The private company has 12,300 employees, 22 production divisions in 12 countries, and over $3 billion in annual revenue.
About_#4: Anna Katharina is a non-executive member of the board of the family holding company.
Did You Know?: She has a bachelor's degree in International Cultural and Business Studies from the University of Passau.

About_#1: Wang Xicheng's fortune rose following the July 2016 IPO of his tire manufacturer, Shandong Linglong Tire, on the Shanghai Stock Exchange.
About_#2: Its predecessor was a state-owned tire factory founded in 1975 in Shandong Province.
About_#3: The company was on the verge of collapse in 1987 when Wang was named leader and shifted its focus to pricier tires.
About_#4: The company is now a supplier to GM, Ford, Tata, Fiat and Hyundai.

Education: Master of Business Administration, University of St. Gallen
About_#1: Urs Wietlisbach is the cofounder of Partners Group, a Swiss private equity firm that has more than $127 billion in assets under management.
About_#2: Wietlisbach started Partners Group in 1996 with Marcel Erni and Alfred Gantner, both of whom he met while working at Goldman Sach's Zurich office.
About_#3: The trio took their firm public a decade later; Wietlisbach currently owns roughly 5% of the company's stock.
About_#4: Wietlisbach is a member of the board of trustees of Blue Earth Foundation, which focuses on impact investing globally.

About_#1: Wong Man Li is the chairman of Man Wah Holdings, one of the world's largest suppliers of recliner sofas.
About_#2: In 2005, the firm was listed in Singapore and became the first Chinese furniture enterprise on the Main Board of the Singapore Stock Exchange.
About_#3: After delisting in September 2009, the firm listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in April the following year.
About_#4: The company generates more than half its revenue in the U.S. Man Wah also manufactures and sells mattresses.
Did You Know?: He got his start earning $4 a day as a factory worker after arriving in Hong Kong from Fujian Province in 1990.

About_#1: Xie was the largest shareholder of Huayou Cobalt, a mainland Chinese supplier of cobalt and lithium battery chemicals. He sold all his stakes in 2021.
About_#2: The company also operates cobalt and copper mining businesses in the Congo.
About_#3: Xie resigned in 2019 after serving as the company's vice chairman for 17 years since its inception.

About_#1: Xu Chuanhua founded a small family workshop to produce liquid soap and detergent in 1986 when he was 52 years old.
About_#2: Today, his Transfar Group generates most of its business from logistics and chemicals. It also operates in agribusiness and investment industries.
About_#3: Xu has retired from daily operations, handing reins to sons Guanju and Guanbao, who are chairman and vice chairman of Transfar Group respectively.

Education: Ph.D, Oxford University
About_#1: Ye Xiaoping is the chairman of Hangzhou Tigermed Consulting, one of China's largest contract research organizations in the pharmaceutical industry.
About_#2: Ye holds an EMBA from Peking University and a Ph.D. from Oxford University.
About_#3: Ye was an executive at Roche before becoming an entrepreneur.
About_#4: Tigermed was founded in 2004.

Education: Drop Out, Adelphi University
About_#1: Ben Ashkenazy bought his first building at age 17, after he went to a Bronx shopping center to check out a site to open a fast food restaurant.
About_#2: Then a recent high school grad, Ashkenazy realized the lease offered was below market value and decided to find a lender and buy the property instead.
About_#3: Since then he's built a portfolio of stakes in more than 100 buildings via real estate firm Ashkenazy Acquisitions, which he founded and runs as CEO.
About_#4: The company owns historical landmarks like Washington D.C.'s Union Station and Boston's Faneuil Hall.

Education: High School Graduate, High School
About_#1: Bill Austin owns Starkey Hearing Technologies, the largest hearing aid manufacturer in the U.S.
About_#2: He bought a hearing aid parts shop, which was then called Starkey Labs, for $13,000 in 1970.
About_#3: Austin fired several top executives of Starkey Hearing in 2015, a tumultuous time for the company.
About_#4: That move unleashed a series of events that resulted in the former company president being found guilty of federal fraud charges in 2018.
Did You Know?: Starkey's customers have reportedly included five U.S. presidents, two popes and singer Dolly Parton.

About_#1: In 1988 software engineer Pavel Baudis wrote his first antivirus program after a friend sent him a floppy disk containing the "Vienna" computer virus.
About_#2: In April that year, he and Eduard Kucera, with whom he'd worked at Research Institute of Mathematical Machines, cofounded ALWIL to sell the software.
About_#3: Following the fall of Communism in 1989, the pair broke off to establish what would become Avast.
About_#4: Now run by an outside CEO, Avast, which secures online activities for more than 435 million users, went public in 2018.

About_#1: Yvonne Bauer runs Bauer Media Group, which has been in her family for five generations since its founding as a small printing company in 1875.
About_#2: Europe's largest magazine company, it focuses on women's content and counts over 600 titles worldwide, including InTouch and Grazia.
About_#3: Yvonne Bauer is the second-youngest child of Heinz Heinrich Bauer. She received 85% of the company, while her three sisters each received 5%.
About_#4: In 2020, Bauer expanded its reach in the German newspaper industry with the acquisition of Mitteldeutsche Zeitung in Halle for an undisclosed sum.
Did You Know?: In the digital sphere, Bauer Group runs over 400 websites and apps, including The Debrief and Lecker.de.

About_#1: Giuliana Benetton and her three brothers, Luciano, Gilberto and Carlo, founded the clothing retailer Benetton Group in 1965.
About_#2: After the death of their father, her brother Luciano - then 14 - started working at a clothing store in Treviso, Italy.
About_#3: A bright yellow sweater knitted by Giuliana caught the attention of Luciano's colleagues and led the siblings to found the Benetton Group.
About_#4: Through holding company Edizione, the family has invested in retail, publishing, banking and their most valuable asset: highway concessions.
Did You Know?: The Benetton Group ran controversial, award-winning shock advertising campaigns in 1982, including a focus on the AIDS epidemic.

About_#1: Luciano Benetton started the Benetton Group in 1965 with his three siblings, Carlo (d.2018), Gilberto (d.2018) and Giuliana.
About_#2: Known for their colorful sweaters, Benetton won over parts of the world, opening its first store in Paris in 1969 and reaching New York in 1980.
About_#3: The brand hit some turbulence at the turn of the century amid falling demand for its sweaters and has continued to struggle in recent years.
About_#4: In 2018, 12 years after leaving and allowing outside managers to take on greater roles, Luciano returned to help revive the ailing company.
Did You Know?: Luciano was elected to the Italian Senate in 1992 and served until 1994.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Brown University; Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business
About_#1: Aneel Bhusri is CEO of business software firm Workday, which he cofounded with Dave Duffield, the founder of PeopleSoft.
About_#2: Bhusri started his career in the early 1990s at business software firm PeopleSoft, where he rose to become vice chairman.
About_#3: He also works as an advisory partner at venture capital firm Greylock Partners; he's been on the Forbes Midas List six times since 2008.
About_#4: He studied electrical engineering at Brown University and has an MBA from Stanford.

About_#1: George Bishop founded oil and gas producer GeoSouthern Energy in 1981.
About_#2: In one of the biggest scores of the oil boom, GeoSouthern sold its south Texas fields to Devon Energy for $6 billion in 2013.
About_#3: In 2015, he redeployed some capital into the Haynesville shale natural gas play in Louisiana in a JV with Blackstone Credit called GEP Haynesville.
About_#4: He sold his stake in GEP Haynesville in December 2021 when Southwestern Energy acquired the company for $1.85 billion.
Did You Know?: Bishop endowed the George H. Bishop Scholarship in Geology at Mississippi State University, where he graduated in 1958 with a degree in petroleum geology.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Miami
About_#1: Chairman emeritus of Indian consumer goods outfit Dabur, Vivek Chand Burman, is the oldest member of the founding Burman clan.
About_#2: Dabur was founded by his great-grandfather in 1884 to sell ayurvedic medicines.
About_#3: He joined the company in 1954 and became chairman in 1998 holding that post for close to a decade.
About_#4: In 2007, he handed over charge to nephew Anand Burman, who is also a billionaire. His son, Mohit, was appointed vice-chairman of Dabur in July 2019.
Did You Know?: Burman's sons Mohit and Gaurav are involved in a slew of privately-held ventures ranging from sports and healthcare to financial services and real estate.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Master of Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Ph.D, Stanford University
About_#1: Chang founded Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing, one of the world's largest manufacturers of semiconductors. He retired from chairman in 2018.
About_#2: His degrees from MIT are in mechanical engineering and his Ph.D. from Stanford is in electrical engineering.
About_#3: Chang worked for a quarter-century at Texas Instruments and then joined the Taiwan research body that spun off TSMC.
About_#4: TSMC customers include Apple, Nvidia and Qualcomm.

Education: Master of Business Administration, IMD; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Southern California
About_#1: Cho Jung-ho is the chairman of Meritz Financial Group.
About_#2: He is the youngest of the four sons of Cho Choong-hoon, the late founder of Hanjin Group, the parent company of Korean Air.
About_#3: He worked for Korean Airlines in Europe and returned home in 1989 as a director with Hanjin Investment & Securities, as Meritz was then named.
Did You Know?: Cho's father started out with a single truck and went on to build an empire based mostly on transportation.

Source of Wealth: real estate, private equity, Self Made
About_#1: A South African native and trained accountant, Jack Cockwell is a famed dealmaker in Canada.
About_#2: From the 1970s through the early 1990s he built the Bronfmans' Edper conglomerate, acquiring massive holdings in real estate, forestry and mining.
About_#3: Now known as Brookfield Asset Management, one of the world's biggest money managers, he handed the reins to fellow billionaire Bruce Flatt in 2002.
About_#4: His wealth comes from a large holding in Brookfield shares, much of it in a partnership shared with other board directors and management.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Notre Dame University
About_#1: Real estate magnate Edward Debartolo Jr. founded and heads up DeBartolo Holdings.
About_#2: The NFL Hall of Fame executive owned the San Francisco 49ers during the 80's and 90's when the team won five Super Bowls.
About_#3: In 1998, DeBartolo pleaded guilty to not reporting a bribe from a Louisiana government official. President Trump pardoned DeBartolo in 2020.
About_#4: His sister, Denise DeBartolo York, took controlling ownership of the 49ers in 2001; her family runs the team today.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Fundacao Getulio Vargas
About_#1: Retail tycoon Abilio dos Santos Diniz's father, a Portuguese immigrant, founded Grupo Pao de Acucar in 1948 in Brazil.
About_#2: Under Diniz's management, Pao de Acucar became Brazil's largest retailer. In 2012, he sold a stake to French supermarket operator Groupe Casino.
About_#3: Within a year, the relationship with the French partners went sour; Diniz ceded control of Grupo Pao de Acucar to Casino in September 2013.
About_#4: In 2016, he became a significant shareholders of Carrefour SA, Casino's competitor. He also chairs meat processor Brasil Foods.
In Their Own Words: Nobody is born a leader. You need to search and to improve yourself.

About_#1: John Dorrance is an heir to the Campbell's Soup fortune; his grandfather invented Campbell's formula for condensed soup.
About_#2: His relatives are still the company's largest shareholders, but he sold his stake in the mid-1990's and emigrated to Ireland.
About_#3: His move was presumably timed to avoid capital gains taxes when he sold his Campbell's stake.
About_#4: The Irish government reportedly gave Dorrance citizenship in 1995 when he spent $1.5 million planting trees.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Zhejiang University
About_#1: Feng Hailiang chairs Zhejiang-based Hailiang Group, whose interests include copper smelting, real estate, education and agribusiness.
About_#2: Feng started a trading company in 1985, followed by a copper products factory in 1989; the latter was the predecessor to Hailiang Group.
About_#3: Feng's son Feng Luming is an executive director of Hong Kong-listed Hailiang International Holding.
About_#4: Liming holds undergraduate and graduate degrees in business from the University of San Francisco.

About_#1: Gao is chairman of Yongxing Special Materials Technology, a supplier of nickel alloy and stainless steel wire rods and bars.
About_#2: Yongxing was established in July 2000.
About_#3: Gao served in the People's Liberation Army Navy from 1981 to 1987.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Universidad Nacional Autonoma de Mexico
About_#1: Carlos Hank Rohn's fortune includes assets in construction, financial services and more.
About_#2: He is the son of the late politician Carlos Hank Gonzalez, who served as Mexico City mayor, Secretary of Agriculture and governor of his home state.
About_#3: In October 2017, Mexico's Grupo Banorte said it would pay $1.4 billion in stock and cash to acquire Hank Rhon's Grupo Financiero Interacciones.
About_#4: Hank Rhon's wife is the daughter of Roberto Gonzalez, the founder of Grupo Banorte.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad
About_#1: Vivek Jain is chairman of the Inox GFL group, which he inherited from his father Devendra Jain after the patriarch divided the family's assets in 2021 between him and his brother, Pavan Jain.
About_#2: An MBA from the elite Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad, Jain started working with his father in 1978 in what was then a paper trading business.
About_#3: Today, the flagship company of his group is Gujarat Flurochemicals, a manufacturer of chemicals and industrial gases, which he helped his father set up.
About_#4: His son Devansh runs Inox Wind, the group's wind energy unit. Its subsidiary Inox Green Energy Services is planning to list in 2022.

Education: Diploma, High School; Drop Out, Western Kentucky University
About_#1: Brad Kelley, a Kentucky native and a farmer's son, built a fortune from discount cigarettes.
About_#2: He built Commonwealth Brands, maker of USA Gold and Malibu cigarettes, and sold it for $1 billion in 2001.
About_#3: Kelley has since used that cash to become one of the largest landowners in the U.S., with 1.5 million acres from Hawaii to Florida.
About_#4: Kelley owns historic stud farm Calumet in Kentucky, which had three starters in the 2017 Kentucky Derby.
Did You Know?: In 2020, Kelley sold travel guide Lonely Planet, which he had bought seven years earlier from the BBC for $75 million.

About_#1: In the early 1960s, Alicia Koplowitz inherited a stake in Spanish construction company Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas after her father died.
About_#2: She sold her stake to sister Esther for $800 million in 1997 and put the money into diverse investments.
About_#3: Over the years she's invested in steelmaker Acerinox, electric utility Iberdrola, and Banco Sabadell.
About_#4: Koplowitz owns hotels in Italy and Miami, real estate in Washington, D.C. and Chicago, as well as a stake in Hospes, a Spanish luxury hotel chain.
Did You Know?: In 1969 when she was a teenager she married Alberto Cortina, six months after her sister Esther married Cortina's cousin, Alberto Alcocer.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Babson College; Master of Business Administration, Babson College
About_#1: C. Dean Metropoulos is best known for saving the iconic Twinkies and Hostess Brands.
About_#2: Through his Metropoulos & Co, he's also turned around and sold Chef Boyardee, Pabst Blue Ribbon, Bumble Bee Tuna and others.
About_#3: Metropoulos and private equity firm Apollo bought Hostess Brands in 2013 and later took it public. Most recently he's been selling his shares.
About_#4: The Greek-born entrepreneur is a trustee of the National Hellenic Museum located in Chicago.
Did You Know?: At age 10, Metropoulos emigrated with his family from Greece to Boston.
In Their Own Words: "People walk up and thank me for bringing back Twinkies."

About_#1: Dan Sten Olsson is CEO and majority owner of Stena Sphere, a privately held Swedish conglomerate.
About_#2: Interests include cruising, shipping, offshore drilling, property and metal recycling.
About_#3: Stena was founded in 1939 as a trading company by Dan's father, Sten.
About_#4: Dan took over in 1983 and now owns 51% of the company; his siblings Stefan Sten Olsson and Madeleine Olsson Eriksson own 24.5% and 12.5%, respectively

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Duke University
About_#1: Tor Peterson is the only American among the five-person cadre of billionaires to earn their fortunes at Swiss commodities-trading powerhouse Glencore.
About_#2: After six years of trading commodities at Phibro-Salomon in New York, he joined Glencore in 1992 and leads marketing operations for its coal division.
About_#3: He owns a minority stake in Glencore, which trades on the London Stock Exchange.
Did You Know?: He attended boarding school in Switzerland, college at Duke in the U.S. and lives in Zug.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Menlo College
About_#1: John Pritzker learned the hotel business at his family's Hyatt Hotel chain; he sold his shares in Hyatt to relatives in 2010.
About_#2: Pritzker went on to build Commune Hotels and Resorts, a boutique hotel management company, which after a merger in 2016 became Two Roads Hospitality.
About_#3: In November 2018, Hyatt Hotels purchased Two Roads Hospitality for $408 million, plus a potential $96 million if certain outcomes are met.
About_#4: John's brother Thomas is the chairman of Hyatt and his sister Gigi Pritzker is a film producer.
Did You Know?: Pritzker, a former Dead Head, took time off between high school and college to be part of the emerging counterculture in San Francisco.
In Their Own Words: Three years ago I gave the commencement speech at Menlo College and received an honorary degree in Rocket Science (true story). Whenever my team doubt the veracity of my assertions I remind them I'm a Rocket Scientist.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Washington
About_#1: Hussain Sajwani is the chairman of Dubai-based luxury real estate developer Damac Properties, which he founded in 2002.
About_#2: He started out in the food services business, catering to the U.S. military and construction giant Bechtel.
About_#3: In 2001, after Dubai allowed foreigners to own property, he shifted to real estate and sold units in a residential building in less than six months.
About_#4: Damac teamed up with Donald Trump in 2013 to develop two Trump-branded golf courses in Dubai developments.
Did You Know?: After Trump was elected president, he announced that Sajwani had offered him a $2 billion real estate deal in Dubai, but he turned it down.
In Their Own Words: It [success] has been a combination of luck and vision. Someone would open the door, and I would run and grab the opportunity.

About_#1: Tseng Cheng inherited his Chang Chun Group stake from his father, Tseng Shin-yi, who died in 2016.
About_#2: Shin-yi co-founded the business in 1949 with classmates M.K. Liao and Lin Shu-Hong.
About_#3: Chang Chun is now one of Asia's largest petrochemicals-and-plastics manufacturers, with plants in Taiwan, China and Southeast Asia.
About_#4: His eldest son serves as a director at both Chang Chun Petrochemicals & Chang Chun Plastics.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University; Master of Science, Stanford University
About_#1: Yang cofounded web portal Yahoo in 1995 after dropping out of a Ph.D. program in electrical engineering at Stanford.
About_#2: Yang served as Yahoo's CEO from 2007 to 2009; he left Yahoo's board in 2012.
About_#3: In 2017, he and his wife, Akiko Yamazaki, pledged $25 million to San Francisco's Asian Art Museum, the largest gift in the museum's history.
About_#4: In 2016, Yahoo completed the sale of its core operating business to Verizon for $5 billion in cash.
Did You Know?: Yang was born in Taiwan; his father died when he was two. He immigrated to the U.S. at age 10 with his mother and brother.
In Their Own Words: When I told my Mom that I was stepping out of my Ph.D. to start a company and basically sell "Internet advertising" for a living, she wasn't too keen on the idea, but she supported me. These days, she doesn't complain very much!

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Keio University
About_#1: Takao Yasuda founded discount retailer Don Quijote, now Pan Pacific International Holdings, in 1980.
About_#2: The retailer has nearly 670 stores and is publicly traded. It sells a wide range of products, from Rolexes to snacks to adult toys.
About_#3: He returned as a board director in January 2019, after having stepped down as CEO and chairman in 2015.
About_#4: Supermarket UNY, formerly a part of retail and convenience-store operator FamilyMart UNY, is now a 100% subsidiary.
Did You Know?: In December 2017, the company opened up its first store in Singapore, called Don Don Donki, part of an expansion in Southeast Asia.

About_#1: Yu Qibing chairs the Kibing Group, an industrial investment and real estate firm.
About_#2: Yu is also the director of Zhuzhou Kibing Group, a leading glass manufacturer in China.
About_#3: Zhuzhou Kibing Group listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 2011.

Full Name: Abdulla bin Ahmad Al Ghurair & family
About_#1: Abdulla Al Ghurair founded Mashreqbank, a leading U.A.E. bank, in 1967. He stepped down as chairman in October 2019, but remains a board member.
About_#2: His eponymous holding company has interests in food, construction and real estate; non-family members are part of the leadership team.
About_#3: His construction company did the exterior cladding of Burj Khalifa, the world's tallest building, and helped build the Dubai Metro.
About_#4: His brother Saif Al Ghurair, who passed away in August 2019, was also a billionaire.
Did You Know?: In 2015, Al Ghurair pledged one third of his group's assets to a foundation that invests in education programs in the U.A.E.

About_#1: Isak Andic is the founder and chairman of $2.5 billion (2017 sales) clothing retailer Mango.
About_#2: The company has over 2,100 stores in 110 countries. Its international business makes up about three quarters of its revenue.
About_#3: Andic opened his first clothing store in Barcelona in 1984, took the company international in 1992 and opened its 1,000th store in 2007.
About_#4: His son and presumptive heir Jonathan Andic (b.1981) is the company's executive vice chairman.
Did You Know?: The media-shy entrepreneur was born in Istanbul in 1953, but his family moved to Barcelona in the 1960s.

About_#1: Originally from Chandigarh, India, Harindarpal Singh Banga, known as Harry, has lived in Hong Kong since the 1970s.
About_#2: The former vice-chairman of the Noble Group made his fortune over a 21-year career with Asia's largest commodity trader.
About_#3: He cashed in the last of his Noble shares in 2012, and started Hong Kong based Caravel Group with sons Guneet and Angad in 2013.
About_#4: The Caravel Group trades and ships commodities.

About_#1: Anne Beaufour gets her fortune from her stake in Ipsen, France's third-largest pharmaceutical company.
About_#2: Founded in 1929 by grandfather Henri Beaufour, the family's 76% share of Ipsen was split between 3 siblings when father Albert Beaufour died in 2000.
About_#3: Anne and her brother Henri now control 52% of Ipsen, which reported 2018 revenues of more than $2.4 billion.
About_#4: Sister Veronica sold her 6% stake.

About_#1: Henri Beaufour's fortune come from his stake in Ipsen, France's third-largest pharmaceutical company.
About_#2: Founded in 1929 by grandfather Henri Beaufour, the family's 76% share of Ipsen was split between 3 siblings when father Albert Beaufour died in 2000.
About_#3: Henri and his sister Anne now control 52% of Ipsen, which reported 2019 revenues of more than $2.6 billion.
About_#4: Sister Veronica sold her 6% stake.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad; Bachelor of Arts/Economics, St Stephen's College (India)
About_#1: Indian internet pioneer, Sanjeev Bikhchandani, draws his wealth from listed Info Edge (India).
About_#2: Info Edge owns portals for job search (naukri.com), matrimony (jeevasathi.com); real estate (99acres.com) and education (shiksha.com).
About_#3: It also owns stakes in online food delivery outfit Zomato and insurance marketplace, policybazaar.com. Both companies went public in 2021.
About_#4: Bikhchandani, who studied at the premier Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad, is founder and executive vice-chairman of Info Edge.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Temple University
About_#1: Norman Braman owns one of Florida's largest car dealerships, Braman Motorcars, which has more than $2 billion in annual revenue.
About_#2: Braman made his first fortune selling pharmaceuticals and cosmetics.
About_#3: Born in Philadelphia to immigrant parents, he was a water boy for the Eagles, a team he bought in 1985 and sold in 1994 for a $120 million profit.
About_#4: An avid art collector, he helped bring the prestigious Swiss art fair, Art Basel, to Miami in 2002.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Florida
About_#1: J. Hyatt Brown chairs New York Stock Exchange-traded Brown & Brown, the fifth largest insurance brokerage in the U.S.
About_#2: His father, J. Adrian Brown, cofounded the company in Daytona Beach in 1939, and Hyatt became CEO in 1961.
About_#3: Under Hyatt, Brown & Brown grew from a local, family-owned business into a national firm with over 7,000 employees and 200 offices.
About_#4: Hyatt's son J. Powell Brown took over as CEO in 2009; the elder Brown remains chairman.

Education: Medical Doctor, University of Malaya
About_#1: Chen Lip Keong's NagaWorld holds a casino license in Cambodian capital Phnom Penh running to 2065, with a guaranteed monopoly to 2035.
About_#2: NagaWorld is the largest casino resort in Indochina. Naga2 opened across the street in November 2017, connected by underground mall NagaCity Walk.
About_#3: NagaCorp is the first casino company to be listed on the Hong Kong stock exchange and the first doing business principally in Cambodia.
About_#4: Frustrated by the interest rates banks demanded to finance Naga2, Chen put up his own $369 million and took payment in company shares.
Did You Know?: He graduated as a medical doctor but opted for a career in business.
In Their Own Words: The idea is to position a first-world product in a third-world market. That is a competitive advantage.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Dartmouth College; Master of Business Administration, Stanford University
About_#1: Jim Coulter is co-CEO and founding partner of private equity giant TPG, which managed over $120 billion in assets as of August 2022.
About_#2: Coulter met his longtime business partner David Bonderman while working for billionaire Robert Bass. The pair left in 1992 to found TPG.
About_#3: Their first big deal was a $66 million investment in faltering Continental Airlines, which ultimately made them a $640 million profit.
About_#4: Coulter serves on the boards of several organizations, including Creative Artists Agency, Philz Coffee, and Rodan + Fields.
Did You Know?: Coulter worked at Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb as a financial analyst.
In Their Own Words: "You get to a certain age and you realize that somehow the world's problems are yours to solve and if not us - who, if not now - when?"

About_#1: Federico De Nora is the chairman of Industrie De Nora, an Italian manufacturer of electrodes, components for green hydrogen and other products.
About_#2: He owns a majority stake in the company, originally founded by his grandfather Oronzio De Nora in Milan in 1923; an IPO is planned for the first half of 2022.
About_#3: Oronzio started De Nora after patenting an antiseptic solution; he then moved into electrodes as well as chlorine production and water treatment.
About_#4: The firm first expanded overseas to Japan in the 1960s; today, De Nora's water treatment clients range from the Chesapeake Bay to Singapore.

About_#1: Dong Wei chairs Liangyungang Hengchuang Pharmaceutical Technology.
About_#2: He chairs the supervisory committee of Shanghai-listed Jiangsu Hengrui Medicine.
About_#3: Liangyungang Hengchuang holds a stake in Hengrui.
About_#4: Dong graduated from China Pharmaceutical University in 1993.

About_#1: Chemical engineer Sandeep Engineer, started out working in the pharma industry before launching his own pharma venture in 1987.
About_#2: A decade later, he latched on to making plastic pipes, convincing India's plumbers about their superiority to metal pipes.
About_#3: Sales at his company, Astral (formerly Astral Poly Technik), got a boost when Bollywood actor Salman Khan became brand ambassador.
About_#4: The $430 million (revenue) firm also makes adhesives and sealants.

About_#1: Alceu Elias Feldmann is the founder of Fertipar, a Brazilian fertilizer giant with revenues of $1.7 billion.
About_#2: He owns 85% of Fertipar, which has about a 15% share of Brazil's fertilizers and pesticides market.
About_#3: Feldmann, armed with a degree in agricultural engineering from the Federal University of Parana, founded the company in 1980.
About_#4: Feldmann still serves as chairman and CEO of Fertipar, which employs about 2,100 in several Brazilian states.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Southern California
About_#1: Frank Fertitta III and his brother, Lorenzo, made the bulk of their fortune through mixed martial arts promoter UFC.
About_#2: The brothers bought UFC for $2 million in 2001; it sold to an investment group led by WME/IMG for $4 billion in 2016.
About_#3: They sold their remaining stakes in UFC in August 2017 at a $5 billion valuation.
About_#4: The Fertittas took their casino business, Red Rock Resorts, public in 2016. It was founded by their father.
Did You Know?: His daughter Kelley, a vice president at her father's gaming company, got married at a lavish wedding at Red Rock Resorts in September 2018 where Bruno Mars sang.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Leonard N. Stern School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, U of San Diego
About_#1: Lorenzo Fertitta and his brother, Frank, made the bulk of their fortune through mixed martial arts promoter UFC.
About_#2: They bought UFC for $2 million in 2001; an investment group led by WME/IMG bought it for $4 billion in 2016.
About_#3: They sold their remaining stakes in UFC in August 2017 at a $5 billion valuation.
About_#4: The Fertittas took public their casino business, Red Rock Resorts, in 2016. It was founded by their father.
Did You Know?: The Fertitta brothers got hooked on martial arts after taking weekly lessons in their casino's basement. Soon after, they bought UFC.
In Their Own Words: The thing that really shocked me was the quality of the fighters. They were world-class athletes. I had this perception that these were just guys getting off a barstool and trying to hurt each other.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University
About_#1: Doris Fisher cofounded clothing retailer Gap in 1969 with her husband, Don (d. 2009), after the couple struggled to find jeans that fit him.
About_#2: The couple raised $63,000 to open their first store, which sold jeans and music, in San Francisco.
About_#3: Doris Fisher served as the company's merchandiser from the day it opened until 2003 and sat on Gap's board until 2009.
About_#4: The 1953 Stanford economics graduate cofounded the KIPP Foundation, which supports public charter schools, donating $15 million.
Did You Know?: Gap is short for "generation gap." The Fishers agreed on the name after Doris nixed her husband's original idea, "Pants and Discs."
In Their Own Words: I had an older sister - I was the middle child - and I just wanted to make my parents proud and to have them notice me, especially my dad. I really idolized him. I wanted to show him what I could do.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Western Michigan University
About_#1: Gores has sponsored more than a dozen SPACs since 2015 as an early adopter of the blank-check frenzy that exploded in 2020.
About_#2: His SPACs have orchestrated mergers to take companies like Luminar Technologies, United Wholesale Mortgage and Twinkie-maker Hostess Brands public.
About_#3: Gores founded private equity firm The Gores Group in 1987, though its assets have shrunk more than 80% in the last decade to $574 million.
About_#4: Gores and his younger brother Tom, also a billionaire, immigrated to America from Israel with their parents and four other siblings in 1968.
Did You Know?: Gores' first job after immigrating to the United States at age 15 was bagging groceries for 25 cents an hour at his uncle's store in Flint, Michigan.
In Their Own Words: "I love this country. I love what it brings. When you come from a different place, and you get to see the freedom that we have, the opportunity that we have -- it's insane."

About_#1: Rajinder Gupta founded and chairs the $610 million (revenue) home textiles and paper company Trident.
About_#2: The Ludhiana-based company makes bath and bed linen such as towels, duvets and fitted sheets.
About_#3: Two thirds of Trident's annual revenue is from exports to nearly 100 countries.
About_#4: Trident's shares rose more than 300% in 2021, fueled by a surge in demand from the U.S. and Europe.
Did You Know?: He founded it in 1990 as a yarn manufacturer.

Education: Master, Moscow Institute of International Relations
About_#1: Megapolis, the company established by retail magnate Igor Kesaev and his partner Sergei Katsiev, controls 70% of Russia's cigarette market.
About_#2: Philip Morris and Japan Tobacco International bought 40% of Megapolis for $1.5 billion in 2013 in one of the biggest deals in the Russian consumer market.
About_#3: In 2019, he merged his Dixy supermarket chain with a chain of alcohol stores Krasnoe & Beloe to create one of the largest retailers in Russia.
About_#4: He founded Mercury, which began as a food and alcohol importer, in 1991.

About_#1: Father-son pair, Raj Kumar and Kishin RK, are among Singapore's leading landlords with their Royal Holdings/RB Capital property empire.
About_#2: The duo went on a dealmaking spree after a 2011 family settlement between Raj and his younger sibling Asok Kumar Hiranandani, also a billionaire.
About_#3: Their prize holdings include the 442-room Holiday Inn Express at Clarke Quay and the five-star hotel Intercontinental Singapore Robertson Quay.
About_#4: Kishin's newest venture is TiffinLabs, an online meal delivery firm with more than 1,000 cloud kitchens in Asia, Europe and the U.S. Its CEO is a former JD.com executive.
In Their Own Words: When you've done hundreds of deals you develop an instinct. That becomes your Midas touch.

About_#1: Li chairs Sun Paper, a paper and pulp producer based in Yanzhou in Shandong Province in China.
About_#2: Born in a poor peasant family, Li worked at a train station as a porter starting at age 18.
About_#3: In 1983, he borrowed 30,000 yuan to set up paper producer Sun Paper in his hometown Yanzhou, an inland city in Eastern China's Shandong Province.

About_#1: Lu Zhongfang retired from a pesticides factory in northern China's Jilin Province in 1993 and invested in test preparation firm Offcn in 1999.
About_#2: Lu's son Liu Yongxin chairs Offcn and is also a billionaire.
About_#3: Offcn Education Technology completed a backdoor listing at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2019.

About_#1: Nirmal Minda is chairman and managing director of UNO Minda (formerly Minda industries), which makes a range of auto parts for cars and two-wheelers.
About_#2: The business was started by his late father in 1958, initially to make electric parts for motorcycles.
About_#3: Minda joined the family business in 1977 in the marketing division but eventually separated from his brother in 1996.
About_#4: From one small workshop in Delhi, the company today has 71 factories worldwide.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of London
About_#1: An accountant by training, Farhad Moshiri once worked for such firms as Ernst & Young and Deloitte Touche.
About_#2: After meeting Russian billionaire Usmanov in the early 90's, he became his minority partner in several projects.
About_#3: Alongside Usmanov, he has stakes in Russian mining and steel manufacturing giant Metalloinvest and Russian wireless operator Megafon.
About_#4: He sold his stake in Arsenal back to Usmanov in 2016 to fund his investment in English soccer club Everton.

About_#1: Hans Georg Naeder heads orthopedic device maker Ottobock SE; it takes its name from his grandfather Otto Bock, who founded the business in 1919.
About_#2: The company has worked with the Paralympics since 1988, producing hockey sledges and custom prosthetics for skiers, snowboarders and sprinters.
About_#3: Since taking the reins from his father at age 28, Hans Georg has expanded the staff more than five-fold to over 8,000 worldwide.
About_#4: Ottobock operates sales and service branches in 50 countries and generates annual revenue of around $1.2 billion.
Did You Know?: An avid sportsman, Hans Georg helmed his 46-meter sailing yacht Pink Gin to victory in the New Zealand Millennium Cup in 2007. He owns Baltic Yachts of Finland.

Education: Master of Business Administration, University of Nevada at Reno
About_#1: Eren Ozmen is chairwoman, president and majority owner of private aerospace and defense company Sierra Nevada Corporation (SNC).
About_#2: SNC's Dream Chaser spacecraft is contracted by NASA for at least seven cargo missions to the International Space Station.
About_#3: In April 2021, SNC spun off its space capabilities, headlined by Dream Chaser, into a new commercial space company, Sierra Space.
About_#4: Sierra Space, which raised $1.4 billion at a $4.5 billion valuation in November, is set to launch its first flight of a cargo Dream Chaser, named Tenacity, by late 2022 or early 2023.
Did You Know?: Ozmen sold baklava and cleaned SNC's office building to put herself through business school at the University of Nevada, Reno.
In Their Own Words: "Look at the United States and what women can do here, compared to the rest of the world. That is why we feel we have a legacy to leave behind."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania; Master of Business Administration, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Ronald Perelman is a dealmaker who built a fortune with a diverse array of holdings, from candy to cosmetics.
About_#2: Perelman sold assets worth billions of dollars to pay off debt in late 2020 after the Covid-19 pandemic ravaged his businesses.
About_#3: He is a longtime shareholder of cosmetics giant Revlon; his daughter Debra became the firm's CEO in 2018.
About_#4: Perelman learned about business from his father. He attended board meetings with him while in elementary school.
Did You Know?: Perelman's foundation pledged $65 million to Princeton in 2018 but did not follow through, prompting the school to remove his name from a new dorm it is building.
In Their Own Words: As I grew, it became very clear to me that what I do, I am not doing alone. I am placed in situations with opportunities that others are not. I don't believe that that is happenstance. I believe that there is a God that has a plan for me.

About_#1: Indian-born farmer's son, Ravi Pillai migrated to Saudi Arabia after his small construction business in his native Kerala state went bust.
About_#2: With help from a well-connected local partner, he started over in 1978 and built his RP Group into a $7.8 billion (revenue) construction heavyweight.
About_#3: The construction magnate has used his Gulf riches to invest back home, picking up stakes in banks, hotels and real estate.
Did You Know?: RP Group is among the biggest employers of Indians in the Middle East.
In Their Own Words: My real home is the sky because I'm always travelling.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, Northwestern University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Tufts University
About_#1: Daniel Pritzker is one of 11 billionaire heirs in the Chicago-based Pritzker family, whose best known creation is Hyatt Hotels.
About_#2: In May 2019, Pritzker released Bolden, a biographical drama about New Orleans trumpeter Buddy Bolden, after working on it for over a decade.
About_#3: He made a silent film, Louis, about the life of Louis Armstrong, which was released to critical praise in 2010.
About_#4: Daniel's brother Tom is the chairman of Hyatt Hotels; his sister Gigi is a film producer.
Did You Know?: Pritzker used to own Jerry Garcia's guitar; he auctioned it and donated the proceeds, $3.2 million, to the Southern Poverty Law Center.

About_#1: Matthias Reinhart is CEO and majority shareholder of VZ Holding Ltd., a Swiss financial services company he took public in 2007.
About_#2: After getting his MBA at University of St. Gallen, he worked at McKinsey & Co. in Zurich and Chicago before co-founding VZ in 1993.
About_#3: VZ's key proposition: bringing transparency to a market that made it hard for customers to compare the prices and benefits of financial products.
About_#4: The firm does not broker financial products; instead, customers pay a fee for advisory and portfolio-management services.
Did You Know?: Reinhart is a member of the advisory board of NZZ (Neue Zuercher Zeitung), a Swiss, German-language daily newspaper.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University
About_#1: Alejandro Santo Domingo, an heir to a beer fortune, sits on the board of beer giant Anheuser-Busch InBev, in which he has a 1.2% stake.
About_#2: Santo Domingo was a key negotiator in the deals that led to the 2016 merger between Anheuser-Busch InBev and SABMiller.
About_#3: A Harvard grad, Santo Domingo is a senior managing director of New York-based Quadrant Capital Advisors, an investment advisory firm.
About_#4: He also sits on the board of Peet's Coffee owner JDE Peet's and is on the board of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Did You Know?: In May 2016 Santo Domingo married Lady Charlotte Wellesley, reportedly a direct descendant of the British general who vanquished Napoleon at Waterloo.
In Their Own Words: Culture is another privilege when one has wealth, but it is also a hopeful motive for enduring adversity.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Delhi University
About_#1: Vivek Chaand Sehgal chairs the $9.8 billion (revenue) Samvardhana Motherson Group, which was set up in 1975.
About_#2: Sehgal draws the biggest chunk of his wealth from flagship Motherson Sumi Systems, India's largest auto components maker by sales.
About_#3: The company, which has Japan's Sumitomo Wiring Systems as a partner, has 271 factories with operations in 41 countries.
About_#4: Its clients include BMW, Ford, Mercedes, Toyota and Volkswagen.
Did You Know?: Sehgal founded the company with his mother as a silver trading outfit, hence the name Motherson.
In Their Own Words: When you want to train someone, you should throw them into the storm.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Madras
About_#1: An early Google backer, Kavitark Ram Shriram has sold of most of his stock but remains on the board of its parent company, Alphabet.
About_#2: Born in India, Shriram studied math at the University of Madras. After moving to the U.S. he joined Netscape in 1994 as an executive.
About_#3: Later he became president of Junglee, an online comparison shopping firm acquired by Amazon in 1998. Ram took on a vice president position at Amazon.
About_#4: He left Amazon and since 2000 has been investing in technology startups through his firm, Sherpalo Ventures.
Did You Know?: In 2014, Shriram and his wife donated $61 million to engineering initiatives at Stanford University, which both of his daughters attended and where he is a trustee.

Education: Bachelor of Science, De La Salle University
About_#1: Hans Sy is the fourth child of Henry Sy, the late founder of SM Investments, one of Philippines largest conglomerates.
About_#2: He stepped down as president of subsidiary SM Prime, a property developer, in 2016 and remains a director.
About_#3: His five siblings, Tessie, Elizabeth, Henry Jr., Harley and Herbert, are all involved in the business.
About_#4: He also serves as an adviser of SM Investments, chairman of China Banking Corporation and chairman of National University.
Did You Know?: Han's father, Henry Sy, acquired Philippines' National University, a private institution, in 2009.

Education: Bachelor of Science, De La Salle University
About_#1: Herbert Sy is an adviser of SM Investments, a major conglomerate, and a director of SM Prime, the group's property developer.
About_#2: He is a son of the late SM founder, Henry Sy, and the second-youngest of six children.
About_#3: His three brothers and two sisters all hold posts in the business, which spans banking, retail, real estate, mining, and hotels.
About_#4: He is actively involved in the group's supermarket operations, which includes an investment arm.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Golden Gate University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Nan Yang University
About_#1: Tahir, who goes by one name, is founder of Mayapada group, a conglomerate with interests in banking, healthcare and real estate.
About_#2: The family has stakes in listed Bank Mayapada and Maha Properti Indonesia.
About_#3: He also owns property in Singapore, including through listed property firm MYP.
About_#4: He co-owns the licensee that publishes Forbes Indonesia.
Did You Know?: Tahir's father was a pedicab maker.

About_#1: Wang Linpeng chairs Beijing Easyhome Investment Holdings Group, a home furnishings retailer.
About_#2: Easyhome in 2018 operated or franchised some 400 home furnishing and building supply superstores in China.
About_#3: Easyhome received investment of approximately $2 billion from a group that included China e-commerce heavyweight Alibaba in 2018.

About_#1: David and Drorit Wertheim are the children of the late Moshe Wertheim (d. 2016), the founder of the Central Bottling Company, Israel's Coca Cola bottler.
About_#2: Before he died, Moshe Wertheim gave his children ownership over the company, as well as his shares in Mizrahi Tefahot Bank and Alony Hetz.
About_#3: In 2018, David purchased all of his sister's shares in Alony Hetz, then sold them because of Israeli anti-monopoly rules.
About_#4: In 2019, the siblings became majority shareholders in Mizrahi Tefahot bank.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Tennessee State University
About_#1: Oprah Winfrey has transitioned her hit talk show, which ran for 25 years, into a media and business empire.
About_#2: Reinvested, the profits from her show plus profits from films like The Color Purple, Beloved and Selma (which her Harpo Productions coproduced) add up to more than $2 billion.
About_#3: In 2011, Winfrey launched cable channel OWN. Her 25.5% of the network is worth more than $65 million.
About_#4: The 'Oprah effect' has spread to Weight Watchers: she bought a 10% stake in 2015 (since lowered to 7%) and acts as a brand ambassador.
Did You Know?: Winfrey overcame a tough childhood, born to a teen mother in rural Mississippi and raised without indoor plumbing.
In Their Own Words: What I learned in all of those thousands of interviews is that there is a common denominator in our human experience. Everybody wants to know did you hear me and did what I say matter?

About_#1: Zhu Xingming cofounded and chairs Shenzhen Inovance Technology, which makes industrial automation control products.
About_#2: Inovance went public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2010; Zhu owns about 13% of the company's stock.
About_#3: Zhu holds a graduate degree from Yanshan University.

About_#1: Abdulla Al Futtaim owns conglomerate Al Futtaim Group, run by his son Omar, who is vice chairman and CEO.
About_#2: In 1955, the group became the exclusive distributor in the U.A.E. of Toyota-- and still has the distributorship today.
About_#3: Al Futtaim also has the license to operate Hertz, Ikea and Toys "R" Us and Marks and Spencer in the U.A.E.
About_#4: The retailers anchor its malls, which include Dubai Festival City, Dubai Festival Plaza, Doha Festival City and Cairo Festival City.
Did You Know?: In 2010, Al Futtaim reportedly bought the yacht of the late Russian oligarch Boris Berezovsky.

About_#1: Suhail Bahwan is the founder and chairman of Suhail Bahwan Group, one of the largest conglomerates in Oman.
About_#2: It is a major producer of fertilizers, generating 1.3 million tons of urea annually. It also owns Nissan and BWM dealerships.
About_#3: He first went into business with his brother Saud in 1965, selling fishing nets and building materials, before scoring the Toyota dealership in 1975.
About_#4: In 2002, he split with his brother, who kept the Toyota dealership and passed it along after his death to his son Mohammed.
Did You Know?: Bahwan attended primary school in India, but dropped out after sixth grade. He sailed a dhow, and sold dried dates and fish.

About_#1: Ulrike Baro is one of the three daughters of Horst Sartorius, who passed on a 50% stake in biopharmaceutical firm Sartorius AG after his death in 1998.
About_#2: Her great-grandfather Florenz Sartorius founded the firm in 1870 to make analytical balances to measure small mass in laboratories.
About_#3: Sartorius AG, which went public in 1990, makes pharmaceutical and laboratory equipment.
About_#4: Today, the company has around 10,600 employees and annual revenue exceeding $2.5 billion.
Did You Know?: Ulrike shares in the legacy with sisters Karin Herbst-Sartorius, Christine Franken and Christine's sons, Andreas and Kai Christian.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University
About_#1: David Baszucki is cofounder and CEO of Roblox, a social gaming platform that allows kids and teens to play games that are made by fellow gamers.
About_#2: Roblox's 50 million daily active users spent 41 billion hours using the platform in 2021.
About_#3: Players on the platform can buy a digital currency, Robux, which lets them purchase special items within games.
About_#4: Robux purchases allow tween developers of games to earn money for their efforts. More than $530 million was paid out to Roblox creators in 2021.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, New York University
About_#1: Thor Bjorgolfsson owns stakes in such businesses as Swiss pharmaceutical company Xantis and Chilean telecom WOM.
About_#2: Bjorgolfsson also has investments in cryptocurrencies and startups Zwift, Deliveroo and Stripe.
About_#3: Bjorgolfsson made his first fortune in the wilds of Russia, cofounding Bravo brewery and creating the popular Botchkarov beer brand.
About_#4: He sold it to Heineken in 2002 and used the proceeds to go on a buying spree in his native Iceland and Eastern Europe.
In Their Own Words: Power, money, that's just the road to respect. After all, money disappears, friends die, and you die, but your reputation remains.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, McGill University
About_#1: In 2000, Charles Bronfman and his nephew Edgar Bronfman Jr. sold their family's spirits and alcohol giant Seagram to Vivendi for $30 billion.
About_#2: His father Samuel Bronfman, a Russian immigrant to Canada, started a small distillery in 1924 and eventually bought out competitor Seagram.
About_#3: Since the sale, Charles, who once co-chaired Seagram, has turned toward philanthropy, authoring two books on the matter and signing The Giving Pledge.
About_#4: Bronfman has given away or pledged at least $350 million, mostly toward promotion of Canadian culture and the Jewish community's connection to Israel.
Did You Know?: Bronfman is one of the main benefactors of Taglit-Birthright Israel, which sends Jewish youth from North America on free educational tours of Israel.

Education: Drop Out, Brigham Young University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Kaohsiung Medical University
About_#1: Chen and his wife, Oi-Lin Chen, lead Sunrider, an herbal-products company whose goods are sold in 2,000 retail stores.
About_#2: Sunrider products are distributed in 48 countries through a mix of franchises and company-owned stores; the firm boasts 100,000 sales reps worldwide.
About_#3: He owns Sunworld-branded hotels in Beijing; the SLS Hotel in Beverly Hills, California; and St. Ermin's Hotel in London.
About_#4: Chen's vast collection of Chinese art is on display at Sunrider headquarters in Torrance, California, near Los Angeles.
Did You Know?: In 1975 he was a starving college student in Utah, buying 20-cent hamburgers by the bunch at a weekly promotion so he could freeze them to eat later on.
In Their Own Words: Doing business is like playing chess. While making a move, plan ahead your next move.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Oklahoma State University
About_#1: Husband and wife, Chuchat Petaumpai and Daonapa Petampai, gave up their bank jobs to start Muangthai Leasing in 1992.
About_#2: They grew the company into Thailand's biggest provider of loans against motorcycles with 5,800 branches.
About_#3: That company's customers include farmers, factory workers and civil servants.
About_#4: The couple took their company public in 2014 and changed its name to Muangthai Capital in 2018.
Did You Know?: Chuchat is an avid wine collector with 2,000 bottles in his private cellar.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Columbia Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Hunter College
About_#1: A Wall Street legend, Leon Cooperman built up Goldman Sachs' asset management division, GSAM, in his quarter century with the investment bank.
About_#2: Cooperman founded Omega Advisors in 1991, a hedge fund known for strong performance; he shut down the fund at the end of 2018.
About_#3: In 2017, Cooperman settled SEC insider trading charges by paying $4.9 million, but neither admitted nor denied the accusations.
About_#4: In 2019 and 2020, Cooperman began shifting more of his assets into his charitable foundation. He plans to give most of his fortune away.

About_#1: Smita Crishna-Godrej hails from the storied Godrej clan and has a one-fifth stake in the family assets.
About_#2: Her brother Jamshyd runs consumer goods firm Godrej & Boyce.
About_#3: Her husband Vijay Crishna, a well-known theatre actor, and daughter Nyrika Holkar, work in the group.
About_#4: The Godrej family controls the $6 billion (revenue) Godrej Group, a 125-year-old consumer-goods giant.

About_#1: Jacques D'Amours co-founded Canadian convenience store conglomerate Alimentation Couche-Tard in 1980.
About_#2: He retired as VP of administration in 2014, but remains on the company's board and is its second-largest shareholder.
About_#3: Couche-Tard has ballooned by snatching up competitors, including Minnesota-based Holiday Stationstores for $1.6 billion in December 2017.
About_#4: The company now boasts annual sales of $59 billion and more than 14,000 owned or franchised stores worldwide.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, IESE Business School
About_#1: Maria del Pino inherited her nearly 9% stake in Spanish infrastructure giant Ferrovial S.A. from her late father.
About_#2: Her father founded Ferrovial in 1952; it manages airports and highways around the world including London's Heathrow Airport.
About_#3: She has been a member of the board of Ferrovial, which trades on the Madrid stock exchange, since 2006.
About_#4: She is also the chairman of the family's charitable foundation, Fundación Del Pino.

About_#1: Husband and wife Yoichi and Keiko Erikawa founded videogame developer Koei four decades ago.
About_#2: The company, now called Koei Tecmo Holdings, trades on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
About_#3: Yoichi is president and CEO and Keiko is chairman. Keiko manages Koei Tecmo's $1.1 billion in assets across Japan, Hong Kong and the U.S.
About_#4: The company is known for its Samurai Warrior games. Shares got a boost from a new hit mobile game in China.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Southern Methodist University; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Southern Methodist University
About_#1: Gerald Ford has been buying distressed banks and turning them around since 1975, when he bought his first bank.
About_#2: His first big success was in 2002, when he and his billionaire friend Ronald Perelman sold Golden State Bancorp to Citigroup for $6 billion in stock.
About_#3: Ford has a 17% stake in publicly traded banking firm Hilltop Holdings, which owns PlainsCapital Bank and property insurer National Lloyds Corp.
About_#4: Ford's son Jeremy Ford is CEO of Hilltop Holdings, and his son-in-law Corey Prestidge is general counsel and executive vice president of the firm.
Did You Know?: Ford and his wife, Kelli, own multi-million dollar ranches in Kentucky and New Mexico as well as homes in Dallas and the Hamptons.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Master of Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
About_#1: Adi Godrej chairs the $6 billion (revenue) Godrej Group, a 125-year-old consumer-goods giant.
About_#2: The group was established by lawyer Ardeshir Godrej, who gave up his profession to make locks in 1897.
About_#3: Key group companies include Godrej Consumer Products, chaired by Adi Godrej's daughter Nisaba, and Godrej Properties, run by his son Pirojsha.
About_#4: The family owns a vast parcel of land in suburban Mumbai that remains its biggest asset.
Did You Know?: Godrej launched the world's first soap made from vegetable oil in 1918.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Illinois Institute of Technology
About_#1: Jamshyd Godrej is chairman and managing director of Godrej & Boyce, a privately held flagship company of the Godrej Group.
About_#2: The company's businesses span ten industries from consumer goods to engineering solutions.
About_#3: He is the cousin of the Godrej clan's billionaire patriarch Adi Godrej.
About_#4: Jamshyd Godrej's son Navroze is a non-executive director at Godrej & Boyce, while his niece Nyrika is an executive director.
Did You Know?: A U.S.-trained mechanical engineer, Jamshyd is a keen sailor.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Master of Science in Engineering, Stanford University
About_#1: Nadir Godrej is the younger sibling of billionaire Adi Godrej and holds a one-fifth share in the assets of the Godrej Group.
About_#2: With degrees from MIT, Stanford University and an MBA from Harvard Business School, he joined the family business more than four decades ago.
About_#3: Today he's the chairman and managing director of Godrej Industries and also chairs agribusiness unit Godrej Agrovet.
About_#4: The Godrej family controls the $6 billion (revenue) Godrej Group, a 125-year-old consumer-goods giant.
Did You Know?: Godrej has a flair for languages and poetry and often delivers public speeches in verse form.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Calcutta University
About_#1: Sanjiv Goenka controls the $4 billion (revenue) conglomerate RP-Sanjiv Goenka Group, headquartered in Kolkata.
About_#2: Its flagship is 123-year-old power utility, CESC, which Goenka has restructured into four separate companies.
About_#3: Other assets include supermarket chain Spencer's and snacks brand Too Yumm!, which son Shashwat looks after.
About_#4: Goenka owns a majority stake in football team ATK and has the franchise for Indian Premier League cricket team Lucknow Super Giants.
Did You Know?: His older brother Harsh Goenka, who runs his separate group, is also a billionaire.

About_#1: Stein Erik Hagen founded the discount supermarket Rimi with his father in the 1970s.
About_#2: In 2014 Hagen appointed his daughter, billionaire Caroline Marie Hagen Kjos, to take over the reins of his family's investment company Canica AS.
About_#3: Caroline, now chairman, owns a majority of the holdings, though Stein Erik maintains a seat on the board.
About_#4: He created Canica upon selling his stake in Rimi in 1998, after the chain had merged with Sweden's ICA; it later merged with Dutch retailer Ahold.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Central Arkansas
About_#1: Donald R. Horton founded homebuilder D.R. Horton in 1978 and took it public in 1992.
About_#2: Horton and his family own around 8% of the $27.8 billion (revenues) company.
About_#3: Horton studied to be a pharmacist at Oklahoma University but joined his father's real estate brokerage before founding D.R. Horton.
About_#4: His company built its first neighborhood in the Dallas/Ft. Worth area and then expanded across the U.S.
Did You Know?: D.R. Horton operates in 104 markets spanning 32 states across the United States.

About_#1: Hu Yangzhou is the general manager of Hangzhou Hikvision Digital Technology, one of the world's largest suppliers of surveillance products.
About_#2: Hikvision's revenue and net profit in 2018 were $7.5 billion and $1.7 billion, up 19% and 20.5%. from a year earlier.
About_#3: Hu graduated from the Huazhong University of Science and Technology.
About_#4: Follow billionaire Gong Hongjia was an early Hikvision investor and is its current vice chairman.

Education: Master of Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
About_#1: MIT engineer Baba Kalyani's Bharat Forge, which his son Amit helps him run, was founded by his father in 1966.
About_#2: Bharat Forge, best known for making auto parts, also manufactures components for sectors such as aerospace and oil and gas.
About_#3: Bharat Forge is the flagship of the $3 billion (revenue) Kalyani Group.
About_#4: Kalyani has a collaboration with Israel Aerospace Industries to make air defense systems.
Did You Know?: Kalyani owns football team Bharat FC.
In Their Own Words: We want to use the ability of our people to do the same level of work as a guy sitting in Michigan or Dusseldorf.

About_#1: Stephen Lansdown cofounded Hargreaves Lansdown, a British financial-services firm.
About_#2: The company manages some $130 billion in assets and boasts more than a million clients.
About_#3: Lansdown stepped down as chairman of the firm in 2009 and left its board in 2012.
About_#4: In 2010 he relocated to Guernsey, where he is a non-executive director of Ravenscroft Group, an investment services firm based on the island.

Education: Master of Business Administration, The University of Western Ontario - Richard Ivey School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Guelph
About_#1: Mark Leonard is chairman of Canadian tech company Constellation Software, which he founded in 1995.
About_#2: Constellation Software, also known as CSI, acquires, manages and builds software businesses. In 2019, the firm acquired nearly 100 tech companies.
About_#3: Constellation Software, also known as CSI, acquires, manages and builds software businesses. In 2018, the firm acquired 8 tech companies.
About_#4: After getting an MBA from the University of Western Ontario, Leonard worked in venture capital for 11 years.
Did You Know?: There are few known photos of the elusive billionaire, who has never talked to the press.

Education: Bachelor of Social Sciences, Peking University
About_#1: Dubbed the "Elon Musk of China," William Bin Li is the founder and chairman of Bitauto, a provider of web content for the auto industry.
About_#2: Li founded Shanghai-headquartered electric car maker Nio, which began taking orders for its first electric SUV in December 2017.
About_#3: Nio, which had raised $2.1 billion in funding, went public in September 2018 on the New York Stock Exchange.
About_#4: Li, who owns just under 14% of auto maker Nio, holds a bachelor's degree in sociology from Peking University.
In Their Own Words: I have no fear of losing.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, National Chiao Tung University
About_#1: Liu Ko-chen, also known as K.C. Liu, is chairman and CEO of industrial-automation-equipment and software supplier Advantech.
About_#2: Liu cofounded Advantech in 1983 at age 29 with two colleagues from HP Taiwan.
About_#3: Advantech also makes industrial computers; in recent years it has expanded to provide Internet of Things intelligent systems and cloud solutions.
About_#4: Liu's wife, Mary Chang, holds a large stake in the company.
Did You Know?: An avid reader of management books, Liu enjoys sharing books with staff, including Built to Last and Blue Ocean Strategy.

About_#1: Indian-born plastics tycoon, Aloke Lohia, is the younger brother of Sri Prakash Lohia, one of Indonesia's richest.
About_#2: The Bangkok resident runs $14.6 billion (revenue) Indorama Ventures, the world's largest producer of PET resins by capacity.
About_#3: To expand its global footprint, Indorama has been on an acquisition spree with a string of acquisitions since 2014.
About_#4: Bullish on his country of origin, Lohia has a joint venture with India's Dhunseri Petrochem to make polyester resin in eastern India.
Did You Know?: Lohia has lunch with his wife, Suchitra, who works with him, nearly every day.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Auburn University; Bachelor of Science, North Carolina State University
About_#1: Mohamed Mansour oversees family conglomerate Mansour Group, which was founded by his father Loutfy (D.1976) in 1952 and has 60,000 employees.
About_#2: Mansour established General Motors dealerships in Egypt in 1975, later becoming one of GM's biggest distributors worldwide.
About_#3: Mansour Group also has exclusive distribution rights for Caterpillar equipment in Egypt and seven other African countries.
About_#4: He served as Egypt's Minister of Transportation from 2006 to 2009 under the Hosni Mubarak regime.
Did You Know?: Mansour's father lost his fortune, when Egypt's then president, Gamal Abdel Nasser, expropriated his cotton trading company in 1964.
In Their Own Words: Empowering best in class management teams is the only way to transform a local player into a diversified conglomerate with multinational exposure.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Bachelor of Science in Engineering, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Chemical engineer from MIT, Kishore Mariwala gets his wealth from his stake in Indian consumer goods outfit Marico.
About_#2: The publicly listed company is chaired by his billionaire nephew Harsh Mariwala.
About_#3: Mariwala sits on the board of Marico's non-profit arm, Marico Innovation Foundation.
Did You Know?: An avid sailor, he is also a founder-board member of the Indian Institute of Human Settlements.

About_#1: McCaleb was an early pioneer in the blockchain space who helped launch three well-known crypto firms.
About_#2: In 2010 he created Mt. Gox, the first major Bitcoin exchange, which he sold a year later before it was hacked.
About_#3: McCaleb cofounded Ripple in 2012, but soon left over reported disagreements with fellow founders.
About_#4: His next venture in 2014 was co-founding Stellar, a Ripple competitor that aims to speed up cross-border payments.

About_#1: Willy Michel is the founder of Ypsomed Selfcare Solutions, a Swiss pharma company that develops self-injection and diagnostic systems.
About_#2: Ypsomed was started in 2003 out of Disetronic Holding, which Michel founded in 1984 with his brother and sold to Roche for $1.2 billion.
About_#3: As part of the sale agreement, Michel got the injection business back from Roche for $310 million, forming what is known as Ypsomed today.
About_#4: Michel and his three children together own a 75% stake in the company.
Did You Know?: Michel founded an art museum with his collection of Franz Gertsch portraits.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Punjab University; Master of Arts, Punjab University
About_#1: Lachhman Das Mittal started his business career in 1990 at age 60 after retiring from the state-owned Life Insurance Corporation of India.
About_#2: Today his Sonalika Group is India's third-largest tractor maker by market share.
About_#3: Japanese firm Yanmar has a 30% stake in his tractor outfit International Tractors.
