About_#4: Mittal has handed over operations to his sons Amrit Sagar and Deepak and grandsons Raman, Sushant and Rahul, but remains keenly interested in the business.
Did You Know?: Sonalika, which means "lines of gold" in Hindi, was named after a wheat seed that fueled India's Green Revolution.
In Their Own Words: I can convince anyone to purchase my tractors.

Education: B.Com, St Xavier's College Calcutta
About_#1: Ravi Modi started Vedant Fashions, named after his only son, in Kolkata city in 2002 to manufacture traditional Indian garments.
About_#2: Vedant's popular brand Manyavar is best known for its men's kurtas, sherwanis and jackets and women's lehengas, sarees and gowns, aimed at the Indian wedding market.
About_#3: Modi's wife Shilpi has a board seat, while his son Vedant is the company's chief marketing officer.
About_#4: The $85 million (revenue) company has more than 600 stores across India and 11 international stores.
Did You Know?: Modi opened the first international Manyavar store in Dubai in 2011.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, Harvard University; Drop Out, University of Michigan
About_#1: As vice chairman of famed holding company Berkshire Hathaway, Charlie Munger is Warren Buffett's right-hand man.
About_#2: Munger is also chairman of publisher newspaper publisher Daily Journal Corp. and sits on the board of retailer Costco.
About_#3: The Omaha native left the Univ. of Michigan to become an Army meteorologist during World War II.
About_#4: He later earned a degree from Harvard Law School and met Buffett at a dinner party in 1959.
Did You Know?: As a kid, Munger worked at Buffett's grandfather's grocery store in Omaha, earning $2 for ten hours of labor.
In Their Own Words: If you don't learn to constantly revise your earlier conclusions, and get better ones...you're like a one-legged man in an ass-kicking contest.

Education: Associate in Arts/Science, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Rishad Naoroji is the low-profile cousin of Indian billionaire Adi Godrej and gets his fortune from a one-fifth share of the Godrej family assets.
About_#2: The Godrej family controls the $6 billion (revenue) Godrej Group, a 125-year-old consumer-goods giant.
About_#3: He founded the Raptor Research and Conservation Foundation to focus on the conservation of Asian birds of prey.
About_#4: The wildlife enthusiast and photographer has never been involved in the business.

About_#1: Fatih Ozmen is CEO and co-owner of private defense and aerospace company Sierra Nevada Corporation (SNC).
About_#2: SNC's Dream Chaser spacecraft is contracted by NASA for at least seven cargo missions to the International Space Station.
About_#3: In April 2021, SNC spun off its space capabilities headlined by Dream Chaser into a new commercial space company, Sierra Space.
About_#4: Ozmen immigrated from Turkey in the 1980s to pursue a master's degree in engineering at the University of Nevada, Reno.
Did You Know?: Ozmen was a former national cycling champion in Turkey.
In Their Own Words: Space is more than a business for us. When we were children, on the other side of the world, we watched the moon landing on a black-and-white TV. It gave us goose bumps.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, New York University
About_#1: Stewart Rahr expanded Kinray, a pharmaceutical distributor his father founded in 1944, and sold it to Cardinal Health in 2010 for $1.3 billion.
About_#2: Rahr is known for his extravagant lifestyle, which he funds through conservative investments in private equity, hedge funds and natural resources.
About_#3: After getting a bachelor's degree in history at NYU, he briefly attended NYU Law before dropping out to run the family business.
About_#4: He has a sizable art collection that includes works by Picasso, Damien Hirst, Jeff Koons and Alexander Calder.
Did You Know?: Close friends with Trump, Rahr regularly meets up with the president in Washington D.C.
In Their Own Words: "Happiness just doesn't happen. You have to force yourself."

About_#1: Cardiologist Prathap Reddy, founded Apollo Hospitals Enterprise in 1983 after he returned from the US in the 1970s.
About_#2: The $1.9 billion (revenue) company operates a network of 71 hospitals, 268 primary care clinics and more than 4,700 pharmacies.
About_#3: His four daughters run the company. Eldest Preetha Reddy and third daughter Shobana Kamineni are executive vice chairpersons.
About_#4: Second daughter Suneeta Reddy is managing director and the youngest, Sangita Reddy is joint managing director.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Central Oklahoma
About_#1: Chad Richison is founder and CEO of Paycom, one of the first companies to process payroll completely online.
About_#2: Richison, a former senior manager at payroll firm ADP, founded Paycom in 1998.
About_#3: He took Paycom public on the New York Stock Exchange in 2014 and owns about 14% of its shares.
About_#4: The company provides payroll and human resource services and joined the S&P 500 in 2020.

About_#1: Karin Sartorius-Herbst inherited a stake in Sartorius AG, which makes pharmaceutical an laboratory equipment.
About_#2: Her great-grandfather Florenz Sartorius founded what become Sartorius AG in 1870 to make analytical balances to measure small mass in laboratories.
About_#3: Her father, Horst Sartorius, died in 1998 and left a 50% stake to his daughters Karin, Christine Franken and Ulrike Baro.
About_#4: An executor oversees their inheritance until 2028.
Did You Know?: Sartorius-Herbst has had roles in various voluntary endeavors and charitable entities throughout her life.

About_#1: Christiane Schoeller is the only child of Holtzbrinck Publishing Group heir Monika Schoeller, who passed away in 2019. She holds a 50% stake.
About_#2: Monika and her brothers, Stefan and Dieter von Holtzbrinck, inherited the business, which includes Macmillan Publishers, from their father, Georg.
About_#3: In 2006, Dieter sold his shares to his siblings, leaving them each with 50% of the company, originally founded as a book club in 1948.
About_#4: Holtzbrinck's venture investments have included many internet and e-commerce startups, such as Zalando, Groupon, HelloFresh and Rocket Internet.
Did You Know?: From 2004 through 2018, the couple reportedly ran a small but popular schnapps distillery in a quiet town in Baden-Wuertemberg, in southwestern Germany.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Samuel Curtis Johnson Graduate School of Management; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yonsei University
About_#1: Suh Kyung-bae is the chairman of Amorepacific, South Korea's largest cosmetic and skincare maker.
About_#2: He's capitalized on the Hallyu wave, a keen interest in Korean pop culture that has swept Asia and the U.S.
About_#3: The only one out of six children interested in the business, Suh joined the company in the 1980s and became CEO in 1997.
Did You Know?: Amorepacific traces its roots to Suh's grandmother, who sold camellia oil as a hair treatment across the Korean peninsula.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Minnesota State University
About_#1: Glen Taylor bought a wedding service business for $2 million in 1975 and turned it into Taylor Corp., a printing firm with over $2 billion in sales.
About_#2: Taylor, who worked at the wedding business throughout college, stepped down as CEO of Taylor Corp. in 2015; he remains chairman.
About_#3: A Minnesotan, Taylor owns stakes in the state's NBA team, the Timberwolves; WNBA team, the Lynx; and the United FC soccer team.
About_#4: In 2016, he sold 5% of his stake in both basketball teams to Lizhang Jiang, the NBA's first Chinese minority owner.
Did You Know?: Taylor grew up poor on a farm in southern Minnesota.
In Their Own Words: I like the garden and the farm stuff because I'm by myself, and it's the opposite of what I do all day long: sit in meetings, solve problems, listen to people, hear complaints and deal with bad things. That's my job.

About_#1: Nadia Thiele inherited her fortune from her late husband, billionaire industrialist Heinz Hermann Thiele, who died in February 2021 at age 79.
About_#2: The biggest piece of her fortune is a stake in brake-system firm Knorr-Bremse AG; her late husband took control of the company in the mid 1980s.
About_#3: Heinz Hermann was named honorary chairman of Knorr-Bremse AG in 2016 and took the company public in 2018.
About_#4: Alongside her step-daughter Julia Thiele-Schuerhoff, Nadia Thiele is a member of Knorr-Bremse Global Care's Executive Board, the company's affiliated charity organization.

About_#1: Yu Huijiao chairs Shanghai-listed YTO Express Group, one of China's largest express delivery firms.
About_#2: Sixteen years ago unpaid customer bills left Yu Huijiao's architectural firm bankrupt; it took a decade to pay back creditors.
About_#3: During that period, Yu decided to start his delivery business with help from his wife, Zhang Xiaoyuan.

About_#1: Zhang Ning chairs chemicals supplier Red Avenue New Materials Group, which trades on the Shanghai stock exchange.
About_#2: In May 2020, the company announced it would produce a type of compostable polyester in a venture with German firm BASF.
About_#3: Zhang Ning lives in Shanghai but holds Canadian citizenship.
About_#4: He holds a doctorate in global financial business management from Arizona State University.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Fordham University
About_#1: Zhao Tao is the chairman of Shandong Buchang Pharmaceuticals, a supplier of traditional Chinese medicine to fight cardiovascular disease.
About_#2: Zhao received an MBA from Fordham University in New York City.
About_#3: Buchang started trading on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in November 2016.
About_#4: Zhao holds a Singapore passport.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Xi'an Jiaotong University; Master of Science, Xi'an Jiaotong University
About_#1: Zhou Hongyi is the cofounder, CEO and chairman of Beijing-based Internet security software provider and search company Qihoo 360 Technology.
About_#2: Zhou previously founded 3721.com, an online search company that was purchased by Yahoo.
About_#3: Qihoo delisted from the New York Stock Exchange in 2016 then relisted in China in 2018.

About_#1: Medical doctor, whose family owned a pharmacy in Jaipur, set up Macleods Pharmaceuticals with his two brothers in 1986 to make anti-TB medicines.
About_#2: Privately held Macleods Pharmaceuticals is among India's top 10 pharma firms.
About_#3: Macleods produces generics for a range of diseases including asthma, osteoporosis and diabetes.
About_#4: Agarwal's older brothers, Girdharilal Bawri and Banwarilal Bawri. who are also billionaires, are chairman and joint managing director respectively.
Did You Know?: Agarwal and his two brothers live together with their families in the same building in Mumbai.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Chapman University
About_#1: The grandson of Greek immigrants, George Argyros worked his way through high school and college in southern California as a paperboy and grocery clerk.
About_#2: Argyros, a real estate mogul, founded property firm Arnel & Affiliates in southern California in 1968 and serves as its CEO.
About_#3: The company owns 5,500 apartments in Orange County, California and nearly 2 million square feet of commercial real estate in southern California.
About_#4: Argyros served as the U.S. Ambassador to Spain and Andorra from 2001 to 2004.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: In 1959 Edward Bass and his three brothers inherited $2.8 million each from oil tycoon uncle Sid Richardson.
About_#2: The brothers parlayed their inheritance into multi-billion dollar fortunes with the help of bets on oil and pipelines that paid off big.
About_#3: In early 2017, Bass and his three brothers sold their oil company to ExxonMobil for $5.6 billion in stock. Future payouts could total $1 billion.
About_#4: In 2018, Bass pledged $160 million to refurbish the Peabody Museum at Yale University.
Did You Know?: In 1991, Bass spent $150 million backing the Biosphere 2 project in Arizona, an experimental enclosed system designed to prove that humans could live in space.
In Their Own Words: Wealth is not a matter of money, it is a matter of being able to forwardly organize our lives in a positive way.

About_#1: Banwarilal Bawri is the joint managing director of privately held Macleods Pharmaceuticals, which is among India's top 10 pharma firms.
About_#2: Bawri, whose family owned a pharmacy in Jaipur, set up Macleods Pharmaceuticals with two siblings in 1986 to make anti-TB medicines.
About_#3: Macleods produces generics for a range of diseases including asthma, osteoporosis and diabetes.
About_#4: Bawri's older brother Girdharilal Bawri is chairman, while younger brother, Rajendra Agarwal, is managing director.
Did You Know?: Bawri and his two brothers live together with their families in the same building in Mumbai.

About_#1: Girdharilal Bawri is the chairman of Macleods Pharmaceuticals, which is among India's top 10 pharma firms.
About_#2: Bawri, whose family owned a pharmacy in Jaipur, set up Macleods Pharmaceuticals in 1986 with his two siblings to make anti-TB medicines.
About_#3: Macleods produces generics for a range of diseases including asthma, osteoporosis and diabetes.
About_#4: His younger brothers, Rajendra Agrawal and Banwarilal Bawri, are managing director and joint managing director respectively.
Did You Know?: Bawri and his two siblings live together with their families in the same building in Mumbai.

About_#1: Chao started Farglory Land, one of Taiwan's largest real estate developers, in 1978 and is still the largest shareholder.
About_#2: Farglory Land is the flagship unit of Farglory Group, whose interests include financial and retail services, air-cargo logistics and hospitality.
About_#3: Chao also controls Farglory FTZ Investment Holding, Farglory Life Insurance and Farglory Hotel.
About_#4: Eldest son Wen-Chia, also known as Frank, took over as Farglory Land chairman in 2014 amid a corruption scandal involving Chao.
Did You Know?: Born into poverty in western Taiwan, Chao moved to Taipei in 1966 and did odd jobs. He saved money to supply cement to construction firms.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Xiamen University
About_#1: Chen Zhisong is co-founder and chairman of Yealink Network Technology, a supplier of video conferencing solutions and Internet phones.
About_#2: Yealink Vice Chairman Wu Zhongyi is also a member of the 2019 Forbes China Rich List.
About_#3: Yealink is headquartered in the eastern Chinese city of Xiamen.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Korea University; Master of Science, University of Chicago
About_#1: Chey Tae-won chairs the SK Group, Korea's third-largest conglomerate with interests in telecom, semiconductors, chemicals and energy, among others.
About_#2: The group's SK Telecom is South Korea's No. 1 mobile carrier; its SK Hynix is the country's second-largest chip maker.
About_#3: In 2013 he was convicted of misappropriating company funds but was later pardoned by then-president Park Geun-hye and returned to his post in 2016.
About_#4: Chey is a nephew of SK Group founder Chey Jong-gun, who started the conglomerate with a textile company called Sunkyong.
Did You Know?: While in jail he authored a book on social enterprises.

About_#1: Hotel tycoon Choo Chong Ngen made his fortune in textiles before launching his Hotel 81 budget chain in Geylang, Singapore's red-light district.
About_#2: He has expanded into the mid-tier market, introducing five more hotel brands since 2009.
About_#3: His privately held hotel empire, which daughter Carolyn has been helping him run since 2002, has 38 hotels across the island.
About_#4: Since 2017, he has expanded into Thailand, Malaysia and Australia with seven hotels managed by Travelodge and Holiday Inn.
Did You Know?: He dropped out of school to become a fishmonger to help make ends meet at home.
In Their Own Words: I'm 100% hands on, not 99%.

About_#1: John Coates is the co-CEO of U.K. company Bet365, one of the world's largest online gambling businesses.
About_#2: He joined his billionaire sister and co-CEO, Denise, in 2001 to launch Bet365 after she sold some of their father's betting shops.
About_#3: Bet365 has since become a global player, with over 53 million customers across 200 countries; John owns a quarter of the firm.
About_#4: In July 2015, he became the vice chairman of English Premier League's Stoke City Football Club, in which Bet365 has a majority stake.
Did You Know?: Coates studied law at Bristol University and started his career as an attorney.

About_#1: Alexandra Daitch owns an estimated 3% stake in Cargill, the largest food company in the world.
About_#2: She's one of four billionaire sisters who inherited stakes in the company from their father W. Duncan MacMillan, who died in 2006.
About_#3: Her great-great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.
About_#4: The family still owns roughly 90% of Cargill, which did $114.6 billion in 2020sales across food, agriculture, financial and industrial divisions.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi
About_#1: Chetan Dube is the founder of New York City-based artificial intelligence company Amelia, whose flagship product is an eponymous chatbot.
About_#2: Amelia's conversational AI technology provides customer service for about 500 corporate clients, including Telefonica, BNP Paribas and Nordic Bank.
About_#3: Indian-born Dube moved to the United States after college to become an applied mathematics professor at New York University in 1992.
About_#4: He left academia and started Amelia as information technology firm IPSoft in 1998, growing it to about $100 million in revenue in 2020.

About_#1: Stockholm-born Daniel Ek is the cofounder and CEO of streaming music service Spotify.
About_#2: The company has more than 381 million users, 172 million of whom are paying subscribers.
About_#3: Via a dual-class share system Ek owns nearly 9% of the shares, but has 37% of voting control.
About_#4: Ek and his business parter Martin Lorentzon founded the company in 2006 in Sweden, and launched the product in 2008.
In Their Own Words: I'm not an inventor. I just want to make things better.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Princeton University; Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business
About_#1: John Fisher is the youngest of Gap founders Doris and Donald Fisher's three sons.
About_#2: He was appointed to Gap's board of directors in October 2018. His brothers Robert and William also sit on the board.
About_#3: John is a founding partner of investment firm Sansome Partners and sits on the board of the Silicon Schools Fund.
About_#4: He is a majority owner of the Oakland A's baseball team and has smaller stakes in MLS' San Jose Earthquakes and the Scottish Glasgow Celtic F.C.
Did You Know?: The three Fisher brothers attended Princeton University and went on to study at Stanford University's School of Business.

About_#1: Bernard Fraisse is the CEO of Fareva, one of the world's largest contract pharmaceutical, household and cosmetics companies.
About_#2: After getting his degree in mechanical engineering, Fraisse worked as a chemical salesman before starting his own business in 1990.
About_#3: The first year his company generated $4.5 million in revenue. In 2020, Fareva pulled in $2.1 billion in revenue.
About_#4: He refuses to take any private equity money and intends to keep the company in family hands and independent.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University; LLB, Stanford University
About_#1: William Franke is the chairman of low-cost carrier Frontier Airlines and the owner of air transport-focused private equity firm Indigo Partners.
About_#2: Raised in Latin America, Franke attended law school at Stanford and then worked as an executive at firms including Valley National Bank and Circle K.
About_#3: He first got into the airline business as the CEO of America West Airlines from 1993 to 2001, turning the company into a low-cost carrier.
About_#4: He was an early investor in Ryanair; since starting Indigo Partners in 2002, he's invested in several airlines including Volaris, Wizz Air, and Spirit.

About_#1: Caroline Hagen Kjos became chairman of her family's Canica AS holding company in 2014.
About_#2: The Swiss resident also received a majority stake in Canica at at that time.
About_#3: Her father, Norwegian billionaire Stein Erik Hagen, founded discount supermarket Rimi with his father in the 1970s.
About_#4: It merged with Sweden's ICA group in 1998 and later with Dutch retailer Ahold; Hagen eventually sold his stake, forming Canica AS with the proceeds.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Guangdong Medical College
About_#1: Lam Kong chairs Hong Kong-listed China Medical System, which distributes drugs to thousands of hospitals around the country.
About_#2: Lam founded the company in 1995, almost a decade after graduating from Zhanjiang Medical College.
About_#3: China Medical went public at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 2010.
About_#4: China Medical System is the largest shareholder in Shanghai-listed Tibet Rhodiola Pharmaceutical.

About_#1: Hans Langer is the world's first 3-D printing billionaire.
About_#2: Langer founded EOS, one of the earliest and most successful 3-D printing companies, more than 30 years ago.
About_#3: Daughter Marie Langer took over as CEO of the largest operating business, EOS GmbH, which makes 3D printers for polymers and metals, in October 2019.
About_#4: While others focused on consumers and 3-D printing, Langer always believed that the technology's true value was in industrial applications.
Did You Know?: Langer's first customer was BMW, which bet on EOS before it even had a product available.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford; Master of Arts/Science, Stanford
About_#1: Joe Lau cofounded Alchemy, whose software powers thousands of blockchain-based Web3 companies.
About_#2: Alchemy, founded in 2020, was valued by private investors at $10.2 billion in February; Lau owns an estimated 26% stake.
About_#3: In December 2021, the company announced the launch of Alchemy Ventures, which invests in current clients with the goal of bootstrapping the industry.
About_#4: Lau and cofounder Nikil Viswanathan, both Stanford grads, found initial success with meetup app Down to Lunch, briefly topping the Apple Store charts.

About_#1: Kevin David Lehmann owns 50% of Germany's leading drugstore chain, dm (drogerie markt), which brings in over $12 billion in annual revenue.
About_#2: The company got its start in 1973 when Goetz Werner opened his first shop in Karlsruhe, Germany. Today, dm has some 3,700 locations.
About_#3: In 1974, Kevin David Lehmann's father, Guenther, then running his family's Pfannkuch grocery chain, invested in dm.
About_#4: Guenther transferred ownership of his 50% dm stake to Kevin David in 2017.
Did You Know?: The dm philosophy, that ensuring employee well being brings greater long-term success for the company, is well known in German-speaking countries.

About_#1: After cashing out of palm oil giant Wilmar more than a decade ago, former stockbroker Peter Lim focused on property, healthcare and sports.
About_#2: Lim has consolidated his healthcare businesses in Singapore and Malaysia with his Singapore-listed Rowsley, renaming it Thomson Medical Group.
About_#3: Lim has opened a boutique luxury hotel in the heritage building of the Northern Stock Exchange in Manchester.
About_#4: Lim ventured into education in 2022, partnering with top British boarding school Wellington Colleges to set up international schools across Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore in the next few years.
Did You Know?: Lim, who once made a failed bid to buy English football club Liverpool, owns a controlling stake in Spanish football club Valencia.
In Their Own Words: At the end of the day the key component is the person. You may target the right company, but if you've chosen the wrong person, you'll get a headache.

About_#1: Sarah MacMillan owns an estimated 3% stake in Cargill, the largest food company in the world.
About_#2: She is one of four billionaire sisters who inherited stakes in the company from their father W. Duncan MacMillan, who died in 2006.
About_#3: Her great-great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.
About_#4: The family still owns roughly 90% of Cargill, which did $114.6 billion in 2020 sales across food, agriculture, financial and industrial divisions.

Education: Master of Business Administration, University of Scranton
About_#1: Politician's son Kalanithi Maran dabbled in his family's modest publishing business before launching Sun TV Network in 1993.
About_#2: Sun is now a regional television heavyweight with 33 channels reaching more than 95 million households in India.
About_#3: Sun's reach also extends to the South Indian diaspora in 27 countries around the world.
About_#4: Maran's other interests include newspapers, radio and direct-to-home television.
Did You Know?: Maran and his brother Dayanidhi, a former telecom minister, were embroiled in a telecom corruption case but were cleared of all charges.
In Their Own Words: I don't take competition lightly. Big or small, we nail them down before they can grow in size.

About_#1: In 1988 Lirio Parisotto founded Videolar, a video and audiotape company, invested the profits in the stock market and built a fortune.
About_#2: His portfolio runs the gamut from banking, electricity and mining to steel companies. He avoids IPOs and favors stocks that pay high dividends.
About_#3: In addition, he owns bonds, real estate, and a majority of Videolar, which merged with Innova to manufacture and market petrochemical products.
About_#4: Innova operates four high-tech industrial facilities: three in Brazil's Amazon region of Manaus and one in southern Brazil.
In Their Own Words: Everyone wants the market to go up. However, the big opportunities show up when the market falls. That's the truth.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Low-profile Rajan Raheja hails from the sprawling Raheja property clan in Mumbai.
About_#2: After a family split he went on to build a separate diversified empire that includes interests in cement, batteries and cable television.
About_#3: Raheja's biggest asset is listed auto battery maker Exide Industries.
About_#4: He also owns listed cable television unit Hathway Cable, in which Mukesh Ambani's Reliance Industries has a majority stake.

About_#1: Alberto Roemmers is the majority owner of Laboratorios Roemmers, Argentina's largest pharmaceutical company.
About_#2: The firm was founded in 1921 by his father, Alberto J. Roemmers, a German immigrant to Argentina.
About_#3: Laboratorios Roemmers, which is privately held, also has operations in Brazil, Uruguay and Mexico.
About_#4: It produces a variety of drugs, including antibiotics and anti-inflammatory treatments.
Did You Know?: A team owned by the Roemmers family won a 2015 world title in the prestigious 52 Super Series yacht racing competition.

Education: Law Degree, University of Witwatersrand
About_#1: Rodney Sacks is chairman and CEO of energy drink maker Monster Beverage Corporation.
About_#2: Sacks and Monster's co-CEO Hilton Schlosberg, are native South Africans. They bought the drink company Hansen Natural in 1992.
About_#3: Hansen's Natural launched the Monster brand energy drink in 2002, and the company changed its name to Monster Beverage in 2012.
About_#4: In June 2015 Coca-Cola bought a 16.7% stake in Monster Beverage for $2.15 billion in cash and opened its global distribution arm to Monster.
Did You Know?: Before his involvement at Monster, Sacks was a senior partner at Werksmans, one of the largest law firms in South Africa.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Boston College
About_#1: Dogus Holding, of which Ferit Sahenk is CEO, covers sectors ranging from tourism, real estate and media to financial services, construction and autos.
About_#2: Most of the fortune derives from Garanti Bank. His family sold its remaining 10% of Garanti to Spain's BBVA in 2017, bringing in $900 million.
About_#3: Dogus has invested $1.7 billion in Istanbul's Galataport. The project includes a cruise terminal, hotel, retail and restaurants.
About_#4: Lately, Dogus has been deleveraging. In 2020, it agreed to sell its 42% stake in high-end Istanbul shopping mail Istinye Park to Qatar Holding LLC.
Did You Know?: Ferit Sahenk came in first in the prestige sailing competition Les Voiles de Saint-Tropez in 2016 and placed second in 2017 in the Wally classification.
In Their Own Words: As a boss, it is not my job to call people to account. My job is to relay our vision to our managers, make sure we are on the same wavelength.

About_#1: Hilton Schlosberg and fellow billionaire Rodney Sacks run Monster Beverage, known for its energy drinks.
About_#2: The duo started off in 1990 by buying soda maker Hansen's Natural. Twelve years later, they introduced Monster Energy.
About_#3: In June 2015 Coca-Cola bought a 16.7% stake in Monster Beverage for $2.15 billion in cash and opened its global distribution arm to Monster.
About_#4: Coca-Cola and Monster went into arbitration in 2018 after Coca-Cola decided to develop two energy drinks. Coca-Cola ultimately won.

Education: Master of Business Administration, SDA Bocconi School of Management; Bachelor of Science, University of Turin
About_#1: Alberto Siccardi founded medical device company Medacta and became a billionaire after taking it public on the Swiss stock exchange in April 2019.
About_#2: The $429 million (sales) firm, based in Castel San Pietro, Switzerland, designs joint replacement and spinal surgery products.
About_#3: In the early 90s, Siccardi had a bad fall in the Swiss Alps and got a double hip replacement. Dissatisfied with the process, he founded Medacta.
About_#4: He and his three children share a two-thirds stake in Medacta, which accounts for the majority of the fortune.

About_#1: Salil Singhal is the chairman emeritus of PI Industries, a maker of plant protection and nutrient products.
About_#2: The company was founded by his father, P.P.Singhal, in 1946 to manufacture edible oils.
About_#3: Singhal's son, Mayank, is the CEO and has been involved with PI Industries since 1996.
Did You Know?: PI Industries started as Mewar Oil & General Mills in India's lake city of Udaipur.

About_#1: Lucy Stitzer chairs Waycrosse, the investment company of the Cargill and MacMillan families, one of the 10 richest clans in America.
About_#2: Stitzer owns an estimated 3% stake in Cargill, the largest food company in the world.
About_#3: She's one of four billionaire sisters who inherited stakes in the company from their father W. Duncan MacMillan, who died in 2006.
About_#4: Her great-great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Rheinisch-Westfälische Technische Hochschule, Aachen, Germany
About_#1: Otto Toto Sugiri is the cofounder and president director of DCI Indonesia.
About_#2: He started the company in 2011 and built it into Indonesia's largest operator of data centers.
About_#3: DCI Indonesia's shares have soared since its listing in January 2021.
About_#4: Prior to DCI, Sugiri founded PT Sigma Cipta Caraka in 1989, which was acquired by PT Telkom Indonesia and is now called Telkomsigma.

Education: Bachelor of Science, De La Salle University
About_#1: Harley Sy is the executive director of SM Investments, one of the country's largest conglomerates, which was founded by his late father Henry Sy.
About_#2: SM Investments has interests in everything from retail, banking, property and equity.
About_#3: He is the youngest of Henry Sy's six children and the fourth son.
About_#4: He also serves as a director of China Banking and as an adviser of BDO Private Bank.
Did You Know?: All of Henry Sy's four sons, including Harley, are graduates of De La Salle University.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Assumption College
About_#1: Teresita Sy-Coson is co-chairman of SM Investments, one of the country's largest conglomerates started by her late father Henry Sy.
About_#2: She is the eldest child and first daughter of the group's founder.
About_#3: Her SM experience spans retail merchandising, mall development, and banking.
About_#4: She also serves as the chairperson of BDO Unibank, a retail bank.
Did You Know?: Her father discouraged her from getting a masters and said, "Come work with me; it's the school of hard knocks."
In Their Own Words: I was not meant to lead the group. Even now I am not leading. I maintain the core.

About_#1: Real estate developer Katsumi Tada founded and chaired property developer Daito Trust Construction, which specialized in building rental apartments.
About_#2: In 2011, Tada stepped down as chairman and sold his stake back to the publicly traded company.
About_#3: He switched his focus to Australia, where he develops and owns office buildings, malls and hotels through his Daisho Co.
About_#4: Daisho has a portfolio of 10 properties in Japan and overseas, including in Tokyo, Okinawa, Sydney, Brisbane, Melbourne and Singapore.

About_#1: Tang Yiu founded footwear and sportswear retailer Belle International in 1981.
About_#2: Top brands in Belle's repertoire include Teenmix and Staccato.
About_#3: The company went public on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 2007.
About_#4: He took Belle private and sold his stake in April 2017, in a deal that valued the company at $6.8 billion.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business; Bachelor of Science, University of Wisconsin Madison
About_#1: Jeff Tangney cofounded Doximity, known as a "LinkedIn for Doctors," in 2010.
About_#2: Tangney, who is not a doctor, owns a 32.9% stake in the $207 million (2021 revenue) social media network.
About_#3: Around 80% of U.S. doctors (totaling 1.9 million) use Doximity -- the name is a mashup of doctor and proximity -- for professional networking.
About_#4: Tangney's first company, mobile medical reference app Epocrates, went public in 2011 and was later sold to Athenahealth for $293 million.
Did You Know?: Tangney's first job was a dishwasher at Pizza Hut.

About_#1: Lottie Tham owns more than 5% of cheap chic fashion retailer H&M.
About_#2: The company was founded by her late father Erling Persson in 1947, and her nephew Karl-Johan Persson is the current CEO.
About_#3: Her brother, Sweden's richest person Stefan Persson, is H&M's former CEO and chairman.
About_#4: Her nephew Tom Persson and niece Charlotte Söderström are also billionaires.

Education: EMBA, National Taiwan University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Tokai University
About_#1: Tsai's father, Tsai Wan-lin, built Cathay Life Insurance into a powerhouse and was Taiwan's richest person at the time of his 2004 death.
About_#2: Tsai struck out on his own in 2010, selling his shares in Cathay Financial Holding, Cathay Life's successor, to his brothers.
About_#3: These days Tsai makes real estate investments through Homax Equity.
About_#4: He has a collection of cars and art, including at least one Monet.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Moscow State Technical University
About_#1: Timur Turlov is the CEO and founder of Freedom Holding, a Kazakhstan-based retail brokerage; it operates in Central Asia, Europe and the U.S.
About_#2: Freedom Holding gives post-Soviet citizens access to the U.S., Russian and European stock exchanges and specializes in IPOs.
About_#3: The company entered the U.S. in 2015 through a shell of a Kazakh oil and gas exploration entity located in Nevada.
About_#4: Freedom Holding began trading on the Nasdaq in 2019, an event that Turlov calls his proudest accomplishment to date.

Education: Master of Business Administration, SUNY Albany
About_#1: Hamdi Ulukaya, known as the yogurt king, is the founder of America's most popular Greek yogurt brand, Chobani.
About_#2: Ulukaya grew up in a Kurdish dairy-farming family in Turkey and raised sheep. He eventually left to study political science at Ankara University.
About_#3: He immigrated to the U.S. in 1994 to study English in upstate New York, an area that reminded him of the small farming villages in Eastern Turkey.
About_#4: With a loan from the Small Business Administration, he bought an old yogurt plant there in 2005 and developed a recipe inspired by his heritage.
Did You Know?: In January 2018, Ulukaya married Louise Vongerichten, daughter of world-renowned French chef Jean Georges Vongerichten. The couple welcomed a son later that year.
In Their Own Words: You cannot do everything alone--especially when you get to a certain level. It is impossible.

About_#1: From a single location opened in 1985, Peter Unger built his namesake auto parts and repair outfit Auto-Teile-Unger (A.T.U.) into a nationwide chain.
About_#2: In 2002, he sold 72% of the company for $900 million. Two years later, he sold his remaining stake for $360 million.
About_#3: Residing in Bavaria, Unger now invests in listed companies, startups and both residential and commercial real estate throughout Germany.
About_#4: Investments include food hygiene company aquagroup, a bike center focused on electric bicycles, and sensor technology startup Tacerion.
Did You Know?: In Berlin, where he also has commercial real estate, Unger has either purchased or invested in the construction of thousands of apartments with partner Groth Gruppe.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford; Master of Arts/Science, Stanford
About_#1: Nikil Viswanathan cofounded Alchemy, whose software powers thousands of blockchain-based Web3 companies.
About_#2: Alchemy, founded in 2020, was valued by private investors at $10.2 billion in February 2022; Viswanathan owns an estimated 26% stake.
About_#3: In December 2021, the company announced the launch of Alchemy Ventures, which invests in current clients with the goal of bootstrapping the industry.
About_#4: Viswanathan and cofounder Joe Lau, both Stanford grads, found initial success with meetup app Down to Lunch, briefly topping the Apple Store charts.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Texas A&M University
About_#1: Anthony Wood is the founder and CEO of Roku, a tech company that lets users stream content on their TVs.
About_#2: He launched Roku in 2002 after selling his previous business, ReplayTV, to SONICblue.
About_#3: Roku now has more than 51 million customers who streamed nearly 59 billion hours of content in 2020.
About_#4: Wood was always making things, building tree houses in elementary school and writing software in high school.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harbin Engineering University; Master of Science, Harbin Institute of Technology
About_#1: Zhang Hongwei chairs United Energy Group, an independent exploration and production company.
About_#2: United Energy made several acquisitions in 2018 including buying Kuwait Energy for a reported $650 million and snapping up more assets in Pakistan.
About_#3: Zhang has 30 years of experience in management in China.
About_#4: His daughter Zhang Meiying is an executive director at the listed company.

About_#1: Zhang Li co-chairs real estate developer Guangzhou R&F with Hong Kong billionaire Li Sze Lim; the duo founded the company in 1994.
About_#2: The developer has properties in 28 cities, mostly in China, but also in foreign markets like Johor, Malaysia and San Jose, California.
About_#3: Zhang once worked in Guangzhou as the Secretary of Youth League Committee of Guangzhou 2nd Light Industry Bureau, as well as a hotel manager.
About_#4: Zhang also owns a stake in Hong Kong-listed Kinetic Mines and Energy, a company he founded with son Johnson in 2006.

Education: Master of Science, Oxford University
About_#1: Alex Beard retired as head of worldwide oil operations at commodities trader and mining giant Glencore in 2019.
About_#2: Beard, who had worked at Glencore since 1995, is based in London and was the highest-ranking Glencore executive in the UK.
About_#3: Before he left, Beard owned a 2.5% stake in the firm, which has assets in oil, gas, agriculture and mining globally.
About_#4: Prior to joining Glencore, Beard spent five years as an oil trader at BP.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Columbia Business School; LLB, University of Witwatersrand
About_#1: Koos Bekker is revered for transforming South African newspaper publisher Naspers into an e-commerce investor and cable TV powerhouse.
About_#2: He led Naspers to pay a reported $34 million for a third of Chinese Internet firm Tencent Holdings in 2001--perhaps the greatest venture investment ever.
About_#3: In 2019, Naspers put some assets into two publicly-traded companies, entertainment firm MultiChoice Group and Prosus, which contains the Tencent stake
About_#4: Naspers sold a 2% stake in Tencent in 2018; in April 2021 Prosus sold nearly $15 billion worth of Tencent, taking its stake to 29%.
Did You Know?: His Babylonstoren estate, nearly 600 acres in South Africa's Western Cape region, features architecture dating back to 1690, a farm, orchard and vineyard and more.

About_#1: Bill Boyd cofounded Boyd Gaming Corporation with his father, Sam Boyd, in 1975.
About_#2: He took over as CEO of the company after his father passed away in 1993 and served in that role until 2008.
About_#3: He still serves as executive chairman and owns around 17% of the company.
About_#4: Today, Boyd Gaming Corporation has 28 properties in ten different states.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Oregon
About_#1: Timothy Boyle is chairman and CEO of Columbia Sportswear.
About_#2: The business started as Columbia Hat Company in Portland, founded in 1938 by Boyle's grandparents, who had fled Nazi Germany for the U.S.
About_#3: Boyle started working at the family business as a college senior, helping his mother run the company after his father's death in 1971.
About_#4: He is the largest shareholder and has served as CEO for over three decades, steering the company to $2.5 billion in sales.
Did You Know?: Boyle's mother Gert took charge of the family business as a 46-year-old housewife with three kids. She served as chairman for nearly 50 years until she died in 2019.
In Their Own Words: "We understand, from personal experience, what it means when government leaders demonize any group as being inferior, unworthy, and fundamentally unwelcome to be a part of a country."

Education: Master of Science, University of Kansas; Ph.D, University of Kansas
About_#1: Anand Burman is the fifth-generation scion of the storied Burman clan.
About_#2: After more than a decade, he stepped down as chairman of the family company Dabur, India's fourth-largest consumer goods company, in July 2019.
About_#3: His wealth is mostly derived from his stake in the Delhi-headquartered company, known for its hair oil, fruit juices and health supplements.
About_#4: He also has stakes in Kolkata-based dry-cell battery maker Eveready and New Delhi-based financial services group Religare.
Did You Know?: Burman has invested in his personal capacity in home healthcare services, cancer diagnostics and life sciences.

About_#1: A native of New Zealand, Richard Chandler relocated to Singapore in 2006 where he now runs Clermont Group, his personal investment outfit.
About_#2: Clermont's portfolio includes interests in healthcare, financial services and aerospace.
About_#3: Clermont has stakes in SBFC, an Indian provider of small business loans, and Hoan My, a healthcare group in Vietnam.
About_#4: His Clermont Aerospace owns MagniX, an aviation engineering firm and a controlling stake in Eviation, an Israeli maker of light electric aircraft.

About_#1: R.G. Chandramogan, a college dropout, started a tiny venture in 1970 to make ice cream.
About_#2: Today, his listed Hatsun Agro Product, which he chairs, is one of India's largest private dairy companies by sales.
About_#3: Every day Hatsun gets milk directly from more than 400,000 farmers spread across 10,000 villages.
About_#4: Hatsun also exports dairy ingredients to 42 countries.

Education: Doctorate, Seoul National University
About_#1: Cho Young-sik is the founder of SD Biosensor, which is best-known for its rapid Covid-19 test called Standard Q.
About_#2: SD Biosensor listed on the Korea Exchange in July 2021, raising some $650 million.
About_#3: In late 2020, the Slovakian government bought 13 million Covid-19 tests from SD Biosensor, enough to test its entire population twice over.
About_#4: Before the pandemic, SD Biosensor made most of its money from blood glucose monitoring devices.

About_#1: Chu Lam Yiu is co-chairman of fragrances and tobacco flavoring supplier Huabao International Holdings.
About_#2: She founded the company in 1996 and took it public in Hong Kong through a "backdoor listing" a decade later.
About_#3: She is currently a member of the Fifth Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference Committee (Shenzhen, Guangdong province).
About_#4: Chu's son Lam Ka Yu became co-chairman in June 2021.

About_#1: Kommer Damen's father and uncle started building boats in a shed next to the family home in the Dutch town of Hardinxveld-Giessendam in 1922.
About_#2: Five years later, they founded Damen Shipyards in 1927.
About_#3: He bought the shipyard from his father in 1969 and brought the modular shipbuilding concept to the construction of small boats and launches.
About_#4: Damen Group is now one of Europe's largest family-owned shipbuilders, generating $2.4 billion in sales worldwide in 2020.
Did You Know?: Damen Shipyards worked with four other companies to develop the world's first 3D printed ship propeller, the WAAMpeller; it was unveiled in late 2017.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Denver
About_#1: Henry Davis is a third-generation beef supplier who owns $1.7 billion (annual revenues) Greater Omaha Packing.
About_#2: His beef is now eaten in 69 countries, including some of the world's top restaurants from Napa Valley's French Laundry to New York's Marea.
About_#3: His Greater Omaha is the fifth-largest beef producer in the U.S., after giants Tyson, Cargill, JBS and National Beef.
About_#4: Davis' grandfather started in 1920, butchering a single steer every day and selling the beef himself. Davis inherited it in 1987 and grew it 10-fold.
Did You Know?: Davis races cars on the side. He owns the first American race car to win at the legendary Le Mans course, a 1966 Ford GT40.

Education: Master of Business Administration, LeTourneau University's School of Business
About_#1: Ray Davis and fellow billionaire Kelcy Warren founded natural gas distributor and pipeline company Energy Transfer in 1995 and built it into a giant.
About_#2: Davis stepped down as co-CEO in 2007 but still owns 3% of the listed company.
About_#3: In 2017, despite protests by the Standing Rock Sioux tribe, Energy Transfer finished building the $3.8 billion Dakota Access Pipeline.
About_#4: Energy Transfer Partners says the 1,172-mile pipeline can transport 500,000 barrels of oil daily.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Princeton University
About_#1: Stephen Feinberg cofounded private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management in 1992.
About_#2: Under Feinberg's leadership, Cerberus has generated some excellent returns, and some abysmal PR.
About_#3: The firm attracted negative attention in 2013 for its stake in Freedom Group, which manufactured the rifle used in the Sandy Hook massacre.
About_#4: Cerberus has recently achieved more success with its investment in grocery chain Albertsons and its global real estate funds.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Boston University
About_#1: Kenneth Feld owns live entertainment company Feld Entertainment, the parent company of Disney on Ice, Monster Jam and other shows.
About_#2: Feld Entertainment grew out of Ringling Bros. circus, which was shut down in 2017 due to falling ticket sales.
About_#3: His father, Irvin, bought Ringling Bros. circus in 1967 for $8 million.
About_#4: Kenneth Feld took over in 1984 following his father's death.
Did You Know?: While Feld remains CEO, he's preparing his three daughters to succeed him as ringmaster.
In Their Own Words: My goal was to grow, and that wasn't always consistent with what everyone else in the company wanted to do.

Education: Ph.D, Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology
About_#1: Alexander Frolov is chief executive of multinational steel company Evraz, in which he holds a nearly 10% stake.
About_#2: He and his partner, Alexander Abramov, sold a 40% stake in Evraz to billionaire Roman Abramovich in 2006 for more than $3 billion.
About_#3: He also has stakes in Norilsk Nickel, Ivi and Renessans Insurance.
Did You Know?: Frolov, who has a doctorate in physics and mathematics, got his start working as a research fellow at the I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Catholic University of the Sacred Heart
About_#1: Mario Germano Giuliani is a healthcare investor who owns a 6% stake in Royalty Pharma, the world's largest acquirer of pharmaceutical royalties.
About_#2: Royalty Pharma went public in 2020 and has collected revenue slices of blockbuster drugs like Humira, Imbruvica, Lyrica and Xtandi.
About_#3: Mario and his brother Giammaria also own stakes in Swiss investment company HBM Healthcare Investments and a number of biotech firms in the U.S.
About_#4: The brothers share ownership of their family's pharmaceutical company, Giuliani, founded by their great-grandfather Germano in Milan, Italy in 1889.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Laval University
About_#1: Serge Godin is chairman of Canadian tech firm CGI Group, which he founded in 1976 at age 26.
About_#2: One of nine children, Godin started working for his father (who had just a fifth-grade education) at the family's sawmill at age 12.
About_#3: He studied computer science and got an MBA from Quebec's Université Laval, then worked in consulting before using $5,000 in savings to start CGI.
About_#4: Godin serves as chairman of the $9.1 billion (revenues) company; he was president and CEO until 2006.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Columbia University
About_#1: Noam Gottesman cofounded hedge fund GLG Partners in 1995, which started out as a subsidiary of Lehman Brothers.
About_#2: GLG went public in 2007 and was sold to Man Group for $1.6 billion in 2010. Gottesman stepped down as CEO at the time of the sale.
About_#3: In 2014, Gottesman cofounded Nomad Foods, which is today Europe's largest frozen food company.
About_#4: Gottesman's art collection has hundreds of works including pieces by Andy Warhol, Francis Bacon and Lucian Freud.
Did You Know?: Gottesman invested in Eleven Madison Park in 2011; six years later it was named the best restaurant in the world by one publication.

About_#1: Philip and Cristina Green own Topshop, Topman, Dorothy Perkins, Miss Selfridge and other British retailers through their Arcadia Group.
About_#2: The Greens have been vilified in Britain for their role in letting their home retailer, BHS, collapse, which put pensions for 19,000 workers at risk.
About_#3: In 2016, Parliament voted to strip Green of his knighthood over a pension deficit scandal. However, he is still a knight; the vote was symbolic.
About_#4: In 2018, Philip stopped a newspaper from publishing its report on its investigation into allegations of his sexual harassment and bullying.
Did You Know?: A college drop-out, Philip started his first business at age 21, importing jeans from Asia with a $30,000 loan from his family.

Education: Doctorate, University of Cambridge
About_#1: Yusuf Hamied is the non-executive chairman of $2.6 billion (revenue) generics maker Cipla.
About_#2: Cipla was founded in 1935 by his father Khwaja Abdul Hamied, a disciple of Mahatma Gandhi.
About_#3: After the patriarch passed away in 1972, Cambridge-educated Hamied and his brother Mustafa inherited the business.
About_#4: Hamied took on big pharmaceutical companies, offering low-cost generic drugs for diseases such as AIDS, earning the label of drug pirate.
Did You Know?: His niece Samina Hamied is Cipla's executive vice-chairman.
In Their Own Words: I've done more humanitarian work than Bill Gates and Warren Buffett put together.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Emory University
About_#1: Former Tennessee governor Bill Haslam was the president of his family's chain of truck stops, Pilot Flying J, for four years until 1999.
About_#2: His father bought a gas station in Virginia in 1958 and founded Pilot Flying J, which now operates in more than 800 locations in North America.
About_#3: Berkshire Hathaway paid a reported $2.8 billion for 39% of Pilot in 2017 and will acquire another 41% by 2023.
About_#4: Haslam was elected the mayor of Knoxville in 2003 and became governor of Tennessee in 2010. He left office in 2019.

Education: Master of Science, University of Saarland
About_#1: One of five cofounders of SAP, Hans-Werner Hector built up the software giant's North American business.
About_#2: In 1996, he transferred to a Jersey Islands trust SAP shares representing more than 10% of the company's voting rights.
About_#3: When the shares were put up for sale, Hector's partners worried that their control of SAP could come under threat.
About_#4: Hector wanted to diversify his portfolio for tax and money-management purposes, but the resulting rift led to him leaving SAP in 1997.
Did You Know?: In 2008, Hector established the Hector Science Fund at Karlsruhe Institute of Technology with a gift of 200 million euros ($290 million at exchange rates prevailing at the time).

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Kiev Polytechnic Institute
About_#1: Ho Hung Anh is chairman of Techcombank, a large commercial bank in Vietnam that went public in June 2018.
About_#2: Ho and fellow billionaire Nguyen Dang Quang, whom he met while studying in Russia, are two close business partners whose interests are intertwined.
About_#3: Ho started investing in Techcombank, in which Nguyen was already an investor, in 1995. They took control in 2006.
About_#4: Together they control two big listed companies, Masan Group and Techcombank, a commercial bank, through Masan JSC, a holding company that they co-own.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Notre Dame University; Master of Arts, Notre Dame University
About_#1: Hsu chairs the Far Eastern Group, a conglomerate that his father started in China in 1940 as an underwear supplier.
About_#2: The company moved to Taiwan in 1949 after the civil war.
About_#3: Far Eastern's businesses include Far EasTone Telecommunications, U-Ming Marine Transport, Everest Textile, Asia Cement and Oriental Union Chemical.
About_#4: Hsu is a trustee emeritus at the University of Notre Dame, where he earned two degrees.

About_#1: Erman Ilicak's Ronesans Holding, founded in 1993, operates as construction contractor and real estate developer in 28 countries.
About_#2: In July 2016, he sold 5% of Ronesans to IFC, a World Bank institution, in a deal that valued the company at $4.3 billion.
About_#3: Construction firm acquisitions include the Swiss Hergiswill and German Heitcamp in 2013, and the Netherlands' Ballast Nedam in 2015.
About_#4: In a public-private partnership with the Turkish government, Ronesans has so far built healthcare complexes with a contract value of $3.4 billion.
Did You Know?: A basketball player during his years at TED high school, Ilicak served as president of the TED Ankara Sports Club from 2014 to 2016.
In Their Own Words: Entrepreneurship was always on my mind. I had many unsuccessful attempts during my university years. Even when I was working as a professional, I knew I would become an entrepreneur.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, California Institute of Technology; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Pomona College; Master of Science, University of California, San Diego; Ph.D, University of California, San Diego
About_#1: Osman Kibar is the founder and CEO of San Diego-based biotech firm Samumed.
About_#2: Samumed raised $438 million in August 2018 to further its work developing drugs to reverse aging, claiming a valuation of $12.4 billion.
About_#3: The names of investors in the round were not disclosed.
About_#4: While getting a Ph.D. from the University of California, San Diego, he founded two companies, but did not have a management role at either.
Did You Know?: Kibar was born in Izmir, Turkey, on the Aegean Coast and met most of his fellow Samumed executives at boarding school in Istanbul.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Stanford University
About_#1: Adam Kwok's father, Thomas, is the second-oldest son of the founder of Sun Hung Kai Properties, the largest developer in Hong Kong.
About_#2: Thomas was the company's co-chairman from 2011 until 2014, when he was sentenced to five years in prison for bribing a government official.
About_#3: In Thomas's absence, Adam has served as an executive director at the company.
Did You Know?: Four of Adam's cousins are also billionaires, along with his father, an uncle and grandmother.

Education: Doctorate, Harvard University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
About_#1: Frank Laukien is the chairman and CEO of Bruker Corp., a scientific instruments manufacturer headquartered in Billerica, Massachusetts.
About_#2: His father, physics professor Gunther Laukien, founded the company in 1960.
About_#3: The firm initially specialized in magnets and power supplies; now it produces a variety of imaging machines and microscopes, among others.
About_#4: The company is publicly traded; Frank Laukien owns a 25.4% stake.

About_#1: Louis Le Duff got his start when he opened a combined restaurant-bakery in a Quebec ski resort while studying abroad for his MBA.
About_#2: In 1976, he took the concept back to France and opened the first Brioche Dorée bakery in Brittany with just $2,000.
About_#3: Groupe Le Duff operates more than 1,250 bakery and restaurant locations, including La Madeleine French eateries chain in the U.S. and Del Arte in France.
About_#4: His restaurants now feed 1 million customers every day across 100 countries.

About_#1: Solomon Lew chairs Melbourne-based Premier Investments, an apparel retailer.
About_#2: The company is the largest shareholder in Australian department store Myer and home appliance maker Breville.
About_#3: Premier's brands also include the Smiggle stationery store franchise, aimed at children and sleepwear label Peter Alexander.
Did You Know?: Lew says he always had an entrepreneurial mindset, working in retail after school and during holidays before opening his first apparel business on his 18th birthday.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Nankai University
About_#1: Liang Rubo is the CEO of ByteDance, the China internet giant that owns TikTok.
About_#2: Liang was a cofounder along with Zhang Yiming, who stepped down as CEO in 2021.
About_#3: The two reportedly were college roommates at Nankai University in China.
About_#4: ByteDance is most known for its news app Toutiao as well as social video app TikTok; its shareholders include Sequoia Capital China.

About_#1: Thailand's coffee king Prayudh Mahagitsiri's Quality Coffee Products is a long-standing joint venture with Nestle.
About_#2: With a 60% market share, Quality Coffee has been cashing in on the country's rising coffee culture.
About_#3: Prayudh also has interests in steel, copper, shipping, offshore drilling and property development.
About_#4: His son Chalermchai, a Boston University grad, is CEO of holding outfit PM Group.
Did You Know?: Prayudh's grandfather emigrated from southern China to Thailand, where he began trading foodstuffs and later imported Japanese-made tuk-tuks.
In Their Own Words: When you have stake in a company it's your baby. You have to take more care of your baby. It's your blood in it.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Ohio Northern University
About_#1: In 1970, after ditching his job as an accountant at the Campbell Soup Company, Clayton Mathile became employee number six at pet food maker Iams.
About_#2: Mathile bought Iams in 1982, when it had $13 million in sales.
About_#3: He ran the business for 17 years, until P&G acquired it from him in 1999 for $2.3 billion.
About_#4: In 2008 he spent $130 million to start Aileron, a Dayton-based school that offers management training for small business owners.
Did You Know?: Mathile was born on a farm in Ohio, starred on his high school basketball team and married a cheerleader from a rival school.
In Their Own Words: I have learned to welcome feedback as a gift, to appreciate it, to say thank you and give it proper consideration.

About_#1: Erwin Franz Mueller owns an eponymous drugstore chain with some 880 stores across seven European countries and annual revenue of around $4.8 billion.
About_#2: The business dates to 1953, when Mueller opened a hairdressing shop in his home in Ulm, Germany.
About_#3: In recent years, working conditions at his drugstores have been the subject of scrutiny in media reports.
About_#4: In 2016, German authorities stopped court proceedings against Mueller involving him having concealed assets in Swiss private bank J. Safra Sarasin.
Did You Know?: Mueller is believed to own at least $1 billion of real estate assets, including a house and a golf course in Mallorca.

Education: Drop Out, High School
About_#1: David Murdock is the former chairman of Dole Food Products.
About_#2: He stepped down from Dole's board in 2021 ahead of the company's IPO after over 35 years in charge.
About_#3: After a stint in the army during World War II, he made a small profit buying and selling a diner; later, he developed property in Arizona.
About_#4: Through Castle & Cooke holdings, he owns a collection of residential and commercial properties in Arizona, California, and Hawaii.
Did You Know?: Murdock has vowed to live until age 125 and has donated heavily to longevity research.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Polytechnic School of the University of Sao Paulo
About_#1: Rubens Ometto Silveira Mello became the world's first ethanol billionaire in 2007. Cosan, his sugar giant, is listed on the New York Stock Exchange.
About_#2: The company's origins date to 1936, when Ometto's grandparents established a sugarcane mill in Sao Paulo.
About_#3: After several takeovers, Cosan became one of the world's largest growers and processors of sugarcane and one of the largest producers of ethanol.
About_#4: Besides his Cosan shares, Ometto also holds a portfolio of real estate investments.
In Their Own Words: We have to recognize merits where they are, and stop complaining about what could have been better.

About_#1: In 1957, Erik Paulsson, then 17, and his younger brother Mats founded a waste management company to service the local farmers in the south of Sweden.
About_#2: The company, later named PEAB, expanded to construction in 1970, the industry it's known for today.
About_#3: While Mats and his family still control the company, Erik has divested into spin-offs of several PEAB property management entities.
About_#4: His most valuable holdings are Fabege, Catena and Wihlborgs Fastigheter, all real estate companies traded on the Stockholm stock exchange.
Did You Know?: In deciding who would get what in the division of PEAB, Paulsson and his brother reportedly flipped a coin.

About_#1: Heloise Pratt is the sister of fellow billionaires Anthony Pratt and Fiona Geminder.
About_#2: The three siblings hold stakes in the Melbourne family's Visy Asia-Pacific packaging business.
About_#3: Heloise also built Thorney Investments with her now-separated husband, Alex Waislitz.
About_#4: The firm holds stakes in more than 20 listed companies, ranging from gas and mining services to renewable energy, biotech and airline bookings.

About_#1: The eponymous company Dirk Rossmann founded at age 25 is now Germany's second-largest drugstore chain, with annual revenues of around $12.5 billion.
About_#2: In 1972, he opened Germany's first self-service drugstore in Hannover just as price deregulation of pharmacy products was beginning.
About_#3: Rossmann has made numerous private equity investments and owns a stake in the German Bundesliga soccer club Hannover 96.
About_#4: Shunning many trappings of wealth, he enjoys writing. He published an autobiography in 2018 and a novel, The Ninth Arm of the Octopus, in 2020.
Did You Know?: Rossmann been married to his wife Alice for more than 30 years and his two sons, Daniel and Raoul, hold managerial roles at the company.
In Their Own Words: I'm trying to show what I stand for as a family entrepreneur.

About_#1: Karin Schick inherited a stake in Bechtle AG from her father, Gerhard, who co-founded the IT company in Heilbronn, Germany in 1983.
About_#2: Bechtle covers the IT landscape, ranging from expert strategy advice to managed services that can take over complete operation of a company's systems.
About_#3: The company has more than 12,000 employees and revenues exceeding $6.5 billion.
About_#4: Bechtle's strong growth in the IT space has been fueled in part through an aggressive M&A strategy (more than 100 acquisitions since 1993).
Did You Know?: Karin Schick stepped down from Bechtle's advisory board in 2017 to focus on social projects through the Schick family foundation.

Education: Doctorate, University of Zurich
About_#1: Stephan Schmidheiny's fortune dates back to 1912 when his grand-uncle founded a business that eventually became a giant in building materials.
About_#2: Schmidheiny became board president of his father's construction materials company Swiss Eternit Group in 1976 at age 29.
About_#3: When his father Max divided the estate in 1984, Stephan inherited Eternit while brother Thomas got cement and concrete supplier Holcim.
About_#4: In 2003 Schmidheiny placed $1 billion in business assets into a charitable trust that helps entrepreneurs across both Central and South America.
In Their Own Words: I continue to give because it has been a profoundly rewarding experience, because I keep learning about the needs and potential of the people and the dynamics of development.

About_#1: Sun Mengquan chairs Shandong-based cooking oil company Luhua Group.
About_#2: Sun began working for the predecessor of Luhua in 1983, when it was a nearly bankrupt metals trading collective with fewer than 10 workers.
About_#3: Sun shifted the company's business to processing and exporting peanuts, and, later, into peanut oil.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Hamilton College
About_#1: Former film financier and founder of production company Legendary Entertainment, Thomas Tull's biggest hits came from backing blockbusters.
About_#2: In January 2015, Tull inked a deal with Chinese billionaire Wang Jianlin's Wanda Group to buy Legendary for up to $3.5 billion in cash, stock and debt.
About_#3: Tull stepped down as CEO of Legendary in January 2016 to concentrate on his Tull Investment Group which has invested in the likes of Magic Leap.
About_#4: His new investment holding company, Tulco, holds stakes in publicly traded medical apparel startup Figs and insurance brokerage Acrisure.
Did You Know?: Tull was born to a single mother in Binghamton, New York and grew up poor.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Brown University
About_#1: When Turner was 12, he worked for his father's billboard company, Turner Advertising.
About_#2: After his father died in 1963, he took control of the business, then rebranded the firm as Turner Broadcasting.
About_#3: He sold Turner to Time Warner for $7.3 billion in stock in 1996 and, after Time Warner bought AOL in 2001, saw his fortune tumble as shares dropped.
About_#4: Turner is America's second-largest individual landowner, with roughly 2 million acres. He also owns 45,000 bison and ranches in Argentina.
Did You Know?: Turner owns a more than 29,000-acre estate in Florida called Avalon Plantation. He married actress Jane Fonda there in 1991.
In Their Own Words: If you're working to help others or make the world better you'll be a lot happier than if all you're doing is trying to make things better for yourself...Because the real greatest joy and satisfaction of all, I think, is helping others.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Virginia
About_#1: David Walentas founded Two Trees Management, which is best known for transforming two Brooklyn neighborhoods, Dumbo and Williamsburg.
About_#2: Walentas owns over two dozen residential and commercial properties across Dumbo, Brooklyn Heights, Williamsburg and Manhattan.
About_#3: In the 1970s he borrowed $12 million to buy 2 million square feet of industrial buildings in an unpopular part of Brooklyn that later became Dumbo.
About_#4: He acquired the Domino Sugar refinery's 11 acres in Brooklyn for $185.5 million in 2012 and is remaking it; the first tower opened in 2017.
Did You Know?: Walentas grew up poor in Rochester, New York, milking cows and shoveling manure on a farm.
In Their Own Words: I just wanted to be a real estate developer. I was attracted to the ability to build stuff, to collect rent, to own it.

About_#1: Xu Yingzhuo is cofounder and director of Guangdong Haid Group, a supplier of aquatic products.
About_#2: Xu holds degrees from South China University and an MBA from HEC Paris.
About_#3: Guangdong Haid Group went public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2009.

About_#1: Christoph Zeller inherited dental products company Ivoclar Vivadent AG and was CEO from 1990 to 2003.
About_#2: Zeller's grandfather bought the company, which is headquartered in Schaan, Liechtenstein, in 1948.
About_#3: Zeller stepped down as chairman in 2019 but continues to serve on the supervisory board of the company.
About_#4: Ivoclar Vivadent has subsidiaries in 30 countries, employs more than 3,500 people and generates annual revenue in excess of $900 million.

Residence: Turks and Caicos Islands, Turks and Caicos Islands
About_#1: Michael Ashcroft's fortune comes from buying and selling a number of companies, most notably home security giant ADT.
About_#2: He purchased ADT in 1987 then flipped it to Tyco International in 1997 for $6.7 billion; proceeds from the sale still form the bulk of his fortune.
About_#3: A longtime Conservative Party supporter, he served as deputy chairman from 2005 to 2010, and stepped down from the House of Lords in March 2015.
About_#4: Ashcroft is also a major investor in Belize and previously served as the Belizean Ambassador to the United Nations from 1998 to 2000.
Did You Know?: In 2015 he released "Call Me Dave", a scathing unauthorized biography of Prime Minister David Cameron that included salacious allegations of drug use and snobbery.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University
About_#1: Alex Atallah is Chief Technology Officer of OpenSea, a marketplace for nonfungible tokens--digital assets that represent real world objects, like art.
About_#2: He cofounded New York-based OpenSea in 2018 with CEO Devin Finzer.
About_#3: Atallah and Finzer became the first NFT billionaires in January 2021, after a funding round that valued their company at $13.3 billion.
About_#4: He was born in Colorado to a Colombian-immigrant father and American mother.

About_#1: Brett Blundy is the former chairman of BB Retail, selling jewelry, lingerie and homewares.
About_#2: He sold some property and retail interests in three IPOs. He's now building a beef cattle empire in northern Australia to feed Asian demand.
About_#3: He has joined with cattle-station owners in Australia's Northern Territory to fund water supply, enabling properties to carry larger herds.
About_#4: In 2010, he cofounded fast fashion jewelry retailer Lovisa, which has over 270 stores worldwide.
Did You Know?: Blundy's interest in business started early. He grew up on a small farm near Melbourne where he and his four siblings would pick mushrooms to sell from a roadside stall for five cents a pound.
In Their Own Words: I'm biased towards using your own energy, your own activity, taking care of yourself, making your own decisions.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Tulane University
About_#1: Chris Britt cofounded San Francisco startup Chime in 2013 as a mobile banking app and debit card with no monthly fees.
About_#2: In September 2020, Chime raised $485 million in funding at a $14.5 billion valuation, nearly tripling its value in six months.
About_#3: During the pandemic, one of Chime's most popular features was a stimulus advance--it let users borrow $1,200 before the government checks arrived.
About_#4: It took Chime five years to reach one million customer accounts. One year later, in 2019, it had four million.

Education: Bachelor of Commerce, Delhi University; Chartered Accountant, Institute of Chartered Accountants of India
About_#1: Yadu Hari Dalmia and the family of his late sibling Jai Hari Dalmia control the Dalmia Bharat Group.
About_#2: He and his brother inherited stakes in the group from his father Jaidayal Dalmia, who set it up in 1939. His brother Jai Hari passed away in July 2021.
About_#3: Listed Dalmia Bharat is the fourth-largest cement producer in the country, with 14 factories.
About_#4: The group also has an interest in sugar through Dalmia Bharat Sugar.
Did You Know?: The cement company sells limited edition art pieces made from cement.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Jinan University
About_#1: Du Weimin is the chairman of Shenzhen Kangtai Biological Products.
About_#2: Kangtai researches, develops, manufactures and sells various vaccinations.
About_#3: Du was born in 1963 in China, but is now a resident of Hong Kong.
About_#4: Du holds a MBA from Jinan University.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Brown University
About_#1: Devin Finzer is CEO of OpenSea, a marketplace for nonfungible tokens--digital assets that represent real-world objects like art.
About_#2: He cofounded New York-based OpenSea in 2018 with Chief Technology Officer Alex Atallah; each of them own an estimated 18% stake.
About_#3: Finzer and Atallah became the first NFT billionaires in January 2021, after private investors valued their company at $13.3 billion.
About_#4: Finzer worked as a software engineer at Pinterest; he sold his first startup, Claimdog, to Credit Karma in 2015 for an undisclosed sum.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Reed College
About_#1: Robert Friedland founded and chairs Toronto-listed Ivanhoe Mines, a leader in the mining and precious metals industry.
About_#2: Based in Singapore, Friedland is praised for finding profitable mines in remote areas like Oyu Tolgoi in Mongolia.
About_#3: A graduate of Reed College, Friedland also funds Ivanhoe Capital Corporation, which invests in emerging markets.
About_#4: He also has a stake in Australia-listed CleanTeQ Holdings, which supplies cobalt and nickel to lithium-ion battery producers.
Did You Know?: Friedland's son Govind is a geologist and founder of uranium mining outfit GoviEx Uranium.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania; Medical Doctor, Yeshiva U Albert Einstein College of Medicine
About_#1: A long-time health care investor, inventor and founder, Phillip Frost now runs diagnostics-maker Opko Health.
About_#2: Frost joined Key Pharmaceuticals in 1972, reformulated its asthma drug and sold the company in 1986 for $836 million.
About_#3: Frost founded Ivax, a generic drugmaker, in 1987. He sold it to Teva Pharmaceuticals for $7.6 billion in 2005.
About_#4: In 2018, the SEC accused him of participating in a "pump-and-dump" scheme that generated over $27 million from unlawful stock sales.
Did You Know?: Born during the Great Depression, Frost is the third son of a shoe-store owner from South Philadelphia.
In Their Own Words: I was interested in a specialty that would permit me the time to reflect...I knew that surgery could never be for me because you're tied up in operating rooms most of the time. And I needed the freedom to do things.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Dartmouth College
About_#1: Gundlach is the cofounder of mutual fund company, DoubleLine Capital, which manages more than $140 billion in assets.
About_#2: The bond-trader extraordinaire is known for his bold calls and correctly predicted the housing crash in 2007.
About_#3: He previously helped build the fixed-income business at TCW, before he was fired in 2009.
About_#4: He is an avid modern art collector and owns works by artists including Warhol, Mondrian and de Kooning.
Did You Know?: Gundlach used to be the drummer in a punk rock band.

Education: Master of Business Administration, University of Notre Dame
About_#1: John Hancock is the eldest child of Australia's richest woman, Gina Rinehart.
About_#2: Together with his three sisters, Bianca, Hope and Ginia, he is the beneficiary of a trust that owns a large stake in mining giant Hancock Prospecting.
About_#3: He is involved in a bitter court battle to take control of the trust from his mother and potentially increase their stake.
About_#4: He is a senior adviser at Lind Partners LLC. He also runs his own private investment fund.
Did You Know?: He changed his surname from Rinehart to Hancock at age 27, after his grandfather, mining mogul Lang Hancock.
In Their Own Words: When your back's up against the wall, you just have to come out fighting.

About_#1: Georg Haub derives his fortune from Tengelmann Group, which began with a shop opened in Muelheim an der Ruhr in 1876.
About_#2: Its operations include home-improvement chain OBI; clothing and non-food discounter KiK; and online retailer babymarkt.de.
About_#3: The group also invests in startups and is active in services (energy, plus audits and consulting), property management and real estate development.
About_#4: Oldest brother Karl-Erivan had taken over as CEO after father Erivan Haub died in early 2018. Then Karl-Erivan went missing while on a ski tour.

About_#1: Hortensia Herrero owns nearly 28% of Mercadona, the Spanish supermarket chain she helped build with her husband Juan Roig (also a billionaire).
About_#2: Herrero, who serves as vice president, was part of the group that bought the company from Roig's father back in 1981, when it had 8 small stores.
About_#3: Herrero and Roig's four daughters are board members of Mercadona; Roig's brother Fernando is also a shareholder and billionaire.
About_#4: Mercadona, which is privately owned, has just over 1600 stores, mostly in Spain, and employs 95,000 people.
Did You Know?: She met Juan Roig at the University of Valencia, where both studied economics.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Southern California
About_#1: B. Wayne Hughes Jr. was born into the self-storage business; his father, B. Wayne Hughes (d. 2021), cofounded Public Storage in 1972.
About_#2: Hughes Jr. worked at Public Storage for almost two decades, starting in 1983.
About_#3: He was vice president of acquisitions from 1992 to 2002 and served on the board until late 2020.
About_#4: In 2005 he launched American Commercial Equities, a real estate company that acquires and manages properties in Hawaii and California.
Did You Know?: Hughes Jr. is the founder of Serving USA, a nonprofit that helps military families, victims of crime and former inmates rebuild their lives.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Duke University; Doctor of Jurisprudence, University of Virginia
