About_#1: Bruce Karsh runs Los Angeles-based private equity firm Oaktree Capital Management with longtime partner Howard Marks; they founded it in 1995.
About_#2: In September 2019, Brookfield Asset Management acquired 61% of Oaktree for roughly $4.9 billion in cash and stock.
About_#3: A leading debt investor, Oaktree manages over $150 billion in assets, two thirds of which is invested in corporate or distressed debt.
About_#4: Karsh still runs the company, which went public in 2012 and continues to operate independently, as co-chairman and CFO.
Did You Know?: Karsh, a rock-and-roll memorabilia collector, owns the rights to the Beatles' movie "A Hard Day's Night," and co-owns the rights to "Help!"

About_#1: Shlomo Kramer is cofounder and CEO of Cato Networks, a cloud security startup valued at $2.5 billion.
About_#2: He cofounded Check Point Software, a firewall security pioneer, with fellow Israelis Gil Shwed and Marius Nacht in 1993. Check Point went public in 1996.
About_#3: Kramer cofounded data security company Imperva in 2002; it went public in 2011 and was acquired by Thoma Bravo in 2019 for about $2.1 billion.
About_#4: Kramer was an early investor and board member at cybersecurity company Palo Alto Networks, founded by former Check Point employee Nir Zuk.

Education: Bachelor of Business Administration, Cornell University
About_#1: Jonathan Kwok is the younger son of the late Walter Kwok, former chairman of Hong Kong's largest developer, Sun Hung Kai Properties.
About_#2: Walter died on Oct. 20, 2018 at age 68. He had been ousted as company chairman in 2008 in a feud with his two brothers, Thomas and Raymond.
About_#3: After his death, Jonathan and his brother, Geoffrey, took over Empire Group Holdings, a property developer that Walter started after he left SHKP.
About_#4: The brothers inherited Walter's direct stake in SHKP and are named beneficiaries of one-third of five large family trusts held by their grandmother.

About_#1: Christian Latouche is the founder, owner and CEO of Fiducial SA, a global accounting firm with $2 billion in annual revenue.
About_#2: A trained auditor and CPA, in 1970 Latouche bought a small accounting business in southern France.
About_#3: Through acquisitions, he eventually grew it into Fiducial, an accounting and business services giant.
About_#4: The company has 1,230 offices globally and employs more than 21,000 people.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Kellogg School of Management; Master of Science in Engineering, Stanford University; Bachelor of Science in Engineering, University of Michigan
About_#1: Martin Lau is the president of Chinese internet giant Tencent.
About_#2: He became a billionaire for the first time in 2017 after Tencent shares jumped by a third over the previous year.
About_#3: Beijing-born Lau grew up in Hong Kong and was educated in the U.S. He left Goldman Sachs to join Tencent as chief strategy and investment officer in 2005.
About_#4: Growth of Tencent slowed down significantly in 2021 as the company was hit on multiple fronts by China's regulatory crackdown on tech companies.
Did You Know?: Lau was once nicknamed the 'Salary King' for making his fortune as an employee rather than a founder.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, South China University of Technology
About_#1: Li Wa spent the first 5 years of his career, back in the mid 1980s, working for the Communist Party's Youth League.
About_#2: He got into the real estate business in 1992, and his Excellence Group has developed both commercial and residential buildings in 14 Chinese cities.
About_#3: Li's brother Li Xiaoping is a vice president at Excellence Group.
About_#4: Li Wa owns 95% of Cayman Islands-registered Excellence Real Estate Group.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Fudan University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Fudan University
About_#1: Liang Xinjun is a former vice chairman and CEO of conglomerate Fosun International.
About_#2: Fosun's investments range from steelmaking to mining, tourism and pharmaceuticals.
About_#3: Fellow Fosun cofounders Guo Guangchang and Wang Qunbin are also billionaires.

About_#1: Lin is the widow of real estate mogul Lin Rong San. She resigned as chairman of 100%-family-owned property developer Union Enterprise Construction in 2021.
About_#2: Lin Rong San died in 2015 and left a $4.2 billion fortune built on real estate developments and investments in northern Taiwan.
About_#3: Eldest son Jeff Lin runs the publicly traded Union Bank of Taiwan, which was started by his father.
About_#4: Second son Andy Lin runs the group's media outlets, including Chinese-language newspaper Liberty Times and its sister English-language Taipei Times.
Did You Know?: Lin Chang Su-O also chairs her late husband's Lin Rong San Foundation of Culture and Social Welfare.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Trinity University of San Antonio
About_#1: Daniel Lubetzky is founder and majority owner of snack bar company Kind Healthy Snacks.
About_#2: Founded in 2004, Kind's most popular items are its bars with whole nuts, which come in 24 flavors. The company has sold 2 billion bars to date
About_#3: Mars, the candy conglomerate behind M&Ms and Snickers, bought an estimated 40% stake in Kind in 2017 for an undisclosed amount.
About_#4: Prior to Kind, Lubetzky started PeaceWorks, a marketing, consulting and distribution company, in 1994.
Did You Know?: While in high school and college, Lubetzky purchased watches wholesale and sold them at a markup at flea markets and shopping mall kiosks.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Howard Marks is the cofounder and co-chairman of Oaktree Capital Management, a Los Angeles-based distressed debt investor.
About_#2: Marks began his career at Citibank, where he started a portfolio of high-yield bonds after meeting with junk bond king Michael Milken.
About_#3: He became an asset manager at TCW, where he met Oaktree cofounder Bruce Karsh. The duo left with four colleagues in 1995 to found their own shop.
About_#4: In September 2019, Brookfield Asset Management acquired 61% of Oaktree for about $4.9 billion in cash and stock. Marks now sits on Brookfield's board.
Did You Know?: Marks is known for his highly detailed investment memos, which cover everything from cryptocurrency to index investing.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University
About_#1: Wireless pioneer Craig McCaw and his brothers took over their dad's cable-TV business in 1966.
About_#2: They sold McCaw Cellular to AT&T in 1994 for $12.6 billion in stock.
About_#3: McCaw, with backing from Bill Gates and Boeing, cofounded Teledesic in 1990 to provide internet access via satellite. It ceased operations in 2002.
About_#4: He has stayed out of the limelight since stepping down as chairman of telecom operator Clearwire in 2010, two years before it was acquired by Sprint.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, East Carolina University
About_#1: Vince McMahon is chairman and CEO of entertainment company World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE), which hauls in nearly $1 billion in annual revenue.
About_#2: A third generation wrestling promoter, McMahon grew up in a trailer park in North Carolina and joined his father's small wrestling company in 1972.
About_#3: McMahon purchased the business 10 years later, then transformed the World Wrestling Federation from a regional operation into a global phenomenon.
About_#4: WWF (now called WWE) went public in 1999; today its programs are broadcast in roughly 150 countries and more than 30 languages.
Did You Know?: His wife, Linda, led the Small Business Administration from 2017 to 2019, under President Trump.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Tsinghua University; Master, Tsinghua University
About_#1: Mu Rongjun is a cofounder, an executive director and a senior vice president at Yelp-like Meituan Dianping.
About_#2: Mu debuted on the China Rich List in 2018 after the company went public in Hong Kong that year with of valuation of more than $50 billion.
About_#3: Mu holds degrees from China's prestigious Tsinghua University.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Brown University; Master of Business Administration, Harvard University
About_#1: Jonathan Nelson is the executive chairman of Providence Equity Partners, the private equity firm he founded in 1989. He was CEO until January 2021.
About_#2: Providence has invested in more than 170 companies, many in the media, communications, education and information industries.
About_#3: The firm sold scuba-diving certification company PADI in 2017 for over $700 million, three times its initial investment.
About_#4: In 2021, Providence sextupled its 2007 investment of $300 million in video game developer ZeniMax Media, which Microsoft acquired for $7.5 billion.
Did You Know?: In college, Nelson worked for a commercial radio station where he broadcast the "Jazz After Hours" program.

About_#1: Bianca Rinehart is the eldest daughter of Australian mining magnate Gina Rinehart and is a trustee of the Hope Margaret Hancock Trust.
About_#2: She replaced her mother as trustee in 2015, after a lengthy court battle.
About_#3: The trust owns nearly a quarter of Gina Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting, on behalf of her four children.
About_#4: She has a degree in hospitality and hotel management from Flinders University in Adelaide.
Did You Know?: She worked briefly at global miner Rio Tinto. Her job included driving a huge haul truck.
In Their Own Words: I am pleased that as a result of this judgment, the trust he [grandfather Lang Hancock] set up will now be able to be managed in the best interests of its beneficiaries: my sisters, my brother and myself.

About_#1: Ginia Rinehart is the youngest child of Australian mining mogul Gina Rinehart.
About_#2: Together with her three siblings, she is the beneficiary of a trust that owns a substantial stake in mining giant Hancock Prospecting.
About_#3: She stayed out of a bitter court battle to wrest control of the trust from her mother.
About_#4: She has a degree in business, majoring in Spanish, from London.
Did You Know?: She once worked as a publicist at the House of Faberge in London.
In Their Own Words: It is very painful to have my family's disagreement argued so publicly in the Supreme Court. My loving and hard-working mother has only ever wanted the best for her children.

About_#1: The wealthiest woman in Turkey, Filiz Sahenk manages the fashion and tourism components of family conglomerate Dogus Holding.
About_#2: Brands that Dogus represents in Turkey include Gucci, Emporio Armani, Loro Piana, Informal and Tod's.
About_#3: Most of the fortune derives from Garanti Bank. The family sold its remaining 10% of Garanti to Spain's BBVA in 2017, bringing in $900 million.
About_#4: Today, besides branded clothing and tourism, Dogus is active in real estate, media, financial services, construction, autos and restaurants.
Did You Know?: Filiz oversees a foundation established in the name of her father, Ayhen Sahenk. The founder of Dogus, he died of a heart attack in 2001.

Education: Master of Science, Boston University
About_#1: Infosys cofounder S.D. Shibulal oversees his family office, Innovations Investment Management.
About_#2: While he stepped down as the company's CEO in 2014, he continues to hold a small stake in the firm.
About_#3: Shibulal cofounded business incubator Axilor Ventures together with former Infosys colleague Senapathy Gopalakrishnan.
About_#4: He also chairs The Tamara, a boutique resort chain, which his daughter Shruti founded and runs.
Did You Know?: Along with wife, Kumari, he donates regularly to various causes through two family foundations.

Education: Master of Science, Moscow Institute of Electronic Technology
About_#1: Alexander Svetakov is one of the biggest property owners in the Moscow region, with most of his land in New Moscow.
About_#2: Svetakov got his start importing electronics from Asia.
About_#3: He sold one of his earlier businesses, Absolut bank, in 2007 for $1.4 billion, then a record for Russia's banking sector.
About_#4: Today his investment group Absolut has businesses in everything from real estate to caviar extraction.
Did You Know?: Svetakov enjoys surfing and tennis, and has built tennis courts in Zhukovka cottage village.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: Jeffrey Talpins runs Element Capital Management, a hedge fund firm that specializes in macro trading and has almost $50 billion under management.
About_#2: Element has been one of the best performing hedge funds since it was founded in 2005, posting annualized returns in excess of 20%.
About_#3: A former Citigroup and Goldman Sachs trader, Talpins invests across bonds, currencies and stocks.
About_#4: Even by hedge fund standards, Talpins is exceptionally secretive and is careful to avoid any publicity.

About_#1: Indian-born Singapore resident Arvind Tiku has interests in property and renewable energy, held through his privately held AT Holdings.
About_#2: Tiku left India at age 18 to study mechanical engineering in Russia and worked as a commodities trader before getting into oil and gas in Kazakhstan.
About_#3: He also owns stakes in Prime US REIT and IREIT Global, both listed in Singapore and owning commercial properties in the U.S. and Europe.
About_#4: Tiku is developing residential and commercial real estate in the Netherlands and in north India.
Did You Know?: Tiku, who has a private jet, prefers using Uber on overseas business trips.

About_#1: Visiting the U.S. in the late 1980s, Torsten Toeller encountered pet supply superstores and decided the concept deserved a try in his native Germany.
About_#2: When he opened his first Fressnapf store in 1990, in Erkelenz, customers were initially unimpressed with his selection and prices.
About_#3: Toeller doubled down by selling his car to raise cash, invested in more inventory and went for broke with aggressive discounts.
About_#4: The gamble paid off, and in 1992 Fressnapf Tiernahrungs GmbH began opening franchise stores, paving the way for rapid growth.
Did You Know?: Toeller has invested in an office building project called Mercator One in Duisburg, close to the company's headquarters in Krefeld.

About_#1: Riaz Valani was a general partner at Global Asset Capital, LLC and the first person to invest in electronic cigarette manufacturer Juul.
About_#2: Valani invested a few million dollars in Juul during its early years, giving him an estimated 20% stake in the company.
About_#3: When tobacco giant Altria bought a 35% stake in Juul in 2018, Valani reportedly got a pre-tax $2.6 billion dividend payout, according to a book about Juul.
About_#4: In November 2020, Valani spent $40 million on a Malibu estate formerly owned by Johnny Carson.

About_#1: Pieter van der Does is the cofounder and CEO of Adyen, an Amsterdam-based payment processing company.
About_#2: He owns a 3 percent stake in the company, which went public in June 2018.
About_#3: He started Ayden in 2006 with fellow billionaire Arnout Schuijff, who retired from his role as chief technology officer in 2020.
About_#4: Schuijff and van der Does first worked together in 2000 at e-commerce platform Bibit.
Did You Know?: van der Does is an avid rock climber and mountaineer.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: Lang Walker is executive chairman and cofounder of Walker Corp., which owns office towers, industrial estates and residential projects.
About_#2: The property developer has been in the industry for more than half a century and has had multiple successes.
About_#3: He sold the bulk of Walker Corp. twice - in 1999 before the dot-com bust and in 2006 before the financial crisis, after which he rebuilt the company.
About_#4: Walker owns a fleet of yachts, all called Kokomo; it's the name he's used for every boat he's owned but one.
Did You Know?: Walker bought a 140-acre private island in Fiji in 2011 and spent millions fixing it up.

About_#1: Hope Welker is the third child of Australian mining billionaire Gina Rinehart.
About_#2: Together with her three siblings, she is the beneficiary of a trust that owns a large stake in mining giant Hancock Prospecting.
About_#3: She joined, then withdrew, from a court battle waged by her siblings to remove their mother as trustee.
Did You Know?: In 2011, she told her mother she was down to her last $60,000.
In Their Own Words: I don't think you [Gina Rinehart] understand what it means now that the whole world thinks you're going to be wealthier than Bill Gates.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, University of Detroit Mercy
About_#1: William Young is CEO of plastic container maker Plastipak, which does about $3 billion in annual sales.
About_#2: Young and his father founded Plastipak in 1967, shortly after he graduated from the University of Detroit Mercy with an engineering degree
About_#3: After six years of running the business, the duo sold the majority to Beatrice Foods for an undisclosed amount.
About_#4: In 1982, the family bought back Plastipak; three decades later, they sold a minority stake to a division of Goldman Sachs.
Did You Know?: Plastipak holds over 600 U.S. patents for package design and manufacturing processes.
In Their Own Words: It's all about driving home the sense of purpose, and our purpose is delivering great products and service to our customers. The great work you do today is going to set the company up for more success tomorrow.

About_#1: Bill and Jean Adderley founded home furnishings retailer Dunelm after setting up a market stall in Leicester, U.K. in 1979.
About_#2: There are now 173 Dunelm stores across the U.K.
About_#3: They took the company public on the London Stock Exchange in 2006.
About_#4: The Adderleys own 43% of the business, most of which is held by the couple's son, Will Adderley, who is Dunelm's deputy chairman.

About_#1: Mohamed Al Fayed was born in Alexandria, Egypt and moved in the mid-1960s to the U.K., where he made his fortune.
About_#2: He's best known for being the one-time owner of London department store Harrod's, which he sold to Qatar for a reported $2.4 billion in 2010.
About_#3: He owns the storied Ritz Paris hotel. After a four-year renovation, it reopened in 2016. Suites are named after illustrious guests, like Coco Chanel.
About_#4: In 2013, Al Fayed sold Fulham Football Club to U.S. auto parts billionaire Shahid Khan for a reported $300 million.
Did You Know?: Al Fayed's son Dodi died in a car crash with Princess Diana in 1997.

About_#1: Faisal Bin Qassim Al Thani is the chairman of Al Faisal Holding, one of Qatar's biggest conglomerates, which he founded in 1964.
About_#2: It owns more than 20 hotels around the world, including the St. Regis in Washington, D.C. and Miami, and the W Hotel in London.
About_#3: Al Faisal Holding also has a majority stake in publicly-traded Aamal, which owns real estate in Qatar and sells medical supplies and pharmaceuticals.
About_#4: Al Thani started selling car parts in Doha at age 16. He became the sole distributor of Bridgestone tires in the 1960s.
Did You Know?: Al Thani is a distant relative of the Qatari royal family.

About_#1: Masaaki Arai is the founder and chairman of Tokyo property developer and agent Open House Co.
About_#2: His company focuses on providing homes for people in bigger Japanese cities such as Tokyo. Its motto is "Let's find a house in Tokyo."
About_#3: The company was founded in 1997 and went public in 2013.
About_#4: It has sold more than 60,000 homes in the Tokyo metro area.

Education: Bachelor of Science, State University of Management
About_#1: Tatyana Bakalchuk, a former English teacher and mother of four, founded e-commerce retailer Wildberries in 2004.
About_#2: She founded the business at age 28 in her Moscow apartment while on maternity leave.
About_#3: Her husband, Vladislav, an IT technician, soon joined her.
About_#4: In the early years, she resold clothes from German retailer Otto.
Did You Know?: Wildberries processes roughly 400,000 orders a day.

Education: Master of Business Administration, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: In 1959 Lee Bass and his three brothers inherited $2.8 million each from oil tycoon uncle Sid Richardson.
About_#2: The brothers parlayed their inheritance into multi-billion dollar fortunes with the help of bets on oil that paid off big.
About_#3: In early 2017 the four Bass brothers sold their oil company to ExxonMobil for $5.6 billion in stock. Future payouts could total another $1 billion.
About_#4: Bass owns El Coyote and La Paloma ranches in deep south Texas, where he raises longhorn cattle.
Did You Know?: Avid conservationists, the Basses have funded efforts to reintroduce the Aplomado falcon in Texas.

About_#1: Alberto Bombassei chairs Brembo, a global leader in high-performance braking technology.
About_#2: Brembo's brakes can be found in Ferraris, Corvettes and Harley-Davidsons around the world.
About_#3: Founded by Alberto's father Emilio, Brembo broke into the big leagues in 1975, when Enzo Ferrari asked Emilio to outfit his race cars.
About_#4: Alberto became general manager of the company in 1976, managing director in 1984 and was chairman from 1993 to 2021.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University
About_#1: One of Facebook's first venture investors, Jim Breyer made much of his fortune investing in the social network.
About_#2: Breyer is the brother-in-law of U.S. senator Mitch McConnell and his wife, former transportation secretary Secretary Elaine Chao.
About_#3: After 28 years at venture firm Accel Partners, Breyer now invests through his own Breyer Capital and is betting big on artificial intelligence.
About_#4: He has invested in over 40 companies that have had successful IPOs or mergers, including Etsy, Marvel Entertainment and Legendary Entertainment.
Did You Know?: Breyer, whose parents fled Hungary, spent his early years living in a funeral home in New Haven because it was the cheapest place to live while his dad went to Yale.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: The son of a grocer, Ron Burkle started working at the market at age 13.
About_#2: He formed investment firm Yucaipa in 1986 and bagged big returns buying and selling supermarket chains Fred Meyer, Jurgensen's, Ralphs and others.
About_#3: Burkle primarily invests in private companies that support the food trade, in areas like logistics, cold storage and food safety.
About_#4: He has invested in tech firms including Airbnb, Uber and Foursquare, failed movie production firm Relativity Media, and the NHL's Pittsburgh Penguins.
Did You Know?: Burkle bought Jesse Owens' 1936 Olympic gold medal at auction for $1.5 million in 2013.

About_#1: Chen Huwen is the chairman and a co-founder of Shanghai M&G Stationary Inc.
About_#2: M&G Stationary was founded in 1996.
About_#3: Chen holds an EMBA degree and has been involved in stationery manufacturing since 1997.

About_#1: Chen Huxiong is the vice chairman and president of Shanghai M&G Stationary Inc.
About_#2: M&G Stationary was founded in 1996.
About_#3: Chen's brother Chen Huwen is M&G's chairman and a fellow billionaire.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, National Cheng Kung University
About_#1: Cheng founded Taiwan Delta as a TV-parts maker in 1971; he built it into a supplier of switches and power suppliers to global brands such as Dell.
About_#2: He stepped down as Delta's leader in 2012 but remained as director, the same year his son Ping became CEO.
About_#3: Apple is Delta's largest customer.

About_#1: Ryan Cohen is the former CEO of online pets supplies store Chewy, which he cofounded in 2011.
About_#2: Cohen grew the business to $3.5 billion in annual revenues and stepped down in 2018 after selling it to PetSmart for $3.4 billion in 2017.
About_#3: At the end of 2020, Cohen spent about $76 million buying a 13% stake in GameStop while urging management to restructure the ailing brick-and-mortar.
About_#4: He joined GameStop's board in January 2021 and his fortune surged that month after Reddit traders coordinated a massive surge in the stock's price.

About_#1: Dermot Desmond started his career in finance at Citibank, and later worked for the Investment Bank of Ireland and PricewaterhouseCoopers.
About_#2: In 1981 he founded NCB Stockbrokers, which became Ireland's largest independent brokerage; he sold it for $39 million in 1994.
About_#3: With the proceeds, Desmond started his own private equity firm, International Investment & Underwriting.
About_#4: IIU now has stakes in travel software firm Datalex, Mountain Province Diamonds, Barchester Healthcare and Glasgow soccer club Celtic PLC.
Did You Know?: An avid golfer, he's known as "The Kaiser" for his distinctive mustache.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Duke Univeristy
About_#1: Fred Ehrsam founded cryptocurrency exchange Coinbase in 2012 with Brian Armstrong. It has since grown into the largest U.S. crypto brokerage.
About_#2: Ehrsam left the company in 2017 but remains on the board and still owns about 6% of its stock; Coinbase went public in 2021.
About_#3: In 2018, he cofounded Paradigm, a cryptocurrency investment firm with more than $1 billion in assets.
About_#4: Ehrsam graduated from Duke and worked as a foreign exchange trader at Goldman Sachs for two years before starting Coinbase.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Politecnico di Torino
About_#1: John Elkann is the chairman and CEO of Exor, the holding company of Italy's Agnelli family, which owns stakes in Ferrari and Italian automaker Fiat.
About_#2: Elkann took the leadership role in the family and at Fiat in 2004, one year after the death of his grandfather and family patriarch Gianni Agnelli.
About_#3: He oversaw deals including FIAT's 2009 acquisition of a stake in Chrysler and its merger with Peugeot in January 2021 to form Stellantis.
About_#4: Exor's portfolio includes Italian football team Juventus and media organizations including the Economist and several leading Italian newspapers.
Did You Know?: Elkann was born in New York and went to high school in Paris; he reportedly speaks English, French, Italian and Portuguese.
In Their Own Words: "Our family has been in business for a long time and has overcome wars, revolutions, crises and pandemics."

About_#1: Bob Ell is the founder and executive chairman of Leda Holdings, which owns three shopping malls in Queensland and a fourth in Canberra.
About_#2: He also has large-scale residential land developments in Queensland and New South Wales, where he owns more than 12,000 housing lots.
About_#3: He started out in Sydney commercial and industrial property in the 1970s.
About_#4: Ell briefly listed Leda Holdings before taking it private in 1990. He has developed more than $3 billion worth of property.

About_#1: Lindsay Fox owns Linfox, Australia's biggest private logistics company, with more than 5,000 trucks across 10 countries in Asia Pacific.
About_#2: The company also owns a large industrial property portfolio, a half-share in a business park, two airports and currency-management outfit Armaguard.
About_#3: Fox is no longer involved in day-to-day operations, leaving management to his son Peter, who is executive chairman and runs the logistics business.
About_#4: His other sons Andrew and David run the property division and look after the airports respectively.
Did You Know?: Fox also owns historic Melbourne amusement park Luna Park, more than 100 vintage cars on display for the public, a race track and four homes.

Education: Drop Out, Santa Rosa Junior College
About_#1: Gary Friedman is the CEO and chairman of publicly traded high-end furniture retailer RH, which had $2.85 billion in revenue in 2020.
About_#2: He's credited with turning around the company formerly known as Restoration Hardware, which was at the brink of bankruptcy when he joined in 2001.
About_#3: The retail veteran started at Gap as a stock boy, eventually working his way up to managing 63 stores in southern California.
About_#4: He then spent 13 years at Williams-Sonoma Inc., where he took Pottery Barn from a $50 million tableware business to a $1 billion plus furniture brand.
Did You Know?: Friedman's dad died when he was 5 years old; he spent much of his childhood moving around with his mom, who had bipolar disorder and schizophrenia.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, San Francisco Conservatory of Music
About_#1: Gordon Getty, whose oil tycoon father J. Paul died in 1976, led the sale of his family's Getty Oil to Texaco for $10.1 billion in 1984.
About_#2: Once the sole trustee of the family trust, Getty orchestrated the breakup into six separate trusts in 1985.
About_#3: In 2015, Gordon's son Andrew died in his Beverly Hills mansion at age 47, reportedly due to medical issues and an unhealthy lifestyle.
About_#4: Getty is a classical music composer, whose compositions include the Canterville Ghost, Plump Jack, and Usher House.
Did You Know?: An opera and wine aficionado, Getty is a partner in Odette Estate winery in Napa Valley.

About_#1: Dennis Gillings is the founder and former CEO and chairman of clinical research firm Quintiles Transnational, which changed its name to IQVIA in 2017.
About_#2: Gillings, a former biostatistics professor, launched Quintiles in 1982 with the goal of making clinical trials for drugs faster and more efficient.
About_#3: Gillings retired from the board of IQVIA in April 2018. He still serves as a partner of healthcare-focused investment firm NovaQuest Capital.
About_#4: In November 2019, NovaQuest raised $275 million for its first private equity fund. The firm manages about $2.75 billion in assets.
Did You Know?: Gillings received a Commander of the Order of the British Empire from Queen Elizabeth in 2004 for his work in the pharmaceutical industry.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Calcutta University; Master of Business Administration, International Institute for Management and Development
About_#1: Harsh Goenka belongs to the fifth generation of a storied Indian business clan and chairs the $4 billion (revenue) RPG Group.
About_#2: RPG is named after the initials of Goenka's late father who divided the family empire between him and younger sibling Sanjiv.
About_#3: Key RPG companies include tire maker Ceat, which is run by Goenka's son Anant.
About_#4: Goenka's biggest asset is power transmission firm KEC International.
Did You Know?: Goenka is an avid art collector and has 1.6 million followers on Twitter.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, University of Melbourne
About_#1: David Hains owns hedge fund Portland House Group, which is now managed by three of his children.
About_#2: A former engineer, Hains stopped working for seven years in the late 1960s to improve his golf game with legendary Australian coach Norman Von Nida.
About_#3: He later became known for restructuring companies such as U.S. steelmaker Wheeling-Pittsburgh, and as a prominent racehorse breeder in Australia.
About_#4: Portland House's sole purpose is to manage the family's wealth.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Boston University
About_#1: Bahaa Hariri is the eldest son of slain Lebanese Prime Minister Rafik Hariri; he inherited his fortune from his father, who was a billionaire.
About_#2: In 2008, he sold his stake in Saudi Oger, the family construction business, to his brother Saad Hariri, a former prime minister of Lebanon.
About_#3: Bahaa Hariri founded and chairs Horizon Group, a real estate holding company with investments in Amman, Jordan and Beirut, Lebanon.
About_#4: He helped revitalize an area of Amman, called Abdali. The project, in partnership with the Jordanian government, is worth an estimated $5 billion.
Did You Know?: Hariri is a graduate of Boston University; he pledged $15 million to its Rafik Hariri Institute for Computing and Computational Science and Engineering.
In Their Own Words: My dream job: CEO of Apple. And what job would I hate to have? Well, what comes to mind is being the president of the U.S.

About_#1: Israeli investor Shmuel Harlap invested $10,000 in automotive tech startup Mobileye in 2001 and eventually acquired a 7.2% stake.
About_#2: In 2017, Intel purchased Mobileye for $15.3 billion in cash. Harlap netted $750 million from the deal, pushing him in to the billionaire ranks.
About_#3: He is also chairman and part owner of Colmobil, Israel's largest car importer, which his father acquired in 1962.
About_#4: Harlap continues to invest in Israeli startups, particularly in the cybersecurity, nanotechnology and life sciences industries.
Did You Know?: While Harlap was fighting in the Six-Day War, his father was persuading Mercedes-Benz to deliver 1,625 trucks to Israel to move supplies.

About_#1: Harvey cofounded and is the executive chairman of furniture and electrical-goods chain Harvey Norman.
About_#2: He also controls a property portfolio and owns the Magic Millions racehorse auction market.
About_#3: He describes his wife Katie Page, who runs Harvey Norman, as "the mastermind" of the operation.
About_#4: Page and Harvey's ex-wife Lynette Harvey also hold shares in the company.

Education: Master of Science, Oxford University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University
About_#1: Reid Hoffman cofounded professional networking site LinkedIn in 2003 and is a partner at venture capital firm Greylock Partners.
About_#2: In 2016, Hoffman sold LinkedIn to Microsoft for $26.2 billion in cash and joined Microsoft's board.
About_#3: He is an investor in Airbnb, which went public in December 2020, and autonomous driving pioneer Aurora, which acquired Uber's self-driving unit.
About_#4: Hoffman is part of the so-called "PayPal Mafia," and was one of the first employees at the payment company that was later sold to eBay.
Did You Know?: Hoffman was an early investor in Facebook; he put in $40,000 after introducing Peter Thiel to the startup in 2004.
In Their Own Words: Part of what we have here in Silicon Valley is this network of people talking to each other about the key lessons to learn. We believe in bringing entrepreneurial knowledge to the world.

About_#1: Hou Juncheng chairs Shanghai-listed Proya Cosmetics, a supplier of moisturizing and whitening skincare products.
About_#2: Most sales are from its own "Proya" brand for women aged 18 to 24 in small and medium sized cities.
About_#3: Hou founded Proya in 2006 as a distributor of local brands such as "Yue Sai" before starting his own product lines.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Stetson University
About_#1: Thomas James inherited and grew his fortune through financial services business Raymond James, which was started by his father, Robert, in 1962.
About_#2: He stepped down as Raymond James' chairman in 2017, having served for over 40 years. He was first made a board member at age 20.
About_#3: He is a graduate of Harvard College and Harvard Business School.
About_#4: He is an avid art collector. Part of his collection is on display at the James Museum of Western & Wildlife Art.

Education: High School Graduate, Arai High School
About_#1: Eiichi Kuriwada's father, Kiyoshi Sagawa, founded a package delivery firm in 1957; now called Sagawa Express, it's Japan's No. 2 delivery outfit.
About_#2: Sagawa Express parent SG Holdings listed its shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in December 2017.
About_#3: Kuriwada stepped down as president of SG Holdings in 2015 but remains chairman.
About_#4: Shares of the company soared on the back of a jump in online buying during the pandemic but have since declined.
Did You Know?: In the early 1990s, Sagawa Express was the focus of a scandal; an executive was convicted of paying off politicians.

About_#1: Kwek Leng Kee inherited a stake in Hong Leong Group from his father, Kwek Hong Khai, one of four brothers who cofounded the conglomerate.
About_#2: Singapore billionaires Kwek Leng Beng and Kwek Leng Peck are his cousins.
About_#3: He sits on the board of the family's Hong Leong Finance.
About_#4: Kwek is also assistant managing director of Hong Leong Holdings.

Education: EMBA, China Europe International Business School
About_#1: Lai Shixian is an executive director and chief financial officer at Anta Sports, China's largest sportswear company.
About_#2: Lai is the brother-in-law of fellow Anta billionaires and executive directors Ding Shizhong and Ding Shijia.
About_#3: Lai holds an EMBA from the China Europe International Business School.

About_#1: Lau Cho Kun is the largest shareholder in Hap Seng Consolidated, through holding company Gek Poh and investment arm Lei Shing Hong.
About_#2: The diversified firm's interests include financial services, plantations and property.
About_#3: Its plantation division is one of the largest producers of palm oil in Sabah, East Malaysia.
About_#4: Hap Seng Consolidated has been operating Mercedes-Benz dealerships in Malaysia since 1969.
Did You Know?: Yaw Chee Ming, CEO of Samling Strategic, a fellow rich lister, is his son-in-law.

Education: Master of Science, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Seoul National University
About_#1: Lee Hae-jin is a cofounder of Naver, South Korea's No. 1 search engine.
About_#2: In February 2018, he stepped down from Naver's board but remains its global investment officer, focusing on the company's expansion.
About_#3: In 2021, Naver and SoftBank agreed to a joint venture, taking control of their respective subsidiaries Line and Yahoo Japan.
Did You Know?: He started Naver while working at Samsung SDS in the late 1990s.

About_#1: Harald Link is the third-generation head of Thailand's storied B. Grimm group, with interests in power, real estate, transport and infrastructure.
About_#2: Founded in 1878 as Siam Dispensary, it was acquired by Link's grandfather Adolf Link in 1914.
About_#3: After studying in Switzerland and Germany, where he grew up, Link arrived in Bangkok in 1978 to join his uncle in the family firm.
About_#4: Chief executive since 1987, Link is grooming daughter Caroline to succeed him.
Did You Know?: Link is an avid polo player.

About_#1: Luo Yangyong chairs mining company Sichuan Anning Iron and Titanium.
About_#2: Anning listed on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in April 2020 in a $166 million IPO; the funds raised will be used to increase its production capacity.
About_#3: Luo worked as a cashier and construction team leader before he started his own business in the late 1990s.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Turkmen State University
About_#1: Igor Makarov is the founder of Itera, Russia's first independent gas company.
About_#2: In the late 1990s, Itera was Russia's main exporter of gas from Turkmenistan, where Makarov was born.
About_#3: In 2012 Itera entered into a joint venture with Rosneft, the state-controlled oil company; the next year, Rosneft bought out Itera for $2.9 billion.
About_#4: Makarov was appointed as an energy adviser to the president of Turkmenistan in 2019.

Education: Master of Laws, Moscow State University
About_#1: Alexander Mamut was trained as a lawyer but made his fortune as an investor.
About_#2: Over the years he's had stakes in a few banks, an insurance company, fertilzer producer and mobile phone chain.
About_#3: He was an owner of Rambler&Co, which unites several internet media projects including news site lenta.ru and politics and society site gazeta.ru.
About_#4: Mamut bought two of Russia's biggest movie chains, Cinema Park and Formula Kino, in 2017.
Did You Know?: In the 1990s, Mamut was close to Russian president Boris Yeltsin and was known as "the Yeltsin family banker."
In Their Own Words: I did not learn anything from other people's mistakes. I was able to learn from someone else's success.

Education: Master of Laws, Stockholm University
About_#1: David Mindus is the founder and CEO of Swedish commercial real estate company Sagax AB.
About_#2: Mindus and two partners began buying warehouses and light industrial properties around Stockholm in 2000 after identifying the sector as undervalued.
About_#3: Mindus owns more than 17 percent of Sagax, which listed on the Stockholm Stock Exchange in 2004.
About_#4: Its portfolio consists of more than 37 million square feet across 673 properties.

About_#1: Yuji Otsuka is the son of the late Minoru Otsuka, who founded Otsuka Corp. in 1961, a software developer and supplier of office copy machines.
About_#2: Yuji, a former banker, took over as CEO when Minoru retired in 2001.
About_#3: Otsuka's last reported annual revenue was $7.7 billion in 2020.

About_#1: The ebullient resources player and former member of the Australian Parliament, Clive Palmer became a billionaire in 2019.
About_#2: His fortune soared after a court ordered a flow of iron-ore royalties to his company, Mineralogy, to resume.
About_#3: He started Mineralogy in 1984 and has built a portfolio of iron-ore, thermal-coal and hydrocarbon assets.
About_#4: He also owned Queensland Nickel, which operated a nickel-and-cobalt refinery, but the company collapsed in 2016.

About_#1: Ajay Parekh is executive director of Pidilite Industries, a company founded by his late father, Balvant Parekh, in 1959.
About_#2: He has a minority stake in Pidilite, which is India's leading maker of adhesives and sealants.
About_#3: Older brother Madhukar Parekh, also a billionaire, chairs Pidilite.
About_#4: Pidilite's range of products includes construction chemicals, art materials and organic pigments.

About_#1: Narendrakumar Parekh is vice chairman of Pidilite Industries, a company founded by his late brother, Balvant Parekh, in 1959.
About_#2: He has a minority stake in Pidilite, which is India's leading maker of adhesives and sealants.
About_#3: His nephew, Madhukar Parekh, chairs the company while his son Apurva Parekh has a board seat.
About_#4: Pidilite's range of products includes construction chemicals, art materials and organic pigments.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Beijing University of Science and Technology; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Changchun College of Posts and Telecommunications
About_#1: Qi Xiangdong chairs Qi An Xin Technology Group, which supplies cybersecurity products and services to government and businesses.
About_#2: Qi An Xin listed on China's STAR Market in July 2020.
About_#3: He founded the company in 2014.
About_#4: Earlier, Qi cofounded 360 Security Technology with fellow China billionaire Zhou Hongyi.

About_#1: Ren Jianhua chairs Shenzhen-listed kitchen appliance maker Hangzhou Robam Appliances.
About_#2: The company claims its products, which include range hoods, microwaves and gas stoves, are in over 35 million households.
About_#3: It was founded in 1979 and its first generation range hood, created by Robam and the deepartment of aeronautics and astronautics, came out in 1987.
About_#4: Ren borrowed $5.4 million at the end of 1998 to take control of the company.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, Berkeley
About_#1: With $720 in savings, Alice Schwartz and her husband David launched Bio-Rad Laboratories in a Berkeley Quonset hut in 1952.
About_#2: Early products included ion exchange resins, substances used to facilitate pharmaceutical manufacturing and lab research.
About_#3: Bio-Rad now sells 10,000 life science research and clinical diagnostics products and had 2021 revenues of $2.9 billion.
About_#4: Bio-Rad held its IPO in 1966. It was listed on the American Stock Exchange in 1980, then the New York Stock Exchange in 2008.
Did You Know?: Schwartz studied biochemistry at UC Berkeley where she met her husband David.

About_#1: Peter Sondakh is head of Rajawali Corpora, an investment firm founded in 1984 whose portfolio includes hotels, media and mining.
About_#2: His Rajawali Property group, founded in 1989, includes the marquee Four Seasons in Jakarta and the St. Regis in Jakarta and Bali.
About_#3: Other assets include internet service provider Velo Networks and TV network Rajawali Televisi.
About_#4: Sondakh's father was an entrepreneur, exporting wood and coconut oil since Sondakh was just a baby.
Did You Know?: A devout Christian, Sondakh is known to read the Bible everyday.
In Their Own Words: I want to know what's wrong with me. Unless you know your weaknesses, how can you improve?

Education: Ph.D, Harvard University; Bachelor of Science, University of California, Berkeley
About_#1: Timothy Springer is an immunologist and professor of biological chemistry and molecular pharmacology at Harvard Medical School.
About_#2: He was a founding investor in publicly traded biotech outfit Moderna in 2010, investing about $5 million; he now owns 3.5% of the firm's shares.
About_#3: Springer also owns shares in three smaller publicly traded biotech firms: Selecta Biosciences, Scholar Rock and Morphic Therapeutic.
About_#4: He first started teaching at Harvard in 1977 as an assistant professor.
Did You Know?: In 2017, Springer established the Institute for Protein Innovation, an independent nonprofit focused on researching proteins, with an initial grant of $10 million.

About_#1: Su Suyu is the controlling shareholder of Shanghai-listed power generation company Luenmei Quantum.
About_#2: Su, one of the world's richest self-made women, co-founded the predecessor company of the Luenmei Group with two sons in Shantou.
About_#3: Su also has interests in real estate, minerals and finance. She shares her fortune with her sons.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Maryknoll College
About_#1: Elizabeth Sy is an adviser of SM Investments, a post she's held since 2012.
About_#2: She is the second child and daughter of the late SM founder, Henry Sy.
About_#3: She is active in the group's tourism, leisure and hospitality operations and serves as chairperson and president of SM Hotels and Conventions.
About_#4: She started out as an assistant at her father's first hotel business, the Manila Royal Hotel.

About_#1: Sukanto Tanoto is owner of Royal Golden Eagle, a group with businesses in pulp and paper, palm oil, and energy.
About_#2: His Bracell is one of the world's largest producers of specialty cellulose, used in everything from baby wipes to ice cream.
About_#3: Roots of the business date back to more than 50 years ago when Tanoto opened up a humble spare parts supply shop known as Toko Motor.
About_#4: His Tanoto Foundation formed a $200 million philanthropic organization in 2022 with some of the world's richest such as Ray Dalio, Li Ka-shing and Indonesia's Widjaja family.
Did You Know?: The eldest of seven boys, Tanoto dropped out of school at age 17 to start his own business.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, San Francisco State University; Master of Science, Santa Clara University
About_#1: Jayshree Ullal has been president and CEO of Arista Networks, a computer networking firm, since 2008.
About_#2: She joined the board of directors of Snowflake, a cloud computing company that went public in September 2020.
About_#3: The publicly-traded company recorded revenue of $2.3 billion in 2020, a decrease of nearly 4% compared to fiscal year 2019.
About_#4: Ullal owns about 5% of Arista's stock, some of which is earmarked for her two children, niece and nephew.
Did You Know?: Ullal studied electrical engineering at San Francisco State University and engineering management at Santa Clara University.
In Their Own Words: As human beings we all want to do a good job, be acknowledged and crave that appreciation. Treat your peers and team respectfully, cultivate their inner strengths and harness their full potential.

About_#1: Son of Indian expat teachers, who migrated to Dubai in 1959, Sunny Varkey controls GEMS Education, the world's largest operator of K-12 schools.
About_#2: The private education firm secured CVC Capital Partners as its key investor in 2019.
About_#3: Sons Dino and Jay run GEMS as CEO and group executive director, respectively.
About_#4: Sunil Munjal, who belongs to the Indian two-wheeler Munjal clan, has acquired a minority stake in GEMS.
Did You Know?: Varkey, who never went beyond high school himself, took over the management of his parents' Our Own English School in 1980 at age 23.
In Their Own Words: I don't believe in giving up even when I hit a hard wall.

Education: Bachelor of Commerce, Bangalore University
About_#1: Property baron Jitendra Virwani's Embassy Group has a mixed portfolio of more than 62 million square feet developed across the country.
About_#2: Embassy, together with private equity firm Blackstone, listed India's first-ever REIT in March 2019.
About_#3: Embassy has a roster of multinational tenants such as Google, IBM and Warburg Pincus.
About_#4: In August 2020, Embassy agreed to merge its residential and commercial projects with listed Indiabulls Real Estate.
Did You Know?: Son Karan oversees a joint venture in shared office spaces with WeWork. His son Aditya is Embassy's chief operating officer.
In Their Own Words: Unless leverage is backed by an identifiable cash flow, I am not comfortable with it.

Education: National Taitung University
About_#1: Wang leads the Dennis Group, which has interests in retailing, real estate and logistics.
About_#2: Dennis Group's main assets are located in Henan Province in central China.
About_#3: Notable properties in Zhengzhou include shopping mall David Plaza.

About_#1: Wang Wenmois a non-executive director at Anta Sports, China's largest sportswear company.
About_#2: Wang is a cousin of fellow Anta billionaires and directors Ding Shizhong and Ding Shijia.
About_#3: Wang oversees Anta's apparel operations.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Fu Jen Catholic University; Master of Business Administration, University of California, Los Angeles
About_#1: Wu is chairman of Taishin Financial Holdings, a financial-services firm based in Taipei.
About_#2: His father, Wu Hu-So, led one of Taiwan's first textile empires after World War II.
About_#3: Wu's older brother Eugene, who's also a billionaire, founded Shin Kong Financial, one of largest financial companies in Taiwan.
About_#4: Thomas went his own way years ago, starting his own financial-services company.

About_#1: Wu Ying chairs Yangling Metron New Materials, a supplier of diamond tools like electroplated diamond wires.
About_#2: Its products are used in the solar energy industry; clients include GCL-Poly, Jinko Solar and LONGi.
About_#3: Early in his career, Wu worked as a director of the computer lab at the China Academy of Machinery Science and Technology Group.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Skidmore College
About_#1: Amy Wyss's father, Swiss billionaire Hansjoerg Wyss, founded medical equipment firm Synthes in the 1970s, where she worked for years.
About_#2: Johnson & Johnson acquired Synthes in 2012 for $19.7 billion in cash and stock. Amy Wyss received a portion of the proceeds from the sale.
About_#3: A 2014 U.S. Senate investigation into offshore tax evasion, which did not implicate the Wyss family, revealed her fortune.
About_#4: She founded the LOR Foundation in 2007 to improve the quality of life for rural communities in the rural Mountain West.
Did You Know?: Wyss met her husband, Ed Jaramillo, on a chairlift in the Rockies.

About_#1: Xiang Guangming chairs Shanghai-listed Zhejiang Weiming Environment Protection.
About_#2: Weiming's main business is solid waste incineration disposal.
About_#3: Xiang's wife, Wang Suqin, also holds shares in the company.

About_#1: Xu Shugen is the founder and chairman of Shanghai-listed Zhejiang Dingli Machinery.
About_#2: Xu's brother, Xu Zhilong, is a board member.
About_#3: Dingli manufactures industrial lifts.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Peking University; Masters of Science in Technology, The University of Texas, Austin
About_#1: Steven Yang is the founder and CEO of Anker Innovations Technology, a supplier of smart charging technologies and a developer of consumer products.
About_#2: Yang holds a degree in computer science and technology from Peking University.
About_#3: He received a master's degree in computing from the University of Texas at Austin and then worked as an engineer at Google in the United States.
About_#4: In 2011, he returned to China and founded Anker Innovations.

About_#1: Clayton Zekelman owns a stake in his family's steel business, Zekelman Industries.
About_#2: The $5 billion (revenues) company is one of North America's largest steel pipe and tube makers.
About_#3: Clayton and his brothers, fellow billionaires Barry Zekelman and Alan Zekelman, split 100% ownership of Zekelman Industries.
About_#4: They sold the company to the Carlyle Group in 2006 for some $1.2 billion, but bought the business back in 2011.

About_#1: Zhao Hongfei chairs Shenzhen-listed software firm Thunder Software Technology.
About_#2: Zhao holds a master's degree from the Beijing Institute of Technology.
About_#3: Zhao worked for a joint venture of Japan's NEC and the Chinese Academy of Science's Institute of Software before founding Thunder in 2008.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: S. Daniel Abraham founded Slim-Fast in 1976. Sales exploded in the late 1980s when former LA Dodgers manager Tommy Lasorda became its spokesman.
About_#2: Abraham sold the weight loss and meal substitute company to Unilever for $2.3 billion in cash in 2000.
About_#3: Since then, he's largely taken a risk-averse approach to investing, keeping most of his fortune in cash and liquid assets.
About_#4: In 2014, Unilever sold the majority of Slim-Fast to Texas private equity firm Kainos Capital for an undisclosed sum.
Did You Know?: Abraham served as an infantryman in the U.S. Army in the 1940s during World War II.
In Their Own Words: Almost everything that I know that is good, all of the good lessons in life, come from my parents.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Universite de Sherbrooke
About_#1: Aziz Akhannouch is the majority owner of Akwa Group, a multibillion-dollar conglomerate founded by his father and a partner, Ahmed Wakrim, in 1932.
About_#2: It has interests in petroleum, gas and chemicals through publicly-traded Afriquia Gaz and Maghreb Oxygene.
About_#3: Akhannouch was appointed prime minister of Morocco in Sept 2021.

About_#1: Russian entrepreneur Andrey Andreev has built five online dating sites and apps since 2004: Mamba, Badoo, Bumble, Chappy and Lumen.
About_#2: His most successful app in the U.S. by far is Bumble, cofounded with Whitney Wolfe Herd, which only allows female users make the first reach-out.
About_#3: In November 2019, Andreev sold his majority stake in Bumble and Badoo to Blackstone Group in a deal that valued the sites at $3 billion.
About_#4: Andreev launched Stereo in August 2020, an audio-only social media platform that competes with Clubhouse, another audio app.
Did You Know?: As a weekend hobby, Andreev would sometimes cook alongside head chef Olivier Limousin at two-Michelin-starred London restaurant L'Atelier de Joël Robuchon.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Far Eastern University
About_#1: Ramon Ang is the president and vice chairman of one of the nation's oldest conglomerates, San Miguel.
About_#2: Originally a brewer, San Miguel is now a leader in food and beverages; but the bulk of its revenue comes from power and infrastructure businesses.
About_#3: He also owns a substantial stake in Eagle Cement, which he took public in 2016. The company is increasing its capacity to 8.6 million metric tons.
About_#4: San Miguel is proposing to build a $15 billion airport and city complex at a 2,500-hectare location along Manila Bay.
Did You Know?: Ang started out by fixing and selling used Japanese car and truck engines; subsequently with the late Eduardo Cojuangco he sold aluminum wheels.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro
About_#1: Guilherme Benchimol is the founder and CEO of XP Inc, a Brazilian financial services firm that went public in December 2019 in the U.S.
About_#2: XP Inc. has grown popular by focusing its products and services on clients with little investing experience.
About_#3: Benchimol founded XP in 2001, with initial capital of less than US$2,000 and after being fired from a brokerage firm in southern Brazil.
About_#4: In March 2021, Benchimol launched the XP Institute, through which he aims to offer free education for 50 million Brazilians over the next 10 years.

About_#1: Julio Bozano made a fortune in banking. In 2000, he sold Banco Bozano, Simonsen to Spain's Banco Santander Central Hispano for a reported $550 million.
About_#2: His investments include a coffee plantation, shopping centers and a stake in a jet engine maker.
About_#3: Octogenarian Bozano controls Bozano Investimentos, a large and diversified Brazilian private equity firm.
About_#4: He invested in low-cost Brazilian airline, Azul Linhas Aereas, which was founded by JetBlue founder David Neeleman and went public in April 2017.

Education: Drop Out, Stanford University
About_#1: Ryan Breslow dropped out of Stanford in 2014 to launch payment startup Bolt. In January 2022 he stepped down as CEO to become executive chairman.
About_#2: Breslow has raised $1.3 billion for Bolt, including $355 million in January 2022, which valued the company at $11 billion.
About_#3: Bolt has attracted investors like BlackRock, General Atlantic and SAP by promising an Amazon-style checkout to millions of online retailers.
About_#4: Breslow--a fan of yoga, meditation and dancing--rarely socializes. He initiated a four-day work week for his 700 employees.

About_#1: Herb Chambers dominates the New England auto sales market, with 59 dealerships selling brands such as BMW, Mercedes Benz, Audi, Lexus and Porsche.
About_#2: Chambers grew up in Boston's working-class Dorchester neighborhood, where he got his first job as a cart collector at the local supermarket.
About_#3: He dropped out of high school during his senior year and joined the U.S. Navy.
About_#4: After returning, he borrowed $500 from his mother to start his first company, a copy distributor, which he sold for $80 million in 1983.
Did You Know?: An avowed car fanatic, Chambers owns vintage Ferraris and a Shelby Cobra.

About_#1: Daniel Chiu chairs Fortune Oil, a Hong Kong-based oil and gas supplier that also operates infrastructure projects in mainland China.
About_#2: Through Fortune, Chiu also owns a large stake in China Gas Holdings, a Hong Kong-listed distributor of natural gas and operator of gas pipelines.
About_#3: Chiu is the founder of the Harrow International Schools in Bangkok, Beijing, Hong Kong and Shanghai.
About_#4: Also known as Chiu Tat Jung, he broke into the billionaire ranks in 2019.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Fuqua School of Business
About_#1: Tim Cook is the CEO of Apple, whose sales of iPhones and more have made it a company with one of the world's largest market capitalizations.
About_#2: Cook, who became CEO in 2011, had previously served as Apple's Chief Operating Officer under Steve Jobs.
About_#3: Cook joined Apple in 1998, having worked briefly at PC maker Compaq and for 12 years at IBM.
About_#4: Cook owns about 3.3 million shares of Apple, far less than a 1% stake; he's sold hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of shares over the years.
Did You Know?: Tim Cook also sits on the board of trustees of Duke, where he got his MBA in 1988.

About_#1: The "king of cashmere," designer Brunello Cucinelli dropped out of engineering school and used a $550 loan to launch a fashion line in 1978.
About_#2: Inspired by brightly-colored wool sweaters, he set out to create a similar garment in cashmere.
About_#3: Today his eponymous luxury brand is best known for those cashmere sweaters, but also sells dresses, suits, shoes, handbags and accessories.
About_#4: Cucinelli took the $810 million (2021 revenues) company public in 2012, listing its shares on the Italian stock exchange.
Did You Know?: Cucinelli contributed to the reconstruction of several monuments in the central Italian town of Norcia, which was damaged in a 2016 earthquake.
In Their Own Words: I want to make profits: I am a capitalist. I want to do it ethically and morally, but I want to make profits. The question is, how do we share the profits?

About_#1: Georgi Domuschiev is the co-owner, alongside his brother Kiril, of Bulgarian investment conglomerate Advance Properties.
About_#2: Founded in 2003, Advance Properties has interests in animal health, shipping, port management, real estate and soccer.
About_#3: Advance's largest asset is Huvepharma, the world's sixth-largest livestock health company, which has factories in four countries including the U.S.
About_#4: The Domuschiev brothers started out selling locally manufactured shoes in the 1990s and then started investing in privatized state-owned companies.

About_#1: Kiril Domuschiev is the co-owner, alongside his brother Georgi, of Bulgarian investment conglomerate Advance Properties.
About_#2: Founded in 2003, Advance Properties has interests in animal health, shipping, port management, real estate and soccer.
About_#3: Advance's largest asset is Huvepharma, the world's sixth-largest livestock health company, which has factories in four countries including the U.S.
About_#4: The Domuschiev brothers started out selling locally manufactured shoes in the 1990s and then started investing in privatized state-owned companies.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, SUNY Stony Brook
About_#1: Glenn Dubin cofounded multi-strategy hedge fund Highbridge Capital in 1992.
About_#2: Dubin sold a majority stake to JPMorgan in 2004 for $1.3 billion.
About_#3: He also cofounded quantitative hedge fund Engineer's Gate and is the lead shareholder of Castleton Commodities, an energy firm he bought with an investor group that included Paul Tudor Jones in 2012.
About_#4: Dubin runs a family office, Dubin & Co., which backs early and late-stage growth companies, including Brex and Scale AI.
Did You Know?: Dubin is a founding board member of the Robin Hood Foundation, a New York poverty-fighting group.

About_#1: Brothers James and Thomas Duff cofounded and co-own Duff Capital Investors, a holding company with total revenue of more than $3.5 billion.
About_#2: Their father Ernest Duff founded dealer Southern Tire Mart in 1973 and sold it in 1998. Duff and his brother Thomas bought it back in 2003.
About_#3: In 2007, the Duffs started Duff Capital, through which they have made multiple acquisitions.
About_#4: Over the years, Duff Capital has acquired trucking company KLLM, construction firm T.L. Wallace Construction and energy firm DeepWell Energy Services.
Did You Know?: Three men were arrested in November 2016 as part of what the Mississippi Bureau of Investigation described as a murder plot to kill James' brother, Tom Duff.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Southern Mississippi
About_#1: Brothers James and Thomas Duff cofounded and co-own Duff Capital Investors, a holding company with total revenue of more than $3.5 billion.
About_#2: Their father Ernest Duff founded dealer Southern Tire Mart in 1973 and sold it in 1998. Duff and his brother James bought it back in 2003.
About_#3: In 2007, the Duffs started Duff Capital, through which they have made multiple acquisitions.
About_#4: Over the years, Duff Capital has acquired trucking company KLLM, construction firm T.L. Wallace Construction and energy firm DeepWell Energy Services.
Did You Know?: Three men were arrested in November 2016 as part of what the Mississippi Bureau of Investigation described as a murder plot to kill Tom Duff.

Education: Drop Out, University of California, Los Angeles; Drop Out, University of California, Santa Barbara
About_#1: Robert Duggan is a serial entrepreneur; he led the 2015 sale of biotech firm Pharmacyclics to AbbVie for $21 billion in cash and stock
About_#2: The success of Pharmacyclics' cancer drug Imbruvica made him a billionaire in 2013.
About_#3: Duggan, whose son died from brain cancer, became passionate about Pharmacyclic's cancer fighting drugs and first invested in 2004.
About_#4: His enthusiasm for investing began four decades earlier in a corporate finance class he took at the University of California at Santa Barbara.
Did You Know?: Duggan is a big donor to the Church of Scientology, of which he is a member; he says he's given the church nearly $360 million over his lifetime.
In Their Own Words: My commercial goal has always been to 'make a significant difference for the betterment of life' in the field of communication, healthcare and education.

About_#1: Maria Franca Fissolo is the widow of Michele Ferrero, who built Ferrero Group into one of the world's leading sweets companies.
About_#2: The firm is best known for its iconic Nutella chocolate-hazelnut spread, Kinder chocolates and Tic Tac mints.
About_#3: Michele Ferrero died in February 2015, leaving the majority of the business to his and Maria's son Giovanni, who now chairs the company.
About_#4: Giovanni and his brother, Pietro, had previously served as co-chief executives, until Pietro died in a biking accident in 2011.
Did You Know?: Prior to their marriage, Maria worked as Michele Ferrero's secretary.

About_#1: Fu is chairman and general manager of Riyue Heavy Industry, a maker of iron castings.
About_#2: Fu early in his career worked as a technician in an elevator factory in the eastern Chinese city of Ningbo.
About_#3: Fu, together with wife Chen Jianmin and daughter Fu Linger, founded Riyue Heavy Industry in 2007.

Education: LLB, University of Ottawa; Bachelor of Arts/Economics, York University
About_#1: Jay Hennick is the CEO and largest shareholder of Toronto-based real estate investment firm Colliers International.
About_#2: He got his start in 1972 as a teenager, when he started a small company that managed a commercial swimming pool, with a $1,000 loan from his dad.
About_#3: In 1989, he turned that firm into real estate services outfit FirstService and took it public on the Toronto Stock Exchange four years later.
About_#4: He merged FirstService with Colliers in 2010; five years later, he spun Colliers out as a publicly traded firm on the NASDAQ.

Education: Drop Out, University of California, Berkeley
About_#1: Orion Hindawi cofounded cybersecurity firm Tanium with his father David in 2007; private investors valued the firm at $9 billion in June 2020.
About_#2: In February 2016, Orion took over as CEO of Tanium from his father, who serves as executive chairman.
About_#3: The father-son team previously worked together on BigFix, an IT software patching system that they sold to IBM for $400 million in 2010.
About_#4: Orion's father David was born in Baghdad, grew up in Israel, and went to UC Berkeley to earn a Ph.D.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University; Master of Science in Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University
About_#1: Ji Qi is the founder and executive chairman of hotel chain H World Group, one of China's biggest multi-brand hotel chain management groups.
About_#2: Ji also cofounded China's leading travel booking site Ctrip.com.
About_#3: H World Group operates thousands of hotels in China under a variety of brands, with a focus on the budget and midscale segments.
About_#4: H World Group, whose shares trade on the Nasdaq, was once known as China Lodging Group and Huazhu Group.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Yonsei University
About_#1: Kim Chang-soo is chairman of F&F, which he started as an apparel business in 1992.
About_#2: The company carries the Korea license for Western brands such as Benetton and Major League Baseball.
About_#3: In May 2021, F&F Holdings spun off its core clothing business to form a new company called F&F Co.

About_#1: Kuan Kam Hon was a high school dropout who began his career in construction in 1969. He worked at his father's company building high-end homes.
About_#2: He set off on his own in 1978 and started Timol Weaving, a manufacturing business that made woven labels and badges.
About_#3: Founded in 1988, his Hartalega Holdings is one of the world's largest makers of nitrile gloves with an annual production capacity of 40 billion gloves.
About_#4: After more than doubling in 2020, shares of Hartalega fell in 2021 due to a slump in demand for rubber gloves.
Did You Know?: As the AIDS epidemic hit, Kam Hon moved into rubber and then synthetic gloves for the medical industry.

Education: Master of Science, Novosibirsk State University
About_#1: Egor Kulkov created Pharmstandard together with Viktor Kharitonin, Roman Abramovich and others by combining five factories bought from ICN Pharmaceuticals in 2003.
About_#2: Kulkov and Kharitonin bought out their partners in 2008. Kulkov still has a stake in, and sits on the board of, Pharmstandard, now Russia's leading pharmaceutical firm.
About_#3: The partners also have stakes in Russian firms, OTCPharm, Biocad and Generium, one of the makers of the Sputnik V covid vaccine.
About_#4: Kulkov is the largest shareholder of British medical technology firm CMR Surgical, which makes the surgical robotic system Versius.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard; Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School
About_#1: Josh Kushner founded and runs VC firm Thrive Capital, which has backed some of the past decade's most notable startups, including Instagram, Spotify and Slack.
About_#2: In May 2021, Goldman Sachs invested an estimated $120 million in Thrive at a $3.6 billion valuation; Kushner's stake is estimated to be worth $1.9 billion.
About_#3: In February 2022, Thrive's eighth and largest fund to date closed at $3 billion, bringing assets under management to roughly $16 billion.
About_#4: The liberal Kushner cofounded a health insurance company built around Obamacare before brother Jared's father-in-law Donald Trump became president.
Did You Know?: Kushner purchased a 2.5% stake in the NBA's Memphis Grizzlies in 2019.
In Their Own Words: There are three ways to make a return. You can create something no one else has created. You can discover something before anyone else. Or access something that very few can.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, City College of New York; Doctorate, Princeton University
About_#1: Laufer joined legendary quantitative hedge fund Renaissance Technologies, founded by Jim Simons, in 1992.
About_#2: He was its chief scientist and vice president of research until retiring in 2009.
About_#3: Laufer still has a stake in Renaissance, which now manages about $55 billion.
About_#4: Prior to Renaissance, Laufer was a math professor at Stony Brook University for two decades.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University
About_#1: Thomas Lee is best known for orchestrating the sale of Snapple for $1.7 billion in 1994, two years after he bought it, at a return of 32 times equity.
About_#2: Today Lee is president of private equity firm Lee Equity Partners, which typically invests $50 million to $150 million.
About_#3: Among his current investments are Summit Behavioral Healthcare, fertility-care provider Prelude Fertility and Taco Bell operator K-Mac Holdings.
About_#4: The art dealer's son owns works by artists like Willem de Kooning and Jackson Pollock and is a trustee of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art.
Did You Know?: Lee's grandfather founded retail outfit Shoe Corporation of America in 1905.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, McMaster University
About_#1: Michael Lee-Chin made a fortune investing in financial companies like National Commercial Bank Jamaica and AIC Limited.
About_#2: The native of Jamaica acquired AIC in 1987, when it had less than $1 million in assets under management.
About_#3: Under Lee-Chin, the Canada-based wealth management and mutual fund business managed more than $10 billion in assets by 2002.
About_#4: But the firm was hit hard by the 2008 recession, and Lee-Chin sold AIC to Canadian financial services group Manulife in 2009 for an undisclosed price.
Did You Know?: As a teenager, Lee-Chin worked landscaping at a hotel, then got a gig cleaning the engine room on the Jamaica Queen cruise ship.

About_#1: Li Xuhui was a director and vice president of Foshan Haitian Flavouring and Food before she left in 2016.
About_#2: Li managed Haitian's oyster sauce factory from 1999 to 2010.
About_#3: Pang Kang and Cheng Xue, chairman and vice chairman of Haitian, are also billionaires.

Education: Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of London
About_#1: Lim Kok Thay is the chairman of Genting, a casino and resorts conglomerate with a global footprint.
About_#2: In January 2022, Lim's troubled cruise operator Genting Hong Kong, which was hit hard by the pandemic, filed a winding up petition. Lim stepped down as chairman.
About_#3: Lim's assets include Empire Resorts, the parent company of loss-making Resorts World Catskills.
About_#4: A long-drawn family feud over the empire's wealth and businesses, which include a palm-oil unit, was finally resolved in early 2020.
Did You Know?: Plans for a theme park at Resorts World Genting were revived after initially collapsing in 2018.

About_#1: Joao Roberto Marinho and his two billionaire brothers, Jose Roberto and Roberto Irineu, inherited control of Globo, Brazil's largest media group.
About_#2: Their grandfather Irineu Marinho launched O Globo newspaper in 1925; he died 25 days after the first issue was published and his oldest son took over.
About_#3: Globo Group includes Brazil's largest broadcaster, Rede Globo; Brazil's largest newspaper company and Globosat, Brazil's largest pay TV provider.
About_#4: Joao Roberto worked at O Globo, one of Brazil's most influential newspapers. He held a number of positions before becoming vice president in 1982.
In Their Own Words: I renew our our commitment to defend the democracy, the republic, the rule of law, and the right to vote. TV and newspaper Globo doesn't defend any parties, religions. We are not going to distance ourselves from what we believe in.

About_#1: Jose Roberto Marinho and his two billionaire brothers, Joao Roberto and Roberto Irineu, inherited control of Globo, Brazil's largest media group.
About_#2: Their grandfather started Globo in 1925 by launching a newspaper. He died 25 days after the first issue was published so his oldest son took over.
About_#3: Globo Group owns Brazil's largest TV broadcaster, Rede Globo; Brazil's largest newspaper company, and Globosat, Brazil's largest pay TV provider.
About_#4: In 1991, Jose Roberto founded CBN, the first Brazilian radio to broadcast 24 hours of news.
In Their Own Words: Our family has ... always invested in Brazil. We believe the country can overcome adversities. We still believe in Brazil.

About_#1: Roberto Irineu Marinho and his two billionaire brothers, Joao Roberto and Jose Roberto, inherited control of Globo, Brazil's largest media group.
About_#2: Grandfather Irineu Marinho started Globo in 1925 with a newspaper. He died 25 days after the first issue was published and his son Roberto took over.
About_#3: Globo Group includes Brazil's largest broadcaster, Rede Globo, Brazil's largest newspaper company and Globosat, Brazil's largest pay TV provider.
About_#4: In December 2017, Roberto Irineu quit as the executive president of the group. For the first time ever, a non-family member assumed that position.
Did You Know?: The low profile media baron also owns Sertaozinho Farm, which produces Orfeu gourmet coffee.
In Their Own Words: I want to make it very clear that the Marinho family will not step back at all from Grupo Globo. We are and continue to want to be a family business, with professional management.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Washington University in St. Louis; Bachelor of Science, Washington University in St. Louis
About_#1: Jim McKelvey cofounded payments firm Square with Jack Dorsey in 2009 after he had trouble selling a $2,000 art piece from his studio.
About_#2: McKelvey remains on Square's board, but has started a new company, Invisibly, which powers micropayments for journalism and publishing.
About_#3: He owns nearly 5% of Square and has netted at least $270 million from selling Square shares.
About_#4: A serial entrepreneur, he has started at least seven companies, ranging from a CD cabinet maker to a glass-blowing studio.
Did You Know?: McKelvey is the author of two textbooks on computer science and one textbook called "The Art Of Fire: Beginning Glassblowing."
In Their Own Words: I have this habit of starting companies, but I can't run them. If I stay around too long, I become disruptive.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Cornell University
About_#1: Robert Miller cofounded Duty Free Shoppers (DFS) in Hong Kong with fellow American Charles Feeney and has co-owned it with LVMH since 1997.
About_#2: Born in the U.S., he has been a Hong Kong resident since 1960.
About_#3: He has three well-known daughters: Marie-Chantal, crown princess of Greece; Alexandra von Furstenberg; and Pia Getty.
About_#4: He has donated millions to support the Hong Kong arts scene through the Asia Society, where he is a trustee emeritus.

About_#1: Megadealer David Nahmad with brother Ezra owns a stockpile of modern and impressionist art, stored in a duty-free warehouse in Geneva, Switzerland.
About_#2: The Nahmads' inventory includes more than 30 blue chip artists, from Monet and Matisse to Renoir and Rothko. They buy and sell mainly at auction.
About_#3: Among the holdings: 300 Picassos, worth at least $1 billion. The whole collection is worth $3 billion. The brothers split their art assets 50/50.
About_#4: David also trades a currency and stock portfolio worth more than $300 million.
Did You Know?: David's son Hillel runs the Helly Nahmad Gallery in the Carlyle Hotel in Manhattan. His nephew runs a gallery by the same name in London.
In Their Own Words: There is very little art, compared to the amount of people who want to buy it.

About_#1: Florentino Perez splits his time running Spain's largest construction company Grupo ACS and popular Spanish soccer team Real Madrid.
About_#2: Perez, president of Real Madrid, boosted advertising and merchandise revenues in his first tenure as president (2000-2006).
About_#3: He was re-elected president of Real Madrid in 2009. The team, owned by its fans, is worth $3.6 billion according to Forbes.
About_#4: Florentino has been CEO of Grupo ACS since 1997; he owns a nearly 13% stake in the publicly-traded construction company.
Did You Know?: Pérez briefly worked for the Madrid city council, then moved to Spain's Ministry of Public Works and Transport, before landing in the private sector in 1983.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Loyola University Illinois
About_#1: Jennifer Pritzker is one of 11 billionaire heirs in the Chicago-based Pritzker clan and is the world's only known transgender billionaire.
About_#2: Pritzker inherited stakes in the family's Hyatt Hotels chain as well as industrial firms run by her late father Robert and his brothers Jay & Donald.
About_#3: The retired Army lieutenant colonel came out as a transgender woman in 2013.
About_#4: Pritzker is also the founder and CEO of private wealth management firm Tawani Enterprises.
Did You Know?: Pritzker responded to President Trump's proposed ban on transgender people in the military by offering to help find "a better solution."
In Their Own Words: There are thousands of transgender veterans, and those currently serving, who have made enormous personal sacrifice to serve their country by subordinating their personal identities to service to our nation.
