About_#1: A scion of the billionaire Pritzker family, Pritzker has steered clear of working in her family's enterprises, devoting herself to Tibetan Buddhism.
About_#2: Pritzker is building a spiritual retreat center in Montana dedicated to Tibetan Buddhist practice and has been offering online courses since 2017.
About_#3: Her father, Robert, with brother Jay Pritzker, built up manufacturing business Marmon Holdings and sold it to Berkshire Hathaway beginning in 2008.
About_#4: Pritzker also goes by Lama Tsomo in her teaching and professional capacities.
Did You Know?: Pritzker published a Westerner's guide to Tibetan Buddhist meditation that included an introductory letter from H.H. Dalai Lama.
In Their Own Words: As long as you have the basics in life - basic food, shelter, clothing - after that, a lot of it is dependent on what's going on in the inside. Because where you experience happiness is in the inside.

About_#1: P.V. Ramprasad Reddy sits on the board of generics maker Aurobindo Pharma, which he cofounded in 1986.
About_#2: Aurobindo Pharma makes drugs to treat a range of diseases such as diabetes and cardiac ailments.
About_#3: The company gets nearly 75% of its $3 billion revenue from the U.S and Europe.

About_#1: Joe Rogers Jr. is the longtime chairman of Waffle House and the son of one of the 24-hour breakfast chain's cofounders.
About_#2: There are now 2,100 locations in 25 states and estimated annual revenue of over $1 billion.
About_#3: He was 26 in 1973 when he took the helm of the chain, which had two family ownership groups, mounting debt and control of only 30% of the locations.
About_#4: Rogers consolidated ownership within his family, which now has a controlling share, while ending the company's reliance on debt.
Did You Know?: Rogers made a point of keeping his diners defiantly open in the face of calamity and showed up in Charleston in 1989 to pour coffee after Hurricane Hugo hit.
In Their Own Words: Most of why we are here today is learning what not to do. We don't have the most creative restaurant concept you've ever seen. We're just a throwback to a diner.

Education: Drop Out, Wichita State University
About_#1: Phil Ruffin owns the Treasure Island Hotel & Casino plus 50% of the Trump International Las Vegas hotel alongside friend Donald Trump.
About_#2: Son of a grocer, Ruffin dropped out of college to sell hamburgers with his buddies, then used the profits to buy convenience stores.
About_#3: From there he expanded into real estate: strip malls, office parks and hotels, including Marriotts in Alabama, California and the Bahamas.
About_#4: In 1998 he bought the New Frontier Hotel & Casino for $165 million; he sold it for $1.2 billion in 2007 to Israeli billionaire Yitzhak Tshuva.
Did You Know?: Donald Trump was the best man at Ruffin's 2008 wedding to his wife Oleksandra, a former Miss Ukraine.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Birla Institute of Technology and Science (BITS) - Pilani
About_#1: An MBA from BITS Pilani, Vinod Saraf started his career working for Aditya Birla, billionaire Kumar Birla's late father.
About_#2: In 1989, he set up his own venture to manufacture isobutyl benzene, the key raw material used for making ibuprofen, a popular painkiller.
About_#3: His listed Vinati Organics is now among the world's largest producers (by volume) of ibuprofen.
About_#4: His older daughter Vinati Mutreja, a Wharton grad after whom the company is named, now runs the company as CEO and managing director.

About_#1: Maria-Elisabeth Schaeffler-Thumann and her son Georg own Schaeffler Group, one of the world's largest ball bearing and machine component producers.
About_#2: She took over in 1996, following the death of her husband (also Georg) who had founded the company with his brother Wilhelm in 1946.
About_#3: In 2008, the company took over tire and auto parts giant Continental AG in a $15-billion, debt-financed deal.
About_#4: In the wake of the financial crisis, it seemed the high-wire act might fail. But as the auto market rebounded, Continental's share price soared.
Did You Know?: Maria-Elisabeth, who owns 20% of Schaeffler Group, lives in the tony Austrian ski resort town of Kitzbuehel, while Georg, with 80%, leads a quiet life in the U.S.
In Their Own Words: It is often said that family businesses think in the long term. This is definitely true for Schaeffler. In addition to economic success, roots and values are important to us.

Education: Doctorate, China Agricultural University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Zhejiang University
About_#1: Shao Genhuo chairs Beijing Dabeinong Technology Group, a supplier of animal feed.
About_#2: Shao founded the company in 1993.
About_#3: Dabeinong is headquartered in Beijing.

About_#1: Shen Xiqiang is vice chairman of Jiangsu Yoke Technology, a supplier of electronics, insulation and plastics materials.
About_#2: Shen cofounded Yoke in 1997 in Yixing in Jiangsu province.
About_#3: Elder son Shen Qi is Yoke's chairman; younger son Shen Fu is deputy general manager.

About_#1: Shi is the founder of Chi Mei Corp., one of Asia's largest plastics businesses. It now has interests in technology.
About_#2: He started Chi Mei with the equivalent of $700 and four employees in 1953.
About_#3: Shi's son-in-law Lin Chia-lung was the mayor of central Taiwan business hub Taichung from 2014 to 2021.
Did You Know?: The active philanthropist has erected one of Taiwan's largest museums in his home city, Tainan.

Education: Master of Science, Eastern Kentucky University
About_#1: Thaksin Shinawatra, the former prime minister of Thailand, has been living in self-imposed exile in Dubai for more than a decade.
About_#2: He owns a controlling stake in property firm SC Asset, among much else.
About_#3: Thaksin has invested in two U.K.-based health tech startups, DNANudge and Owlstone Medical.
About_#4: His sister Yingluck, also a former prime minister, fled the country in 2017 to escape arrest over a rice subsidy scheme.
Did You Know?: In 2017, the ruling military junta imposed a retrospective tax on Thaksin's sale of telecom firm Shin Corp's shares to Singapore's Temasek.

Education: Master of Science, Plekhanov Russian University of Economics
About_#1: Alexander Skorobogatko and partner Alexander Ponomarenko started out with sea ports and banking and then moved into airport construction.
About_#2: In 2013 the two, with Arkady Rotenberg, a judo partner of President Vladimir Putin, won a tender to develop Sheremetyevo, the state-owned airport.
About_#3: The partners and Rotenberg also founded TPS Real Estate, which owns more than half of the real estate in Ocean Plaza, Kiev's biggest shopping center.
About_#4: The two Alexanders first set up a small perfume factory in the Ukraine and then founded a bank in Moscow.

About_#1: In 2003, Sylvia Stroeher netted over $1 billion when her family sold 80% of hair-care group Wella AG to Procter & Gamble.
About_#2: In 1927, her great-grandfather Franz bought the rights to a process that used hot curlers and chemicals to put long-lasting waves into women's hair.
About_#3: Sylvia and her husband, a former nurse, have a renowned collection of contemporary German art that includes works by Baselitz, Immendorff and Kiefer.
About_#4: Part of the collection is housed in the Museum Kueppersmuehle in Duisburg, Germany.

About_#1: Lawyer-turned-investor Wichai Thongtang, gets a substantial chunk of his fortune from a minority stake in hospital operator Bangkok Dusit.
About_#2: Wichai's portfolio includes TWZ, a distributor of mobile phones and peripheral devices and E For L Aim, a dealer of medical equipment and suppliers.
About_#3: He is chairman of listed Royal Orchid Hotel (Thailand), Grande Asset Hotels and Wind Energy Holdings, a renewable energy producer.
Did You Know?: He has represented former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra.
In Their Own Words: I'm low profile but high profit.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Indiana University; Doctor of Jurisprudence, University of Virginia
About_#1: With business partner Mark Cuban, Todd Wagner joined the billionaire ranks after selling video portal Broadcast.com to Yahoo in 1999.
About_#2: The $5.7 billion sale didn't just benefit Wagner and Cuban: their 300 employees became millionaires.
About_#3: Wagner safeguarded his shares against the dot-com bubble's epic burst with put options.
About_#4: Since then, Wagner and Cuban have continued to invest together in ventures such as Magnolia Pictures, AXS TV and the Dallas Mavericks.
In Their Own Words: What Mark [Cuban] and I did was lightning in a bottle. A unicorn doesn't happen often, and it happened to me at a very young age. I felt success was something to be proud of, but I had a lot of advantages that other folks don't.

Education: Drop Out, Chicago State University
About_#1: Entrepreneur and musician Kanye West lost his lucrative multi-year deal to design sneaker brand Yeezy for Adidas after making antisemitic comments.
About_#2: Other brands and companies that cut ties to West, who formally changed his name to Ye, include Gap, CAA and Balenciaga.
About_#3: Forbes had valued the Adidas deal at $1.5 billion. Without it, West's fortune drops to $400 million.
About_#4: His current fortune includes cash, real estate, the value of his music catalog and a 5% stake in his ex-wife Kim Kardashian West's shapewear brand Skims.

Education: Drop Out, University of Nebraska Lincoln
About_#1: Evan Williams, also referred to as "Ev," has started three digital publishing companies: Blogger, Twitter and Medium.
About_#2: A University of Nebraska dropout, Williams grew up on his family's soybean and corn farm.
About_#3: Williams' venture capital firm, Obvious Ventures, was one of the largest investors in Beyond Meat, which had a successful IPO in May 2019.
About_#4: He cofounded Twitter and has served as a member of its board of directors until February 2019. He was President and CEO from July 2009 to March 2010.
Did You Know?: Williams has been credited as the person who coined the term "blogger."
In Their Own Words: Maybe it was because I grew up on that farm with so many ideas in my head and so few people to share them with that I couldn't think of anything more exciting than a system with the potential to connect brains from all over the planet.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Shenzhen University
About_#1: Wu Zhongyi is the vice chairman of Yealink Network Technology, a supplier of video conferencing solutions and Internet phones.
About_#2: Yealink Chairman Chen Zhisong is also a member of the 2019 Forbes China Rich List.
About_#3: Yealink is headquartered in the eastern Chinese city of Xiamen.

About_#1: Xu Zhihan chairs Maxscend Microelectronics, an electrical components supplier that produces products like smart phone radio frequency switches.
About_#2: Maxscend was founded in 2012 by a group of Silicon Valley alums.
About_#3: Xu holds master's and bachelor's degrees in computer science and technology from Tsinghua University.
About_#4: He also holds master's degree in electrical engineering from Santa Clara University.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Wuhan University
About_#1: A former advertising executive, Yan Zhi chairs Hong Kong-listed Zall Smart Commerce Group, previously called Zall Group.
About_#2: The firm started with shopping mall development and then got into e-commerce as well as wholesale trading, logistics and warehousing.
About_#3: Yan holds an EMBA from the Cheung Kong Graduate School.
About_#4: Yan holds 30% of Z-Bank, a Wuhan-based bank that specializes in lending to small businesses involved in supply chain transactions.

About_#1: Michael Ying is the former chairman of Hong Kong-listed fashion retailer Esprit.
About_#2: He has kept a low profile and sold most of his stake in the company after stepping down in 2006.
About_#3: In 2017 Ying transferred the rest of his Esprit shares to his two daughters.
About_#4: Ying joined Esprit in the 1970s and played a key role in building it into a global brand.

About_#1: Yuan Liping received a 24% stake in Shenzhen Kangtai Biological Products in 2020 after she divorced Du Weimin, Kantai's chairman.
About_#2: Yuan was deputy general manager at Kangtai Biological Products from 2012-2015 and a company director from 2012-2015.
About_#3: Yuan has been deputy general manager of Kangtai subsidiary Beijing Minhai Biotechnology since March 2017.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Anu Aga derives her wealth from a majority stake in listed engineering firm Thermax.
About_#2: Aga started working at Thermax in 1985 when it was run by her husband and took the helm in 1996 after he died of a heart attack.
About_#3: She stepped down as chairman in 2004, ceding the spot to her daughter Meher, a UK-trained chemical engineer who lets hired executives manage the firm.
About_#4: Consumer goods billionaire Harsh Mariwala has a board seat in the company.
Did You Know?: Aga cofounded Teach for India in 2008, a non-profit that recruits young people to teach for 2 years in schools for low-income kids.

About_#1: Son of a jewelry store owner and school dropout, Joy Alukkas went to the Middle East to open the family's first overseas store in 1987 in Abu Dhabi.
About_#2: He broke off to launch his own Joyalukkas brand, which now has 84 outlets spread across India and 43 overseas.
About_#3: His other interests include a money exchange outfit, malls and real estate.
About_#4: Alukkas' son John Paul is managing director of the international jewelry business.
Did You Know?: In 1956 Alukkas' father, Varghese Alukkas, opened the first jewellery store in the family's native Thrissur town.
In Their Own Words: Mobile phones and motorbikes have no resale value, but jewelry is worth it.

About_#1: Sezai Bacaksiz and his billionaire partner, Nihat Ozdemir, met as students at Gazi University and founded Limak Construction in 1976.
About_#2: Besides being contractor for some of the world's largest infrastructure projects, Limak has operations in energy, tourism, transportation and cement.
About_#3: It's part of a consortium building Istanbul's new airport. When all phases are complete, it will be the world's largest based on passenger capacity.
About_#4: Limak is a major builder and operator of hydroelectric power plants, ranking among Turkey's top ten electricity producers.

About_#1: Bai Baokun chairs Guangdong KinLong Hardware Products, a supplier of components for curtain walls as well as door and window hardware.
About_#2: Kinlong went public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2016.
About_#3: Bai cofounded the predecessor of Guangdong KinLong Hardware Products in 2003.

About_#1: Acharya Balkrishna derives his fortune from consumer goods giant Patanjali Ayurved.
About_#2: Balkrishna owns the bulk of the privately held company, which he cofounded with politically well-connected yoga guru Baba Ramdev.
About_#3: Patanjali sells everything from herbal toothpastes and cosmetics to noodles and jams.
About_#4: To push online sales, Patanjali has agreements with several e-commerce giants, such as Amazon and BigBasket.
Did You Know?: Balkrishna is often dressed in an all-white traditional dhoti.
In Their Own Words: We want to use this wealth to serve others and not ourselves.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Beijing University
About_#1: Coal entrepreneur Kiki Barki founded Harum Energy in 1995 and listed it in 2010.
About_#2: His eldest son Lawrence Barki runs Harum as president commissioner while youngest son Steven Scott Barki is commissioner.
About_#3: Kiki Barki also owns a privately-held coal mine Tanito Harum.
About_#4: The family owns a stake in Australian-listed Nickel Mines, which has one nickel mine and two nickel pig iron plants in Indonesia.

About_#1: John Bloor is one of the largest builders in the UK through his Bloor Homes and also owns Triumph Motorcycles, the iconic bike manufacturer.
About_#2: He reportedly left school at age 15 and began an apprenticeship as a plasterer, then built his first house before turning 20.
About_#3: Now the privately-held Bloor Homes puts up more than 3,500 homes every year.
About_#4: In 1983 he bought the manufacturing rights for Triumph motorcycles.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: Nicola Bulgari is vice chairman of luxury goods brand Bulgari, which was founded by his great-grandfather.
About_#2: Bulgari established itself as a global luxury brand in jewelry, watches, fragrances, apparel, hotels and resorts.
About_#3: In 2011, the Bulgari family sold its controlling stake to luxury goods conglomerate LVMH for $5.2 billion in cash and stock.
About_#4: Nicola Bulgari is well known for his car collection, which includes mostly American cars from 1920s to the 1940s.
Did You Know?: He once turned down an offer from Andy Warhol to exchange a painting for Bulgari jewels. "It was the worst deal of my life," he said.

About_#1: Bulgheroni and his late brother Carlos (d. Sept. 2016) took over Argentine energy company Bridas Corp., founded by their father, in 1985.
About_#2: Bridas, now called BS Energy Investments, was created in 1948 to provide parts for the national oil company's pipeline network.
About_#3: The Bulgheroni brothers sold a 50% stake in Bridas to China's state overseas oil company, CNOOC, for $3.1 billion in 2011.
About_#4: In September 2017 they entered into a cash-free agreement with BP to form the largest privately-owned integrated energy company in Argentina.
In Their Own Words: Get a lot of advice because it's very easy to make mistakes.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Kellogg School of Management; Bachelor of Business Administration, Universidad Iberoamericana
About_#1: Chico Pardo started his first company in Mexico City at age 27, a stock brokerage called Acciones y Asesoría Bursátil.
About_#2: That brokerage later became part of Grupo Financiero Inbursa, a banking and financial group controlled by Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim.
About_#3: After he left Inbursa in 2003, Chico Pardo became a controlling shareholder in Grupo Financiero del Sureste (Asur), which operates 9 Mexican airports.
About_#4: He also runs private equity fund Promecap, which has acquired interests in or provided funding for a variety of Mexican companies.

About_#1: Jose Luis Cutrale, known as Brazil's "Orange King" for his company's size in processing concentrated orange juice, died at age 75 in August 2022.
About_#2: He was chair of Sucocitrico Cutrale, which owns juice brands and is a supplier of orange-juice concentrate to Minute Maid and Simply Orange, both part of Coca-Cola.
About_#3: He helped his father, who founded Sucocitrico Cutrale in 1967, to build it into a multinational business.
About_#4: With fellow Brazilian billionaire Joseph Safra (d. 2020), he acquired banana producer Chiquita Brands International in 2015 for $1.3 billion.
In Their Own Words: If you don't work, you don't get anything.

Education: Master of Business Administration, INSEAD; Bachelor of Engineering, Polytechnic University of Madrid
About_#1: Leopoldo del Pino y Calvo Sotelo inherited a stake in Ferrovial S.A., Spain's largest infrastructure construction and management company.
About_#2: His father, who founded the company in 1952, died in 2008. Leopoldo's two siblings also inherited stakes in Ferrovial.
About_#3: Leopoldo's brother Rafael del Pino is the chairman and co-CEO of Ferrovial.
About_#4: Leopoldo, who owns about 4% of Ferrovial, served as a board member of the company until early 2016.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: James Dinan founded York Capital Management in 1991 and is the chairman, CEO and a managing partner of the money management firm.
About_#2: York Capital had $19 billion of assets under management as of July 2019.
About_#3: In 2014 Dinan purchased a minority stake in the NBA's Milwaukee Bucks, alongside fellow finance tycoons Marc Lasry and Wes Edens.
About_#4: Dinan obtained his B.S. degree in economics from the Wharton School and his M.B.A from Harvard Business School.
Did You Know?: Dinan lost much of his savings in the 1987 Black Monday stock market crash. Four years later, he founded York Capital Management.

About_#1: Francois Feuillet led French motorhome maker Trigano for 39 years before stepping down as its chairman in 2020.
About_#2: Started in 1935, Trigano first made camping equipment and then branched out to become a leader in European leisure vehicles.
About_#3: Feuillet took the company public in 1998, and he and his family owns 58% of the business.
About_#4: He previously worked in finance and had an auditing job at KPMG.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Columbia Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Fordham University
About_#1: Mario Gabelli runs Gamco, a mutual fund and investment firm he founded in 1977.
About_#2: Gabelli's reputation for stock-picking took off in the 80s when he found success betting on the media and telecom sectors.
About_#3: A first-generation college student, Gabelli graduated from the Fordham College of Business Administration in 1965.
About_#4: He is a big donor to higher education and a signatory of the Giving Pledge.
Did You Know?: A life-long contrarian, even as a schoolboy Gabelli refused to hide with classmates during air raid drills.
In Their Own Words: That's my approach to life: Go where others fear to tread. Hell, I bought a Cadillac in the middle of the oil embargo.

Education: Master of Business Administration, INSEAD
About_#1: Reinold Geiger heads up French cosmetics retailer L'Occitane, which brings beauty products inspired by the Provence region to consumers worldwide.
About_#2: Since Geiger first invested in the company in 1994, he has overseen L'Occitane's global expansion to over 3,400 outlets in 90 countries.
About_#3: L'Occitane was the first French company to go public on the Hong Kong stock exchange when its shares debuted in 2010.
About_#4: Geiger stepped down from his role as CEO in September 2021, after leading the beauty company for more than 25 years. He remains chairman and executive director.

About_#1: He chairs Leshan Giantstar Farming & Husbandry, a supplier of leather products.
About_#2: The company listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange on Dec. 18, 2017.
About_#3: He is also a director and the majority shareholder of Shanghai-listed chemicals supplier Sichuan Hebang Biotechnology.
About_#4: He worked for a city government commercial bureau in Leshan, China from 1971 to 1993 and founded Hebang's predecessor company in 1993.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Ibero-American University
About_#1: Roberto Hernández Ramírez made a fortune in banking, beginning with the establishment of brokerage firm Acciones y Valores, also known as Accival.
About_#2: Accival purchased Mexican bank Banamex in 1991, becoming Grupo Financiero Banamex-Accival, which Hernandez chaired.
About_#3: In 2001 Citigroup purchased Grupo Financiero Banamex-Accival for $12 billion in cash and stock.
About_#4: Since that sale, Hernandez has invested in a number of Mexican public companies.

About_#1: Huang Qiaoling, one of China's most successful theme park entrepreneurs, chairs Songcheng Performance Development.
About_#2: Huang businesses operate 30 theme parks and 10 resorts.
About_#3: Huang served in the army from 1975-80, and his early career was in the arts.

About_#1: Willis Johnson is the founder of Dallas-based Copart, a leader in online auctions for used and totaled cars; he owns about 7% of the stock.
About_#2: Johnson founded the company out of a single lot in Vallejo, California in 1982 after several years operating a dismantling yard near Sacramento.
About_#3: He took the company public in 1994 and expanded across the country; Copart now has 243 locations in 11 countries.
About_#4: Johnson stepped down as CEO in 2010 and handed over the reins to his son-in-law, Jay Adair, who first joined Copart in 1989 at age 19.
Did You Know?: Johnson was drafted into the Vietnam War and was awarded a Purple Heart for his service.

About_#1: Scion of a Thai property clan, Keeree Kanjanapas is the founder and chairman of BTS Group Holdings, operator of Bangkok's famous Skytrain.
About_#2: His U.K.-educated son, Kavin, has been running BTS since 2015.
About_#3: Making a foray into hotels, BTS acquired Vienna House in 2017 for $350 million, with a string of properties in Europe and Asia.
About_#4: Keeree's interests include media firm VGI, which has a joint venture with SET-listed developer Sansiri. It also has a stake in parcel delivery firm Kerry Express.
In Their Own Words: Thailand sees the benefit of investing in infrastructure. Without it you cannot grow quickly.

About_#1: Kim Dae-il is the founder of Pearl Abyss, an online gaming company that went public in Seoul in September 2017.
About_#2: His company's role-playing game Black Desert reportedly has some 18 million registered users since its 2015 debut.
About_#3: A bulk of Black Desert's revenue comes from overseas.

About_#1: Kim Hyoung-nyon is cofounder and executive vice president of Dunamu, which operates South Korea's dominant cryptocurrency exchange.
About_#2: In September 2021, Dunamu raised $85 million at a valuation of $8.7 billion.
About_#3: Its investors include Kakao Ventures and Silicon Valley-based venture capital firm Altos Ventures.
About_#4: Before starting Dunamu with Song Chi-hyung, Kim worked at local mobile payment company Danal.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Ural Polytechnic Institute
About_#1: Andrei Kozitsyn is CEO of Ural Mining Metallurgical Company, one of the top Russian producers of commodities like copper, zinc, coal and gold.
About_#2: Kozitsyn grew up in the Urals, where he studied metallurgy and later went to work as a mechanic at Uralelectromed, now UMMC's main factory.
About_#3: Kozitsyn cofounded UMMC with Iskander Makhmudov, who is the group's president and his longtime partner.
About_#4: In January 2019, UGMK opened the Korova (Cow) restaurant in the elite district of Yekaterinburg.
Did You Know?: President and sponsor of KHL hockey club named Avtomobilist, Kozitsyn plans to build an ice arena with 15,000 seats in Ekaterinburg in 2022.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Imperial College London; Master of Business Administration, London Business School
About_#1: Thomas Kwok is the second-oldest son of the founder of Sun Hung Kai Properties, the largest developer in Hong Kong.
About_#2: He was co-chairman from 2011 until 2014, when he was sentenced to five years in prison for bribery. He was released in 2019.
About_#3: In Thomas's absence his son Adam has served as an executive director for the company.
About_#4: Kwok and his two brothers, Raymond and Walter (d. 2018) inherited the publicly traded company after the death of their father, Kwok Tak-seng, in 1990.
In Their Own Words: "It means so much to me that I could see you last week, with all three brothers holding hands in unity," jailed Thomas wrote in the memorial book at Walter's funeral in 2018.

About_#1: Real estate mogul David Lichtenstein first racked up $89,000 in credit card debt to purchase a two-story, multi-family home in New Jersey in 1986.
About_#2: Today his Lightstone Group oversees some 23,000 rental units across 120 properties across 28 states.
About_#3: Lightstone is also developing a new brand of millenial-focused city hotels with Marriott, called Moxy. Its Times Square location opened in 2017.
About_#4: In 2007 he paid $7.4 billion in debt and $200 million in equity for Extended Stay America, a chain of mid-priced hotels.
Did You Know?: The son of Brooklyn public school teachers, Lichtenstein never went to college.
In Their Own Words: You don't have to be too bright to get into real estate.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School
About_#1: Kaspi is Kazakhstan's largest payments and fintech ecosystem with over 7 million monthly users.
About_#2: In October 2020 the group listed on the London Stock Exchange with a $6.5 billion valuation.
About_#3: Kaspi earned $515 million in net income on $1.3 billion in revenue in 2019.
About_#4: The IPO was the largest London listing by a company from Kazakhstan since 2007.

About_#1: Yusaku Maezawa founded Japan's largest online fashion mall, Zozotown, in May 1998. Its parent company, Zozo, is listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
About_#2: In September 2019, Maezawa announced that he was resigning as CEO and selling most of his stake to Yahoo Japan in a deal worth more than $2.3 billion.
About_#3: Maezawa got his start selling CDs and records of his favorite bands by mail from his home.
About_#4: He collects modern art and plans to build a museum to display it in Chiba, east of Tokyo.
Did You Know?: In 2017, he paid $110.5 million for Jean-Michel Basquiat's 1982 painting "Untitled," a new record for the artist.

About_#1: Katarina Martinson and her sister Louise Lindh each own a 14% stake in their family's investment outfit L.E. Lundbergforetagen AB.
About_#2: The company holds interests in property management and a variety of other investments, including a pulp and paper company.
About_#3: Both sisters have board seats in the group companies along with their father Fredrik Lundberg.
About_#4: The company was founded by their paternal grandfather Lars in 1944 as a construction outfit. Fredrik took over management of the firm in 1981.
Did You Know?: Martinson reportedly spent roughly $15 million in 2017 on a townhouse in central Stockholm, one of the most expensive house ever sold in Sweden.

Education: Bachelor of Commerce, University of Bologna
About_#1: Romano Minozzi is the founder and president of Iris Ceramica Group, a ceramics multinational based in central Italy.
About_#2: Minozzi derives most of his wealth from his stock holdings in Snam and Italgas, two publicly traded natural gas companies in Italy.
About_#3: Minozzi cofounded Iris Group in 1961.
About_#4: While he still serves as the president of Iris Group, his daughter Federica is the CEO.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, Los Angeles
About_#1: Pedro Moreira Salles is a member of one of Brazil's oldest banking families.
About_#2: His late father, Walther Moreira Salles, was the founder of Unibanco and a former ambassador to the United States.
About_#3: In 2008 Unibanco merged with Itau, one of Brazil's largest commercial banks, creating Itau-Unibanco, the largest private sector bank in Latin America.
About_#4: Moreira Salles and his three brothers, all billionaires, also own stakes in CBMM, the world's leading supplier of the mineral niobium.
In Their Own Words: Leaders have to know how to tolerate mistakes.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Leningrad Technological Institute
About_#1: Alexander Nesis got his start in the late 1980s using uranium production waste from a mine in Uzbekistan to produce and sell rare-earth metals.
About_#2: Nesis later founded his investment holding company ICT Group, which at one point had a stake in gold and silver producer Polymetal.
About_#3: The company also had stakes in railcar maker United Wagon and Nomos Bank.
About_#4: In 2013, he sold most of his stake in Nomos Bank and became co-owner of Otkritie Bank, which was nationalized in 2017.

About_#1: Nguyen Dang Quang invested in commercial bank Techcombank in 1993 and later founded Masan Group with business partner, Ho Hung Anh, in 2004.
About_#2: Masan Group has interests in a wide range of consumer and food product businesses, ranging from animal feeds to food processing.
About_#3: While Ho Hung Anh, who is chairman of Techcombank, is in charge of the bank, Nguyen is focused on building Masan Group as its chairman.
About_#4: In 2021, Masan Group's revenue increased 15% to $4 billion.
Did You Know?: Nguyen Dang Quang belongs to the wave of Vietnamese students who studied in Russia and Eastern Europe in the 1980s, after the Vietnam War.

About_#1: Late Indonesian billionaire Eka Tjipta Widjaja's son, Oei Hong Leong, is a Singapore citizen and longtime resident of the island-state.
About_#2: The bulk of his wealth is derived from a corporate bond portfolio and real estate assets.
About_#3: In July 2019, Oei won a four-year legal battle against Canadian property firm Concord Pacific Group, over his prime waterfront property in Vancouver. He's planning a mixed-use development there.
About_#4: He sold his entire stake in Raffles Education in 2021 after differences with its founder.
Did You Know?: Oei is an avid collector of Buddhist art and has a private museum in Singapore with more than 50,000 items.

About_#1: Nihat Ozdemir and his billionaire partner, Sezai Bacaksiz, met as students at Gazi University and founded Limak Construction in 1976.
About_#2: Besides being contractor for some of the world's largest infrastructure projects, Limak has operations in energy, tourism, transportation and cement.
About_#3: It's part of a consortium building Istanbul's new airport. When all phases are complete, it will be the world's largest based on passenger capacity.
About_#4: Limak is a major builder and operator of hydroelectric power plants, ranking among Turkey's top ten electricity producers.
Did You Know?: As an academic at what is now Gazi University, Ozdemir was for a short while assistant to Necmettin Erbakan, who went on to become minister of Turkey.

About_#1: Gretel Packer is the elder sister of fellow billionaire James Packer.
About_#2: She became a billionaire after James split their family estate 10 years after the 2005 death of their father, media mogul Kerry Packer.
About_#3: Famously low-profile, she was the driving force behind the establishment of the $160 million National Philanthropic Fund in 2014.
About_#4: The fund is supported by the family's Crown Resorts and the Packer Family Foundation, which she chairs.

Education: Jiangsu Province Wujin Teacher School
About_#1: Pan "Benjamin" Zhengmin is CEO of miniaturized electronics components firm AAC Technologies.
About_#2: Pan and his wife Ingrid cofounded AAC in 1993. It now makes speakers, receivers, microphones and antennas, often used in smartphones.
About_#3: AAC, whose customers include Apple, went public in Hong Kong in 2005.
About_#4: Pan graduated from the Jiangsu Province Wujin Teacher School in 1987.

Education: Doctorate, Dniepropetrovsk Metallurgical Institute
About_#1: Viktor Pinchuk used his Ph.D. in pipe design to found Interpipe, producer of steel products, in 1990.
About_#2: Already devastated by the annexation of Crimea in 2014, Interpipe halted production and exports in late February 2022 after the invasion began.
About_#3: Pinchuk owns Grand Buildings, a landmark historical building on Trafalgar Square in London.
About_#4: He is a son-in-law of Ukraine's former president Leonid Kuchma.
Did You Know?: Pinchuk sponsors an annual lunch on Ukraine at the World Economic Forum at Davos.
In Their Own Words: I do not hide my wealth, but I do not show it off, and most importantly I try to use it for improving society. The more you own, the more you can do for your country.

Education: Master of Science, Russian State Academy of Management; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Simferopol State University
About_#1: Alexander Ponomarenko is chairman of the board of Sheremetyevo, the biggest airport in Russia.
About_#2: Ponomarenko was sanctioned by the EU and the U.K. in March 2022; he has disputed the sanctions.
About_#3: Ponomarenko and partner Alexander Skorobogatko started out with sea ports and banking and then moved into airport construction.
About_#4: In 2013 the two, with Arkady Rotenberg, a judo partner of President Vladimir Putin, won a tender to develop Sheremetyevo, the state-owned airport.
Did You Know?: In 2011 Ponomarenko paid $350 million for a complex of buildings and land near the Black Sea known as Putin's Palace. He later sold it to Arkady Rotenberg.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Zhejiang University
About_#1: Qi Jinxing is the chairman of Hangzhou Binjiang Real Estate Group, a real estate developer headquartered in Hangzhou.
About_#2: Qi got his first job in a government district office before moving on to a management position at a construction firm.
About_#3: In 1996 he turned down a bigger government position to set up Hangzhou Binjiang.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Larry Robbins is founder and CEO of Glenview Capital Management, a New York hedge fund that oversees some $7 billion in assets.
About_#2: Robbins is known for his hot and cold streaks, with his returns swinging wildly from one year to the next.
About_#3: Through his Robbins Family Foundation, he is an active supporter of education reform both in New York City and on the national level.
About_#4: In 2017, Robbins began serving as chairman of the Robin Hood Foundation, which fights poverty in New York City.
Did You Know?: Robbins named his firm Glenview after the town outside Chicago where his childhood hockey team practiced.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Ashland University
About_#1: Dwight Schar is the chairman of Virginia-based NVR, one of the largest homebuilders in the United States, with nearly $9 billion in annual revenue.
About_#2: He founded NVHomes in 1980 and borrowed big to acquire his former employer and competitor, Ryan Homes, in 1987. The combined company was called NVR.
About_#3: NVR declared bankruptcy in 1992, but reorganized and recovered the next year. Today, the company builds homes in 14 states.
About_#4: Schar bought a minority stake in the NFL's Washington Redskins (now called Washington Commanders) in 2003 for $200 million.
Did You Know?: Schar has sold over $1 billion of NVR stock since 2003.

About_#1: Sun Hongjun chairs Shanghai Awinic Technology, a supplier of chips used in mobile phones.
About_#2: Awinic customers include mobile phone companies Oppo, Vivo, Lenovo and Xiaomi.
About_#3: Sun worked as an engineer at China telecommunications giant Huawei earlier in his career.

Education: Bachelor of Commerce, Bangalore University
About_#1: Anand Surana is a director at the $588 million (revenue) pharma company Micro Labs.
About_#2: The Bangalore-headquartered generics company makes drugs for cardiac diseases, diabetes and pain management.
About_#3: The privately held Micro Labs gets nearly 60% of its annual revenue from the domestic market.
About_#4: It also makes ophthalmic products for Bausch & Lomb's Asia-Pacific market.
Did You Know?: The company was founded by their late father G.C. Surana, a former pharma distributor, in 1973 in Chennai.

Education: Bachelor of Commerce, Bangalore University
About_#1: Dilip Surana chairs the $588 million (revenue) pharma company Micro Labs.
About_#2: The Bangalore-headquartered generics company makes drugs for cardiac diseases, diabetes and pain management.
About_#3: It also makes ophthalmic products for Bausch & Lomb's Asia-Pacific market.
About_#4: The privately held company gets nearly 60% of its annual revenue of from the domestic market.
Did You Know?: The company was founded by their late father G.C. Surana, a former pharma distributor, in 1973 in Chennai.

About_#1: Djoko Susanto is the founder of Alfamart, which has more than 19,000 convenience stores across Indonesia and more than 1,200 stores in the Philippines.
About_#2: The sixth of 10 siblings, he started managing his parents' modest food stall inside a traditional market in Jakarta at age 17.
About_#3: He later partnered with clove cigarette tycoon Putera Sampoerna to open similar stalls and then a discount supermarket chain.
About_#4: When Putera sold his cigarette business to Philip Morris in 2005, Susanto bought the retail business and developed it into the Alfamart chain.
Did You Know?: His daughter Feny and sons, Budiyanto and Harryanto, hold senior positions at Alfamart.

About_#1: Alain Taravella is chairman and CEO of Altarea Cogedim, France's third-largest real estate development firm.
About_#2: Headquartered in Paris, the firm also operates in Spain and Italy and boasts a shopping center portfolio and $1.3 billion in revenue.
About_#3: Taravella co-founded the firm as Altarea SA in 1994 and retains 45% ownership of the group.
About_#4: Taravella took the firm public in 2004 and three years later acquired Cogedim to form Altarea Cogedim Group.

Education: Diploma, University of Erlangen
About_#1: Martin Viessmann is chairman of the executive board of Viessmann Group, a German manufacturer of heating, refrigeration and climate-control equipment.
About_#2: He is the grandson of founder Johann Viessmann. The private company has 12,000 employees and 23 production divisions in 12 countries.
About_#3: Martin envisions a world where CO2 emissions are reduced by 80% and the consumption of fossil energy by two-thirds.
About_#4: In 2012, the firm received the Energy Globe Award for Sustainability in the "Air" category. In 2013, Martin was named Greentech Manager of the Year.
Did You Know?: Viessmann Group is a prominent sponsor of winter sports and underwrites the Viessmann Academy, which provides training for heating architects and engineers.
In Their Own Words: Everything we do for sustainability is the result of teamwork. Together, we are convinced that we can only keep up our standard of living and protect natural resources for future generations if we act sustainably.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, University of Rhode Island
About_#1: Georg von Opel's Hansa AG has diverse holdings in real estate, public companies and private equity, including investments in renewable energy.
About_#2: Hansa owns 96% of investment company Athris AG, which went public on the Bern Stock Exchange in June 2018.
About_#3: Von Opel, an heir to the Opel automotive fortune, sold his energy firm GVO Wind to a Malaysian investment fund in March 2018.
About_#4: His private real estate includes properties in England (London and Hampshire), the Spanish island Majorca and the Engadine region in the Swiss Alps.
Did You Know?: Georg is the great-grandson of Adam Opel, the pioneering namesake of the German car company.

About_#1: Wang Chaobin chairs the Zhonglu Group, one of the largest non-government real estate owners in the central Chinese city of Zhengzhou.
About_#2: Son George is heir apparent.
About_#3: The Wang Chaobin Charitable Foundation in Zhenzhou provides financial support for disaster relief, cultural exchanges, education and other fields.

Education: Master of Arts/Science, National Central University; Bachelor of Business Administration, National Taiwan University
About_#1: Wang started athletic-gear-maker Feng Tay Enterprises in 1971. Eight years later it formed a partnership to make sports shoes for Nike.
About_#2: Other clients include Cole Haan, Dr. Martens and Converse. Over the years it's expanded into soccer balls, inline skates and ice-hockey equipment.
About_#3: Headquartered in the western Taiwan county of Yunlin, Feng Tay operates plants in mainland China, India, Indonesia and Vietnam, as well as Taiwan.
About_#4: Wang's older son Richard took over for him as chairman in 2018. Younger son Kevin became vice chairman in 2017.

About_#1: Wei Yin-Heng and his three brothers -- Ing-Chou, Yin-Chun and Ying-Chiao -- started Tingyi in 1991.
About_#2: Tingyi is now a big producer of ready-to-drink tea and bottled water in China, and it supplies half of the country's instant-noodle market.
About_#3: The family also controls the Dicos fried-chicken chain.
About_#4: The family's private company, Ting Hsin, sold its 37.17% stake in Taipei 101, Taiwan's tallest building, to Itochu for $665 million in July 2018.

Education: Drop Out, Auburn University
About_#1: David Zalik is the cofounder and CEO of financial technology company GreenSky.
About_#2: The Atlanta-based company has facilitated $16 billion in loans for home improvement projects via a network of banks and 13,000 contractors.
About_#3: GreenSky has also begun to branch into financing for doctor, dentist and veterinary visits.
About_#4: Zalik took the $415 million (sales) company public in May 2018.
Did You Know?: Zalik started his first business at the age of 14, buying computer parts from distributors and assembling them himself.
In Their Own Words: We've kept a truly maniacal focus on the product. And maniacal is the right word.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, New York University; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Western State University College of Law
About_#1: In late 2017 Leslie Alexander sold the Houston Rockets NBA team to Tilman Fertitta for $2.2 billion, 25 times what bought it for.
About_#2: Alexander paid $85 million for the Rockets in 1993, just before Hakeem Olajuwon led the team to NBA titles in the next two seasons.
About_#3: He debuted on the Forbes 400 in 2006 due to his stake in student loans securitizer First Marblehead, though the Rockets proved a better investment.
About_#4: Alexander started building his fortune by trading bonds after dropping out of Brooklyn Law School.
Did You Know?: Alexander dropped out of Brooklyn Law School at age 21 after his father died and headed to Wall Street to help provide for his mother.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Ekaterinburg Institute of Economics
About_#1: Igor Altushkin is the founder and largest shareholder of the Russian Copper Company (RMK), Russia's third-largest copper producer.
About_#2: He started his career as a scrap metal trader in the early 1990s.
About_#3: Altushkin, who has six children, is a key supporter of the Russian Orthodox Church.
About_#4: In May 2017, Altushkin was awarded the Order of Friendship by Vladimir Putin.
Did You Know?: Altushkin owns one of Madonna's former homes in London.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Pontificia Universidad de Chile
About_#1: Roberto Angelini Rossi heads one of Chile's largest investment groups, Inversiones Angelini.
About_#2: The group was previously headed by Roberto's uncle, Anacleto Angelini, who died in 2007.
About_#3: Its biggest holding is publicly traded Antarchile, which distributes fuel, operates fishing and shipping firms and invests in energy and forestry.
About_#4: He also owns stakes in agribusiness firm Siemel and commercial fishing outfit Nutravalor, formerly called Eperva.
In Their Own Words: Businessmen are never allowed to say 'I'm done.' We can never sit down to see what happens. There is constant evolution... We must provide orientation to our companies and keep expanding and innovating.

About_#1: Nigel Austin is the founder and majority owner of the Cotton On clothing and stationery group. Its brands include Cotton On, Supre, Factorie and Typo.
About_#2: His company has grown rapidly in the past few years, expanding to 1,450 stores in 18 countries and estimated sales of $1.5 billion in 2017.
About_#3: About half of these stores are in Australia, while the other half are spread across countries including Singapore, South Africa and the U.S.
About_#4: Founded in 1991, Austin started selling acid-washed denim jackets from the trunk of his car in his hometown southwest of Melbourne.
Did You Know?: Austin's late father, Grant Austin, ran a publicly traded clothing wholesale and import business called the Austin Group, where Austin would spend school holidays working.
In Their Own Words: There was plenty of tough love. My family had a very successful business, but I was limited with resources when I went to college. I was forced to go out there and have a strong work ethic.

About_#1: Bang Jun-hyuk is the chairman of South Korea's largest mobile-gaming company, Netmarble, which he founded in 2000.
About_#2: He's built Netmarble into a $2 billion gaming empire with its action-packed role-playing games that have become hits across Asia and the U.S.
About_#3: In May 2017, he took the company public, raising $2.4 billion in what became South Korea's largest listing in seven years.
Did You Know?: A high school dropout, Bang is an outlier among the country's richest tech entrepreneurs who typically boast pedigrees from elite universities.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: O. Francis Biondi cofounded hedge fund King Street Capital Management in 1995 with fellow First Boston alum Brian Higgins.
About_#2: King Street Capital Management oversees about $20 billion in assets and focuses on out-of-favor investments in stocks and bonds.
About_#3: Biondi retired from King Street in 2020, but kept his ownership stake in the firm.
Did You Know?: Biondi and Higgins also run the King Street Charitable Trust, whose grant recipients include his alma mater Yale, Memorial Sloan Kettering and others.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, KAIST; Master of Arts/Science, KAIST; Ph.D, KAIST
About_#1: Chang Byung-gyu is chairman of online gaming company Krafton (formerly known as Bluehole), which he founded in 2007.
About_#2: In 2018 Tencent invested more than $500 million in the company for a 10% stake, catapulting Bluehole to unicorn status overnight.
About_#3: Its shooter game, PlayerUnknown's Battlegrounds, broke a world record in 2017 after posting $100 million in pre-release sales in just 79 days.
In Their Own Words: Masterpieces are created through enduring painful and patient processes.

Education: Bachelor of Science, University of Southern California
About_#1: Chang Kuo-Ming is the second son of shipping tycoon Chang Yung Fa, who died in 2016 at the age of 88.
About_#2: In 1968 Yung Fa founded Evergreen Marine, now one of the world's largest transportation companies.
About_#3: Brothers Kuo-Hua, Kuo-Ming and Kuo-Cheng also inherited stakes in EVA Airways and hotels in Taiwan, mainland China, Paris and Bangkok.

About_#1: Chen is chairman and founder of Shanghai Aiko Solar Energy, which established in 2009.
About_#2: Aiko Solar, founded in 2009, sells solar cells globally.
About_#3: The company manufacturers cells in Foshan, Yiwu and Tianjin.

About_#1: Chen Liying cofounded Yunda Express, one of China's biggest logistics companies, in Shanghai in 1999.
About_#2: Yunda Express went public through a reverse merger on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in December 2016.
About_#3: Chen owns roughly 21% of the listed company Yunda Holding, and serves as vice chairman.
About_#4: Husband Nie Tengyun is a fellow billionaire and chairman of Yunda Holding.

About_#1: A Cambridge law graduate, Mark Coombs started his career at Australia and New Zealand Banking Group.
About_#2: He founded investment manager Ashmore as a new division of the company in 1998, then led a buyout a year later and took it public in 2006.
About_#3: The London-based firm specializes in emerging markets and manages nearly $90 billion in assets.
About_#4: Combs reportedly lives in a modest home in Wimbledon bought before becoming a billionaire.

About_#1: Tench Coxe has served on the board of chip designer Nvidia since 1993, accumulating enough stock (as compensation) to become a billionaire.
About_#2: Coxe is the third largest individual shareholder at Nvidia, behind founder Jensen Huang and fellow board member Mark Stevens.
About_#3: Coxe spent more than three decades at venture capital firm Sutter Hill Ventures, serving as a managing director from 1989 to 2020.
About_#4: As of late 2021 he also owned about 1% of shares of software firm Snowflake, in which Sutter Hill was the earliest investor.

About_#1: Dutch entertainment mogul John de Mol is one of the biggest names in reality TV.
About_#2: With Joop van den Ende, he founded Endemol, the company responsible for international hits "Deal or No Deal," "Fear Factor" and "Big Brother."
About_#3: De Mol sold Endemol for $5.3 billion to Spanish telecom giant Telefonica in 2000.
About_#4: In 2015, he sold most of his Talpa Media, creator of hit shows like "The Voice," to British ITV for an initial cash payment of $545 million.
Did You Know?: Endemol is the world's largest independent producer, with more than 800 productions in 76 territories airing on 295 channels around the world.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Fundacao Getulio Vargas; Bachelor of Engineering, Instituto Maua de Tecnologia
About_#1: Alfredo Egydio de Arruda Villela Filho is a member of one of Brazil's oldest banking families.
About_#2: His great-grandfather founded the bank Itau, which merged with Unibanco in 2008 to form Itau-Unibanco, Brazil's biggest private sector bank.
About_#3: He is the largest individual shareholder of Itausa, the bank's holding company, with a 12% stake.
About_#4: His grandfather founded Duratex, a publicly-traded Brazilian maker of wood paneling and bathroom fixtures; he owns a stake in the company.

About_#1: Ibrahim Erdemoglu and his brother, Ali, together own over 75% of a top producer of materials used in carpet, SASA Polyester.
About_#2: They initially acquired 51% of SASA in 2015 for $102 million, then added to their stake in the publicly traded company and watched it soar in value.
About_#3: The brothers' Erdemoglu Holding also includes the two privately held companies, Merinos Carpet and Dinarsu Carpet.
About_#4: In 1970, their father, Mehmet Erdemoglu, along with family members, started Merinos with two rug-weaving looms.
Did You Know?: SASA has a $935 million licensing and technical service agreement with Invista, a subsidiary of Koch Industries that makes chemicals, polymers, fabrics and fibers.
In Their Own Words: My biggest hobby is my job.

About_#1: Philip Fayer is chairman and CEO of Nuvei Corp.; he founded the predecessor to the payment processor company in 2003.
About_#2: The Montreal based firm process payments in over 150 currencies, with clients ranging from online casinos to e-commerce platforms.
About_#3: He took Nuvei, which has over 50,000 customers, public on the Toronto Stock Exchange in September 2020.
About_#4: The IPO raised $700 million, which was then the highest amount raised by a tech company in Toronto Stock Exchange's history.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Baylor University
About_#1: Oil refiner Tesoro bought Paul Foster's Western Refining for $6.4 billion in 2017; the combined company was renamed Andeavor.
About_#2: In April 2018, Marathon announced it would buy Andeavor for $23.3 billion; the deal later closed in October.
About_#3: As a teenager Paul Foster got his start in the oil fields, welding pipes, digging ditches, and cleaning tanks.
About_#4: A graduate of Baylor University and a registered CPA, Foster handled the books for small oil refineries across the Southwest.
Did You Know?: Foster is a vice chairman of the University of Texas System Board of Regents.
In Their Own Words: I like to think of it not so much as rolling with the punches but rolling with the opportunities.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Florida Southern College
About_#1: James France inherited an estimated 36% of Nascar, the stock-car racing business founded in 1948 by his father, William France Sr.
About_#2: He has sat on Nascar's board of directors since 2000.
About_#3: Viewership is down, but the business remains afloat due to 10-year TV deals with Fox and NBC, worth $8.2 billion in rights, that began in 2015.
About_#4: France also serves as chairman of Nascar's sister company, publicly traded International Speedway Corp, which operates 13 racetracks.
Did You Know?: His niece Lesa France Kennedy is International Speedway's CEO, while nephew Brian France is Nascar's chief executive.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Nihon University
About_#1: Yasuhiro Fukushima founded gaming software firm Enix, which merged with rival Square in 2003 to become Square Enix.
About_#2: The Tokyo-listed company made its mark with its Final Fantasy franchise and its Dragon Quest series.
About_#3: He currently serves as the honorary chairman of Square Enix Holdings.
About_#4: The company's much-awaited game, the Triangle Strategy for Nintendo Switch was released in March 2022.

Education: Ph.D, Michigan State University
About_#1: Gan is cofounder and chairman of Shanghai-listed Gan & Lee Pharmaceuticals.
About_#2: Founded in 1998, Gan & Lee Pharmaceuticals produces insulin and injection pens and is publicly traded.
About_#3: Gan graduated from Peking University and later became a teacher in the biology department.
About_#4: Gan holds a PhD from Michigan State University and worked for Merck before he founded Gan & Lee.

About_#1: Rahul Gautam is the chairman and managing director of Sheela Foam, best known for its Sleepwell brand of mattresses.
About_#2: The business was set up his late mother Sheela Gautam in 1971.
About_#3: The $330 million (revenue) company was listed in 2016.
About_#4: Sheela Foam has 10 factories in India, three in Australia and one in Spain.
Did You Know?: Gautam's son Tushaar heads research for the company.

Education: Ph.D, KTH Royal Institute of Technology; Master of Business Administration, Mid Sweden University; Master of Science in Engineering, Mid Sweden University
About_#1: Ali Ghodsi is cofounder and CEO of software startup Databricks, valued at $38 billion in August 2021. Investors include cloud giants Microsoft and Amazon.
About_#2: After a career in academia, Ghodsi cofounded Databricks with six UC Berkeley academics who built the popular analytics engine Apache Spark.
About_#3: Databricks is built on top of Spark and uses AI to power, in Ghodsi's words, a "data lakehouse" that helps companies store and utilize their data.
About_#4: Ghodsi was tapped to lead Databricks in 2016 amid company struggles to generate revenue; initially, he had joined in 2013 as a part-time engineer.
In Their Own Words: I grew up in a war. If you?re seeing people die on the streets as a kid, you know anything can change at any given time.

About_#1: Giammaria Giuliani is a healthcare investor who owns a 4% stake in Royalty Pharma, the world's largest acquirer of pharmaceutical royalties.
About_#2: Royalty Pharma went public in 2020 and has collected revenue slices of blockbuster drugs like Humira, Imbruvica, Lyrica and Xtandi.
About_#3: Giammaria and his brother Mario also own stakes in Swiss investment company HBM Healthcare Investments and a number of biotech firms in the U.S.
About_#4: The brothers share ownership of their family's pharmaceutical company, Giuliani, founded by their great-grandfather Germano in Milan, Italy in 1889.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Trinity University
About_#1: Christopher "Kit" Goldsbury's fortune comes from selling salsa maker Pace Foods to Campbell Soup for $1.12 billion in 1994.
About_#2: Goldsbury worked on the assembly line at Pace in 1969, two years after marrying founder David Pace's daughter Linda. He became president in 1977.
About_#3: After Goldsbury and Linda separated in 1987, Goldsbury purchased her half for $95 million, a fraction of what he sold it for seven years later.
About_#4: The San Antonio billionaire is backing the revitalization of the downtown Pearl neighborhood through his private equity firm Silver Ventures.
In Their Own Words: "I was raised in Mexico, so I had a lot of influence in that area, with the food, with the people, everything."

About_#1: Alexandre Grendene Bartelle and his twin brother Pedro Grendene Bartelle cofounded Grendene, one of the world's largest sandal makers.
About_#2: In 2013, he stepped down as Grendene's CEO, but has remained as the company's chairman.
About_#3: He owns 41% of Grendene, which trades on the Sao Paulo exchange.
About_#4: Alexandre Grendene Bartelle has investments in various industries, from steel to ethanol production and petrochemicals.

About_#1: Surjit Kumar Gupta gets his fortune from his stake in Havells India, a company founded by his late brother-in-law, Qimat Rai Gupta.
About_#2: Havells sells a range of electrical products such as fans and lights as well as consumer durables, such as air conditioners and water heaters.
About_#3: Gupta used to work at the company but now has a board seat as a non-executive director.
About_#4: His son, Ameet, is also a director and oversees new projects and new product roll-outs.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Villanova University
About_#1: Brian Higgins is the cofounder of King Street Capital Management, a distressed-debt focused hedge fund.
About_#2: He started King Street in 1995 with fellow billionaire O. Francis Biondi, whom he met on First Boston's high-yield desk in the late 1980's.
About_#3: King Street Capital Management oversees about $20 billion.
Did You Know?: He and cofounder Francis Biondi manage the King Street Charitable Trust, which donates to medical research and Villanova, Higgins' alma mater, among others.

About_#1: David Hindawi cofounded cybersecurity firm Tanium with his son Orion in 2007.
About_#2: Tanium has raised $800 million from investors who valued it at $6.5 billion in October 2018.
About_#3: In February 2016, Orion took over as CEO from his father. David is executive chairman.
About_#4: David, now a U.S. citizen, was born in Baghdad, grew up in Israel, and went to UC Berkeley for a Ph.D. in operations research.

About_#1: Hu Chengzhong is the chairman of China Delixi Holding Group.
About_#2: The group's diversified interests include mining, transportation, environmental engineering and real estate.
About_#3: The group has 21,000 employees.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Minnesota
About_#1: Veteran media mogul Stanley Hubbard helms Hubbard Broadcasting, which owns 13 TV stations and 45 radio stations across the U.S.
About_#2: Founded by Hubbard's father in 1925, the Minnesota-based company has expanded its portfolio to include cable network Reelz and a stake in PodcastOne.
About_#3: Hubbard grew up with the family business, working as prop person at 17, a photojournalist in college and later moving into management.
About_#4: Hubbard Broadcasting has donated more than half a million dollars to Republican causes. Hubbard himself donated to President Trump's campaign in 2016.
Did You Know?: Hubbard played hockey for the University of Minnesota.

About_#1: Hui Lin Chit was running a garment factory in the 1980s when he decided to enter the sanitary napkins market.
About_#2: Hengan International leads the market in China despite competition from global giants such as Procter & Gamble, Johnson & Johnson and Kimberly-Clark.
About_#3: Hui, who cofounded the company with Sze Man Bok (also a bllionaire), is Hengan's CEO.

About_#1: Hal Jackman and his family are the largest shareholders of E-L Financial Corporation, a Toronto investment and insurance holding company.
About_#2: His father, former Parliament member Harry Jackman, built a financial services empire, which Hal continued to expand over his decades at the helm.
About_#3: His son, Duncan, now runs the business as chief executive officer, president and chairman of E-L Financial.
About_#4: Jackman followed in his father's footsteps into politics, serving as the 25th lieutenant governor of Ontario from 1991 to 1997.
Did You Know?: Jackman was chancellor of his alma mater, The University of Toronto, from 1997 to 2003.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Cornell University; Master of Business Administration, Harvard University; Master of Arts, The University of Chicago
About_#1: Stephen Jarislowsky made the bulk of his fortune at the helm of Jarislowsky Fraser, the investment management firm he founded in 1955.
About_#2: He stepped down as CEO in 2012 but remains chairman emeritus of the company and president of the Jarislowsky Foundation.
About_#3: Canadian bank Scotiabank bought Jarislowsky Fraser for about $750 million in stock and cash in April 2018.
About_#4: He owns a sizable art collection that is largely comprised of Canadian art, but also includes Chinese jade and French impressionism.
Did You Know?: Jarislowsky owns the 2,000-acre Marina Island in the Strait of Georgia near Vancouver.
In Their Own Words: My wife and I have always lived like anybody else. We have not lived like rich people. We have no plane. We have no yacht. I drive my car; I don't have a chauffeur. I do the dishes every evening myself.

About_#1: Robyn and Mark Jones are the cofounders of Goosehead Insurance, where Mark is chairman and CEO, and Robyn is vice chairman.
About_#2: The Alberta natives were teenage sweethearts and married each other straight out of high school.
About_#3: Robyn raised their six children while Mark, who was once a truck driver, went to college, attended Harvard Business School and consulted at Bain.
About_#4: Frustrated with her husband's lifestyle, Robyn started a property and casualty insurance agency in 2003. Mark left Bain in 2004 to join the business.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University
About_#1: George Joseph is the founder of Mercury General, an insurance provider with $3.5 billion in annual revenues.
About_#2: After raising $2 million in capital, he started Mercury General in 1962 and offered cut-rate deals to safer-than-average drivers.
About_#3: He owns 34% of the publicly-traded insurance firm, which offers automotive, home and fire insurance.
About_#4: Raised in the midst of the Great Depression, Joseph was a flight navigator during World War II.
Did You Know?: Joseph named the company after the Roman god Mercury, because he wanted the company to be nimble in business ventures.
In Their Own Words: I learned a long time ago that if you're not active in politics, then you can't create change that benefits the consumer.

Source of Wealth: shapewear, cosmetics, reality TV, Self Made
About_#1: Kim Kardashian has parlayed reality TV stardom into a ten-figure fortune, selling a mobile game, cosmetics and shapewear.
About_#2: A large portion of her wealth comes from her stakes in KKW Beauty, her cosmetics and fragrance company, and Skims, her shapewear business.
About_#3: Kardashian sold 20% of KKW Beauty to publicly traded Coty in 2020 for $200 million.
About_#4: Skims raised $240 million in January 2022 from firms led by the likes of billionaires Stephen Mandel and Josh Kushner, doubling its valuation to $3.2 billion in less than a year.
Did You Know?: Kardashian is an advocate for criminal justice reform, gun safety and cancer causes.
In Their Own Words: I do feel like success is the best revenge.

Education: Master, University of Poznan
About_#1: Dominika and her brother Sebastian inherited a fortune from their father Jan, who died in 2015 from complications of minor heart surgery.
About_#2: The siblings divvied up the estate in 2018, with Dominika getting most of the cash from the family's 2016 sale of its SAB Miller stake.
About_#3: She also took over the stake in renewable energy outfit Polenergia and now chairs its supervisory board.
About_#4: With her parents, she started the Kulczyk Foundation in 2013, which fights discrimination and inequality that affects women around the world.
Did You Know?: Dominika Kulczyk has her own tv-show "Efekt Domina" that is tied to her charity work.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: After a stint at Goldman Sachs' risk arbitrage department, Edward Lampert founded hedge fund ESL Investments in 1988, betting on undervalued stocks.
About_#2: He took over as CEO of struggling retail giant Sears Holdings (Sears, Kmart, Kenmore) in 2013 with hopes of a turnaround, but failed miserably.
About_#3: ILampert's ESL Investments promised Sears nearly $1 billion in loans in the first 10 months of 2017.
About_#4: In October 2018, Sears Holdings filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy and announced that it would close 142 Sears and Kmart stores.
Did You Know?: Lampert survived a kidnapping in 2003; his captors released him after two days.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Clark University; Doctor of Jurisprudence, New York Law School
About_#1: Marc Lasry and his sister Sonia founded Avenue Capital Management in 1995 with $7 million in funding from friends and family.
About_#2: The firm manages about $10 billion in assets and focuses on distressed and undervalued securities.
About_#3: Lasry was born in Morocco and moved to the U.S. at age 7 with his family, sharing a bedroom with his 2 siblings for a decade.
About_#4: He is a major supporter of the Democratic Party, having raised funds for President Obama and candidate Hilary Clinton in the past.
Did You Know?: In August 2017, his daughter Sophie married Alex Swieca, the son of a cofounder of hedge fund Highbridge Capital.

About_#1: Michiel Le Roux of South Africa founded Capitec Bank in 2001 and owns about an 11% stake.
About_#2: The bank, which trades on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange, targets South Africa's emerging middle class.
About_#3: He served as chairman of the board of Capitec from 2007 to 2016 and has continued on as a board member.
About_#4: Le Roux previously ran Boland Bank, a small regional bank in Cape Town's hinterland.
Did You Know?: Fellow South African Jannie Mouton's PSG Group owns a 30% stake in Capitec Bank.

About_#1: Peter Leibinger owns 29.4% of the world's largest manufacturer of machine tools, TRUMPF.
About_#2: The company traces its roots to 1923 when Christian Trumpf acquired a machine shop in Stuttgart.
About_#3: Peter's father, Berthold Leibinger, joined the company in 1961 and developed the first contour "nibbling" machine tool with numerical control.
About_#4: Christian Trumpf, who had no children, chose Berthold as his successor and handed over control of the company to him in 1972.
Did You Know?: Peter studied mechanical engineering at RWTH University in Aachen, Germany, and worked as an engineer at Ingersoll Milling Machine Company, in Rockford, IL.

About_#1: Regine Leibinger owns 29.4% of the world's largest manufacturer of machine tools, TRUMPF.
About_#2: The company traces its roots to 1923 when Christian Trumpf acquired a machine shop in Stuttgart.
About_#3: Regine's father, Berthold Leibinger, joined the company in 1961 and developed the first contour "nibbling" machine tool with numerical control.
About_#4: Christian Trumpf, who had no children, chose Berthold as his successor and handed over control of the company to him in 1972.
Did You Know?: Regine, who serves on the company's supervisory board but is not involved day-to-day operations, teaches at Technical University of Berlin.

About_#1: Nicola Leibinger-Kammueller owns 29.4% of the world's largest manufacturer of machine tools, TRUMPF, and serves as CEO.
About_#2: The company traces its roots to 1923 when Christian Trumpf acquired a machine shop in Stuttgart.
About_#3: Nicola's father, Berthold Leibinger, joined the company in 1961 and developed the first contour "nibbling" machine tool with numerical control.
About_#4: Christian Trumpf, who had no children, chose Berthold as his successor and handed over control of the company to him in 1972.
Did You Know?: Nicola, in addition to being active in various scientific, cultural and social institutions, is a board member at Siemens AG and Axel Springer SE.
In Their Own Words: We need a stronger focus on economic policy again in Germany, because the challenges we are facing in terms of the digital transformation and global competition are tremendous.

About_#1: Wolfgang Leitner heads listed Austrian plant and equipment manufacturer Andritz; he said in July 2021 that he would step down as CEO become chairman of the board.
About_#2: A chemist by training, Leitner joined Andritz in 1987, became CEO in 1994 and took a 26% stake in the company in 1999.
About_#3: He eventually turned Andritz into one of Austria's largest companies.
About_#4: In 2018, Andritz completed the biggest acquisition in its history, buying North Carolina based Xerium Technologies for $833 million.
Did You Know?: Leitner comes from a modest background - his father also worked for Andritz, serving the company for three decades as a metal worker.
In Their Own Words: I wonder why politicans don't show any interest in supporting businesses and keeping them in the country.

Education: Diploma, Liaoning Radio and TV University
About_#1: Liu Zhongtian is the founder of Hong Kong-listed aluminum products manufacturer China Zhongwang Holdings.
About_#2: Liu resigned as the chairman of China Zhongwang due to "personal health reasons" in November 2017.
About_#3: Zhongwang USA, majority owned by Wang, ended a deal to buy aluminum processor Aleris in November 2017, citing U.S. regulatory uncertainty.
About_#4: In September 2016, Liu denied reports that his company might be dodging U.S. tariffs by storing a reported 6% of the world's aluminum in Mexico.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Birla Institute of Technology and Science (BITS) - Pilani
About_#1: Bill Malhotra is the founder and CEO of Claridge Homes, one of the largest real estate developers in Ottawa, Canada.
About_#2: Malhotra founded Claridge in 1986 and the company has since built more than 14,000 properties, including condos, houses and retirement homes.
About_#3: He was born in India and studied civil engineering in college before moving to Canada in 1971 at age 22, where he worked at an engineering firm.
About_#4: From 1977 to 1986, Malhotra was the chief structural engineer for the city of Ottawa, before leaving to start Claridge.
Did You Know?: The company is named after The Claridges, a luxury hotel in New Delhi that Malhotra used to visit as a child with his father.

About_#1: Charlwin Mao is the CEO of Shanghai-headquartered social and e-commerce platform Xiaohongshu.
About_#2: Mao co-founded the company with Miranda Qu in 2013.
About_#3: Earlier in his career, he worked at Bain Consulting and Bain Capital.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, San Francisco State
About_#1: San Francisco Bay Area real estate broker George Marcus has been in the business for over 40 years.
About_#2: Most of his fortune lies in a 35% stake in Marcus & Millichap, the publicly-traded real estate brokerage he founded in 1971.
About_#3: Marcus & Millichap specializes in commercial real estate in the U.S. and Canada, closing nearly 9,000 transactions valued at $42.3 billion in 2016.
About_#4: Marcus also controls a 3% stake in Essex Property Trust, a REIT he founded that owns more than 60,000 apartments along the West Coast.
Did You Know?: He graduated with a B.A. in economics from San Francisco State University and served on the Board of Regents of the University of California from 2000 to 2012.

About_#1: Yves-Loic Martin is the former chief technology officer of Eurofins Scientific, a laboratory testing company listed on the French stock exchange.
About_#2: Martin owns about 10% of the company, which went public in 1997.
About_#3: He joined Eurofins in 1992 and became chief technology officer in 1998. He stepped down in 2015 but remains a board member.
About_#4: Eurofins has 400 labs in 41 countries and is prominent in food and pharmaceutical products testing.

Education: Medical Doctor, Hahnemann Medical College; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Temple University
About_#1: Gary Michelson is a retired orthopedic & spinal surgeon who holds over 340 U.S. patents for orthopedic and spinal surgery instruments.
About_#2: He became a billionaire in 2005 when he reached a $1.35 billion settlement with medical device giant Medtronic after years of litigation.
About_#3: Michelson, who signed the Giving Pledge in June 2016, has founded several nonprofits to give to medical research, animal welfare and education.
Did You Know?: A few of his philanthropic efforts include planting 3.5 million teak trees in Costa Rica and creating a foundation to pair animal pets with homes.
In Their Own Words: Inventors are constantly finding out what's wrong with the world and saying, 'I wanna go fix that.'

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Rider University
About_#1: Canadian Robert Miller cofounded electronics distributor Future Electronics in 1968.
About_#2: In 1976, he bought out his partner for $500,000; now the Quebec-based company is one of the world's largest electronics distributors.
About_#3: Future Electronics has a reported $5 billion in revenues from operations in 44 countries.
About_#4: Its products include adapter boards for LED screens, microcontrollers and LED lighting.
Did You Know?: Miller rarely grants interviews or attends public ceremonies, and does not allow his picture to be taken.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Fundacao Getulio Vargas
About_#1: Fernando Roberto Moreira Salles is a member of one of Brazil's oldest banking families.
About_#2: His late father, Walther Moreira Salles, was the founder of Unibanco and a former ambassador to the United States.
About_#3: In 2008 Unibanco merged with Itau, one of Brazil's-largest commercial banks, creating Itau-Unibanco, the largest private sector bank in Latin America.
About_#4: Moreira Salles and his three brothers, all billionaires, also own stakes in CBMM, the world's leading supplier of the mineral niobium.

About_#1: Brazilian documentary filmmaker Joao Moreira Salles is a member of one of Brazil's oldest banking families.
About_#2: His late father, Walther Moreira Salles, was the founder of Unibanco and a former ambassador to the United States.
About_#3: In 2008 Unibanco merged with Itau, then Brazil's second-largest commercial bank, creating Itau-Unibanco, the largest bank in Latin America.
About_#4: Moreira Salles and his three brothers, all billionaires, also own stakes in CBMM, the world's leading supplier of the mineral niobium.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Southern California
About_#1: Brazilian filmmaker Walther Moreira Salles Junior (also known as Walter Salles) is a member of one of Brazil's oldest banking families.
About_#2: His late father, Walther Moreira Salles, was the founder of Unibanco and a former ambassador to the United States.
About_#3: In 2008 Unibanco merged with Itau, then Brazil's second-largest commercial bank, creating Itau-Unibanco, the largest bank in Latin America.
About_#4: Moreira Salles and his three brothers, all billionaires, also own stakes in CBMM, the world's leading supplier of the mineral niobium.

About_#1: Liora Ofer chairs investment vehicle Ofer Investments, which was cofounded by her father Yuli (d. 2011) and uncle Sammy Ofer (d. 2011).
About_#2: The company's largest asset is a controlling stake in publicly traded real estate firm Melisron.
About_#3: In 2015, Liora won a years-long court battle with her brother Doron Ofer over their inheritance, which left her with nearly 52% of Ofer Investments.
About_#4: She now owns 85% of the investment company, after a conflict-of-interest law forced her cousin, Eyal, to divest.
Did You Know?: She is one of just two female billionaires in Israel; the other is Shari Arison.

About_#1: Mrudula Parekh inherited her late husband Sushilkumar Parekh's minority stake in Pidilite Industries, India's leading maker of adhesives and sealants.
About_#2: The company was founded by her late brother-in-law, Balvant Parekh, in 1959.
About_#3: Today, Balvant's son Madhukar Parekh chairs the company.

Education: Master of Science, Temple University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Madras
About_#1: David C. Paul is the founder and executive chairman of spine implant manufacturer Globus Medical.
About_#2: A mechanical engineer by training, Paul moved to the U.S. from India to get his master's degree at Temple University.
About_#3: Paul worked as an engineer for medical device giant Synthes before leaving in 2003 to start Globus.
About_#4: Paul took Globus public in 2012.
Did You Know?: Globus makes the Excelsius GPS, one of the only spinal surgery robots on the market today.

About_#1: The son of Quebecor's founder, Pierre Karl Péladeau is the largest individual shareholder in the media company, which prints Le Journal de Montréal.
