About_#2: Péladeau has spent two decades as CEO--with a three year break between 2014 and 2017--and expanded the company into telecom, sports and entertainment
About_#3: In 2015, he won and led the separatist Parti Québécois for nearly a year, before resigning in May 2016.
About_#4: In February 2017, he returned as CEO of a very healthy Quebecor, as shares rose 70% during his political stint.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Beijing Foreign Studies University
About_#1: Miranda Qu is the president of Shanghai-based social and e-commerce company Xiaohongshu, which translates as "Little Red Book."
About_#2: She cofounded the company in 2013 with Charlwin Mao, who is CEO. Xiaohongshu now has over 200 million monthly active users.
About_#3: Qu and Mao each own an estimated 10% of the company.
About_#4: Xiaohongshu was valued at $20 billion after a funding round in November 2021 that raised money from investors like Tencent and Alibaba.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
About_#1: Phillip Ragon, known as Terry, founded InterSystems, a software company that enables hospitals and banks to analyze big data, in 1978.
About_#2: Ragon retains full ownership of the company, which had $704 million in 2018 sales.
About_#3: After a trip to South Africa in 2009 where Terry and Susan saw the ravages of AIDS, they established the Ragon Institute to pursue an HIV vaccine.
About_#4: Ragon and his wife, Susan Ragon, joined the Giving Pledge in May 2017.
Did You Know?: Ragon spent his high school senior year in Bogota, Colombia and has donated over half a million dollars since 2013 to a religious school there.

About_#1: G. Rajendran chairs privately held GRT Jewellers, which he founded in 1964 as GR Thangamaaligai.
About_#2: The jewelry chain sells diamond, gold, platinum and silver jewelry mostly in south India.
About_#3: His sons G.R. Ananthapadmanabhan and G.R. Radhakrishnan are managing directors at GRT Jewellers.
About_#4: He also chairs the GRT Institute of Engineering and Technology located outside Chennai.
Did You Know?: Rajendran hails from a family of jewelers from Kumbakkonam in Tamil Nadu.

About_#1: Media baron Krit Ratanarak controls Bangkok Broadcasting & TV, which operates Thailand's market leader, Channel 7.
About_#2: He also owns a minority stake in Bank of Ayudhya, the country's fifth-largest bank in terms of loans and deposits.
About_#3: In October 2020, Bank of Ayudhya acquired a 50% stake in the Philippines-based SB Finance, a lender to small businesses.
About_#4: Other assets include a stake in Siam City Cement, which his late father Chuan founded in 1969.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, George Washington University; Law Degree, Northwestern University
About_#1: Jerry Reinsdorf made a fortune in sports, buying Chicago teams in the 1980s and watching values skyrocket over the next three decades.
About_#2: Reinsdorf led a group that bought the Chicago White Sox baseball team in 1981 for $19 million. He still owns an estimated 19% stake.
About_#3: He and investors bought a controlling stake in the NBA's Chicago Bulls for $9.2 million in 1985, one year after the team drafted Michael Jordan.
About_#4: Six championships and 33 years later, the Bulls are worth $2.5 billion net of debt; Reinsdorf still owns an estimated 40%.

About_#1: Mochtar Riady is the founder of the diversified Lippo group, now run by sons James and Stephen.
About_#2: Born in East Java, Riady opened a bicycle shop at age 22 and went on to build a successful banking career until the 1997 Asian financial crisis.
About_#3: Today Lippo group's interests include real estate, retail, healthcare, media and education.
About_#4: Riady's son Stephen runs Singapore property outfit OUE, which in July 2020 agreed to sell the iconic U.S. Bank Tower in downtown Los Angeles.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Rajju Shroff is the founder of BSE-listed crop protection company UPL.
About_#2: After its $4.2 billion acquisition of Arysta LifeSciences in 2018, UPL became one of the top agrochemical companies in the world.
About_#3: UPL's product range includes insecticides, fungicides and seeds.
About_#4: Shroff's older son Jai is the company's chief executive officer and vice chairman.
Did You Know?: The company was started in 1969 to produce red phosphorus for industrial chemicals.
In Their Own Words: What India's farmers need is training in modern farm practices.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Erasmus University Rotterdam, The Netherlands; Master of Science, Erasmus University Rotterdam, The Netherlands
About_#1: Frank Slootman is the CEO of Snowflake, a cloud-based database firm he joined in 2019 and took public in September 2020 in a blockbuster IPO.
About_#2: The IPO was the third for Dutch-born Slootman, who moved to California for a job at Compuware in the dotcom boom, then worked at Borland Software.
About_#3: In 2003, he became CEO of storage startup Data Domain, taking it public in 2007 and selling it to EMC in 2009 for $1.8 billion.
About_#4: Two years later, he was back at it again as chairman of enterprise software business ServiceNow, which he guided to a 2012 IPO.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Columbia Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, SUNY Stony Brook
About_#1: A Wall Street veteran, Henry Swieca cofounded hedge fund firm Highbridge Capital Management in 1992 with childhood friend Glenn Dubin.
About_#2: The duo sold part of the business to JP Morgan Chase in 2004 and the rest in 2009.
About_#3: After the sale Swieca opened Talpion Fund, which manages his own fortune.
About_#4: Talpion's portfolio includes real estate and startup cash for new money management firms.
Did You Know?: Swieca learned stock investing from his dentist uncle, and turned to the market to fund his and his brother's education after losing both of his parents at age 19.

About_#1: Tao Yuequn chairs Shenzhen-listed Ovctek China, a supplier of contact lenses.
About_#2: Tao holds an engineering Ph.D.from the University of Southern California, and once taught at California State University.
About_#3: Tao founded Ovctek in the central Chinese city of Hefei in 2001.

About_#1: Robert Toennies owns 50% of German food industry giant Toennies Lebensmittel, with annual revenue of around $8 billion.
About_#2: Operating meat, convenience, ingredients and logistics divisions, the company specializes in pig, sow and beef cattle slaughtering and processing.
About_#3: Robert's father, Bernd, and uncle, Clemens, cofounded Toennies Lebensmittel in 1971. It employs around 16,500 people in Germany and Denmark.
About_#4: Bernd died in 1994, at age 42. Robert inherited his stake and now serves on the board of advisors of the holding company.
Did You Know?: Robert fought in court with Clemens for several years. In 2017, they settled their dispute over ownership of stakes in the company.

Education: Graduate, Stockholm University
About_#1: Torbjorn Tornqvist is the Swedish co-founder of Gunvor Group, one of the largest commodities conglomerates in the world.
About_#2: The massive oil trader benefits from an increasingly diverse presence with refineries, pipelines, terminals and mining operations in 35 countries.
About_#3: Tornqvist got his start at British Petroleum in 1977 and founded Gunvor with Russian billionaire, Gennady Timchenko, in 2000.
About_#4: In 2014, one day before the US Treasury imposed sanctions against Timchenko over Russia's annextion of Crimea, Tornqvist bought out Timchenko.
Did You Know?: Tornqvist grew up playing hockey and is an avid sailor; his Artemis Racing team competed in 2017's Americas Cup, reaching the semi-finals.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Paris
About_#1: Campbell Soup Co. heir Charlotte Colket Weber served on the company's board from 1990 until 2014.
About_#2: Her billionaire cousins, Bennett Dorrance and Mary Alice Dorrance Malone, are still directors.
About_#3: Their grandfather, John T. Dorrance, invented the condensed soup formula that turned the company into a global soup giant.
About_#4: Weber is a devoted equestrian and owns the Live Oak Stud Farm, a 4,500-acre horse farm and commercial cattle operation near Ocala, Florida.
Did You Know?: Weber is a trustee at New York's Metropolitan Museum of Art and provided funding for the Charlotte C. Weber Galleries for the Arts of Ancient China.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, George Washington University
About_#1: Dubbed the "Queen of Las Vegas," Elaine Wynn became the largest individual shareholder of publicly traded Wynn Resorts in 2018.
About_#2: Her ex-husband Steve Wynn stepped down as CEO amid sexual misconduct allegations, which he denied; he sold all his shares in March 2018.
About_#3: In May 2018, Elaine Wynn launched a proxy battle and successfully forced the resignations of two longtime board members who were Steve loyalists.
About_#4: After marrying Steve during her third year of college, Wynn worked Sundays at his father's Maryland bingo hall before the couple moved to Las Vegas.
Did You Know?: At the Bellagio, which the Wynns opened in 1998, she commissioned the hotel's iconic glass installation by artist Dale Chihuly.
In Their Own Words: I never do anything half-way. If I'm invested, I'm all the way in.

About_#1: Xu Xudong chairs Ningbo Xusheng Auto Technology.
About_#2: Xusheng is a supplier of gear boxes and battery protection shells to Tesla.
About_#3: Other customers include Chrysler, Mahler and Bosch.

About_#1: Yang Xuegang is the chairman and CEO of China Risun Group, a supplier of coke and chemicals.
About_#2: Founded in 1995, China Risunis headquartered in Beijing.
About_#3: Yang Xuegangworked at the Dongwushi Reservoir Management Center-- under a government water bureau -- earlier in his career.
About_#4: Yang Xuegang holds an executive master's degree in business administration from Hebei University of Technology in Tianjin.

About_#1: Zhang Xuexin is chairman of Xinfa Group, which owns power stations, aluminum refineries and an aluminum smelter.
About_#2: Xinfa was founded in 1972 as a state-owned company.
About_#3: Xinfa is headquartered in China's Shandong Province.

Education: Ph.D, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Bachelor of Science, McGill University
About_#1: Noubar Afeyan is the founder and CEO of Cambridge, Mass. life sciences innovation firm Flagship Pioneering.
About_#2: He's also the chairman and cofounder of biotech firm Moderna, known for its Covid-19 vaccine which was authorized by the U.S. FDA in December 2020.
About_#3: Afeyan has helped start more than 70 public and private healthcare and life sciences companies over the course of his career.
About_#4: Born in Beirut, Lebanon, in 1962 to Armenian parents, he and his family fled the Lebanese Civil War to move to Montreal in 1975.
Did You Know?: Afeyan is a lecturer at Harvard Business School and also taught at MIT's Sloan School of Management from 2000 to 2016.
In Their Own Words: What keeps you from innovating is being comfortable. If you're an immigrant, then you're used to being out of your comfort zone.

About_#1: Farkhad Akhmedov got his start selling Russian sables at the London commodity exchange.
About_#2: In 1987 he founded Tansley Trading, which supplied equipment to Russian gas producers.
About_#3: Six years later, he became a minority shareholder in Nortgas, an oil and gas company in Siberia.
About_#4: In 1998, he bought out the 44% stake of another investor, Bechtel Energy, and became chairman of Nortgas.
Did You Know?: Akhmedov invested $55 million in a pomegranate juice factory in his native Azerbaijan, where his father worked during the Soviet era.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign
About_#1: Andreessen runs influential Silicon Valley venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz, whose successful bets include Instagram, Oculus VR and GitHub.
About_#2: His first claim to fame was cofounding web browser firm Netscape, which AOL bought in 1998 for $4.2 billion in stock.
About_#3: Andreessen's biggest score was as a seed investor in Facebook.
About_#4: He also cofounded Loudcloud, which, renamed Opsware, sold to Hewlett-Packard for $1.6 billion in 2007.
Did You Know?: His wife Laura is daughter of billionaire John Arrillaga, who built his fortune in Silicon Valley real estate.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Cornell University; Master of Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
About_#1: In 2015 Sanjit Biswas and John Bicket cofounded Samsara, a company that offers hardware and cloud-based software to collect and analyze data.
About_#2: Bicket serves as the chief technology officer of Samsara, which is based in San Francisco.
About_#3: Samsara operates in North America and Europe and has more than 20,000 customers.
About_#4: Biswas and Bicket met at MIT as graduate students.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: An Iraqi native, Zadik Bino moved to Israel and worked his way up the chain at First International Bank of Israel, known as FIBI.
About_#2: Bino went on to serve as CEO of FIBI from 1978 to 1986 before buying the company two decades later; he still owns 38% of the bank.
About_#3: He purchased a 60% stake in Israeli company Paz Oil in 1999 for $48 million.
About_#4: He has since liquidated his position in Paz Oil in transactions worth an estimated $800 million.
Did You Know?: He purchased FIBI Holdings from Brazil's Safra brothers for $90 million in cash in 2003.

About_#1: Alex Birkenstock is an heir to German footwear company Birkenstock, which traces its roots back to 1774.
About_#2: The company began making its trademark sandals in the 1960s, under the leadership of Alex's father, Karl Birkenstock.
About_#3: In 2002, Alex and his two brothers, Christian and Stephan, were given control of the company.
About_#4: Stephan Birkenstock sold his stake to his two brothers in 2013 for an undisclosed amount.

About_#1: Christian Birkenstock is an heir to German footwear company Birkenstock, which traces its roots back to 1774.
About_#2: The company began making its trademark sandals in the 1960s, under the leadership of Christian's father, Karl Birkenstock.
About_#3: In 2002, Christian and his two brothers, Alex and Stephan, were given control of the company.
About_#4: Stephan Birkenstock sold his stake to his two brothers in 2013 for an undisclosed amount.

Education: Master of Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Bachelor of Science, Stanford University
About_#1: In 2015 Sanjit Biswas and John Bicket cofounded Samsara, a company that offers hardware and cloud-based software to collect and analyze data.
About_#2: Biswas serves as CEO of Samsara, which is based in San Francisco; the company listed its shares on the New York Stock Exchange in December 2021.
About_#3: Samsara operates in North America and Europe and has more than 20,000 customers.
About_#4: Biswas and Bicket met at MIT as graduate students.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Kansas; Master of Science, University of Kansas
About_#1: When David Booth cofounded Dimensional Fund Advisors in 1981, he began a decades-long experiment in applying academic theory to real-world investing.
About_#2: His former professor Eugene Fama authored the efficient markets hypothesis, which argues that it's impossible to consistently beat the market.
About_#3: In light of Fama's research, Booth eschewed stock picking and focused on offering investors low-cost, passive mutual funds.
About_#4: Dimensional manages more than $600 billion in assets, most of which is steered via hand-vetted financial advisors.
Did You Know?: Booth paid $4.3 million for James Naismith's original rules of basketball, written in 1891, which is now displayed at the University of Kansas.
In Their Own Words: The number of managers that can successfully pick stocks are fewer than you'd expect by chance. So why even play that game? You don't need to.

About_#1: Frozen-food king Josef Boquoi presides over bofrost, which has approximately 11,000 employees, four million customers and $1.4 billion in revenue.
About_#2: He joined his father's small coffee- and grain-roasting firm in 1953, after receiving a business degree and completing an apprenticeship in Hamburg.
About_#3: He founded bofrost in 1966, and its first refrigerated vans hit the streets of Germany in 1969.
About_#4: He introduced new items and developed a business model based on freezing and packaging a variety of fresh food, and delivering direct to households.
Did You Know?: In Venice, customer orders are brought by boat, while in Madrid small vehicles are deployed to be able to navigate through the narrowest of alleys.

Education: Bachelor of Business Administration, University of Wisconsin, Madison
About_#1: Saket Burman is the fifth-generation member of the storied Burman clan that founded Dabur, India's fourth-largest consumer goods company.
About_#2: He inherited a minority stake and a board seat in Dabur from his father Siddharth Burman, who died in 2015.
About_#3: Other assets he owns include property and financial investments.
About_#4: Saket founded and sold an IT company and is now running a general trading company.
Did You Know?: He is a member of Mumbai Angels, a group that backs startups.

About_#1: Cai Mingtong chairs Fujian Torch Electron Technology, a supplier of ceramic capacitors.
About_#2: The predecessor of Fujian Torch Electron Technology was a collective owned electronic component factory founded in Quanzhou in 1989.
About_#3: Cai taught high school teacher and worked as a factory technician before he joined the predecessor of Torch.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, National Chung Hsing University
About_#1: Chen got his start selling office clocks in 1965. He later expanded into office equipment, furniture and electronics.
About_#2: Today his listed Aurora Corp., chaired by wife Yuan Hui-Hua since 2018, sells electronics in over 1,500 locations in Taiwan and mainland China.
About_#3: Aurora also owns real estate, including a 38-story tower, in Shanghai's Lujiazui financial district.
About_#4: Chen studied economics in college. That department is now part of National Taipei University.
Did You Know?: Chen was born into a well-off family but worked as a small trader and street merchant after his father died in his youth.

About_#1: Manas Chiaravanond is part of the clan behind Thai conglomerate Charoen Pokphand Group.
About_#2: He derives his wealth from his 3.62% stake in holding outfit CP Group.
About_#3: Manas has been chief operating officer of the family's food outfit Chia Tai.
About_#4: He's a cousin of CP group head, Dhanin Chearavanont.

Education: Master of Science, University of California, Davis
About_#1: Phongthep Chiaravanont is a cousin of Thai billionaire Dhanin Chearavanont.
About_#2: He has been a director on the board of Charoen Pokphand Foods, part of the family's Charoen Pokphand conglomerate, since 1994.
About_#3: Phongthep studied avian sciences at the University of California, Davis.

About_#1: Slovakia's first billionaire, Ivan Chrenko went into the real estate business in the early 1990s.
About_#2: His company, HB Reavis, developed the first business centers in Bratislava and the top shopping mall, later sold.
About_#3: In one of the earliest big post-Brexit real estate deals in London in 2016, HB Reavis, sold 33 Central to Wells Fargo for a reported $400 million.
About_#4: In Warsaw, it is constructing one of the tallest buildings in Europe.

About_#1: Sol Daurella is the chairwoman of the world's largest Coke bottling company, Coca-Cola European Partners.
About_#2: The Daurella family's ties to Coca-Cola began in 1951, when they were awarded a bottling license.
About_#3: In 2015 their Coca-Cola Iberian Partners SA merged with Germany's Coca-Cola Erfrischungsgetränke AG and Coke subsidiary Coca-Cola Enterprises.
About_#4: Daurella owns about 7% of Coca-Cola European Partners, the combined company, which is listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

Education: Doctorate, The University of Texas at Austin; Medical Doctor, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro
About_#1: Dulce Pugliese de Godoy Bueno and Edson de Godoy Bueno, who died in February 2017, founded health insurance and medical care firm Amil in 1972.
About_#2: Dulce Pugliese and Edson Bueno, who were married when they cofounded Amil, later divorced. Dulce kept her roughly 33% ownership stake at Amil.
About_#3: AMIL's IPO was in 2007. It became Latin America's largest health care company, providing medical care and discount pharmacy coverage to millions.
About_#4: Giant U.S. health insurer United Health Group purchased 90% of Amil in 2012 for $4.9 billion in cash.

About_#1: Norbert Dentressangle sold his eponymous transportation and logistics company to XPO Logistics for $3.53 billion in June 2015.
About_#2: He founded Norbert Dentressangle SA in 1979 and grew it into a European industry leader with $5.5 billion in revenues and more than 43,000 employees.
About_#3: Now he focuses on real estate, industrial ventures and other investments through his family-owned holding company, Dentressangle Initiatives.
About_#4: In 2017, he was part of a group of investors who acquired 70% of Kiloutou, the fourth largest construction rental company in Europe.

Education: Master of Science, Moscow State University; Master of Economics, Plekhanov Russian University of Economics
About_#1: Oleg Deripaska is the founder of Basic Element, a Russian industrial group with interests in aluminum, energy, construction, agriculture and more.
About_#2: In April 2018, the U.S. Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control imposed sanctions against Deripaska and some of his companies.
About_#3: In January 2019, OFAC lifted sanctions on En+ Group, UC Rusal and Eurosibenergo, and Deripaska agreed to permanently reduce his stake to 44.95%.
About_#4: He was the richest person in Russia and the 9th richest in the world in 2008 before nearly losing it all due to crashing markets and heavy debts.
Did You Know?: Deripaska was married to the daughter of Valentin Umashev, former chief of staff and current son-in-law of Russia's first president, Boris Yeltsin.
In Their Own Words: I started my business in a unique time - one country was gone, and the other had not yet appeared. The first gave me the opportunity to get a wonderful education, the second, to succeed.

About_#1: Dong Jinggui is cofounder and chairman of Yadea Group, which produces electric scooters and bicycles.
About_#2: His wife, Qian Jinghong, is cofounder and vice chairman.
About_#3: Yadea was set up in 2001 in Jiangsu province.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Dartmouth College; Medical Doctor, Harvard University
About_#1: Keith Dunleavy is the founder of Inovalon, a cloud-based healthcare data analytics company.
About_#2: He came up with the idea for Inovalon in 1998 while doing his medical residency at Johns Hopkins University.
About_#3: Dunleavy has a 64% stake in Inovalon; he briefly became a billionaire in 2016.
About_#4: Inovalon had 2020 revenues of $667.5 million.

About_#1: Donald Foss, the founder and former chairman of subprime auto lender Credit Acceptance Corp, died at age 78 in August 2022.
About_#2: He launched the company in 1972 and was one of the first to offer loan programs that help dealers sell cars to customers with poor or no credit.
About_#3: Foss ran Credit Acceptance as CEO for three decades, taking it public in 1992.
About_#4: In early 2017 he stepped down as director of the company and retired.
Did You Know?: Foss learned the trade from his father, who owned a used-car dealership in Detroit.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Zurich
About_#1: Rolf Gerling inherited insurer Gerling Konzern, showed little interest in managing it and saw the legacy plunge into turmoil.
About_#2: His grandfather Robert founded the business in 1904 and his father, Hans, expanded it into a global insurance group. Hans died in 1992.
About_#3: Mismanagement, losses from the September 11 attacks and costly asbestos claims led Rolf to sell the company for an estimated $1 billion in 2005.
About_#4: His portfolio includes real estate through companies like DufourIm AG, which is headed by long-time Gerling confidant Heino von Have.
Did You Know?: In the 1990s, Gerling was instrumental in getting 50 insurance companies to sign a UN pledge to consider environmental problems in their business practices.

Education: Master, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Malaya
About_#1: Former tobacco executive G. Gnanalingam chairs Westports Holdings, a multicargo port operator that he cofounded with Ahmayuddin bin Ahmad on securing the concession in 1994.
About_#2: The group owns a 60-year concession to operate and expand its container terminals in Pulau Indah and Port Klang, which will end in 2054.
About_#3: Westports is one of three main port operators in the Strait of Malacca.
About_#4: His son, Ruben Emir Gnanalingam, is Westports' group managing director.
In Their Own Words: Taj Mahal was not built by Shah Jahan, it was built by the workers.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology
About_#1: He Zhaoxi is the chairman of Sangfor Technologies, a supplier of IT infrastructure solutions.
About_#2: The company went public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2018.
About_#3: He graduated from China University of Science and Technology in 1998 with a degree in automatic control and economic management.
About_#4: After his graduation, Mr. He worked for Huawei Technologies from 1998 to 2000.

About_#1: U.S.-born hotelier William Heinecke came to Thailand as a child and started his first business before he turned 18, hence naming his company Minor.
About_#2: A Thai citizen since 1991, his Minor International has more than 500 hotels and resorts, nearly 2,400 restaurants and 470 retail stores, spread across more than 50 countries.
About_#3: He tripled the size of his hotel portfolio by acquiring Spain's NH Hotels for $2.6 billion in 2018, the year of Minor's golden anniversary.
About_#4: Minor also has franchises for such brands as Swensens, Sizzler, Dairy Queen and Burger King.
Did You Know?: An auto enthusiast, Heinecke has a collection of 36 cars and motorcycles.
In Their Own Words: You learn through every crisis, every challenge.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Boston University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Korea University
About_#1: Huh Jae-myung is the largest shareholder of Iljin Materials, a manufacturer of electric foils used in consumer electronic products, and lithium batteries. He stepped down as CEO in 2021.
About_#2: The firm is a subsidiary of the Iljin group, a conglomerate with interests in electric machinery, steel, construction, medical equipment and media.
About_#3: He is the second son of Iljin group's founder and chairman Huh Jin-kyu, who started the company as a metal maker in Seoul in 1968.
About_#4: He is married to Eun-hye Park of Kumho Asiana, a conglomerate with primary interests in transportation.

About_#1: Jia Tianjiang chairs Tianyuan Manganese Industry Group.
About_#2: Jia controls Hong Kong-listed Huarong International Financial Holding.
About_#3: Tianyuan is headquartered in western China's Ningxia Province.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill
About_#1: Regarded by most as the NBA's greatest all-time player, Michael Jordan won six titles with the Chicago Bulls.
About_#2: His salary during his career totaled $90 million, but he has earned $1.8 billion (pre-tax) from such corporate partners as Nike, Hanes and Gatorade.
About_#3: MJ joined sports-betting firm DraftKings as a special advisor to the board and an investor in September 2020.
About_#4: He also became a NASCAR team co-owner in late 2020.
Did You Know?: Jordan was the NBA's highest-paid player only two seasons during his 15-year playing career.
In Their Own Words: I've missed more than 9,000 shots in my career. I've lost almost 300 games. Twenty-six times I've been trusted to take the game-winning shot...and missed. I've failed over, and over and over again in my life. And that is why I succeed.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Seoul National University; Master of Science, Seoul National University
About_#1: Kim Taek-jin is the founder of NCSoft, South Korea's No. 2 online game company which he founded in 1997.
About_#2: He took the company public in 2003, and still serves as CEO.
About_#3: NCSoft now provides online game services to more than 60 countries.
About_#4: He sold most of his NCSoft shares in 2012 and now holds just under 12% of the company.
Did You Know?: While still a student at Seoul National University's College of Engineering, he developed software that helped users practice typing in Korean.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Rochester Institute of Technology; Master, Stanford Graduate School of Business
About_#1: Koo Kwang-mo is the chairman and chief executive of LG, one of South Korea's top five conglomerates.
About_#2: He inherited the shares of his late father and former LG chairman Koo Bon-Moo after his death in May 2018.
About_#3: He is an adopted son of the former chairman, who lost his biological son in 1994; Kwang-mo was born as a nephew to Bon-Moo.
About_#4: In 2019, at age 41, he became the youngest chairman of a major Korean conglomerate.

About_#1: Tony Langley owns Nottinghamshire, UK-based engineering and manufacturing giant Langley Holdings.
About_#2: He started the business in 1975, at age 20, with what was left of his grandfather's failed engineering firm.
About_#3: He launched Langley Mining, which sold equipment to the UK coal industry and eventually moved into steel, oil and gas customers as well.
About_#4: In 2000 he further diversified, buying Clarke Chapman, a crane manufacturer, from Rolls Royce.
Did You Know?: An accomplished yachtsman, Langley owns the Gladiator Sailing Team that competes in elite racing competition.

Education: Doctorate, Korea University
About_#1: Lee Joong-keun is credited with introducing rental housing in South Korea and is the founder of Booyoung Group, a property and construction giant.
About_#2: In February 2018, he went to jail on charges of embezzlement, tax evasion and creating a slush fund. He denied the charges and is awaiting trial.
About_#3: In November 2018, he was convicted and sentenced to five years in prison but was released on bail due to health problems.
About_#4: In 2020, an appeals court sentenced him to two and a half years in prison.
Did You Know?: In 1979, he filed for bankruptcy and put Booyoung's shares in his relatives' names in order to do deals.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Indiana University; Medical Doctor, Indiana University
About_#1: James Leininger, known as "Doctor Jim," made his fortune founding medical devices company Kinetic Concepts (KCI), which focuses on wound care.
About_#2: In November 2012, private equity firm Apax Partners led a $6.3 billion acquisition of the company. Leininger was the largest shareholder.
About_#3: He also founded the Texas Public Policy Foundation in 1989 to support free-market policies and research.
About_#4: He has mostly invested through his Medcare Investment Funds, which manages $1 billion in assets.
Did You Know?: Leininger started KCI in an one-bedroom apartment in 1976.

About_#1: Li Haiyan is a co-founder of hot-pot chain Haidilao International Holdings; she has been a company supervisor since 2009.
About_#2: Li is the wife of billionaire Shi Yonghong, a director at Haidilao and chairman of hotpot seasonings supplier Yihai International.
About_#3: Haidilao co-founders Li, Zhang Yong, Shu Ping and Shi Yonghong funded their first restaurant with personal savings in 1994.
About_#4: Haidilao today is one of the most popular restaurant chains in China and has about 1,300 locations worldwide.

About_#1: Li Weiwei, also known as Li Yifei, is vice chairman and general manager of Wuhu Shunrong Sanqi Interactive Entertainment Network Technology.
About_#2: Li holds an EMBA from Cheung Kong Graduate School of Business in Beijing.
About_#3: Li worked for several IT companies including Sina before he founded Sanqi in 2011.

Education: High School Graduate, High School
About_#1: Jimmy John Liautaud is the founder of sandwich chain Jimmy John's.
About_#2: He launched the business in 1983 using a $25,000 loan from his father, an army veteran.
About_#3: As a student, Liautaud had struggled with undiagnosed dyslexia and graduated second-to-last in his high school class.
About_#4: Jimmy John's now has 2,800 locations; virtually all of them are franchises.
Did You Know?: Liautaud owns dozens of luxury cars, including numerous Ferraris and Porsches.
In Their Own Words: My success is a byproduct of my curiosity and breaking things apart. And here I am, I brought a lot of people along the way.

About_#1: Louise Lindh and her sister Katarina Martinson each own a 14% stake in their family's investment outfit, L.E. Lundbergforetagen AB.
About_#2: The company has investments in property management and a variety of other businesses, including stakes in firms like truck-maker Volvo and Ericsson.
About_#3: Both sisters have board seats in the group companies along with their father Fredrik Lundberg.
About_#4: The company was founded by their grandfather Lars in 1944 as a construction outfit. Fredrik took over management of the firm in 1981.
Did You Know?: In 2018, Lindh and her husband bought battery maker IABÖ Global Holding for 36 million Swedish kronor, roughly $4 million.

About_#1: Lu Di was an early investor in Chinese drone maker DJI when it was founded in 2006.
About_#2: Today the Shenzhen-headquartered business is one of the world's largest drone makers.
About_#3: Lu has been called a "penny pincher" by DJI's CEO Frank Wang.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University; Master of Business Administration, Harvard University
About_#1: Anand Mahindra is the third generation scion of the Mahindra clan and chairs the $19 billion (revenue) Mahindra & Mahindra conglomerate.
About_#2: The group's operations span 22 industries from auto to information technology to real estate.
About_#3: Mahindra is best known for its tractors and its sports utility vehicles, such as the Scorpio and Bolero. In 2021, he launched the XUV 700 SUV and in 2022, the revamped version of the Scorpio.
About_#4: Anand Mahindra also owns a small but valuable stake in Kotak Mahindra Bank.
Did You Know?: Mahindra tweets regularly and has close to 10 million followers.
In Their Own Words: We are spending a significant amount of money on electric. We are ahead of the game.

About_#1: Bruce Mathieson operated his poker machine and pub empire Australian Liquor and Hospitality in a joint venture with supermarket giant Woolworths.
About_#2: Mathieson is now a minority shareholder in the listed Endeavour Group, which holds both the Australian Liquor assets and Woolworth's extensive liquor retailing business.
About_#3: He has a fondness for racehorses and part-owned a horse that ran in the Melbourne Cup.

Source of Wealth: real estate, oil, cars, sports, Self Made
Education: Drop Out, The University of Texas at Austin
About_#1: From his start selling Ford Edsels, "Red" built a network of 55 auto dealerships, now down to 12 in Texas.
About_#2: In 1972 he was a cofounder of radio giant Clear Channel, which he tapped to run car ads.
About_#3: He owned a stake in Constellis, formerly known as Blackwater, which he sold in 2016.
About_#4: The McCombs Institute for the Early Detection and Treatment of Cancer at MD Anderson is named after Red and his wife, who donated $30 million in 2005.
Did You Know?: Over the years McCombs has owned and sold the San Antonio Spurs, the Denver Nuggets and the Minnesota Vikings. He also invested in Formula One.

Education: Bachelor of Science, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Deepak Mehta gets his wealth from listed Indian chemicals firm Deepak Nitrite, which he chairs.
About_#2: The company was founded by his father Chimanlal Mehta in 1971.
About_#3: With a portfolio of 100 products, Deepak Nitrite is a leading producer of phenol and acetone in India.
About_#4: The $566 million (revenue) company has lately benefited from increasing demand amid the government's efforts to encourage domestic producers.

About_#1: Mario Moretti Polegato founded his comfort-focused shoe brand Geox in 1995 with his patented "breathable shoe technology."
About_#2: Polegato worked at his family's wine business where he got itchy feet, but it was a hot trip to Nevada that inspired him to slice holes in his shoes.
About_#3: He took his technology to Nike and other footwear giants, who were uninterested; he started his own company instead.
About_#4: He took Geox public in 2004 while also running the family wine label, Villa Sandi.
Did You Know?: Polegato was named a Knight of the National Order of Romania in 2000, and was appointed Cavaliere del Lavoro, one of Italy's highest civilian honors, in 2005.
In Their Own Words: What I recommend to my colleague entrepreneurs is that today it's impossible to have success in a business if you don't innovate.

About_#1: Alberto Palatchi transformed a store he inherited from his parents in 1964 into Pronovias, one of the largest wedding dress companies in the world.
About_#2: In 2017, Palatchi sold 90% of Pronovias to British private equity firm BC Partners for an estimated $550 million.
About_#3: Pronovias wedding dresses are sold in more than 105 countries through a network of 123 stores and more than 4,000 points of sale.
About_#4: Palatchi also has more than $1.1 billion invested in a Spanish investment fund that is similar to a mutual fund.
Did You Know?: Palatchi's father fled Turkey during World War I and moved to Barcelona.

Education: Drop Out, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Nelson Peltz, an activist investor, is a founder of investment firm Trian Fund Management.
About_#2: Trian now has $8.5 billion in assets under management.
About_#3: The firm has a highly concentrated portfolio that includes stakes in Bank of New York Mellon, DuPont and food conglomerate Mondelez International.
About_#4: In early 2017, Peltz battled with Proctor & Gamble over a board seat the company didn't want to grant him. He ultimately won the seat.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, CW Post College; Master of Science, University of Michigan
About_#1: Jorge Perez runs Related Group of Florida, which claims to have developed more than 80,000 condos, mostly in Miami, since it was founded in 1979.
About_#2: As a young urban planner, Perez met developer Stephen Ross, which led to a partnership. Today Ross' affiliate Related Companies owns a 25% stake.
About_#3: They built affordable housing in the 1980s, then switched to high-end condo construction.
About_#4: Perez has started diversifying where he develops, branching out elsewhere in South Florida, as well as in Uruguay, Mexico and Argentina.
Did You Know?: A son of Cuban parents, Perez grew up in Argentina and Colombia before moving to the U.S. for college.

About_#1: Alberto Prada and his sisters, Miuccia and Marina, inherited a share of Prada, the handbag and fashion empire founded by their grandfather in 1913.
About_#2: A year after the siblings inherited their stakes in Prada, Miuccia married Patrizio Bertelli; the duo now oversee Prada together as co-CEOs.
About_#3: Neither Marina or Alberto are involved in running the business but own an estimated 12% stake in the company.

About_#1: Marina Prada and her siblings, Miuccia and Alberto, inherited a share of Prada, the handbag and fashion empire founded by their grandfather in 1913.
About_#2: A year after the siblings inherited their stakes in Prada, Miuccia married Patrizio Bertelli; the duo now oversee Prada together as co-CEOs.
About_#3: Marina and Alberto are not involved in running the business but each hold an estimated 12% stake in Prada.

Education: Ph.D, Osmania University
About_#1: Pharma tycoon M.Satyanarayana Reddy is the founder and chairman of MSN group, headquartered in Hyderabad.
About_#2: He founded the group, which today consists of five privately held companies, in 2003 to make affordable generic drugs.
About_#3: Today it has 16 factories across India, Myanmar and the U.S.
About_#4: In 2020, MSN started making a low-priced version of Covid-19 drug Favipiravir under the brand name Favilow.
Did You Know?: Reddy has a PhD in organic chemistry.

About_#1: Rihanna, Barbados' most famous export, is a billionaire thanks to the success of cosmetics line Fenty Beauty.
About_#2: The cosmetics company, which she co-owns with French luxury retailer LVMH, generated more than $550 million in revenue in 2020.
About_#3: Her stake in the fast-growing cosmetics company comprises the majority of her fortune.
About_#4: She also has a 30% stake in the Savage x Fenty lingerie line, which raised money at a $1 billion valuation in February 2021.
Did You Know?: Fenty is Rihanna's last name

Education: Master of Arts/Science, Leningrad Institute of Physical Culture
About_#1: A friend of President Vladimir Putin, Arkady Rotenberg was once his judo sparring partner.
About_#2: In the late 2000s Rotenberg became an owner of SGM Group and Mostotrest, now two of Russia's biggest construction contractors.
About_#3: Both companies were targeted by EU sanctions in 2018 due to their participation in the construction of the Crimean bridge.
About_#4: Rotenberg was also the target of U.S. and European sanctions in 2014.
Did You Know?: An ice hockey fan, Rotenberg apparently still plays with Putin and is chairman of the executive board of Russian Ice Hockey Federation.

About_#1: Dieter Schnabel owns 60% of Helm AG, a chemical marketing firm with annual revenue of around $6 billion and offices in 30 countries.
About_#2: By its own account, Helm began in 1900 as a Hamburg-based import-export business "for merchandise of every description."
About_#3: Dieter's father, Hermann, took over from the namesake founder, Karl O. Helm, in 1950 and set a path focused on chemicals.
About_#4: After succeeding Hermann as chairman of the executive board in 1984, Dieter continued to expand overseas.

About_#1: Renate Sick-Glaser and her son, Sebastian Glaser, are majority shareholders of Sick AG, a world leader in sensor technology.
About_#2: Her father, Erwin Sick, an optical engineer, founded the company in 1946, using earnings from selling radios he made himself to support his family.
About_#3: After Erwin died in 1988, his wife Gisela became the company's primary shareholder and installed external managers.
About_#4: Active globally with more than 50 subsidiaries, Sick AG now employs around 10,000 people and has annual sales exceeding $2 billion.
Did You Know?: Sick-Glaser trained as a physiotherapist. Together, she and her son Sebastian (listed separately as a billionaire) own almost 53% of Sick AG.

Education: Master of Arts, Patna University
About_#1: Basudeo Singh is the executive chairman of Indian generics firm Alkem Laboratories.
About_#2: His son Dhananjay Kumar Singh, Alkem's joint managing director, has been named to succeed him as executive chairman.
About_#3: Basudeo Singh is the cousin of Alkem's late billionaire cofounder Samprada Singh.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, St. John Fisher College
About_#1: Ed Stack is the executive chairman and largest individual shareholder of Dick's Sporting Goods.
About_#2: His father, Dick Stack, founded the retailer in 1948 with a $300 loan from his grandmother.
About_#3: Ed and his siblings bought the company from his father when it only had two stores in upstate New York.
About_#4: When his father retired in 1984, Ed took over as CEO and chairman; he stepped down as CEO in February 2021.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Shandong Institute of Business and Technology
About_#1: Sun Weijie chairs the Yantai Jereh Oilfield Services Group, a supplier of oil exploration equipment.
About_#2: Jereh was listed at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2014.
About_#3: Sun founded Jereh in 1999.

Education: Bachelor of Commerce, Chulalongkorn University
About_#1: Vonnarat Tangkaravakoon is the eldest son of Prachak Tangkaravakoon, who chairs TOA Paint (Thailand), Thailand's biggest paints company.
About_#2: Vonnarat became a billionaire after the backdoor listing of his cable and wire firm, Stark Corporation, in 2019. He sold some shares in 2021 to increase the company's free float.
About_#3: Vonnarat also owns a stake in TOA Paint (Thailand).
About_#4: TOA Paint has three plants in Thailand, plus factories in Vietnam, Laos, Myanmar, Malaysia, Indonesia and Cambodia.

About_#1: Byron Trott is the founder, chairman and CEO of BDT & Co., a Chicago-based advisory and private equity firm.
About_#2: He started the company in 2009 after nearly thirty years at Goldman Sachs.
About_#3: Trott began his career as a stockbroker at Goldman Sachs and eventually became vice chairman of investment banking.
About_#4: One of BDT's first investments was grill-maker Weber. The company went public in August 2021.
Did You Know?: While at Goldman Sachs, Trott worked under former Treasury Secretary Hank Paulson, who was CEO of the bank.

About_#1: Jan Van Geet is the founder and CEO of VGP, a Belgian real estate company.
About_#2: VGP specializes in developing industrial office parks, with properties in 12 European countries.
About_#3: Van Geet founded the company in 1998 in the former Czech Republic.
About_#4: He currently owns about a third of the publicly-traded company, which listed its shares in 2007.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Indian Institute of Technology Madras (IIT Madras)
About_#1: Radha Vembu gets her wealth from her stake in privately held Zoho Corp, which offers business software on the cloud.
About_#2: The company was cofounded by her older brother Sridhar Vembu, who started the business initially as AdventNet in 1996.
About_#3: A graduate in industrial management from the elite IIT Madras, Vembu is a product manager for email service, Zoho Mail.
About_#4: In 2020 Zoho launched a remote work tool kit called Zoho Remotely to help businesses to switch to work-from-home.
Did You Know?: Zoho is headquartered in Austin, Texas where it has a 375-acre campus.

Education: Ph.D, La Sapienza University of Rome
About_#1: Patrizio Vinciarelli founded Vicor Corp in 1981 and is the president, CEO and chairman of the company.
About_#2: Vicor designs, develops, and manufactures power components such as AC-DC converters.
About_#3: Before starting Vicor, Vinciarelli studied high-energy physics at CERN in Switzerland and the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, NJ.
About_#4: He has a PhD in physics from the University of Rome and holds more than 100 patents electronics conversion technology.

Education: EMBA, Sun Yat-sen University
About_#1: Wang Mingwang is the co-founder of China electronics maker Sunwoda, a supplier of lithium-ion battery modules.
About_#2: Wang Wei, his brother and co-founder, chairs the Shenzhen-headquartered company.
About_#3: Sunwoda's customers include Apple and Huawei.

About_#1: Wang Yanqing inherited her fortune from her husband Chen Guangwei, who died in April 2017.
About_#2: Chen Guangwei founded Weihai Guangwei Group in 1987; Wang is a company director.
About_#3: The group owns 38% of Weihai Guangwei Composites, which listed on the Shenzhen exchange in September 2017.
About_#4: Founded in 1992, Guangwei produces advanced composites and fibre fabric.

About_#1: Lars Wingefors is the cofounder and CEO of Embracer Group, Europe's biggest gaming company.
About_#2: Wingefors owns 28% of the company, which listed on the Stockholm stock exchange in 2016.
About_#3: Embracer has a catalog with over 200 game franchises, operates 57 gaming studios and has over 5,500 employees spread across 40 countries.
About_#4: In, 1993, at age 15, Wingefors started a company to buy and flip used video games.
Did You Know?: At 9, Wingefors sold seeds and newspapers, and at 13 he started a company to trade comic books. Two years later, he was running Sweden's largest mail-order company.

Education: Master of Science, Stanford University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, The University of Texas at Austin
About_#1: Stephen Winn is the founder and CEO of RealPage, a firm that provides rental management software to landlords across the nation.
About_#2: Its products help landlords manage finances and compliance requirements, and enable tenants to pay rent and file maintenance requests electronically.
About_#3: An electrical engineer by training, Winn started his career working for his father's accounting software firm, Computer Language Research.
About_#4: He eventually took over as CEO of the family business, and founded RealPage in 1998.
Did You Know?: RealPage's software is used to manage over 11 million rental units in the U.S.

About_#1: Ian Wood transformed a family-owned fishing business based in Aberdeen, Scotland into John Wood Group, a multinational oil services company listed on the London Stock Exchange.
About_#2: He joined the firm in 1962, became CEO in 1967 and took the business public in 2002. He later served as chairman before retiring in 2012.
About_#3: Under his watch, John Wood Group expanded its operations to over 50 countries and had over 60,000 employees.
About_#4: Wood and his family have sold much of their stake in the company over the years, diversifying into other investments.
Did You Know?: Wood is believed to be the only Scot to hold both a KT and GBE, Scotland's high order of chivalry and the highest rank in the Order of the British Empire.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Princeton University; Master, Princeton University
About_#1: Gordon Wu chairs Hopewell Holdings, one of Hong Kong's largest builders of roads, tunnels and bridges.
About_#2: The Princeton University-educated business icon also boasts extensive interests in southern China.
About_#3: Son Thomas Jefferson was a managing director until 2019.
About_#4: In April 2018, Wu and his son accepted a cash offer to sell their entire stake in Hopewell Highway Infrastructure.

About_#1: Yao Kuizhang chairs Hebei Yangyuan Zhihui Beverage, a supplier of walnut drinks.
About_#2: Yao owns 30% of the company.
About_#3: Yao worked for Hebei Hengshui Laobaigan Liquor as a technician early in his career.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Mendeleyev Chemical Engin; Master of Economics, Moscow State University
About_#1: Vladimir Yevtushenkov owns 59% of AFK Sistema, which has stakes in Russia's largest cellular operator MTS, online retailer Ozon and healthcare chain Medsi.
About_#2: A former plastics engineer, Yevtushenkov cofounded Sistema in 1993.
About_#3: He took Sistema public in 2005.
About_#4: In 2014, AFK Sistema was accused of illegally acquiring a controlling stake in oil firm Bashneft. The shares were returned and sold to state-owned Rosneft.
In Their Own Words: Any state will always find a way to put you in your place.

About_#1: Yi Dasheng chairs Hunan Fortune Group, whose business interests include property development, auto-related services and trade.
About_#2: Yi worked in a government office in the southern Chinese city of Yueyang before taking the plunge as an entrepreneur.
About_#3: He made his early fortune in auto repair.

Education: Master of Science, University of Rochester; Bachelor of Commerce, University of Toronto
About_#1: Alan Zekelman owns a stake in his family's steel business, Zekelman Industries.
About_#2: The $5 billion (revenues) company is one of North America's largest steel pipe and tube makers.
About_#3: Alan and his brothers, fellow billionaires Barry Zekelman and Clayton Zekelman, split 100% ownership of Zekelman Industries.
About_#4: They sold the company to the Carlyle Group in 2006 for some $1.2 billion, but bought the business back in 2011.

About_#1: Zeng Kaitian became a billionaire in 2015 when Sanqi Interactive Entertainment Shanghai Technology (cofounder) was bought by Wuhu Shunrong Auto Parts.
About_#2: Sanqi Interactive owns web game platforms 37.com and 6711.com.
About_#3: Wuhu Shunrong is now called Wuhu Shunrong Sanqi Interactive Entertainment.

About_#1: Zhang Jingzhang chairs two companies: Shanghai-listed Ningbo Haitian Precision Machinery and Hong Kong-listed Haitian International Holding.
About_#2: Haitian International Holdings designs and manufactures plastic injection molding machines and related parts.
About_#3: Ningbo Haitian Precision Machinery is a maker of machining centers.

About_#1: Zhou Zongwen chairs Chow Tai Seng Jewelry, which listed on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2017.
About_#2: Zhou is a graduate of the China University of Geosciences.
About_#3: Zhou opened the first Chow Tai Seng jewelry store in Beijing in 1999.

About_#1: Zhu Yiming chairs Shenzhen-listed GigaDevice Semiconductor (Beijing), a supplier of computer memory chips.
About_#2: Zhu holds degrees from Tsinghua University and State University of New York at Stony Brook.
About_#3: Zhu worked for iPolicy Networks and Monolithic System Technologies before he founded GigaDevice in 2004.

About_#1: Zhu Zhaojiang chairs Shenzhen Transsion, a supplier of mobile phones global emerging markets.
About_#2: Transsion isheadquartered in Shenzhen.
About_#3: Zhu founded Transsion Technology--the predecessor of the listed company -- in 2006.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Florida; Master of Arts, University of North Florida
About_#1: Anita Zucker is CEO of Charleston, South Carolina-based InterTech Group, a private, family-owned chemicals manufacturer.
About_#2: InterTech was founded in 1982 by Zucker's late husband, Jerry, who died of a brain tumor in 2008 at age 58.
About_#3: The company, which has estimated revenues of roughly $3 billion, also owns an aerospace engineering firm and extensive commercial real estate.
About_#4: Jerry Zucker, an immigrant from Israel, was a prolific inventor who was granted numerous patents.
Did You Know?: The daughter of a holocaust survivor, Zucker is a former elementary school teacher. Now she's the only billionaire in South Carolina.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Williams College
About_#1: Herbert "Herb" A. Allen controls boutique investment bank Allen & Co., which focuses on tech companies.
About_#2: Allen & Co. has had a hand in several large tech IPOs of the last decade, including Twitter, Groupon and LinkedIn.
About_#3: The firm was founded as an investment partnership in 1922 by Allen's uncle Charles.
About_#4: Allen was reportedly named president of the firm's nascent underwriting business in 1966 at the age of 26.
Did You Know?: Allen is the largest individual holder of Coca-Cola stock, though his 12 million shares account for less than 1% of the company's stock.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Alma-Ata Institute of National Economy
About_#1: Vasily Anisimov's development company Coalco has 37,000 acres of land near Moscow.
About_#2: Some of the land is in a high end village called Akulinino where friends of President Vladimir Putin, like billionaire Arkady Rotenberg, have houses.
About_#3: Anisimov made his first fortune in non-ferrous metals trading.
About_#4: Later he became a partner of billionaires Alisher Usmanov and Andrei Skoch, before selling out to move into real estate.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Tel Aviv University
About_#1: Mori Arkin got his start in business in 1972 helping his father run a small Israeli pharmaceutical distribution company.
About_#2: The Arkins eventually moved into generic drug manufacturing, founding Agis Industries.
About_#3: In 2004, they sold Agis to U.S. pharmaceutical company Perrigo for $818 million in cash and stock.
About_#4: Still bullish on healthcare, he oversaw a January 2018 public offering on Nasdaq of Sol-Gel Technologies, a dermatology company. He owns over 62%.
Did You Know?: His two sons are involved in the family business; his daughter is serving in the Israel Defense Forses.

About_#1: Semahat Sevim Arsel is an heir to the Koc family fortune. She's the oldest member of the clan and the largest shareholder in its main holding company.
About_#2: Besides energy, automotive, durable consumer goods and finance, Koc is active in technology, food, retail, tourism, agriculture and shipbuilding.
About_#3: Semahat Arsel serves on the board of Koc Holding and is chairman of its tourism company, Setur. Her husband, Dr. Nusret Arsel, died in 2014 at age 92.
About_#4: He left all of his wealth to the Vehbi Koc Foundation, named after his father-in-law. Semahat Arsel is president of the foundation.
Did You Know?: She suffered from an extended childhood illness, which later motivated her to establish the Semahat Arsel Nursing Education and Research Centre (SANERC).

Education: Doctorate, University of Chicago; Master of Business Administration, University of Chicago; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Cliff Asness is the cofounder of AQR Capital Management, a money management firm that oversees $124 billion.
About_#2: AQR stands for Applied Quantitative Research. It focuses on factor-based investing, offering products ranging from hedge funds to mutual funds.
About_#3: A finance Ph.D, Asness is an active researcher and worked in quantitative research for Goldman Sachs before starting AQR in 1998.
Did You Know?: Asness backed lawmakers who supported New York's marriage equality initiative and is a board member of the International Rescue Committee.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Columbia Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Middlebury College
About_#1: One of Wall Street's macro-trading legends, Louis Bacon cut his teeth as a commodities and currencies trader, earning big profits in the 1987 crash.
About_#2: He created hedge fund Moore Capital in 1989 using trading profits and a small inheritance.
About_#3: Bacon announced he was closing his hedge fund and returning outside investors' money in November 2019, citing years of "disappointing results."
About_#4: Moore Capital still manages internal money and scored 70% returns in 2020 for Bacon and his employees.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology Delhi
About_#1: Hari Bhartia co-chairs the Jubilant Bhartia group with interests in energy, fast food, pharma and auto distribution.
About_#2: The Jubilant group includes four listed companies.
About_#3: Jubilant FoodWorks has 1,500 Domino's Pizza outlets and 29 Dunkin Donuts stores in India.
About_#4: Jubilant Life Sciences was split into two companies, Jubilant Pharmova and Jubilant Ingrevia. The latter was listed in March 2021.
Did You Know?: Jubilant FoodWorks has 32 restaurants in Bangladesh with a partner.

About_#1: Shyam Bhartia chairs the Jubilant Bhartia group with interests in energy, fast food, pharma and auto distribution.
About_#2: The Jubilant group has four listed companies.
About_#3: Jubilant Foodworks has 1,500 Domino's Pizza outlets and 29 Dunkin Donuts stores in India.
About_#4: Jubilant Life Sciences was split into two companies, Jubilant Pharmova and Jubilant Ingrevia. The latter was listed in March 2021.
Did You Know?: Jubilant FoodWorks has 32 restaurants in Bangladesh with a partner.

Education: Master of Science, Columbia University; Master of Business Administration, Judge Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Lehigh University
About_#1: Amit Burman is chairman of Indian consumer goods giant Dabur. He was appointed in July 2019.
About_#2: An MBA from Cambridge University, he started off in Dabur's industrial engineering department where he worked on mechanization and packaging.
About_#3: He went on to lead Dabur's foray into processed foods spanning the gamut from cooking pastes to fruit juices.
About_#4: In 2020, Burman acquired a stake in No Worry No Tension Healthcare, a startup that uses artificial intelligence to gauge emotional wellness.
Did You Know?: Apart from a minority stake in Dabur, he also has stakes in other privately held businesses such as restaurant chain Lite Bite Foods.

About_#1: Chen Tianshi chairs microchip supplier Cambricon Technologies.
About_#2: Chen founded Cambricon in March 2016.
About_#3: Before setting up Cambricon, he worked for the Chinese Academy of Sciences' Institute of Computing Technology as a researcher.
About_#4: Chen holds a Ph.D. from the University of Science and Technology of China.

About_#1: Robert Clark is the founder of Chicago-based construction firm Clayco, which he started in 1984 as a college dropout.
About_#2: The St. Louis native owns roughly half of the company and built it into one of the largest construction firms in the U.S.
About_#3: Clayco's projects include the Washington University School of Medicine and several Amazon e-commerce centers.
About_#4: Clark stepped down as Clayco's executive chairman in September 2021 to become the commissioner general for the U.S. pavilion at Expo 2020 in Dubai.

Full Name: Ana Lucia de Mattos Barretto Villela
About_#1: Ana Lucia de Mattos Barretto Villela is a member of one of Brazil's oldest banking families and is the youngest female billionaire in Brazil.
About_#2: Her great-grandfather founded the bank Itau, which merged with Unibanco in 2008 to form Itau-Unibanco, Latin America's biggest private sector bank.
About_#3: She is one of the largest individual shareholders of Itausa, the bank's holding company, with about 12% of common shares and 3% of preferred shares.
About_#4: Her grandfather founded Duratex, a publicly-traded Brazilian maker of wood paneling and bathroom fixtures; she is a shareholder.
In Their Own Words: It is so obvious that children need nature as much as nature needs children. However, we forgot this obvious fact and swept it under the carpet.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School
About_#1: Jamie Dimon runs JPMorgan Chase, the largest bank in the U.S. in terms of assets.
About_#2: He began his finance career at American Express in 1982 and later helped build the modern day Citigroup.
About_#3: The Harvard Business School grad joined JPMorgan Chase in 2004; he became CEO and chairman soon after.
About_#4: His move to unload $12 billion of subprime mortgages in 2006 buffered his bank against the 2008 crash.
Did You Know?: His Greek grandfather worked at Bank of Athens and changed the family name from Papademetriou to Dimon.
In Their Own Words: Never fool yourselves into thinking that your success is yours alone.

Education: Master of Business Administration, University of St. Gallen
About_#1: After running the aluminum business for Glencore, Gary Fegel left the commodities giant in 2013 and built a diversified investment portfolio.
About_#2: Through his companies, Fegel invests in everything from assisted living to tech startups, private companies and financial instruments.
About_#3: His New York-based investment firm GMF Capital owns 20,000 apartments and over 100 healthcare properties.
About_#4: Most recently, Fegel bought an estimated stake of 15% in Israeli medical cannabis firm InterCure, whose chairman is former Israeli premier Ehud Barak.
Did You Know?: Fegel, his wife Yael who is a British lawyer, and their children split their time between Switzerland, London and New York.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Peking University
About_#1: Gao Yunfeng chairs Han's Laser Technology Industry Group, a supplier of laser-based products for industrial applications.
About_#2: Han's Laser Technology was founded by Gao in 1996.
About_#3: Gao holds an undergraduate degree in aircraft design from Beihang University and an MBA from Peking University.

About_#1: Philippe Ginestet owns French discount chain GiFi, known for its low prices on household goods, the majority of which cost less than five euros.
About_#2: GiFi boasts annual revenue of about $1.8 billion and some 530 stores, mostly in France.
About_#3: Ginestet founded the company in 1981 and remains chairman. His son, Alexandre, is CEO.
About_#4: In 2017, GiFi acquired Tati, a famous French discount chain often identified by its bright pink logo.
Did You Know?: The name GiFi is a patronym, combining the first syllables of Ginestet's last name and first name.

About_#1: Sebastian Glaser and his mother, Renate Sick-Glaser, are majority shareholders of Sick AG, a world leader in sensor technology.
About_#2: His grandfather Erwin Sick, an optical engineer, founded the firm in 1946, using earnings from selling radios he made himself to support his family.
About_#3: After the death of Erwin in 1988, his wife Gisela became the company's primary shareholder and installed external managers.
About_#4: Active globally with more than 50 subsidiaries, Sick AG now employs around 10,000 people and has annual sales exceeding $2 billion.
Did You Know?: After World War II, the American military in Munich granted Erwin Sick a license to set up own engineering firm, which became Sick AG.

About_#1: Son of a Fujian farmer, Sam Goi owns Tee Yih Jia Food Manufacturing, the world's largest maker of popiah skins, which are used for spring rolls.
About_#2: Goi dropped out of school to work in his father's grocery store then got into frozen foods when he bought a struggling food unit.
About_#3: He also has real estate interests through his stakes in listed firms GSH and KOP.
About_#4: Goi is Singapore's non-resident ambassador to Brazil.
Did You Know?: Goi sold a 28-story office tower in Singapore for $512 million to a Chinese buyer in 2017.
In Their Own Words: When you have a plateful while others are hungry for a mouthful, it's a recipe for trouble.

Education: Bachelor of Science, The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania; Bachelor of Science, University of Pennsylvania, School of Engineering and Applied Science
About_#1: Lance Gokongwei is the only son of the late John Gokongwei Jr. who founded JG Summit, one of Philippines' largest conglomerates.
About_#2: He now serves as chief executive of the company, which spans interests in airlines, telecom, banking, food, power and property.
About_#3: He also has a stake in Robinsons Retail, one of Philippines' largest retailers, which was started by his father as a department store in 1980.
About_#4: Gokongwei got his start selling Jack 'n Jill snacks to supermarkets and sari-sari stores in the Philippines.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Togliatti Academy of Management
About_#1: Sergei Gordeev is an investor in startups including Hyperloop One, a U.S. highspeed-travel startup.
About_#2: In 1995, he founded Rosbuilding, which bought shares of different plants.
About_#3: He bought a 20% stake in home builder PIK Group from billionaire Suleiman Kerimov in 2013, and eventually became the controlling shareholder.
About_#4: He made his fortune buying up shares of industrial companies in Moscow and then turning factories into office complexes.
Did You Know?: Gordeev, who is interested in architecture, designed his own house in a London suburb.
In Their Own Words: We set ourselves a goal to become something like Apple in residential construction. We pay great attention to product and design.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Anderson School of Management; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Duke University
About_#1: Gross cofounded PIMCO, an investment management firm, in 1971 and became known as a superstar bond fund manager.
About_#2: He decamped in 2014, and joined Janus Henderson to manage a global macro bond fund; he retired in March 2019.
About_#3: Gross sued PIMCO for wrongful dismissal in 2015. The case was settled in March 2017 for $81 million, which went to the Sue and Bill Gross Foundation.
About_#4: In 2016, Gross' wife of 31 years, Sue, filed for divorce. She eventually walked away with over $1 billion.
Did You Know?: Named after him, the William H. Gross Stamp Gallery at the Smithsonian National Postal is the world's largest gallery dedicated to philately.

Education: Associate in Arts/Science, Saddleback College
About_#1: Sue Gross is the ex-wife of PIMCO cofounder and billionaire Bill Gross. The two divorced in 2017 after 32 years of marriage.
About_#2: Gross got roughly $1.3 billion including a $36 million house in Laguna beach and half of the couple's art collection.
About_#3: After the divorce, she sold a Picasso painting for $35 million and purchased a number of properties in Orange County.
About_#4: In 2017, Sue Gross started her own charitable vehicle, Sue J. Gross Foundation.

Education: Bachelor of Science, University of Wisconsin Madison; Ph.D, University of Wisconsin Madison
About_#1: Patrick Hanrahan cofounded data analytics company Tableau in 2003.
About_#2: Salesforce acquired Tableau in June 2019 in a $15.7 billion, all-stock deal.
About_#3: Hanrahan is a computer graphics and electrical engineering professor at Stanford University.
About_#4: Tableau was born out of research he and one of his cofounders were doing while analyzing and visualizing large databases of information at Stanford.

About_#1: Lutz Mario Helmig, a doctor by training, is well known in Germany for having founded the company that became Helios Hospital Group.
About_#2: In 2005, Helmig sold Helios to competitor Fresenius for $2 billion.
About_#3: His family investment firm, Aton AG, is active in four segments: engineering, mining, medical and aviation.
About_#4: Helmig owns 60% of Aton, which is based in Munich. The remaining 40% is held by his wife and two daughters.
Did You Know?: In 2013 Helmig donated almost $3 million to Grebenhain, a village where he has resided since the 1970s.

About_#1: Ilkka Herlin is the great-grandson of famed Finnish business leader Harald Herlin, who invested in Kone Elevators in 1924.
About_#2: After his father's death in 2003, Ilkka and his siblings discovered the will had been rewritten leaving most of the ownership in Kone to their brother Antti.
About_#3: Angered that they had never been informed, the siblings battled for control. The dispute ended in 2005, with Kone being split in two.
About_#4: Antti maintained control over the elevator business while his siblings were given stakes in Cargotec, producer of machinery for heavy duty ship cargo.
Did You Know?: Ilkka Herling has a PhD in History from the University of Helsingfors.

About_#1: Asok Kumar Hiranandani is the cofounder of the erstwhile Royal Brothers property group.
About_#2: He separated from his older brother Raj Kumar in 2011 after dividing their property empire.
About_#3: His Royal Group, run by son Bobby, owns the 215-room Sofitel Singapore Sentosa Resort.
About_#4: Hiranandani is setting up Singapore's second Raffles hotel in Sentosa, consisting of 62 villas.
In Their Own Words: I'd rather give the business over when I'm alive.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, National Chiao Tung University
About_#1: Hwang founded Hermes-Microvision in 1977 as a distributor of semiconductor equipment.
About_#2: He sold his semiconductor-equipment supplier to ASML of the Netherlands for $3.1 billion in 2016.
About_#3: Hermes-Epitek, the parent company of Hermes-Microvision, has offices in China, Malaysia, Singapore and Taiwan.
About_#4: Hwang, who also goes by the name Hwang Min Qi, chairs the group.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University
About_#1: Jared Isaacman is the founder and CEO of Allentown, Pennsylvania-based payment processing firm Shift4 Payments.
About_#2: Shift4 handles payments for a third of America's restaurants and hotels; Isaacman took it public in June 2020 and owns 38% of the stock.
About_#3: He started the firm at age 16 in his parents' basement in Far Hills, New Jersey in 1999.
About_#4: In 2011, he founded Draken International, a defense firm that trains Air Force pilots and owns the world's largest private fleet of military aircraft.
Did You Know?: Isaacman is a fighter jet pilot and his call sign is "Rook."
In Their Own Words: You only get so many flight hours. It's not a whole lot of time, so it really just comes down to maximizing it while you can.

About_#1: Motorcycle tycoon Rahul Bajaj's nephew Anurang Jain started Endurance Technologies in 1985 to supply aluminum castings to his uncle's Bajaj Auto.
About_#2: Jain owns a majority stake in Endurance, which supplies parts for two-wheelers and three-wheelers in India and car parts in Europe.
About_#3: Endurance has 18 factories in India and 9 in Europe.
About_#4: Jain made news when he bought two apartments in 2020 for $14 million in a Mumbai luxury high-rise, close to Mukesh Ambani's residence.
Did You Know?: Jain's twin Tarang runs his own auto components firm called Varroc Engineering.
In Their Own Words: At Endurance, we believe that uncertainty is the new normal in business.

Education: Bachelor of Business Administration, University of Buckingham
About_#1: Sunjay Kapur is chairman of Sona BLW Precision, which manufactures precision forged gears for cars, trucks, tractors and off-road vehicles.
About_#2: The company was founded in 1997 by his late father Surinder Kapur, who was a pioneer in India's auto components industry.
About_#3: Sunjay took over as managing director after his father's death in 2015.
About_#4: Sona has nine factories spread across India, China, Mexico and the U.S.
Did You Know?: Sona, which means gold in Hindi, was named after his grandfather's jewelry business.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University; Master of Business Administration, University of California, Los Angeles
About_#1: Richard Kayne cofounded alternative asset manager Kayne Anderson Capital Advisors.
About_#2: The $26 billion (assets under management) company is the largest investor in energy pipelines in the United States.
About_#3: Kayne began his career as an analyst in New York in the mid 1960s then managed money at financials services firm Cantor Fitzgerald.
About_#4: He launched Kayne Anderson in 1984 and remains its co-chairman.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Radford; Doctor of Jurisprudence, University of Virginia
About_#1: Randal Kirk, a former practicing attorney, is chairman of venture capital and private equity firm Third Security, LLC.
About_#2: In January 2020, he stepped down as CEO of biotech firm Precigen (formerly Intrexon), but was appointed executive chairman.
About_#3: He achieved his first entrepreneurial success with an injectable drug and vaccine distributor, which he eventually sold for $145 million.
About_#4: His investments have made waves for innovative products, like apples that never brown and a genetically modified species of salmon.
Did You Know?: Kirk's father was a master sergeant in the U.S. Air Force.
In Their Own Words: Every man will yield the results he deserves.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Harvard University; Master of Business Administration, Harvard University
About_#1: Jim (James) Koch created Samuel Adams beer in 1984 and has since been known as a founding father of the American craft brewery movement.
About_#2: A Harvard graduate, Koch quit his consulting job and began brewing beer in his kitchen, using his great-great grandfather's 1870s recipe.
About_#3: The first batch Koch brewed was Boston Lager. He started selling the beer door-to-door at Boston bars and restaurants.
About_#4: He took Boston Beer public in 1995 and owns a 19.5% stake. In 2020, the company sold more than $1.7 billion worth of 60-plus types of beer.
Did You Know?: Koch still taste tests every batch of beer himself.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Doctorate, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
About_#1: William "Bill" Koch, brother of Koch Industries CEO Charles Koch, is the founder of petroleum coke and sulphur products company Oxbow Corp.
About_#2: The Kansas native formed his own company after selling his stake in Koch Industries to brothers Charles and David (d. 2019) for $470 million in 1983.
About_#3: He battled his brothers for more than a decade over the payout amount, but eventually lost the case.
About_#4: William's brother Frederick also sold his stake in Koch Industries to Charles and David in 1983.
Did You Know?: Bill and David were fraternal twins; the duo went to MIT together and played on the same basketball team.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Kansai University
About_#1: Kagemasa Kozuki is the founder and chairman of Konami Holdings, a developer of videogames.
About_#2: The Tokyo-listed company has had success with free-to-play smartphone soccer games.
About_#3: His company also produces gaming machines for casinos in the U.S. and elsewhere.
About_#4: His son Takuya is a director of Konami Holdings.
Did You Know?: Kozuki got his start repairing jukeboxes and cathode ray tube televisions.

About_#1: Arvind Lal is executive chairman of the $ 216 million (revenue) diagnostics chain, Dr Lal PathLabs, in which he owns a majority stake.
About_#2: The company has 281 clinical labs and more than 4,000 collection centers across India.
About_#3: It offers nearly 5,000 pathology and radiology tests, including Covid-19 tests.
About_#4: The business was founded by his father S.K. Lal, also a doctor, in 1949 in Delhi. Arvind Lal joined the business after studying medicine, at age 28.
Did You Know?: Lal is a published author whose book, 'Corporate Yogi: My Journey as a Spiritual Seeker and an Accidental Entrepreneur' was published in 2018.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Cornell University; Doctorate, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
About_#1: Robert Langer is a scientist and professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, where he leads the eponymous Langer Lab.
About_#2: Langer was a founder of Cambridge, Mass.-based biotech firm Moderna; he owns a 3% stake in the company and has never sold a share.
About_#3: He also owns shares in SQZ Biotechnologies, Seer and Sigilon Therapeutics, which were founded by him and postdoc students from his lab.
About_#4: Langer is estimated to be the most cited engineer in history, with more than 350,000 citations and more than 1,500 articles published.
Did You Know?: Langer has received more than 200 prizes throughout his career, including the National Medals of Science and Technology.

About_#1: Theodore 'Ted' Leonsis is founder, majority owner and CEO of Monumental Sports, which owns several teams and arenas in Washington, D.C.
About_#2: Subsidiaries include the NBA's Wizards, the NHL's Capitals, the WNBA's Washington Mystics and Capital One Arena.
About_#3: The grandson of Greek immigrants, Leonsis initially built his fortune as a senior executive at AOL, where he worked for nearly 14 years.
About_#4: He is a cofounder and partner at Revolution Growth, a venture capital firm helmed by AOL cofounder Steve Case.
Did You Know?: Leonsis runs a blog called Ted's Take, where he posts commentary on business and sports.

About_#1: David Li is chairman and co-founder of YY, a Nasdaq-listed live streaming and social media platform in China.
About_#2: Before co-founding YY, Li was chief editor at Chinese portal Netease.com.
About_#3: Earlier in his career, Li founded CFP.cn, a copyright trading platform for journalists and amateur photographers.
About_#4: Li received an undergraduate degree in philosophy from Renmin University of China in 1997.

About_#1: Li Jiaquan chairs Lomon Group, a chemical supplier.
About_#2: Li founded the predecessor company of Lomon in Sichuan Province in 1985.
About_#3: Li sold Lomon's titanium dioxide business to Shenzhen-listed Henan Billions Chemicals for $1.3 billion in 2016.

Education: Chinese University of Hong Kong
