About_#1: Property tycoon Li Sze Lim has planted his R&F Properties flag from Johor, Malaysia to San Jose, California.
About_#2: Li cofounded R&F Properties in 1994 with Zhang Li on the mainland.
About_#3: His company soon diversified into hotels in partnership with Marriott, Hyatt, and Hilton, and quickly expanded into shopping malls and offices.
About_#4: With its $3 billion acquisition of 77 hotels from Wanda Group in 2017, R&F says it has become the world's biggest luxury hotel owner, with 90 hotels.

About_#1: Li Yongqing is a director of Rongsheng Petrochemical, a petrochemical and chemical fiber manufacturer.
About_#2: Brother Li Guoqing, a Rongsheng supervisor, was also a member of the 2021 Forbes Billionaires List.
About_#3: Rongsheng is headquartered in the eastern Chinese city of Hangzhou.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Sul Ross State University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Malaya
About_#1: Lim Wee Chai started Top Glove with his wife Tong Siew Bee in 1991 and took the company public in 2001.
About_#2: Top Glove is one of the world's largest producers of rubber gloves. It has 50 factories with an annual capacity of 100 billion gloves.
About_#3: Lim, whose parents are rubber plantation owners and traders, also holds a stake in property developer Tropicana.
About_#4: Top Glove shares fell in 2021 as the pandemic-induced demand for gloves eased.

About_#1: Liu Ming Chung and his wife, Cheung Yan, who is also a billionaire, lead Nine Dragons Paper, one of Asia's largest paper producers.
About_#2: Hong Kong-listed Nine Dragons started out as a supplier of packaging for exporters in China, and now also benefits from consumer demand inside China.
About_#3: Liu is CEO and deputy chairman of Nine Dragons. He is the second husband of Nine Dragons cofounder and chairwoman Cheung Yan.
About_#4: Liu was born in Taiwan and grew up in Brazil. He holds a bachelor's degree in dental surgery from the University of Santo Amaro, in Brazil.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, University of New South Wales
About_#1: The bulk of Vincent Lo's fortune stems from his listed Shui On Land, best known for developing Shanghai's entertainment district, Xintiandi.
About_#2: Lo also owns Shui On Centre, a landmark building in Wan Chai.
About_#3: His daughter and heir apparent Stephanie is an executive director at Shui On Land.
About_#4: Vincent has been supporting his brother Lo Ka Shui against their mother, Lo To Lee Kwan, in a family feud over a trust fund.
Did You Know?: Vincent Lo was sued by Donald Trump in 2005, who claimed former partners Lo and Henry Cheng had not consulted him and closed on a deal for less than he would have.

About_#1: Brandt Louie presides over grocery retailer H.Y. Louie and drug store chain London Drugs.
About_#2: His Vancouver-based holding company H.Y. Louie is the third-largest private firm in British Columbia, with an estimated $4.2 billion in revenues.
About_#3: His grandfather, Hok Yat Louie, immigrated to Vancouver from China in 1896 and worked as a farm laborer.
About_#4: Hok Yat eventually saved enough money to open a small general store in the city's Chinatown in 1903.
Did You Know?: Prior to working for H.Y. Louie, Brandt was a chartered accountant.

About_#1: Catherine Lozick inherited an estimated 65% stake in Swagelok, a valve-making business her father, Fred Lennon, cofounded in 1947.
About_#2: Lennon (d. 1998) started Swagelock with a $500 loan; he first appeared on The Forbes 400 list of richest Americans in 1990.
About_#3: Lennon left his son, John Lennon, a much smaller inheritance ($25 million) than his daughter.
About_#4: John Lennon's son William sued Lozick and her trustees in 2002, exposing the details on the family's finances.

About_#1: Lu Zongjun chairs Shanghai Zhonggu Logistics, a domestic container shipping company in China.
About_#2: Zhonggu went public at the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 2020.
About_#3: Lu holds a graduate degree from the Wuhan University of Technology.

About_#1: Lv Jianming chairs Shanghai-listed Topchoice Medical, a supplier of medical equipment and disinfection products.
About_#2: Lv graduated from Hangzhou University (now part of Zhejiang University) with a major in Chinese.
About_#3: Lv has been a board member at Zhejiang University since 2017.

About_#1: Cargill MacMillan III is one of 12 billionaire heirs to Cargill, the world's biggest agriculture business.
About_#2: His great-great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.
About_#3: The family still owns roughly 90% of Cargill, which did $114.6 billion in 2020 sales across food, agriculture, financial and industrial divisions.
About_#4: The Cargill-MacMillan family collects an estimated 18% of net profits as dividends every year.

About_#1: Duncan MacMillan cofounded financial data and media company Bloomberg LP in 1981 with Mike Bloomberg, Thomas Secunda and Charles Zegar.
About_#2: MacMillan left a job at investment bank Salomon Brothers to help Bloomberg with what was then called Innovative Market Systems.
About_#3: He is credited with designing many of Bloomberg LP's computer systems.
About_#4: Bloomberg has estimated revenues of $10 billion.
Did You Know?: An active philanthropist, MacMillan has signed the Giving Pledge, a promise to give at least half of his fortune to charitable causes.

About_#1: John MacMillan is one of 12 billionaire heirs to Cargill, the world's biggest agriculture business.
About_#2: His great-great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.
About_#3: The family still owns roughly 90% of Cargill, which did $114.6 billion in 2020 sales across food, agriculture, financial and industrial divisions.
About_#4: The Cargill-MacMillan family collects an estimated 18% of net profits as dividends every year.

About_#1: Martha MacMillan is one of 12 billionaire heirs to Cargill, the world's biggest agriculture business.
About_#2: Her great-great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.
About_#3: The family still owns roughly 90% of Cargill, which did $114.6 billion in 2020 sales across food, agriculture, financial and industrial divisions.
About_#4: The Cargill-MacMillan family collects an estimated 18% of net profits as dividends every year.

About_#1: William MacMillan is one of 12 billionaire heirs to Cargill, the world's biggest agriculture business.
About_#2: His great-great-grandfather, W.W. Cargill, founded the business as a single grain warehouse on the end of an Iowa railroad line in 1865.
About_#3: The family still owns roughly 90% of Cargill, which did $114.6 billion in 2020 sales across food, agriculture, financial and industrial divisions.
About_#4: The Cargill-MacMillan family collects an estimated 18% of net profits as dividends every year.

Education: Doctorate, Carleton College; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Wales
About_#1: A dual U.K. and Canadian citizen, Terence (Terry) Matthews made his fortune with telecom firms Mitel and Newbridge Networks.
About_#2: In December 2018, he left his Chairman role at Mitel, the company he co-founded with Michael Cowpland, after it was acquired for $2 billion.
About_#3: In 1986, Matthews founded data networking business Newbridge Networks before selling it to Alcatel in 2000 for $7.1 billion.
About_#4: He claims to have funded or founded more than 100 companies, many through his Ottawa-based investment firm Wesley Clover.
Did You Know?: Matthews was knighted by Queen Elizabeth in 2001; the honor created a diplomatic incident in Canada, which does not allow its citizens to accept foreign titles.

About_#1: Kazuo Okada founded Universal Entertainment, which manufactures and sells pachinko machines and casino equipment, in 1969.
About_#2: Formerly known as Aruze Corporation, Universal Entertainment trades on Tokyo's JASDAQ exchange.
About_#3: The firm owns and operates the Okada Manila casino and resort in the Philippines.
About_#4: In October 2021, Universal Entertainment announced the merger between Okada Manila and 26 Capital Acquisition Corp., a NASDAQ-listed special purpose acquisition company.
Did You Know?: An art enthusiast, Okada possesses art from Japan, China and Korea, which are displayed at The Okada Museum of Art in Hakone, Japan.

About_#1: Tomás Olivo López owns nearly all of shopping center chain General de Galerías Comerciales.
About_#2: His company has developed six shopping malls in the Andalucia and Catalonia regions of Spain.
About_#3: He began buying land outside of Marbella in the 1990s and built his first shopping mall, Parque Comercial La Canada, on that land.

About_#1: Jorge Pinheiro is the elder son of Candido Pinheiro Koren de Lima, the founder of Hapvida, a Brazilian healthcare and health insurance firm.
About_#2: Jorge, who studied medicine at the Federal University of Ceara in Brazil, has been the company's CEO since 2001.
About_#3: Hapvida went public in April 2018 on the Sao Paulo stock exchange; it has a network of 47 hospitals plus nearly 200 clinics in Brazil.
About_#4: Hapvida's origins date to 1986, when Jorge's father Candido, an oncologist, opened a hospital in northeastern Brazil.

Full Name: Candido Pinheiro Koren de Lima Junior
About_#1: Candido Junior is the younger son of Candido Pinheiro Koren de Lima, who founded Brazilian health insurance and hospital firm Hapvida.
About_#2: He is Hapvida's commercial and relationship vice president and serves as a board member.
About_#3: His older brother Jorge Pinheiro Koren de Lima, also a billionaire, is Hapvida's CEO.
About_#4: The family took Hapvida public on the Sao Paulo Stock Exchange in April 2018. His father Candido, the company's chairman, is also a billionaire.

About_#1: Qian is a co-founder and director of Shenzhen-listed pig breeder Muyuan Foods, one of the world's largest pig breeders.
About_#2: She is married to Muyuan chairman Qin Yinglin, with whom she co-founded the company in 1992 at age 26.
About_#3: The couple started out with 22 pigs.
About_#4: Qian is a graduate of the Henan University of Animal Husbandry Economy.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Nanjing Normal University; Diploma, Nanjing University of Chinese Medicine
About_#1: Ren is the founder and chairman of Simcere Pharmaceutical Group, a pharmaceuticals supplier. .
About_#2: Simcere has research development centers in Nanjing, Shanghai and Boston.
About_#3: Ren holds an undergraduate degree in traditional Chinese pharmacology from the Nanjing University of Chinese Medicine.
About_#4: He also holds a master's degree in business administration from the Nanjing Normal University.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Brian Roberts, the CEO and chairman of media and technology company Comcast, has sole voting power over approximately a third of the company's stock
About_#2: His father Ralph (d.2015) was the founder of Comcast, where Brian had his first internship at age 15.
About_#3: Roberts became president in 1990 at age 31; seven years later, his father Ralph transferred the bulk of his voting shares in the company to him.
About_#4: Comcast posted revenues of nearly $109 billion and a profit of $13.1 billion in 2019.
Did You Know?: A top ranked squash player, Roberts earned a gold medal with the U.S. team in 2005 and silver medals at the 1981, 1985 and 1997 Maccabiah Games in Israel.

Education: Drop Out, Stanford University
About_#1: College dropout Austin Russell founded and runs automotive sensor firm Luminar Technologies, which went public in a SPAC merger in Dec. 2020.
About_#2: An optics prodigy, Russell developed the idea for Luminar when he was just 17 and studying physics at Stanford University.
About_#3: He dropped out of college in 2012 after receiving a $100,000 Thiel Fellowship, a program funded by billionaire Peter Thiel to nurture entrepreneurs.
About_#4: Following Luminar's listing on Nasdaq, Russell became the world's youngest self-made billionaire at age 25.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Northeastern University; Master of Science in Engineering, Northeastern University; Bachelor of Science in Engineering, University of Maine
About_#1: George Sakellaris is the founder and CEO of Ameresco, a clean technology integrator that trades on the New York Stock Exchange.
About_#2: He got his start working for the utility New England Electric System, then purchased and expanded an energy services company.
About_#3: Ameresco provides clean energy consultation, development and implementation services for organizations.
About_#4: He took Ameresco public in 2010.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University
About_#1: Sheryl Sandberg has served as chief operating officer of Facebook, now Meta, since 2008; she will step down in the fall of 2022 but continue to serve on the board of directors.
About_#2: Sandberg announced in a Facebook post on June 1, 2022 that she would step down later in the year, saying that she will focus on her philanthropic work.
About_#3: As COO, Sandberg positioned Facebook as a platform for small business advertising, helping increase ad revenue by 37% during 2021, to nearly $115 billion.
About_#4: Sandberg was reportedly accused of pressuring the Daily Mail to drop a story about her then-boyfriend Activision CEO Bobby Kotick, which the company denies.
Did You Know?: Sandberg, armed with a Harvard M.B.A., began her career as chief of staff to then U.S. Treasury Secretary Larry Summers.
In Their Own Words: The seeds of resilience are planted in the way we process the negative events in our lives.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Brown University
About_#1: Andres Santo Domingo inherited a part of his father Julio Mario's multibillion dollar stake in the beer giant SABMiller when he died in 2011.
About_#2: The bulk of his fortune is now in Anheuser-Busch InBev, following its $100 billion acquisition of SABMiller in 2016.
About_#3: Santo Domingo is of Colombian heritage but has grown up and lived in the United States for years. He graduated from Brown University in 2000.
About_#4: He sits on the boards of Conservation International and the New York Public Library.
Did You Know?: Santo Domingo cofounded the vinyl-loving, rock-oriented record label Kemado Records, now called the Kemado Media Group, in 2002.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, The College of William & Mary; Master of Business Administration, The University of Pittsburgh
About_#1: Paul Saville leads Virginia-based NVR, one of the largest homebuilders in the United States, with nearly $9 billion in annual revenue.
About_#2: Saville joined Ryan Homes, now a subsidiary of NVR, in 1981. He was promoted to president and CEO in 2005.
About_#3: NVR builds homes in 14 states, primarily in the Mid-Atlantic and Midwest. Their homes sold for an average of $404,000 in 2021.
About_#4: In 2020, Paul and his wife, Linda, donated $20 million to open a new cancer screening and prevention center in Falls Church, Virginia.

Education: Master of Science, Rostov Institute of National Economy
About_#1: Ivan Savvidis, a Greek-Russian businessman, is the founder of Agrokom Group, whose assets include Russian tobacco firm Donskoy Tabak.
About_#2: In 1980 he got a job at the Don State Tobacco Factory (now Donskoy Tabak) and was elected general director in 1993.
About_#3: In 2003 he was elected a deputy of the State Duma, the lower chamber of the Russian Legislation, as a member of United Russia, a pro-Putin party.
About_#4: In 2004 Savvidis founded Agrokom Group; it also owns meat processing and packing plants, greenhouse facilities and a sparkling water factory.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
About_#1: Michael Saylor founded business analytics software firm MicroStrategy and ran it as CEO until early August 2022, when he moved into the chairman's role.
About_#2: One of the best-known executives of the Internet bubble, Saylor was a multibillionaire in the late 1990s thanks to his stake in MicroStrategy.
About_#3: He fell from the billionaire ranks after questionable accounting led to a restatement of financial results and the dot-com bust crashed the stock.
About_#4: He's a billionaire again thanks to timely bitcoin investments. In October 2020, he disclosed he personally bought 17,732 bitcoins for $175 million.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University
About_#1: Gerald Schwartz runs Onex, one of Canada's largest private equity firms.
About_#2: He got his start working with buyout legends Jerome Kohlberg, Henry Kravis and George Roberts at Bear Stearns in the 1970s.
About_#3: The Americans left to start KKR in 1976; Schwartz went home to Canada and cofounded the media company CanWest in 1977.
About_#4: In 1984 he started Onex, which has quietly outperformed many of the vaunted American private equity shops.
Did You Know?: Schwartz also serves as a director of bookstore chain Indigo Books & Music, which his wife, Heather Reisman, founded and runs.

About_#1: Sathien Setthasit runs Carabao Group, maker of Thailand's hugely popular Carabao Dang energy drink.
About_#2: Sathien founded the company in 2002 with his folk singer pal Aed Carabao and took it public in 2014.
About_#3: Aiming to become a global brand and win over Europeans, Carabao has sponsored English Premier League football club Chelsea.
About_#4: His younger son Romtham is assistant managing director at Carabao, while older son, Veeratham, is deputy managing director of retailer CJ Express.
Did You Know?: Carabao, which has close to a fourth of the Thai energy drink market, outsells Red Bull in Thailand.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Cornell University
About_#1: Niraj Shah is cofounder and CEO of online home goods retailer Wayfair.
About_#2: He started the business in 2002 with Steve Conine, who is also a billionaire. The two met as high school students at a program at Cornell University.
About_#3: Shah and Conine ended up living in the same dorm their freshman year at Cornell and became good friends.
About_#4: Wayfair, which now offers more than 18 million products, generated $14 billion in net revenue in 2020, up 55% from the previous year.
Did You Know?: In their final semester of college, Conine and Shah both enrolled in a class on entrepreneurism, which sparked a business plan that turned into their first company.

Education: Medical Doctor, Kyoto University
About_#1: Keiichi Shibahara started Amvis Holdings in 2013 to provide home nursing care for patients with permanent illnesses or needing hospice care.
About_#2: Shibahara worked as a researcher for 20 years, specializing in immunology and molecular biology, before he started Amvis at age 48.
About_#3: The company was listed on the JASDAQ bourse for startups in 2019.
About_#4: Amvis posted nearly $140 million in revenue in the fiscal year ended in September 2021.
Did You Know?: The company's name Amvis is derived from the phrase 'ambitious vision'.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Fordham University; Master of Science, Gubkin Institute of Petrochemicals and Natural Gas
About_#1: Evgeny Shvidler, who became an American citizen in 1994, is the best friend and a partner of Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich.
About_#2: His core assets are a stake in Russian steelmaker Evraz and an investment in Norilsk Nickel.
About_#3: Shvidler is executive chairman of Highland Gold Mining, where he has a 12% stake.
About_#4: Shvidler was born in Moscow, Russia. He got an MBA from Fordham University in 1992 and worked for Deloitte & Touche in New York.
Did You Know?: His 370-foot yacht, Le Grand Bleu, was a gift from Abramovich.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Brigham Young University
About_#1: Ryan Smith is the cofounder and was longtime CEO of Utah-based cloud computing company Qualtrics.
About_#2: He cofounded the company--known for its feedback surveys of customers and staff-- in Provo, Utah in 2002 with his brother, Jared, and father Scott.
About_#3: Three days before its scheduled IPO in January 2019, Qualtrics was acquired by German software firm SAP for $8 billion in cash.
About_#4: SAP spun out Qualtrics as a stand alone public company in late January 2021; Smith purchased about $120 million worth of the stock.
In Their Own Words: This profile is paid for by the featured executive’s company.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, Santa Barbara; Master of Business Administration, University of Phoenix
About_#1: Peter Sperling stepped down as the chairman of the Apollo Education Group when it was taken private in a $1.1 billion deal in February 2017.
About_#2: Sperling joined the company in 1983, about a decade after his father founded it.
About_#3: The for-profit education company became well-known for its online University of Phoenix network.
About_#4: His father John Sperling, former San Jose State University professor, founded the University of Phoenix in 1973.

Education: Ph.D, Carnegie Mellon University
About_#1: Ion Stoica is cofounder and executive chairman of software startup Databricks, valued at $38 billion in August 2021. Investors include cloud giants Microsoft and Amazon.
About_#2: He served as the original CEO from its inception in 2013 until early 2016, when he ceded the position to cofounder Ali Ghodsi.
About_#3: Prior to Databricks, Stoica cofounded video streaming startup Conviva. He is also a UC Berkeley computer science professor.
About_#4: Stoica cofounded Databricks alongside six UC Berkeley academics who had built the popular data analytics engine Apache Spark.

About_#1: Bambang Sutantio founded and runs Cimory group, a manufacturer and distributor of dairy products and processed foods in Jakarta.
About_#2: Cimory is known for its range of dairy products such as milk and yogurt as well as processed meats.
About_#3: Sutantio first set up meat processor Macroprima Panganutama in 1993. He started the dairy business in 2004 to support dairy farmers in East Java.
About_#4: Sutantio took group flagship Cisarua Mountain Dairy public in December 2021, raising more than $200 million.
Did You Know?: Sutantio has a diploma in food technology from the Technical University of Berlin.

Education: Bachelor of Science, University of Malaya
About_#1: Tan Yu Yeh gets his wealth from his stake in Mr. D.I.Y, a home improvement retail chain, which he founded in 2005.
About_#2: The company was listed on the Malaysian stock exchange in October 2020 making him and his brother, Tan Yu Wei, both billionaires.
About_#3: Mr. D.I.Y has 894 stores in Malaysia and six stores in Brunei.
About_#4: D.I.Y stores are typically 10,000 square feet and carry products across ten categories including electrical items, stationery and toys.

About_#1: David Teoh is the founder and executive chairman of TPG Telecom. He emigrated from Malaysia in 1986.
About_#2: A series of smart acquisitions transformed the company from a computer retailer into a major internet service provider in Australia.
About_#3: Teoh's listed internet service provider, TPG merged with Vodafone Hutchison Australia in 2020 and was relisted as TPG Telecom.
About_#4: He resigned as executive chairman in 2021.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Oklahoma State University; Master of Business Administration, Stanford Business School
About_#1: A co-founder of private equity firm Thoma Bravo with Orlando Bravo, Carl Thoma is one of the deans of the buyout business.
About_#2: A graduate of Oklahoma State University and the Stanford's business school, Thoma cofounded GTCR in 1980 and then split from the firm in 1998.
About_#3: Created Thoma Cressey in 1998 and hired a young dealmaker, Orlando Bravo, who would go on to build the firm's software strategy.
About_#4: Thoma and Bravo split from Cressey in 2008. Since, software-focused Thoma Bravo has posted top returns and grown to $39 billion in assets.

About_#1: A former athlete, Ion Tiriac heads Tiriac Group, which has interests in real estate, auto, financial services and more.
About_#2: After he retired as a tennis player in the 1970s, Tiriac coached and managed top players like Guillermo Vilas, Marat Safin and Boris Becker.
About_#3: He began his investment career after the fall of communism in Romania, and eventually founded the Tiriac Group.
About_#4: He owns a car and motorcycle collection of more than 400 models, including cars previously owned by Al Capone, Sammy Davis Jr. and Elton John.
Did You Know?: Known as Count Dracula in his tennis years, Tiriac is one of the richest former athletes of all time.

About_#1: Clemens Toennies owns 45% of German food industry giant Toennies Lebensmittel, with annual revenue of around $8 billion. His son Maximilian owns 5%.
About_#2: Operating meat, convenience, ingredients and logistics divisions, the company specializes in pig, sow and beef cattle slaughtering and processing.
About_#3: Clemens attended butchery college and, in 1971, cofounded the company with his brother, Bernd.
About_#4: Bernd died in 1994, at age 42. His son, Robert, now owns 50% of the business, which employs around 16,500 people in facilities in Germany and Denmark.
Did You Know?: For many years, Clemens presided over pro soccer team FC Schalke 04. He resigned from his post as chairman in June 2020.

About_#1: Tran Ba Duong got his start working at an auto repair factory in the 1980s and eventually worked his way up to management.
About_#2: He founded Truong Hai in 1997; it initially sold cars and later started assembling cars for foreign brands such as Kia, Mazda and Peugeot.
About_#3: His company's turning point came in 2008, when Jardine Cycle and Carriage, a car distributor in Singapore, bought a stake in it.
About_#4: Thaco, as it's called, is the biggest car company in Vietnam with more than a third of the nation's automobile market.
Did You Know?: He received the EY Asean Entrepreneurial Excellence Award in 2020.

About_#1: Tseng Sing-ai inherited her Chang Chun Group stake from her father, Tseng Shin-yi, who died in 2016.
About_#2: Shin-yi co-founded the business in 1949 with classmates M.K. Liao and Lin Shu-Hong.
About_#3: Chang Chun is now one of Asia's largest petrochemicals-and-plastics manufacturers, with plants in Taiwan, China and Southeast Asia.
About_#4: Sing-ai serves as a supervisor at the board of directors at Chang Chun Plastics.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Utah State University
About_#1: Scott Watterson is the cofounder of Logan, Utah-based fitness equipment maker iFIT.
About_#2: The firm makes interactive treadmills, bikes and other machines and offers fitness content under brands like NordicTrack and ProForm and the iFIT app.
About_#3: Watterson and his college buddy Gary Stevenson started iFIT, then named Weslo, as college students at Utah State in 1977.
About_#4: iFIT raised $200 million from Bernard Arnault-backed private equity firm L Catterton in October 2020 at a $7 billion valuation.
Did You Know?: Watterson spent five years as a Mormon missionary in Taiwan over two separate visits; he speaks fluent Mandarin Chinese.

About_#1: Wei Ing-Chou and his three younger brothers, Ying-Chiao, Yin-Chun and Yin-Heng, started Tingyi in 1991.
About_#2: Tingyi is now one of the largest suppliers of ready-to-drink tea and bottled water in China and supplies half of the country's instant-noodle market.
About_#3: As of 2019, Ing-Chou is no longer a director of Tingyi (Cayman Islands) Holding, but he remains a senior consultant to the company.
About_#4: His eldest son, Wei Hong-Ming, born in 1978, is now the chairman. His third son, Wei Hong-Chen, born in 1982, is an executive director.
Did You Know?: Ing-Chou's second son, Wei Hong-Fan, started his own bicycle business in 2011.

About_#1: Yin-Chun Wei and his three brothers founded Tingyi, one of the largest producers of ready-to-drink tea and bottled water in China.
About_#2: Tingyi is also China's leading supplier of instant noodles.
About_#3: The family also controls the Dicos fried-chicken chain.
About_#4: The family's private company, Ting Hsin, sold its 37.17% stake in Taipei 101, Taiwan's tallest building, to Itochu for $665 million in July 2018.

About_#1: Wei Ying-Chiao and his three brothers, Ing-Chou, Yin-Chun and Yin-Heng, started Tingyi in 1991.
About_#2: Tingyi is now a big producer of ready-to-drink tea and bottled water in China, and it supplies half of the country's instant-noodle market.
About_#3: The family also controls the Dicos fried-chicken chain.
About_#4: The family's private company, Ting Hsin, sold its 37.17% stake in Taipei 101, Taiwan's tallest building, to Itochu for $665 million in July 2018.

About_#1: Tom Werner rose to prominence as a TV executive, producing hits like That 70's Show and 3rd Rock From The Sun, as well as Roseanne and The Cosby Show prior to their controversies.
About_#2: In 2001, Werner cofounded Fenway Sports Group (then called New England Sports Ventures) and bought the Boston Red Sox for $380 million a year later.
About_#3: Werner owns more than 10% of FSG, which controls the Red Sox, Liverpool FC and the Pittsburgh Penguins, and counts LeBron James as an investor.
Did You Know?: Werner's first foray into Major League Baseball was as majority owner of the San Diego Padres in 1990.
In Their Own Words: At one point I had the top three shows on television, and millions of people were watching my shows every week. But there was nothing in my life that is comparable to the experience of when the Red Sox won the World Series in 2004.

About_#1: Malaysian investor Kie Chie Wong, who has lived in Australia since the 1980s, gets the bulk of his wealth from a minority stake in Fortescue Metals Group.
About_#2: A longtime backer of billionaire Andrew Forrest, Wong once held a 26.5% stake in Fortescue, for which he paid about $1 million in 2003.
About_#3: Wong was part of a Malaysian consortium, which bought an Australian realtor in 1988.
About_#4: He reportedly hails from a Sarawak timber family in Malaysia.

About_#1: Xu Guozhong chairs Jiangsu Guomao Reducer, a Chinese motor manufacturer.
About_#2: Xu founded the processor of Guomao in Jiangsu Province in 1993.
About_#3: Son Xu Bin, 32, is Guomao's general manager.

About_#1: Yu Peidi chairs Shanghai-listed real estate developer Greattown Holdings.
About_#2: Yu left his hometown Fuzhou in 1976 and made his early money in the home appliances trade in Indonesia.
About_#3: Yu began to invest in Fuzhou in the 1980s, starting with minerals and later real estate.

Education: Ph.D, University of California, Berkeley; Bachelor of Science, University of Waterloo
About_#1: Matei Zaharia is cofounder and chief technology officer of software startup Databricks, valued at $38 billion in August 2021. Investors include Microsoft and Amazon.
About_#2: He is the mastermind behind popular analytics engine Apache Spark, which was conceived when he was a 24-year-old Ph.D. student at UC Berkeley.
About_#3: Spark set a world record for speed of data sorting in 2014 and won Zaharia an award for the year's best computer science dissertation.
About_#4: In 2013, Zaharia and six UC Berkeley collaborators cofounded Databricks, whose software is built on top of Spark.
In Their Own Words: Our group was one of the first to look at how to make it easy to work with very large data sets for people whose main interest in life is not software engineering.

About_#1: Zheng Jianjiang is chairman of Ningbo Sanxing Medical Electric.
About_#2: Zheng began working from a bankrupt watch parts factory in 1986 with seven other people.
About_#3: Sanxing's parent company, AUX Group, also has interests in air conditioning manufacturing and real estate development.

About_#1: Zhong Sheng Jian chairs Yanlord Land, one of the largest non-government-owned real estate developers in China.
About_#2: Zhong, a mainland native, moved to Singapore in 1988.
About_#3: Yanlord's prominent China partners include Ping An Insurance, China Merchants Property Development and Poly Real Estate Group.
About_#4: Yanlord's shares are publicly traded in Singapore.

About_#1: Antti Aarnio-Wihuri heads Wihuri Group, a Finnish conglomerate that has been in his family for over 100 years.
About_#2: The group has interests in the packaging, technical trade, food wholesale and aviation and operates Caterpillar construction equipment dealerships.
About_#3: Wihuri Group, which employs 5,000 people, also runs Metro daily goods wholesale stores and a private jet charter and ambulance service.
About_#4: He is the largest shareholder of Winpak, a Canadian company that specializes in producing packaging materials.

About_#1: Hamdi Akin is the founder of Akfen Holding, a conglomerate with investments in energy, real estate development and infrastructure.
About_#2: During college, he produced heating boilers and water and fuel tanks in his father's workshop. After graduating, he started Akfen as a contractor.
About_#3: Winning tenders for operating the Istanbul Ataturk Airport and Ankara Esenboga Airport led him to establish TAV Airports Holding.
About_#4: In 2012, he sold 38% of TAV to Aeroports de Paris Group for $874 million. In 2017, he sold his remaining 8% to Aeroports de Paris for $160 million.
Did You Know?: Akin has transferred ownership of Akfen to daughter Pelin and son Selim. They both serve on its board.
In Their Own Words: Companies grow when they are sold, when they get new partners. If you don't sell, if shares don't change hands, they don't become immortal but die with their owners.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Baroda University; Master of Business Administration, Seton Hall University
About_#1: Pharma tycoon Chirayu Amin's Alembic Pharmaceuticals is one of India's oldest pharma companies.
About_#2: Alembic was founded by Amin's grandfather in 1907 to make tincture and alcohol.
About_#3: Today, Alembic gets a chunk of its $734 million annual revenue from the domestic market selling generic drugs, including popular cough syrup Glycodin.
About_#4: While Amin is chairman and chief executive, his three sons work in different parts of the business.
Did You Know?: Amin is the brother-in-law of consumer goods billionaire Harsh Mariwala.

About_#1: Joachim "Joe" Ante is cofounder and chief technology officer of online and mobile game engine company Unity Software.
About_#2: He owns about 6% of the company, which listed on the New York Stock Exchange in September 2020.
About_#3: Ante cofounded Unity in 2004 with two others in Copenhagen; the company has since moved its headquarters to San Francisco.
About_#4: Some of the world's most popular games were built using Unity's engine, including Pokemon Go, Among Us and Overcooked.
Did You Know?: Ante initially began writing the core of the Unity platform as a teenager.

About_#1: Ziv Aviram is the cofounder of autonomous vehicle technology firm Mobileye.
About_#2: He launched the company in 1999 with fellow billionaire Amnon Shashua, a computer science professor at Hebrew University.
About_#3: The pair took Mobileye public in 2014, then sold it to Intel in 2017 at a $15.3 billion valuation.
About_#4: Aviram and Shashua also co-CEOs of Or-Cam, which makes portable, artificial vision devices for visually impaired people. They founded the company in 2010.

About_#1: Danna Azrieli is an heir to the Azrieli Group real estate fortune.
About_#2: She and her two sisters, Naomi and Sharon Azrieli, own about 46% of the publicly traded company.
About_#3: She inherited her stake after her father, David Azrieli, died in 2014.
About_#4: Danna chairs Azrieli Group, which builds shopping malls and office buildings in Israel.

About_#1: Naomi Azrieli is an heir to the Azrieli Group real estate fortune.
About_#2: She and her two sisters, Danna and Sharon Azrieli, own about 46% of the publicly traded company.
About_#3: She sits on the board and inherited her stake after her father, David Azrieli, died in 2014.
About_#4: Noami also chairs the family's Azrieli Foundation, which supports a number of causes, including science, music and Holocaust education.

About_#1: Sharon Azrieli is an heir to the Azrieli Group real estate fortune.
About_#2: She and her two sisters, Danna and Naomi Azrieli, own about 46% of the publicly traded company.
About_#3: She sits on the board and inherited her stake after her father, David Azrieli, died in 2014.
About_#4: Sharon is also on the board of the family's Azrieli Foundation, which supports a number of causes, including science, music and Holocaust education.

About_#1: Lesley Bamberger is the owner of Kroonenberg Groep, a privately-held real estate company in the Netherlands.
About_#2: The group has a portfolio of retail, industrial and residential buildings in the Netherlands and the United States.
About_#3: His grandfather, Jacob Kroonenberg, founded the company.
About_#4: Bamberger joined the company in 1986 and inherited it in 1996 after his grandfather's death.

About_#1: Bernhard Braun-Luedicke owns 12% of the medical device company B. Braun Melsungen, which began in 1839 as a small pharmacy that sold herbal remedies.
About_#2: His mother's cousin Ludwig Georg Braun took the reins in 1977, when the company had just $24 million in annual sales (now around $8 billion).
About_#3: Today, with more than 64,000 employees globally, B. Braun manufactures products ranging from infusion and injection solutions to surgical instruments.
Did You Know?: Bernhard is a sixth-generation family member and his mother, Barbara, is a member of the company's supervisory board.

About_#1: Eva Maria Braun-Luedicke owns 12% of the medical device company B. Braun Melsungen, which began in 1839 as a small pharmacy that sold herbal remedies.
About_#2: Her mother's cousin Ludwig Georg Braun took the reins in 1977, when the company had just $24 million in annual sales (now around $8 billion).
About_#3: Today, with more than 64,000 employees globally, B. Braun manufactures products ranging from infusion and injection solutions to surgical instruments.
About_#4: Eva Maria works as a Communications Manager for B. Braun.
Did You Know?: Eva Maria is a sixth-generation family member and her mother, Barbara, is a member of the company's supervisory board.

About_#1: She owns 30% of Grupo Breca, a Peruvian holding company with interests in agriculture, finance, hotels, mining and real estate.
About_#2: She inherited her fortune from her father, Fortunato Brescia Tassano (d.1951), who built a real estate company that capitalized on Lima's growth.
About_#3: Her assets were managed by her brothers Mario and Pedro until they passed away in 2013 and 2014, respectively.
About_#4: Grupo Breca owns Tasa, one of the largest producers of fish meal in the world.
Did You Know?: Nonagenarian Brescia Cafferata never married and doesn't have any children.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Leningrad Institute of Railway Engineers
About_#1: Nikolay Buinov is the main shareholder of Irkutsk oil company, the largest independent private oil company in Russia.
About_#2: Buinov got his start with a timber company in the early 1990s.
About_#3: In 1995, Buinov and his father founded Bodaibo energy company, which supplied fuel and lubricants to gold miners in the north of Irkutsk in Siberia.
About_#4: Buinov purchased the license for an oil field in 1997, which was the start of what would become Irkutsk Oil Company.

About_#1: Paolo Bulgari, a great-grandson of the founder of luxury jeweler Bulgari, joined the company when he was 18.
About_#2: A law student at the time, he was asked by his father to design necklaces, rings and bracelets.
About_#3: Paolo became chairman of Bulgari in 1984, while his brother Nicola became vice chairman.
About_#4: In 2011, the Bulgari family sold its controlling stake to French luxury conglomerate LVMH for $5.2 billion in cash and stock.
Did You Know?: Paolo has designed jewelry for generations of Hollywood actresses, from Elizabeth Taylor to Nicole Kidman.

Education: Bachelor of Technology, University Of Northampton; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University ORT Uruguay
About_#1: Andrés Bzurovski is the cofounder and a director of Uruguay-based fintech and international payments startup dLocal; he owns about 17% of the shares.
About_#2: Founded in Montevideo in 2016, dLocal went public on the NASDAQ in June 2021, just nine months after becoming Uruguay's first unicorn in September 2020.
About_#3: dLocal operates in emerging markets such as Brazil and India and its clients include Amazon, Netflix, Google, Microsoft, Nike and Uber.
About_#4: Bzurovski started dLocal with fellow billionaire and board member Sergio Fogel and the firm's founding CEO, Sebastián Kanovich.

About_#1: Although Ahmet Calik built his fortune on denim, selling to Diesel, Levi's, Gap and other Western brands, textiles are now ancillary.
About_#2: With a footprint stretching from Turkey and the Middle East to Eastern Europe and Central Asia, Calik is active in construction, banking, telecom and mining.
About_#3: Calik Holding has a partnership with Mitsubishi Corp. dating back to 1990s, when the companies began collaborating on plant construction in Central Asia.
About_#4: In 2015, Mitsubishi acquired 4.5% of Calik Energy, which serves five cities in Turkey and has projects in such places as Turkmenistan, Libya, Georgia and Yemen.
In Their Own Words: There's a formula for success we call the 'Calik Manifesto.' First, you have to feel it in your heart, believe in your work. Then use your mind and define your strategy. Never go back on your word, and work, work, work.

About_#1: Giuliana Caprotti inherited her fortune from her late husband Bernardo Caprotti, who was the founder of Italian supermarket chain Esselunga.
About_#2: Bernardo left his second wife Giualiana and their daughter Marina a 67% stake in the company, and gave the remaining third to his other two children.
About_#3: In 2020, Giuliana and Marina bought out the remaining stake of Esselunga for nearly 2 billion Euros.
About_#4: Giuliana was named honorary chair of Esselunga in 2020.

About_#1: Marina Caprotti inherited most of her wealth from her late father, Bernardo Caprotti, who was the founder of Italian supermarket chain Esselunga.
About_#2: Bernardo left his second wife Giuliana and daughter Marina a 67% stake in the company, and gave the remaining third to his other two children.
About_#3: In 2020, Giuliana and Marina bought out the remaining stake for nearly 2 billion Euros.
About_#4: Marina was named executive chair of Esselunga in 2020.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Williams College
About_#1: Steve Case cofounded investment firm Revolution, which has invested in over 50 companies.
About_#2: His Rise of the Rest tour funds startups from non-coastal states, stopping in cities to a host pitch competition for a $100,000 investment.
About_#3: Revolution has also invested in restaurant chain Sweetgreen, fantasy sports firm Draft Kings and wine retailer Vinfolio.
About_#4: In 1985 Case helped found Quantum Computer Services. He became CEO in 1991 and changed its name to America Online (AOL).
Did You Know?: Born and raised in Hawaii, Case attended Punahou School, where Barack Obama went to high school. He later served on Obama's Council on Jobs and Competitiveness.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, University of Pennsylvania; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Safra Catz has served as CEO of software firm Oracle since September 2014, when founder Larry Ellison stepped down from the role.
About_#2: She joined Oracle in 1999 and is credited with spearheading Oracle's aggressive acquisition strategy, helping close more than 130 acquisitions.
About_#3: Catz, who was born in Israel, earned a law degree at University of Pennsylvania and worked on Wall Street for 14 years covering the software industry.
About_#4: Catz and her husband Gal Tirosh gave $250,000 to President Trump's fundraising committee in June 2020.
In Their Own Words: The fact is you can recover from being stupid, but you can never recover from being a liar. Integrity matters. Don't be afraid to look stupid, but never let your integrity be compromised.

About_#1: Binod Chaudhary controls CG Corp Global and is Nepal's sole billionaire.
About_#2: His biggest assets are a controlling stake in Nepal's Nabil Bank and CG Foods, maker of the popular Wai Wai noodles.
About_#3: Wai Wai has overseas factories in India, Serbia and Bangladesh with a new one being constructed in Egypt. It plans to launch a range of sauces.
About_#4: CG's hotel assets consist of 135 owned and managed properties, including a string of luxury hotels with India's Taj hotel chain.
Did You Know?: His late father opened Nepal's first department store.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Zhejiang University of Technology
About_#1: Chen Baohua is general manager of Shanghai-listed Zhejiang Huahai Pharmaceutical, a pharmaceuticals supplier.
About_#2: Chen holds a degree in chemical analysis from the Zhejiang University of Technology.
About_#3: After graduation, he worked at a state-run pharmaceuticals factory.
About_#4: In 1989, Chen quit and cofounded the predecessor of Huahai in the eastern Chinese city of Linhaiat with less than $3,000; he was only 29 years old.

About_#1: Chen Xianbao is the chairman and general manager of Qiaqia Food, a supplier of nuts and roasted foods.
About_#2: Headquartered in Hefei, Qiaqia supplies sunflower seeds, watermelon seeds, beans, pumpkin seeds, pistachios, walnuts, almonds and other nuts.
About_#3: Chen worked in state-run Anhui Sugar Tobacco and Wine earlier in his career.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Brown University
About_#1: Chung Yong-jin is a grandson of Samsung group founder, Lee Byung-Chull, and a nephew of Samsung chairman Lee Kun-Hee.
About_#2: The bulk of his fortune comes from Samsung Electronics and E-Mart, Korea's largest discount retailer.
About_#3: He serves as vice chair of Shinsegae, a retail conglomerate.
About_#4: In 2021, Shinsegae acquired Korean baseball team SK Wyverns (now SSG Landers), winner of four championships, from the SK group for about $120 million.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Cornell University
About_#1: Steve Conine is cofounder and co-chairman of online home goods retailer Wayfair.
About_#2: He started the business in 2002 with fellow billionaire Niraj Shah. The two met as high school students at a summer program at Cornell University.
About_#3: Wayfair, which now offers more than 18 million products, generated $14 billion in net revenue in 2020, up 55% from the previous year.
About_#4: Conine sits on the board of online marketplace CarGurus.
Did You Know?: Conine is a competitive mountain biker who has traveled the globe competing in races.

About_#1: After working as a stockbroker and finance executive, Eduardo Costantini founded real estate development firm Consultatio S.A. in 1991.
About_#2: The Buenos Aires-traded firm has developments in Argentina and the U.S., including a $700 million luxury residential complex near Miami.
About_#3: He owns nearly 70% of Consultatio S.A., his largest asset.
About_#4: He's also a majority shareholder of Consultatio Asset Management, a Buenos Aires firm with over $700 million of assets under of management.
In Their Own Words: We have to be conscious that there's income inequality, and that we have a responsibility...as business leaders and other leaders, to try to promote programs of inclusion.

About_#1: Dai Wenjun chairs Juewei Food, a supplier of duck necks and braised duck parts through a retail chain across China.
About_#2: Juewei went public at the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 2017.
About_#3: Dai holds an EMBA from the Cheung Kong Business School in Beijing.
About_#4: Juewei is headquartered in the southern Chinese city of Changsha.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay; Master of Business Administration, University of Michigan, Stephen M. Ross School of Business
About_#1: Bharat Desai founded IT consulting and outsourcing company Syntel with his wife Neerja Sethi from their apartment in Troy, Michigan in 1980.
About_#2: In October 2018 French IT firm Atos SE acquired Syntel for $3.4 billion in cash.
About_#3: In its first year, Syntel generated just $30,000 in sales; before it was acquired, annual revenue grew to more than $900 million.
About_#4: Desai, who was Syntel's chairman, was born in Kenya, raised in India and came to the U.S. in 1976 as a programmer for Tata.
Did You Know?: Desai and Sethi started the company with just $2,000.

About_#1: Mohammed Dewji is the CEO of METL, a Tanzanian conglomerate founded by his father in the 1970s.
About_#2: METL is active in textile manufacturing, flour milling, beverages and edible oils in eastern, southern and central Africa.
About_#3: METL operates in at least six African countries and has ambitions to expand to several more.
About_#4: Dewji, Tanzania's only billionaire, signed the Giving Pledge in 2016, promising to donate at least half his fortune to philanthropic causes.
Did You Know?: Dewji retired from Tanzania's parliament in early 2015 after completing two terms.

About_#1: Mathias Doepfner is chairman and CEO of German media giant Axel Springer, which is active in over 40 countries and in the U.S. owns Politico and Business Insider.
About_#2: Axel Springer hired him in 1988 as Editor-in-Chief of its newspaper Die Welt. He joined the company's executive board in 2000 and became CEO in 2002.
About_#3: His success in building revenue from digital activities, from under $150 million to around $3 billion, helped earn the trust of controlling shareholder Friede Springer.
About_#4: To ensure continuity, in 2020 Friede Springer gave him a 15% stake in Axel Springer and sold him an additional 4.1%. He was awarded additional stock and now owns nearly 22%.
Did You Know?: Acquisitions under Doepfner have included TV news station N24 (since rebranded as Welt) and the digital news outlet Business Insider.

About_#1: Domenico Dolce is the Sicilian half of fashion power-duo Dolce & Gabbana.
About_#2: Dolce founded the company in 1985 with Stefano Gabbana, whom he had met in a Milan night club.
About_#3: The next year Dolce & Gabbana, known for its extravagant style and animal print designs, made its runway debut at the Milan Fashion Week.
About_#4: Their big break came in 1993 when Madonna chose Dolce & Gabbana to design the costumes for her Girlie tour.
Did You Know?: Despite being based in Milan, the company's first boutique opened in Japan in 1989.

About_#1: Marek Dospiva is cofounder of Penta Investments, which has investments in the healthcare, banking, real estate and aeronautical industries.
About_#2: Penta has controlling stakes in Privatbanka, pharmacy chain Dr. Max and sports betting operator Fortuna.
About_#3: Dospiva and Slovak Jaroslav Hascak, who were both studying in Beijing, got started importing Chinese textiles to chain stores in Czechoslovakia.
About_#4: During Slovakia's 1996 privatization, Penta gained control over the nation's biggest fund, paying only 20 percent of its real market value.
Did You Know?: Dospiva is developing an office building complex in Prague that was the last project of famous British architect Zaha Hadid, who died in 2016.

About_#1: Fritz Draexlmaier's eponymous auto parts maker counts among its customers Audi, BMW, Cadillac, Land Rover, Maserati, Mercedes-Benz, Porsche and Tesla.
About_#2: Founded by his parents, Draexlmaier Group began in 1958 with an order for wiring harnesses for the Goggomobil, a microcar produced by Hans Glas GmbH.
About_#3: A company speciality, wiring harnesses run throughout the entire vehicle connecting electrical components and relaying data and electrical power.
About_#4: It has diversified into the manufacture of electronic components, consoles, door and instrument panels and exclusive interiors for specific model
Did You Know?: Fritz is an only child. His father, Fritz Sr., died in 1995 at age 80, and his mom, Lisa, died in 2018 at age 100.

Education: Drop Out, Stanford University
About_#1: Henrique Dubugras is co-CEO of Brex, a fintech startup aiming to overhaul the corporate credit card.
About_#2: He met his cofounder Pedro Franceschi through a Twitter argument in 2012, when they were both high school seniors living in their home country of Brazil.
About_#3: In 2013, the cofounders launched a payments startup called Pagar.me for small business in Brazil and sold it to a larger Brazilian rival in 2015.
About_#4: Dubugras grew up in Sao Paulo, Brazil, and attended Stanford with Franceschi for less than a year before they dropped out to start Brex in 2017.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Georgetown University
About_#1: Egon Durban is co-CEO of Silver Lake, a private equity firm that specializes in technology investments.
About_#2: Durban joined Silver Lake in 1999 as a founding principal; prior to that he worked in Morgan Stanley's investment banking division.
About_#3: Durban, who owns an estimated 17% of Silver Lake, is known for orchestrating the firm's wildly successful investments in Dell Technologies and Skype.
About_#4: Silver Lake manages about $75 billion of assets.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Imperial College London; Master of Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
About_#1: Bulent Eczacibasi and brother Faruk are partners in a conglomerate that has 25 production facilities in Turkey and 16 abroad.
About_#2: It is a global exporter of ceramic and wall tiles, plus bathroom fixtures and accessories (brands include VitrA, Villeroy & Boch and Engers Keramik).
About_#3: Bulent and Faruk's father, Dr. Nejat F. Eczacibasi, focused on pharmaceuticals before expanding into personal health care and other businesses.
About_#4: Eczacibasi Holding also operates in healthcare services and the production and distribution of medical products to hospitals.
Did You Know?: An avid collector, Bulent heads the Istanbul Foundation for Culture and Arts and the Istanbul Modern Art Foundation, which includes the Istanbul Modern Art Museum.
In Their Own Words: There are countless examples of how those who combine creativity and entrepreneurship succeed professionally. We cannot hope to become successful by repeating ourselves, keeping the status quo, and confining our hopes and dreams to our comfort zone.

About_#1: Faruk Eczacibasi and brother Bulent are partners in a conglomerate that has 25 production facilities in Turkey and 16 abroad.
About_#2: It is a global exporter of ceramic and wall tiles, plus bathroom fixtures and accessories (brands include VitrA, Villeroy & Boch and Engers Keramik).
About_#3: Faruk and Bulent's father, Dr. Nejat F. Eczacibasi, focused on pharmaceuticals before expanding into personal health care and other businesses.
About_#4: Eczacibasi Holding also operate in healthcare services and the production and distribution of medical products to hospitals.
Did You Know?: Faruk has an extensive modern art collection (assembled with his wife, Fusun), loves jazz and lives in Istanbul's historic peninsula of Galata.
In Their Own Words: The most essential difference in the thought process of the post-internet generation is thinking exponentially. Whether positive or negative, the increasing speed of developments force us all to a new way of thinking, whether we want to or not.

Education: Master of Business Administration, INSEAD; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Michigan
About_#1: The son of a Chicago meat-packer, Henry Engelhardt aspired to be a journalist before turning to entrepreneurship.
About_#2: His insurance company Admiral Group, founded in 1993, offers car and home insurance and created the UK's first insurance price comparison website.
About_#3: Based in Cardiff, Wales, Admiral also has operations in Spain, France, Italy, and the U.S.
About_#4: Its American brands include Elephant Auto Insurance and Compare.com.
Did You Know?: Admiral's Ministry of Fun organizes events for its employees, such as dress-up days, rock band contests, and surfing trips.
In Their Own Words: How wealthy we've become is a recipe of three parts luck, one part smarts and one part determination.

About_#1: Ali Erdemoglu and his brother, Ibrahim, together own over 75% of a top producer of materials used in carpet, SASA Polyester.
About_#2: They initially acquired 51% of SASA in 2015 for $102 million, then added to their stake in the publicly traded company and watched it soar in value.
About_#3: The brothers' Erdemoglu Holding also includes the two privately held companies, Merinos Carpet and Dinarsu Carpet.
About_#4: In 1970, their father, Mehmet Erdemoglu, along with family members, started Merinos with two rug-weaving looms.
Did You Know?: SASA has a $935 million licensing and technical service agreement with Invista, a subsidiary of Koch Industries that makes chemicals, polymers, fabrics and fibers.

About_#1: Eurnekian, the son of Armenian immigrants to Argentina, first operated in the textile industry.
About_#2: He delved into the cable TV business in the 1980s. In the 1990s, he netted $750 million in the sale of Argentine TV firm Cablevision.
About_#3: Under his Corporacion America, Eurnekian and partners own more than 50 airports around the world, with reported revenues of more than $1.5 billion.
About_#4: In February 2018, Corporacion America Airports went public on the New York Stock Exchange; His nephew, Martin Eurnekian is CEO.
Did You Know?: In 2011, he sold 21 duty free shops in Argentina, Uruguay, Ecuador and Armenia to Switzerland's Dufry AG for $975 million.
In Their Own Words: If you work to make money, you're screwed. You don't work to make money. An artist doesn't paint to make money. And a good businessman is like an artist.

Education: Ph.D, Polytechnic Institute
About_#1: John Farber is the longtime chairman of ICC Industries, which trades basic and specialty chemicals. It also held a controlling stake in Frutarom.
About_#2: In May 2018, Frutarom was sold to International Flavors & Fragrances for $7.1 billion in cash and stock.
About_#3: He started ICC Industries in 1952 as a chemical trading division of his father-in-law's textiles export-import firm, Leslie Kleyman Corporation.
About_#4: Farber and his family left Romania after his father's business was nationalized following World War II. He reacquired the company in the 1990s.

About_#1: Clement Fayat built a fortune in construction and civil engineering. He died in July 2022 at age 90.
About_#2: The son of a bricklayer, Fayat started his own civil engineering firm in 1957 when he was just 25.
About_#3: By the time of his death, Fayat Group was one of the largest privately held construction firms in France, with 4.6 billion Euros in annual revenues and more than 21,000 employees in 170 countries.
About_#4: He ran the company for 56 years, but handed off management to his sons, Jean-Claude and Laurent, in 2013.
Did You Know?: A wine lover, Fayat owned three vineyards in Bordeaux, where he spent some of his time.

Education: Law Degree, Universidade Presbiteriana Mackenzie
About_#1: Daniel Feffer is one of 4 billionaire brothers who control of Suzano Papel e Celulose, a Brazilian paper firm founded in 1924 by their grandfather.
About_#2: The second-eldest of the brothers, he is vice-chairman of Suzano, which in early 2019 acquired Brazilian pulp and paper firm Fibria Celulose.
About_#3: An advocate of open markets, Daniel Feffer is the President of the Brazilian branch of the International Chamber of Commerce.
About_#4: He also founded Intelligent Tech & Trade Initiative, a think tank that aims to inform and influence foreign trade professionals.

Education: Law Degree, Universidade Presbiteriana Mackenzie
About_#1: David Feffer is the oldest son of Max Feffer, whose immigrant father Leon Feffer launched the family business.
About_#2: His grandfather Leon Feffer founded Brazilian pulp and paper firm Suzano Papel e Celulose in 1924.
About_#3: David and his three brothers - Daniel, Jorge and Ruben- each inherited shares in Suzano; David, Daniel and Jorge are also board members.
About_#4: Suzano acquired Fibria Celulose in January 2019 for about $7.5 billion, creating Brazil's largest paper producer.

About_#1: Ruben Feffer is one of four billionaire brothers who control Suzano Papel e Celulose, a Brazilian paper giant founded by their grandfather.
About_#2: Known as Binho, he is the only brother who is not a board member of Suzano.
About_#3: Ruben, a pianist, is credited with the music for Boy and the World, a 2013 Brazilian film nominated for Academy Award for best animated feature.
About_#4: He has developed a career creating music for movies and TV shows via his company Unisson Productions.

About_#1: Feng Yuxia chairs Joinn Laboratories (China), a China medical services provider.
About_#2: Feng holds a master's degree in pharmacology from Academy of Military Medical Sciences and a MBA from Peking University.
About_#3: Feng worked as a doctor at a military hospital from 1986 to 1989; she founded Joinn in 1995 in Beijing.

Education: Master of Business Administration, INSEAD; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology; Master of Science, Technion-Israel Institute of Technology
About_#1: Sergio Fogel is the cofounder and a director of Uruguay-based fintech and international payments startup dLocal; he owns about 17% of the shares.
About_#2: Founded in Montevideo in 2016, dLocal went public on the NASDAQ in June 2021, just nine months after becoming Uruguay's first unicorn in September 2020.
About_#3: dLocal operates in emerging markets such as Brazil and India and its clients include Amazon, Netflix, Google, Microsoft, Nike and Uber.
About_#4: Fogel started dLocal with fellow billionaire and board member Andrés Bzurovski and the firm's founding CEO, Sebastián Kanovich.

Education: Drop Out, Stanford University
About_#1: Pedro Franceschi is co-CEO of Brex, a fintech startup aiming to overhaul the corporate credit card.
About_#2: He met cofounder Henrique Dubugras in a Twitter argument in 2012, when they were both high school seniors living in their home country of Brazil.
About_#3: In 2013, the pair launched a payments startup, Pagar.me, for small business in Brazil and sold it to a larger Brazilian rival in 2015.
About_#4: Franceschi grew up in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, and attended Stanford with Dubugras for less than a year before they dropped out to start Brex in 2017.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Istituto Superiore di Industrie Artistiche
About_#1: Stefano Gabbana is the Milanese half of fashion house Dolce & Gabbana.
About_#2: Born to a printing factory worker father and a mother who ironed clothes for a laundry service, he started the company with Domenico Dolce in 1985.
About_#3: The next year Dolce & Gabbana, known for its extravagant style and animal print designs, made its runway debut at the Milan Fashion Week.
About_#4: The duo's big break came in 1993 when Madonna chose them to design the costumes for her Girlie tour.
Did You Know?: He met Domenico Dolce at a Milan nightclub in the early 1980s.

About_#1: Gao Yi is the chairman of Yifeng Pharmacy Chain, which has more than 4,000 stores across China.
About_#2: Yifeng employs more than 20,000.
About_#3: Yifeng, headquartered in the central China city of Changsha, was founded by Gao in 2001.

Education: Drop Out, High School
About_#1: Alan Gerry started building a cable TV network in upstate New York in 1956.
About_#2: It became Cablevision Industries, which at its peak had 64 cable systems in 18 states.
About_#3: Gerry sold Cablevision Industries to Time Warner in 1996 for a reported $2.7 billion; he pocketed an estimated $900 million.
About_#4: He used that money to start own venture capital firm, Granite Associates, in 1996 to invest in emerging communications technologies.
Did You Know?: Gerry bought the site of the 1969 Woodstock festival and a decade later turned the location into the Bethel Woods Center for the Arts, an 800 acre cultural center.

About_#1: Balkrishan Goenka controls and runs the $2.2 billion (revenue) Welspun Group in Mumbai, with interests in textiles, pipes and steel.
About_#2: Spurning his family's trading business, Goenka borrowed $100,000 from his father, took a bank loan and started Welspun in 1985 to make polyester yarn.
About_#3: He expanded into home linen, focusing on the export market, with customers such as Walmart and Macy's.
About_#4: His Welspun Corp is one of the largest pipe companies in the world.
Did You Know?: Goenka has a passion for vintage cars.

About_#1: Esther Grether owns one of the world's most valuable and significant collections of 20th-century art, consisting of more than 600 pieces.
About_#2: The collection includes works by Picasso, Cezanne, Dali and one of Francis Bacon's triptychs.
About_#3: She has been a major shareholder in Swatch and is a former board member of the watchmaker.
About_#4: She inherited Doetsch Grether from her late husband Hans Grether in 1975. Hans' father Oscar cofounded the personal care product company in 1904.
Did You Know?: Esther Grether holds her art collection in a converted printing factory, where she also lives.
In Their Own Words: Art should never leave one cold.

About_#1: Gu Wei chairs Shenzhen MTC, which makes consumer electronics products, including TVs, for brands such as Philips.
About_#2: Shenzhen MTC trades on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange; Gu owns about half the company.
About_#3: Gu holds a MBA from Cheung Kong Graduate School of Business.

About_#1: Torstein Hagen started Viking Cruises in 1997, at age 54, with four riverboats in Russia.
About_#2: He had previously served as CEO of upmarket cruise line Royal Viking. He was forced to step down in 1984 after a failed bid to buy the company.
About_#3: Viking caters to wealthy, American retirees and has over 70 river cruise ships, which primarily traverse Europe's major waterways.
About_#4: Hagen began to offer ocean cruises in 2015 and now has six, 930-passenger ships.
Did You Know?: Hagen helped Holland America stave off bankruptcy in the 1970s and served on its board for three decades.
In Their Own Words: I love risk. I really do.

About_#1: Kenneth Hao is chairman of Silver Lake, a private equity firm specializing in making technology investments.
About_#2: Silver Lake is based in Silicon Valley and oversees about $75 billion.
About_#3: Hao joined Silver Lake in 2000. He previously worked as a managing director at Hambrecht & Quist.
About_#4: Hao led Silver Lake's expansion into Asia, opening offices in China and Japan and leading Silver Lake's profitable investment in Alibaba Group.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Oklahoma
About_#1: Inspired by geologist father, Timothy Headington founded Headington Oil in 1978. He sold his North Dakota oilfields to XTO Energy in 2008.
About_#2: He found a new passion in filmmaking and helped bankroll "Hugo," "Argo," "World War Z," and the 2018 reboot of "Lara Croft: Tomb Raider."
About_#3: He has invested in downtown Dallas, where he owns the Joule Hotel and department store 4510 and is partnering on a Virgin Hotel with Richard Branson.
About_#4: After Oklahoma University, Headington earned graduate degrees in theology and psychology at Fuller Theological Seminary.
Did You Know?: Headington was inducted into the Oklahoma Hall of Fame in 2014.

About_#1: Ilona Herlin is the great-granddaughter of Finnish business leader Harald Herlin, who invested in Kone Elevators in 1924.
About_#2: After her father's death in 2003, Ilona and her siblings discovered the will had been rewritten leaving most of the ownership in Kone to brother Antti
About_#3: Angered that they had never been informed, the siblings battled for control. The dispute ended in 2005, with Kone being split in two.
About_#4: Antti maintained control over the elevator business while his siblings were given stakes in Cargotec, producer of machinery for heavy duty ship cargo.
Did You Know?: Ilona is a linguist by training and an associate professor at Helsinki University.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Indian property tycoon Niranjan Hiranandani cofounded Hiranandani Group with brother Surendra, who now runs his independent venture.
About_#2: The brothers still own some assets jointly, mainly the Powai township in suburban Mumbai, which they built on a former quarry.
About_#3: They sold part of their commercial and retail assets in Powai to Canda's Brookfield Asset Management for $1 billion in 2016.
About_#4: Through his family office Nidar Group, Hiranandani is investing in energy infrastructure, building natural gas pipelines and gas storage terminals.
Did You Know?: His wife Kamal is involved in the group.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
About_#1: Drew Houston is the CEO of Dropbox, a file storage and sharing service that has more than 500 million users.
About_#2: Houston cofounded the company in 2007, when he was 24, with MIT classmate Arash Ferdowsi.
About_#3: The cloud storage provider went public in March 2018, with shares jumping more than 35% on its first day.
About_#4: Houston, who owns more than 20% of the company, is Dropbox's largest individual shareholder.
Did You Know?: He worked at a industrial robotics startup when he was 15.
In Their Own Words: Maximize your rate of learning. Pick opportunities that will push you and surround you with the most talented people.

About_#1: Huang Rulun leads the Century Golden Resources Group, which has investments in Chinese hotels and shopping malls.
About_#2: Huang, who was in the trading business in the Philippines in his youth, attended Philippines President Duterte's inauguration ceremony in June 2016.
About_#3: Huang's son, Huang Tao, has been president of Century Golden Resources Group since 2012.

About_#1: Matt Hulsizer cofounded options trading firm Peak6 in 1997 with his now-wife Jenny Just.
About_#2: The duo have launched or bought about 15 companies through Peak6, which now operates as an investment firm.
About_#3: Hulsizer's fortune comes from Apex Fintech Solutions, which handles backend trading and technology for fintechs such as SoFi, Ally, eToro and WeBull.
About_#4: Apex Fintech Solutions canceled plans to go public via a SPAC merger in December 2021; the deal would have valued the company at $4.7 billion.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Michigan State University; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Vanderbilt University
About_#1: Justin Ishbia is an investor in Michigan-based mortgage lender United Wholesale Mortgage (UWM), founded by his father, Jeff, in 1986.
About_#2: He owns a 22% stake in the company, which went public through a merger with a blank check company in January 2021.
About_#3: Launched as a side gig while Jeff worked as an attorney for his day job, UWM grew to become America's largest wholesale lender in 2015.
About_#4: His brother, Mat, who is also a billionaire, serves as UWM's CEO.

About_#1: Peter Jackson, a film director, is best known for his "Lord of the Rings" and "Hobbit" trilogies, which have grossed $6 billion worldwide.
About_#2: Jackson became a billionaire in November 2021 after selling a chunk of his Weta digital film effects shop to Unity Software for $1.6 billion in cash and stock.
About_#3: He made $10 million up front for each of the three "Lord of the Rings" films (2001-2003), with at least another 10% of profits earned from each film's box office receipts.
About_#4: For the "Hobbit" movies, he likely made $20 million per film with 20% backend.

About_#1: Jin Lei is CEO of GenSci Pharmaceutical, a manufacturer of recombinant human growth hormone.
About_#2: GenSci went public by merging with Shenzhen-listed Changchun High & New Technology Industries Group in 2019.
About_#3: Jin holds a master's degree from the Chinese Academy of Sciences and a Ph.D. from University of California.
About_#4: After receiving a doctorate, Jin worked for biomedical firm Genentech in the U.S.

About_#1: Conni Jonsson founded Swedish investment company EQT Partners AB in 1994.
About_#2: He has been the chairman of the board since 2014.
About_#3: Jonsson owns nearly 5% of EQT, which listed its shares on the Stockholm stock exchange in 2019.
About_#4: EQT has roughly $62 billion (52 billion Euro) in assets under management.

About_#1: Jenny Just started out as an options trader in Chicago, then cofounded options trading firm Peak6 in 1997.
About_#2: Just used her trading profits to start or buy about 15 companies through Peak6.
About_#3: Her star investment: Apex Fintech Solutions, which handles the back-end trading and technology for fintechs such as SoFi, Ally, eToro and WeBull.
About_#4: Apex Fintech Solutions canceled plans to go public via a SPAC merger in December 2021; the deal would have valued the company at $4.7 billion.
In Their Own Words: I grew up with four brothers so it's not a radical surprise that I had chosen to be in a male-dominated field. I probably would have, frankly, failed in a totally female-dominated industry. This is my comfort zone

Education: Drop Out, Temple University
About_#1: Sidney Kimmel founded apparel company Jones Group more than four decades ago; it owned brands including Stuart Weitzman and Nine West.
About_#2: In 2014, he sold the company for $2.2 billion to private equity firm Sycamore Partners.
About_#3: He owns production company Sidney Kimmel Entertainment, which produced the films 'Hell or High Water' and 'The Kite Runner.'
About_#4: Kimmel donated $110 million to Thomas Jefferson University in 2014.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Cornell University; Master of Business Administration, Harvard University
About_#1: Investment legend Seth Klarman runs Boston-based firm Baupost. With $30 billion under management, Baupost is one of the largest hedge funds.
About_#2: Klarman is seen as an expert in value investing. His book "Margin of Safety," a cult classic among investors, sells for as much as $3,000 on Amazon.
About_#3: An avid philanthropist, his foundation's assets hit $640 million as of the latest public filing.
About_#4: Once a major donor to the Republican Party, Klarman publicly denounced Trump in 2016, and has been contributing to the Democratic Party.
Did You Know?: In 2017, Klarman's horse, Cloud Computing, won the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico, the racetrack he grew up next to in Baltimore.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Johns Hopkins University
About_#1: Mustafa Rahmi Koc is honorary chairman of Koc Holding, a conglomerate whose main sectors are energy, automotive, durable consumer goods and finance.
About_#2: Other activities include technology, food, retail, tourism, agriculture and shipbuilding. Koc Group has 14 companies traded on the Borsa İstanbul.
About_#3: In 2003, after running the group's main public company, Koc Holding, for 19 years, Rahmi Koc handed the chairmanship to his eldest son, Mustafa Koc.
About_#4: After Mustafa Koc had a fatal heart attack in 2016, at age 56, his brother Omer took over.
Did You Know?: His childhood dream was to go on a world tour. In 2006, he completed two years of extensive voyaging on his sailboat, "Nazenin IV."
In Their Own Words: Being a collector is, essentially, a passion. There is no rule that says lots of money will result in a beautiful collection.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Magnitogorsk Mining and Metallurgical Institute
About_#1: Pyotr Kondrashev started working at Silvinit's fertilizer factory in 1972.
About_#2: Kondrashev became the company's CEO in 1990 and later led its privatization.
About_#3: In 2010 he and his partners sold their stakes in Silvinit, Russia's second-largest producer of potassium fertilizer, for an estimated $3 billion.
About_#4: In 2014 he bought Solikamsk Magnesium Plant (SMZ), which produces 60% of Russia's rare earth metal magnesium.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Jinan University
About_#1: Kong Jian Min chairs KWG Property Holding, a property developer based in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou.
About_#2: Kong served as a credit officer at the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China in Guangzhou before taking the plunge as an entrepreneur.
About_#3: Kong founded KWG in 1995.
About_#4: Kong received a degree in computer science from Jinan University in China in 1989.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, University of Mumbai
About_#1: Veteran investment banker Hemendra Kothari chairs DSP Investment Managers, which has $15 billion in assets under management.
About_#2: He founded the firm in 2008 in partnership with BlackRock but bought out BlackRock's stake ten years later.
About_#3: Kothari started his career with family firm D.S. Purbhoodas & Co before founding financial services firm DSP Financial Consultants in 1975.
About_#4: He partnered with Merrill Lynch in 1995 but sold his 57% stake in tranches between 2005 and 2009.
Did You Know?: A wildlife enthusiast, he founded the Wildlife Conservation Trust and has named meeting rooms at his office after tiger reserves.

About_#1: Eduard Kučera is the cofounder of Prague-based internet security company Avast Software.
About_#2: In 1988, he and Pavel Baudis, with whom he'd worked at Research Institute of Mathematical Machines, cofounded ALWIL to sell an antivirus software.
About_#3: Following the fall of Communism in 1989, the pair broke off to establish what would become Avast.
About_#4: Now run by an outside CEO, Avast, which secures online activities for more than 435 million users, went public in 2018.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University; Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business
About_#1: Christopher Kwok is the younger son of property mogul Raymond Kwok, chairman of Sun Hung Kai Properties, the largest developer in Hong Kong.
About_#2: He's served as an executive director at Sun Hung Kai since April 2016, taking charge of sales, project management and the leasing of major projects.
About_#3: He's also a member of the Beijing Municipal Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference.
About_#4: In 2012 his father and his uncle Thomas became involved in a bribery investigation. Raymond was acquitted but Thomas was found guilty and sentenced to five years in prison in 2014.
Did You Know?: Christopher's brother, Edward, and three of his cousins are also billionaires.

About_#1: Edward Kwok is the older son of property mogul Raymond Kwok, chairman of Sun Hung Kai Properties, the largest developer in Hong Kong.
About_#2: He's served as an alternate company director to his father since 2012, when Raymond and his uncle Thomas became involved in a bribery investigation.
About_#3: His father was acquitted but Thomas was found guilty of bribing a government official and sentenced to five years in prison in 2014.
About_#4: He joined Sun Hung Kai in 2010 and is a sales and project manager, responsible for planning and marketing the group's Hong Kong residential projects.
Did You Know?: Edward's brother, Christopher, and three of his cousins are also billionaires.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Stanford University; Masters of Public Health, UCLA; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, Irvine
About_#1: Joe Lacob led an ownership group that in 2010 paid $450 million for the Golden State Warriors NBA team.
About_#2: The value of the team is up almost tenfold since then, and his 25% stake is worth more than $900 million, net of debt.
