About_#3: The Warriors won three titles during the decade and posted the best record in NBA history during the 2015-16 season with 73 wins.
About_#4: Lacob was a minority owner of the NBA's Boston Celtics for five years before selling to buy the Warriors.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Fudan University
About_#1: Lai Jianfa is a director and executive vice president of express delivery firm ZTO Express.
About_#2: ZTO was founded in 2002.
About_#3: ZTO's business partners include Alibaba and JD.com.

About_#1: Manuel Lao Hernandez founded Cirsa, a multinational casino company. He sold it to Blackstone for an estimated $2.6 billion (including debt) in 2018.
About_#2: He started the business in 1978 and expanded it to nine countries in Latin America and Europe. He still owns Cirsa's Argentina operations.
About_#3: His three children all worked for the family business, which was based just outside of Barcelona.
About_#4: Through his Nortia investment firm, Lao Hernandez owns a swath of rural land in central Spain and two hotels in Barcelona.
Did You Know?: As a hobby, Lao Hernandez grows bonsai trees.

Education: Doctorate, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology; Master of Science, Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Seoul National University
About_#1: Lee Joon-ho is a cofounder of South Korea's largest internet portal, Naver.
About_#2: He now chairs NHN Entertainment, which was Naver's online-games business until the two split in 2013.
About_#3: He sold $225 million worth of Naver shares in 2014 and another $115 million worth in 2016.
Did You Know?: He was an associate professor at Soongsil University, a private Christian University in Seoul.

Education: Drop Out, La Sapienza University of Rome
About_#1: Manfredi Lefebvre d'Ovidio is the chairman of Heritage Group and co-chair of luxury travel company Abercrombie and Kent.
About_#2: Lefebvre spent two decades running Silversea Cruises, which his father Antonio started in 1994 with two ships in Italy.
About_#3: Lefebvre took over the company in 2001 and turned it into a luxury cruise line that travels to 900 destinations worldwide.
About_#4: He sold Silversea Cruises to Royal Caribbean in two transactions, in 2018 and 2020, for a total of $1.25 billion in cash and Royal Caribbean stock.
Did You Know?: Lefebvre studied to be a lawyer in Rome but dropped out before getting his degree.

About_#1: Lu Rongfu is deputy general manager of Shenzhen-listed Yealink Network Technology, a supplier of communication equipment.
About_#2: Lu cofounded the predecessor of Yealink with Wu Zhongyi, Chen Zhisong and Zhou Jiwei in 2001.
About_#3: Wu Zhongyi and Chen Zhisong ranked No. 1,337 on 2020 billionaires list with wealth of $1.6 billion each through Yealink states.
About_#4: Chen Zhisong and Wu Zhongyi are chairman and vice chairman of the Yealink.

About_#1: Rafique Malik's Metro Brands is a popular multi-brand footwear retailer with 624 stores across 142 cities in India.
About_#2: The $177 million (revenue), privately held company is known for its brands such as Mochi, Metro and Walkway.
About_#3: Farah Malik Bhanji, the second of his five daughters, runs the company as managing director.
About_#4: Malik listed the company in December 2021.
Did You Know?: The late billionaire investor Rakesh Jhunjhunwala's family has a minority stake in Metro Brands.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Auburn University; Bachelor of Science in Engineering, North Carolina State University
About_#1: Youssef Mansour is chairman of family-owned conglomerate Mansour Group, which was founded by his father Loutfy (d.1976) in 1952.
About_#2: Mansour Group is the exclusive distributor of GM vehicles and Caterpillar equipment in Egypt and several other countries.
About_#3: He oversees the consumer goods division, which includes supermarket chain Metro, and sole distribution rights for L'Oreal in Egypt.
About_#4: Younger brothers Mohamed and Yasseen are also billionaires and part owners of Mansour Group.
Did You Know?: Former Egypt President Gamal Abdel Nasser nationalized his father's original cotton trading business.

About_#1: Mao Lixiang is the founder of Fotile, one of China's largest kitchen appliance brands.
About_#2: Son Mao Zhongchun currently chairs the business from its headquarters in the eastern Chinese city of Ningbo.
About_#3: Fotile's top sellers include kitchen range hoods.
About_#4: Fotile's rivals include Robam Appliances, led by fellow billionaire Ren Jiahua.

About_#1: David McMurtry is the executive chairman of Renishaw, the engineering and scientific technology company he cofounded in 1973.
About_#2: Renishaw supplies high-tech laser components used by drones and self-driving cars, and metal 3D printers used to make medical implants and teeth.
About_#3: McMurtry has invented or co-invented more than 150 of the company's products, and was on 47 patents at Rolls-Royce, where he worked before Renishaw.
About_#4: He stepped down as the firm's CEO in 2018.
Did You Know?: In his spare time, Sir David enjoys squash and table tennis.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, College of William & Mary; Master of Business Administration, The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania
About_#1: Miller founded Universal Health Services, a chain of hospitals and other health providers, in 1979.
About_#2: The company has more than 400 facilities across the US and UK and brings in $11 billion in annual revenue.
About_#3: In January 2021, Miller stepped down as CEO and his son Marc Miller now runs the company.
About_#4: Miller remains the executive chairman of UHS's board of directors.

About_#1: Greg Mondre is co-CEO of Silver Lake, a private equity firm specializing in making technology investments.
About_#2: Silver Lake is based in Silicon Valley and oversees about $75 billion.
About_#3: Mondre joined Silver Lake in 1999 after stints at Goldman Sachs and private equity firm TPG.
About_#4: Mondre has worked on deals for Motorola Solutions, Red Ventures, WP Engine, GoodRx and GoDaddy.

About_#1: Massimo Moratti is the largest shareholder and former CEO of Saras, Italy's largest oil refinery.
About_#2: His father, Angelo, founded the firm in 1962; Massimo and his late billionaire brother, Gian Marco (d.2018), took Saras public in 2006.
About_#3: Massimo owns 20% of the company, which has a liquified fuel gasification plant, a wind farm in Sardinia and gas stations mainly in Spain.
About_#4: Gian Marco controlled a similar stake as Massimo and passed it on to his two sons, Angelo and Gabriele, when he died.
Did You Know?: Moratti was an owner of soccer club Inter Milan for more than two decades before selling the last of his shares in mid-2016.

About_#1: Robert Mouawad inherited the family's eponymous high-end jewelry business that his grandfather founded in Beirut in 1890.
About_#2: He turned over management of the business to his sons Fred, Alain and Pascal in 2010.
About_#3: Mouawad boasts one of the world's most dazzling gem collections, including Dynasty, a 51.12 carat Russian diamond estimated at nearly $10 million.
About_#4: Robert Mouawad also owns extensive real estate and has developed luxury residences on a man-made island in Bahrain.
Did You Know?: Mouawad has a private museum in a 110 year-old Beirut palace displaying his collection of Roman and Phoenician antiquities.
In Their Own Words: Success is a rare cocktail that requires a bottomless glass of passion, common sense as the basic ingredient, and a pinch of experience to make it delectable.

About_#1: Together with brother David, Ezra Nahmad is an international megadealer of modern and impressionist art, which they trade mostly at auction.
About_#2: The two own an inventory worth some $3 billion that they store in a duty-free warehouse next to the airport in Geneva, Switzerland.
About_#3: Their stockpile includes works by more than 30 blue chip artists, from Monet and Matisse to Renoir and Rothko.
About_#4: Among their holdings: 300 Picassos, worth at least $1 billion.
Did You Know?: Ezra's sons Hillel and Joe run art galleries in London. Their American cousins, also named Hillel and Joe, run galleries in New York.

About_#1: Tadako Nakatani is the widow of Taro Nakatani, who founded medical testing equipment maker Sysmex as a subsidiary of electrical equipment maker Toa Electric in 1968.
About_#2: Taro, who died in 1984, led Toa's efforts to research, develop and manufacture medical equipment in the early 1960s.
About_#3: The company is run by her son-in-law Hisashi Ietsugu, who joined the firm in 1986 and became president a decade later.
About_#4: Sysmex listed on the second sections of the Osaka Stock Exchange in 1995 and the Tokyo Stock Exchange in 1996, moving up to the first section of both in 2000.

About_#1: Kentaro Ogawa founded fast-food outfit Zensho in 1982. Publicly traded Zensho has a network of nearly 10,000 restaurants.
About_#2: Its Sukiya chain serves shredded beef over rice (called gyudon). It also owns a steak chain called Big Boy and pasta specialty chain Jolly-Pasta.
About_#3: Ogawa wants to turn Zensho into the world's number one food company so that it "can help eradicate hunger and poverty from the world."
About_#4: The launch of new products such as a home delivery lunch box in 2021, boosted Zensho's sales and profits.
Did You Know?: Ogawa is a former shipyard worker and labor union activist in Japan.

Education: Master of Science, Columbia University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, SUNY Stony Brook
About_#1: Jon Oringer started Shutterstock with $10,000 in 2003 to create a more affordable way to supply stock photos.
About_#2: He took the photo service public in 2012 and served as its CEO until April 2020, when he became executive chairman.
About_#3: Oringer owns nearly 33% of Shutterstock, which had 2021 revenues of $773 million.
About_#4: A serial entrepreneur, Oringer created one of the first pop-up blockers as a computer science graduate student at Columbia University.
Did You Know?: To launch Shutterstock, he bought a camera, took 30,000 pictures and started a website that sold pictures for cheap.

About_#1: Niti Osathanugrah gets a chunk of his wealth from a stake in Osotspa, his family's 131- year-old maker of popular energy drink M-150.
About_#2: The company, which listed in 2018, is run by his cousin Petch, who is an avid art collector.
About_#3: Niti also has valuable stakes in fellow billionaire William Heinecke's Minor International as well as Central Plaza Hotel and Home Product Center.

About_#1: Dragos Paval and his brother, Adrian, own Dedeman, a leading Romanian construction materials and do-it-yourself home products retailer.
About_#2: The $2 billion (sales) company's 57 stores stock some 60,000 products, ranging from tools and building supplies to furniture and appliances.
About_#3: The brothers founded the business in 1992 with a single location in Bacau, Romania.
About_#4: They also own shares of several publicly traded Romanian companies and a portfolio of real estate in Bucharest and the northern city of Cluj.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Duke University
About_#1: Zach Perret is CEO of Plaid, which helps other fintechs connect to customers' bank accounts so the customers can make deposits and payments.
About_#2: Perret and his cofounder William Hockey met as junior Bain consultants before founding Plaid in 2012.
About_#3: Plaid's customers include Robinhood, Coinbase and Venmo.
About_#4: Visa called off a $5.3 billion deal to buy Plaid in early 2021 after the Department of Justice filed an antitrust lawsuit aiming to block the acquisition.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, London Business School
About_#1: Karl-Johan Persson, the third generation of his family to head up H&M, was appointed to chairman of the fast fashion favorite in 2020.
About_#2: He served as CEO from 2009 when he took the reins from his father, billionaire Stefan Persson.
About_#3: Karl-Johan's grandfather, Erling Persson, founded H&M in 1947.
About_#4: The company has since grown into a global retail power house with more than 4,400 stores in 66 countries.
Did You Know?: Crown princess Victoria is the godmother to one of his children.

About_#1: Markus "Notch" Persson made his fortune selling the rights to his game Minecraft to Microsoft.
About_#2: In September 2014, after selling 15 million copies of Minecraft across gaming consoles, Persson sold out to Microsoft in a $2.5 billion cash deal.
About_#3: Persson has since been jetting around the world while programming new games in his spare time.
About_#4: An avid social media user, Persson has been open about the downsides of instant success as he used Reddit to express loneliness.
Did You Know?: Persson created Minecraft as a hobby project, and released the boxy designed game in indie-game forums, which won immediate popularity.
In Their Own Words: Partying is not a sane way to spend money, but it's fun. When we were young we did not have a lot of money at all, so I thought, if I ever get rich, I'm not going to become one of those boring rich people that doesn't spend money.

About_#1: Tom Persson is third generation of the family that made its fortune from global cheap chic retailer H&M.
About_#2: His grandfather, Erling Persson, founded the chain in 1947.
About_#3: Brother Karl-Johan is set to be appointed chairman at the annual shareholders meeting in 2020.
About_#4: Tom's father, brother, sister Charlotte Söderström, and aunt Lottie Tham are all billionaires.
Did You Know?: Persson is a graduate of the Met Film School in London.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Robert H. Smith School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Maryland
About_#1: Under Armour founder Kevin Plank built a popular sportswear brand as the underdog competitor to Nike.
About_#2: Noticing his football teammates' sweat-soaked shirts, Plank came up with a lightweight, sweat-wicking shirt using fabrics from women's undergarments.
About_#3: In the mid 1990s he sold his first shirts from his grandmother's basement, exaggerating to early customers to make the company sound bigger.
About_#4: Plank, who stepped down as Under Armour's CEO in 2019 and is now chairman, took the company public 2005; he owns a nearly 16% stake.
Did You Know?: Plank got kicked out of his high school after an alcohol-fueled brawl with Georgetown U football players; he later walked onto the U. of Maryland's football team.
In Their Own Words: We were always smart enough to be naive enough to not know what we could accomplish.

About_#1: Andreas Pohl is CEO of Deutsche Vermoegensberatung (DVAG), the leading German company offering mutual funds, consumer insurance and annuities.
About_#2: His brother Reinfried and he inherited the DVAG empire from their father, Reinfried Pohl Sr., who died in 2014.
About_#3: The DVAG founder supported a range of schools and organizations in his home city of Marburg, which has led some to refer to it as "Pohl City."
About_#4: The family's holding company, owned 50/50 by the brothers, holds 60% of DVAG, with the remaining 40% held by Generali Deutschland Holding AG.
Did You Know?: He is a vintage car aficionado and occasionally participates in vintage car races.

About_#1: Reinfried Pohl Jr. is chief representative of DVAG, the leading German company offering mutual funds, consumer insurance and annuities.
About_#2: His brother Andreas and he inherited the DVAG empire from their father, Reinfried Pohl Sr., who died in 2014.
About_#3: The family's holding company, owned 50/50 by the brothers, holds 60% of DVAG, with the remaining 40% held by Generali Deutschland Holding AG.
About_#4: Reinfried grew up in the company, attended openings of new branches with his father as a teenager, then sold insurance and later helped manage DVAG.
Did You Know?: The DVAG founder supported a range of schools and organizations in his home city of Marburg, which has led some to refer to it as "Pohl City."

Education: Master of Business Administration, University of Chicago Booth School of Business
About_#1: Emigrated to America from Soviet Ukraine with his wife in 1976 with $500.
About_#2: Invenergy is seeking to build 1,000 wind turbines in western Kansas and an 800 mile power line to carry their power east. For $7 billion.
About_#3: Sold natural gas generator SkyGen to Calpine for $450 million in 2001.
About_#4: Invenergy now owns more than 10,000 megawatts, including nearly 7,000 wind turbines.
In Their Own Words: "When you have a mission, a conviction, you perform on a completely different level. You believe so strongly, you don't take no for an answer."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Andhra University
About_#1: Airports tycoon G.M.Rao controls listed airports operator GMR Infrastructure.
About_#2: The company operates airports at Hyderabad and Delhi as well as the Mactan Cebu International Airport in the Philippines.
About_#3: In January 2022, it demerged its airports business creating two listed entities, GMR Indra for the airports business and GMR Power and Urban Infra Limited for the non-airports business.
About_#4: Former jute trader, split from family and moved into banking, later infrastructure.

Education: Bachelor of Science, St. John's University
About_#1: Mike Repole cofounded sports drink BodyArmor in 2011 and serves as the company's chairman.
About_#2: Coca-Cola bought 15% of BodyArmor in 2018, then purchased the rest in 2021 for $5.6 billion, the company's largest acquisition of a brand.
About_#3: BodyArmor's investors included tennis star Naomi Osaka and the late Kobe Bryant, who discovered the brand while rehabbing from a torn Achilles tendon.
About_#4: The son of a waiter and a seamstress, Repole studied sports management at St. John's before working in sales for a small company, Mistic Beverage.

About_#1: Fernando Roig owns ceramics firm Pamesa as well as a 9% stake in Spanish supermarket chain Mercadona.
About_#2: His billionaire brother Juan Roig is the majority shareholder of Mercadona, which was founded by their parents in 1977.
About_#3: Juan and Fernando took over Mercadona with their sisters in 1981 when it was only an eight-store chain.
About_#4: Since then they have turned it into one of Europe's largest food retailers, with more than 1,600 supermarkets.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Oxford University; Master, Oxford University
About_#1: Chris Rokos is the founder of hedge fund firm Rokos Capital Management.
About_#2: Rokos is a macro investor who trades currencies, interest rates and commodities, as well as equities.
About_#3: Rokos founded his London-based firm in 2015 and it now manages some $12 billion and employs more than 200 people.
About_#4: A founding partner of Brevan Howard Asset Management, Rokos left the hedge fund firm after having a falling out with his partner, Alan Howard.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, Berkeley
About_#1: Revered investment manager Fayez Sarofim, founder and chairman of money management firm Fayez Sarofim & Co., died in May 2022 at age 93.
About_#2: Sarofim, an immigrant from Egypt who rarely spoke to the media, was nicknamed "The Sphinx;" he was one of the first investors in energy pipeline firm Kinder Morgan.
About_#3: He received an M.B.A. from Harvard Business School before starting his investment firm in Houston in 1958; it had $29.4 billion in assets under management as of December 2021.
About_#4: Sarofim donated $70 million to the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston and was known for his extensive art collection, which included works by Mary Cassatt and Edward Hopper.
Did You Know?: He is the son of a wealthy Egyptian cotton farmer.

About_#1: Antonio Luiz Seabra founded Natura Cosmeticos in 1969 as Brazil's answer to Avon and built it into Brazil's largest beauty company.
About_#2: Some 1.4 million "consultants" (mainly women) sell Natura products door-to-door across Brazil, six other Latin American countries and France.
About_#3: Natura Cosmeticos, which went public in 2004, bought bought UK Cosmetics chain The Body Shop from L'Oréal in 2017 for over $1 billion.
About_#4: Seabra is co-chairman of the board of Natura and also owns Bresco, a Brazilian property-rental operation focused on warehouses, offices and hotels.
In Their Own Words: The impossible is only the beginning of all possibilities!

About_#1: Amnon Shashua is the cofounder and CEO of autonomous vehicle technology firm Mobileye.
About_#2: A computer science professor at Hebrew University, Shashua launched the company in 1999 with fellow billionaire Ziv Aviram.
About_#3: The pair took Mobileye public in 2014, then sold it to Intel in 2017 at a $15.3 billion valuation.
About_#4: Aviram and Shashua also co-CEOs of Or-Cam, which makes portable, artificial vision devices for visually impaired people. They founded it in 2010.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Plekhanov Russian University of Economics
About_#1: Yuri Shefler owns SPI Group, which produces and sells alcohol under 380 brands in 170 countries.
About_#2: Its best known brand is Stolichnaya vodka, which Shefler bought from state-owned VVO Soyuzplodoimport for $285,000 in 1997.
About_#3: Russia's Supreme Court ruled the sale illegal in 2001, banning Shefler from selling the vodka inside its borders.
About_#4: In 2014, the Netherlands, Luxembourg and Belgium joined Russia in banning sales of Stolichnaya.

Education: Master of Science, Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology
About_#1: Mikhail Shelkov is the former head of the investment division of state-owned Rostec, which controlled military contractors in Russia.
About_#2: Shelkov's former boss Sergey Chemezov, CEO of Rostec, is a member of Putin's inner circle, befriending Russia's president in Germany in the 1980s.
About_#3: From 2012 to 2014, Shelkov and partners bought a controlling stake in VSMPO-AVISMA Corporation from Rostec and Gazprombank.
About_#4: VSMPO-AVISMA is the world's largest titanium producer for the aerospace industry, with such customers as Boeing, Airbus, Rolls-Royce and Embraer.

About_#1: Charlotte Söderström is the daughter of Sweden's richest person, Stefan Persson, chairman of global cheap chic retailer H&M, where she holds a stake.
About_#2: Her grandfather Erling Persson founded the chain in 1947.
About_#3: Brother Karl-Johan is set to be appointed chairman at the annual shareholders meeting in 2020.
About_#4: Brother Tom Persson and aunt Lottie Tham are also billionaires.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Southern California
About_#1: Edwin Soeryadjaya is the son of the late William Soeryadjaya, founder of conglomerate Astra International.
About_#2: William sold his shares in Astra in 1992 to bail out Bank Summa, run by a family member; as a result his fortune was wiped out.
About_#3: Edwin helped rebuild the family fortune via holding company Saratoga Investama Sedaya, which he founded in 1997.
About_#4: Edwin's son Michael is President Director of the firm, which is publicly traded and has stakes in around 20 companies, including coal firm Adaro Energy.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Stanford University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: Tom Steyer spent 26 years running hedge fund Farallon Capital; he sold his stake in 2012 and switched his focus to politics and the environment.
About_#2: The San Francisco resident spent some $65 million to back select Democratic candidates and environmental causes in the 2016 election cycle.
About_#3: Steyer is a passionate advocate of clean energy and founder of the environmental group NextGen Climate.
About_#4: Steyer and his wife, Kat Taylor, have donated tens of millions of dollars to alma maters Stanford and Yale for "advanced energy" research.
Did You Know?: Steyer was captain of the soccer team at Yale University.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Stanford University
About_#1: Kevin Systrom launched photo-sharing mobile phone app Instagram in 2010.
About_#2: Facebook bought Instagram for $1 billion in stock and cash in 2012, and Systrom stayed on to continue running it. He left Facebook in September 2018.
About_#3: Systrom owned 40% of Instagram going into the deal, and got mostly Facebook stock.
About_#4: Under Systrom as CEO, Instagram became a fast growing app, with roughly 1 billion monthly users. It's continued to grow since he left.
Did You Know?: Systrom convinced well known public figures to join Instagram, including Pope Francis and singer Selena Gomez.

About_#1: Hary Tanoesoedibjo got his start building a media business soon after college; he still owns more than 60 TV stations, radio stations and a newspaper.
About_#2: He stepped down as CEO of his Media Nusantara Citra (MNC), which owns four national TV stations, in 2016 to focus on politics.
About_#3: Via his listed firm MNC Land, he is building resorts in Bali and Java that will be managed by Donald Trump's company.
About_#4: His daughter Angela Herliani Tanoesoedibjo is Indonesia's Deputy Tourism and Creative Economy Minister.
Did You Know?: Hary, who attended Donald Trump's inauguration, is building a Trump Hotel luxury resort in Bali.

About_#1: Jonathan Tisch's late father Bob (d. 2005) started Loews Corporation with his brother Laurence as a New Jersey hotel venture in 1946.
About_#2: Tisch is co-chairman of Loews alongside his cousin Andrew Tisch; he's also the CEO of Loews' hotel unit.
About_#3: Loews is active in insurance, drilling rigs, natural gas pipelines and hotels.
About_#4: His father Bob also bought a 50% stake in the New York Giants for $75 million in 1991.
Did You Know?: He and his wife Lizzie donated more than $2.8 million to the the University of Michigan Museum of Art in May 2019.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Skidmore College
About_#1: Wilma Tisch owes her fortune to her late husband Laurence (d. 2003) and his brother Bob, who started Loews Corp as a New Jersey hotel venture in 1946.
About_#2: Wilma's son James is the president and CEO of publicly traded Loews, which now has interests in drilling, natural gas pipelines and insurance.
About_#3: Her sister-in law Joan Tisch, also a billionaire, died in 2017; Wilma's son Andrew co-chairs Loews' board with Joan's son Jonathan.
About_#4: At NYU, the Tisch family donated funds to support the Tisch School of the Arts and the Tisch Hospital at Langone Medical Center.
Did You Know?: Tisch was the first woman to be elected president of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Southern Illinois University
About_#1: Kenny Troutt founded long-distance phone company Excel Communications in 1988 and took the company public in 1996.
About_#2: In 1998, Troutt sold Excel Communications to Teleglobe in a $3.5 billion deal and reinvested the profits in stocks, bonds and horses.
About_#3: An avid horse racing fan, Troutt owns WinStar Farm in Versailles, Kentucky, breeder of Thoroughbreds including a Kentucky Derby winner.
Did You Know?: The son of a single mother who worked as a bartender, Troutt grew up in public housing in Mount Vernon, IL.

About_#1: Thomas von Koch joined publicly traded Swedish investment company EQT AB at its founding in 1994.
About_#2: He ran EQT as CEO and managing partner from 2014 to 2019.
About_#3: Von Koch owns 4% of EQT, which has roughly $62 billion (52 billion Euro) in assets under management.
About_#4: EQT primarily invests in private equity, but has also put funds into venture capital, real estate and infrastructure.

About_#1: Myron Wentz is the founder of USANA, a multilevel marketing company that sells nutritional supplements and skincare products.
About_#2: Wentz owns 42% of the business, which trades on the NYSE and has $1.2 billion in net sales. He took it public in 1996.
About_#3: In December 2019, he retired as USANA's chairman.
About_#4: Prior to USANA, he founded Gull Laboratories in 1974 to sell diagnostic tests to hospitals and labs; he sold his stake in 1994 for $22 million.
Did You Know?: He spends most of his time at Sanoviv Medical Institute, a holistic care center he founded in 1998 in Rosarito, Mexico.

About_#1: Wu Kaiting is the chairman of Xiamen Intretech Inc., a supplier of electronics products including remote controls for home entertainment equipment.
About_#2: Intretech went public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange on Jan. 15, 2018.
About_#3: Wu owns a 55% stake in Intretech.
About_#4: Wu is the son of Wanlida Group founder Wu Huitian, a member of the Forbes China Rich list in 2008; Wu died in 2012.

About_#1: Xu Zhenhua cofounded Moonton Games, a business bought by ByteDance for $4 billion in 2021.
About_#2: Cofounder Justin Yuan is also a billionaire.
About_#3: Xu worked at China online game leader Tencent before taking the plunge as an entrepreneur himself.

About_#1: Xue Jiping is chairman of Jiangsu Zhongtian Technology, a supplier of optical fiber communication products.
About_#2: Zhongtian's predecessor business was a small collective factory that made bricks and tiles.
About_#3: ZTT Group, Xue's listed arm, entered the field of optical fiber communication in the early 1990s.
About_#4: ZTT went public at the Shanghai Stock Exchange on Oct 24, 2002.

About_#1: Zhang Yin, also known as Cheung Yan, chairs Hong Kong-listed Nine Dragons Paper, one of Asia's largest packaging and paper producers.
About_#2: Zhang's husband Liu Ming Chung, the CEO of Nine Dragons, is also a billionaire.
About_#3: Zhang's younger brother, Zhang Cheng Fei, the deputy CEO of Nine Dragons, is a billionaire, too -- one of three in the family.
About_#4: Zhang Yin is vice chair of the Guangdong Federation of Industry and Commerce.

Education: LLB, Calcutta University; M.Com, Calcutta University; Chartered Accountant, Institute of Chartered Accountants of India; Company Secretary, Institute of Company Secretaries of India
About_#1: Radhe Shyam Agarwal gets his wealth from his stake in consumer goods company Emami, which he cofounded with his buddy Radhe Shyam Goenka.
About_#2: Emami's range of more than 300 products, including popular brands Zandu balm and antiseptic cream Boroplus, are sold through 4.5 million retail outlets.
About_#3: Agarwal also has interests in real estate, edible oils and healthcare.
About_#4: In 2019, Agarwal and Goenka sold their privately held cement business to fellow billionaire Karsanbhai Patel's company for $730 million.
Did You Know?: Agarwal and Goenka were school friends who gave up corporate jobs to start Emami in 1974.

Education: Drop Out, High School
About_#1: Low-profile Syed Mokhtar AlBukhary started as a rice trader after dropping out of high school.
About_#2: The bulk of his wealth comes from stakes in DRB-HICOM and MMC Corp.
About_#3: MMC's operations span ports, logistics, construction and engineering while DRB-HICOM is an automotive firm with interests in property and education.
About_#4: DRB-HICOM sold a 49.9% stake in Malaysian car-maker Proton to Chinese auto group Zhejiang Geely in 2017.
Did You Know?: In 2018 his philanthropic venture, the Albukhary Foundation, opened a new permanent gallery at the British Museum showcasing art related to the Islamic world.

About_#1: Nerio Alessandri is the founder and president of the Italian gym and fitness equipment manufacturer Technogym.
About_#2: Alessandri founded the company in Cesena, Italy in 1983 at age 22.
About_#3: Alessandri took the company public on the Milan Stock Exchange in 2016.
About_#4: When he started Technogym, Alessandri designed and built the first pieces of equipment in his garage.

About_#1: Patricia Angelini Rossi inherited a stake in Grupo Empresas Angelini, the Chilean investment group headed by her brother, Roberto Angelini Rossi.
About_#2: The group's largest holding is publicly-traded Antarchile, which distributes fuel, operates fishing and shipping businesses and invests in energy.
About_#3: Antarchile's forestry subsidiary, Arauco, entered North America in 2012 with the purchase of Canada's Flakeboard, which manufactures wood panels.
About_#4: The group was previously headed by Patricia's uncle, Anacleto Angelini, who died in 2007.

Education: Bachelor of Business Administration, The University Of Georgia
About_#1: Tope Awotona is the founder and CEO of scheduling software company Calendly.
About_#2: Awotona, a former salesman for tech firms including EMC (now Dell EMC), founded Calendly out of his own frustration with the back-and-forth emails required to schedule meetings.
About_#3: He bootstrapped Calendly for years before taking on a $350 million investment in 2021 that valued the firm at $3 billion.
About_#4: Born in Lagos, Nigeria, Awotona immigrated to the United States as a teenager.
In Their Own Words: "In my life, I've benefited from not taking the conventional wisdom. It's benefited me personally, and I think it has benefited the business."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, State University of Management
About_#1: Russia's wealthiest woman, Elena Baturina, is married to Yury Luzkhkov, who was the mayor of Moscow for years.
About_#2: In 2010, Luzhkov was removed from the mayor's post; Baturina and their daughters left the country.
About_#3: Baturina soon sold almost all of her assets in Russia including a construction company called Inteko and a cement factories.
About_#4: The Russian government seized land she owned in an exclusive area of Moscow. She filed a lawsuit, unsuccessfully demanding $1 billion in compensation.
Did You Know?: Baturina bought two commercial properties in Brooklyn near the Barclays Center in 2015.

About_#1: Sabrina Benetton is a daughter of Gilberto (d. 2018), one of four siblings who founded clothing retailer Benetton in 1965.
About_#2: She is on the board of the main family holding, Edizione Srl; she and her sister Barbara each inherited part of their father's fortune after he died.
About_#3: Initially Giuliana knitted sweaters, Luciano and Gilberto took care of sales and financials, and Carlo acted as the product manager.
About_#4: Benetton's colorful sweaters soon won over Italy, and the siblings expanded abroad with their first store in Paris in 1969.
Did You Know?: Sabrina studied at the exclusive Swiss boarding school Le Rosey.

Education: Master of Business Administration, University of Saarland
About_#1: Thomas Bruch inherited a stake in European retailer Globus, a family-owned company with roots dating back to 1828.
About_#2: Globus operates hypermarkets, DIY and electrical appliance stores, in Germany, Luxembourg, Russia and the Czech Republic.
About_#3: Bruch owns just over 48% of the company, with the rest held by family members, a family foundation and a charitable foundation.
About_#4: The charitable Globus Stiftung -- of which Bruch's wife, Graciela, is CEO -- holds just over 26% and will inherit Bruch's stake after his death.
Did You Know?: Globus Stiftung has supported more than 400 social projects with $10.5 million, ranging from building schools in Rwanda to helping Ebola patients in Sierra Leone.
In Their Own Words: Globus should live as a company that is constantly renewing itself from within.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, University of Toronto
About_#1: Marina Budiman is cofounder and president commissioner of data center company DCI Indonesia.
About_#2: She set up DCI in 2011 with Otto Toto Sugiri.
About_#3: She worked with Otto Toto Sugiri at Bank Bali in 1985 and joined Sigma Cipta Caraka in 1989.
About_#4: She cofounded Indonet, the first internet service provider in Indonesia, in 1994.
In Their Own Words: You will never get bored with the tech sector.

Education: Master of Philosophy, University of Cambridge; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Victoria
About_#1: Stewart Butterfield is the cofounder and CEO of team-based messaging software Slack.
About_#2: In July 2021, cloud software giant Salesforce acquired Slack for $27.7 billion in cash and stock.
About_#3: Slack, which debuted in June 2019 on the New York Stock Exchange via a direct listing, has over 156,000 paying customers.
About_#4: Though he leads a tech company, Butterfield proudly majored in philosophy as an undergraduate at Canada's University of Victoria.

About_#1: Richard Chang is vice chairman of Advanced Semiconductor Engineering.
About_#2: ASE is reportedly the world's largest provider of independent semiconductor assembling and test manufacturing services
About_#3: He and his brother Jason are the main investors in Chinese real estate developer, Sino Horizon.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Fudan University
About_#1: Chen Tianqiao is the founder, chairman and CEO of Shanda Investment Group, founded in 1999 by Chen and his family.
About_#2: Chen is credited with having pioneered and built the online game industry and the online literature industry in China.
About_#3: Chen stepped down as CEO of Shanda Interactive Entertainment in 2012 and then took the company private.
About_#4: Chen and his wife Chrissy are active philanthropists, supporting research programs on brain science.

About_#1: Chen Wenyuan chairs HYC Technology, a supplier of testing equipment for LCD, semiconductor and new energy electronics businesses.
About_#2: HYC listed on China's new STAR market for innovative companies on the Shanghai Stock Exchange on July 22, 2019
About_#3: His wife Zhang Qian cofounded the predecessor business of HYC in 2005.

Education: Diploma, China University of Technology
About_#1: Chin Jong Hwa is the controlling shareholder of Hong Kong-listed and China-based auto-parts supplier Minth, which he started in 1997.
About_#2: His daughter, Chin Chien Ya, is an executive director at Minth.
About_#3: In 2016, Minth Group became the first auto-parts maker to receive a permit from China to make electric cars.
About_#4: Chin stepped down from Minth's chairman and CEO in 2019. The company is now chaired by his wife Wei Ching Lien.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, National Chiao Tung University; Master, National Chiao Tung University
About_#1: Cho Jyh-jer retired as vice chairman at smartphone chipmaker MediaTek in 2015.
About_#2: He joined the firm in 1997 as its president when it was spun off from his then employer, United Microelectronics.
About_#3: The bulk of his wealth comes from his stake in MediaTek.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Central Missouri State University
About_#1: Jim Crane led an investment group that paid $615 million in 2011 for MLB's Houston Astros and a minority stake in a regional sports network.
About_#2: The value of the team has quadrupled since Crane's acquisition. Crane owns an estimated 40% stake.
About_#3: Crane pocketed more than $300 million when he sold his freight logistics firm Eagle Global Logistics to Apollo Global Management in 2007.
About_#4: Crane launched another logistics business, Crane Worldwide, in 2008; annual revenue is more than $900 million.

Education: Master of Science, Université de Caen Normandie; Ph.D, University Paris VI - Pierre et Marie Curie
About_#1: Thierry Cruanes is a cofounder and chief technology officer of Snowflake, a cloud-based database company.
About_#2: Cruanes started Snowflake with Benoit Dageville (a fellow billionaire) and Marcin Zukowski in 2012.
About_#3: Snowflake went public in September 2020 with a valuation of $3.9 billion, the largest software IPO in U.S. history.
About_#4: Cruanes and Dageville met while working at Oracle.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Université de Paris VI; Master of Science, Université de Paris VI; Ph.D, Université de Paris VI
About_#1: Benoit Dageville is president of products at Snowflake, the cloud-based database company he cofounded with Thierry Cruanes in 2012.
About_#2: The French-born computer science PhD got his start at Bull Information Systems before spending 16 years at Oracle in California's Bay Area.
About_#3: Dageville and Cruanes, both architects at Oracle, teamed up on a startup to store a company's data in the cloud to make it more easily usable.
About_#4: In September 2020, the San Mateo-based company went public as the largest software IPO in history.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, Berkeley
About_#1: Weili Dai cofounded semiconductor company Marvell Technology with her husband, Sehat Sutardja, in 1995.
About_#2: Dai was president of the company until she and Sutardja were forced out in 2016 amid an internal accounting investigation.
About_#3: No evidence of fraud was found in the Marvell accounting investigation.
About_#4: The couple moved to Las Vegas in 2017 and have been investing in real estate and technology.
Did You Know?: Dai played semi-professional basketball in Shanghai as a teen.
In Their Own Words: Most of the time, at best, I find that people follow their enthusiasms until they run out. Passion is a very different thing. Following your passion means a willingness to give everything you have every day.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: Tech entrepreneur Darwin Deason sold his Affiliated Computer Services to Xerox in 2010 for $6.4 billion.
About_#2: The day after he graduated high school, the Arkansas native moved to Tulsa, Oklahoma and got a job as a mail boy at Gulf Oil.
About_#3: Deason eventually joined Dallas data-processing firm MTech; he became its CEO at age 29 after all but his division failed. He sold it in 1988.
About_#4: Within days of sale, he started ACS to handle computer and other business process services for clients such as E-ZPass.
Did You Know?: Deason left his small town the day after he graduated high school, with $50 borrowed from his dad and a 1949 Pontiac.
In Their Own Words: I don't know of anyone who enjoys their success more than I do. There is little I do that I don't want to do, and little I don't do that I want to do.

About_#1: Diego Della Valle took the small shoe factory his grandfather started and turned it into global shoe- and purse-maker Tod's S.p.A.
About_#2: Della Valle, who is chairman, and his brother Andrea together own the majority of the company.
About_#3: The brothers also hold stakes in Italian scooter-maker Piaggio, multimedia conglomerate RCS MediaGroup and investment bank Mediobanca.
About_#4: The brothers owned Florence-based soccer team AC Fiorentina from 2002 to 2019, when they sold it to fellow billionaire Rocco Commisso.
Did You Know?: He has spearheaded a campaign to renovate the crumbling Roman Colosseum, committing millions of euros from Tod's for the project.

About_#1: Deng Yingzhong chairs Shenzhen-listed paper manufacturing company C &S Paper.
About_#2: He started his first business in the paper industry in 1979 at age 28 and founded the predecessor of C & S Paper in 1999.
About_#3: In February 2020, a C&S subsidiary was licensed to produce surgical masks in China in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak.

About_#1: Mark Dixon is the founder and CEO of IWG (formerly Regus), a flexible workplace provider.
About_#2: The son of a Ford engineer, Dixon dropped out of school at age 16 to start a business delivering sandwiches by bicycle.
About_#3: He held jobs as a logger and an encyclopedia salesman before founding IWG in 1989, after spotting businesspeople meeting around coffee tables.
About_#4: Now the company rents out meeting rooms, office space by the hour, virtual offices and space in co-working sites across more than 120 countries.
Did You Know?: Earlier in his career Dixon launched The Bread Roll Company to supply bread to food vendors after realizing it was hard to procure buns for hot dogs and hamburgers.
In Their Own Words: It is worth remembering that money isn't everything. People don't work for financial reward alone. For the great majority, it's about being recognized for the work you do.

About_#1: Du Shaunghua chairs Rizhao Steel Holding Group.
About_#2: Rizhao Steel Holding is one of China's largest private steel manufacturers.
About_#3: Du is a philanthropist whose donations have supported youth causes.

About_#1: Delhi-based Mukand Lal Dua and his younger brother Ramesh Kumar Dua, also a billionaire, get their wealth from a majority stake in Relaxo Footwears.
About_#2: The $323 million (revenue) company is known for affordable brands such as Sparx (sports shoes), Bahamas (flip flops) and Schoolmate (school shoes).
About_#3: The company has eight factories with the capacity to produce one million pairs a day.
About_#4: Dua's son, Nikhil, has a board seat in the company.

About_#1: Delhi-based Ramesh Kumar Dua and his brother Mukand Lal Dua, also a billionaire, get their wealth from a majority stake in Relaxo Footwears.
About_#2: The $323 million (revenue) company is known for affordable brands such as Sparx (sports shoes), Bahamas (flip flops) and Schoolmate (school shoes).
About_#3: Dua joined the family business of manufacturing bicycle parts and footwear in 1974. Today he runs the company as managing director.
About_#4: The company has eight factories with the capacity to produce one million pairs a day.
Did You Know?: Ramesh Kumar Dua is a London-trained rubber technologist.

About_#1: Fang Hongbo is the chairman of China's Midea, one of the world's largest makers of home appliances.
About_#2: Fang was born in a 10-family village in impoverished Anhui Province in central China.
About_#3: He was hired by Midea in 1992 to edit the company newsletter.

About_#1: William "Bill" Foley II founded title insurance company Fidelity National Financial in 1984 and still serves as its chairman.
About_#2: He also served as chairman of Black Knight, a software and data provider for the mortgage industry, and Fidelity National Information Services.
About_#3: With decades of experience overseeing acquisitions, sales and spinoffs of public companies, Foley was quick to capitalize on Wall Street's SPAC boom.
About_#4: A serial dealmaker, he has sponsored 6 blank-check companies; one that has gone public merged in March 2021 with payments firm Paysafe.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Fundacao Getulio Vargas; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Universidade de Sao Paulo
About_#1: Jayme Brasil Garfinkel is the biggest shareholder of Brazilian insurance giant Porto Seguro, with a 40% stake.
About_#2: He was 26 when his family bought the small business in 1972.
About_#3: Garfinkel took a prominent position in the family business after his father passed away in 1978, six years after he had acquired Porto Seguro.
About_#4: The company, one of the leading auto insurers in Brazil, went public in 2004. Garfinkel was CEO until 2012. He is now chairman of the board.
In Their Own Words: Business people are different from politicians. We do not face elections every four years. Business people face elections every single day. Tomorrow our clients have to vote for us.

Education: LLB, Calcutta University; M.Com, Calcutta University
About_#1: Radhe Shyam Goenka gets his wealth from his stake in consumer goods company Emami, which he cofounded with his buddy Radhe Shyam Agarwal.
About_#2: Emami's range of more than 300 products, including popular brands Zandu balm and antiseptic cream Boroplus, are sold through 4.5 million retail outlets.
About_#3: Goenka also has interests in real estate, edible oils and healthcare.
About_#4: In 2019, Goenka and Agarwal sold their privately held cement business to fellow billionaire Karsanbhai Patel's company for $730 million.
Did You Know?: Goenka and Agarwal were school friends who gave up corporate jobs to start Emami in 1974.

Education: Drop Out, West Virginia University
About_#1: Maggie Hardy Knox, formerly known as Maggie Magerko, is the owner of 84 Lumber, the largest privately-owned building materials suppliers in the U.S.
About_#2: Knox's father, Joe Hardy, founded the now $3.86 billion (2018 sales) company in 1956 in the rural town of Eighty Four, Pennsylvania.
About_#3: Hardy turned over the company to Knox, one of his four kids, in 1992 when she was just 26 years old. The company topped $1 billion in sales in 1993.
About_#4: 84 Lumber took a hit during the 2009 recession and Knox closed half of its 500 stores. Today the company operates nearly 250 stores in 30 states.
In Their Own Words: [You] always want to kind of please your parents ... I've always done that. But now, after coming out of those horrifying years, I now know who I really need to please is me.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Georgetown University
About_#1: Ayman Hariri is a son of the late Rafik Hariri, Lebanon's prime minister, who was assassinated while in office in 2005.
About_#2: He inherited a stake in his father's Saudi-based construction company Saudi Oger, and sold it to his brother Saad in 2014.
About_#3: In 2017, he sold his 42% stake in family holding company GroupeMed, which has interests in banking and real estate, for $535 million.
About_#4: He invests in startups through New York-based firm Red Sea Ventures; among its investments was smart thermostat Nest, now part of Google.

About_#1: Christoph Henkel is the vice chairman of Henkel AG's shareholders committee and founding partner of investment firm Canyon Equity.
About_#2: With brands like Persil, Schwarzkopf and Fa, and over $20 billion in annual revenue, Henkel is among the world's biggest cleaning product companies.
About_#3: After the death of his father Konrad in 1999, Christoph Henkel inherited his interest and became the largest single stockholder in the company.
About_#4: He also invests in tech, biotech and movie-production companies, and has real estate holdings in Europe and the U.S.
Did You Know?: Henkel co-founded Los Angeles-based production company Cineville; actors in its films have included Kevin Spacey, Sean Penn and Selma Hayek.
In Their Own Words: We were taught from early childhood that the family business comes before the family.

About_#1: Daniel Hirschfeld is chairman of Nebraska-based casual clothing retailer Buckle; he owns about a third of the company.
About_#2: Buckle has 440 stores in 42 U.S. states and sells clothing online as well, with denim accounting for 40% of sales in fiscal 2021.
About_#3: Hirschfeld's grandfather opened a men's clothing store in the early 1900s and his dad started the current business in 1948.
About_#4: Under Hirschfeld, the retailer turned its attention to denim and added women's clothing in the 1970s.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Emory University
About_#1: In 2012, William Hockey cofounded payments company Plaid, which helps other fintechs connect to customers' bank accounts.
About_#2: He met his cofounder Zach Perret while they were both working as junior consultants at Bain & Company.
About_#3: He stepped down as Plaid's chief technology officer in 2019, but he remains a board member.
About_#4: In early 2021, Visa's planned $5.3 billion acquisition of Plaid fell apart after the Department of Justice filed an antitrust lawsuit to block the deal.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Zhejiang University of Technology
About_#1: Huang Guanlin is an executive director of Shenzhou International Group, one of the world's largest suppliers of knitwear.
About_#2: Huang is responsible for overseeing production and marketing at Shenzhou.
About_#3: Huang is the brother-in-law of Ma Jianrong, Shenzhou's chairman.
About_#4: Huang holds a degree in chemical industry management and engineering from Zhejiang University of Technology.

About_#1: Huang Xiaofen is a major shareholder and a director of Shenzhen Kinwong Electronics.
About_#2: Her husband, Liu Shaobo, heads the company. He previously worked for a state-owned company in Shenzhen early in his career.
About_#3: Kinwong grew out of a joint venture backed by that government business.

About_#1: Even in a year without a tour or album release, Jay-Z mints millions from his Armand de Brignac champagne and D'Usse cognac.
About_#2: The Brooklyn-born rapper was crowned hip-hop's first billionaire in 2019, thanks to a sprawling and diversified empire.
About_#3: Jay-Z's assets range from entertainment company Roc Nation to a fine art collection including works by Jean-Michel Basquiat.
About_#4: Named after the housing project in which he grew up, his Marcy Venture Partners raised an $85 million fund in 2019.

About_#1: Jiang Yintai chairs auto parts maker Shanghai Daimay Automotive Interior.
About_#2: Daimay produces sun visors, seats and headrests, steering wheels and roof consoles.
About_#3: Customers include GM, Ford, Chrysler, Volkswagen, PSA and Great Wall.
About_#4: Jiang set up Daimay on the island of Daishan in the Chinese coastal city of Zhoushan in Zhejiang Province in 1982.

About_#1: Johan Johannson and his family own nearly 75% of NorgesGruppen, the Norwegian grocery store chain he inherited from his father and uncle.
About_#2: His father still oversees the company as chairman of the board; Jahon has no role in running the business.
About_#3: The company has been family run since it was founded in 1866.
About_#4: Norgesgruppen has more than 1,850 grocery stores and 650 convenience stores and nearly 40% market share in Norway.
Did You Know?: In 2012 the company vowed to reduce sugar sales by 10% by promoting more healthy alternatives. Between 2012 and 2017, sales of fruits and vegetables were up 28%.

About_#1: Ramesh Juneja and his younger brother Rajeev Juneja cofounded privately held Mankind Pharma in 1995.
About_#2: The company is a low-cost generics champion generating most of its $850 million in revenue in India.
About_#3: Private equity firms Capital International and ChrysCapital are key investors in Mankind.
About_#4: His U.K.-educated son Arjun heads international operations.
Did You Know?: Bollywood veteran Amitabh Bachchan is Mankind's brand ambassador.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, The University of Chicago; Master of Business Administration, The University of Chicago; Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Williams College
About_#1: Founder and CEO of HPS Investment Partners, one of the world's biggest alternative credit managers with $60 billion in assets.
About_#2: Kapnick spent 21 years at Goldman Sachs, rising to become co-head of investment banking and co-CEO of Goldman Sachs International.
About_#3: Left Goldman in 2007 to join hedge fund Highbridge Capital after its sale to JPMorgan, eventually building up its credit arm HPS.
About_#4: Kapnick was CEO of Higbhridge from 2013-to-2016, when he and the principals bought HPS from JPMorgan in a carveout. Assets have since swelled.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Novosibirsk State University
About_#1: Viktor Kharitonin created multinational pharmaceutical firm Pharmstandard with Roman Abramovich and others in 2003 by combining five factories.
About_#2: Kharitonin and his partner Egor Kulkov bought out their partners in 2008, a year after Pharmstandard went public in London.
About_#3: In 2016 Kharitonin and Kulkov took Pharmstandard private, buying out the shares and delisting from the London Stock Exchange.
Did You Know?: In October 2014 Kharitonin became co-owner of Nurbugring in Germany, one of the oldest race tracks in Europe.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Korea University
About_#1: Kim Jun-ki, founder of the Dongbu Group, stepped down as its chairman in September 2017 after being accused of rape and sexual harassment.
About_#2: In April 2020 Kim was convicted of the sexual assault charges and was sentenced to two and a half years in prison, which was suspended for four years.
About_#3: Dongbu, now named DB, has interests in steel, chemicals, finance, electronics and real estate.
About_#4: His net worth includes the shares of his only son, Kim Nam-ho, who is CEO and heir-apparent as well as his daughter.
Did You Know?: He started the company with two employees and the equivalent of $25,000.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Chosun University
About_#1: Kim Sang-yeol is founder and chairman of Hoban Construction, one of South Korea's top builders.
About_#2: Kim rose to billionaire status in 2019, after an internal merger more than doubled the net assets of his developer.
About_#3: Kim expanded Hoban during the 1997-1998 Asian financial crisis by snapping up properties when prices were at an all-time low.
About_#4: In an early plan for succession, his eldest son, Kim Dae-heon, was promoted to Hoban's vice president in 2019 and is now its largest shareholder.
Did You Know?: Kim was born to a poor farming family in the southern province of Jeolla.

About_#1: Christine Brigitte Knauf is an heir to one of the world's leading producers of building materials and systems, Knauf Gips KG.
About_#2: Based in Iphofen, Germany, the company employs more than 35,000 people around the world and has annual revenue of over $11 billion.
About_#3: Its product line includes plasterboards, cement boards and insulating materials.
About_#4: Knauf Gips dates to 1932, when brothers and mining engineers Alfons and Karl Knauf obtained rights to gypsum deposits in Schengen, Germany.

About_#1: Karl Knauf is an heir to one of the world's leading producers of building materials and systems, Knauf Gips KG.
About_#2: Based in Iphofen, Germany, the company employs more than 35,000 people around the world and has annual revenue of over $11 billion.
About_#3: Its product line includes plasterboards, cement boards and insulating materials.
About_#4: Knauf Gips traces its roots to 1932, when brothers and mining engineers Alfons and Karl Knauf obtained rights to gypsum deposits in Schengen, Germany.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Mumbai University; Master of Science in Engineering, University of Massachusetts
About_#1: Yogesh Kothari is chairman and managing director of Alkyl Amines Chemicals, a Mumbai specialty chemicals manufacturer.
About_#2: The $171 million (revenue) company was set up by him in 1979.
About_#3: Alkyl Amines supplies to the pharmaceutical, agrochemical and rubber chemical industries.
About_#4: His older brother Hemendra Kothari is a veteran investment banker and also a billionaire.

About_#1: Kurt Krieger purchased Hoeffner Group in 1967 and turned it into one of Germany's leading furniture retailers.
About_#2: After the fall of the Berlin wall in 1989, he seized the opportunity to tap into new markets in eastern Germany.
About_#3: Besides Hoeffner Group, Krieger owns real estate in his hometown Berlin, having acquired almost 100 acres in 2010.
About_#4: He's planning a development project with schools, shopping centers and, of course, a furniture store in the northern part of the city.
Did You Know?: In his youth, Krieger wanted to become a musician. He still plays the piano today.

About_#1: Mustafa Kucuk is the biggest shareholder of LC Waikiki, a producer and retailer of ready-to-wear fashions and home items.
About_#2: Designer Georges Amouyal and a partner founded LC Waikiki in France in 1985. Kucuk and partners including Sefik Yilmaz Dizdar acquired it in 1997.
About_#3: LC Waikiki's first international store opened in Romania in 2009. In 2016, it expanded into home textile products under the brand name LCW Home.
About_#4: The company prides itself on promoting women into its management ranks.
Did You Know?: The brand combines the name of the famous Hawaiian beach with "LC," as in "Les Copains" ("friends" in French).

Education: London School of Economics; Master, University of Poznan
About_#1: Sebastian and his sister Dominika inherited a fortune from their father Jan, who died in 2015 from complications of minor heart surgery.
About_#2: In 2018, the siblings divvied up assets, with Sebastian getting a stake in Autostrada Eksploatacja, which maintains a major highway.
About_#3: He also took over the chemical business Ciech and shares in mining companies, the latter of which he sold.
About_#4: Sebastian also founded and runs VC tech fund Manta Ray.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Stanford Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania
About_#1: Gary Lauder's fortune stems from Estée Lauder, the cosmetics giant founded by his grandmother.
About_#2: His father Leonard ran the family's publicly traded company for more than three decades and stepped down as CEO in 1999.
About_#3: Lauder, who is not involved with the family company, is managing director of Lauder Partners LLC, a Silicon Valley-based venture capital firm.
About_#4: A venture capitalist since 1985, he has invested in over 60 private companies.

Education: Doctorate, Princeton; Bachelor of Science, University of Washington
About_#1: Art Levinson has been chairman of the board of Apple since 2011; he owns more shares of Apple than CEO Tim Cook.
About_#2: He was the CEO of successful biotech firm Genentech from 1995 to 2009 and served as its chairman from 1999 to 2014.
About_#3: Levinson was also on the board of Google from 2004 to 2009. A few years later, he was named CEO of Calico, a health company created by Google.
About_#4: He has authored or co-authored dozens of scientific papers and been named an inventor on 11 U.S. patents.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, National Chung Hsing University
About_#1: Lin cofounded lens supplier Largan Precision with Tony Chen in 1987.
About_#2: The company is a leading smartphone lens maker and a major supplier to Apple, claiming a quarter of the global market.
About_#3: Largan is now run by his sons, Adam and En-Chou.

About_#1: Jenny Lindén Urnes is the chairman and owner of $1.9 billion (sales) Lindéngruppen, which she inherited from her father in 2009.
About_#2: The industrial group owns 50% of Höganäs AB, a leading maker of powdered metal, and Beckers, which produces industrial coatings.
About_#3: Her father, Ulf G. Lindén, a former Volvo executive, built up a private stake in Höganäs AB, and took it private in 1987.
About_#4: Beckers, a former subsidiary of Volvo, came into the family's hands in 1985, when Ulf bought the company from his employer.
Did You Know?: Höganäs AB has a one third market share of the world's powdered metals, a product used in construction of metal parts and to remove contaminants from drinking water.

Education: Masters in Finance, Moscow Institute of International Relations
About_#1: Anatoly Lomakin started out trading chemicals and sharing an office with future billionaire Vladimir Potanin.
About_#2: In 1992 he persuaded three of the largest post-Soviet producers of fertilizer--Silvinit, Uralkali and Belaruskali--to unite.
About_#3: In 2010 Lomakin and his partners sold their stakes in Silvinit, Russia's second-largest producer of potassium fertilizer, for roughly $3 billion.
About_#4: Today Lomakin owns 50% of Investstroy, a company that invests in housing and residential property development.
Did You Know?: Anatoly Lomakin became a Yedinaya Rossiya party deputy in Russia's State Duma in 2012 but stepped down less than a year later, citing health problems.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Denver
About_#1: Jeffrey Lorberbaum built Georgia-based Mohawk Industries into the largest flooring company in the world; he owns a nearly 15% stake.
About_#2: His father Alan founded Aladdin Mills in 1957 as a maker of bath mats; Lorberbaum joined the company in 1976 and later became CEO.
About_#3: In 1994, the family sold Aladdin to Mohawk Industries. Lorberbaum took charge of Mohawk in 2001 and expanded into hard-surface flooring.
About_#4: The publicly-traded flooring company is now in more than 170 countries and has completed 45 acquisitions since it went public in 1992.

Education: Drop Out, Western State College of Colorado
About_#1: Gary Magness's late father, Bob, started cable giant TCI, then merged with AT&T in 1999 in a $48 billion deal.
About_#2: He inherited half of the fortune (his late brother, Kim, got the rest) and now focuses on off-road racing, movie producing and philanthropy.
About_#3: He collects vintage cars, owns cattle ranches in Colorado, a data center, fish and palm tree farms and invests in oil, gas and real estate.
About_#4: His wife, Sarah Siegel-Magness, runs the couple's film company, Smokewood Entertainment, which produced the Oscar winning "Precious."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, National University of Singapore
About_#1: Mao Zhongwu is a director of the Sany Group, a construction equipment manufacturer.
About_#2: Mao is one of three billionaires from Sany Group including Liang Wengen and Xiang Wenbo.
About_#3: Mao resigned as a director at Sany International in October 2019.

About_#1: A former gold miner, Ilson Mateus built up supermarket chain Grupo Mateus and took it public in October 2020.
About_#2: The company is controlled by Mateus and his ex-wife, Maria Barros Pinheiro, who is a former billionaire.
About_#3: Now Brazil's fourth-biggest food retailer, Grupo Mateus operates 137 stores throughout the country's northern and northeastern regions.
About_#4: Grupo Mateus had revenues of $1.4 billion in 2019 and employs more than 29,000 workers in several Brazilian states.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Moscow Institute of Radioengineering, Electronics and Automation
About_#1: Vadim Moshkovich is chairman of agro-industrial firm Rusagro, a big manufacturer of pork and sugar.
About_#2: Moshkovich was sanctioned by the EU in March.
About_#3: He started out selling apartments, vodka and oil in the early 1990s.
About_#4: He later invested in land and created Rusagro.

About_#1: Jerry Moyes and his father founded Swift Transportation in 1966 with one truck, moving cotton and imported steel between Arizona and California
About_#2: Swift grew to nearly 20,000 trucks and some $4 billion in annual revenue before it merged with Knight Transportation in 2017.
About_#3: Moyes owns nearly a quarter of the merged company, called Knight-Swift Transportation.
About_#4: He stepped down as chairman of Swift in 2016, after 50 years in the business.
Did You Know?: Moyes resigned as Swift CEO in 2005 after an insider-trading case (he did not admit to wrongdoing). Two years later, he took Swift private in a leveraged buyout.

Education: Chartered Accountant, Institute of Chartered Accountants of India; Bachelor of Commerce, University of Kerala
About_#1: With his two brothers, George Alexander Muthoot runs Muthoot Finance, India's biggest lender against gold.
About_#2: The Muthoot Group was founded by his grandfather in 1887 as a trader in timber and food grains, supplying rations to large British-run plantations.
About_#3: The company has 5,400 branches across India and serves more than 200,000 customers daily.
About_#4: For the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021, the company reported a 21% rise in net profit to $522 million, partly due to higher online transactions.
Did You Know?: Muthoot is currently the president of the Association of Gold Loan Companies in India.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Manipal University
About_#1: With his two brothers, George Jacob Muthoot runs Muthoot Finance, India's biggest lender against gold.
About_#2: The Muthoot Group was founded by his grandfather in 1887 as a trader in timber and food grains, supplying rations to large British-run plantations.
About_#3: The company has 5,400 branches across India and serves more than 200,000 customers daily.
About_#4: For the fiscal year ended March 31, 2021, the company reported a 21% rise in net profit to $522 million, partly due to higher online transactions.
Did You Know?: Muthoot is a civil engineer by training.

About_#1: With his two brothers, George Thomas Muthoot runs Muthoot Finance, India's biggest lender against gold.
About_#2: The Muthoot Group was founded by his grandfather in 1887 as a trader in timber and food grains, supplying rations to large British-run plantations.
About_#3: The company has 5,400 branches across India and serves more than 200,000 customers daily.
About_#4: For the fiscal year ended March 2021, the company reported a 21% rise in net profit to $522 million, partly due to higher online transactions

Education: Bachelor of Science, University of Kerala; Master of Science, University of Kerala
About_#1: Sara George Muthoot inherited a stake in listed gold finance company Muthoot Finance after her husband M.G. George Muthoot passed away in 2021.
About_#2: The Muthoot Group was founded by M.G. George Muthoot's grandfather in 1887 as a trader in timber and food grains, supplying rations to large British-run plantations.
About_#3: The company has 5,400 branches across India and serves more than 200,000 customers daily.
About_#4: For the fiscal year ended March 2021, the company reported a 21% rise in net profit to $522 million, partly due to higher online transactions.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Hebrew University, Jerusalem
About_#1: Marius Nacht wrote the original code for cybersecurity firm Check Point Software Technologies, which made him and cofounder Gil Shwed billionaires.
About_#2: In 2021 he sold the remainder of his stake in Check Point, netting an estimated $491 million.
About_#3: He served as vice chairman of Check Point from 2001 until he was appointed non-executive chairman of the board in September 2015.
About_#4: Nacht cofounded aMoon, an Israeli healthtech VC firm, in 2016; it raised $400 million from investors in the spring of 2018.
Did You Know?: Nacht is a veteran of Talpiot, an elite division of the Israeli army.

Education: City University of New York Baruch
About_#1: Adam Neumann cofounded coworking firm WeWork; he resigned as CEO in September 2019 shortly before the company canceled a planned IPO.
About_#2: After the failed IPO, new leadership led WeWork to sell some of its assets, including a wave pool business it had acquired.
About_#3: WeWork ultimately went public, in October 2021, by merging with blank check company BowX Acquisition Corp.
About_#4: Neumann owns a nearly 10% stake in the public company, after having sold nearly $1 billion worth of his WeWork shares while the business was private.
Did You Know?: Before WeWork, Neumann ran a business that made baby overalls with built-in knee pads.

Education: Drop Out, Nottingham University
About_#1: Simon Nixon earned the bulk of his fortune from his price-comparison website MoneySuperMarket.
About_#2: He cofounded the company in 1993, took it public in 2007, and sold all his shares in it by 2016.
About_#3: Nixon has invested in dozens of private companies, including--before they went public--Airbnb, Robinhood and Wise (formerly called Transferwise).
About_#4: He also owns luxury homes around the globe, including in Malibu and Barbados, which he lists for private holiday rentals on his site, SimonEscapes.
Did You Know?: In 2013, Nixon moved from Chester, England, to tax haven Jersey, where he owns a multi-million dollar home.

About_#1: Stefan Olsson is a part owner of Stena Sphere, a privately held Swedish conglomerate.
About_#2: Interests include cruising, shipping, offshore drilling, property and metal recycling.
About_#3: Stena was founded in 1939 as a trading company by Stefan's father, Sten.
About_#4: His brother Dan took over in 1983 and now owns 51% of the company. Stefan and his sister Madeleine Olsson Eriksson own 24.5% and 12.5%, respectively.
Did You Know?: Olsson is a catholic priest.

About_#1: Medical doctor Ranjan Pai controls Manipal Group, an education and healthcare empire with six colleges and 27 hospitals.
About_#2: Pai's Manipal University has overseas campuses in Malaysia, Antigua, Dubai and Nepal.
About_#3: Pai also has interests in stem cell research and student hostels.
About_#4: Pai acquired a 51% stake in Cigna TTK Health Insurance and renamed it as Manipal Cigna Health Insurance.
Did You Know?: The Manipal Group was started in 1953 by his grandfather who founded India's first privately-owned medical school in the town of Manipal in Karnataka.
In Their Own Words: An entrepreneur does not have to go to the investor who writes the biggest cheque, or gives the highest valuation.

About_#1: Antonio Percassi is a real estate and retail mogul with properties in Italy and the United States.
About_#2: Percassi's older brothers founded a real estate company in the 1960s, and he branched out into commercial real estate in the 1980s.
About_#3: Percassi got his start in retail when he met fellow billionaire Luciano Benetton in 1976, and went on to manage stores for the Benetton fashion brand.
About_#4: Percassi brought Zara to Italy in 2001 and opened the first Starbucks store in Milan in 2018.
Did You Know?: Percassi owns a stake in his hometown soccer club, Atalanta Calcio, and played for the team from age 17 to 23.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pennsylvania
About_#1: Mark Pincus cofounded Zynga, an online social game maker known for Words With Friends, Mafia Wars and FarmVille; he owns 7% of Zynga.
About_#2: A serial entrepreneur who made early investments in Facebook and Twitter, Pincus launched several successful websites before creating Zynga in 2007.
About_#3: Pincus served as CEO of Zynga from 2007 to July 2013 and again from April 2015 through March 2016. He's currently chairman of the board.
About_#4: In 2018 he founded investment firm Reinvent Capital, which has put money into SpaceX, health insurance firm Oscar and rideshare firm Lyft.
Did You Know?: Zynga is named after Pincus' late dog, Zinga, an American Bulldog. The company's red and white logo is a rendering of the bulldog.

Education: Master of Science, The National Research University Higher School of Economics
About_#1: Alexey Repik is founder of R-Pharm, one of Russia's largest pharmaceutical companies and one of the biggest state contractors.
About_#2: In 2017 Mitsui & Co., Ltd. acquired 10% shares of R-Pharm for $200 million.
About_#3: Repik started R-Pharm in 2001 with $40,000 in startup capital, half of which came from his mother.
About_#4: Repik got his first job in healthcare in 1995.
Did You Know?: Repik is president of the Russian Business Association 'Delovaya Rossiya' ('Business Russia'), which unites more than 3,000 entrepreneurs.
In Their Own Words: "I have no plane; I have no yacht; not even an island, that's what is the most pity."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Lake Forest College
About_#1: Roszak is cofounder and chairman of Bloq, a blockchain technology startup that consults on projects such as helping banks store digital assets.
About_#2: Bloq also helps companies that are trying to process transactions for "stablecoins," or cryptocurrencies pegged to the value of a fiat currency.
About_#3: In the 1990s and early 2000s, Roszak worked in VC and as an entrepreneur before amassing a crypto portfolio starting in 2012.
About_#4: He settled insider trading charges in 2006 related to stock purchases of Blue Rhino, a propane tank exchange business.

Education: Chartered Accountant, Institute of Chartered Accountants of India; B.Com, Pune University
About_#1: Mumbai property tycoon Subhash Runwal chairs the Runwal Group, known for building middle class homes in the city's central suburbs.
About_#2: It also owns several malls and counts the Singapore government's GIC as a key investor in that business.
About_#3: A trained accountant, Runwal was born in a small town in Maharashtra and migrated to Mumbai at age 21.
About_#4: He worked as an accountant for nearly a decade before taking the plunge into real estate in 1978.
Did You Know?: Runwal's lives in a sea-front home in Mumbai next to Bollywood star Shah Rukh Khan.
In Their Own Words: My projects never get stuck for approvals. Nothing is impossible.

About_#1: Carlos Sanchez owns and runs privately-held generic drug firm EMS S.A., which was founded by his late father.
About_#2: EMS S.A. sells prescription, generic, branded generic and over-the-counter products.
About_#3: In recent years, the company has benefited from adding drugs including generic versions of Viagra and Lipitor to its sales arsenal.
About_#4: EMS was founded by Sanchez' father, Emiliano, in 1950 as a small pharmacy. Sanchez inherited EMS at age 26 when his father died.
In Their Own Words: The pharmaceutical industry in Brazil is world class.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Washington
About_#1: Martin Selig is one of the biggest property developers in Seattle.
About_#2: Selig owns more than 4 million square feet of office space in the city and has at least 1 million more under development.
About_#3: Selig fled Nazi Germany with his family when he was age 3 and traveled through Poland, Russia and Korea until arriving by boat in Seattle.
About_#4: Selig started working at his father's linen store in Seattle when he was eleven years old.
Did You Know?: One of his daughters is a film producer.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology
About_#1: Bhadresh Shah founded and runs AIA Engineering, a niche metallurgical company in Ahmedabad city.
About_#2: Shah started a small foundry in 1978 and parlayed it into a $392 million (revenue) company.
About_#3: AIA is the world's second largest manufacturer of high chromium grinding parts (by sales) for the cement, mining and power industries.
About_#4: Shah is a metallurgy engineer from the premier Indian Institute of Technology (Kanpur).
Did You Know?: Shah hails from a family of doctors but chose to study engineering rather than medicine.

About_#1: Shu Ping is director and one of the founders of Chinese hot pot chain Haidilao International Holdings.
About_#2: Shu is the wife of Zhang Yong, the chairman of Haidilao.
About_#3: Haidilao cofounders Shu, Zhang Yong, Shi Yonghong and Li Haiyan set up their first restaurant with personal savings in 1994.
About_#4: Shu helps oversee Haidilao's management and strategic development.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: Ben Silbermann is cofounder and the CEO of the photo bookmarking site Pinterest, which went public in April 2019.
About_#2: Silbermann owns a 38% stake in the company, which had 454 million users worldwide as of June 2021.
About_#3: Silbermann, along with cofounders Evan Sharp and Paul Sciarra, launched the first desktop version of Pinterest in March 2010.
About_#4: Pinterest lets users save and share image collections from recipes to hairstyles to crafts and home decor through their mobile phones or computers.
Did You Know?: Ben Silbermann grew up in Iowa and collected dried insects which he then would pin on cardboard.
In Their Own Words: "I hope Pinterest is my last job. I don't think there are a lot of tools at scale that let you indulge in who you want to be."

Education: Bachelor of Science, London School of Economics
About_#1: Jared Smith is president of Utah-based cloud computing company Qualtrics.
About_#2: He cofounded the company in Provo, Utah in 2002 with his brother, Ryan, and father, Scott; Ryan was the CEO.
About_#3: Three days before its scheduled IPO in January 2019, Qualtrics was acquired by German software firm SAP for $8 billion in cash.
About_#4: Jared owned about 14% of the company at the time of the sale.

About_#1: Denis Sverdlov is the founder and CEO of electric vehicle startup Arrival.
About_#2: Sverdlov founded Arrival in 2015, using capital from the sale of Russian phone maker Yota in 2012.
About_#3: Arrival makes lightweight, zero-emission vans at a competitive price to diesel- and gasoline-powered vehicles.
About_#4: He took Arrival public on the Nasdaq, via a merger with a SPAC, in March 2021.

About_#1: Prachak Tangkaravakoon chairs $566 million (revenue) TOA Paint (Thailand), the country's biggest paint company with a market share of 49%.
About_#2: TOA Paint has three plants in Thailand, plus factories in Vietnam, Laos, Myanmar, Malaysia, Cambodia and Indonesia.
About_#3: The company's IPO in 2017 raised $360 million to ramp up regional expansion, including in Myanmar and Cambodia.
