About_#4: His son Vonnarat became a billionaire after the backdoor listing of his cable and wire firm Stark Corporation, in 2019.
Did You Know?: In 1964, Prachak expanded the family's hardware business into paint supplies, opening the first paint factory in 1972.

About_#1: Lina Tombolato is the widow of Ennio Doris, the former chairman of Italian bank Banca Mediolanum, who died at 81 in November 2021.
About_#2: She and her two children, Mediolanum CEO Massimo and vice president Annalisa, own 40% of the bank, which has 108 billion euros in assets under administration.
About_#3: She and Ennio were both born in the small northern Italian town of Tombolo and were married for 55 years.

About_#1: Luiza Helena Trajano is chairman of retailer Magazine Luiza, which has nearly 1,000 stores in Brazil and a booming e-commerce arm.
About_#2: She owns a bit more than 17% of the Sao Paulo-listed firm, which her parents founded in 1957 and named after her mother (also named Luiza).
About_#3: Trajano was hired as an apprentice by her parents at age 18, working in different roles until she became CEO in 1991.
About_#4: She led Magazine Luiza's expansion into online sales, a fast growing part of the business that now accounts for nearly 40% of revenues.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: John Van Lieshout founded and made his fortune from the Super A-Mart furniture chain. He sold it in 2006 but retained the freehold to some stores.
About_#2: His wealth is now underpinned by a large property portfolio that includes shopping malls and offices.
About_#3: He also owns the Unison Projects Group, which has property interests in tourism, residential, industrial and commercial assets.
About_#4: He arrived in Australia in 1960 with his parents and 12 siblings, emigrating from the Netherlands.

About_#1: Vardis J. Vardinoyannis co-founded Motor Oil Hellas, a petroleum company based in Greece, with his late brother in 1970.
About_#2: It went public on the Athens stock exchange in August 2001. Saudi Arabia's Aramco was a major investor before divesting in 2005.
About_#3: Vardis's oldest son, John, is vice chairman while nephew, Nikos, is also a major shareholder.
About_#4: Vardinoyannis is also reported to be the owner of Vegas Oil and Gas in Egypt.
Did You Know?: Vardinoyannis served a number of years in the Greek Naval Forces before being discharged with the grade of Vice-Admiral.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Stockholm University
About_#1: Jens von Bahr cofounded publicly traded casino supplier Evolution AB with Fredrik Österberg in 2006.
About_#2: He was CEO of Evolutions until 2016 and is now chairman of the company, which primarily sells live-streamed tables of blackjack, poker, craps and roulette to online gambling operators.
About_#3: The company went public in Stockholm in 2015 and now provides its services to over 600 gambling sites in 21 countries.
About_#4: Evolution's first casino studio was set up in Riga, Lithuania. Today the company has live-casino studios in nine countries, including the U.S.

About_#1: Wang Jian is the president of BGI, one of Asia's largest genomics companies.
About_#2: Wang worked as a senior research fellow at the University of Washington between 1990 and 1994.
About_#3: Wang Jian graduated from Central South University and holds a master's degree from Beijing University of Chinese Medicine.
About_#4: After graduation, he performed postdoctoral research at the University of Texas and the University of Iowa from 1988 to 1990.

About_#1: Werner O. Weber holds just over half of publicly-traded LEM, a Swiss manufacturer of current and voltage transducers that measure electricity.
About_#2: Founded in 1972, LEM has been listed on the SIX Swiss Exchange since 1986.
About_#3: It has production plants in Beijing, China; Geneva, Switzerland; Machida, Japan, and Sofia, Bulgaria.
About_#4: Weber also has a sizable stake in Zug Estates Holding, a Swiss real estate developer.

About_#1: David and Drorit Wertheim are the children of the late Moshe Wertheim (d. 2016) who founded the Central Bottling Company, Israel's only Coca Cola bottler.
About_#2: Before he died, Moshe Wertheim gave his children ownership over the company, as well as his shares in Mizrahi Tefahot Bank and Alony Hetz.
About_#3: In 2018, David purchased all of his sister's shares in Alony Hetz, then sold them because of Israeli anti-monopoly rules.
About_#4: In 2019, the siblings became majority shareholders in Mizrahi Tefahot bank.

Education: Waseda University
About_#1: Wu is the founder of Shin Kong Financial, one of Taiwan's largest private-sector financial companies.
About_#2: Wu stepped down as the firm's chairman in June 2020, after 18 years at the helm.
About_#3: A third brother, Thomas, runs an unrelated financial-services firm, Taishin Financial, and is also a billionaire.
About_#4: Eugene Wu's late father, Wu Ho-Su, built a fortune in trading and textiles starting in the 1940s.

About_#1: Wu Xushun is the cofounder and a director of Wuhu Shunrong Sanqi Interactive Entertainment Network Technology in China.
About_#2: Wuhu Shunrong Auto Parts, which is listed on the Shenzhen stock exchange, acquired 60% of Sanqi Interactive Entertainment Shanghai Technology in 2014.
About_#3: Following the acquisition, Wuhu Shunrong Auto Parts was rebranded as Wuhu Shunrong Sanqi Interactive Entertainment Network Technology.
About_#4: Wu dropped out of school after he finished middle high school in 1963. He was once a government official in Xitan in Nanling County in Anhui Province.

Education: Master of Science, Dalian University of Technology
About_#1: Xiang Wenbo is vice chairman of Sany Group, a heavy equipment manufacturer.
About_#2: Xiang is one of three billionaires from Sany Group, along with Liang Wengen and Mao Zhongwu.
About_#3: Xiang is a graduate of Dalian University of Technology with a master's degree in molding.

About_#1: Swift Xie heads up marketing at Dajiang Innovation Technology Co. (DJI), the world's largest consumer drone manufacturer.
About_#2: Xie is the high school best friend of DJI founder and CEO Frank Wang, who nicknamed him "fat-headed fish."
About_#3: Xie owns an estimated 12% stake in DJI.

Education: Medical Doctor, Columbia University; Ph.D, Columbia University
About_#1: George Yancopoulos is the chief scientific officer of biotech firm Regeneron.
About_#2: He received his M.D. and Ph.D. from Columbia University and became a professor of biology by age 28.
About_#3: Regeneron was cofounded by now-billionaire Leonard Schleifer in 1988. Yancopoulos joined the next year.
About_#4: Yancopoulos led the invention of seven approved drugs and a technology platform designed to invent more.
Did You Know?: Yancopoulos was the first pharmaceutical research chief to become a billionaire.
In Their Own Words: I think we do discovery differently and better. And I think part of it is we've really learned how to brainstorm and think inventively in a group.

Source of Wealth: precious metals, real estate, Self Made
About_#1: Gavril Yushvaev has gotten rich betting on a wide assortment of businesses.
About_#2: In the early 1990s Yushvaev cofounded Trinity, which owned Moscow dance club Metelitsa, one of the city's first casinos, and car dealerships.
About_#3: He later invested in dairy and juice company Wimm-Bill-Dann, which went public in 2002.
About_#4: Yushvaev sold his 19.6% stake in Wimm-Bill-Dann to Pepsico for $1.1 billion in 2010.
Did You Know?: Wimm-Bill-Dann's prospectus for its 2002 IPO revealed that Yushvaev served nine years in a Soviet prison camp after being found guilty of a "violent crime" in 1980.

About_#1: Zhuo Jun took over a controlling stake of Shenzhen Kinwong Electronics in November 2013 when her husband, Shen Jitang, passed away.
About_#2: Zhuo sits on the board of the Shenzhen electronics manufacturing giant. Her younger brother Zhuo Yong serves as vice chairman.
About_#3: She was a clerk at Heung Yee Kuk, a statutory advisory body representing interests in the New Territories, Hong Kong, for 4 years after high school.

Education: Bachelor of Business Administration, Stockholm University, Business economics, marketing/management
About_#1: Fredrik Österberg cofounded Evolution AB with Jens von Bahr in 2006.
About_#2: Evolution sells casino solutions to online gambling operators, primarily live-streamed tables of blackjack, poker, craps and roulette.
About_#3: Evolution's first casino studio was set up in Riga, Lithuania in 2006. Today the company has live-casino studios in nine countries, including the U.S.
About_#4: The company went public in Stockholm in 2015 and today provides its services to over 600 gambling sites in 21 countries.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, Universidad Complutense de Madrid
About_#1: Cousins Alberto Alcocer and Alberto Cortina married sisters Esther and Alicia Koplowitz, heiresses to one of the largest construction firms in Spain.
About_#2: The cousins, dubbed Los Albertos, ran their wives' Construcciones y Contratas firm from the early 1970s until 1989, when both marriages fell apart.
About_#3: Alcocer and Cortina then moved into banking, running Banco Zaragozano. They sold their combined 40% stake to Barclays in 2004
About_#4: Each of the cousins indirectly own stakes in Grupo Empresarial ENCE, the largest eucalyptus pulp producer in Europe.
Did You Know?: Alcocer owns several ranches in Cadiz and Toledo, Spain, along with houses in Paris and Madrid.

About_#1: Alexandra Andresen and her sister Katharina, one year her senior, each inherited 42% of the family-owned investment company Ferd.
About_#2: Andresen's father Johan still runs the company and controls 70% of the votes via a dual-class share structure.
About_#3: Ferd runs hedge funds, is an active investor on the Nordic stock exchange, and has private equity investments.
Did You Know?: Alexandra is a three-time junior Norwegian champion in dressage riding.

About_#1: Katharina Andresen, born 1995, is one of the world's youngest billionaires.
About_#2: She and her sister Alexandra, one year her junior, each inherited 42% of the family-owned investment company Ferd.
About_#3: The sisters' father Johan still runs the company and controls 70% of the votes via a dual-class share structure.
About_#4: Ferd runs hedge funds, is an active investor on the Nordic stock exchange, and has private equity investments.
Did You Know?: In 2017 Katharina was stopped by police at tony ski resort Hafjell and was found to be driving under the influence and was eventually fined $32,000.

Education: Master of Economics, Lund University
About_#1: Rutger Arnhult owns large stakes in Swedish real estate companies, Castellum, Sagax and Corem Property, the latter owns 500 properties including five in Manhattan.
About_#2: Arnhult founded, and listed, office and warehouse company Corem Property in 2007, via a reverse takeover.
About_#3: Since then, Arhult has built up a large and complex portfolio of cross-owned holdings in more than a dozen publicly traded real estate companies.
About_#4: His wife Eva Landén is the CEO of Corem, while Arnhult heads the more office-centered Castellum.

About_#1: Thai property tycoon Anant Asavabhokin's biggest asset is a stake in SET-listed Land And Houses.
About_#2: He founded the company with his mother, Piangjai Harnpanij, in 1983. The company is known for its focus on semi-detached houses.
About_#3: The Covid-19 pandemic hit the company's rental income but saw an increase in the sale of semi-detached houses and townhouses.
About_#4: In 2021, the company acquired SpringHill Suites by Marriott, a 120-rooom hotel in California for $31 million.

About_#1: Mehmet Ali Aydinlar is founder and leader of Turkey's largest chain of private hospitals, Acibadem Healthcare Group.
About_#2: He build the company after starting out as a consultant in the same field, took it public in 2000, and brought in a partner, Abraaj Capital, in 2008.
About_#3: The company was delisted in 2012, after Aydinlar struck a deal with Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund and Kuala Lumpur-based IHH Healthcare Berhad.
About_#4: Aydinlar exchanged Acibadem shares for cash and stock in IHH. He still owns 10% of Acibadem and serves as chairman of its board of directors.
Did You Know?: Aydinlar has been buying real estate since his days as a consultant for hire. In 2019, he was named Entrepreneur of the Year in Turkey by Ernst & Young.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology
About_#1: Former Amazon executive Binny Bansal teamed up with pal Sachin Bansal in 2007 to found Flipkart as an online seller of books.
About_#2: The duo, who share the same surname but are not related, pooled $6,000 of their combined savings and started operating out of their apartment.
About_#3: In 2018, Walmart bought a 77% stake in Flipkart for $16 billion in what was reportedly the world's biggest deal for an internet firm.
About_#4: Bansal pared his stake in Flipkart in 2022. He now owns about 2% of the online retailer and has a board seat.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Indian Institute of Technology
About_#1: Former Amazon executive, Sachin Bansal, teamed up with pal Binny Bansal, also a billionaire, in 2007 to found Flipkart as an online seller of books.
About_#2: The duo, who share the same surname but are not related, pooled $6,000 of their combined savings and started operating out of their apartment.
About_#3: In 2018, Wal-Mart bought a 77% stake in Flipkart for $16 billion in what was the world's biggest deal for an internet firm.
About_#4: Bansal cashed out, selling his minority stake for $1 billion.
Did You Know?: Bansal is an online gaming enthusiast.

About_#1: Barbara Benetton is one of two daughters of Gilberto Benetton, who founded the Benetton Group in 1965 with siblings Carlo, Gilberto and Giuliana.
About_#2: In 2018, with the death of their father, Barbara and her sister Sabrina each inherited part of his fortune; Barbara is not involved in the business.
About_#3: The Benetton family started knitting and selling colorful sweaters from their home in Treviso, Italy and opened their first store abroad in 1969.
About_#4: The four siblings later diversified their portfolio, and now own investments in infrastructure, catering, and financial firms.

Education: Diploma, Ecole Polytechnique de Lausanne
About_#1: Othman Benjelloun is CEO of BMCE Bank of Africa, which has a presence in more than 20 African countries.
About_#2: His father was a shareholder in RMA, a Moroccan insurance company; Benjelloun built it into a leading insurer.
About_#3: Through his holding company FinanceCom, he has a stake in the Moroccan arm of French telecom firm Orange.
About_#4: He inaugurated in 2014 a $500 million plan to build the 55-story Mohammed VI Tower in Rabat. It will be one of the tallest buildings in Africa.
Did You Know?: He co-owns Ranch Adarouch, one of the biggest cattle breeders in Africa.

About_#1: Angela Bennett's wellspring of wealth is her share of a royalty paid by mining giant Rio Tinto on every ton of iron ore it mines in Western Australia.
About_#2: The royalty was negotiated by her father, Peter Wright, and his partner, Lang Hancock, father of fellow Western Australian billionaire Gina Rinehart.
About_#3: Bennett holds a major stake in Wright Prospecting, which is in litigation with Rinehart's Hancock Prospecting over various iron-ore properties.
About_#4: In 2009 Bennett sold her Mosman Park mansion in Perth for A$57.5 million, an Australian record then and still a Western Australian record.

Education: Master of Science, Moscow Aviation University; Master of Business Administration, Russian National Academy of National Economy and Public Administration
About_#1: Oleg Boyko's private equity firm Finstar Financial currently manages and consults portfolio companies operating in 30+ countries.
About_#2: After Russia invaded Ukraine, his mother who held all of his shares in fintech 4Finance gave 9.9% each to Ukrainian relatives and a nonprofit in Switzerland.
About_#3: She sold the rest of the family's 4Finance stake to four new, non-Russian minority shareholders.
About_#4: Boyko opened Moscow's first stores with credit card readers in the 1990s.
Did You Know?: Boyko, who was injured in an accident in 1996 and often appears in a scooter-style wheelchair, is the main private sponsor of Russian Paralympics team.

About_#1: Anna Maria Braun is CEO of medical device company B. Braun Melsungen, which began in 1839 as a small pharmacy that sold herbal remedies.
About_#2: A sixth-generation family member, she owns 10% of the company and also serves as president of its Asian/Pacific operations.
About_#3: Her father, Ludwig Georg Braun, took the reins in 1977, when the company had just $24 million in annual sales (now around $8 billion).
About_#4: Today, with more than 64,000 employees globally, B. Braun manufactures products ranging from infusion and injection solutions to surgical instruments.
Did You Know?: Anna Maria is a member of the board of Dr. August Oetker KG, a $9 billion (sales) conglomerate with interests in food, beverages, financial services and hotels.

About_#1: Edouard Carmignac founded Carmignac Gestion, one of Europe's largest asset managers, in 1989.
About_#2: Carmignac owns 79% of the company, which now has over $40 billion in assets under management; employees and executives own the rest.
About_#3: His daughter Maxime works at the company and is the heir apparent. His son directs Foundation Carmignac and another daughter, Lucrece, is an actress.
About_#4: In 2019, Carmignac stepped back from managing Carmignac Patrimoine, which he had run since 1989. He is chairman and chief investment officer.
Did You Know?: Edouard Carmignac wanted to be a rock star but settled for finance after receiving a BA in economics from the University of Paris and an MBA from Columbia.

About_#1: Anthony Casalena founded website building startup Squarespace in his University of Maryland dorm room in 2003.
About_#2: Casalena founded Squarespace with a $30,000 loan from his parents.
About_#3: Squarespace sells monthly or annual plans that range from a simple domain name and website to more advanced options for e-commerce.
About_#4: With traditional retailers flocking online during the pandemic, Casalena took Squarespace public in May 2021.

About_#1: Chang Jing chairs Beijing Roborock Technology, a maker of household vacuum cleaners.
About_#2: Chang Jing founded Roborock in 2014.
About_#3: Roborock is headquartered in Beijing.
About_#4: Roborock's shareholders include China smartphone heavyweight Xiaomi.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Victoria University
About_#1: Jeffrey Cheah is the executive chairman of Malaysian conglomerate Sunway.
About_#2: Over four decades, he transformed his obscure tin-mining company into a group with interests in education, healthcare, hotels and infrastructure.
About_#3: His daughter, Sarena, and sons, Adrian and Evan, work in the family business.
About_#4: Sunway's healthcare arm has two hospitals in Kuala Lumpur and has plans to open five more across the country.
Did You Know?: He is an avid philanthropist and has disbursed thousands of scholarships in Malaysia over the years.
In Their Own Words: I believe that education is an extremely powerful tool, and we should never stop pursuing knowledge at all ages.

About_#1: Chen Shiliang is the chairman of Tongkun Group, a supplier of textile products under the "Golden Cock" brand.
About_#2: Tongkun Group's predecessor business was a county-owned chemical fiber plant.
About_#3: Chen took charge of the small collective chemical fiber business in 1991 when it went into bankruptcy.
About_#4: Chen and other managers were granted shares of Tongkun in 1999 when the company reorganized.

About_#1: High school dropout Chua Thian Poh got his start making hooks and spikes for the logging industry.
About_#2: Chua went on to found luxury property developer Ho Bee Land, known for building high-end condos in Sentosa.
About_#3: The company has a diversified portfolio that includes commercial property overseas, notably in London and Munich.
About_#4: Since 2020 it has bought five sites in suburban Australia where it plans to build master-planned residential communities.
Did You Know?: Chua was once Singapore's non-resident ambassador to the Republic of Maldives.
In Their Own Words: We learned from the Asian financial crisis. Spread the risk. Don't rely on a single market. Diversify.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, Universidad Complutense de Madrid
About_#1: Cousins Alberto Cortina and Alberto Alcocer married sisters Alicia and Esther Koplowitz, heiresses to one of the largest construction firms in Spain.
About_#2: The cousins, dubbed Los Albertos, ran their wives' Construcciones y Contratas firm from the early 1970s until 1989, when both marriages fell apart.
About_#3: Alcocer and Cortina then moved into banking, running Banco Zaragozano. They sold their combined 40% stake to Barclays in 2004.
About_#4: Each of the cousins owns stakes in Grupo Empresarial ENCE, the largest eucalyptus pulp producer in Europe.
Did You Know?: Cortina owns several ranches in Toledo, Spain, along with houses in Mallorca and Madrid.

About_#1: The most powerful banker in Hungary, Sandor Csanyi is CEO of OTP Bank, one of the largest financial services firms in Central and Eastern Europe.
About_#2: When he took over OTP in 1992, he did the unthinkable in a formerly socialist country and fired a number of managers and introduced new technology.
About_#3: Csanyi is also one of Hungary's biggest investors in agriculture, whose Bonafarm operates the second biggest slaughterhouse in the nation.
About_#4: He also sits on the board of regional oil giant MOL.

About_#1: Lebanon-born Sasson Dayan founded Brazil's Daycoval bank in 1968 along with his since-deceased brother, Alberto Dayan.
About_#2: Daycoval has become one of Brazil's biggest lenders to small and mid-sized businesses.
About_#3: Dayan transferred most of his shares to his three sons in 2018, when Daycoval was considering an initial public offering, an idea it postponed.
About_#4: Dayan is president of the bank. Daily operations are headed by his sons.

Education: Bachelor of Technology, Indian Institute of Technology (IIT) Kharagpur, India; Ph.D, Indiana University - Bloomington
About_#1: Anand Deshpande is chairman and managing director of software firm Persistent Systems, headquartered in Pune.
About_#2: He started the company in 1990 as a database firm, pooling $21,000 from his savings and borrowings from his father and some friends.
About_#3: Persistent gets the bulk of its $566 million revenue from North America and 10% from India.
About_#4: It provides digital engineering and data and artificial intelligence products to the software, banking, financial services and healthcare sectors.

About_#1: Richard Desmond founded Northern & Shell, which published the Daily Express newspapers, OK! and Star magazines, and operates UK's Health Lottery.
About_#2: He was raised by his secretary mom in a garage apartment -- his parents divorced after his dad, an advertising executive, gambled away their savings.
About_#3: Desmond started his first magazine, International Musician, at age 22 with a $60,000 loan, then became Penthouse's U.K. licensee.
About_#4: He expanded to titles like Asian Babes and Posh Housewives, then sold some holdings and went mass market, launching OK! and buying Express Newspapers.
Did You Know?: In 2003, Desmond created the band RD Crusaders with Roger Daltrey from The Who and other musicians.

About_#1: Shlomo Eliahu owns about 64% of Migdal, a leading insurance and finance group in Israel.
About_#2: Eliahu grew up poor and, in 1950, emigrated with his family from Iraq to Israel, where he went from living in a transit camp to founding an underwriting agency.
About_#3: His Eliahu Insurance Company was the country's first insurance company.
About_#4: Politically active, Eliahu served as a member of Israel's parliament from 1978 to 1981 and was chairman of the finance committee.

About_#1: Jose Roberto Ermirio de Moraes is an heir to a stake in Brazilian industrial conglomerate Votorantim.
About_#2: His grandfather, Jose Ermirio de Moraes, founded Grupo Votorantim in 1918; in 2021 the group had revenues of about $7 billion.
About_#3: The group does business in more than 20 countries in the aluminum, pulp and paper, energy, banking, and cement industries.
About_#4: Jose Roberto inherited an 8% stake in the family-owned company after the death of his father, Jose Ermirio de Moraes Filho, in 2001.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Fundacao Getulio Vargas
About_#1: Jose Ermirio de Moraes Neto is an heir to Grupo Votorantim, a Brazilian family-owned industrial conglomerate.
About_#2: His grandfather and namesake, Jose Ermirio de Moraes, founded Grupo Votorantim in 1918.
About_#3: The company does business in more than 20 countries in the aluminum, pulp and paper, energy, banking and cement industries.
About_#4: Jose Ermirio inherited an 8% stake in the company after his father, Jose Ermirio de Moraes Filho, died in 2001.

Education: Bachelor of Social Sciences, University of Haifa
About_#1: David Fattal is founder of the Fattal Hotel Chain, Israel's largest hotel organization.
About_#2: Fattal got his start as a waiter and bellboy and rose through management ranks before starting Fattal Hotels in 1998 at age 41.
About_#3: Fattal Hotels owns 36 hotels with 9,000 rooms in Israel. It manages more than 160 hotels across Europe, many in Germany.
About_#4: In February 2018, the hotel chain's parent company, Fattal Holdings 1998, went public on the Tel Aviv stock exchange.

Education: Bachelor of Business Administration, The University of Texas at Austin
About_#1: Sold half his apartment portfolio to Greystar for $2 billion in late 2021. Top of the market?
About_#2: Owes his success to famously un-zoned Houston, "the only major city that really has no restrictions to entry. It's certainly allowed me to develop at will."
About_#3: In the early 1970s he got financing from Ace Greenberg at Bear Stearns.
About_#4: Trophy properties include One Park Place in downtown Houston and 500 Crawford, across from Minute Maid Park.

About_#1: Adam Foroughi is the cofounder and CEO of AppLovin, which makes mobile games and provides marketing services to app developers.
About_#2: Based in Palo Alto, California, AppLovin was founded in 2011 and went public in April 2021. Foroughi owns 9.2% of its shares.
About_#3: Foroughi bootstrapped AppLovin for years without outside funding. KKR became its biggest backer with a $400 million investment in 2018.
About_#4: Foroughi was born in Iran a year after the 1979 Iranian Revolution and immigrated to California as a child.

About_#1: Richard Fortin is a cofounder and board member of Couche-Tard, a Canadian convenience store chain that also owns the Circle K chain.
About_#2: Couche-Tard brought in $59 billion in revenue in 2019 from over 14,000 stores.
About_#3: Fortin, a golf and fishing enthusiast, also owns stakes in the National Bank of Canada and Canadian packaging and publishing company Transcontinental.
About_#4: His Fondation Lise et Richard Fortin supports causes like assistance for the elderly and services for children who are survivors of sexual assault.

About_#1: Luiz Frias is chairman of PagSeguro Digital, a payments company that went public on the New York Stock Exchange in 2018, raising over $2 billion.
About_#2: Frias' late father acquired one of Brazil's most popular daily newspapers in the 1960s, today known as Folha de S. Paulo.
About_#3: Group Folha became one of Brazil's largest media conglomerates; Frias joined in 1981, was appointed CEO in 1989 and chairman in 1991.
About_#4: In 1996, Frias founded UOL, a pioneering Brazilian Internet company, and one of the most visited websites in the country.
In Their Own Words: Regardless of the constitution, it is important that there is no kind of censorship.

About_#1: Susumu Fujita founded website and online blog and TV platform CyberAgent in 1998.
About_#2: He owns a minority stake in the Tokyo-listed company.
About_#3: The company also has an internet and mobile phone advertising agency.

About_#1: Simona Giorgetta is the largest shareholder and on the board of MAPEI, a manufacturer of chemical products used in construction based in Milan, Italy.
About_#2: She is the niece of Giorgio Squinzi, who led MAPEI from 1984 until his death in October 2019; Giorgio's father Rodolfo founded the company in 1937.
About_#3: The company's products have been used in projects ranging from the Panama City metro to the restoration of the Coliseum in Rome.
About_#4: Giorgetta shares ownership of the company with her cousins Marco and Veronica, Giorgio's two children, who serve as co-CEOs of MAPEI.

Education: Chartered Accountant, Institute of Chartered Accountants of India; Bachelor of Commerce, University of Rajasthan
About_#1: Premchand Godha chairs the $711 million (revenue) generics firm Ipca Labs, which manufactures formulations, bulk drugs and drug intermediates.
About_#2: Godha acquired Ipca Labs together with the family of Bollywood superstar Amitabh Bachchan in 1975.
About_#3: Ipca's shares jumped on higher sales of its anti-malaria drug hyroxychloroquine, which was being used to treat Covid-19 despite doubts about its efficacy for such treatment.
About_#4: A qualified chartered accountant, he started his practice in 1971 before moving into pharma.
Did You Know?: Godha hails from a family of farmers.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Kazakh Technological Institute
About_#1: Mikhail Gutseriev is a founder and the main shareholder of Safmar Group, a conglomerate with interests in oil, coal, real estate and retail.
About_#2: Between 2015 and 2017, he spent $2 billion acquiring banks, pension funds, oil fields, factories, warehouses, real estate and retail companies.
About_#3: In 2017 Binbank, which was headed by his nephew, former billionaire Mikail Shishkhanov, was nationalized by Russian Central Bank.
About_#4: He has eight Russian radio stations, including the popular Radio Shanson.
Did You Know?: Gutseriev is an owner of Hotel National, the hotel in Moscow where Trump stayed during his first visit to Russia in 1987.
In Their Own Words: In Russia there will never be a family business because of the lack of culture. In Russia, the family business is seen as a mafia clan.

About_#1: Hang Hong is a director of Wuxi Shangji Automation, a supplier of precision equipment for the photovoltaics industry.
About_#2: Hang Hong cofounded Shangji with husband Yang Jianliang in 2002 and is a director now.
About_#3: Husband Ynag Jianliang is chairman and president of Wuxi Shangji Automation.

About_#1: Alfredo Harp Helú made a fortune in finance, beginning with the cofounding of stock brokerage Acciones y Valores de Mexico, also known as Accival.
About_#2: In 1991 Accival merged with Mexican bank Banamex to form Grupo Financiero Banamex-Accival (Banacci). Harp Helu became chairman of the group.
About_#3: Citigroup acquired Grupo Financiero Banamex-Accival for $12 billion in stock and cash in 2001, and Harp Helu joined Citigroup's board.
About_#4: He has a minority stake in publicly-traded tile producer Internacional de Ceramica.
Did You Know?: A baseball enthusiast, he published an autobiography in 2003 titled, "To Live and Die Playing Baseball."

About_#1: Jaroslav Hascak is cofounder of Penta Investments, which has investments in the healthcare, banking, real estae and aeronautical industries.
About_#2: Penta, which he controls with Mark Dospiva, has controlling stakes in Privatbanka, pharmacy chain Dr. Max and sports betting operator Fortuna.
About_#3: Hascak and Czech Dospiva, who were both studying in Beijing, got started importing Chinese textiles to chain stores in Czechoslovakia.
About_#4: During Slovakia's 1996 privatization, Penta gained control over the nation's biggest fund paying only 20 percent of its real market value.
Did You Know?: Hascak spent one-tenth of his early earnings to buy his first car, a Fiat Uno; the rest he invested into the stock brokerage business.

Education: Bachelor of Business Administration, Central Missouri State University
About_#1: David Hoffmann owns 42 commercial properties in Naples, Florida, making him the biggest developer in the city.
About_#2: His early fortune came from executive search firm DHR International, which he established in 1989 and still owns.
About_#3: He and his wife Jerri moved to Naples in 2015 and spent $75 million on their initial purchase of seven buildings and a parking lot on the city's main boulevard, Fifth Avenue South.
About_#4: Hoffmann also owns Hertz Arena and the Everblades hockey team, the Old Collier Golf Club and small businesses such as Stan's Coffee and Mitch's Cookies.
In Their Own Words: I'm not any happier today than I was back then, so it's not about the money.

About_#1: Francis Holder founded and runs Groupe Holder, a French baked goods conglomerate with annual revenues of about $1 billion.
About_#2: The group's Paul bakery-cafe chain has 710 stores in 44 countries, and its high-end macaron house Laduree has more than 100 shops in 50 countries.
About_#3: Its white-label firm Chateau Blanc sells more than 500 kinds of breads, pastries and macaron to more than 200 clients worldwide, including McDonald's.
About_#4: Chateau Blanc's factory in Lille, France makes more than 30,000 macaron shells an hour.
Did You Know?: Holder plans to create a baking museum in Paris with his collection of more than 18,000 paintings and books on the subject.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Wenzhou Normal College
About_#1: Huang Wei controls Xinhu Zhongbao, one of China's largest real estate developers.
About_#2: Xinhu Zhongbao holds a minority stake in Wind, one of China's largest providers of financial information.
About_#3: Huang's Xinhu Group has a controlling stake in Xiangcai Securities, a Chinese brokerage.
About_#4: Huang's son Huang Licheng is a company supervisor at Xinhua Zhongbao.

About_#1: Zarakh Iliev and his longtime partner God Nisanov are building trade centers, hotels and residential property in Moscow.
About_#2: The pair, who moved to Moscow from Azerbaijan, own roughly 14 million of square feet of real estate in Moscow.
About_#3: The partners developed a 225-acre wholesale distribution center, Food City, in Moscow and also several shopping centers on Moscow's outskirts.
About_#4: Ililev is co-owner of 5- star Moscow Royal Radisson hotel, which served as FIFA's headquarters during the World Cup 2018 in Russia.
Did You Know?: The son of a shoemaker, Iliev helped make shoes as a child.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Brandeis University; Law Degree, New York University
About_#1: Mitchell Jacobson began working for MSC Direct, an office and industrial equipment distributor founded by his father Sidney, in 1976.
About_#2: In 1995, Jacobson took over as CEO of the Melville, N.Y.-based firm, which now distributes hundreds of products, from staplers to air conditioners.
About_#3: Jacobson held the CEO position through 2005 and, since 2013, the non-executive chairman.
Did You Know?: Jacobson's parents, who married six weeks after they met, poisoned themselves in 2005 after Sid was diagnosed with cancer. They had been married 59 years.

About_#1: Rajeev Juneja and his older brother Ramesh Juneja cofounded privately held Mankind Pharma in 1995.
About_#2: The company is a low-cost generics champion generating most of its $850 million in revenue in India.
About_#3: Private equity firms Capital International and ChrysCapital are key investors in Mankind.
About_#4: Juneja's U.K.-educated nephew Arjun heads international operations.
Did You Know?: Juneja and his younger brother were born on the same date, ten years apart.

About_#1: Peter Kelly founded I.T. infrastructure provider Softcat in 1993, spending a reported $44,400 and working out of his garden shed.
About_#2: Kelly, a college dropout, started out in sales at Xerox Corp.
About_#3: He took Softcat public in 2015 on the London Stock Exchange and owns just over 30% of the company.
About_#4: Kelly is known to offer his staff free breakfast and a weekly shirt-ironing service

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Korea University; Master of Business Administration, University of Michigan, Stephen M. Ross School of Business
About_#1: Kim Nam-jung is the vice chairman of Dongwon, a conglomerate best known as the makers behind South Korea's famous canned tunas.
About_#2: He is the younger son of Dongwon founder Kim Jae-chul, who started the business in 1969; his first overseas base was in Ghana in 1973.
About_#3: In addition to a wide range of packaged seafood, Dongwon provides outsourced meals, operates cold-storage facilities and has a logistics operation.
About_#4: He now controls the group, after the elder Kim stepped down as Dongwon's chairman after 50 years.
Did You Know?: Nam-jung joined the business in a blue-collar position in 1996.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, University of Wales
About_#1: Koon Poh Ming is the executive vice chairman of aluminum company Press Metal while his brother Koon Poh Keong is group CEO.
About_#2: They started Press Metal with their three brothers--Poh Tat, Poh Weng and Poh Kong--in the mid-1980s.
About_#3: The brothers pooled $50,000 to start the aluminum-extruding company, at a time when Malaysia was in a recession.
About_#4: Press Metal is Southeast Asia's largest integrated aluminum producer and competes with Rio Tinto, Russia's RUSAL and the Aluminum Corp of China.

Education: Doctorate, St Petersburg State University
About_#1: Yuri Kovalchuk is friends with Russia's president Vladimir Putin; they met when Putin was deputy mayor of St. Petersburg.
About_#2: They both had country houses in the Ozero dacha cooperative, and when Putin became president, many of the cooperative's members' careers improved.
About_#3: Kovalchuck is now the largest shareholder of Rossiya Bank and has a large stake in Sogaz insurance company.
About_#4: He controls National Media Group, an investment firm with controlling stakes in popular Russian media assets.
Did You Know?: After US sanctions hit Kovalchuk's Rossiya Bank, Vladimir Putin moved his payroll account to the bank.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign
About_#1: Michael Krasny founded Computer Discount Warehouse (CDW) in 1984 as an online store for IT products.
About_#2: In 2007, he sold the company to Madison Dearborn Partners for $7.3 billion and has maintained a low profile ever since.
About_#3: Krasny is an active donor to Jewish causes and medical research through his Circle of Service Foundation.
Did You Know?: In March 2017, Krasny reportedly paid $4.35 million for a condominium on the 50th floor of Park Tower in Chicago.

Education: Master of Arts, Cambridge University; Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School
About_#1: Raymond Kwok is the youngest son of the founder of Sun Hung Kai Properties, the largest developer in Hong Kong.
About_#2: Since 2011 he's served as first the developer's co-chairman and now as the chairman.
About_#3: The three Kwok brothers inherited the publicly traded company after the death of their father, Kwok Tak-seng, in 1990.
About_#4: The brothers fought for a decade over the family's assets until Walter, the eldest brother, decided to drop his lawsuit.
In Their Own Words: "I remain grateful for knowing you as my brother, you will remain my brother," Raymond wrote in the memorial booklet at Walter's funeral in 2018.

About_#1: Heikki Kyostila is president of Planmeca, one of the world's largest dental equipment manufacturers, headquartered in Helsinki, Finland.
About_#2: Kyostila founded Planmeca in 1971 in Helsinki as a small dental-stools and -cabinets manufacturer.
About_#3: The company has expanded to making 2D and 3D imaging X-ray devices and software for dentists.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Samuel Curtis Johnson Graduate School of Management; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Seoul National University
About_#1: Lee Ho-jin is a former chairman of Taekwang Industrial, a manufacturer that became synonymous with Korea's textile and petrochemical prowess.
About_#2: He rose to chairman after his oldest brother, Lee Sik-jin, died. He has now stepped down and is reportedly struggling against liver cancer.
About_#3: In 2011, he was sentenced to 54 months in prison for embezzling $128 million from the company but has been out on bail due to his illness.
About_#4: In February 2019, he was sentenced to three years in prison on charges of embezzlement and breach of trust.
Did You Know?: Lee is credited for diversifying the group into media and entertainment.

About_#1: Bernard Lewis founded UK-based clothing retailer River Island Fashion in 1948; it now sells online and has stores in several European countries.
About_#2: The business had revenue of $800 million in 2020-- down about 30% from the prior year due to the pandemic.
About_#3: His nephew Ben Lewis, who started as a store manager in 1990, served as CEO from 2010 to 2019.
About_#4: Lewis and his family also maintain interests in hotels in the U.S., property development and asset management businesses.

Education: Associate in Arts/Science, Henan Normal University; EMBA, Peking University
About_#1: Li Fengluan sits on the board of Tianrui Group, whose business includes steel, tourism, cement and minerals.
About_#2: Li's husband, Li Liufa, is Tianrui Group's chairman.
About_#3: Li holds degrees from Henan University and Peking University in China

About_#1: Lin Zhijun is the vice chairman of Double Medical Technology.
About_#2: Double Medical Technology supplies trauma implant consumables and spinal implant consumables.
About_#3: Lin's elder brother Lin Zhixiong is a member of the 2017 Forbes China Rich List.

About_#1: Lin Zhixiong chairs Double Medical Technology.
About_#2: Double Medical Technology's main products are trauma implant and spinal implant consumables.
About_#3: Lin studied at Chiba University in Japan from April 2003 to June 2004.
About_#4: Lin founded the predecessor of Double Medical Technology after he returned from Japan in 2004.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Hebei Normal University; Doctorate, Renmin University of China; Master of Arts, Renmin University of China
About_#1: Liu Ming Hui is the chairman and cofounder of China Gas Holdings, a natural gas services operator listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.
About_#2: Liu is a graduate of China's Hebei Normal University.
About_#3: Liu's brother Liu Mingxing and daughter Liu Chang sit on China Gas Holding's board.

About_#1: Liu Xuejing chairs privately held GMK Holding, which has two core businesses: chicken processing and copper smeltering.
About_#2: GMK supplies chicken to KFC and McDonald's in China and Southeast Asia.
About_#3: Liu's son Liu Zhiguang is GMK's CEO.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Renmin University of China; Soochow University Graduate School of Humanities
About_#1: Lu chairs Jiangsu Linyang Energy, an electronics supplier.
About_#2: The company was established in 1995 and trades on the Shanghai Stock Exchange.
About_#3: It currently employs 3,000 people that churn out a variety of meters and offgrid solar power systems.
About_#4: Customers include State Grid Corporation of China and China Southern Power Grid.

About_#1: Lu Zhaoxi, also known as Jonathan Lu, has held numerous posts in the Alibaba Group over the years, most recently vice chairman.
About_#2: His fortune arises from holdings in Ant Group, the financial services arm of Alibaba Group.
About_#3: On November 3, 2020, Chinese authorities held up Ant's planned dual IPO listing in Shanghai and Hong Kong due to regulatory concerns.
About_#4: He holds a graduate certificate in hotel management from Guangzhou University and an MBA from China Europe International Business School.

Education: Drop Out, Indiana University
About_#1: Fred Luddy, a serial entrepreneur, cofounded enterprise software company ServiceNow in 2004, a few weeks before he turned 50.
About_#2: At the time, Luddy had just lost a nearly $35 million fortune when his previous employer, Peregrine Systems, filed for bankruptcy.
About_#3: Advised by Sequoia Capital, Luddy turned down a $2.5 billion acquisition offer for ServiceNow in 2011 and took it public the next year.
About_#4: Luddy stepped down as CEO in 2011 to serve as chief product officer, a role he held until 2017. In June 2018, he became chairman of the board.
In Their Own Words: There is no better experience than giving someone a piece of technology that lets them do something they never thought they could do.

About_#1: Danish aviation entrepreneur Martin Møller Nielsen founded aircraft leasing firm Nordic Aviation Capital in 1990.
About_#2: A quarter of a century later, he sold a 67% stake in it to private equity firms EQT and Krikbi in a transaction that valued the firm at $3.3 billion.
About_#3: He still owns 33% of NAC, which initially leased aircraft for humanitarian aid organizations looking to fly into remote areas.
About_#4: The group, which started in Skive, Denmark, now has offices in Denmark, Ireland, North America and Singapore.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Universidade Presbiteriana Mackenzie
About_#1: Neide Helena de Moraes is an heir to a stake in Grupo Votorantim, a Brazilian industrial conglomerate.
About_#2: She is a granddaughter of Jose Ermirio de Moraes, who founded Grupo Votorantim in 1918; she previously appeared on Forbes? billionaires list in 2014.
About_#3: The company does business in more than 20 countries in the aluminum, pulp and paper, energy, banking and cement industries.
About_#4: Neide Helena inherited an 8% stake in the family-owned company after the death of her father, Jose Ermirio de Moraes Filho, in 2001.

About_#1: Yoshiko Mori is the widow of real estate tycoon Minoru Mori, who died in 2012.
About_#2: She inherited part of Minoru's estate, including a share of his real estate firm, Mori Building.
About_#3: Mori Building is known for developments such as Tokyo's swank Roppongi Hills complex, a mix of retail, restaurants, apartments, hotel and offices.
About_#4: Mori Building also co-developed one of China's tallest buildings, the Shanghai World Financial Center.

About_#1: Mumbai real estate magnate Mofatraj Munot started developing property in 1969 after working with his uncle.
About_#2: Munot snatched lucrative construction contracts during the 1970s in the Middle East oil boom, where he built the palace of the ruler of Sharjah.
About_#3: Today, his Kalpataru, run by son Parag, is focusing on its 11.2-million-square-foot township in suburban Mumbai.
About_#4: Engineering contractor Kalpataru Power Transmission is Munot's only listed asset.
Did You Know?: The name Kalpataru is derived from Kalpavruksha, a mythological tree of wish fulfillment.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, Boston University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Connecticut
About_#1: Lawyer turned money man Randal Nardone owns a nearly 13% stake in natural gas infrastructure firm New Fortress Energy.
About_#2: In March 2022, New Fortress Energy said it was planning to build the first offshore LNG (liquefied natural gas) export facility in the U.S.
About_#3: Nardone previously appeared on the 2007 Forbes list of billionaires after the IPO of Fortress Investment Group, which he cofounded.
About_#4: Nardone served as Fortress Investment Group's chief executive officer from July 2013 through December 2017.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Academy of Civil Aviation (Leningrad)
About_#1: Vadim Novinsky owns Ukraine's Smart Holding Group, which has a 24% stake in Rinat Akhmetov's iron ore producer Metinvest.
About_#2: Novinsky started working in Ukraine in the mid 1990s with Russian oil producer Lukoil, then began buying Ukrainian metallurgy companies.
About_#3: The Russian native got his Ukrainian citizenship in 2012; he has been a member of parliament since 2013.
About_#4: Long seen as one of Ukraine's most Putin-friendly billionaires, he tried to jump-start negotiations with Russia before the invasion and fled the country as tensions rose.

About_#1: Satyanarayan Nuwal started Solar Industries India in 1995 to trade in industrial explosives then started manufacturing them.
About_#2: The biggest chunk of its annual revenue is from exports, followed by housing and infrastructure, state-owned coal companies and the defense sector.
About_#3: The son of a government employee, Nuwal set up his first business, an ink manufacturing unit in 1970 at age 18.
Did You Know?: Nuwal tried his hand at several businesses before latching on to industrial explosives but they all failed.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Santa Clara University
About_#1: John Ocampo is chairman of semiconductor maker Macom Technology Solutions.
About_#2: He's served on the board since the company started in 2009.
About_#3: He's the largest individual shareholder at Macom with 27.8% of shares.
About_#4: He and his wife Susan founded Gaas Labs, a venture capital firm that invests in communications and semiconductor industries.

Education: Oregon State University; Walla Walla College
About_#1: Forrest Preston founded Life Care Centers of America in 1970 and has since made a fortune with facilities that house and care for the elderly.
About_#2: The private firm raked in $2.7 billion in sales in 2020 from nursing homes, assisted living facilities and retirement living communities in 28 states.
About_#3: Preston is the CEO and sole owner of the company, which is based in Cleveland, Tennessee.
About_#4: In 2016, the company agreed to pay $145 million to settle a government lawsuit alleging that the firm had over-billed federal healthcare programs.
Did You Know?: Before founding the company, Preston sold vacuum cleaners, worked as an X-ray technician and ran a printing business with his brother.

About_#1: Riju Raveendran is the younger brother of edtech billionaire Byju Raveendran, the cofounder of learning app Byju's.
About_#2: He has been associated with the company since its start in 2011 and now oversees administration and operations.
About_#3: Riju has a small but valuable stake in Byju's parent company Think & Learn, which was valued at $22 billion in its last founding round.
About_#4: Byju's went on an acquisition spree in 2021, spending more than $2 billion.

About_#1: A farmer's son, P.P. Reddy founded Megha Engineering Enterprises to build small pipes for municipalities in 1989.
About_#2: He soon expanded into building infrastructure such as dams, natural gas distribution networks, power plants and roads.
About_#3: In 2006, he changed the company's name to Megha Engineering and Infrastructure.
About_#4: His nephew P.V. Krishna Reddy runs the company.
Did You Know?: Megha also has projects in Bangladesh, Kuwait, Tanzania and Zambia.

About_#1: P.V. Krishna Reddy is the managing director of privately held Megha Engineering and Infrastructure.
About_#2: He cofounded it with his uncle, P.P. Reddy, in 1989 to build small pipes for municipalities.
About_#3: Megha soon expanded into building infrastructure projects such as dams, natural gas distribution networks, power plants and roads.
About_#4: Megha also has projects overseas in Zambia, Tanzania, Bangladesh and Kuwait.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Osmania University; Master of Science, Purdue University
About_#1: Satish Reddy is the chairman of listed pharma company Dr Reddy's Laboratories, in which he has a minority stake.
About_#2: The company was founded by his late father K.Anji Reddy in 1984.
About_#3: Reddy, brother-in-law G.V.Prasad, who is also a billionaire, is the co-chairman and managing director of the company.
About_#4: In 2020, the company acquired the rights to conduct clinical trials of Sputnik V, the Russian Covid-19 vaccine and to distribute it in India.
Did You Know?: He is a member of the board of governors at the Indian Institute of Management in Visakhapatnam.

About_#1: Brazil-born Lily Safra, who inherited most of her fortune from the late banker Edmond J. Safra, died in July 2022 at age 87.
About_#2: Edmond's 1999 death in a fire at his Monaco penthouse made global headlines and prompted conspiracy theories despite his nurse's admission of guilt.
About_#3: Edmond left most of his fortune to the Edmond J. Safra Philanthropic Foundation, but he also left Lily enough assets to make her a billionaire.
About_#4: Lily's fortune also stemmed from a stake in Brazilian appliance giant Ponto Frio, inherited after second husband Alfredo Monteverde's 1969 suicide.
Did You Know?: Safra supports the only synagogue on the ancient Greek island of Rhodes.
In Their Own Words: My husband, Edmond, would always put money in his pocket so that he could give something to every needy person we saw in the street. At the same time, he was providing millions to hospitals, universities, and welfare programs around the world.

Education: Drop Out, California State University Northridge
About_#1: Richard Saghian is the founder and CEO of fast fashion company Fashion Nova, which has over $1 billion in annual sales.
About_#2: The son of Iranian immigrants, he started the company in 2006 after dropping out of college.
About_#3: Saghian offered hundreds of new clothing styles a week, promoted on Instagram by influencers and celebrities like Cardi B.
About_#4: In 2018, Fashion Nova was the most Googled fashion brand, beating out the likes of Louis Vuitton, Versace and Gucci.

About_#1: Deniz Sahenk is the widow of Dogus Holding founder Ayhan Sahenk, who died of a heart attack in 2001. She has no active role in the conglomerate.
About_#2: Dogus operates in sectors ranging from tourism, real estate and media to financial services, construction, autos and restaurants.
About_#3: Most of the fortune derives from Garanti Bank. The family sold its remaining 10% of Garanti to Spain's BBVA in 2017, bringing in $900 million.
About_#4: Deniz's son, Ferit Sahenk, is CEO of Dogus Holding, and her daughter, Filiz Sahenk, manages its fashion and tourism components.
Did You Know?: Dogus has been deleveraging. In 2020, it agreed to sell its 42% stake in high-end Istanbul shopping mail Istinye Park to Qatar Holding LLC.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Columbia Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Uppsala University
About_#1: Former hedge fund manager and activist investor Thomas Sandell closed up shop in 2019, transforming his Sandell Asset Management into a family office.
About_#2: Hit hard by the great recession, the Swedish credit market specialist has built up his fortune twice.
About_#3: Sandell earned an MBA from Columbia University and landed a spot at Bear Stearns in 1988 before founding Sandell Asset Management a decade later.
About_#4: Initially a risk arbitrage specialist, Sandell later shifted tactics and engaged in loud proxy battles with firms like Bob Evans Farms in 2013.
Did You Know?: Sandell is a former badminton champion in his native Sweden.

About_#1: Hajime Satomi is the chairman and group CEO of Sega Sammy, a Japanese pachinko machine and gaming software firm.
About_#2: He founded pachinko machine maker Sammy, which got into the videogame business when it acquired Sega in 2004.
About_#3: His son, Haruki, is the president and group COO of Sega Sammy.
About_#4: Sega Sammy has a 45% stake in South Korean gambling-and-entertainment resort Paradise City.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Columbia University; Master of Business Administration, University of Michigan
About_#1: James Scapa left his job as a computer engineering consultant for General Motors to start Altair Engineering with two coworkers in 1985.
About_#2: He has been Altair's CEO since its founding and took the company public in 2017. He owns 24% of Altair's shares.
About_#3: Based in Troy, Michigan, Altair provides software in engineering simulation, high-performance computing and artificial intelligence.
About_#4: Scapa grew up in New York as the son of Greek immigrant Holocaust survivors and graduated from Columbia before leaving the East Coast.
In Their Own Words: I have a sense of the opportunity being so large. Math and algorithms are going to drive all the decisions of the future, so I think we were sort of a rocket sitting on the launching pad.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yale University
About_#1: Paul Sciarra cofounded photo-bookmarking site Pinterest in 2010 with Ben Silbermann and Evan Sharp and left the company in 2012.
About_#2: Sciarra held onto a roughly 7% slice of Pinterest, which went public on the New York Stock Exchange in April 2019, making him a billionaire.
About_#3: Since 2014, he has served as executive chairman of electric air taxi maker Joby Aviation. He holds a 10% stake.
About_#4: Joby went public in August 2021 through a reverse merger with Reinvent Technology Partners, Mark Pincus and Reid Hoffman's SPAC.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Kazan State Technical University
About_#1: Albert Shigaboutdinov got rich as a co-owner of the TAIF Group, a large regional holding company with assets in the Republic of Tatarstan.
About_#2: In 2021 TAIF merged with petrochemical company Sibur, owned by billionaires Leonid Mikhelson and Gennady Timchenko.
About_#3: Shigaboutdnov, who headed TAIF for 24 years, joined the board of directors of Sibur
About_#4: As part of the $27 billion merger, Shigaboutdinov and other TAIF shareholders received a 15% of Sibur.
Did You Know?: Shigaboutdinov was a member of regional parliament, The State Council of the Republic Tatarstan, for five years until 2014.
In Their Own Words: The merger of TAIF with SIBUR will allow the new company to take a leading position in the global market, enter the top 5 world leaders in the production of petrochemical products.

About_#1: Nobutoshi Shimamura built one of Japan's leading discount retailers, publicly traded Shimamura Co.
About_#2: The chain has more than 2,200 stores, including shoe stores and those overseas.
About_#3: The company's overseas stores are in China and Taiwan.
About_#4: Nobutoshi Shimamura retired more than two decades ago.

About_#1: Ron Sim is the founder of OSIM International, maker of high-end massage chairs.
About_#2: He took the company private in 2016 when its shares had dropped steeply from their 2014 high.
About_#3: In February 2022, V3 Brands, part of his V3 Group filed for an IPO in Hong Kong. V3 Brands includes the group's flagship high-end massage chair maker OSIM and luxury tea brand TWG Tea.
About_#4: In 2022, he launched Bacha Coffee, a 110-old Moroccan cafe chain, in Singapore.
Did You Know?: At age 20, he started a company that sold knife sharpeners and other household goods.
In Their Own Words: The key for us is to continue designing new products that people need.

About_#1: Alexander Sixt, together with his brother, Konstantin, owns 56% of Sixt SE, one of the world's largest car rental companies. They are the co-CEOs.
About_#2: Their grandfather Martin Sixt founded the firm in 1912. Their father, Erich, took over in 1969 when it was a local operation with just 200 vehicles.
About_#3: Together with his wife, Regine, Erich turned the company into a global player. He stepped down as CEO in 2021; he is chair of the supervisory board.
About_#4: Sixt SE, which went public in 1986, had 2021 revenues of around $2.5 billion, 7,000 employees and some 2,000 locations in over 100 countries.
Did You Know?: In 2015, Alexander and his brother Konstantin joined Sixt's executive board.

About_#1: Konstantin Sixt, together with his brother, Alexander, owns 56% of Sixt SE, one of the world's largest car rental companies. They are the co-CEOs.
About_#2: Their grandfather Martin Sixt founded the firm in 1912. Their father, Erich, took over in 1969 when it was a local operation with just 200 vehicles.
About_#3: Together with his wife, Regine, Erich turned the company into a global player. He stepped down as CEO in 2021. He now chairs the supervisory board.
About_#4: Sixt SE, which went public in 1986, had 2021 revenues of around $2.5 billion, with 7,000 employees and some 2000 locations in over 100 countries.
Did You Know?: In 2005, after receiving an MSc in International Accounting and Finance from Cass Business School in London, he assumed responsibility for Sixt's online operations.

About_#1: Canberra native Terry Snow is the executive chairman of Capital Airport Group, which operates Canberra Airport.
About_#2: He became a billionaire in 2017, thanks to a bumper increase in the value of his property around the capital city's main airport.
About_#3: He's invested more than $2 billion developing the airport and building office and industrial parks on the 1,062 acres of surrounding land.
About_#4: Snow trained as an accountant but worked as a property developer in the 1980s with his father, Bob, and brother George.

About_#1: Marco Squinzi is the co-CEO and part-owner of MAPEI, a manufacturer of chemical products used in construction based in Milan, Italy.
About_#2: He and his sister Veronica became co-CEOs in July 2019, three months before the death of their father Giorgio, who took over the company in 1984.
About_#3: MAPEI was founded by Giorgio's father, Rodolfo, in 1937; its products have been used to restore the Coliseum in Rome and in the Panama City metro.
About_#4: Marco shares ownership of MAPEI with Veronica and his cousin Simona Giorgetta, who owns the largest stake in the company.

Education: Master of Business Administration, SDA Bocconi School of Management; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Milan
About_#1: Veronica Squinzi is the co-CEO and part-owner of MAPEI, a manufacturer of chemical products used in construction based in Milan, Italy.
About_#2: She and her brother Marco became co-CEOs in July 2019, three months before the death of their father Giorgio, who took over the company in 1984.
About_#3: MAPEI was founded by Giorgio's father, Rodolfo, in 1937; its products have been used to restore the Coliseum in Rome and in the Panama City metro.
About_#4: Veronica shares ownership of MAPEI with Marco and her cousin Simona Giorgetta, who owns the largest stake in the company.

Education: High School Graduate, High School
About_#1: Manny Stul took over a struggling company named Moose Toys in 2000. Sales have soared since.
About_#2: Its Shopkins collectibles, inspired by grocery and department store items, with names like Milk Bud and Kris P. Lettuce, are some of their best-known.
About_#3: He made a fortune building and selling a giftwares company. He then dabbled in various ventures like organic farming before investing in Moose Toys.
Did You Know?: Stul's parents were Polish Holocaust survivors. He was born in a German refugee camp before the family traveled to Australia after World War II.
In Their Own Words: Everyone thinks we are a toy company. I keep telling our team we are not a toy company, we are a creative house, a creative hub. Innovation is in our DNA.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Kazan Institute of Civil Engineering
About_#1: Rusteem Sulteev got rich as co-owner of TAIF Group, a large regional holding company with assets in the Republic of Tatarstan.
About_#2: TAIF became a shareholder in most of its companies during Russia's privatization in the mid 1990s.
About_#3: He and his co-owner Albert Shigaboutdinov merged TAIF with petrochemical company Sibur in 2021.
About_#4: Sulteev and other shareholders of TAIF received shares in Sibur, owned by billionaires Leonid Mikhelson and Gennady Timchenko.
Did You Know?: Ex-shareholders of TAIF include billionaires Radik and Airat Shaimiev, sons of Tartarstan's first president.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, Berkeley
About_#1: Sehat Sutardha cofounded semiconductor company Marvell Technology with his wife, Weili Dai, in 1995.
About_#2: He was CEO of the company until he and Dai were forced out in 2016 amid an internal accounting investigation.
About_#3: No evidence of fraud was found in the Marvell accounting investigation.
About_#4: The couple moved to Las Vegas in 2017 and have been investing in real estate and technology.

About_#1: Tony Tan Caktiong is the founder and chairman of Jollibee Food, one of the world's fastest-growing Asian restaurant chains.
About_#2: Jollibee operates more than 3,300 eateries in the Philippines and more than 2,500 stores overseas.
About_#3: Jollibee sells Filipino, Chinese, American and European dishes adapted to a quick-serve and affordable format.
About_#4: With partner Edgar Sia II, Caktiong also owns a stake in the fast-growing DoubleDragon Properties.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, San Jose State University
About_#1: Jim Thompson started his moving company, Crown Worldwide, in Japan in 1965, with $1,000.
About_#2: Crown Worldwide is now one of the world's largest privately held relocation companies, with operations in 45 countries and more than 3,000 employees.
About_#3: The company is also involved in document storage and fine-arts transportation.
About_#4: Thompson moved the company's headquarters to Hong Kong in 1978. He is a permanent resident of Hong Kong.
Did You Know?: In his adopted home, Hong Kong, Thompson served as chairman of the American Chamber of Commerce in Hong Kong.
In Their Own Words: I didn't have a vision. Because when you're small, there are so many things that you have to accomplish that the vision is: can I make my payroll next week? You can't think too far beyond that.

About_#1: Carmen Thyssen inherited her fortune from her husband, Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza, when he died in 2002.
About_#2: She owns an art collection being exhibited at the Thyssen Museum in Madrid that is valued by the Spanish government at more than $1 billion.
About_#3: Carmen Thyssen, a former Miss Spain, married Hans Thyssen-Bornemisza, heir to a German industrial fortune, in 1985; she was his fifth wife.
About_#4: Hans' son Georg and Carmen settled a 3-year court battle over control of the family's Monaco-based TBG Group months before the Baron died

Education: Medical Doctor, University of Maryland
About_#1: August Troendle is the president and CEO of Medpace, a clinical research company he founded in Cincinnati, Ohio in 1992; he owns 21% of the stock.
About_#2: Medpace conducts clinical trials for pharmaceutical companies seeking to bring drugs, vaccines or medical devices to market.
About_#3: Before starting Medpace, Troendle spent five years as a director at Swiss pharma company Sandoz, now known as Novartis.
About_#4: He also briefly worked as a medical review officer at the FDA's division of metabolic and endocrine drug products from 1986 to 1987.

About_#1: Joop van den Ende is a Dutch entertainment mogul and theatrical producer who founded Amsterdam-based Stage Entertainment in 1998.
About_#2: Advance Publications acquired Stage in 2018 for a reported price of about $1.1 billion (975 million euros). Prior to the sale, Van den Ende owned 40%.
About_#3: Van den Ende was Stage's sole owner until 2015, when CVC Capital Partners reportedly bought a 60% stake for $550 million.
About_#4: Stage's original productions have included Rocky, Sister Act and Ice Age Live.
Did You Know?: Van den Ende partnered with John de Mol, also a billionaire, to create reality TV production company Endemol in 1994.

Education: Bachelor of Technology, Indian Institute of Technology Madras (IIT Madras)
About_#1: Sekar Vembu get his wealth from his holding in privately held Zoho, which offers business software on the cloud.
About_#2: He cofounded AdventNet, the precursor to Zoho, along with his two brothers as well as three other friends.
About_#3: In 2002, he set up Vembu Technologies in Chennai, which offers data backup and disaster recovery solutions to small and medium firms.
About_#4: His brother Sridhar is the face of the company, while Sekar keeps a low profile.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Verona
About_#1: Sandro Veronesi is the president of Calzedonia, a hosiery and lingerie retail chain he founded in 1986 in Verona, Italy.
About_#2: He got his start in the business by working for the Italian king of hosiery, Nerino Grassi, at the Golden Lady Company.
About_#3: Today, his Calzedonia Group with subsidiary brands Intimissimi, Tezenis, and Falconeri, boasts 4,859 stores in 54 countries.
About_#4: Veronesi is passionate about wine, and opened Signorvino, a chain of wine shops, cafes and restaurants across Italy.

About_#1: Wan Long is the chairman and CEO of meat processor WH Group.
About_#2: WH acquired Virginia-based Smithfield, the world's largest pork processor and hog producer, in 2013.
About_#3: Smithfield completed the acquisition of Clougherty Packing, California's largest pork processor, in 2017.
About_#4: WH Group was formerly known as Shuanghui International, and renamed itself in 2014.

Education: Associate in Arts/Science, Zhejiang University of Technology
About_#1: Wang Jianyi is the founder and chairman of Futong Group, a supplier of fiber optic cable products.
About_#2: Futong, founded in 1987, is headquartered in the eastern Chinese city of Hangzhou.
About_#3: Futong's customers include China Mobile, China Unicom, and China Telecom.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Georgia Institute of Technology; Master of Business Administration, University of Pennsylvania, The Wharton School
About_#1: Alfred West runs SEI, the $1.6 billion (revenue) financial services firm he founded in 1968.
About_#2: SEI, which stands for Simulated Environments Inc., first developed a computer program to train loan officers by simulating a lending environment.
About_#3: West took SEI public in 1981 and branched out into investment advisory and money management.
Did You Know?: West dreamed of becoming a fighter pilot when he was younger and studied aerospace engineering at Georgia Tech.
In Their Own Words: CEOs need to be shareholders ... They should have just as much at stake as their employees or their investors.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: Dan and his brother Farris got a combined $3.5 billion (pretax) in 2011 selling their fracking company to a group led by Singapore-based firm Temasek.
About_#2: The brothers have acquired more than 672,000 acres of land in six different states across the West, becoming America's 12th-largest landowners.
About_#3: They first founded Wilks Masonry in 1995, following in their stone mason father's footsteps.
About_#4: In 2002 they went into fracking, launching Frac Tech and growing it into an oil and natural gas giant before cashing out less than a decade later.
Did You Know?: Dan Wilks and his brother are active Republican donors.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: Farris and his brother Dan got a combined $3.5 billion (pretax) in 2011 selling their fracking company to a group led by Singapore-based firm Temasek.
About_#2: The brothers have acquired more than 672,000 acres of land in six different states across the West, becoming America's 12th-largest landowners.
About_#3: The brothers began their careers as stone masons, like their father, founding Wilks Masonry in 1995.
About_#4: In 2002 they went into fracking, launching Frac Tech and growing it into an oil and natural gas giant before cashing out less than a decade later.
Did You Know?: Farris Wilks is the pastor of his own church, the Assembly of Yahweh Seventh Day Church, near Cisco, Texas.

About_#1: Xu Jin chairs Shanghai-listed Anhui Kouzi Distillery, a spirits supplier headquartered in central China.
About_#2: The predecessor of Kouzi Distillery was a state-owned wine company set up in 1949.
About_#3: Xu has led Kouzi Group since 1997.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, Berkeley
About_#1: Tony Xu cofounded restaurant delivery service DoorDash in 2013 and became a billionaire after its 2020 IPO. He owns 4.6% plus options.
About_#2: Cofounders Andy Fang and Stanley Tang, who Xu met while they were all studying at Stanford, own about 4% each. Xu is the CEO.
About_#3: DoorDash is America's largest food delivery service. It delivers meals and more from 390,000 restaurants and other merchants like CVS.
About_#4: Xu was born in China and moved to the U.S. at age five. Growing up, his mom worked as a server at a Chinese restaurant.
In Their Own Words: DoorDash exists today to empower those like my Mom who came here with a dream to make it on their own. Fighting for the underdog is part of who I am and what we stand for as a company.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Stetson University
About_#1: Patrick Zalupski is the founder, chairman and CEO of Dream Finders Homes, a Florida-based homebuilder.
About_#2: Dream Finders Homes went public in January 2021 via an IPO.
About_#3: Zalupski started the company in 2008 and focuses on first time homebuyers and move-up buyers--homeowners who are moving to a newer or bigger home.
About_#4: The company builds homes in eight states, primarily in the Southeast.
In Their Own Words: My mindset is: 'What do we do tomorrow?'

About_#1: Zeng Chaoyi is a director of Tianshan Aluminum Group, a Chinese supplier of aluminum products.
About_#2: Tianshan's shares trade at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange; it's headquartered in Xinjiang.
About_#3: Shimge Pump Industry Group acquired Tianshan Aluminum Group in 2020 in a backdoor listing and changed its name to Tianshan Aluminum Group.
About_#4: Brother Zeng Chaoyi's brother Zeng Chaolin is Tianshan's chairman and also a billionaire.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, South East University
About_#1: Zhang Guiping is the chairman of Suning Universal, a property and hotel business headquartered in Nanjing, a city in eastern China.
About_#2: Zhang has been working to diversify Shenzhen-listed Suning with investments in cosmetic surgery, hospitals and health insurance companies.
About_#3: Zhang's brother Zhang Jindong is also a billionaire.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Kiev State Economic University
About_#1: Konstyantin Zhevago owns a majority stake in London-listed mining firm Ferrexpo, which declared force majeure during Ukraine war for certain customers.
About_#2: Ferrexpo established a $7.5 million humanitarian fund on March 7 to provide housing, free meals, childcare support and medical supplies, among other services.
About_#3: Zhevago, a member of Ukraine's parliament from 1998 to 2019, stepped down as the firm's CEO in late 2019 amid an investigation by Ukraine's state prosecutor office.
About_#4: He is wanted for questioning about alleged money laundering and embezzlement at his former bank, Finance & Credit, which went bankrupt in 2015.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Suzhou University of Science and Technology
About_#1: Zhu Xingliang is the largest shareholder of Suzhou Gold Mantis Construction Decoration, a pioneer in China's interior design and decoration industry.
About_#2: Zhu founded Suzhou Gold Mantis in 1993.
About_#3: Gold Mantis has done interior/exterior decorating, landscaping, design and other work for some of China's eminent new structures.

Education: Medical Doctor, Nanjing University of Chinese Medicine
About_#1: Zhu Yiwen is the founder of Hygeia Healthcare, an operator of oncology-focused hospitals and radiotherapy centers in China.
About_#2: Zhu started his career in 2007 at the Affiliated Hospital of Xuzhou Medical University in China.
About_#3: Zhu majored in neurosurgery and obtained a graduate degree in clinical medicine from Nanjing Medical University in 1992.

Education: Chartered Accountant, Institute of Chartered Accountants of India
About_#1: Sanjay Agarwal is managing director and CEO of the Jaipur-headquartered AU Small Finance Bank.
About_#2: The bank has 811 branches across India and more than 2 million customers.
About_#3: The chartered accountant set up a finance company in 1996 and converted it into a bank in 2017.

Full Name: Hamad bin Jassim bin Jaber Al Thani
About_#1: Hamad bin Jassim Al Thani was prime minister of Qatar between 2007 and 2013; he also served as foreign minister from 1992 until 2013.
About_#2: His great uncle founded modern Qatar in 1971, and he's a cousin of the current Emir.
About_#3: Through an entity called Paramount Services Holdings, Al Thani owns 3% of Deustche Bank, his biggest publicly-traded holding.
About_#4: In 2016, he was mentioned in the "Panama Papers"--leaked files from Panama law firm Mossack Fonseca, which set up offshore entities for clients.
Did You Know?: Al Thani, known as HBJ, has a 436-foot superyacht, called Al Mirqab, worth an estimated $300 million, according to the Panama Papers.

Education: Bachelor of Commerce, Assumption College
About_#1: Betty Ang is the president and cofounder of Monde Nissin, one of the Philippines' largest food manufacturers.
About_#2: Ang's husband, Hoediono Kweefanus, is the company's vice-chairman and also owns shares in Monde Nissin along with her.
About_#3: Ang founded Monde Nissin in 1979 with her late father-in-law, Hidajat Darmono.
About_#4: Monde Nissin debuted on the Philippines' bourse in June 2021, raising 55.9 billion pesos ($1.1 billion) in what was the country's biggest-ever IPO.
Did You Know?: In February 2016 the company partnered with Indonesia's largest bread-products producer, Nippon Indosari, to begin operations in the Philippines.

About_#1: Christian Angermayer invests in life sciences, fintech, AI, psychedelics and cryptocurrencies through his family office Apeiron Investment Group.
About_#2: He made his first millions cofounding biotech firm Ribopharma with his college professors; he sold his stake when it merged with Alnylam in 2003.
About_#3: His Malta-based Apeiron owns shares in several publicly traded firms and private companies in the U.S., Germany, Canada and Australia.
About_#4: His holdings include psychedelics biopharma firm Atai Life Sciences and blockchain holding company Cryptology, alongside co-investor Mike Novogratz.

About_#1: Mika Anttonen heads and owns a majority stake in the nearly $8 billion (sales) Scandinavian fuel distributor St1 Group.
About_#2: Anttonen uses profits to finance projects he hopes will combat climate change and eventually replace oil, such as developing bioethanol from trash.
About_#3: He got his start as an oil trader working for Finland-based oil refiner and marketer, Neste Oyj, in the early 1990s.
About_#4: He founded his own company, Greenergy Baltic, in 1995. He renamed it St1 in 2005.
Did You Know?: Anttonen plays hockey in his spare time and is a fan of the New York Rangers.

About_#1: Jose Maria Aristrain is the former owner of steelmaker Arcelor, which was acquired by Mittal Steel in 2006 for nearly $34 billion in cash and stock.
About_#2: He is now believed to own a 2% stake of ArcelorMittal, among the world's largest steel companies.
About_#3: He owns about 10% of Spain's Tubacex, the second-largest global manufacturer of seamless stainless steel tubes.
About_#4: Aristrain inherited the business conglomerate when he was 24 years old, after his father, also named José María Aristrain, died in 1986 in a helicopter crash on the Côte d'Azur.

About_#1: Emilio Azcárraga Jean inherited control of Mexico's largest television company, Televisa, after his father, Emilio Azcárraga Milmo, died in 1997.
About_#2: Televisa was founded by his grandfather, Emilio Azcárraga Vidaurrieta.
About_#3: After two decades at the helm, Azcárraga decided to step down as Televisa's CEO at the beginning of 2018, but retains his role as chairman.
