Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Michigan State University; Master of Business Administration, University of Western Ontario
About_#1: Thomas Bailey's fortune comes from mutual fund giant Janus, which he founded in Denver in 1969.
About_#2: Bailey sold his 12% stake in Janus to its parent, Stillwell Financial, for $1.2 billion (pretax) in 2001-2002.
About_#3: Janus had two decades of remarkable returns, but its funds began losing money in the early 2000s.
About_#4: He served as the CEO of Janus for 33 years until 2002 and as chairman through 2003.
In Their Own Words: Too much money can ruin a good mutual fund.

Education: Master of Arts/Science, Finance Academy under the Government of the Russian Federation
About_#1: Andrei Bokarev runs Transmashholding, Russia's biggest producer of rolling stock for railways and subway systems.
About_#2: Bokarev previously headed Krutrade AG, which ran the export operations of the Kuzbassrazrezugol coal company.
About_#3: Bokarev is a partner in most of his senior partner Iskander Makhmudov's projects including Transmashholding, Kuzbassrazrezugol and UGMK.
About_#4: He owns half of Ust-Luga Oil company, largest oil terminal in Europe with capacity of 30 million tons per year.
Did You Know?: In June of 2018 Alexei Krivoruchko, Bokarev's former partner, was appointed deputy minister of defense of Russia.

About_#1: Stéphane Bonvin founded Investis, a Swiss residential real estate firm, in 1994.
About_#2: Investis' portfolio consists of more than 3,000 apartments in the Lake Geneva region.
About_#3: He took Investis public in 2016 on Swiss stock exchange SIX.
About_#4: In 2006, Bonvin cofounded a private equity group called Patrimonium, where he was managing director until 2015.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Al Salam Institute
About_#1: Ashok Boob gets his wealth from his holding in specialty chemicals maker Clean Science and Technology.
About_#2: The Pune company made a stellar debut on the stock market in July 2021, listing at a 98% premium.
About_#3: The bulk of the company's $70 million revenue comes from specialty chemicals that are used in everything from infant food formulas to cosmetics to cereals.
About_#4: It also makes pharma intermediaries which are used in cough syrups and anti-retrovirals.

About_#1: Ludwig Theodor Braun owns 10% of the medical device company B. Braun Melsungen, which began in 1839 as a small pharmacy that sold herbal remedies.
About_#2: His father, Ludwig Georg Braun, took the reins in 1977, when the company had just $24 million in annual sales (now around $8 billion).
About_#3: A sixth-generation family member, Ludwig Theodor is the youngest son of Ludwig Georg. His sister Anna Maria is CEO of B. Braun.
About_#4: Today, with more than 64,000 employees globally, B. Braun manufactures products ranging from infusion and injection solutions to surgical instruments.

About_#1: Friederike Braun-Luedicke owns 12% of the medical device maker B. Braun Melsungen, which began in 1839 as a small pharmacy that sold herbal remedies.
About_#2: Her mother's cousin Ludwig Georg Braun took the reins in 1977, when the company had just $24 million in annual sales (now around $8 billion).
About_#3: Today, with 60,000 employees globally, B. Braun manufactures products ranging from infusion and injection solutions to surgical instruments.
About_#4: Friederike works for B. Braun as a Manager in Personnel and Organizational Development.
Did You Know?: Friederike Braun-Luedicke is a sixth-generation family member and her mother, Barbara, is a member of the company's supervisory board.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Massachusetts Institute of Technology
About_#1: Pradip Burman gets his wealth from his stake in listed consumer goods outfit Dabur.
About_#2: He chairs privately held Ayurvet, which makes a range of herbal products for animals.
About_#3: Burman is chairman of Dabur Nepal and also sits on the board of Aviva Life Insurance.
About_#4: In 2015, he founded the Mobius Foundation, a non-profit aimed at promoting environmental sustainability.

About_#1: Cai Hongbin's fortune comes from his stake in Jiangsu Hengrui Medicine.
About_#2: Jiangsu Hengrui is one of China's largest pharmaceutical companies, employing more than 20,000 people.
About_#3: Fellow Chinese billionaire Sun Piaoyang is Hengrui's chairman.

Education: Bachelor of Business Administration, Boston University
About_#1: Chang Kuo-Cheng is the third son of shipping tycoon Chang Yung Fa, who died in 2016 at the age of 88.
About_#2: In 1968 Yung Fa founded Evergreen Marine, now one of the world's largest transportation companies.
About_#3: Brothers Kuo-Hua, Kuo-Ming and Kuo-Cheng also inherited stakes in EVA Airways and hotels in Taiwan, mainland China, Paris and Bangkok.

Education: Master of Arts, Zhejiang University
About_#1: Chen controls Wolong Real Estate, a property developer, and Wolong Electric, a supplier of motors, power transmission equipment and batteries.
About_#2: Wolong Electric acquired the parent of ATB Group of Austria in 2011; it's one of the largest suppliers of industrial electric drive systems in Europe.
About_#3: Chen's daughter Yanni chairs Wolong Real Estate.

About_#1: Chen Xueling is vice president and cofounder of Shanghai-headquartered M&G Stationary, a supplier of stationary products.
About_#2: Chen is the elder sister of fellow billionaires Chen Huwen and Chen Huxiong, who are also cofounders of M&G.
About_#3: M&G Stationary was founded in 1996.

About_#1: Cheng Lili chairs Jiangsu Lihua Animal Husbandry, a chicken breeder and supplier of poultry feed.
About_#2: Lihua debuted at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange on Feb. 28, 2019, after raising $171 million in an IPO.
About_#3: Lihua is headquarterd in the eastern Chinese city of Changzhou.

About_#1: Yvon Chouinard, founder of outdoor clothing and gear retailer Patagonia, gave all the stock in the company to a trust and a nonprofit in September 2022.
About_#2: Chouinard spelled out the ownership transfer in an open letter on Patagonia's website; the nonprofit, Holdfast Collective, is dedicated to fighting environmental crises and defending nature.
About_#3: His apparel business took off in the 1970s when Chouinard imported rugby shirts from England and sold them to climbers.
About_#4: Since 1985, Patagonia has set aside 1% of sales to finance grassroots environmental groups in the U.S. and abroad. Revenues hit $800 million in 2017.
Did You Know?: On Black Friday 2011, Patagonia ran a full-page ad in The New York Times encouraging customers not to buy its products, but to reuse or repair items instead.
In Their Own Words: If you want to understand the entrepreneur, study the juvenile delinquent. The delinquent is saying with his actions, "This sucks. I'm going to do my own thing."

About_#1: Luigi Cremonini supplies hamburger meat to McDonald's and Burger King in Italy and other countries through his privately-held Inalca SpA.
About_#2: Born to poor farmers in an Italian village near Modena, Cremonini got his start by opening a small butcher shop in 1963.
About_#3: Beginning in the late 1970s he diversified into cured meats, distribution and catering and within a decade expanded the business internationally.
About_#4: Today Cremonini Group employs more than 18,500 workers all over the globe and generated $4.2 billion in revenues in 2018.
Did You Know?: In 1994 the University of Bologna awarded Cremonini an honorary degree in Veterinary Medicine.
In Their Own Words: Flying low but always flying.

About_#1: A scion of a Silicon Valley investing dynasty, Tim Draper is a founding partner of venture capital firm Draper Fisher Jurvetson.
About_#2: Draper has made hundreds of VC investments in companies including Tesla and Theranos, and has made a fortune investing in cryptocurrencies.
About_#3: In 2014, he bought 29,656 bitcoins confiscated by U.S. Marshals from the shuttered Silk Road black market for $18.7 million, or just $632 per coin.

Education: Doctorate, Moscow State University
About_#1: Gleb Fetisov joined Mikhail Fridman's Alfa Group in 1995. He later led the group's takeover of an aluminum plant in Siberia.
About_#2: Fetisov sold all of his business interests in 2014, including a stake in telecom outfit Vimpelcom, for approximately $1.4 billion in cash.
About_#3: Soon after cashing out, he was arrested and accused of embezzling assets of now-bankrupt My Bank in Moscow.
About_#4: In February 2015, he paid $200 million to creditors and was soon after released from prison.
Did You Know?: Fetisov was a member of the Federation Council, the upper house of Russia's parliament, from 2001 to 2009.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Princeton University; Master of Business Administration, Stanford University
About_#1: Robert "Bob" Fisher is one of three sons of Gap founders Donald (d. 2009) and Doris Fisher.
About_#2: He chairs Gap's board and is managing director of the Fisher family's investment firm, Pisces Inc.
About_#3: Like his two billionaire brothers, he attended Princeton, where he played tennis and majored in English, before heading to Stanford's business school.
About_#4: A philanthropist, Fisher cofounded the California Water Foundation, which focuses on improving California's water supply, in 2010.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Princeton University; Master of Business Administration, Stanford University
About_#1: William Fisher is one of the heirs to the Gap retail fortune. He sits on Gap's board alongside his brother Robert.
About_#2: Known as "Bill," he was founder and president of the International Division for Gap Inc. and expanded the company into Canada, Japan and Europe.
About_#3: He is CEO of Manzanita Capital, a London-based private equity firm he founded in 2001.
About_#4: Bill's parents Doris and Don (d. 2009) founded retailer Gap in San Francisco in 1969.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University
About_#1: J. Christopher Flowers runs private equity firm J.C. Flowers & Co., which focuses on the financial services sector.
About_#2: Flowers studied math at Harvard and then joined Goldman Sachs in 1979, becoming a partner in 1988.
About_#3: He struck out on his own a decade later and in 2000 bought a beleaguered Japanese bank, Long Term Credit Bank, which had been nationalized in 1998.
About_#4: He resold the business to the public under the moniker Shinsei Bank in 2004; the partners reaped $2.3 billion.
Did You Know?: Flowers joined board of directors for the Kasparov Chess Foundation, named for legendary chess grandmaster Garry Kasparov, in 2015.

About_#1: Bernd Freier opened his first clothing store in Wuerzburg, Germany in 1969. He named it Sir Oliver after the hero of Dickens' novel Oliver Twist.
About_#2: The company, whose name was later shortened to s.Oliver, initially focused on standard mix-and-match casual fare.
About_#3: It has diversified into underwear, beachwear and nightwear, as well as licensing and sub-labels for evening clothes and trend-focused collections.
About_#4: With annual sales of around $1.5 billion, s.Oliver now has more than 700 stores and partner stores in over 20 countries.
Did You Know?: Freier's son Christian has taken his place on s.Oliver's advisory council.
In Their Own Words: I was always good at one thing: sales. If somebody wanted a pair of pants, I sold him three.

Education: Master of Business Administration, University Of Texas At Arlington
About_#1: Geng Diangen is the chairman of Beijing Sinnet Technology, a supplier of Internet data services.
About_#2: Sinnet was listed on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2014.
About_#3: Geng founded the company in 1999.

Education: Diploma, High School
About_#1: Dan Gertler built a fortune through mining ventures in Africa, primarily in the Democratic Republic of Congo.
About_#2: In February 2017, he sold his stake in two mines in the Congo to commodities giant Glencore for $960 million; Gertler made an estimated $400 million.
About_#3: In December 2017, the U.S. government placed Gertler on its sanctions list for his alleged corrupt business deals in the Congo.
About_#4: In June 2018, the U.S. levied sanctions against 14 additional companies of his, including Fleurette Africa Resources and Ventora Development Sasu.
Did You Know?: Gertler's grandfather, Moshe Schnitzer, cofounded the Israel Diamond Exchange in 1947.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Dartmouth College; Master of Business Administration, University of Michigan
About_#1: David Girouard is the CEO of New York City-based fintech lender Upstart, which he cofounded in 2012.
About_#2: Upstart listed on the Nasdaq in December 2020, raising about $240 million and nabbing a $12.2 billion market cap on its first day of trading.
About_#3: Girouard became a billionaire in March 2021 after a blockbuster earnings release sent shares soaring; he owns 14% of Upstart's stock.
About_#4: A Dartmouth College graduate, he dabbled in consulting at Accenture's Boston office before pursuing an MBA at the University of Michigan.

Education: Chartered Accountant, University of Texas
About_#1: John Goff made a fortune selling his Crescent Real Estate to Morgan Stanley for $6.5 billion in 2007, just before the financial crisis.
About_#2: With Barclays Plc., Goff bought it back at a steep discount after the market collapse
About_#3: When the joint venture ended in 2017, Goff regained full control of Crescent.
About_#4: The real estate group's most prized asset is Canyon Ranch, the legendary wellness spa and resort founded near Tuscon, Ariz.
Did You Know?: Goff got his big break working for famed Fort Worth investing guru Richard Rainwater.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard College; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Harvard Law School
About_#1: Golub is the founder of Golub Capital, a $35 billion in assets credit investor that specializes in loans to midsized buyout firms like Thoma Bravo.
About_#2: Lawrence recruited his younger brother David to join Golub Capital in 2003. David is now CEO of Golub's publicly traded finance vehicle.
About_#3: Golub Capital started as a buyout firm, but after a failed deal in 2000, Lawrence pivoted to lending.
About_#4: Before the crisis, Golub Capital was a small lender with $1.5 billion in assets. It's since topped league tables and assets are up fifteen-fold.

Education: Drop Out, Stockholm University
About_#1: Sven Hagströmer is the founder and chairman of publicly traded investment company Creades and online broker Avanza.
About_#2: Hagströmer co-founded HQ AB, later HQ Bank, in 1990. The bank collapsed in 2010 because of an overvalued trading portfolio.
About_#3: Creades was one of the first investors in Klarna, investing as early as 2007, but sold their stake in 2014.
About_#4: Hagströmer was, for the first three seasons, one of the sharks in the Swedish version of Shark Tank.

About_#1: Fahed Hariri is the youngest son of the late billionaire Rafik Hariri, who was Lebanon's prime minister and was assassinated while in office in 2005.
About_#2: In 2012, Fahed sold his shares in family construction firm Saudi Oger to his brother Saad Hariri, who was Lebanon's prime minister until Oct. 2019.
About_#3: He invested some of the proceeds in real estate in New York, Paris and Monte Carlo and in now beleaguered Lebanese banks.
About_#4: He is also developing residential buildings in Beirut.
Did You Know?: He's an avid collector of modern and contemporary European and American art. Collection includes Picasso, Louise Bourgeois and Lucian Freud.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Lehigh University
About_#1: Former hippie Richard Hayne opened his first apparel shop with his ex-wife in the mid-70s near the University of Pennsylvania with only $4,000.
About_#2: Today, Urban Outfitters is a nationwide chain with more than 200 locations and over $3.9 billion in revenue.
About_#3: Hayne took Urban Outfitters public in 1993 and owns nearly a quarter of the company with his wife.
About_#4: Hayne became the company's CEO in 2012 after former CEO Glen Senk left to run New York-based jeweler and watchmaker David Yurman.
Did You Know?: Hayne also owns the 700-acre Doe Run Dairy farm in Pennsylvania, which produces cheese.

About_#1: He Yamin chairs Chengdu Leejun Industrial, a supplier of equipment to the cement and mining industries.
About_#2: He Yamin's daughter He Jia is being groomed as his successor; she and her father each hold about 1/3 of the company's shares.
About_#3: Leejun was founded in 1999 in the central Chinese city of Chengdu.

About_#1: Michael Heine started Netwealth in 1999 with his brother Leslie, who has since sold down his shares, and son Matt.
About_#2: Michael's father, Walter, built a steel-trading business, Heine Bros., after fleeing Nazi Germany. It expanded into property and mortgage lending.
About_#3: Michael worked with his father in international financing, mortgage lending and property development, then started a fund-management business in 1982.
About_#4: He sold his business in 1999 and launched Netwealth, which went public in 2017 and now has more than A$56 billion in funds under management.

About_#1: Heikki Herlin, born 1990, is an heir to the Kone fortune in Finland.
About_#2: He is the great-great-grandson of Harald Herlin, who invested in Kone Elevators in 1924.
About_#3: Heikki Herlin inherited shares in several Scandinavian companies from his father Niklas, who died in 2016.
About_#4: His most valuable holdings are stakes in Kone and Cargotec, a producer of machinery for heavy duty cargo ships.
Did You Know?: Like his father, Herlin is a journalist and writer. In 2020, he published a memoir about his father's life.

Education: Master of Science, Purdue University; Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Shanghai Jiaotong University
About_#1: Hong Feng is a cofounder of Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi.
About_#2: Hong is the senior vice president in charge of the firm's mobile operating system, MIUI.
About_#3: Hong Feng worked at Siebel, then he joined Google as a senior software engineer who oversaw apps like Google Calendar and Google Map.
About_#4: He was later a senior product manager at Google China and led the China team to develop a series of local products like Google Music.

About_#1: Hu Kun chairs Shenzhen-listed Contec Medical Systems, a supplier of medical instruments.
About_#2: Contec went public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in August 2020.
About_#3: More than 70% of Contec's revenue comes from overseas.

About_#1: Huang Shanbing chairs Shenzhen-listed Jiangsu JieJie Microelectronics, a microchip maker.
About_#2: Huang founded the predecessor of Jiejie Microelectronics in Qidong in Jiangsu province in 1995.
About_#3: From 1974 to 1995, Huang worked in a transistor crystal valve factory in Jiangsu Province.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Alexandria; Ph.D, University of Birmingham; Master, University of Bradford
About_#1: Mohammed "Mo" Ibrahim founded Celtel International in 1998, one of the first mobile phone companies serving Africa and the Middle East.
About_#2: He sold Celtel to Kuwait's Mobile Telecommunications Company for $3.4 billion in 2005 and pocketed $1.4 billion.
About_#3: Since then, he's focused on fighting corrupt leadership in Africa through the Mo Ibrahim Foundation, directed by his daughter, Hadeel.
About_#4: He has a majority stake in Satya Capital, a private equity fund that invests in African startups, such as Pan-African digital firm company Cellulant.
Did You Know?: Ibrahim also owns the majority of assets in Satya Capital, a private equity fund that invests in African businesses, education and healthcare.

About_#1: Hedda im Brahm-Droege and her husband Walter Droege founded Droege Group in 1988. It is one of the world's largest advisory and investment practices.
About_#2: Droege Group has a hybrid business model, providing expertise to consulting clients and making "buy-and-build" investments, which is now its focus.
About_#3: By providing capital, management resources and "value-add" know-how, it follows an "Entrepreneurship-as-a-Service" principle in engaging with clients.
About_#4: In 2018, Ernest-W. Droege, the couple's eldest son, joined the management board and succeeded his father as CEO.
Did You Know?: Hedda owns 22% of the company and is vice-chairwoman of the supervisory board. Walter, who remains on the board of directors, owns the rest.

About_#1: Rameshchandra Jain is the chairman and managing director of textile company Bhilosa Industries, which makes everything from yarn to knitted fabric.
About_#2: He founded the Mumbai-based company in 1988 to make textured yarn.
About_#3: Jain's younger son, Sandeep, is the CEO of the company, while his older son, Kumarpal, is a director.

About_#1: Laurent Junique is the CEO and founder of Singapore-based call center and business process outsourcing firm TDCX.
About_#2: TDCX went public on the New York Stock Exchange in October 2021; Junique owns 87% of the company's shares.
About_#3: Junique, a French citizen, founded TDCX as a 29-year-old in 1995 after a two-year stint at consumer goods giant Unilever.
About_#4: TDCX's two largest clients are Facebook and Airbnb, which collectively made up 62% of revenues in 2020.

About_#1: Zbigniew Juroszek is the founder of Atal S.A., a real estate developer listed in Warsaw, Poland.
About_#2: Juroszek first founded Atal in 1990 as a supplier to clothing manufacturers, before investing in real estate.
About_#3: He built his first residential projects in 2003; Atal now develops properties in Katowice, Warsaw, and other major Polish cities.
About_#4: He now runs his business with his son Mateusz, who is the CEO of gambling company STS.

About_#1: Along with family, Chatchai Kaewbootta owns a big stake in Srisawad, one of Thailand's largest providers of loans against motorcycles and cars.
About_#2: Srisawad has nearly 5,000 branches and also provides nano-finance loans.
About_#3: Son of a tractor distributor, he joined the family trade then went on to become a dealer for Honda motorcycles.
About_#4: Chatchai started the business in 1984, sold to AIG in 2007, but got back into the same business with a new name in 2009.
Did You Know?: Srisawad's service slogan is "Mee Baan Mee Rod Ngern Sod Than Jai," which translates to "Your car and/or your home can bring you instant cash."

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Marymount California University
About_#1: Shirley Kao is the biggest individual shareholder of Uni-President, the food and beverage conglomerate cofounded by her father, Kao Chin-Yen, in 1967.
About_#2: She was the sole inheritor of her father's fortune after he died in 2016.
About_#3: She's been a board member at Uni-President since 2013 and has chaired the group's health and beauty-related subsidiaries and its department stores.
About_#4: Her husband, Alex Lo, was promoted to CEO of the group in 2007 and doubled as its chairman after his father-in-law retired in 2013.
Did You Know?: Kao and her husband, Alex Lo, were high school sweethearts, but had a second chance at love only after her first marriage failed.

About_#1: The adopted daughter of Inan and Suna Kirac, Ipek Kirac is an heir to one of Turkey's largest conglomerates, Koc Holding.
About_#2: Koc Holding operates in four main sectors: energy, autos, durable consumer goods and finance. Ipek Kirac joined its board of directors in 2016.
About_#3: Other activities include technology, food, retail, tourism, agriculture and shipbuilding. Koc Group has 14 companies traded on the Borsa İstanbul.
About_#4: Since 2012, Ipek Kirac has served as chairwoman and CEO of Sirena Marine Maritime Industry and Trade, a subsidiary of her father's Kiraca Holding.
Did You Know?: Her mother's condition led Ipek to study biology at Brown University. She graduated in 2007.

Education: Master of Science, University for Applied Sciences in Konstanz
About_#1: Carsten Koerl founded and runs sports data firm Sportradar, which he took public on the Nasdaq in September 2021; he owns about 32% of the company.
About_#2: Sportradar, based in Switzerland, helps sports leagues compile data like in-game statistics and distribute it to media companies and betting operators.
About_#3: He made his first entry into the sports data space in 1997 by founding Bwin (then called betandwin), later taking it public on Austria's Vienna Stock Exchange.
About_#4: He earned a master's degree in electronic and microprocessor engineering from the University for Applied Sciences in Konstanz, Germany.
Did You Know?: Koerl developed a love for sports and competition during his youth and was an avid fan of German soccer club Bayern Munich.
In Their Own Words: I'll smash myself to beat you in whatever you choose. Tennis, table tennis, you can jump from a helicopter, I will try this with you.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Moscow Power Engineering Institute
About_#1: Andrei Kosogov is a member of Russian conglomerate Alfa Group's supervisory board and is in charge of its investment units.
About_#2: Kosogov cofounded international investment company LetterOne in 2013 and now sits on its board.
About_#3: LetterOne has invested in oil and gas firm Wintershall Dea, cellular companies Vimpelcom and Turkcell, and health food chain Holland & Barrett.
Did You Know?: Born in Estonia when it was part of the Soviet Union, Kosogov graduated from Moscow Power Engineering Institute.

Education: Bachelor of Science, University of California, Santa Barbara
About_#1: John Krystynak is a cofounder of AppLovin, which makes mobile games and provides marketing services to app developers.
About_#2: He owns 8.2% of the Palo Alto, California-based company.
About_#3: Krystynak served as AppLovin's chief technology officer until July 2020.
About_#4: AppLovin was founded in 2012 by Krystynak, Adam Foroughi and Andrew Karam and was bootstrapped for years, then raised $800 million from KKR.

About_#1: John Kusuma draws his wealth from a majority stake in Bank Aladin Syariah, previously Bank Net Syariah.
About_#2: He acquired shares in the bank in 2019 and increased his holding in 2020.
About_#3: The bank got listed in February 2021. Shares have soared since on expectations of the bank providing digital banking services.
About_#4: Kusuma belongs to the third generation of the family behind cigarette-maker Nojorono Tobacco International.
Did You Know?: Bank Aladin Syariah's president is Dyota Marsudi, the son of Indonesia's foreign affairs minister, Retno Marsudi.

About_#1: Indonesian-born Hartono Kweefanus is chairman of Monde Nissin, a food manufacturer based in the Philippines known for its instant noodles and snacks.
About_#2: Kweefanus' wealth lies in a significant personal stake in the company.
About_#3: His late father cofounded Monde Nissin in 1979 together with Betty Ang, the company's president.
About_#4: Kweefanus is the brother-in-law of Ang, who's also among the richest people in the Philippines.

About_#1: Kwek Leng Peck is the executive chairman of Singapore-listed Hong Leong Asia, which makes, trades and distributes cement and steel products.
About_#2: Singapore billionaires Kwek Leng Beng and Kwek Leng Kee are his cousins.
About_#3: Kwek has a board seat in the family's Hong Leong Finance.
About_#4: He inherited a stake in Hong Leong Group from his father, Kwek Hong Leong, who cofounded it with the fathers of Kwek Leng Beng and Kwek Leng Kee.

Education: Masters in Computer Engineering, University of Tartu
About_#1: Kristo Käärmann cofounded cross-border payments startup Transferwise in 2011 and took it public as Wise in July 2021 on the London Stock Exchange.
About_#2: Wise offers low-cost money transfers across 56 different currencies, allowing users to avoid big banking fees for moving money abroad.
About_#3: Käärmann and cofounder Taavet Hinrikus became Estonia's first two billionaires. The pair met while working in London.
About_#4: Käärmann and Hinrikus started Wise after having become sick of losing money to their banks in fees charged for sending money to Estonia.

About_#1: In 1984, Guy Laliberté, a former street performer, cofounded Cirque du Soleil, which would become one of the world's biggest entertainment companies.
About_#2: His empire began with a show, funded by $1 million from the Canadian government, put on for the 450th anniversary of the discovery of Canada.
About_#3: The celebration went global, and the shows have been performed for more than 180 million spectators across more than 450 cities in 60 countries.
About_#4: He sold much of his 90% stake to U.S. private equity firm TPG Capital and Chinese investment group Fosun in 2015, but kept 10% of the company.
Did You Know?: Guy Laliberté was the first private Canadian citizen to explore space as part of a 2009 mission to raise awareness on water issues facing humankind.

Education: Master of Science, Hanyang University
About_#1: Lee Sang-ryul is founder and co-CEO of Chunbo, a chemicals company, which he started in 1997.
About_#2: Lee's wife, Seo Ja-won, is the other co-CEO of Chunbo.
About_#3: The company specializes in making chemicals for lithium-ion batteries that power electric vehicles.
About_#4: Lee was formerly head of development at Hanvit Chemical, a cleaning-supplies maker.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Seoul National University; Doctorate, Seoul National University
About_#1: Lee Seung-gun is the founder and CEO of Viva Republica, which operates the Korean finance app Toss.
About_#2: In June 2021, Viva Republica raised more than $400 million in a financing round that valued the company at over $7 billion.
About_#3: Viva Republica's investors include PayPal, Singapore sovereign-wealth fund GIC and venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins.
About_#4: Before starting Viva Republica in 2013, Lee was a dentist at a hospital affiliated with the Samsung Group.

About_#1: Li Hongjing is chairman and general manager of Shanghai-listed automotive electronic components manufacturer Autel Intelligent Technology.
About_#2: Li is also the founder and majority shareholder of drone supplier Autel Robotics.
About_#3: Li holds a MBA from Carnegie Mellon University.
About_#4: Li once worked at Pittsburgh National Corp. as an strategic analyst.

About_#1: Li Wanqiang is a cofounder and senior vice president of Xiaomi, one of the world's most popular smartphone brands.
About_#2: Li is in charge of marketing at the Chinese smartphone company, which went public in July 2018.
About_#3: Li previously worked at software firm Kingsoft with Xiaomi chairman Lei Jun.

About_#1: Lu Hongyan chairs Shanghai-listed online games company G-bits Network Technology.
About_#2: Its business benefited when Chinese people quarantining at home during the Covid-19 pandemic turned to online gaming for fun.
About_#3: Lu worked for telecom firms ZTE and Salira Optical Network Systems as a software engineer before he founded G-bits in 2004.

About_#1: Carsten Maschmeyer founded German financial services provider AWD Holding AG in 1988 and took it public in 2000.
About_#2: After Swiss Life acquired his AWD stake in 2008, Maschmeyer cofounded a consulting boutique focused on pension and health care plans.
About_#3: Today, he invests in renewable energy and startups and runs his own asset management company, Paladin.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Brigham Young University; Master of Science, California Polytechnic State University
About_#1: Todd McKinnon is the cofounder and CEO of Okta, a cloud security company.
About_#2: He previously served as a vice president at Salesforce, leaving in 2009 to found Okta.
About_#3: When he left, he created a Powerpoint presentation for his wife explaining why the risk was worth it.
About_#4: In late August 2020 he joined the ranks of the Forbes billionaires list.
In Their Own Words: When I look at stock performance, or my own net worth, I think that it's satisfying to see the company be successful. I'm putting my money where my mouth is.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais
About_#1: Rubens Menin founded MRV Engenharia in 1979, and turned it into Brazil's leading home builder; it trades on the Sao Paulo exchange.
About_#2: The company started in his home state of Minas Gerais and eventually spread to Brazil's southern states.
About_#3: He is also the founder of Banco Inter, a Brazilian bank that went public in 2018.
About_#4: In January 2019, Menin announced the launch of CNN Brasil, a licensed brand, which will begin operations in late 2019.

About_#1: Lőrinc Mészáros founded a small gas-fitting company in Felcsút, the hometown of Prime Minister Viktor Orbán, in 1990.
About_#2: Orban, who founded the Ferenc Puskas Football Academy, tapped Meszaros to be its president.
About_#3: Mészáros' gas-fitting company, Mészáros & Mészáros Ltd, is now a big player in the construction market thanks to contracts from the government.
In Their Own Words: That I have been able to come so far, God, luck and the person of Viktor Orbán have certainly played a role.

About_#1: In 1982 Ulrich Mommert took over Austrian lightning company ZKW, which was then on the brink of bankruptcy.
About_#2: He refocused ZKW on lighting technology for high-end automobiles, with clients such as BMW, Mercedes, Porsche and Audi.
About_#3: In 2018 Mommert sold the company to South Korean firm LG for $1.2 billion.
About_#4: Mommert owns a horse racing team and a trotting track in Berlin-Mariendorf.

About_#1: Park Kwan-ho is founder and chairman of Wemade, an online game developer, which he started in 2000.
About_#2: Park took the company public on Korea's technology-rich Kosdaq stock exchange in 2009.
About_#3: Previously, Park was the development team leader at Korean game developer ActozSoft.

About_#1: George Pedersen is the cofounder ManTech International, which he started in 1968 with a single contract with the U.S. Navy.
About_#2: Today, the defense and intelligence contractor has 8,700 employees and nearly $2.5 billion in revenue.
About_#3: Pedersen, a Staten Island native, owns a third of the firm, which is based in Virginia's Fairfax County.
About_#4: ManTech went public on the Nasdaq in February 2002

About_#1: David Penaloza Alanis is the son of David Penaloza Sandoval, the founder of construction and infrastructure company Grupo Tribasa.
About_#2: Tribasa, known for building and operating toll roads, ran into financial problems after the peso 1994 crisis and was forced to renegotiate its debts.
About_#3: The company began trading on the Mexican stock exchange again in 2005 and was renamed Promotora y Operadora de Infraestructura, or Pinfra, in 2006.
About_#4: During the restructuring, Penaloza Alanis replaced his father at the helm and as its largest shareholder.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Montan University
About_#1: Stefan Pierer is the CEO of $1.7 billion (sales) Pierer Mobility, one of the leading motorcycle manufacturers based in Austria.
About_#2: Pierer founded Cross holding group (now Pierer Industrie) in 1987 and is still its majority shareholder.
About_#3: He is also a member of the Supervisory Board of auto parts company SHW AG.
About_#4: He began his career as a sales assistant at heating and air conditioning maker Hoval.

About_#1: Murdaya Poo is founder of Central Cipta Murdaya, which has investments in engineering, IT, palm oil and plywood.
About_#2: His Jakarta International Expo is one of the city's biggest convention centers.
About_#3: He owns a substantial stake in listed property developer Metropolitan Kentjana where three of his four children have board seats.
Did You Know?: Poo once earned a living selling newspapers.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Oklahoma
About_#1: Michael Price, who ran MFP Investors, a New York-based hedge fund with over $1 billion in assets, died in March 2022 at age 70.
About_#2: Price began his career in finance as a research assistant at Heine Securities in 1975 and bought the company after Michael Heine died in 1988.
About_#3: Price increased the value of the firm's assets under management to $17 billion before selling it to Franklin Securities for $670 million in 1996.
About_#4: After the sale, Price stayed on at Franklin Securities as chairman and to manage the mutual funds. He left in 2001.
In Their Own Words: When you're looking at companies, one of the best things you can do is to go where they're not. You want to find companies where 40,000 don't go to the annual meeting, only 4 people go.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Northwestern University
About_#1: Leonid Radvinsky is the majority owner and a director of OnlyFans, a U.K.-based video and social site popular with online creators, especially adult entertainers.
About_#2: Born in Ukraine, he founded a porn website referral business called Cybertania while he was a student at Northwestern University.
About_#3: In 2018, Radvinsky bought a stake in OnlyFans from the U.K.-based Stokely family, who founded it in 2016.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, State University of Management
About_#1: In the mid-1990s Rahimkulov became chief executive and 10% owner of a joint venture between gas giant Gazprom and Hungary's oil and gas concern MOL.
About_#2: He also headed AEB, a Hungarian bank that Gazprom bought to process payments from its local customers; he later bought it from Gazprom.
About_#3: In 2007 he sold the bank and used the proceeds to buy shares in MOL and OTP, Hungary's largest bank. He also owns shares in Gazprom and VTB.
About_#4: He headed Gazprom's office in Hungary for a while.
Did You Know?: Before his return to Russia in 2008 he was the richest person in Hungary.
In Their Own Words: I don't have expensive real estate, yachts or planes. I have seven grandchildren. That's what brings real happiness.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Donetsk National University
About_#1: Andrei Rappoport worked for two billionaires, Michael Fridman and Michail Khodorkovsky, before becoming one himself.
About_#2: Rappoport worked at Fridman's Alfa-Bank for four years, then joined Khodorkovsky's YUKOS-Rosprom before moving to RAO Unified Energy System.
About_#3: After RAO UES, he bought Georgian Global Utilities and a Georgian water and power company that he then sold to BGEO Group in 2016.
About_#4: These days he has cashed out of nearly all his investments.
Did You Know?: Rappoport is a master of sports in high-speed pistol shooting.

Education: B.Com, Osmania University; Master of Business Administration, University of Manchester
About_#1: Dasari Uday Kumar Reddy is chairman and chief executive of the $320 million (revenue) cloud communications company Tanla Platforms based in Hyderabad.
About_#2: Tanla is a leader in the CPaaS or Communication Platform as a Service segment. It offers wireless data services for mobile messaging.
About_#3: Reddy founded Tanla as a short messaging service centre for telecom companies and took it public in 2006.
About_#4: Tanla's shares more than doubled in 2021 after it introduced two new platforms.
Did You Know?: His first venture was in real estate in 1993.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Catholic University of Buenos Aires; Master of Business Administration, IESE Business School
About_#1: Helena Revoredo is chair of Prosegur, a Spanish private security company known for its fleet of 9,000 yellow armored trucks and 150,000 employees.
About_#2: Her late husband, Herberto Gut, founded the company in 1976; Gut died in a car accident in 1997.
About_#3: Her son, Christian, is Prosegur's CEO, and her daughter Chantal Gut sits on the board.
About_#4: Prosegur, which went public in 1987, operates throughout Europe, Latin America and Asia.
Did You Know?: Revoredo was the first woman to sit on the board of Endesa, Spain's largest electric utility company.

About_#1: Duke Reyes is CEO of Reyes Holdings, a food and beverage distribution company with more than $30 billion in sales and nearly 30,000 employees.
About_#2: His older brothers Chris and Jude Reyes are co-chairmen, while younger brothers James and Tom are executives at a beer distribution subsidiary.
About_#3: His older brothers and their father started the group in 1974 with a small Schlitz beer distributor in South Carolina purchased for $740,000.
About_#4: Reyes Holdings owns food distributor Martin-Brower, beer distributor Reyes Beverage Group and two Coca-Cola bottlers.
Did You Know?: Reyes Beverage Group distributes 171 million cases of beer each year.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Anderson School of Management
About_#1: Saji is chairman of drinks powerhouse Suntory Holdings, which bought Beam, purveyor of Jim Beam and Maker's Mark bourbon, for $16 billion in 2014.
About_#2: He stepped down as president in 2014, turning the reins over to a non-family member for first time since the business was founded in 1899.
About_#3: Saji owns nearly 8% of Suntory Holdings, a closely held company. Its Suntory Beverage & Food unit trades on the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
About_#4: Saji's nephew Nobuhiro Torii, a great grandson of Suntory's founder, was promoted to COO and executive vice president of Suntory Holdings in 2016.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Cornell University; Medical Doctor, University of Virginia; Ph.D, University of Virginia
About_#1: Leonard Schleifer cofounded drugmaker Regeneron in 1988, and remains CEO of the Tarrytown, New York company.
About_#2: Schleifer took Regeneron public in 1991; he owns nearly 4% of the company's common stock.
About_#3: Sales of Regeneron's blockbuster drug Eylea, a treatment for macular degeneration, reached $4.6 billion in the U.S. in 2019.
About_#4: Regeneron has developed six FDA-approved medicines.
Did You Know?: Schleifer attended Cornell on scholarship and dreamed of a medical career.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Moscow Power Engineering Institute, Kazan
About_#1: Airat Shaimiev made his fortune as a co-owner of the TAIF Group, a large regional holding company with assets in the Republic of Tatarstan.
About_#2: In 2021, TAIF merged with petrochemical company Sibur. He and other TAIF shareholders got 15% of Sibur in exchange.
About_#3: Shaimiev is also CEO of Tatautodor, the government-owned group that does road construction and repair in Tatarstan.
Did You Know?: Airat's father, Mintimer Shaimiev, was Tatarstan's first president; his brother, Radik is also a billionaire.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Kazan Institute of Civil Engineering
About_#1: Radik Shaimiev made his fortune as a co-owner of the TAIF Group, a large regional holding company with assets in the Republic of Tatarstan.
About_#2: He and his cofounders bought up most of TAIF's assets during Russia's privatization era in the mid 1990s.
About_#3: In 2021, TAIF merged with petrochemical company Sibur. He and other TAIF shareholders got 15% of Sibur in exchange.
About_#4: His father, Mintimer Shaimiev, was Tatarstan's first president and his brother, Airat Shaimiev, is a fellow billionaire.
Did You Know?: TAIF was a sponsor of football club Rubin Kazan, which won the Russian Football Premier League In 2008 and 2009.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Delhi University
About_#1: Son of a schoolteacher from a small city in north India, Vijay Shekhar Sharma founded fast-rising mobile wallet Paytm in 2011.
About_#2: One of the biggest beneficiaries of India's 2016 demonetization, Paytm has notched up 400 million users and 25 million transactions daily.
About_#3: Sharma made a splash in August 2018 by getting Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway to invest $300 million in Paytm.
About_#4: Sharma has also created Paytm Mall, an e-commerce business and the Paytm Payments Bank.
Did You Know?: Paytm is an acronym for "pay through mobile."

Education: Medical Doctor, University of Mysore
About_#1: Cardiac surgeon Devi Shetty founded and runs Bangalore-based hospital chain Narayana Health.
About_#2: It has 21 hospitals, six heart centers and 19 primary care centers across India. It also has a hospital in the Cayman Islands.
About_#3: U.K.-trained Shetty founded Narayana Health as Narayana Hrudayalaya in the year 2000.
About_#4: Shetty took the company public in 2015. Biopharma billionaire Kiran Mazumdar-Shaw has a small stake in the company.
Did You Know?: He's often seen in his trademark blue surgeon's outfit.

Education: University of Pennsylvania
About_#1: A pioneer of the modern hedge fund, Michael Steinhardt closed his fund in 1995 after making a fortune in the 1990s from stellar returns.
About_#2: He came out of retirement a decade later to help run WisdomTree Investments, where he is still a leading shareholder.
About_#3: He retired as chairman of the board in October 2019.
About_#4: WisdomTree is a publicly traded asset manager that focuses on ETF investing.
In Their Own Words: For me, running hedge funds was an art. It was something that I thought I did exceptionally well, and most of the world did not. But they didn't care the way I did.

About_#1: Petter Stordalen and his three children own Scandinavia's largest hotel chain, Nordic Choice Hotels, which has 180 high-end hotels in five countries.
About_#2: In 2018 he signed over almost all ownership, but none of the control, of the hotel chain to his kids; he has vowed to keep control until his death.
About_#3: Stordalen got his start working at his father's grocery store at age 10, and later helped found one of Norway's largest commercial real estate firms.
About_#4: He married model-turned-physician Gunhild Stordalen in a lavish $5 million affair officiated by Irish singer Bob Geldof in 2010.
Did You Know?: A committed environmentalist, Stordalen chained himself to the U.K.'s Sellafield nuclear reprocessing plant in protest in 2002.

About_#1: Winarko Sulistyo gets his wealth from his stake in listed packaging paper producer Fajar Surya Wisesa.
About_#2: The company went public in 1994. It produces industrial paper, such as coated duplex boxboard and corrugated cardboard.
About_#3: The company's packaging paper is used by leading consumer good companies such as Nestle, Unilever and Samsung.
About_#4: In May 2019, he sold a 45% stake to Thailand's Siam Cement for $557 million.

Education: EMBA, Guanghua School of Management
About_#1: Sun Huaqing chairs Guangdong Marubi Biotechnology, a supplier of cosmetics and skin care products.
About_#2: Sun worked for an electric machinery factory in Chongqing more than 20 years ago.
About_#3: He founded the "Marubi" brand in Guangzhou in 2000.
About_#4: Marubi investors include L Capital, an affiliate of LVMH.

About_#1: Luc Tack is managing director of weaving machine and cast iron parts manufacturer Picanol Group. He joined the Belgian company in 2009.
About_#2: He's now a controlling shareholder in Picanol, owning over 90% of the company.
About_#3: Tack is also CEO and executive director of plastic and chemical manufacturer Tessenderlo Group, which reported over $2 billion in revenue in 2019.
About_#4: Tack requested emancipation from his parents at 18 so that he could legally start his first business, an importer of American wood products.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Far Eastern University
About_#1: Lucio Tan is the founder and chairman of the $1.7 billion (2021 sales) LT group, which has interests in tobacco, spirits, banking and property development.
About_#2: In 1982, Tan established Asia Brewery. Now a subsidiary of LT, the brewery was the only one then to compete with the market leader San Miguel.
About_#3: His eldest son Michael is president of LT group.
About_#4: Tan's 29-year-old grandson Lucio Tan III was appointed vice chairman and chief operating officer of LT Group in May 2022.
Did You Know?: Lucio Tan enjoys riding helicopters.
In Their Own Words: Even the accomplished suffers setbacks sometimes. The more bitter the lessons, the greater the successes will be.

About_#1: Yoshikazu Tanaka's company Gree develops free-to-play mobile and social-network-based games.
About_#2: He founded the company in 2004 and took it public in 2008.
About_#3: Tanaka is the company's chairman and CEO; he owns a substantial stake.

About_#1: Sam Tarascio owns a portfolio of real estate across Melbourne, including a business park, two distribution sites, a large shopping mall and a market.
About_#2: Tarascio, who emigrated from Italy in the 1950s, also owns several inner-city apartment developments.
About_#3: He started out in property development in the 1960s by building a warehouse for German pharmaceutical company Hoechst, where he had worked in sales.
About_#4: That led him to establish logistics and industrial-development business Salta Properties, now run by his son Sam.
Did You Know?: Tarascio imported an olive press in 2014 for his Taralinga Estate on the Mornington Peninsula, near Melbourne.

About_#1: Alexander Tedja's real estate developer Pakuwon Jati was established in 1982 and went public in 1989.
About_#2: The listed company is known for its mixed-use developments that combine condos, hotels, malls and offices in Jakarta and Surabaya.
About_#3: Tedja started his career as an executive in the film industry in the 1970s.
About_#4: The company is developing a slew of new projects to rebound from the pandemic slowdown.
Did You Know?: An art lover, Tedja received the Distinguished Patron of the Arts in 2017 for his long-term loan of a collection of paintings to the National Gallery Singapore.

About_#1: Laurie Tisch's late father Bob (d. 2005) started Loews Corporation with his brother Laurence as a New Jersey hotel venture in 1946.
About_#2: Today, Loews is active in insurance, drilling rigs, natural gas pipelines, and hotels.
About_#3: Laurie's mother Joan Tisch (d. 2017) was the largest individual Loews shareholder with 6%. Laurie and her two siblings inherited her mother's stake.
About_#4: In 1991, her father Bob bought a 50% stake in the New York Giants football team for $75 million.
Did You Know?: An avid art collector, Laurie Tisch is a trustee at the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York City.

About_#1: Steven Tisch is chairman and executive vice president of NFL's NY Giants. His late father Bob paid $75 million in 1991 for a 50% stake in the team.
About_#2: Steven's father Bob Tisch (d. 2005) cofounded Loews Corp. with his brother Laurence as a New Jersey hotel venture in 1946.
About_#3: Today, Loews Corp., a publicly traded company, is active in insurance, drilling rigs, natural gas pipelines and hotels.
About_#4: Steven's mother Joan (d. 2017) was the largest individual shareholder (with 6%) of Loews, where his brother Jonathan is co-chairman.
Did You Know?: Steven is the only known person to have won both an Academy Award and a Super Bowl ring: he won an Oscar for producing Forrest Gump, and the Giants won two Super Bowls.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, University of Florence
About_#1: Stefania Triva is CEO and the largest shareholder of Italy-based Copan, one of the world's largest producers of flocked swabs for diagnostic tests.
About_#2: Founded in 1979 by her father, Giorgio, Copan initially distributed lab products and started to make swabs in 1982, when her brother Daniele joined the firm.
About_#3: Daniele succeeded Giorgio after his death in 2002; in 2003, he invented flocked swabs, which collect more sample material than regular cotton Q-tips.
About_#4: Stefania took over as CEO after Daniele's death in 2014; the Covid-19 pandemic led to a dramatic surge in demand for Copan's products.

Education: Bachelor of Science, De La Salle University
About_#1: Maria Uy and her husband Dennis founded Converge ICT Solutions, one of the Philippines' largest operators of high-speed internet.
About_#2: They took the company public in 2020, raising more than $500 million in what was one of the Philippines' largest IPOs in recent years.
About_#3: Maria serves as the company's president, Dennis as its CEO. The couple remains majority owners of the company.
About_#4: Converge ICT's fixed broadband services now reach more than 9.6 million homes in 440 cities and municipalities in the Philippines.

About_#1: Wim van der Leegte ran VDL Groep, one of Europe's largest privately held auto and bus manufacturers, for 50 years before retiring in November 2016.
About_#2: When he retired, his son Willem took over as president. Wim's other two children, Pieter and Jennifer, serve on the executive board.
About_#3: Van der Leegte sits on VDL's supervisory board and owns a majority of the company; his children own the rest.
About_#4: His late father, Pieter van der Leegte, founded the company in 1953.
Did You Know?: Van der Leegte started working at the firm when he was just 19 years old while studying at a technical college; within three months he was running the company.

About_#1: Civil engineer Thongma Vijitpongpun founded Pruksa in 1993 and built it intoThailand's biggest property developer of low-to-middle income housing.
About_#2: Pruksa, which is known for its affordable prefab townhouses, went public in 2005.
About_#3: In a 2016 restructuring, Thongma delisted Pruksa Real Estate and formed a new holding outfit, Pruksa Holding.
About_#4: Fewer project launches due to the pandemic, resulted in sales and net profit declining sharply in the first nine months of 2020.
Did You Know?: As a youngster, he helped his father hawk fish-maw soup.
In Their Own Words: I don't know where to spend cash. I'm usually working in the office.

About_#1: Wang is vice chairman of Yantai Jereh Oilfield Services Group,a supplier of oil exploration equipment.
About_#2: Jerehis headquartered in the coastal city of Yantai in China's Shandong Province.
About_#3: Jereh is founded by in 1999 by its chairman Sun Weijie, who is also a member of the 2021 Forbes Billionaires List.

About_#1: Wang chairs vaccine maker Chengdu Kanghua Biological Products and footwear supplier Zhejiang Aokang Shoes.
About_#2: Zhejiang Aokang Shoes went public on the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 2012.
About_#3: Chengdu Kanghua Biological Products went public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2020.

Education: Bachelor of Science, University of Florida
About_#1: Wayne Weaver is the chairman of shoe retailer Show Carnival.
About_#2: Together Weaver and his wife Delores are the largest individual shareholders of Shoe Carnival, with a 29% stake.
About_#3: He was the first owner of the NFL's Jacksonville Jaguars and owned a majority of the team for 18 years
About_#4: He sold his stake in the Jaguars to billionaire Shahid Khan in 2011 for $770 million

About_#1: Germany's shoe billionaire, Horst Wortmann established Wortmann KG in 1967, in the city of Detmold in North Rhine-Westphalia.
About_#2: Considered the European market leader in women's fashionable shoes, its brands include Tamaris, Marco Tozzi, Caprice, Jana and s.Oliver.
About_#3: Nephew Jens Beining developed "Agenda 2020" to prepare the company for future challenges, with special focus on online retail.
About_#4: Heir apparent Beining, who assumed operational management control in 2016, owns 10% of the company.

Education: University of California, Los Angeles
About_#1: Wu Chung-yi is the chairman of central Taiwan auto-parts-maker Fine Blanking.
About_#2: Most of his fortune comes from the 2007 sale of a stake he owned in Hong Kong-listed beverage-and instant-noodle-maker Tingyi.
About_#3: He is also known by his Western name Tony.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Tunghai University
About_#1: Wu founded WUS Printed Circuit in Taipei in 1972. Twenty years later he brought the business to Kunshan, Jiangsu.
About_#2: The printed-circuit board manufacturer went public in 2010.
About_#3: The company makes electrical equipment for telecom products, vehicles, data centers and semi-conductors, among other products.

About_#1: Yeh Kuo-I is the founder and group president of Inventec, which started as a maker of electronic notebooks in 1975.
About_#2: Inventec has since expanded into other consumer electronic products and today employs nearly 33,000 people.
About_#3: Apart from Inventec, Yeh also has stakes in Taiwan-based Win Semiconductors.
About_#4: His wealth includes stakes held by his wife, his two sons and his two daughters-in-law.

About_#1: Yu Faxiang chairs Sunriver Holding Group, which was founded as a tourism business in in Hainan in 1992.
About_#2: Sunriver Holding has stakes in animation company Zhejiang Sunriver Culture and highway construction firm Gourgen Traffic Construction.
About_#3: Sunriver Holding has 5,000 employees with the total asset of 45 billion yuan, or $6.4 billion, according to the company's website.

About_#1: Zeng Chaolin chairs Shenzhen-listed Tianshan Aluminum Group, a Chinese supplier of aluminum products.
About_#2: Tianshan's shares trade at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange; it's headquartered in Xinjiang.
About_#3: Shimge Pump Industry Group acquired Tianshan Aluminum Group in 2020 in a backdoor listing and changed its own name to Tianshan Aluminum Group.
About_#4: Brother Zeng Chaolin's brother Zeng Chaoyi is a director of the listed company.

Education: Doctorate, Zhejiang University
About_#1: Zheng Shusheng chairs Hangzhou DPtech Technologies, a supplier of network security products.
About_#2: DPTech is headquartered in the eastern Chinese city of Hangzhou.
About_#3: Zheng holds a Ph.D. in telecommunications and electronics.

About_#1: A. Jayson "Jay" Adair is the CEO of Dallas-based Copart, a leader in online auctions for used and totaled cars.
About_#2: He joined the company in 1989 at age 19 as a manager; Copart's founder, Willis Johnson, is Adair's father-in-law.
About_#3: Adair pioneered Copart's move into online auctions in 1998, and by 2003, the company eliminated in-person bids and put auctions 100% online.
About_#4: He took over as Copart's CEO in 2010 after Johnson stepped down and now owns about 4% of the company's stock.
Did You Know?: Adair owns a vineyard in Suisun Valley wine country in northern California.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Faculdade Dom Pedro II
About_#1: Consumer goods tycoon Joao Alvez de Queiroz Filho, known as Junior, cofounded Arisco, a cleaning products business, with his father in 1969.
About_#2: In 2000, he founded Hypermarcas, a Brazilian version of Unilever selling food, drugs, cleaning supplies, and beauty and personal hygiene products.
About_#3: Hypermarcas SA went public in 2008. It grew through acquisitions, new product launches and publicity with celebrities.
About_#4: Coty, founded in Paris in 1904, purchased the personal care and consumer goods units of Hypermarcas for a reported $1 billion in 2016.
In Their Own Words: I do not remember the things that I did well when I was starting my company. But I remember the mistakes I made very well.

About_#1: Ryuji Arai started Bic Camera, the electronics and appliances retailing giant, in 1978.
About_#2: The company posted $7.6 billion in revenue in the fiscal year through August 2021.
About_#3: Arai also owns stakes in temporary staffing firm Hit Communications Holdings and contact lens-maker Seed.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Florida State University
About_#1: Sara Blakely is founder and owner of shapewear brand Spanx, which sells undergarments, leggings, swimwear and maternity wear in over 50 countries.
About_#2: Blackstone announced it would buy a majority stake in Spanx in October 2021, valuing the company at $1.2 billion.
About_#3: She initially shilled her new invention, which became shapewear brand Spanx, on the sales floor at various Neiman Marcus stores.
About_#4: While Spanx is a celebrity favorite, Blakely is becoming a celebrity herself. She was a guest judge on 'Shark Tank' and had a cameo in 'Billions.'
Did You Know?: Her husband Jessie Itzler is the founder of private jet membership company Marquis Jets, which was acquired by Net Jets in 2010 for an undisclosed sum.
In Their Own Words: I did not have the most experience in the industry or the most money, but I cared the most.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Harvard University; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Harvard University
About_#1: Blankfein was CEO and chairman of financial behemoth Goldman Sachs from 2006 to 2018, when he was succeeded by David Solomon.
About_#2: Before leading Goldman Sachs, he worked under then-CEO Henry Paulson as the company's president and chief operations officer from 2004 to 2006.
About_#3: Blankfein first became a partner at the firm in 1988.
Did You Know?: Blankfein grew up in the projects in Brooklyn, graduated as a valedictorian from Thomas Jefferson High School before getting a Bachelor and JD degrees from Harvard.

About_#1: With fellow Ukrainian billionaire Ihor Kolomoyskyy, Henadiy Boholyubov founded PrivatBank with $1 million in capital in the early 1990s.
About_#2: Over the years it grew to be a key bank in Ukraine, handling more than a third of private deposits and serving about half the country's population.
About_#3: In 2016, Ukraine's government nationalized the bank; an investigation indicated large-scale fraud over a period of ten years.
About_#4: In December 2017, the U.K. froze more than $2.5 billion in assets belonging to Kolomoyskyy and Boholyubov. They denied wrongdoing.

Education: Master of Economics, Stockholm School of Economics
About_#1: Caspar Callerström joined Swedish investment company EQT AB in 1996.
About_#2: Callerström is chief operating officer and partner at now publicly traded EQT, which has roughly $81 billion in assets under management.
About_#3: EQT primarily invests in private equity, but has also put funds into venture capital, real estate and infrastructure.
About_#4: EQT has minted seven billionaires, nearly as many as Google or Facebook.

About_#1: Cao Kejian chairs Zhejiang Kaishan Compressor, China's biggest manufacturer of air compressors and rock drilling equipment.
About_#2: Cao owns 52% of Zhejiang Kaishan, which went public in 2011 and whose customers include giant GE.
About_#3: Cao holds a degree from Zhejiang University of Technology, where he majored in chemical machinery.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Istanbul Academy
About_#1: Turgay Ciner (pronounced "jin-ner"), who worked as an errand boy in tea shops during high school, presides over a fortune built on soda ash.
About_#2: Soda ash is used in glass, detergents and various industrial products. Ciner's Eti Soda and Kazan Soda are among the world's top producers.
About_#3: In 2015, Ciner acquired a controlling interest in a huge soda ash facility in Green River, Wyoming; it trades publicly under the name Ciner Resources.
About_#4: Ciner has tapped financing from the Industrial and Commercial Bank of China to expand soda ash production in Turkey and make big energy investments.

Education: Master of Science, Peking University; Ph.D, Princeton University
About_#1: Dai Lizhong chairs Sansure Biotech, a supplier of diagnostic kits.
About_#2: Dai holds undergraduate and graduate degrees from Peking University.
About_#3: He holds a PhD from Princeton University and did post-doctoral work in biochemistry at MIT.
About_#4: From 2000 to 2008, Dai worked for U.S.-based Gen-Probe, a maker of diagnostic products.

About_#1: At age 29, Pedro de Godoy Bueno is Brazil's youngest billionaire. He is CEO of Brazilian laboratory firm Diagnosticos da America SA.
About_#2: His late father, Edson de Godoy Bueno, was Brazil's richest healthcare billionaire. His sister, Camilla de Godoy Bueno Grossi, is also billionaire.
About_#3: Edson died of a heart attack in 2017 at age 73 and left most of his fortune to his children, Pedro and Camilla.
About_#4: His father's first wife, Dulce Pugliese de Godoy Bueno, cofounded healthcare firm Amil and is also a billionaire.

About_#1: Aydin Dogan owns 29% of Dogan Holding, a public company active in oil distribution, electricity production, real estate, tourism and e-commerce.
About_#2: He was once Turkey's biggest media boss but came into conflict with the policies of the Turkish government.
About_#3: In 2018, he sold his portfolio (including TV channels Kanal D and CNN Turk, and the newspapers Hurriyet, Posta and Fanatik) for around $1.1 billion.
About_#4: In 2012, he entered into a licensing deal with Donald Trump for an office tower and shopping mall project in Instanbul.
Did You Know?: In 2009, Dogan handed over management of the Dogan companies to his four daughters.
In Their Own Words: First honor, then health, then wealth.

About_#1: Wolfgang Egger is founder and CEO of publicly traded real estate company Patrizia AG.
About_#2: Based in Augsburg, Germany, it employs around 800 people across 24 global offices and manages over $50 billion in real estate assets.
About_#3: Egger started Patrizia in 1984 at the age of 19 and took it public in 2006.
About_#4: He remains the largest shareholder, with just over 50%.
Did You Know?: Egger's Patrizia Foundation has provided educational support to nearly 240,000 children and young people through its KinderHaus facilities.

About_#1: Gabriel Escarrer founded Meliá Hotels International, now one of the world's largest hotel chains, with a 60-room hotel when he was 21.
About_#2: Now in his late 80s, Escarrer sits atop an empire of more than 350 hotels and resorts in 35 countries.
About_#3: Escarrer is chairman, and his son, Gabriel Escarrer Jaume, is vice chairman and CEO. They live on Mallorca, an island off the coast of Spain.
About_#4: Together with his family, Escarrer owns nearly 54% of publicly-traded Melia Hotels International.
Did You Know?: Escarrer is an avid golfer and has been very involved with the Meliá Golf Tour.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business; Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Stanford University
About_#1: Richard Fairbank is the chairman and CEO of Capital One Financial, a U.S. bank known for its credit cards.
About_#2: He presided over the bank's creation in 1994, helping it branch out into credit card and loan services.
About_#3: He owns just under 1% of the bank's shares and has sold hundreds of millions of dollars of the stock over the years.
About_#4: He resides in the Washington D.C. area and is a part owner of the Washington Capitals professional ice hockey team.

About_#1: Benedicte Find is the daughter of the late Aage Louis-Hansen, founder of Danish healthcare company Coloplast.
About_#2: Coloplast provides medical devices and services in the fields of colostomy, continence and urology; products include colostomy bags and catheters.
About_#3: The company went public in 1983 and trades on the Copenhagen Stock Exchange. Find owns approximately 4% of Coloplast stock.
About_#4: Her brother, Niels Peter Louis-Hansen, is Coloplast's deputy chairman. He is also a billionaire.

About_#1: Paul Fireman bought the US distribution rights for a British company in 1979, turned it into Reebok and rode the sneakers & aerobics craze in the 80s.
About_#2: Nike pulled ahead in the early 1990s, and shareholders demanded that Fireman step down in 1996, which he eventually did.
About_#3: Fireman returned in 1999 and revived the business before selling it to Adidas for $3.8 billion in 2005, a deal that earned him $600 million.
About_#4: Fireman owns Liberty National Golf Course, a $250 million country club built on a New Jersey landfill overlooking the Statue of Liberty.
Did You Know?: Liberty National Golf club is one of the most exclusive courses in the world, with members reportedly paying $500,000 to join.

About_#1: Donald Friese's fortune stems from C.R. Laurence, which manufactures or distributes more than 65,000 products for the glass industry.
About_#2: In 2015 he sold C.R. Laurence to a big customer, Oldcastle BuildingEnvelope, a subsidiary of Irish conglomerate CRH, for $1.3 billion in cash.
About_#3: Friese grew up a poor orphan in rural Pennsylvania, going to work on a dairy farm at age 12 before enlisting in the Army after high school.
About_#4: After a three-year tour, he moved to California with just $125 and landed in the warehouse of C.R. Laurence, then a small distributor of supplies.
Did You Know?: When Friese sold C.R. Laurence, he gave his employees $85 million. All 1,600 longtime workers got a bonus check -- some for more than $1 million.
In Their Own Words: You know the saying, 'Some people are born with a silver spoon?' I didn't even have a spoon.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Waseda University
About_#1: Soichiro Fukutake inherited and expanded Benesse Holdings, which provides education and other services, including senior care and language classes.
About_#2: He now serves as an honorary advisor to the company. His son Hideaki Fukutake is a board member.
About_#3: The company is listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange; Fukutake's family owns a minority stake.
About_#4: In 2014 Benesse purchased Tokyo-based Minerva, which runs 400 English-language schools for children.
Did You Know?: The company's name, Benesse, is derived from Latin and means well-being.
In Their Own Words: Tokyo is chaos and madness, like New York. There is too much--too much entertainment, too many products, too many people.

About_#1: Antonio Gallardo Ballart's father founded pharmaceutical company Almirall in 1943 in Barcelona.
About_#2: When their father died in 1988, Antonio and his brother Jorge took over running Almirall.
About_#3: The company listed its shares in Madrid in 2007; Antonio owns about 25% of the company.
About_#4: Antonio Gallardo Ballart served as vice president and advisor until 2014, when he retired.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Harvard College; Master of Philosophy, Oxford University; Master of Business Administration, Stanford Business School
About_#1: Golub is president of Golub Capital and CEO of the $30 billion in assets firm's publicly traded finance arm.
About_#2: After stints at Centre Partners and a fund affiliated with Lazard, Golub joined his brother at Golub Capital in 2003.
About_#3: Golub is on the board of Burton Snowboards and also spends significant time backing Parkinson's research with the Michael J. Fox Foundation.

About_#1: GuanYihong chairs Jiumaojiu International, one of China's largest restaurant chains.
About_#2: GuanYihong started his first noodle restaurant in China's Hainan Province in 1995 and found Jiumaojiua decade later.
About_#3: He holds a bachelor's degree in business management from Tianjin Institute of Textile Science and Technology.
About_#4: Jiumaojiu listed at the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in 2020.

Education: Master of Science, City University of London; Bachelor of Arts/Science, London School of Economics
About_#1: The son of a Greek Cypriot shipping magnate, Stelios Haji-Ioannou gets the bulk of his fortune from his stake in budget airline easyJet.
About_#2: Stelios founded easyJet in 1995 after leaving his father's company; his siblings Clelia and Polys both have large stakes in the airline.
About_#3: The family's collective stake dropped below 16% for the first time in 2021 amid ongoing disagreements with easyJet's management.
About_#4: Stelios maintains ownership of the easy brand through his private company, easyGroup.
Did You Know?: His Stelios Philanthropic Foundation supports food distribution centers in Greece and Cyprus and funds an award for disabled entrepreneurs.

About_#1: Mustafa Hamied is the non-executive vice chairman of $2.7 billion (revenue) generics maker Cipla.
About_#2: Cipla was founded in 1935 by his father Khwaja Abdul Hamied, a disciple of Mahatma Gandhi.
About_#3: After the patriarch passed away in 1972, Mustafa, a science graduate from Bombay University, inherited the business along with his older brother Yusuf Hamied, also a billionaire.
About_#4: In 2020, Cipla launched a range of drugs to treat Covid-19, including a generic version of Remdesivir manufactured under license from Gilead Sciences.

About_#1: Han Arming Hanafia cofounded DCI Indonesia with Otto Toto Sugiri and Marina Budiman in 2011.
About_#2: The company is Indonesia's largest operator of data centers.
About_#3: Hanafia has minority stakes in DCI Indonesia and Indonet, a listed internet service provider.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Western University
About_#1: Ronnen Harary is the cofounder and co-CEO of Spin Master Corp., known for its popular kids' toys like Hatchimals, Air Hogs and Paw Patrol.
About_#2: Harary started the company in 1994 with his childhood friend Anton Rabie.
About_#3: Armed with $10,000, Rabie and Harary released Spin Master's first toy in 1994. It was called "Earth Buddy" and resembled a Chia Pet.
About_#4: Spin Master had its IPO in 2015.
Did You Know?: Rabie and Harary reportedly met at summer camp in Ontario when they were both 11 years old.

About_#1: Iceland-born David Helgason cofounded game engine company Unity Software in 2004 in Copenhagen, Denmark.
About_#2: Some of the world's most popular online and mobile games were built using Unity's engine, including Pokemon Go, Among Us and Overcooked.
About_#3: In September 2020, Unity Software went public on the New York Stock Exchange; he owns a nearly 4% stake.
About_#4: Helgason served as CEO from 2003 to 2014, and is still a board member, but spends most of his time as a venture capital investor.
Did You Know?: Helgason is one of just two billionaires from Iceland; the other is investor Thor Bjorgolfsson.

About_#1: Christian Herz owns 45% of the private equity firm Mayfair SE, whose investments have included the sports apparel company Puma.
About_#2: He is the grandson of Tchibo co-founder Max Herz, who built a fortune based on the importation and sale of coffee.
About_#3: His father, Guenter, ran Tchibo for almost 35 years. The family also built a stake in skin-care company Beiersdorf, whose brands include Nivea.
About_#4: Guenter and his sister, Daniela Herz-Schnoeckel, founded Mayfair after they were bought out of the family business in 2003.
Did You Know?: Italian restaurant operator Vapiano, in which Mayfair had a stake, filed for bankruptcy after all locations in several countries closed in response to the pandemic.

About_#1: Michaela Herz owns 45% of the private equity firm Mayfair SE, whose investments have included the sports apparel company Puma.
About_#2: She is a granddaughter of Tchibo cofounder Max Herz, who built a fortune based on the import and sale of coffee.
About_#3: Her father, Guenter, ran Tchibo for almost 35 years. The family also built a stake in skin-care company Beiersdorf, whose brands include Nivea.
About_#4: Guenter and his sister, Daniela Herz-Schnoeckel, founded Mayfair after they sold their stake in the family business in 2003.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Tufts University
About_#1: Eduardo Hochschild is chairman of the Hochschild Group, a Peru-based mining and industrial group.
About_#2: Eduardo joined the business, which his great uncle had started, as a mine safety assistant in 1987; he was appointed head of the mining group in 1998.
About_#3: Hochschild chairs Hochschild Mining, a silver and gold mining business operating three underground mines, two located in Peru and one in Argentina.
About_#4: Based in Lima, Hochschild Mining trades on the London Stock Exchange and operates gold and silver mines in Peru, Chile and Argentina.
Did You Know?: His great uncle, Moritz Hochschild, who started the company in 1911, is called the 'Bolivian Oskar Schindler' for helping 9,000 European Jews come to S. America.

Education: Master of Laws, Harvard University; Law Degree, Seoul National University
About_#1: Hong Seok-joh heads Korea's largest convenience store company, BGF Retail.
About_#2: Operating under the brand name CU, BGF boasts more than 8,000 stores.
About_#3: His sister, Hong Ra-hee, is the widow of the late Samsung Group chairman Lee Kun-hee.
About_#4: Prior to his start in the business, Hong was a prosecutor.
Did You Know?: The business got its start in 1989 via a franchise-licensing agreement between the Hong family's Bokwang Group and Japanese convenience store operator FamilyMart.

About_#1: Huang Jiangji is cofounder and vice president of Chinese smartphone maker Xiaomi.
About_#2: He worked for Microsoft from 1997 to 2010, serving as the director of development at Microsoft's China Academy of Engineering.
About_#3: Huang is a graduate of Purdue University.

About_#1: Patriarch Subba Rao Jasti's wealth comes from his stakes in listed Suven Pharmaceuticals and Suven Life Sciences, both run by his son Venkateswarlu Jasti.
About_#2: Suven was founded in 1989 by his son Venkateswarlu Jasti and went public in 1995.
About_#3: The Hyderabad company was demerged in 2020 into Suven Pharmaceuticals, which does contract research and Suven Life Sciences, which focuses on neuroscience therapies.
Did You Know?: His daughter-in-law Sudharani is a director on the board of Suven Life Sciences.

Education: Master of Arts, Renmin University of China; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Tsinghua University; Ph.D, University of Maryland
About_#1: Jiang Long is vice chairman and president of Goertek Inc., a maker of electronic components; Goerek's customers include Apple.
About_#2: Jiang, who joined Goertek in 2004, holds a doctorate from the University of Maryland.
About_#3: Brother Jiang Bin, who founded Goertek in 2001, chairs the company.

About_#1: Ingvar Kamprad, who died in 2018, transferred the bulk of his Ikea empire to foundations in the 80's, but kept enough to make his sons billionaires.
About_#2: Jonas and his brothers own Ikano Group, which was created to manage Ikea's real estate and financial service businesses, but was spun out in 1988.
About_#3: Today Ikano Group is a $9.1 billion (sales) company with interests in banking, real estate and Asian shopping centers.
About_#4: Jonas, the middle child, studied industrial and furniture design in Switzerland and applied his skills in Ikea-run subsidiary Habitat.

About_#1: Ingvar Kamprad, who died in 2018, transferred the bulk of his Ikea empire to foundations in the 80's, but kept enough to make his sons billionaires.
About_#2: Mathias and his brothers own Ikano Group, which was created to manage Ikea's real estate and financial service businesses, but was spun out in 1988.
About_#3: Today Ikano Group is a $9.1 billion (sales) company with interests in banking, real estate and Asian shopping centers.
About_#4: Mathias, the youngest brother, is a board member of Inter Ikea Holding, the owner of the intellectual property assets.
Did You Know?: Mathias put in two years as assistant to Ikea's founder, Ingvar Kamprad, ranked among the top 10 richest people in the world for five years.

About_#1: Ingvar Kamprad, who died in 2018, transferred the bulk of his Ikea empire to foundations in the 80's, but kept enough to make his sons billionaires.
About_#2: Peter and his brothers own Ikano Group, which was created to manage Ikea's real estate and financial service businesses, but was spun out in 1988.
About_#3: Today Ikano Group is a $9.1 billion (sales) company with interests in banking, real estate and Asian shopping centers.
About_#4: Peter, the eldest brother, ran Ikea's Belgian operations for 12 years; he now chairs the Ikano Group.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Tufts University; Bachelor of Engineering, Tufts University
About_#1: Andrew Karam is a cofounder of AppLovin, which which makes mobile games and provides marketing services to app developers.
About_#2: Karam serves as vice president of product at the Palo Alto-based technology company.
About_#3: Before AppLovin, Karam cofounded mobile marketing firm Social Hour and Style Page, a now-defunct social platform for designers and creatives.
About_#4: Karam owns nearly 8% of AppLovin, which went public in April 2021.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Yerevan Polytechnic Institute
About_#1: Samvel Karapetyan owns $2.8 billion (sales) Tashir Holding, a commercial real estate developer.
