About_#2: Karapetyan was born in Armenia but came to Russia in the 1990s and settled in the town of Kaluga.
About_#3: A long time subcontractor of Gazprom, Tashir also has state contracts to light the central streets in Moscow.
About_#4: Karapetyan's son Sarkis and daughter Tatevik are Tashir's top managers. Tatevik is responsible for the development of its chain of movie theaters.
Did You Know?: Samvel Karapetyan's hometown in the former Soviet Union was called Kalinino. After he became rich and powerful, Karapetyan had it renamed into Tashir.
In Their Own Words: All decisions concerning all projects I'm taking by myself, solo. There are not any discussions!

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Haverford College; Doctor of Jurisprudence, Stanford University
About_#1: Alex Karp is cofounder and CEO of data mining firm Palantir Technologies, which received early backing from CIA investment arm In-Q-Tel.
About_#2: The company does contract work for government agencies like the Department of Defense, the FBI and the Danish National Police.
About_#3: Palantir went public on the New York Stock Exchange in an unusual direct listing process in September 2020.
About_#4: Karp met Palantir cofounder and billionaire Facebook investor Peter Thiel while at Stanford Law School.
Did You Know?: In addition to his J.D. degree from Stanford, Karp holds a Ph.D. in neoclassical social theory from the Goethe University in Frankfurt, Germany.

About_#1: Ke Guihua chairs Shanghai-listed Keboda Technology, a supplier of electronics components to the auto industry.
About_#2: Keboda's customers include Porsche, Bentley, Lamborghini and BMW and Audi.
About_#3: Ke hails from the eastern China city of Wenzhou.

Education: Associate in Arts/Science, Daelim University
About_#1: Kim Jung-woong is the founder and chief executive of GP Club, a Seoul-based cosmetics firm.
About_#2: His company is best known for its line of JM Solution facial masks, which are a mega hit in mainland China.
About_#3: In just two years since their launch, GP Club had sold more than one billion masks, ballooning sales by more than 900% and profits by 3,000% in 2018.
About_#4: In October 2018, Goldman Sachs invested 75 billion won ($67 million) for a 5% stake in the company.
Did You Know?: Kim started his entrepreneurial journey selling video games and consoles from a small Seoul apartment.
In Their Own Words: Success is a byproduct of circumstances; I rode the wave well.

Education: Master of Business Administration, New York University; Master of Economics, Stockholm School of Economics
About_#1: Harry Klagsbrun joined publicly traded Swedish private equity firm EQT AB in 2006.
About_#2: EQT has roughly $83 billion in assets under management.
About_#3: EQT primarily invests in private equity but has also put funds into venture capital, real estate and infrastructure.
About_#4: Klagsbrun joined the board of publicly traded Securitas AB in 2021.

About_#1: Alexander Knauf is an heir to one of the world's leading producers of building materials and systems, Knauf Gips KG.
About_#2: Based in Iphofen, Germany, the company employs more than 35,000 people around the world and has annual revenue of over $11 billion.
About_#3: Its product line includes plasterboards, cement boards and insulating materials. Alexander has served as managing director since 2012.
About_#4: Knauf Gips dates to 1932, when brothers and mining engineers Alfons and Karl Knauf obtained rights to gypsum deposits in Schengen, Germany.
Did You Know?: Alexander began his professional career with an apprenticeship at Deutsche Bank before joining Knauf Gips.

About_#1: Martin Bernhard Knauf is an heir to one of the world's leading producers of building materials and systems, Knauf Gips KG.
About_#2: Based in Iphofen, Germany, the company employs more than 35,000 people around the world and has annual revenue of over $11 billion.
About_#3: Its product line includes plasterboards, cement boards and insulating materials.
About_#4: Knauf Gips dates to 1932, when brothers and mining engineers Alfons and Karl Knauf obtained rights to gypsum deposits in Schengen, Germany.

About_#1: Robert Matthias Knauf is an heir to one of the world's leading producers of building materials and systems, Knauf Gips KG.
About_#2: Based in Iphofen, Germany, the company employs more than 35,000 people around the world and has annual revenue of over $11 billion.
About_#3: Its product line includes plasterboards, cement boards and insulating materials.
About_#4: Knauf Gips dates to 1932, when brothers and mining engineers Alfons and Karl Knauf obtained rights to gypsum deposits in Schengen, Germany.

About_#1: Hotelier and property magnate Koh Wee Meng controls Fragrance Group with interests extending to Australia and the U.K. He took the company private from the Singapore Stock Exchange in October 2021.
About_#2: Son of a jeweler and schoolteacher, Koh broke away from Aspial, his family's jewelry business to start his own property venture in the 1990s.
About_#3: He was once known as the Geylang King for Fragrance's beginnings in Singapore's red light district.
About_#4: His younger sibling Koh Wee Seng runs Aspial and has his own property interests.
Did You Know?: In the early years, he named his hotels after precious stones, such as Ruby, Sapphire and Emerald, inspired by his days as a jeweler.
In Their Own Words: Only buy and hold what you are able to afford.

Education: Master of Science, Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology
About_#1: Sergei Kolesnikov owns 50% of Technonicol, a global producer of roofing, waterproofing and thermal insulation materials.
About_#2: He is a managing partner of Technonicol, which owns 53 companies and factories in six countries in Europe and Asia.
About_#3: Kolesnikov founded the company with his classmate Igor Rybakov in 1993.
Did You Know?: Kolesnikov finances biathlon schools and built two biathlon stadiums.
In Their Own Words: I am engaged in biathlon, I go to competitions. Why? I like experiencing the stress that appears at the start, and the euphoria at the finish. Business, like sports, is a test of yourself.

Education: Master of Science, Moscow Institute of Chemical Engineering
About_#1: In March 2021, Komarov sold his 87% stake in Chelyabinsk Tube Rolling Plant, also known as ChelPipe, one of Russia's leading steel pipe makers to the fellow billionaire Dmitry Pumpyansky for $1.13 bil
About_#2: He managed Moscow's Satiricon Theater in the last years of communism.
About_#3: He traded cars, metal products and steel pipes in the early 1990s.
About_#4: In the mid-90s, in his hometown of Chelyabinsk, he teamed up with the manager of the town's pipe-making plant to private the business.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Korea University
About_#1: Koo Bon-neung runs Heesung Electronics, which makes display components for TVs, computers, tablets and smartphones.
About_#2: He is the younger brother of Koo Bon-moo, the late chairman of the LG Group, one of the top five conglomerates in South Korea.
About_#3: In 2004 his son Koo Kwang-mo was adopted by his brother who lost his own son in a car accident. Kwang-mo now helms LG as its chairman.
Did You Know?: Koo is a former president of the Korea Baseball Organization.

Education: Master, University of Michigan
About_#1: Koo Bon-sik runs LG affiliate Heesung Electronics with his brother Koo Bon-neung, who is also one of the richest people in South Korea.
About_#2: He is the youngest of the four Koo brothers of the LG Group.
About_#3: Heesung is LG's largest supplier of backlights, which are used to illuminate LCD displays.
About_#4: Heesung group's affiliates include LT Precision, LT metal and LT Material.
Did You Know?: More than 50% of his fortune comes from his stake in LG Corp.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Madras Christian College; Master of Arts, University of Munich; Master of Arts, University of Wisconsin, Madison
About_#1: Suresh Krishna chairs the $419 million (revenue) Sundram Fasteners, which makes components for the auto sector.
About_#2: Krishna is the oldest member of the third generation of the storied T.V. Sundaram Iyengar family from the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu.
About_#3: Four families tied to the TVS Group restructured their cross-holdings, as per a December 2020 agreement, which gave each family both ownership and control of their respective companies.
About_#4: Eldest daughter Preethi has a board seat while second and third daughters Arathi and Arundathi run the company.
Did You Know?: Krishna founded the company in 1966 as a small industrial unit in Ambattur, a suburb of Chennai city.

Education: Doctor of Jurisprudence, Cleveland State University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Cincinnati
About_#1: Nancy Lerner owes her riches to her billionaire dad, Al Lerner (d. 2002), and to his banking fortune.
About_#2: Al started his career as a furniture salesman, invested in Cleveland-area real estate and bought control of Equitable Bancorp in 1981.
About_#3: Equitable Bancorp and Maryland National formed the credit card giant MBNA, whose 2005 merger with Bank of America created a $35 billion enterprise.
About_#4: The Lerners bought the Cleveland Browns in 1999 and sold the team to Jimmy Haslam for about $1 billion in 2012.

About_#1: Norma Lerner is the widow of Al Lerner (d. 2002), who made a fortune as founder of credit card giant MBNA.
About_#2: Al started his career as a furniture salesman, invested in Cleveland-area real estate and bought control of Equitable Bancorp in 1981.
About_#3: Equitable Bancorp and Maryland National formed the credit card giant MBNA, which was acquired by Bank of America for $35 billion in 2005.
Did You Know?: The family sold the English football club Aston Villa for $88 million to Chinese businessman Tony Xia in 2016 after a decade of ownership.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Columbia University; LLB, Columbia University
About_#1: Randy Lerner owes his riches to his billionaire dad, Al Lerner (d. 2002), who made a fortune in credit cards.
About_#2: His father got his start as a furniture salesman then invested in Cleveland-area real estate. He later bought control of Equitable Bancorp in 1981.
About_#3: Equitable Bancorp merged with Maryland National to form credit card giant MBNA, which was acquired by Bank of America for $35 billion in 2005.
Did You Know?: The Lerners bought the Cleveland Browns in 1999, bringing pro football back to the city. They sold the team to billionaire Jimmy Haslam for about $1 billion in 2012.

About_#1: Li chairs Kinglai Hygienic Materials, a maker of stainless steel products such as vacuum chambers, pumps and pipe fittings.
About_#2: Li founded Kinglai in Taiwan in 1991 and moved its headquarters to Kunshan, Jiangsu province in 2000.
About_#3: The company went public on the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2011.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Sichuan University
About_#1: Li Tan, with Li Li, is part of the husband-wife billionaire duo that leads Shenzhen Hepalink Pharmaceutical, a supplier of heparin sodium.
About_#2: She graduated from Sichuan University -- the same school as her husband -- in July 1987 with a bachelor's degree in chemistry.
About_#3: Li worked as a bureaucrat in Anhui Province from 1987 to 1992 before joining her husband at Chongqing Tongda, a heparin sodium supplier.

Education: Master, Jilin University
About_#1: Li Wenmei is cofounder and general manager of Guangzhou Wondfo Biotech, a supplier of medical diagnostic tests.
About_#2: Li set up the business with his wife Wang Jihua, who is Wondfo's chairman.
About_#3: Li holds a master's degree from Jilin University and taught at the University of South China in the 1980s.
About_#4: Li and Wang cofounded Wondfo's predecessor business, Wanfu, in 1992.

Source of Wealth: palm oil, nickel mining, Self Made
About_#1: Lim and his family own a majority stake in Singapore-listed palm oil producer Bumitama Agri; its plantations are located in Indonesia.
About_#2: His son Lim Gunawan Hariyanto is chairman and CEO of Bumitama Agri.
About_#3: The family's Harita group also owns the majority of listed bauxite mining firm Cita Mineral Investindo.
About_#4: Lim's father emigrated from China to East Kalimantan and reportedly opened a grocery store in 1915.

About_#1: Lin Jie is the cofounder of Shenzhen-listed Zhejiang Tianyu Pharmaceutical, a supplier of pharmaceutical compounds.
About_#2: Lin worked at the predecessor of Tianyu, a chemical factory founded in the eastern Chinese city of Taizhou.
About_#3: Lin shares her fortune with busband Tu Yongjun, who has been the chairman of Zhejiang Tianyu Pharmaceutical since 2003.
About_#4: Tianyu went public at the Shenzhen Stock Exchange in 2017.

About_#1: Lou is co-founder and chairman of Pharmaron, a drug research and development business.
About_#2: Lou received his M.S.degree (1986) and Ph.D. in organic chemistry (1989) at the Shanghai Institute of Organic Chemistry.
About_#3: Lou did post-doctoral research at the University of Montreal in 1990-1994.

About_#1: LunRuixiang is the chairman of real estate developer Huijing Holdings.
About_#2: Huijing entered the real estate industry in 2002 using financial resources he accumulated in the car business in the Dongguan.
About_#3: Huijing is a residential and commercial property developer, with a focus on China's southern Guangdong and Hunan provinces.

About_#1: Ma Xiuhui is the general manager of China lighting manufacturer Opple Lighting.
About_#2: Ma and husband Wang Yaohui started out making traditional light bulbs in Guangdong Province in the 1990s, before moving the headquarters to Shanghai.
About_#3: Wang is also a billionaire.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, George Washington University
About_#1: Yasseen Mansour is a shareholder in family-owned conglomerate Mansour Group, which was founded by his father Loutfy (d.1976) in 1952.
About_#2: Mansour Group is the exclusive distributor of GM vehicles and Caterpillar equipment in Egypt and several other countries.
About_#3: His brothers Mohamed and Youssef are also billionaires and part owners of Mansour Group.
About_#4: He's chairman of Palm Hills Developments, one of Egypt's biggest real estate developers.

Education: Master of Business Administration, University of Miami
About_#1: Jorge Mas is one of the most prominent Cuban American businessmen in the United States.
About_#2: Mas is the largest shareholder and chairman of MasTec, a Miami-based infrastructure engineering and construction company.
About_#3: He started at his father's Church and Tower in 1984. At $6.3 billion in revenue in 2020, MasTec is one of the largest Hispanic-owned U.S. firms.
About_#4: Mas co-founded Neff Rentals, a construction equipment and tool rental company, which he sold in 2005 for a reported $510 million.
Did You Know?: Jorge is son of Jorge Mas Canosa, a Cuban ex-pat and staunch opponent of both Batista and Castro, who sought exile fleeing to Florida in 1960.

About_#1: Michael McCain is the CEO of Maple Leaf Foods, a Canadian packaged meat company that made $3.1 billion in sales in 2019.
About_#2: McCain's father, Wallace McCain, cofounded frozen food company McCain Foods with his brother Harrison in 1956.
About_#3: The family bought a controlling stake in Maple Leaf Foods in 1995.
About_#4: In January 2020, Michael McCain grabbed headlines for his scathing tweets about then-U.S. President Donald Trump and his foreign policy.

About_#1: Gabriella Meister and her daughter Franziska Wuerbser, who is also a billionaire, are among four family heirs who inherited 63% of kitchen appliance manufacturer Rational AG.
About_#2: Gabriella's late husband, Siegfried Meister, founded the company in 1973 and died in 2017, at age 78.
About_#3: Rational has more than a 50% share of the global market for multifunctional food preparation appliances used in large-scale and commercial kitchens.
About_#4: The company's products include ovens, steamers and grills.
Did You Know?: Siegfried Meister had the idea to cook using steam after disliking how food was prepared at restaurant chain Wienerwald, where he worked previously.

About_#1: Ulrike Meister is among a community of four family heirs who inherited 63% of kitchen appliance manufacturer Rational AG.
About_#2: Siegfried Meister founded the company in 1973 and died in 2017, at age 78. Its products include ovens, steamers and grills.
About_#3: Rational has more than a 50% share of the global market for multifunctional food preparation appliances used in large-scale and commercial kitchens.
About_#4: The company, which went public in 2000, has grown consistently without acquisitions, and prides itself on innovative, energy-efficient technology.
Did You Know?: Siegfried Meister had the idea to cook using steam after disliking how food was prepared at restaurant chain Wienerwald, where he worked previously.

About_#1: Jeffrey Michael is a founding investor and board member of Corvel Corporation, a healthcare technology company.
About_#2: He and family members hold a 38% stake in Corvel through Michael's investment vehicle, Corstar Holdings, Inc.
About_#3: Michael helped start Corvel in 1987; originally named Fortis, it began as a small chain of vocational rehabilitation firms.
About_#4: The company has since grown into a national provider of risk management solutions for payors and employers and generated $592 million of revenue in 2020.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Tufts University
About_#1: Soichiro Minami founded and runs Visional, a job search and human resources software firm.
About_#2: U.S.-educated Minami, founded the firm in 2009 after working for Morgan Stanley and Japanese e-commerce giant Rakuten, founded by billionaire Hiroshi Mikitani.
About_#3: In April 2021, Minami listed the firm on the Tokyo Stock Exchange's bourse for startups, Mothers.
About_#4: Visional posted over $263 million in revenue in the fiscal year ended in July 2021.
Did You Know?: Minami has a double degree in economics and international relations from Tufts University.

Education: Bachelor of Science, University of Michigan
About_#1: Bob Muglia is an enterprise software executive and the former CEO of Snowflake, a data warehousing company. He stepped down in 2019.
About_#2: Snowflake went public in a September 2020 IPO; he owns about 1.4% of Snowflake stock.
About_#3: Muglia sold half of his Snowflake shares to Berkshire Hathaway as part of Snowflake's IPO.
About_#4: He is currently the executive chairman of database startup Fauna and a board member at data startup Fivetran, among others.

About_#1: Erik Must is one of the largest private investors in the Norwegian stock market.
About_#2: He got his start as a stock broker at the firm Hans P. Jeppesen, where he met Kjell Christian Ulrichsen.
About_#3: The duo formed the brokerage firm Fondfinans and dominated Norwegian capital markets in the 70's and 80's thanks to savvy salesmanship.
About_#4: In 1996, Must bought out Ulrichsen, and have used profits from Fondfinans to build up a large private stock portfolio.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Cape Town
About_#1: Kerr Neilson owns more than 40% of international equities fund manager Platinum Asset Management together with his ex-wife Judith.
About_#2: They had partially cashed out in a well-timed 2007 IPO.
About_#3: Known for his value-based contrarian stock picks that have earned him comparisons with Warren Buffett, Neilson bought his first stock at age 13.
About_#4: A Johannesburg native, he cofounded Platinum in 1994, after moving to Sydney from South Africa a decade earlier to work for Bankers Trust Australia.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Master of Business Administration, Stanford Graduate School of Business
About_#1: John Oyler is the CEO and cofounder of Beijing-based biotech outfit BeiGene. He owns about 6% of the publicly traded company.
About_#2: BeiGene, which was founded in 2010 as a research and development firm, went public on the Nasdaq in 2016 and listed in Hong Kong two years later.
About_#3: Before he cofounded BeiGene, Oyler helped start and then sell two companies in the U.S. and China.
About_#4: Telephia, a consumer telecom research firm Oyler founded in 1997, was sold to The Nielsen Co. for $449 million in 2007.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Korea University
About_#1: Park Hyeon-joo founded Mirae Asset Investment Advisory and a venture capital affiliate in 1997.
About_#2: He is known as the father of South Korea's mutual fund industry and launched the country's first closed-end mutual fund in 1998.
About_#3: Now operating in 12 countries, his firm has approximately $190 billion in assets under management.
Did You Know?: The Mirae Asset Park Hyeon Joo Foundation provides scholarships to academically promising students from disadvantaged families.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Universidade do Brasil
About_#1: Jose Issac Peres founded Multiplan, company that develops, owns and manages shopping malls in Brazil.
About_#2: At age 22 while an economics student, he founded his first company, real estate developer Vepan, which he turned into publicly-traded Multiplan.
About_#3: He and his wife together own nearly 26% of Multiplan's stock.
About_#4: In 2014 Peres' Village Mall property in Rio de Janeiro became the site of Brazil's first official Apple store.

About_#1: Catherine Phillips and her husband John invested in Canadian e-commerce firm Shopify early on.
About_#2: They each own about 1.5% each of the wildly successful company.
About_#3: Phillips is a psychologist who specializes in helping cancer patients deal with stress.
About_#4: She leads support groups and in 2013 published a book titled, Calm Your Mind, Warm Your Heart.

Education: Law Degree, University of Toronto; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Toronto (Trinity College)
About_#1: John Phillips is an angel investor who made an early bet on Shopify, a Canadian e-commerce software company.
About_#2: He and his wife Catherine are now among the company's largest shareholders; Each owns about 1.5% of Shopify.
About_#3: Phillips has also served on Shopify's board of directors since 2010.
About_#4: He has invested in a slew of other early-stage companies that are lesser known, like Virtual Marine Technology and Sequence Bio.

About_#1: Pu Zhongjie chairs Shenzhen-listed company Lepu Medical Technology (Beijing).
About_#2: Lepu Medical, founded in 1999, produces medical equipment and devices such as coronary stents, mechanical heart valves and spinal implants.
About_#3: The company has subsidiaries in Netherland, Turkey and India and has built distribution channels in over 80 countries.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Western University
About_#1: Anton Rabie is the cofounder and co-CEO of Spin Master Corp., known for its popular kids' toys like Hatchimals, Air Hogs and Paw Patrol.
About_#2: Rabie started the company in 1994 with childhood friend Ronnen Harary.
About_#3: Armed with $10,000, Rabie and Harary released Spin Master's first toy in 1994. It was called "Earth Buddy" and resembled a Chia Pet.
About_#4: Spin Master had its IPO in 2015.
Did You Know?: Rabie and Harary reportedly met at summer camp in Ontario when they were both 11 years old.

Education: Master of Science, Moscow Institute of Physics and Technology
About_#1: Igor Rybakov owns 50% of Technonicol, a global producer of roofing, waterproofing and thermal insulation materials.
About_#2: Technonicol owns 56 factories in seven countries in Europe and Asia.
About_#3: Rybakov founded the company with classmate Sergei Kolesnikov in 1992, at age 20.
About_#4: He ran the business until 2015, when he cofounded technology company Prytek.
Did You Know?: Rybakov and his wife Ekaterina started a foundation in 2015 that sets up programs to support education.
In Their Own Words: Entrepreneurs paradoxically combine ultimate idealism, even romanticism, with extreme pragmatism and selfishness.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, D.A-V College
About_#1: K. Rai Sahi oversees a $21.3 billion real estate portfolio as CEO and chairman of Morguard Corp.
About_#2: His firm's 200 commercial, residential and hotel properties extend from Ontario to Illinois.
About_#3: Sahi also heads TWC Enterprises, the largest golf club owner and operator in Canada.
About_#4: Sahi immigrated to Canada from India when he was 24 and started by selling insurance door to door.

About_#1: Owners of Swiss jewelry and watchmaker Chopard, Karl Scheufele III and his family control one of the best-known luxury accessory lines in the world.
About_#2: A goldsmith and watchmaker by training, the German-born Scheufele bought the Geneva-based company in 1963 and transformed it into a global brand.
About_#3: More than 50 years later, Scheufele remains active in the company, though his children Karl-Friedrich and Caroline lead the business.
About_#4: Chopard's jewelry is a regular on the red carpet, with 11 Oscar winners having won while wearing Chopard, including Kate Winslet and Julianne Moore.
Did You Know?: Scheufele was born in Pforzheim, Germany, nicknamed the "Golden City" due to its longstanding tradition in jewelry and watchmaking.
In Their Own Words: When I visited the workshops in Geneva and saw the venerable Mr. Chopard at his workbench, I immediately saw that our companies would be a good fit. We talked for half an hour and then I knew that this was the right choice.

About_#1: Schuurman cofounded Elastic, a Netherlands-based software company that went public in October 2018.
About_#2: Schuurman, who has an 18.9% stake in Elastic, first became a billionaire in December 2018.
About_#3: He served as Elastic's CEO from 2012 to 2017, and now sits on the board of directors.
About_#4: He cofounded another software company, SpringSource, which was acquired by VMware in 2009 for $420 million.
Did You Know?: Some of Schuurman's hobbies include cooking and playing guitar.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Boston University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Delhi University
About_#1: Analjit Singh is the youngest son of Bhai Mohan Singh, founder of pharma firm Ranbaxy Laboratories.
About_#2: Today he controls the $4.5 billion (revenue) Max Group, with interests in healthcare, insurance and specialty packaging film.
About_#3: In recent years, Singh has invested in South Africa where he owns a vineyard and two boutique resorts.
About_#4: His son, Veer, runs Vana, a private wellness retreat in the northern Indian city of Dehradun.
Did You Know?: The Boston University grad made an early investment in India's telecom sector and made a pile when he sold his stake in that business to Li Ka-shing.

About_#1: Kavita Singhania has a stake in J K Cement, a listed cement manufacturer, which her late husband Yadupati Singhania ran as managing director.
About_#2: JK Cement is a well-known brand in its northern India stronghold where the company is based.
About_#3: Singhania plays no role in the cement company. She's a director of Express Infrastructure, a developer in the southern Indian city of Chennai.
About_#4: Singhania's grandfather was newspaper baron Ramnath Goenka, who built a media empire that is best known for its daily newspaper, the Indian Express.

Education: Drop Out, University of Colorado
About_#1: Michael S. Smith built Freeport LNG, a $15 billion complex on the Texas coast that chills and exports liquefied natural gas.
About_#2: He made his first fortune with oil and gas company Basin Exploration, which he sold in 2001 for $428 million.
About_#3: Enjoys homes in Miami Beach, Malibu and the Hamptons.
About_#4: Freeport LNG was originally envisioned as an LNG import terminal; when the shale gas boom arrived, Smith turned his strategy 180 degrees.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Brigham Young University; Master of Business Administration, Michigan State University; Ph.D, Pennsylvania State University
About_#1: Scott Smith is one of three cofounders of Utah-based cloud computing company Qualtrics.
About_#2: He cofounded the company in Provo, Utah in 2002 with his two sons, Ryan and Jared; Ryan is the CEO.
About_#3: Three days before its scheduled IPO in January 2019, Qualtrics was acquired by German software firm SAP for $8 billion in cash.
About_#4: Scott owned about 14% of the company at the time of the sale.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Asian Institute of Management; Bachelor of Engineering, IIT, Roorkee
About_#1: IT veteran Ashok Soota gets his wealth from a majority stake in Bangalore-based tech firm Happiest Minds Technologies.
About_#2: Soota worked at fellow billionaire Azim Premji's software giant Wipro before striking out on his own with IT provider Mindtree.
About_#3: Mindtree was acquired by engineering firm Larsen & Toubro in a hostile takeover in 2019.
About_#4: Soota moved out of Mindtree in 2011 to set up Happiest Minds that same year, along with nine cofounders. He took it public in 2020.
Did You Know?: Soota is on the board of governors of his alma mater, the Asian Institute Management in the Philippines.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Oxford University
About_#1: Spencer founded inter-broker dealer NEX Group (formerly ICAP), which was acquired by CME Group in 2018 for $5.4 billion.
About_#2: After the half stock, half cash deal, Spencer was granted 3 million shares of CME.
About_#3: He now owns and runs private IPGL Group, which has more than £1 billion in assets.
About_#4: A loyal Tory, Spencer served as the Conservative Party's treasurer from 2006 to 2010.

Education: Bachelor of Engineering, Anna University, Chennai, India; Master of Business Administration, Purdue University
About_#1: Venu Srinivasan is chairman emeritus and managing director of TVS Motor Company, India's third-largest maker of two-wheelers.
About_#2: TVS Motor is the flagship of the TVS Group, which was founded in 1911 by T. V. Sundaram Iyengar. Srinivasan belongs to the third generation.
About_#3: The $ 3.2 billion (revenue) company has three factories in India and one in Indonesia.
About_#4: Veteran auto executive Ralf Speth, who had a board seat, was appointed chairman of TVS Motor Company in February 2022.
Did You Know?: He was awarded the Padma Bhushan, India's third highest civilian award, in 2020.

About_#1: Dirk Stroeer is the son of Heinz W. Stroeer, who laid the foundation for Stroeer SE & Co. KGaA setting up billboards in Germany back in 1963.
About_#2: In 1990 Heinz joined forces with competitor Udo Mueller, now CEO of Stroeer SE, to create one of Germany's biggest out-of-home media providers.
About_#3: Dirk inherited a 50% stake from his father, and the company went public in 2010. He currently owns just under 20%.
About_#4: Headquartered in Cologne, Stroeer SE employs more than more than 10,000 people in over 100 locations and generates annual revenue of about $2 billion.

Education: Bachelor of Electronics and Telecom Engineering, Trisakti University
About_#1: Susanto Suwarto cofounded Elang Mahkota Teknologi (Emtek), which was established in 1983 as a provider of PC services and computer equipment.
About_#2: Today Emtek's businesses include IT solutions, media and telecom.
About_#3: Suwarto is commissioner at Emtek as well as at some of the company's subsidiaries.
About_#4: With a degree in electronics and telecom engineering, Suwarto gets his wealth from a minority stake in Emtek.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Central South University
About_#1: Tang Xiuguo is one of four founders of Sany Group, one of China's largest supplier of construction equipment.
About_#2: He has been the director and president of Sany Group since 2002.
About_#3: Sany's holding company was founded in Hunan Province in 1989 as a small welding material factory.
About_#4: Tang holds a bachelor degree in metallic materials from Central South University in 1983.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Stanford University
About_#1: Mehmet Sinan Tara is chairman of one of Turkey's largest construction and energy companies, ENKA. It was cofounded by his father, Sarik Tara, in 1957.
About_#2: Turkey's leading private electricity producer, ENKA also operates in real estate, tourism, transport and trade (construction equipment and machinery).
About_#3: In Moscow, ENKA owns a hotel, shopping malls and approximately 370,000 square meters of net rentable Class A office space.
About_#4: Sarik Tara's brother-in-law Sadi Gulcelik, with whom he founded ENKA, died in a plane accident in Saudi Arabia in 1980.
Did You Know?: Over the last 20 years or so, ENKA has been the biggest builder of U.S. consular and embassy buildings.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Cornell University; LLB, University of Pennsylvania
About_#1: Robert Toll, whose luxury homebuilder Toll Brothers built "McMansions" and reshaped suburbs around the country, died on October 7 at age 81.
About_#2: The cause of death was Parkinson's disease.
About_#3: Toll cofounded the firm with his younger brother Bruce in 1967. The company's first project was a new community of 171 homes in Chester County, PA.
About_#4: He served as CEO of Toll Brothers until 2010 and executive chairman until 2018; he was the company's largest individual shareholder.

Education: High School
About_#1: Low-profile tycoon Surin Upatkoon made his fortune across sectors from insurance to telecom.
About_#2: Most of his fortune comes from selling a 10% stake in Thai telecom company InTouch in 2013.
About_#3: He owns stakes in listed gaming company Magnum Corp, textile firm MWE and insurance-and-property company MPHB Capital.
About_#4: He started his career as a manager at MWE Weaving in 1971 and rose through the ranks.
Did You Know?: Upatkoon is a Thai national but moved to Penang for school, stayed for work and has been a Malaysia resident ever since.

About_#1: Sunil Vachani is the founder and chairman of India-listed Dixon Technologies.
About_#2: Vachani borrowed two million rupees ($27,600) from his father to set up the company in 1993 to manufacture TV sets.
About_#3: The company makes products such as smartphones, washing machines and TVs, for a range of clients including Samsung, Panasonic and Xiaomi.
About_#4: The company listed in 2017 and its shares have been rising ever since.

About_#1: Co-founder of Turkey's largest provider of mobile service, Murat Vargi has diversified into real estate and hotels, startups and renewable energy.
About_#2: Although having divested most all of his Turkcell stake, he has 80% of KVK, a mobile phone distributor supplying a retail network with 1,000+ outlets.
About_#3: Dost Energy, of which Vargi's owns 51%, has found success by focusing exclusively on producing power from wind.
About_#4: Vargi is an active venture investor. In 2015, Gedik Yatırım and Vargi's MV Holding opened a startup hub in Istanbul, StartersHub.
Did You Know?: Vargi started his career working as an export representative with Koc Holdings, founded by one of Turkey's leading business families.

About_#1: Medical doctor Pongsak Viddayakorn cofounded hospital operator Bangkok Dusit Medical Services with fellow doctor Prasert Prasarttong-Osoth.
About_#2: In 2012, he sold his Bangkok Dusit shares to build a property portfolio through listed outfit Principal Capital, overseen by his son Satit.
About_#3: In 2017, Principal expanded into healthcare with the acquisition of four hospitals in the northern provinces.
About_#4: The company is aiming to grow its healthcare network to 20 hospitals by 2023.
Did You Know?: He supported himself through high school and medical school by selling stationery.

About_#1: Richard Warke is a Canadian investor with holdings in gold, zinc and copper mining in Canada, Mexico, the U.S. and South America.
About_#2: He sold Ventana Gold, which discovered the La Bodega gold deposit in Colombia, for $1.6 billion in 2011.
About_#3: His Augusta Resource advanced one of the largest copper deposits in the U.S.; Warke sold the firm for $600 million in 2014.
About_#4: His Arizona Mining discovered the largest zinc deposit in the U.S. in Arizona; he sold the firm for $1.3 billion in 2018 and retains a minority stake.

About_#1: Anne Marie Werninghaus is the largest individual shareholder of WEG, the largest manufacturer of electrical motors in Latin America.
About_#2: The company was cofounded by her grandfather Geraldo Werninghaus along with late billionaires Eggon Joao da Silva and Werner Ricardo Voigt.
About_#3: A publicly-traded multinational with factories in five countries, WEG had revenues of US $3.05 billion in 2020.
About_#4: Anne doesn't work at the company or hold a board seat; she is the founder of VestesBr, a short-lived B2B fashion marketplace launched in 2011.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, University of Hong Kong; Master of Science, University of Wisconsin
About_#1: Allan Wong cofounded electronic toymaker VTech Holdings, which is also the largest manufacturer of residential phones in the U.S.
About_#2: The company is headquartered in Hong Kong with manufacturing facilities in mainland China, Malaysia and Mexico.
About_#3: He is an independent non-executive director of the Bank of East Asia and deputy chairman of the board.
About_#4: He's also an independent non-executive director of China-Hongkong Photo Products Holdings.

About_#1: Wu Chaoqun is the chairman and cofounder of Qianhe Condiment and Food, one of China's largest suppliers of condiments.
About_#2: Qianhe's products include soy sauce, soy sauce powder, vinegar and cooking wine.
About_#3: Wu and his brother Wu Xueming entered the business in 1996 when they cofounded Hengtai Industrial, the predecessor to Qianhe.
About_#4: Qianhe is headquartered in the western Chinese city of Meishan.

About_#1: Wu Yonghua is a director and CEO of Anta Sports, one of the world's largest sportswear businesses.
About_#2: Wu joined Anta in 2003 and has over 20 years of experience in sales and marketing.
About_#3: Anta is headquartered in southern China's Fujian Province.

About_#1: Franziska Wuerbser is the daughter of Gabriella Meister, who is one of four family heirs who inherited 63% of kitchen appliance manufacturer Rational AG.
About_#2: Rational has more than a 50% share of the global market for food preparation appliances used in large-scale and commercial kitchens.
About_#3: The company, which went public in 2000, has grown without acquisitions, and prides itself on innovative, energy-efficient technology.
About_#4: More than 2,200 employees work for Rational AG, which is headquartered just outside Munich, Germany.

About_#1: Xiong Jun chairs biopharmaceutical company Shanghai Junshi Biosciences.
About_#2: Xiong has been investing in Shanghai Junshi Biosciences since January 2013.
About_#3: Xiong obtained an MBA from the Chinese University of Hong Kong in December 2007.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Fudan University; Doctorate in Pedagogical Sciences, University of Pennsylvania
About_#1: Jane Yan chairs Venustech Group, a supplier of information security products and services.
About_#2: Venustech Group, founded by Yan in 1996, is headquartered in Beijing.
About_#3: Yan's husband Yan Li is a company director and vice general manager.

Education: Diploma, National University of Kyiv-Mohyla Academy
About_#1: Vlad Yatsenko is cofounder of digital bank Revolut, the most valuable fintech company in the U.K., worth $33 billion.
About_#2: The dual British-Ukrainian citizen called Vladimir Putin "one of the most brazen liars in history" on February 24, the day Russia invaded Ukraine.
About_#3: Revolut, which he runs with Nik Storonsky, who grew up in Russia but left at age 20, helped raise $11 million in donations for the Ukrainian Red Cross.
About_#4: Yatsenko is Revolut's chief technology officer; he previously built software at UBS, Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse.

About_#1: Yi Xianzhong chairs Bio-Thera Solutions, which develops drugs to treat tumors and cardiovascular and autoimmune diseases.
About_#2: Bio-Thera listed on the Shanghai Stock Exchange's Sci-Tech Innovation Board in February 2020.
About_#3: Yi graduated from the South China University of Technology, where he majored in computers and radio.
About_#4: He worked for a state-owned firm in Guangzhou after graduation before founding his first company, computer maker Hedy Computer.

About_#1: Yoshiaki Yoshida is the founder of Japanese beauty brand DHC. He started the company in 1972 to provide translation services.
About_#2: In 1980, he started the cosmetics business using organic olives. In 1983 he got into the mail order segment.
About_#3: The privately held company, which sells both through retail stores and online, posted nearly $820 million in revenue in the fiscal year ending July 2021.
About_#4: The company also sells nutritional supplements and health foods and still does translations.
Did You Know?: DHC stands for Daigaku Honyaku Center.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, Novocherkassk Polytechnic Institute; Master of Economics, Russian Foreign Trade Academy
About_#1: Igor Yusufov is the founder of Energy Corporation, which invests in oil and gas, mining and infrastructure companies.
About_#2: In the early 1990s, Yusufov was a deputy secretary of Foreign Economic Relations.
About_#3: From 2001 to 2004, he was the Russian Federation's energy minister.
About_#4: He also served on the board Russian gas giant Gazprom from 2003 to 2013.

About_#1: Zhang Cheng Fei is the deputy CEO of Nine Dragons Paper of China, one of Asia's largest paper and packaging companies.
About_#2: Zhang's sister Cheung Yan, the chairlady of Nine Dragons, is also a billionaire.
About_#3: Zhang's brother-in-law Liu Ming Chung, the CEO of Nine Dragons, is also one of three billionaires in the family.

Education: Doctorate, Duke University; Master of Science, Nanjing University
About_#1: Zhang Fangliang is the chairman and a cofounder of Genscript Biotech Corp.
About_#2: The company is headquartered in New Jersey, with branches in Europe, Japan and China.
About_#3: Zhang obtained a master of science degree from Nanjing University in 1987; he received a Ph.D. from Duke University in 1995.

About_#1: Zhong Baoshen chairs LONGi Green Energy Technology, one of the world's largest solar panel and cell suppliers.
About_#2: LONGi went public at the Shanghai Stock Exchange in 2019.
About_#3: Zhong graduated from Lanzhou University in 1990 with a major in metallurgy.
About_#4: LONGi President Li Zhenguo is also a billionaire.

About_#1: Descendant of the storied Bangur clan of Kolkata, Krishna Kumar Bangur chairs graphite electrodes-maker Graphite India.
About_#2: The $266 million (revenue) company was set up in 1962 in collaboration with Great Lakes Carbon, an American firm.
About_#3: The company, which supplies leading steelmakers in India and overseas, is the world's third-largest producer of graphite electrodes.
About_#4: It has lately benefitted from China's decision to replace polluting blast furnaces with electric arc furnaces to make steel.
Did You Know?: Bangur joined the business at the age of 16.
In Their Own Words: We are in a venture-not an adventure.

Education: Ph.D, Brown University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, Georgia Tech
About_#1: Math whiz worked for IBM on NASA's Saturn rockets in the 1960s.
About_#2: Founded pioneering high-speed-trading outfit Quantlab, which at one point moved 3% of volumes on the NYSE.
About_#3: According to court documents, Quantlab generated more than $2 billion in net profits over the past 15 years. Ed's 72% stake is held via trusts.
About_#4: Bosarge is the beneficiary of trusts, domiciled in South Dakota, that according to court filings hold assets of more than $1 billion.

About_#1: Johanna Braun owns 10% of the medical device company B. Braun Melsungen, which began in 1839 as a small pharmacy that sold herbal remedies.
About_#2: Her father, Ludwig Georg Braun, took the reins in 1977, when the company had just $24 million in annual sales (now around $8 billion).
About_#3: A sixth-generation family member, Johanna is the youngest daughter of Ludwig Georg. Her sister, Anna Maria, is CEO of B. Braun.
About_#4: Today, with more than 64,000 employees globally, B. Braun manufactures products ranging from infusion and injection solutions to surgical instruments
Did You Know?: Johanna Braun is a member of the board of the B. Braun Foundation, which works in education, science and public health in the field of human medicine.

About_#1: Karl Friedrich Braun owns 10% of the medical device company B. Braun Melsungen, which began in 1839 as a small pharmacy that sold herbal remedies.
About_#2: His father, Ludwig Georg Braun, took the reins in 1977, when the company had just $24 million in annual sales (now around $8 billion).
About_#3: A sixth-generation family member, Karl Friedrich is one of three sons of Ludwig Georg.His sister Anna Maria is CEO of B. Braun.
About_#4: Today, with more than 64,000 employees globally, B. Braun manufactures products ranging from infusion and injection solutions to surgical instruments.
Did You Know?: Karl Friedrich is a doctor at Berlin's Charité, with a focus on traumatology.

About_#1: Jean-Pierre Cayard's father founded spirits group La Martiniquaise in 1934 and quickly established links with major retailers to expand the company.
About_#2: Jean-Pierre, now CEO, joined in 1970 and has turned it into one of France's largest spirits groups, with a portfolio of international brands.
About_#3: Its "millionaire" brands include Porto Cruz, a leading Port; Label 5, a best-selling scotch whiskey brand; and Poliakov, France's top-selling vodka.
About_#4: 4)The private company, which he owns, has more than 38 subsidiaries and production sites globally and operates in more than 100 countries.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, National Cheng Kung University
About_#1: Chen cofounded Largan Precision, a lens supplier to Apple and other tech outfits, with fellow billionaire Scott Lin.
About_#2: A former chairman, he and his wife both remain on the company's board of directors.
About_#3: The company is a leading smartphone lens maker and a major supplier to Apple, claiming a quarter of the global market.

About_#1: Vivien Chen is the younger daughter of the late billionaire Chen Din Hwa. She resigned as chairman of the family's Nan Fung Group in 2016.
About_#2: She was appointed honorary chairman of the privately held group and doesn't have day-to-day involvement.
About_#3: She had called the shots at one of the largest business dynasties in Hong Kong since 2009, after three decades of being groomed for the role.
About_#4: Outside of Nan Fung, she's been buying commercial property in Hong Kong and London.

About_#1: Chey Ki-won is the younger sister of SK Group chairman Chey Tae-Won.
About_#2: Her stake in SK Holdings accounts for most of her wealth.
About_#3: She chairs SK's Happiness Sharing Foundation, which conducts educational programs for poor children and sets up and runs social enterprises.
Did You Know?: Since 2006, her Happiness Sharing Foundation has provided more than 40 million lunch boxes to starving children.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Golden Gate University
About_#1: Pollyanna Chu was Hong Kong's wealthiest woman in 2017 based mainly on her stake in Kingston Financial Group, which she cofounded in the early 1990s.
About_#2: She has tapped her personal network, the city's proximity to China and a more liberal stock market regime to build Kingston into a financial powerhouse.
About_#3: She chose to bet on the region's growing capital markets, instead of stepping into her family's hotel and casino business.
About_#4: In 2018, Chu led a consortium of investors who paid $5.2 billion for the Center in Hong Kong, making it the world's most expensive skyscraper.
Did You Know?: Chu named the company after her only son, Kingston.

Education: Doctorate, The University of Warwick
About_#1: Roy Chi Ping Chung cofounded Techtronic Industries with fellow billionaire Horst Julius Pudwill in 1985.
About_#2: He debuted as a billionaire in 2021 when shares in Techtronic, a maker of power equipment and floor-care cleaning products, rose amid consumer demand.
About_#3: The company makes cordless powered products for Milwaukee Tool, Ryobi DIY power equipment and the iconic Hoover brand.
About_#4: He retired as group vice chairman and executive director of Techtronic in 2011, and has since been a non-executive director.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Monash University
About_#1: Software engineer Douglas Clarke cofounded film industry gear and software maker Blackmagic Design in Melbourne, Australia with Grant Petty in 2001.
About_#2: Petty reportedly met Clarke in the 1990s at an Apple computer user group and originally hired him for a summer job.
About_#3: Blackmagic Design's professional cinema cameras, electronic equipment and software known as DaVinci Resolve are used by Hollywood studios and YouTubers.
About_#4: Clarke has reportedly never held a management position at Blackmagic but is known for his unflappable ability to turn ideas into working products.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Colby College; Master of Business Administration, Cornell University
About_#1: Ronald Clarke is the CEO and chairman of Fleetcor Technologies, a $2.4 billion (sales) digital payments company.
About_#2: The Atlanta-based company offers businesses credit cards geared to travel expenses like gas, tolls, and lodging.
About_#3: Clarke joined the company in 2000. Ten years later he took it public on the New York Stock Exchange.
About_#4: Fleetcor has 800,000 customers and operates in more than 100 countries worldwide.

About_#1: Jean-Paul Clozel and his wife Martine Clozel cofounded Swiss biotech firm Actelion in 1997 with three other colleagues.
About_#2: The husband-and-wife team sold the company to Johnson & Johnson for $30 billion in 2017.
About_#3: Actelion makes drugs for orphan diseases, which affect fewer than 200,000 peopleand typically receive little research funding.
About_#4: Following the Johnson & Johnson acquisition, the couple spun out publicly-traded Idorsia, which they now run together.
Did You Know?: To start Actelion, the Clozels reportedly sold their house and worked out of a rented garage in the company's early days.

About_#1: DeSantis founded Sundown Vitamins, later renamed Rexall Sundown, in 1976 and took the company public in 1993.
About_#2: Dutch food giant Royal Numico acquired Rexall Sundown for $1.8 billion in 2000, and DeSantis then started a family office in Boca Raton, Florida.
About_#3: A business partner introduced him to Celsius Holdings, an energy drink producer then based in nearby Delray Beach, in the mid-2000s.
About_#4: DeSantis owns 30% of Celsius shares, which soared tenfold in 2020, making him a billionaire.

About_#1: Sefik Yilmaz Dizdar is a partner in LC Waikiki, a producer and retailer of ready-to-wear fashions and home items.
About_#2: Designer Georges Amouyal and a partner founded LC Waikiki in France in 1985. Dizdar and partners including Mustafa Kucuk acquired it in 1997.
About_#3: LC Waikiki's first international store opened in Romania in 2009. In 2016, it expanded into home textile products under the brand name LCW Home.
About_#4: The company prides itself on promoting women into its management ranks.
Did You Know?: LC Waikiki, with annual revenue of around $2.5 billion, is managed by Kucuk, also a billionaire, and his family.

About_#1: In 1989, Charles Dunstone started Carphone Warehouse in his apartment with $12,000 in savings.
About_#2: In 2000 the company floated on the London Stock Exchange as U.K. mobile phone sales boomed.
About_#3: In 2014, Carphone merged with Dixons, a general electronics retailer. In 2021 Dixons Carphone was then folded into the 800-store Currys brand.
About_#4: Dunstone also founded TalkTalk network in 2002, which demerged from Carphone Warehouse in 2010 but remained listed.
Did You Know?: Outside of the office, he is an avid yachtsman and participates in sailing regattas around the globe.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Anderson School of Management; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of California, Los Angeles
About_#1: Larry Fink is the founder, CEO and chairman of powerhouse investment management firm BlackRock, one of the world's largest asset managers.
About_#2: He and seven partners founded BlackRock in 1988. Originally it was part of The Blackstone Group.
About_#3: BlackRock was spun off from Blackstone in 1994 and went public in 1999.
About_#4: Today Blackrock has $8.7 trillion in assets under management.

About_#1: Jorge Gallardo Ballart's father founded pharmaceutical company Almirall in 1943 in Barcelona.
About_#2: After their father died in 1988, Jorge and his brother Antonio took over running Almirall; the company is publicly traded.
About_#3: Jorge is executive president of Almirall, which had about $900 million revenues in 2020.
About_#4: In 2018, Almirall announced the acquisition of five products from the dermatology division of Allergan.

Education: M.Com, Colegio de San Juan de Letran
About_#1: Nari Genomal , who died in August 2022, drew his wealth from a minority stake in BSE-listed Page Industries.
About_#2: Page is one of the biggest licensees in the world for underwear maker Jockey.
About_#3: He cofounded Page Industries in 1994 with his two brothers with the aim of bringing Jockey to India.
About_#4: The Bangalore-headquartered Page Industries is also the exclusive Indian licensee of swimwear brand Speedo.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Hofstra University
About_#1: Ramesh Genomal gets his wealth from a minority stake in apparel maker Page Industries.
About_#2: Page is one of the biggest licensees in the world for underwear maker Jockey.
About_#3: He cofounded Page Industries with his younger brother Sunder with the aim of bringing Jockey to India.
About_#4: The Genomal family has been the sole licensee of Jockey in the Philippines for over 65 years.

Education: Master of Science in Engineering, De La Salle University
About_#1: Sunder Genomal runs Page Industries, one of the biggest licensees in the world for underwear maker Jockey.
About_#2: The Bangalore-headquartered Page Industries is also the exclusive Indian licensee of swimwear brand Speedo.
About_#3: Genomal set up Page Industries in 1994 with the aim of bringing Jockey to India.
About_#4: His son Shamir is the company's deputy managing director.

Education: Bachelor of Business Administration, Western Washington University
About_#1: Horst-Otto Gerberding owns 5% of Symrise AG, one of the world's largest makers of ingredients for fragrances, flavors, nutrients and cosmetics.
About_#2: Symrise resulted from the 2003 merger of Dragoco and Haarmann & Reimer.
About_#3: Founded in 1919 by Carl-Wilhelm Gerberding in Holzminden, Germany, Dragoco started out producing formulations for perfume and soap.
About_#4: Horst-Otto serves on the advisory board of Symrise, which employs more than 10,000 people and has annual revenue of around $4 billion.
Did You Know?: He holds a BA in Business Administration from Western Washington University in Bellingham, WA.

About_#1: Guo Jiangang chairs Guangdong Xinbao Electrical Appliances Holdings, a producer of kitchen appliances.
About_#2: Xinbao holds rights for the Morphy Richards appliance brand in China and has found success through social media.
About_#3: Xinbao also sells its own Donlim brand.

About_#1: Polys Haji-Ioanno is the son of late Cypriot shipping magnate Loucas Haji-Ioannou (d. 2008), who once owned the world's largest private tanker fleet.
About_#2: Most of his wealth derives from a large stake in easyJet, the discount airline founded by his younger brother, Stelios.
About_#3: Polys continues the family's shipping legacy with his own 17-tanker fleet.
About_#4: He has also invested heavily in both commercial and residential real estate, particularly in Cyprus, Greece and Norway.
Did You Know?: Haji-Ioanno's yacht, "Esmeralda," is named after one of the world's largest tortoises.

About_#1: Huang Jian is a former president of Midea Group, the biggest home appliances manufacturer in China.
About_#2: Huang Jian departed in 2013 when Midea Group competed a backdoor listing on Shenzhen stock exchange.
About_#3: Huang Jian still owned more than 1% of Midea Group in early 2021.

About_#1: Huang Weibin chairs Shenzhen-listed Marssenger Kitchenware, a supplier of kitchenware.
About_#2: Huang cofounded the predecessor of Marssenger Kitchenwarein in Zhejiang Province in 2010.
About_#3: Huang worked for a cashmere factory for near 10 years before the started his own sweater business in 1992.
About_#4: Sequoia Capital China owned more than 7% of Marssenger after its IPO in Dec. 2020.

About_#1: Hiroshi Ishibashi is a grandson of the founder of Bridgestone, the world's largest tire maker.
About_#2: He owns a small but valuable stake in the Tokyo-listed company but does not hold any executive position.
About_#3: Hiroshi heads the Ishibashi Foundation, which operates Tokyo's Bridgestone Museum of Art.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Southern Denmark
About_#1: Bent Jensen is the owner and CEO of Linak, a $600 million (sales) Danish company that manufactures and sells linear actuators.
About_#2: Linear actuators are devices that convert power into linear motion and are used in industrial equipment, furniture and hospital beds.
About_#3: Jensen's grandfather founded the company in 1907; it originally made pulleys, grinding mills and forges.
About_#4: Jensen, who received a mechanical engineering degree, joined the firm in 1976 -- with an idea for a new product: the linear actuator.

About_#1: Boris Jordan is the executive chairman of Curaleaf, a cannabis distributor that went public in 2018.
About_#2: The Long Island native and grandson of Russian immigrants moved to Moscow in the1990s and cut his teeth in investing.
About_#3: He returned to the U.S. in 2012 and invested in Curaleaf, then named PalliaTech, when recreational marijuana was legal only in Washington state.
About_#4: Curaleaf generated $627 million in 2020 revenues from producing and selling marijuana; it operates in 23 U.S. states.

About_#1: Morris Kahn cofounded Amdocs, a customer-relationship management-and-billing software firm for large telecom outfits.
About_#2: He sold nearly $1 billion worth of shares after Admocs went public in 1998.
About_#3: A South African native, he lives on the Israeli coast and spends much of his time on a 100-foot yacht.
About_#4: Through his Aurum Ventures, Morris invests in life sciences and clean-tech companies that he hopes will contribute to the wellbeing of the planet.

Education: Master of Business Administration, MIT Sloan School of Management; Bachelor of Arts/Economics, Universidade de Sao Paulo
About_#1: Marcelo Kalim cofounded digital bank C6 in 2018; it sold a 40% stake to JP Morgan in June 2021 for an undisclosed amount.
About_#2: C6 says that as of 2021 it had attracted 7 million customers since it launched in 2019.
About_#3: Prior to C6, Kalim was a significant shareholder and longtime executive of Brazil's BTG Pactual, Latin America's largest investment bank.

Education: Master of Science, Institute of Cryptography, Telecommunications and Computer Science (FSB Academy)
About_#1: Eugene Kaspersky graduated from the High School of KGB and began creating his first antiviral programs in the early 1990s.
About_#2: Kaspersky became interested in computer security in 1989 when his computer was infected with the 'Cascade' virus.
About_#3: The young engineer founded Kaspersky Lab in 1997, with Eugene heading the company's antivirus research.
About_#4: Over 400 million users now use Kaspersky Lab products to protect their computers.
Did You Know?: Kaspersky Lab is the official sponsor of Scuderia Ferrari, one of the most successful Formula One racing team.
In Their Own Words: It's not popular to be Russian right now in some countries, but we cannot change our roots, and frankly, having these roots do not make us guilty.

About_#1: Ke Yunfeng is the chairman of Dashenlin Pharmaceutical Group.
About_#2: Dashenlin went public at the Shanghai Stock Exchange on 2017.
About_#3: The company opened its first store in the southern Chinese city of Zhenjiang in 1999; it has more than 4,000 today.
About_#4: Dashenlin has more than 23,000 employees.

About_#1: Ken Kendrick is the managing general partner and largest shareholder of the Arizona Diamondbacks baseball team.
About_#2: Kendrick was a member of the group that brought the MLB expansion team to Arizona in 1995.
About_#3: He built a fortune in software and banking, founding Datatel (later renamed Ellucian) and investing in Woodforest National Bank.
About_#4: In 2021, Kendrick joined a group of investors, including Larry Fitzgerald, Kevin Durant and Andy Roddick, that purchased memorabilia authenticator Collectors for $850 million.
Did You Know?: Kendrick owns one of the world's most valuable baseball card collections, estimated to be worth nine figures; it includes a 1952 Topps Mickey Mantle card.
In Their Own Words: If you've been an entrepreneur, you have to have had failure or you haven't really done very much. And you don't spend a lot of time talking about your failures, but you spend a lot of time thinking about them.

Education: Master of Science, Dniepropetrovsk Metallurgical Institute
About_#1: With fellow Ukrainian billionaire Henadiy Boholyubov, Ihor Kolomoyskyy founded PrivatBank in the early 1990s.
About_#2: He served as the governor of his native Dnipro region from March 2014 until March 2015, when he was fired by then-president Petro Poroshenko.
About_#3: In 2016, Ukraine's government nationalized PrivatBank, after an investigation suggested large-scale fraud over a period of ten years.
About_#4: In Dec 2017, the High Court of London ordered a freeze on some $2.5 billion worth of assets held by Kolomoyskyy and Boholyubov.
Did You Know?: Kolomoyskyy holds triple Ukrainian-Israeli-Cyprus citizenship.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Michigan
About_#1: Jeff Lawson is the CEO of Twilio, a cloud communications platform that adds messaging, voice and video to web and mobile apps.
About_#2: Lawson launched his first Internet startup while he was at the University of Michigan and went on to become the first CTO of ticket reseller StubHub.
About_#3: The serial entrepreneur went on to work at Amazon, where he helped build the technology behind Amazon Web Services.
About_#4: Along with two friends, Lawson started Twilio in 2008 then took it public in 2016; it now has over 220,000 customers.
Did You Know?: Lawson started filming videos of bar mitzvahs in middle school then moved on to weddings; by the time he graduated high school, he made up to $5,000 some weekends.

About_#1: Liang Jiankun chairs Nanjing Hanrui Cobalt, a supplier of cobalt products.
About_#2: Liang founded Nanjing Hanrui Cobalt in May 1997.
About_#3: Liang began his career in a supply and marketing cooperative in Anhui Province in 1980

About_#1: Liu Baolin chairs Jointown Pharmaceutical Group, an operator of pharmacies and wholesaler of pharmaceuticals and medical equipment.
About_#2: Liu was born in a village in Yingcheng in 1953.
About_#3: After finishing middle school during China's chaotic Cultural Revolution, he became a "barefoot doctor," minimally trained to work in rural areas.

About_#1: Udo Mueller is advertising and marketing firm Stroeer SE's largest single shareholder and the company's co-CEO.
About_#2: The company dates back to 1963, when it began setting up billboards in Germany.
About_#3: In 1990, Mueller joined forces with competitor Heinz W. Stroeer to create one of Germany's biggest out-of-home media providers.
About_#4: Headquartered in Cologne, Stroeer SE went public in 2010. Muller's stake is now just over 22%.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Washington
About_#1: Bruce Nordstrom and his sister, Anne Gittinger, are the largest individual shareholders of fashion retailer Nordstrom Inc.
About_#2: The department store chain was founded by their grandfather as a shoe store in 1901.
About_#3: Nordstrom became president of the family company in 1963 and retired as chairman of the board in 2006.
About_#4: During his tenure as chairman, revenues grew from $40 million to $8 billion.
Did You Know?: Bruce Nordstrom started working at age 9 in the stockroom and on the sales floor of a Nordstrom store.

Education: Bachelor of Science, The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania
About_#1: Scott Nuttall is the co-CEO of storied private equity giant KKR.
About_#2: He and Joseph Bae were appointed as chief executives in October 2021 when KKR co-founders Henry Kravis and George Roberts stepped down.
About_#3: Nuttall first joined KKR in his early 20s, in 1996, following a brief stint at Blackstone.
About_#4: He spearheaded KKR's capital markets, fundraising, insurance, credit and hedge fund initiatives, and helped take the company public in 2010.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University
About_#1: Roberto Ongpin chairs Alphaland, his high-end property developer that delisted in 2014 after a messy split with a U.K. investment group.
About_#2: As the former Philippine trade minister, Ongpin was accused of insider trading in 2009. He was cleared of the charges in 2017.
About_#3: Ongpin worked at Procter & Gamble for two years and then got his M.B.A. from Harvard Business School before returning to the Philippines.
About_#4: His daughter Anna Ongpin, who has a bachelor's degree from U.S.-based Wellesley College, was appointed as vice chair of Alphaland in February 2020.
Did You Know?: In August 2016, Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte vowed on TV to destroy oligarchs and singled out Ongpin.
In Their Own Words: I have had many setbacks but more successes.

About_#1: Adrian Paval and his brother, Dragos, own Dedeman, a leading Romanian construction materials and do-it-yourself home products retailer.
About_#2: The $2 billion (sales) company's 57 stores stock some 60,000 products, ranging from tools and building supplies to furniture and appliances.
About_#3: The brothers founded the business in 1992 with a single location in Bacau, Romania.
About_#4: They also own shares of several publicly traded Romanian companies and a portfolio of real estate in Bucharest and the northern city of Cluj.

About_#1: A director, actor, producer and writer, Tyler Perry is best known for his "Madea" franchise, which has grossed more than $660 million.
About_#2: Perry started out in live theater in the 1990s and became extremely popular before transitioning to film and television in the 2000s.
About_#3: Perry's wealth comes both from his cut as a producer and from a library dating back to the early 1990s: he owns 100% of the content he's created.
About_#4: In 2019, he opened Tyler Perry Studios, a 330-acre property in Atlanta with 12 sound stages and custom sets that include a to-scale White House.

About_#1: Grant Petty cofounded film industry hardware and software company Blackmagic Design in his garage in Melbourne, Australia in 2001.
About_#2: Blackmagic Design's professional cinema cameras, electronic equipment and software known as DaVinci Resolve are used by Hollywood studios and YouTubers.
About_#3: During the pandemic, Blackmagic profits soared tenfold to $115 million, as networks bought its low-cost gear to accommodate work-from-home.
About_#4: Petty, who grew up poor, writes the code for all of Blackmagic's internal processes and stars in hour-long instructional videos for company products.

Education: Bachelor of Science in Engineering, Illinois Institute of Technology; Master, Purdue University
About_#1: G.V.Prasad is the co-chairman and managing director of pharma company Dr Reddy's Laboratories.
About_#2: The company was founded by his late father-in-law K.Anji Reddy in 1984.
About_#3: Prasad runs the company with Satish Reddy, the late founder's son, Satish Reddy, who is also a billionaire.
About_#4: In 2020, the company acquired the rights to conduct clinical trials of Sputnik V, the Russian Covid-19 vaccine and to distribute it in India.
Did You Know?: Prasad sits on the boards of the Indian School of Business and Ashoka University.

About_#1: Jupally Rameshwar Rao founded My Home Constructions, a residential and commercial property developer, in 1981.
About_#2: The privately held My Home is a prominent real estate player in the southern Indian city of Hyderabad.
About_#3: The company's projects span the gamut from apartments to villa communities to office buildings.
About_#4: The My Home Group also has interests in cement and education.

About_#1: Vera Rechulski Santo Domingo is the widow of Julio Mario Santo Domingo Jr., son of Colombian beer baron Julio Mario Santo Domingo, who died in 2009.
About_#2: She controls about 11% of the Santo Domingo family's Luxembourg-based holding company, through which she owns shares in Anheuser-Busch InBev.
About_#3: Her two children, Tatiana Casiraghi and Julio Mario Santo Domingo III, own smaller stakes of about 5% each.
About_#4: The family also owns a stake in Château Pétrus, a French wine estate near Bordeaux that produces some of the world's most expensive wines.

Education: Master of Arts/Science, Massachusetts Institute of Technology; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Pittsburgh
About_#1: Rees is cofounder and co-president of Blue Owl, which manages $94 billion and formed in 2021 when his Dyal Capital merged with Owl Rock Capital.
About_#2: Dyal is known for buying minority stakes in other private equity firms like Robert F. Smith's Vista Equity Partners and Tom Gores' Platinum Equity.
About_#3: Since 2020 Dyal has turned its attention to professional sports, buying stakes of the NBA's Phoenix Suns, Sacramento Kings and Atlanta Hawks.
About_#4: Rees still heads Dyal as a branch of Blue Owl, while Blue Owl CEO Doug Ostrover manages Owl Rock's credit business.

About_#1: Mark Rein is the cofounder and vice president of business development of Cary, North Carolina-based Epic Games.
About_#2: The private company is the maker of Fortnite, one of the world's most popular games, with over 400 million players.
About_#3: Epic raised $1 billion in an April 2021 funding round that valued the company at $28.7 billion; Rein owns a 4% stake.
About_#4: Epic Games is also the creator of the Unreal Engine, one of the most used game development tool kits for other studios.

Education: Bachelor of Science, Chongqing Universtiy
About_#1: Ren Zhengfei leads Huawei Technologies, one of the world's largest manufacturer of telecommunication hardware and mobile phones.
About_#2: Ren is the son of school teachers and grew up in a mountainous town in southern China's Guizhou Province.
About_#3: Ren held technician posts in China's military and worked for Shenzhen South Sea Oil before establishing Huawei with the equivalent of $3,000 in 1987.
About_#4: Huawei today does business in more than 170 countries with 180,000 employees.

About_#1: Francisco José Riberas Mera and his billionaire brother Juan Maria each own about 25% of listed autoparts firm Gestamp Automocion.
About_#2: Francisco is executive chairman of Gestamp Automocion, which listed on the Madrid stock exchange in 2017.
About_#3: The company does business in 21 countries and has 36,000 employees.
About_#4: The brothers are the largest shareholders of Madrid-listed car components maker CIE Automotive.

Education: Master of Arts/Science, Leningrad Institute of Physical Culture
About_#1: Boris Rotenberg and his older brother, Arkady, are co-owners of SMP Bank.
About_#2: The Rotenberg brothers were hit by U.S. sanctions and had assets frozen in 2014 because of their close ties to President Vladimir Putin.
About_#3: The U.S. Treasury claimed that Putin had awarded the Rotenbergs billions of dollars in contracts with Gazprom and for the Sochi Olympics.
About_#4: Unlike Arkady, Boris was not subject to European Union sanctions because he has Finnish citizenship.
Did You Know?: Boris is vice president of the Russian Judo Federation. He sponsors the SMP Racing Project, which supports young Russian drivers. He also owns Sochi football club.

About_#1: Chinese-Thai businessman Chanchai Ruayrungruang, also known as Yan Bin, leads the privately held Reignwood Group.
About_#2: Reignwood's best-known assets are Reignwood Centre - an office, hotel and retail complex in Beijing, and the Pine Valley golf course, also in Beijing.
About_#3: Chanchai started the business in Thailand in 1984 and moved into China a dozen years later.

About_#1: Alan Rydge is chairman and lead shareholder of cinema, hotel and ski-resort group Event Hospitality & Entertainment, formerly Amalgamated Holdings.
About_#2: He inherited the Greater Union cinema chain after his father died in 1980.
About_#3: He's also chairman and the major shareholder of equities investment company Carlton Investments.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, WHU - Otto Beisheim School of Management
About_#1: Oliver Samwer and his brothers Alexander and Marc founded Berlin-based tech incubator Rocket Internet in 2007 and took it public in October 2014.
About_#2: Oliver is the middle brother and the CEO of Rocket Internet, which delisted from the Frankfurt Stock Exchange in October 2020.
About_#3: Together, the Samwers own around 45% of Rocket. The company was valued at more than $8 billion at the time of its IPO.
About_#4: Inspired by the dot-com boom, they created a German auction site, Alando, in 1999 and sold it to eBay for $43 million after a few months.
In Their Own Words: My mother always wanted to me to work for Bertelsmann. Sometimes it's good not to tell your mother what you are working on.

About_#1: Glenn Sanford is chairman and CEO of eXp World Holdings, a real estate brokerage firm.
About_#2: Sanford founded the company, which is based in Bellingham, Washington, in 2008. .
About_#3: The company went public on the Nasdaq in February 2018; revenue grew 84% to $1.8 billion in 2020.
About_#4: Sanford worked at the executive level with a number of internet startups in the 1990s.

Education: Master of Arts/Science, The University of Cambridge; Master of Business Administration, The Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania
About_#1: Cambridge-educated engineer and Wharton grad, Dhruv Sawhney joined his uncle's floundering engineering and sugar firm and turned it around.
About_#2: Eventually, he took charge of his father's sugar interests as well and merged the two businesses into Triveni Engineering and Industries.
About_#3: Triveni produces sugar and liquor and also has a power transmission business. He also owns listed Triveni Turbine, which makes turbines for the power sector.
About_#4: His older son Tarun runs Triveni Engineering while younger son Nikhil runs Triveni Turbine.

About_#1: Stephan Schnabel owns 40% of Helm AG, a chemical marketing firm with annual revenue of around $6 billion and offices in 30 countries.
About_#2: By its own account, Helm began in 1900 as a Hamburg-based import-export business "for merchandise of every description."
About_#3: Stephan's grandfather Hermann took over from the namesake founder, Karl O. Helm, in 1950 and set a path focused on chemicals.
About_#4: Stephan's father, Dieter, took over from Hermann as chairman of the executive board in 1984 and continued to expand overseas.

Education: Bachelor of Arts/Science, Delhi University; Master of Business Administration, Delhi University; Master of Science, Oakland University
About_#1: Neerja Sethi cofounded IT consulting and outsourcing firm Syntel with her husband Bharat Desai in 1980 in their apartment in Troy, Michigan.
About_#2: French IT firm Atos SE bought Syntel for $3.4 billion in October 2018. Sethi got an estimated $510 million for her stake.
About_#3: Sethi, who had served as an executive at Syntel since 1980, did not join Atos after the acquisition.
About_#4: Sethi met her husband in the U.S. while working for pioneering IT firm Tata Consultancy Services, which they attempted to emulate.

About_#1: Ramesh Chandra Sharma gets his wealth from a majority stake in non-banking finance company Capri Global Capital, which is run by his son Rajesh Sharma.
About_#2: Mumbai-based Capri offers home loans, construction loans as well as customized business loans for medium and small-scale enterprises.
About_#3: It has more than 100 branches across India, with a substantial presence in northern and western India.
Did You Know?: Capri Global started as a construction finance company in 2011.

Education: Drop Out, Purdue University
About_#1: Dean Solon founded Shoals Technologies in 1996; it makes electrical gear for some of the biggest U.S. solar installations.
About_#2: Solon, who stepped down as CEO to join the board, owns 40% of Shoals Technologies Group, which had its IPO in January 2021.
About_#3: Solon got his start at age 8 carrying his dad's toolbox to repair air conditioners; by 16 he had his own customers.
About_#4: He dropped out of Purdue University and was soon designing and manufacturing automotive parts.
Did You Know?: Since the 1970s Solon has visited Disney World at least twice a year. His favorite movie is Beauty And The Beast.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard Business School; Bachelor of Arts/Science, University of Arizona
About_#1: Mike Speiser is a managing partner at venture capital firm Sutter Hill Ventures, which he joined in 2008.
About_#2: Speiser was an initial investor in software firm Snowflake and served as its founding CEO from 2012 to 2014.
About_#3: He became a billionaire after the company went public in September 2020 in what was the largest ever software IPO.
About_#4: He owns a bit more than a 1% stake in Snowflake's stock.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Pepperdine University; Bachelor of Science, University of Wisconsin
About_#1: Jeff Sprecher is the founder and CEO of global stock exchange operator Intercontinental Exchange, also known as ICE.
About_#2: In 1997, Sprecher was working at a California power plant developer when he negotiated to buy a struggling Georgia company called Continental Power Exchange.
About_#3: He had an idea to create a platform that would allow traders to buy and sell commodities online.
About_#4: In 2000, Sprecher folded Continental into new firm ICE; he took that company public in 2005.
Did You Know?: Sprecher is married to Kelly Loeffler, who was appointed U.S. Senator from Georgia in 2019 to fill an empty seat; she lost the special election in January 2021.

About_#1: Real estate billionaire Axel Stawski founded Stawski Partners in 1973.
About_#2: The company owns six office buildings and three condos in Manhattan.
About_#3: He is developing two luxury residential towers in Queens' Long Island City, his first developments in about a decade.
About_#4: Stawski was born in post-war Germany to Jewish parents who both survived the Holocaust.
Did You Know?: Stawski is a board member of the American Society for Yad Vashem, which supports the Yad Vashem World Holocaust Remembrance Center in Jerusalem.

Education: Master of Business Administration, Harvard University; Bachelor of Arts/Science, New York University
About_#1: Joseph Steinberg is the chairman of Jefferies Financial Group, a New York-based financial services firm best known for investment banking.
About_#2: He served as president of Leucadia National Corporation, an investment firm which was often compared to a mini-Berkshire Hathaway, from 1979 to 2013.
About_#3: During his time at the helm, Leucadia purchased companies like National Beef and helped finance Bill Ackman's Pershing Square Capital Management.
